TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Bender's Quarry
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned, noting that Senator Robert Bell has introduced a Bill into the Senate to ensure that no further blasting at Bender's Quarry is permitted without the consent of both Houses of Parliament, respectfully call upon the Federal Government to support the Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: World Heritage Listing of the Nullarbor Region
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We the undersigned oppose the attempts by the Federal Government to World Heritage List the Nullarbor Region.
In doing so, we condemn the State and Federal Government for failing to consult with the residents of the Nullarbor in relation to the listing proposal.
Further, we affirm the excellent record of pastoralists, highway operators and the local communities in protecting the heritage and environmental value of the region.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty The Queen of Australia as our head of State and as in duty bound will ever pray. God save The Queen.
Holy Family Parish,
Albany 6330

We the undersigned give our support to the Bill being presented to Federal Parliament by Senator Shirley Walters to reduce the violence in `M' and `R' rated videos, and to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of `X' rated videos.
We do this because of our concern regarding violence, particularly sexual violence in the community.

(b)notes, with dismay, that, despite an international outcry against the Indonesian Government over the killings, repression in East Timor has, if anything, intensified since the massacre; and
(c)extends its deepest sympathies to the families of those who were killed or are still missing, and expresses the hope that those deaths may yet prove not to have been in vain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: TRANSPORT AND COMMUNICATIONS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1992
This Bill makes amendments to 8 Acts administered within the Transport and Communications portfolio.
Most of the amendments are of a technical nature and represent a "fine tuning" and clarification of provisions of various Acts administered within the portfolio.
The amendments do not introduce substantial new policy schemes, although some of the amendments introduce minor policy initiatives.
I will not deal with the minor technical amendments in this speech, but will instead concentrate on each of the more significant amendments in turn.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act to allow the ABC to carry corporate sponsorship and promotional material on its new international satellite service to South-East Asia.

The service will initially be provided on a free-to-air basis to enable the ABC to develop an audience. It will convert to an encrypted signal after the first one to two years, drawing income partly from subscriptions and partly from paid sponsorship announcements and promotional programming. There will be no spot promotional commercials carried on the service.

The amendment applies only to the ABC's international satellite television service and its associated audio channels. It will not enable the ABC to take sponsorship or promotional programming on its domestic services or on Radio Australia.

I believe that the satellite service will have far reaching foreign and trade policy benefits for Australia and will improve Australian information and cultural penetration of the South-East Asian area. The acceptance of sponsorship announcements and promotional programming on the service will enhance its financial viability. I applaud the ABC for this initiative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Broadcasting Services Act 1992

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is totally committed both to the protection of fundamental human rights under the law and to the important role of the media in protection of the public interest. However, it recognises that, in legislation dealing with the media, there is likely to be conflict between the need for journalists to protect their sources of confidential information and for the courts to gather all relevant information. In those cases, we rely heavily on the judgment of the courts to protect journalistic sources wherever possible.

We cannot compromise the principle that all citizens are bound to give information necessary to the administration of justice. No one is above the law. What we can do is try to strike an appropriate balance between two basic protections of our democratic society. The Broadcasting Services Act 1992 sought to do so by providing a confidential investigation function which would apply in the very few cases where identification of a confidential source would be relevant to an ABA decision. However, journalists have said this process could be abused by unscrupulous litigants.

The Media Alliance has asked for amendments to the Act to make it a reasonable excuse for a journalist, at an ABA investigation or hearing, to refuse to answer a question or produce a document if to do so would disclose a confidential source of material used in a broadcast program. The Government considers this proposal to be reasonable and the Bill includes amendments to implement it. The amendments will not compromise the basic legal principles since the powers of the courts remain unimpaired, but avoids possible abuse of the ABA processes.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Civil Aviation Act 1988

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill amends the Civil Aviation Act to provide greater flexibility in the method of determining charges under the Act and to provide a mechanism under which charges can be waived or remitted in appropriate cases. The Bill also amends the Act's regulation-making provision to expressly provide that regulations can be made under the Act which deal with the design and manufacture of aircraft.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Amendments of the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act 1983

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments to the Protection of the Sea (Prevention of Pollution from Ships) Act will significantly reduce the amount of oil discharged into the sea during the normal operations of ships. The amendments are a direct result of changes to the International Convention for the Prevention of Pollution from Ships, known as MARPOL 73/78. This Convention has been accepted by 70 countries representing some 90% of world shipping tonnage. It is expected that the amendments included in the Bill will enter into force globally on 6 July 1993.

The amendments have two main objectives. Firstly, the present standard for the discharge in near-coastal zones and special areas of oily wastes and residues from machinery spaces is to apply to all sea areas. The oil content in permitted discharges is not to exceed 15 parts per million. Secondly, the amendments will improve the standard for the instantaneous rate of discharge of oil or oily mixtures from cargo tanks of oil tankers outside special areas by reducing the permitted rate of discharge from 60 to 30 litres per nautical mile. For existing ships, the new requirements will be phased in over a period of five years.

The impact of these amendments on the shipping industry will be negligible. More than 86% of all ships are already fitted with the required 15 parts per million filtering equipment and the manufacture of 100 parts per million equipment has been almost entirely discontinued.

It is clear that the will, technology and equipment now exist within the international shipping community to take this step towards the fundamental goal of MARPOL 73/78 which is the complete elimination of intentional pollution of the marine environment. The present discharge standards were formulated more than 20 years ago when the subject was new, concern for the environment was not as acute as it is today, and the technology was not available to achieve such low discharge levels.
The Bill makes a large number of amendments to the Telecommunications Act. These amendments come within 4 categories. I will deal with each of these categories in turn.
(1)Access Agreements
Part 8 of the Telecommunications Act gives telecommunications carriers rights of access to the networks and services of other carriers.
Under that Part, carriers can negotiate access agreements and variations of such agreements, AUSTEL can arbitrate when negotiations break down and AUSTEL can register completed agreements.

An access agreement has been negotiated between AOTC Limited and Optus Communications and was registered by AUSTEL on 19 August 1992. The AOTC/OPTUS access agreement is an agreement between 3 carriers by virtue of the fact that the OPTUS licences are held by two subsidiary companies.
Prior to signing the agreement, concerns were raised as to whether the provisions of Part 8 of the Telecommunications Act envisage the registration by AUSTEL of a multi-party access agreement.

The Government has been approached by AUSTEL and the carriers seeking amendments to the Act which will ensure that there is no doubt about the legal status of the access agreement and the related matters which led to and give effect to it.
The proposed amendments clarify the current provisions of the Act to ensure that there is no legal uncertainty in relation to the making of access agreements between more than two carriers.
(2)Protection of Communications

Section 88 of the Telecommunications Act deals with the protection of communications. Section 88 creates obligations on employees and former employees of carriers not to disclose or use confidential personal or commercial information for purposes other than those prescribed in the Act.
The Bill amends section 88 to extend these obligations to suppliers and former suppliers of eligible services and their employees and former employees.

The amendment is necessary to protect such information in a consistent way, given that service providers will have increasing access to calling line identification information for the purpose of billing their own customers.
(3)Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman

The Bill also amends the Telecommunications Act to facilitate the creation and operation of the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman by the telecommunications carriers. The Government required the carriers to enter into a Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman Scheme as a condition of their carrier licences.

Under the scheme, the Telecommunications Industry Ombudsman (the TIO) will investigate unresolved complaints by consumers about any matters relating to service, billing and the manner of charging for telecommunications services (other than investigation of the setting of tariffs). The proposed amendments will ensure that there are no impediments to the free flow of information between the TIO, participants and complainants in the investigation of complaints, and specifically enable AUSTEL to refer complaints to the TIO.
(4)Rules relating to the general carriers' reserved rights
The Bill contains some minor amendments to clarify the reserved rights of the general carriers.

In particular, the amendments will ensure that, subject to certain exceptions, the general carriers will retain the reserved right to install or maintain line links on a property whose title is not defined by reference to geographical coordinates.

The Bill will also clarify the status of certain reserved line links which the Telecommunications Act allows to be installed and maintained by other persons as exceptions to the carriers' reserved rights in relation to line links. If the title over "excepted" line links passes to another person, those line links are required to be used for the purpose for which they were originally excepted or within the scope of an authorisation previously granted.
The measures contained in this Bill are expected to have no significant effect on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
Details about the minor technical amendments in the Bill which I have not referred to in this speech are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS (TRANSITIONAL PROVISIONS AND CONSEQUENTIAL AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

The Radiocommunications (Transitional Provisions and Consequential Amendments) Bill 1992 provides for the saving of regulations made, instruments granted or various actions commenced under the Radiocommunications Act 1983 which is to be replaced by the proposed Radiocommunications Act 1992.

The transitional provisions included in the Bill deem various instruments made under the 1983 Act to have been made under the new Act. For example, clause 4 saves transmitter licences in force under the 1983 Act and continues them in force as if they had been issued by the Spectrum Management Agency established under the new Act. Consultation procedures which have been undertaken under the 1983 Act for the purposes of making certain instruments will be deemed to have been done under the corresponding provisions of the new Act.

The Bill also provides for consequential amendments to a number of other Acts by replacing outdated references to the 1983 Act. These consequential amendments are set out in the Schedule. The Bill also includes amendments to the Telecommunications Act 1991 to allow AUSTEL to include in standards made under that Act, matters related to interference to radiocommunications. This will avoid the need for issuing separate technical standards under the 1992 Act.

The Bill also repeals the Radiocommunications Act 1983, the Radiocommunications (Frequency Reservation Certificate Tax) Act 1983 and the Radiocommunications (Temporary Permit Tax) Act 1983. Frequency reservation certificates and temporary permits will no longer be required under the new radiocommunications licensing scheme provided for under the Radiocommunications Act 1992.

The decision to abolish frequency reservation certificates implements one of the recommendations of the report on spectrum management prepared by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. As a transitional measure, clause 7 allows existing certificates to continue, but these will not be re-issued upon their expiry.
The explanatory memorandum sets out the purpose of the provisions in more detail. I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIOCOMMUNICATIONS BILL 1992
Introduction
In my statement to the Parliament on 15 September 1992, I outlined the Government's reform strategy for spectrum management.

My statement followed the Government's acceptance of the 1991 report on spectrum management by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The Committee had recommended substantial changes, in view of the increasing importance of spectrum management and the communications industry generally in the development of the Australian economy.

The Radiocommunications Bill 1992 and the related legislation being introduced in the Parliament gives effect to those changes. The new Bill will replace the existing Radiocommunications Act 1983. As well as including the reform measures I outlined in my earlier statement, the Bill incorporates provisions from existing legislation which are not being substantially changed, although the opportunity has been taken to modernise the drafting of the legislation.

Following my earlier statement, the Department of Transport and Communications has undertaken consultations with users and industry groups and the views expressed have been taken into consideration in drafting of the Bill.

While the Bill is fairly technical in nature it represents a significant reform measure which complements and extends the government's reforms in telecommunications and broadcasting. The reforms are innovative and broad ranging in their implications.

The changes contained in this Bill are directed to the future. The spectrum is an important resource in the development of communications services. The new management regime contained in the Bill provides for increased flexibility to meet the demands of a rapidly changing communications environment. Over time, it will lead to a more efficient allocation and use of spectrum which will improve the benefits for all users of radiocommunications. The new arrangements will allow a more rapid introduction of new technologies and services. There will also be increased opportunities for Australian manufacturers of equipment and a more competitive supply of services.

I do not propose to go into a detailed description of all the features of the Bill. Instead I would like to concentrate on some of the more significant and innovative changes being introduced. Senators wishing further detail should consult the explanatory memorandum which accompanies the Bill.
Market-based Reforms

Perhaps the most innovative change being introduced in the Bill is the introduction of a market-based system of spectrum management in selected areas of the spectrum. It was perhaps the key recommendation of the HORSCOTCI report and is a major feature of the new legislation. The current system of licensing, which the Bill now refers to as "apparatus licensing", is based on the issue of annual licences to operate specified types of transmitters for specified purposes. These licences are subject to strict technical constraints and cannot be traded. This system is cumbersome and inflexible in many of its applications and cannot readily cope with the increasingly rapid pace of technological change and commercial initiative.

The new market-based system of licensing contained in Part 3.2 of the Bill represents a radical departure from this traditional approach. The cornerstone of the new system will be a new type of licence, to be called a "spectrum licence" which will provide explicit and continuing rights to spectrum access in defined parts of the spectrum in defined geographic areas. These licences will be freely tradeable and will be able to be split or amalgamated to suit the needs of users. The licence will allow users to determine the use they make of that spectrum and, within the constraints of the standards regime, the type of equipment they use. They will also be able to authorise third parties to use spectrum under their control without the need for further licensing. Licensees will be free to buy spectrum access rights on a local, State or national level or any combination in between. They will also be able to amalgamate licences to create large blocks of spectrum which they will be able to manage themselves. Spectrum licences will be issued for periods of up to 10 years which will provide a secure term for users. They will generally be allocated by a price-based allocation system but will only have to pay low annual fees related to the costs of administration of spectrum management.

Introduction of the market-based approach will occur selectively and progressively under the control of the Minister. Other spectrum will remain under the administrative system, resulting in a dual market/administratively-based system of spectrum management. The Bill provides opportunity for public consultation during the transition to the market-based system.

Once the Minister has designated a part of the spectrum for conversion to the market system, Part 2.2 of the Bill provides for two processes as to how spectrum licences are to be issued. Firstly, conversion plans will be developed by the SMA to convert existing apparatus licences to spectrum licences. Licensees will be offered spectrum licences, subject to payment of a spectrum access charge. The spectrum access charge will be determined according to a Ministerial policy direction which will be a disallowable instrument. Secondly, marketing plans will be developed for the sale of spectrum licences for unencumbered spectrum by auction, tender or for a pre-determined or negotiated price.

In line with the recommendations of the HORSCOTCI report spectrum access rights will not be perpetual. There will be no automatic right of renewal of spectrum licences at the end of the fixed term. However the SMA will be able to renew licences if this is in the public interest.

The market-based system will not apply to broadcasting services bands used for AM/FM radio and VHF/UHF television. These bands will continue to be planned by the Australian Broadcasting Authority under the Broadcasting Services Act 1992.
HORSCOTCI identified two areas of potential concern with a market-based system—interference and access by non-commercial users. Special attention has been given to these issues.

The Bill contains a number of explicit procedures to deal with interference. But the heart of the matter is to confer on the holders of licences the right to use the spectrum without interference. This right can then be protected at law. In support of this concept the Bill provides for five related measures. Firstly, spectrum licences will be subject to specified emission limits outside the areas of spectrum under their control. Secondly, all high powered transmitters operating under a spectrum licence, or any other licence, whether by the licensee or by authorised third parties, will need to be registered with the SMA. Thirdly, the SMA will be able to reject registration or changes to licences where this would result in interference to other services. In support of those processes the SMA will be accrediting non-government engineers and others, under the accreditation scheme in Part 5.4 of the Bill, to issue certificates to licensees about the impact of their proposed changes on other services. Fourthly, spectrum licensees will be able to initiate civil proceedings in the Federal Court under clause 50 against persons unlawfully interfering with their services. Fifthly, the SMA will be able to appoint conciliators to deal with any interference disputes that may arise.

The SMA will be able to designate frequency bands for exclusive use by public or community services anywhere in the spectrum. Special provisions are also included to ensure public or community services have access to spectrum within the market system. The SMA will be able to reserve spectrum licences for direct sale to such organisations, in some cases at concessional rates set in line with Ministerial policy direction. For example, community organisations solely devoted to safety of life who currently do not pay licence fees will not have to pay spectrum access charges for their spectrum licences.

Concern had been expressed to HORSCOTCI that a market-based system of spectrum management would lead to permanent alienation of spectrum in private hands and that this could prevent the government from introducing new services which would be in the national interest or could eventually deny spectrum for essential public or community services. To deal with such possibilities the SMA is empowered under the Bill to purchase spectrum licences in the open market or to resume spectrum licences by compulsory process subject to payment of just compensation.
Administrative and Other Reforms
I now want to turn to some of the other changes being introduced in this Bill.

An important initiative is the introduction of a new scheme for determination of standards and other forms of technical regulation. The setting of technical standards is an important tool for achieving efficiency in spectrum use and minimising interference. With the proliferation, on the one hand, of communications services that depend on spectrum and, on the other, with electric and electronic equipment which affects and can in turn be affected by radiocommunications transmitters, there is increasing need to provide mechanisms to ensure compatibility. The Bill provides for an updated, more flexible scheme of technical regulation designed to achieve those objectives. It also provides for the making of agreements with Standards Australia for the drafting of standards and technical licence specifications, for recognition of overseas standards without the need for additional type testing of equipment and for devolution of compliance testing of equipment to recognised laboratories.

The new Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) being established by the Bill will in future issue apparatus licences. The Government recognises that changes are also required in this area. The current system of approximately 130 licence categories, with a wide disparity in the level of fees paid, needs to be made simpler, more rational and more equitable. One of the first tasks of the new SMA will be to undertake a review of the existing administrative licensing and pricing system, following an opportunity for public input.

A new system of class licensing is being provided for under the Bill. A class licence is an open, standing authority allowing anyone to operate a device provided this is in keeping with the conditions of licence. Class licences will be introduced for those low powered devices and services which do not require individual licensing, for example remote control devices such as garage door openers.

The provisions relating to the conciliation of interference disputes have also been updated and a publicly accessible on-line data base on all licences and frequency assignments is to be established to assist in the registration of licences and frequency assignments.

Other changes will allow the SMA to determine classes of apparatus licences, thereby streamlining the licensing process; will increase the maximum period of such licences to 5 years; and will introduce an explicit renewal procedure into the legislation. Further changes will allow the SMA to make arrangements with banks and post offices for the collection of licence fees and charges. This should be of particular benefit to users in country areas.

Opportunity has also been taken, in consultation with the Attorney-General's Department, to review the offence and penalty provisions of the legislation and to remove a number of anomalies. The new penalties recognise the increasing importance of interference-free communications, particularly in situations involving safety of life.
Spectrum Management Agency

The success of the reforms contained in this Bill will depend on having an efficient and effective organisation to implement them. There is a need for an organisation which is responsive to the needs of users, and able to manage market based reforms. Such an organisation requires greater administrative flexibility and accountability than is possible under current arrangements. Accordingly the Bill establishes a specialist spectrum management agency to administer the new arrangements.

The Spectrum Management Agency (SMA) will be established as a separate statutory agency within the Transport and Communications portfolio and will have a structure similar to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, Customs and similar bodies. Like those agencies it will operate within the legal umbrella of the Commonwealth. It will not be a statutory authority with its own body corporate.

It will be headed by a statutory officer, to be called the Spectrum Manager, appointed by the Governor-General for a term of up to 5 years. The Spectrum Manager will have the powers of a Departmental Secretary. SMA staff will be appointed under the Public Service Act 1922. Approximately 350 to 400 of the staff within the Department of Transport and Communications engaged in spectrum management related activities will be transferred to the new agency. Its headquarters will remain in Canberra.

The SMA will be more user oriented and will bring a sharper focus to spectrum management issues. It will have increased planning and operational flexibility but will be more transparent and accountable in its method of operation. The SMA will be required to provide an annual report and will present its corporate plan and financial projections to the Minister. Its major decisions will be effected through disallowable instruments.

The SMA will also be able to establish committees to advise on its operations. The recently established Radiocommunications Consultative Council is an example of the consultative process now to be adopted, bringing together representatives of users of the spectrum to provide views on future policy and management directions.

The SMA will operate on a full cost recovery basis. It will charge users for services and facilities provided to them. The overhead costs of the SMA will be recovered through a relatively small annual charge on all licensees. In the case of spectrum licensees this will be the only annual charge that they will have to pay. Spectrum access charges for sale of spectrum licences will be returned to Consolidated Revenue. Annual licence fees paid by apparatus licensees are currently levied as taxes under related taxing legislation, with the level of the tax being set by regulations under those Acts. This is in recognition of the fact that these fees are not necessarily related only to costs or to the value of those licences. As mentioned earlier, it is the government's intention to move to a more rational, equitable system of setting annual licence fees for such licences and this will be one of the first major tasks of the new agency. Until a new scheme is in place these fees will continue to be levied under the tax Acts, but the level of the fee will in future be determined by the SMA through the use of disallowable instruments.

In conclusion, I would add that the measures included in this Bill provide for the most comprehensive reform of spectrum management ever undertaken in Australia. They will provide Australia with a system of spectrum management appropriate for a modern communications based economy, one better able to respond to a rapidly changing international communications environment.
Mr President, I present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: MIGRATION (OFFENCES AND UNDESIRABLE PERSONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Robert Ray, at the request of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Migration Act 1958.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray, at the request of the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the explanatory memorandum and a statement of Australia's criminal deportation policy, and move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Following the challenge to the decision to exclude from Australia, non Australian members of the Hell's Angels Motor Cycle Club, there has been close scrutiny of the decision making regime for the exclusion of persons of bad character and of persons generally who may represent a danger to the Australian community or a segment of it. This Bill represents the results of that process and enables the Minister to exclude from Australia persons of bad character and other undesirable persons.

The Bill provides that, from the dates of commencement, certain decisions under the Migration Act will be subject to determinative merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The commencement dates take account of the fact that some provisions in the Bill apply to the Migration Act in its current form and others will only apply to provisions introduced into the Act by the Migration Reform Bill which are scheduled to come into operation on 1 November 1993, if passed by the Parliament.

The Bill provides the Minister or his or her delegate, with the power to refuse or cancel a visa or entry permit where a person fails to meet the character criteria set out in the Act. There is also a power for the Minister, acting personally, to refuse or cancel visas or entry permits where, on the basis of information available to the Minister, he or she is satisfied that a person, if permitted to enter or remain in Australia would be likely to engage in criminal conduct or would represent a danger to the Australian community or a segment of it, or would engage in vilification of a segment of the community or would foment discord in the community.

The power is intended to be exercised in a manner consistent with well accepted Australian values such that it is aimed at those persons who may regard entry to this country as a means to attack those values. The new provisions would not be used to breach established standards of industrial democracy, for example.

The provisions will also not impact on the continued implementation of current Government policy in relation to criminal deportation. That policy has been effective since May 1983. It was updated in December 1988 when the then Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs clarified certain important issues for the benefit and guidance of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. It will be open to the Government to change that policy from time to time, in order to maintain its effectiveness, and to give appropriate direction to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Apart from re-stating it and revising and updating the policy to take account of the legislative changes, there is no need, at present, to make any major changes now. A statement of the amended policy is tabled in conjunction with this amending legislation. This will ensure the currency of Government policy on criminal deportation and provide up to date guidance to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal in such matters.

The amendments render unnecessary the character criteria for the grant of visas and entry permits. These are currently set out in the Migration Regulations. In future, this Bill will provide a basis in the primary legislation for refusing or cancelling visas or entry permits on the grounds of character. Under this Bill, the Minister will be able to consider whether a person is of good character by reference to a person's actual criminal conduct, his or her general conduct or by reference to a person's association with any other person, group or organisation who the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe has been or is involved in criminal conduct. Policy guidance will be developed in due course to assist those decision makers delegated with the power to make decisions under this legislation.

All decisions taken under the powers provided for in this legislation will be subject to merits review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Specifically, the decisions which will be subject to such review will be criminal deportations, decisions to refuse a visa or entry permit or decisions to cancel a visa or entry permit on the grounds of bad character or where a person may engage in criminal conduct, vilify a segment of the community, foment discord in the community or represent a danger to the community. These decisions will be subject to such review from the date of Royal Assent of this Bill.

There will be special arrangements for protection visas under provisions introduced by the Migration Reform Bill 1992, presently before the Parliament. Protection visas will be granted on the basis that the applicant is entitled to protection under the United Nations Convention and Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees. Decisions to refuse protection visas will be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, where adverse determinations are made against persons such that character concerns are sufficiently serious to engage those Articles of the Convention which provide for the exclusion of an individual from the provisions of the Convention (Article 1F) or for the expulsion of a refugee (Articles 32 and 33(2)). Such decisions will only be reviewable by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on and after 1 November 1993.

Review by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal of the exercise of the new powers provided by this Bill will not be permitted, however, where the Minister, acting personally, decides that it is in the national interest that such persons should not be permitted to enter or remain in Australia. In such cases the Minister will be required to include, as part of the decision, a certificate stating that, in the national interest, the person is refused entry to or permission to remain in the country.
In those cases where a certificate is included, the Minister will be required to table a notice of the decision in the Parliament within 15 sitting days of the taking of the decision.

Providing for determinative review of these cases by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, will mean that it is the sole merits review body for criminal deportation decisions, decisions refusing or cancelling visas or entry permits under the new character provisions including decisions made relying on those Articles of the Refugee Convention which allow for exclusion or expulsion of individuals and those decisions taken on the basis of information which satisfies the Minister that a person would vilify, incite discord or represent a danger to the Australian community or segment of it or would be likely to engage in criminal conduct in Australia. In these cases, the Immigration Review Tribunal, the new Refugee Review Tribunal created under the Migration Reform Bill and internal Departmental review officers will have no jurisdiction whatsoever. For the sake of clarity, any visa or entry permit refusal or cancellation involving the exercise of the powers provided for in this Bill will only be reviewable on the merits by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The Tribunal, in reviewing such matters will be guided by relevant policy directives of the Government, such as the criminal deportation policy and that developed to guide the use of the powers provided for in this legislation. In such cases, this Tribunal will also then review all other aspects of the decision.

Review before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal will only be permitted to a person whose visa or entry permit has been refused or cancelled if he or she is present in Australia at the time of the decision. If the person is not present, the Bill provides for that person's nominator or sponsor in Australia, if any, to take the matter before the Tribunal.

Finally, if a person has his or her visa or entry permit refused or cancelled, the person will be excluded from Australia for a period set out in the Migration Regulations. This will mean that, prior to 1 November 1993, those persons in Australia whose entry permits are cancelled because of these provisions, will not be permitted, after being deported, to re-enter Australia for period set out in the Regulations. After that date, criminal deportees, who will continue to be subject to deportation and persons in Australia whose visas are cancelled and who are thus liable to detention and removal from Australia as unlawful non-citizens will be similarly prevented from re-entering Australia for a period set out in the Regulations. Persons who have not entered Australia, will not be permitted to enter Australia for the period prescribed in the Regulations. The Regulations will be able to set out variable exclusion periods.
I commend this Bill to the Senate and present the explanatory memorandum to the Bill.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.
Motion (by Senator Walters) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to regulate certain video material.
Motion (by Senator Walters) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: The purpose of the Bill is twofold. It is:
1) to reduce the violence in "M" and "R" rated videos.
2) to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of "X" rated videos.

In 1988 the Joint Select Committee enquiring into video material tabled a report containing about 30 recommendations. There were 2 areas of particular concern to the Committee regarding content: firstly the strength of the violence in videos and secondly that "X" rated videos were degrading to women and should be abolished.

Following the tabling of the report, the Australian Attorney's-General met and as a result of that meeting a unanimous agreement was reached between the State Attorneys-General. It was agreed that most Australians wanted "X" rated and excessively violent videos to be outlawed and that the way to accomplish this was to have a national approach on the issue. This was necessary because while all the States had for some time banned the sale or hire of "X" rated videos under their jurisdiction, the Commonwealth had refused to do so in the Territories, resulting in the free trade of these videos being carried out between the States and Territories and so thwarting the States' legislation.

However the Federal Government refused to abide by the combined decision of the Attorneys-General from the various States and the situation still exists where, because the Australian Constitution allows free trade between the States and Territories, the various States' legislation is overridden.

There is certainly a need for national legislation in this regard and all the States support this approach. To substantiate the need for this legislation I will refer to both the findings of the 1989 International Crime Survey and evidence given to the Joint Select Committee.

Following the release of the Trends and Issues Paper No.23, dated 23 June 1990, put out by the Australian Institute of Criminology entitled "A Comparison of Crime in Australia and Other Countries", the Australian Institute claimed that the statistics give, and I quote, "a result which must surely give cause for concern to all Australians and reinforce the need for the establishment of a National Crime Prevention Strategy". There are no suggestions in the paper as to what should constitute a National Crime Prevention Strategy and the Government has not taken up this suggestion.

Let me come to the statistics that gave rise to this concern. The survey of a comparison of crime in Australia and other countries points out how difficult comparisons have been in the past, due to the variety and complexity of the criminal justice systems. However, it also points out that with the advent of standardised crime surveys and victimisation experiences, many of these dilemmas have been overcome. The Issues paper uses victim surveys. It summarises the findings of the 1989 International Crime Survey and says: " The Survey findings reveal that Australia has crime rates which are much more comparable to those of North America than Europe. In a number of cases these rates are the highest recorded among the 14 jurisdictions. I quote: "In assaults involving force, in the less serious types of sexual incidents, in burglary and in motor vehicle thefts, Australia ranked highest of all countries surveyed".
The paper suggests that some aspects of the Australian lifestyle may actually be responsible for our high crime rates.

What it attempted to point out is that our life style may, and it stresses may, contribute to the fact that Australia is ranked 3rd in the 14 countries surveyed in terms of overall victimisation behind USA and Canada. We rank highest in sexual incidents and 3rd in sexual assault, yet the paper ignores national characteristics—why? We do know that other societies have different mores, eg. in Western Sumatra where women have always been respected and influential members of the community, anthropologists say rape is low or non-existent. The survey points out that some European countries such as Switzerland and England also rank very low in the more serious sexual assault rates, Switzerland having no incidents reported in 1988, and England 0.1% compared to Australia's 1.6% (201,147 incidents).

May I suggest it is possible that the Australian characteristic of the macho chauvinist male has taught some of our men that being male gives them a right to dominate women, with masculinity meaning being aggressive both sexually and otherwise, and with their need for mate approval, may be and again I stress may, be the reason Australia ranks so high among those countries surveyed for sexual abuse. Another survey that reinforces my view, undertaken by the Office of the Status of Women, points out that 22% of men, an amazing one in 5 of our male population, believe it is acceptable for a man to use physical force against his wife. Surprisingly, 17% of women agree.

As I have already indicated, Australia tops the survey in sexual incidents against women and does so by quite a large margin. In Australia 7.3% of the sample were victimised in sexual incidents in 1988. The next country was the USA with 4.5%. The UK and France were amongst the lowest with 1.2%. As regards sexual assault, including rape, as I've said, Australia came 3rd; but by a much smaller margin.

As I've said, a Joint Select Committee of the Federal Parliament was required to enquire into video material and as I indicated there were 2 areas of particular concern to the Committee regarding content: firstly the strength of the violence in videos and secondly that "X" rated videos were degrading to women and should be abolished. Evidence supporting the concerns of the community was considerable. Dr Paul Wilson, formerly of the Institute of Criminology, gave evidence to our Committee, telling us that while he found no hard evidence that sadistic sexual pornography causes serial, lust, or child killing, he found evidence that in the killer's background there was, first of all, a preoccupation with this material, secondly, a feeling that their sexual and sadistic fantasies are fuelled by this material and, thirdly, a feeling in some cases that the material is not strong enough and that their fantasies are not satisfactorily fulfilled. He said that it was his view that with particular personalities, material of a sadistic, sexual kind which combines sex and violence reinforces existing predisposition towards the sadistic acts that are carried out and he was deeply concerned. He said: " my basic philosophical position has always been one of allowing adults to read or view what they want in private. However, I believe there is a strong case for censoring material which combines sex and sadism ". His concerns were supported by Dr William Belson's evidence. He was a prominent researcher on video violence. His study, "Television Violence and the Adolescent Boy" formed the basis of his evidence. He stated ". . . long term exposure to television violence increases boys' participation in violent behaviour, increases their preoccupation with violent acts shown on television, makes them more callous in their reactions to the spectacle of violence in the world around them. . . .

Dr Patricia Edgar, Director of the Australian Children's Television Foundation, agreed. She sees it as `feasible' that some individuals may select materials that exaggerate their aggressive tendency and hence allow the committal of a violent crime, a crime that otherwise may not have occurred. Many more eminent academics and researchers gave similar evidence on violence.

Professor James Check, who undertook research for the Fraser Committee on Pornography and Prostitution in Canada, found that the anti-social effects of pornography were the most pronounced in individuals who already possessed a certain `sexual aggressivity'. Moreover, the data revealed that it was the frequent users of pornography who had the most striking inclinations to sexually aggressive behaviour. Again many eminent academics and researchers supported this view. Dr J.H. Court, of Kent Town, South Australia; Mr F.M. Horwill, of Victoria; Dr James Weaver, of Kentucky, USA; and Zillman and Bryant of London to name but a few. Others outside the Committee hearings included Scotland Yard and many Australian Police Forces.

The evidence that made most sense to me was given by Professor Sheehan, University of Queensland. As with Dr. Wilson's evidence on violence, he too argued that the personality of the viewer was of prime importance, he said ". . . the critical thing in whether or not there will be these so-called effects of sexually explicit material is how aggressive the person is in the first place. . . .There is no question that a lot of people are stimulated mildly or strongly by seeing sexually explicit material. When one is aroused one tends to behave as a consequence of that arousal and I think if the person is aggressive, aggression will out . . . In and of itself, I do not think that sexually explicit material divorced from aggression leads to strong negative effects. Once you combine sexually explicit material with aggression you have a different kettle of fish. . . The critical thing is how much someone is aroused and how aggressive he is in the first place". If you consider this evidence in conjunction with the survey on domestic violence where nearly 1/4 of Australian men consider it acceptable to use physical force against their wives, then I believe we have a real problem.

The three main concerns of witnesses who opposed any censorship of either X-rated videos or violence in R-rated were that (1) `Adults should be able to view what they like and that censorship is a violation of civil rights'. I find it illogical that those who gave this type of evidence did not also object to censorship of child pornography. Again there is no proven evidence of a causative link between the viewing of child pornography and criminal child sexual abuse. Yet those who gave the Committee this evidence were all in favour of banning child pornography. It wasn't that they really objected to censorship, it's just where they wanted the line drawn. The next concern was `if banned, it would open up a black market'. Similarly those who made this claim didn't seem to think that just because there was a black market in child pornography, that type of censorship should be lifted. They agreed that, yes, a minority would continue to use the black market but you would not be able to walk down to the supermarket and get "the stuff"; use would certainly be greatly reduced. The third concern—`that there is no proven evidence of a causative link between the viewing of violent or non-violent pornography and violent criminal behaviour and so there is no justification for its ban'. There is evidence that convicted paedophiles have libraries of videos showing child pornography and there is evidence that many convicted murderers and rapists have libraries of X-rated and sexually violent R-rated videos, as Dr. Wilson said: "I have found evidence that in the killer's background there is, first of all, a preoccupation with this material".

There are no studies that give clear, proven evidence that the viewers of child pornography, violent pornography or non-violent pornography of itself causes criminal behaviour, but I do believe that there is a reasonable expectation that frequent viewing of any of these types of videos by people with aggressive characteristics can, as Professor Sheehan says, stimulate them mildly or strongly and they behave accordingly. As I have already pointed out, he is not alone in this belief. Substantial evidence was presented to us claiming viewing of such material desensitises the viewers, a claim we could all identify with. How often have we become desensitised to the use of unacceptable language or to the viewing of violence either in the news or in films. We all know that today, when we hear on the ABC certain expletives that were previously considered unacceptable, we no longer turn a hair. This is fact. Yet there seems to be a lack of acceptance of this fact by some people. They do not believe that regular viewing of pornography, and indeed sexual violence, so readily found in these videos, leads to the desensitisation of the viewer, even though so many experts have brought this evidence to the Senate Committee. Considering such doubt, I believe we must not allow, or even run the risk of allowing, these videos to desensitise our population. The cost is too great.

In the Supreme Court of NSW in May last year, when sentencing a young 19 year old man for the murder of a young mother, Justice Mathews, having given the history of the case and having accepted the evidence of both Dr Bruce Webster, a highly qualified psychiatrist for the defence and Dr Milton who gave evidence for the Crown, said: "It is not so easy to absolve a system which allows such a violent and unmeritorious film as "Nightmare at Shadow Woods" to be viewed indiscriminately by members of the community regardless of their underlying problems or susceptibilities. It was a film with no discernible artistic merit at all. As far as I could see it was nothing more than a vehicle for depicting gratuitous, mindless and ghoulish violence", the Judge said. She continued: " Dr Milton considered that the film acted as a trigger for the prisoner, transforming fantasies about violence into an intention to inflict actual violence. Dr Westmore also thought that the film acted as a trigger in that it was a disturbing agent in the prisoner's already disturbed brain. So that whichever version one were to accept, the viewing of this film had a real part to play in the tragedy which followed. Certainly the prisoner was already a vulnerable person, but it is precisely such a person which is likely to be adversely affected by watching such a film as this".

The Judge went on: "I am not in a position to suggest any measures which might have been taken to prevent this tragedy, or which might be taken to prevent a similar one in the future. Clearly, a free and open society requires that there be freedom of communication. On the other hand, I cannot help wondering what benefits society can derive from having such a mindlessly violent film as this generally available to be viewed by anyone, no matter how disturbed he or she might be. The potentially devastating effects can be seen in the events of 27 February".

The video that triggered this horrendous crime was classified "M"—suitable for 15 years and over. In questioning the members of the office of Film and Literature Classification following the murder trial, I was informed the classification would not be altered. The government's guidelines made this video suitable for viewing by anyone over 15 years. I believe my Bill would alter that classification.

A recent report was put out following research undertaken by Check and Sommers in Canada involving 44 women who suffered severe battering by their male partners. They were compared with a control group of women who had not been battered. It was found that the partners of the battered women were high consumers of pornography, in the form of both videos and magazines, while the partners of the control group were not.

It is ironical that X-rated videos are considered by the Government too degrading to women to be shown in cinemas—they ban that—but they believe it's quite suitable for home entertainment, where, as we are fully aware, our young can and do, gain access to them. Could anyone be happy for their children to view X-rated videos as an introduction to their sex education? Does anyone believe this would contribute to a happy, healthy relationship in their future life?

There is considerable concern in the community regarding the increase in the figures of sexual abuse—the latest figures on rape alone put out by the Institute show an increase of 159% in ten years. Every day we have newspaper articles reflecting the concerns of women in this country and the new ABC program "Without Consent", is just one of many responses to this growing concern in the community. Women are taking self defence courses, they talk about one-sex car-parking lots, they no longer go for walks in their neighbourhoods after dark. I know when doorknocking at election time, women will no longer open their doors even in the middle of the day, but wait until they establish who is knocking. On the last occasion when I introduced a similar Bill, every Women's organisation supported it. From the most conservative to the most radical—all pleaded with the Government to support my legislation. They were ignored. The Office of the Status of Women has put out a Position Paper to provide the basis for the work of the National Committee on Violence against Women. In it, they give examples of some of the more common types of sexual violence and they include " forcing her to view pornographic material". They say sexual violence is not only an attack on the woman's physical body it is also a violation experienced at emotional and intellectual levels. Dr. Wilson is quoted in the Daily Telegraph as saying "I think there's a view that pervades Australian culture that sex is readily available and if you can't get it you should take it". This view is reflected in the latest survey conducted this year by the Domestic Violence Resource Centre in Brisbane, which found 1 in 3 of the 14-15 year old boys surveyed, believed it was "okay" to rape a girl under certain circumstances.

As I said in the beginning, the Institute of Criminology in its Trends and Issues paper "Comparing Crime in Australia and Other Countries" said the Survey's results "must surely give cause for concern to all Australians". Evidence given to our Committee underlined this concern and while I have only referred to one judgement, many judges throughout Australia have expressed similar concerns.
As legislators I believe we must, we are required and it is our obligation to do everything in our power to make Australia a safer place for our women and men, and their families.

SPEECH.PARA: CORPORATE LAW REFORM BILL 1992

This Bill implements major reforms on directors' duties, related party transactions, corporate insolvency laws, and stock exchange settlement procedures. The Bill is the most significant piece of legislation, in terms of the content of Australia's corporate law, introduced during the life of this Parliament.
Financial impact
The Bill is not expected to have any significant financial impact on Government. The Explanatory Memorandum details the potential impact of the Bill on business.
The content of the Bill
Mr President, this is a long Bill because it has much to say.

One of the key areas of reform relates to directors' duties. On that matter, the Bill says that directors should be under an obligation to show the degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person in their position would exercise. At the same time, the Bill and its supporting material make clear that the courts should never apply hindsight to the decisions of directors, but should judge those decisions based on the information which was available to the director at the time when the decision was made.

The Bill also provides that where a director breaches his or her duty, but is not acting with any dishonest or fraudulent intent, the director should no longer be exposed to criminal sanctions and possible gaol terms. But it also says that shareholders should be protected against breaches by the substitution of appropriate civil penalties, including pecuniary penalties and disqualification in the case of serious breaches.

On related parties, the Bill will ensure that companies do not give benefits on less than commercial terms to directors or holding companies without shareholders having an opportunity to say whether the benefit should be given. It says that directors who have a material personal interest in a matter before the Board should disclose that interest and should be prevented from participating in Board consideration of that matter, unless their fellow directors are prepared to agree to them participating.

In relation to companies in difficulty, the Bill makes plain that there are ways to deal with a company which is facing solvency difficulties that are more constructive and efficient than current remedies.
It will ensure that receivers are accountable to shareholders and creditors for what they are doing while controlling a company.

It says that mortgagees should not be able to avoid being accountable by taking possession of an asset through an agent rather than appointing a receiver. The same accountability should apply whenever a mortgagee has taken over a company.

In addition, the Bill will prevent directors from avoiding liability for insolvent trading by deliberately refusing to take any part in the management of the company. It substitutes alternative defences which protect diligent and reasonable directors, without giving comfort to the reckless.

The Bill will also enable directors who act honestly and reasonably to be absolved by a court from liability for insolvent trading. But such directors will also be specifically encouraged to take early action to tackle emerging difficulties, such as through the appointment of an administrator under the new voluntary administration procedure.
Under the Bill, liquidators will be able to more easily reverse transactions where companies have paid out monies to related parties just prior to a company's insolvency.
This process will be assisted by ensuring that there are no technical restrictions on what a liquidator can examine in trying to ascertain what has actually happened with a company which has failed.

The Bill also makes it clear that it is not good enough to provide for corporate law by making obscure and difficult cross-references to the Bankruptcy Act and substitutes clear provisions adapted specifically for companies.

Companies will no longer be able to resist statutory demands on purely technical grounds such as a minor misstatement of the quantity of a debt. Demands will be able to be set aside only where injustice would otherwise be caused.
The Bill will also enable Australia's stock exchange settlement procedures to continue to remain on a par with the world's best and meet the standards of quick settlement that are nowadays demanded.

And finally, the Bill will ensure that Australian and New Zealand accounting standards will as far as possible be brought into alignment, so that investors dealing with a company from the other country will be able to accurately assess the financial information with which they are provided.
The context of the Bill
Mr President, this Bill needs to be seen in the context of the Government's overall agenda for corporate law reform during the life of this Parliament.
In 1990, the Parliament passed a Bill which established the national scheme for corporate regulation that we have enjoyed, for the first time in this country, since 1 January 1991.
The next element in the Government's corporate law agenda was a series of shorter Bills, dealing with particularly urgent issues of reform, such as:
-consolidation of accounts and the compulsory application of accounting standards;
-the implementation of the report by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on Insider Trading;
-measures to deal with the liquidity crisis which emerged in the unlisted property trust industry last year; and
-measures to secure greater international co-operation in corporate law enforcement.

This Bill represents the next stage in the process of corporate law reform, a stage which involves tackling very significant and fundamental issues of reform in a number of different areas of corporate law.
The history of the Bill

These reforms have not emerged from a vacuum. On the contrary, as is the case with all of the Government's corporate law reform initiatives, the 4 main elements of this Bill have their origins either in a major law reform report or in calls by industry for the introduction of particular changes.

For example, the insolvency reforms in this Bill result from a report by the Australian Law Reform Commission. It is now some 9 years since the inquiry which led to that report commenced. The Commission first published an issues paper and received submissions on it. This was followed by the publication of a 351-page discussion paper (which generated some 204 more detailed submissions), and a 620-page report.

The Bill also includes provisions which implement the report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the "Social and Fiduciary Duties and Obligations of Company Directors". That report itself followed the receipt of many submissions by the Committee and public hearings in a number of cities.

The related party transactions provisions in the Bill result from a report by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee, which followed a 2-year period of public consultation, with the public release of first a report and then a draft Bill. When the Corporate Law Reform Bill was released for public exposure in February this year, the provisions in this Part of the Bill were criticised on the basis that they were too long and complex and failed to give the kind of clear guidance in this area which seemed necessary following the many disastrous related party transactions which took place in the 1980s.

In response to those concerns, the Government has arranged for the provisions to be redrafted in a simpler form—one which focuses much more directly on the general principles involved, supports those principles by examples where appropriate, and eschews any attempt to provide by long "black letter" formulations a precise description of how the law should apply in every particular case.

The Stock Exchange settlement reforms in the Bill result from recommendations of a high level clearing and settlement steering committee established by the Australian Stock Exchange to look at implementation of a report by "The Group of 30" (a private international organisation concerned with major economic and financial issues). These reforms will enable the Australian Stock Exchange to keep up with world best practice.

As is appropriate for a Bill of its significance, unprecedented consultation has been associated with every aspect of the development of the Bill, and major efforts have been made to as far as possible meet all the concerns which have been raised.

Even before the Bill was drafted, the Attorney-General's Department circulated discussion papers to interested peak organisations and professional bodies for the purpose of testing their reaction to the general approach which might be taken in the Bill. After the Bill was released for public exposure in February of this year, this consultation process intensified. The Department and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee jointly sponsored a series of practitioners' forums on the Bill, each of which was attended by a large number of business and professional people. The Joint Parliamentary Committee for Corporations and Securities held hearings in a number of cities. The Attorney-General has spoken at a number of seminars and other gatherings organised to consider the Bill, and officers from the Department have attended as many as possible of the many professional seminars which have considered the Bill during the year.

Over 200 submissions were received on the Bill and these have been carefully analysed, and many changes have been made to the Bill that was exposed. The Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill outlines the more significant changes that have been made. There have also been many minor technical improvements, which have resulted from the welcome willingness of many within the business and professional communities to involve themselves in a consultation process. It is a process that has been far more thorough than has ever taken place before in Australian corporate law, and, I dare say, is one of the most thorough processes of consultation that has ever taken place on any Bill in this country.
Main features of the Bill
I now want to outline a few of the most important features of the Bill. A more detailed survey is set out at the start of the Explanatory Memorandum.
- directors' duties

The Bill amends subsection 232(4) of the Corporations Law to reinforce that an officer's duty of care is an objective one, requiring the officer to exercise the degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person in a like position as an officer of a corporation would exercise in the corporation's circumstances.

In the case of a business corporation, the proposed standard will reflect the fact that corporate decisions involve risk-taking. The courts have in the past recognised that directors and officers are not liable for honest errors of judgement. They have also shown a reluctance to review business judgments taken in good faith. Thus, in Harlowe's Nominees Pty. Limited v Woodside 121 CLR 483 at 493, the High Court said:

Directors in whom are vested the right and duty of deciding where the company's interests lie and how they are to be served may be concerned with a wide range of practical considerations, and their judgment, if exercised in good faith and not for irrelevant purposes, is not open to review in the courts.

In addition, the courts have exercised their discretion to excuse directors who have acted honestly and who ought fairly to be excused. The Corporations Law already contains a provision of this nature (section 1318), and the application of that section is effectively being extended by clause 17 of this Bill.

The Government endorses this approach and does not intend any change in the law by the revised wording of subsection 232(4). No attempt has been made in the Bill to enact a U.S. style of Business Judgment Rule since no state in the USA has adopted a legislative statement of the Rule. Instead the matter has been left to the courts to develop. Similarly the Government considers that the development of similar principles in Australia is better left to the courts.

The Bill also decriminalises certain key directors' duties provisions by providing that breaches of those provisions are no longer subject to criminal sanctions unless the breaches are committed with a dishonest intent. In the course of a planned general review of the penalty provisions in the Corporations Law, the Government will be considering carefully the extent to which the decriminalisation initiatives in this Bill should be taken further.

Civil penalties are substituted in respect of breaches which are committed without a dishonest intent. The Bill provides that a pecuniary penalty of up to $200,000 may be imposed. However, no pecuniary penalty may be imposed unless the Court considers that the breach is a serious one. The Bill also allows the Court to disqualify a director. However, the Court may only do so where it concludes that the director is not a fit and proper person to manage a corporation.
- related party transactions
Perhaps the most important provisions in the Bill are the provisions which deal with related party transactions, such as loans to directors and loans between companies in a group.

The Corporations Law is currently almost silent on related party transactions. Certainly, the general duties and fiduciary principles which are reflected in some of the more general provisions in the Law do have relevance in this area. There is also a complex and rather outdated provision which deals with three types of benefits which can be given to directors. But there is nothing which sets out clearly, and in a coherent fashion, what this Parliament has to say on the matter generally.

In particular, there is nothing in the Corporations Law which says specifically that money should not be given to holding companies without minority shareholders having an opportunity to consider the transaction.
There is nothing in the Corporations Law which says specifically that remuneration for directors must not be unreasonable.
There is nothing in the Corporations Law that says specifically that directors cannot act in concert with others to pillage a company's resources.
In all of these respects, areas where investors in so many Australian companies have suffered so badly in recent years, the Corporations Law is currently silent.
This Bill fills that void. It will represent this Parliament's view about what ought to have happened in all those cases.

It does so in a reasoned and principled way. It does not seek to deal with every conceivable situation and to provide a specific rule for that situation. Many feel that that kind of approach only encourages the search for loopholes.

Equally, the Bill does not impose undue compliance costs. Generous exceptions are allowed to the rules in the Bill, and even where the policy of the Bill dictates that a shareholder meeting should be held to approve a particular transaction or type of transaction, the Bill is concerned to ensure that those meetings can be held in a manner that is as inexpensive as possible, yet still consistent with the need to ensure that shareholders are fully informed.
- insolvency reforms
Mr President, in relation to the multi-faceted insolvency reforms, special mention should be made of those relating to companies in financial difficulty.

It is often said of our insolvency laws that they are so inflexible and expensive to use that it is impossible for a company to seek to recover through an insolvency administration without facing the likelihood of liquidation. This is because most current forms of administration suffer from the fatal flaw that individual creditors can disrupt them to the point where they become unworkable.

What is really needed, when a basically sound company faces solvency difficulties, is a capacity for that company to obtain a breather. This Bill offers that opportunity. Directors will be able to appoint an administrator, who will have the benefit of a moratorium on actions against the company while formulating a plan of action for consideration by the creditors. The emphasis is on informality and flexibility. The emphasis is also on speed of action. The procedure does not allow the indefinite administrations which can occur, for example, under the United States Chapter 11 approach. The emphasis is also on appropriate protection of creditors' interests, so that they will find that they are not unduly disadvantaged by the short moratorium proposed.

It has been suggested that, in addition to the new voluntary scheme of administration, consideration should also be given to a form of insolvency administration that can be readily invoked by unsecured creditors. That is something the Attorney-General has some sympathy for, and will examine in the light of the experience with the voluntary scheme.
What comes after the Bill
Finally, Mr Speaker, a word about the future.

As the Attorney-General has indicated on previous occasions, this Bill, and the proposed Enhanced Statutory Disclosure Bill, will bring to completion a stage of the Government's corporate law program which has been concerned to redress deficiencies in the law which were exposed by the problems of the late 1980s. During this stage of that program, the Government has addressed issues such as the lack of guidance in the law on related party transactions, the lack of rigour in application of accounting standards, the lack of on-going disclosure by listed companies, and inflexibility in our insolvency laws.

But we also need to look forward and to build on the achievements attained during the life of this Parliament. In particular, we need to forge the odd mix of corporate laws that we have inherited from the co-operative scheme into a streamlined engine for economic progress and development. We need to give Australian business the kind of corporate law that it will need for the twenty-first century.

Some months ago, the Attorney-General said that he would be looking to commence a process of simplifying and modernising our corporate law as soon as the current Bills were finalised. That next stage of the Government's corporate law program is about to commence. I know that there are many elements of the business and professional community that are eager to get started. I know, from experience this year, that they will make valuable contributions. And they know, also from experience this year, that the Government will involve them very closely in the process.
Conclusion

Mr President, in accordance with the Heads of Agreement between the Commonwealth, the States and the Northern Territory on corporate regulation, the Ministerial Council for Corporations has been consulted on the Bill and has approved its introduction into Parliament.
