TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (CAR PARKING) BILL 1992

This Bill will give effect to the Budget measure announced on 18 August 1992 to tax certain car parking benefits. The Government finds it inequitable that some employees receive these car parking benefits in a tax exempt form while other employees, most of whom will not get a tax deduction for their car parking costs, must pay for equivalent facilities out of their after tax income.

Accordingly, the Bill will amend the Fringe Benefits Tax Assessment Act 1986 to impose fringe benefits tax on certain car parking benefits received by employees. However, a benefit will only arise where a car used to commute from home to work is parked at or near the employee's main workplace for more than 4 hours between the hours of 7.00 a.m. and 7.00 p.m.

Where the employer reimburses an employee's car parking expenses, the value of the benefit will be the amount of that reimbursement. Where the employer provides car parking facilities to an employee, the value of the benefit will be determined in accordance with the mechanism set out in the budget papers. That is, the value of the lowest cost all-day parking at a permanent commercial parking station available to the public within one kilometre of the employer-provided facilities.

The Bill will also amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to deny to employees a deduction for similar car parking expenses which arise from parking a car used to commute to work at or near the employee's main workplace for more than 4 hours between the hours of 7.00 a.m. and 7.00 p.m. This denial of a deduction will ensure that the overall tax effect of providing either a car parking benefit or an allowance to an employee to cover car parking expenses is substantially similar.

To minimise concerns about any unintended impact of these measures, the Government has ensured that the Bill provides that the provision of certain parking facilities can be exempted by Regulation. Such exemptions may include parking facilities provided by employers that are of a minimal value or parking facilities which would not normally be considered to be "commercial parking stations" for the purpose of these measures. The Government will consider the circumstances under which it would be appropriate for it to recommend to the Governor-General to make such Regulations.
The measures introduced in this Bill will result in an increase to revenue of $90m in 1993-94, $253m in 1994-95 and $203m in each subsequent year.

In order to give employers and car parking operators sufficient time to adjust their procedures as a result of this Bill, and so that the Government can consider what Regulations may be required, the provisions of this Bill will not apply until 1 July 1993.

CUSTOMS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
This Bill is an omnibus measure proposing amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1985. The main proposals contained in the Bill relate to:

(1) amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Customs Administration Act 1985 to provide the legislative framework for the electronic transmission to Customs of information relating to the reporting, screening and clearance of cargo, and to permit limited on-line computer access to such information by other specified agencies;
(2) amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to improve waterfront security in accordance with recommendations of the Joint Review Committee of the National Crime Authority;

(3) amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to extend eligibility for the diesel fuel rebate scheme to vessels servicing oil and gas operations in the North West Shelf and Timor Gap exploration areas when those vessels travel to and from Australian ship repair yards for repairs or refits; and
(4) amendments to the Customs Act 1901 to effect minor technical changes consequential on the introduction of the electronic lodgement reforms to the import entry regime in Act No. 34 of 1992.
I will now refer briefly to each of those proposals:
(1) Cargo Automation

The proposed amendments in Clauses 6, 7 and 10 of the Bill are a response to the increasing role that electronic data interchange plays in international trade. The Australian Customs Service is continuing to play an important role in the development of electronic initiatives to keep pace with EDI changes in international trade communications.

The proposed cargo automation scheme introduced by this Bill is the third leg of the improvement and updating of Customs entry facilities for imports and exports, and is modelled on the two earlier initiatives passed unanimously by this Parliament in Act No. 111 of 1990 (for exported goods), and in Act No. 34 of 1992 (for imported goods).

Similar to the two previous electronic schemes, the cargo automation system will operate on the basis of legislative amendments and contractual arrangements between Customs and users of the system. The proposed amendments in this Bill introduce an electronic/computer option for the communication
to Customs of information concerning cargo, to complement the current documentary/manual cargo reporting facilities.

The cargo automation system will allow airlines, shipping companies and freight forwarders to give Customs reports of the cargo intended to be discharged at Australian ports in advance of the arrival of that cargo. Those details will enable the cargo to be effectively screened against various profiles; for example, those relating to prohibited imports. The profiles can be altered by Customs at any time to target specific types of goods or destinations and can be further refined on the basis of intelligence and data relating to import practices. The advantage of an automated system is of course the speed with which it reacts to changing information, so that effective risk assessment and risk management is maintained.

With the amendments proposed in Clause 27 of the Bill, Port authorities will be provided with access to these cargo report details to facilitate the gathering of statistics and the calculation of wharfage charges, whilst the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service will be provided with access to the cargo reports for the purposes of facilitating the detection of possible breaches of the Quarantine Act 1908.

The new cargo automation system proposed in this Bill introduces considerable benefits for all parties involved in the entry and clearance of cargo; not the least of which are the significant reductions in paperwork and the more speedy access to information, on the one hand, whilst, on the other, it will provide a major enhancement of Customs ability to speedily screen reports for correct details against various risk profiles and provide a more effective control over landed cargo and its subsequent movement under Customs control.
(2) Waterfront Security

The amendments contained in Clauses 5 and 23 of the Bill are intended to improve waterfront security by obliging persons in `Customs areas' to produce satisfactory identification upon request by a Customs officer and by strengthening the powers of Customs officers to stop and search vehicles in certain circumstances.

The proposed amendments are designed to overcome weaknesses in the present system which were highlighted by the National Crime Authority in its 1989 report on `Port Security'; in particular, problems faced by law enforcement agencies in their attempts to inhibit the flow of illegal drugs.

The Joint Review Committee established to examine the National Crime Authority recommendations had noted that the inability to control or identify wharf visitors and waterfront workers was hindering barrier enforcement. The present amendments squarely address that issue, and are discussed in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum accompanying the Bill.
(3) Diesel Fuel Rebate

The amendments relating to the diesel fuel rebate scheme (DFRS) contained in Clause 21 of the Bill extend the eligibility criteria of the scheme, with effect from the Government's 18 August 1992 Budget decision to allow certain ships to claim a rebate on diesel-fuel used while travelling to and from Australian ports for repairs or refits.
The ships concerned are those engaged in the servicing of the oil and gas operations off the Western Australian coast, including the North West Shelf and Timor Gap areas.

Currently these servicing ships have an option to have repairs or refits undertaken either in Australian or Singaporean ship repair yards. Diesel fuel taken on by the ships in Singapore is at the international price, which does not include Australian excise. This has resulted in Australian ship repair yards being placed at a competitive disadvantage, especially those in Western Australia which are almost equidistant from the repair yards in Singapore.

The proposed amendments will effectively remove this disadvantage by reducing the cost of the Australian diesel fuel for those ships travelling to Australian ports for the necessary repairs or refits.
(4) Other Amendments

In addition to the amendments outlined above, the Bill proposes a number of minor amendments to the electronic lodgement provisions of the Customs Act 1901, which were introduced last Sittings by Act No. 34 of 1992. These amendments are explained in greater detail in the Explanatory Memorandum's Clause Notes for Clauses 11,12,19,20 and 22.

CUSTOMS LEGISLATION (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Act 1901 and the Anti-Dumping Authority Act 1988 as part of the legislative package announced by the Government in December 1991 to introduce a new system for the imposition and collection of dumping and countervailing duties. This Bill provides the mechanism for the determination of interim and final duties, as well as introducing the two means by which subsequent adjustments of duty liability can be effected. The other Bill in the package, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Bill, introduces the new taxing regime for the imposition and collection of both interim and final dumping and countervailing duties.
The proposed amendments contained in this package represent the final change to Australia's anti-dumping and countervailing provisions which

SPEECH.PARA: were announced by the Government on 5 December 1991 following a review of anti-dumping policy and administrative arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Last sittings, as part of Act No. 89 of 1992 this Parliament passed legislation which:

SPEECH.PARA: reduced the total time allowed for the processing of anti-dumping and countervailing applications to the preliminary finding stage to a maximum of 125 days, or for more complex cases, a maximum of 145 days;
extended, to five years, the period for which anti-dumping and countervailing measures remain in place;
made provision for a review to be undertaken by the Anti-Dumping Authority following a request by an interested party as to whether measures should continue after the five year expiry date;
extended the life of the Anti-Dumping Authority to August 2001; and
introduced a number of technical changes to facilitate the processing of applications.

PARA.TAB: Goods are said to be dumped if the export price of the product is less than the `normal value', that is, the comparable price for the like product in the domestic market of the exporting country.

Anti-dumping action is taken only if it is established as a result of inquiries undertaken by Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority that goods have been dumped and that the dumping is causing or threatening material injury to an Australian industry.

The Government strongly believes that effective and timely anti-dumping and countervailing measures are necessary to protect Australian industry from material injury caused by dumped or subsidised imports.
At the same time, the Government is determined not to allow the anti-dumping and countervailing system to be used as a de-facto means of industry protection.

Australia's anti-dumping system is now one of the fastest and fairest in the world. There is scope, however, to improve its effectiveness by altering the manner in which duties are imposed and collected.

In broad terms the present legislation imposes a dumping duty which represents the difference between the export price and the normal value of the goods, or where the Minister so directs, a lesser amount sufficient to remove the injury.

Under the present regime, duty is not payable where the dumping margin is purportedly eliminated by raising the actual export price to the level of the normal value determined at the inquiry. The Government considers that a more effective way to apply duties and strengthen the overall operation of the anti-dumping and countervailing system can be achieved with an approach similar to that used by the US and the European Community.
The proposals put forward in this package provide a mechanism whereby an interim duty will be imposed on each importation of goods subject to anti-dumping or countervailing measures.

The other Bill in this package, the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Bill provides that interim dumping duty will be based initially on the difference between the normal value and the export price as determined by the inquiries. Important additional features of that Bill are that the Minister will be able to determine the duty on an ad valorem or specific rate basis, and, where the export price falls below the export price ascertained by the inquiry, the difference between these prices will also be collected.
That Bill also provides that the interim countervailing duty will be determined on the basis of the amount of the subsidy identified by the inquiries.

In either case, and consistent with both our current law and Australia's obligations as a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (the GATT), the new taxing regime will continue to require the Minister to consider the desirability of imposing a lesser rate of duty where this is sufficient to remove injury.
With the introduction of an interim duty system in the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Bill, this Bill proposes two means by which subsequent adjustments of duty liability can be effected.

The first such mechanism is a repayment or reimbursement facility, whereby interim duty collected in excess of the actual dumping margin (in the case of dumping duties) or the actual subsidy (in the case of countervailing duties) can be repaid.

To reduce the possibility of applications being lodged on a selective basis for those consignments where it is known that a repayment is likely, this Bill requires that any application cover all consignments during a 6 month period. Duty will not be repaid unless the total interim duty paid exceeds the total actual duty liability for the period.
If no application has been received within 6 months of the end of the relevant importation period the interim duty paid will be taken to be the final duty payable.

The second mechanism to enable subsequent adjustments of the duty liability on goods the subject of a dumping or countervailing notice is introduced in the Bill via a review facility under which interested parties may seek a review of the interim duty to be paid on future shipments.

The Bill proposes that a request for such a review may only be made 12 months after the interim duty has been imposed or 12 months after the last review of the rate. However, the Minister may, where it is considered appropriate, request at any other time that a review of the duty rate be undertaken.

The Bill details the type of information required in support of a request for a review together with provisions allowing interested parties to make submissions. It also places strict time limits on the review consistent with the other time limits applying throughout the dumping process.

The Government is confident that the proposed new system strikes an equitable balance between the interests of importers and local industry, while conforming with Australia's obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT).

SPEECH.PARA: Financial Impact Statement

PARA.TAB: The proposed amendments contained in this Bill are expected to result in additional salary and administrative costs totalling $0.4m in 1992-93 and $0.75m in 1993-94 and 1994-95, in present dollar values.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING AMENDMENTS) BILL (No. 2) 1992

This Bill proposes to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 as the second Bill of the legislative package to introduce a new system for dumping and countervailing duties. This Bill introduces the new taxing regime for the imposition and collection of both interim and final dumping and countervailing duties, while the other Bill in the package which I have just introduced, the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill, provides the mechanism for the determination of interim and final duties, as well as introducing the two means by which subsequent adjustments of duty liability can be effected.

As I noted in the second reading speech for the Customs Legislation (Anti-Dumping) Bill, interim dumping duty imposed under this Bill will be based initially on the difference between the normal value and the export price as determined by the inquiries. Important additional features of the new regime are that the Minister will be able to determine the duty on an ad valorem or specific rate basis, and, where the export price falls below the export price ascertained by the inquiry, the difference between these prices will also be collected.
Interim countervailing duty will be imposed on the basis of the amount of the subsidy identified by the inquiries.

In either case, and consistent with Australia's obligations as a signatory to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (the GATT), the Minister will continue to consider the desirability of imposing a lesser rate of duty where this is sufficient to remove injury.
Financial Impact Statement
The proposed amendments contained in this Bill have no direct financial implications.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its explanatory memorandum.
QANTAS SALE BILL 1992

PARA.TAB: Mr President, the proposed sale of Qantas Airways Limited is an important part of the Government's extensive program of reform of the Australian aviation industry.

From 1988 on, the Boards of Directors for both Qantas and Australian Airlines had repeatedly raised with the Government the question of their being given greater access to equity capital. The airlines were weighed down by grossly un-commercial debt to equity ratios at a time of rapid business expansion. The Government therefore had to face up directly to the question of whether or not to invest a large amount of funds in the airlines and, if so, to then forgo expenditure in other higher priority areas as a consequence.
Faced with this choice, the Government decided in September 1990 to sell 100 per cent of Australian Airlines and 49 per cent of Qantas.

In doing so, the Government recognised that, in the particular circumstances prevailing in the aviation industry, much of the benefits that are thought to come from public ownership in the sector could still be achieved under private ownership.
Shortly after that decision was taken, the Government introduced the successful de-regulation of domestic aviation, which has seen unprecedented numbers of people flying at markedly reduced fares.

After a detailed `scoping study' of the various sales options open to it, the Government announced in April 1991 that the sale of each of Qantas and Australian Airlines would proceed on the basis of an initial `trade sale' process—thereby offering large prospective purchasers the chance to acquire a significant equity interest in either or both airlines, at a premium—followed by a public float to sell any remaining equity.
As a result of the respective sales processes, both airlines would be appropriately recapitalised and suitable employee share ownership schemes would also be introduced.

Subsequently, in the `One Nation' Statement made to Parliament by the Prime Minister on 26 February 1992, further far-reaching aviation reforms were announced. The Statement established the framework and timetable for removing the barriers between Australia's domestic and international aviation sectors, permitting multiple designation of Australia's international air services, and for developing a single aviation market with New Zealand.

The sale process involved submission of expressions of interest from prospective trade buyers, with indicative non-binding bids. From this it became clear that a number of prospective purchasers, as well as Qantas and Australian Airlines themselves, believed that substantial synergistic benefits and operational efficiency gains could be achieved if Qantas and Australian Airlines were to be combined into a single entity.

Accordingly, on 2 June 1992 the Government announced that Qantas would be permitted to acquire Australian Airlines for $400m, thus providing the best mechanism for quickly achieving the synergistic benefits offered by a link-up between the two airlines, to the overall financial advantage of taxpayers generally.

The Government also announced then that 100 per cent of the expanded Qantas Group would be sold—rather than 49 per cent, as originally decided—with the community's interests being protected by a number of national interest safeguards.

The artificial distinction between domestic and international aviation has largely been broken down. At the same time, Qantas has acquired a local aviation network and secured a strong domestic base for its international operations in future through the acquisition of Australian Airlines.

The Bill now before the House contains the legislative changes that need to be made to enable the sale of Qantas to be finalised, taking into account all possible outcomes, including the fact that varying levels of ownership could be sold during the current `trade sale' process prior to the ensuing public float next year.

The Bill also reflects key sale requirements relating to the national interest safeguards required with the sale of 100 per cent of Qantas, the recapitalisation of Qantas, the reconstruction of its debts in preparation for the impending change of ownership and the terms and conditions of employment for its staff.

The vast bulk of the Bill is concerned with the removal of both airlines from the ambit of a variety of Commonwealth legislation so that, post sale, the expanded Qantas Group will be treated the same as other private sector enterprises generally.

SPEECH.PARA: National Interest Safeguards

PARA.TAB: The fundamentals of the national interest safeguards, referred to earlier, need to be enshrined in legislation.

These safeguards are important to maintain the basic Australian character of Qantas as well as to ensure that Qantas' operating rights under Australia's various bilateral air service agreements and arrangements with other countries are not put under threat.
Once in legislation, these safeguards will not be subject to the whim of the Government of the day.

Thus, the Bill requires that Qantas' Articles of Association must contain provisions which will ensure that: Qantas' main operational base and headquarters remain in Australia; that the name of `Qantas' is preserved for the company's scheduled international passenger services; that the company be incorporated in Australia; that at least two-thirds of the Board of Qantas be Australian citizens; that the Chairman of the Board also be an Australian citizen; and, in particular, that total foreign ownership is not to exceed 35 per cent.
The Bill will also require Qantas' Articles to specify that no single foreign interest can exceed 25 per cent of the equity of Qantas.

Qantas' Articles will be required to provide Directors with wide powers to act, including to deny registration or to force the disposal of shares held by foreigners, to ensure the 35 per cent foreign ownership limit and the 25 per cent limit on single foreign interests are not breached.

The Bill requires that a restriction apply to any `block' shareholdings of foreigners representing more than 15 per cent of the voting shares in Qantas. All such foreign block holdings, either individually or in aggregate, will not be able to vote on more than one-third of Board members.

The Directors of Qantas have a clear commercial incentive, as well as a moral and legal duty, to adhere to the specific new Articles that the Bill requires. The Bill ensures that any attempt by shareholders to change the Articles required by the Bill can not have any effect.

In addition, specific provision is made in the Bill for the Minister for Transport and Communications to monitor the level of foreign ownership and control of Qantas in future—and to take appropriate legal action in the event that the stipulated national interest safeguards are breached or seem likely to be breached.

SPEECH.PARA: Debt and Capital Reconstruction

PARA.TAB: Consistent with the rationale for the sale of Qantas, the Bill provides the basis for the recapitalisation of Qantas.
It is important to note that the Government intends to remove the substantial amount of Commonwealth-guaranteed debt in Qantas' existing debt portfolio, prior to sale.

Apart from the important question of principle involved, the Commonwealth cannot countenance the possibility of it still being potentially liable for over a billion dollars of Qantas' debt once control of the airline shifts to the private sector. This would be tantamount to the Commonwealth retaining a major stake in the company despite its 100 per cent sale.
Only a small amount of the Commonwealth-guaranteed debt is able to be paid out up-front because it is in the form of widely held bearer bonds.

Thus, the Bill allows the Commonwealth to assume the obligations and to make all the necessary payments, including the payment of interest and the repayment of principal, associated with this debt as they become due and payable. It also appropriates the funds required to meet these obligations. At current exchange rates, the face value of the Commonwealth-guaranteed debt is about $1.1 billion and the associated interest payments total about $500m.
Qantas will pay the Commonwealth to assume this debt.

To enable Qantas to do this, the Bill provides sufficient appropriation for Qantas to receive a subscription to share capital from the Commonwealth of an amount at least equal to the face value of the debt to be taken over by the Government, at the exchange rates prevailing at the time of the debt assumption.

In fact, the Bill provides for a total appropriation of up to $1.4 billion to cover possible subscriptions to Qantas' share capital in order to allow for adverse movements in exchange rates between now and the time of assumption of the Commonwealth-guaranteed debt. It also provides scope for a separate share subscription to be made to Qantas for recapitalisation purposes should that be needed. This could conceivably involve discharging other Qantas debt as part of debt restructuring prior to sale.

Short-term Commonwealth guarantees are also allowed for in the Bill to cover possible contingencies, particularly in relation to the re-financing of the short term commercial paper program of Australian Airlines prior to a 100 per cent sale.

The Bill provides for a debt assumption of up to $300 million should it be considered necessary or desirable to neutralise any effect of the debt restructuring on the profit and loss account. This will cover the `worst case' scenario. At current exchange rates, the net loss to Qantas' profit and loss account would be less than $100m.

To the extent that the takeover of some of Qantas' debts by the Commonwealth—including any payment made to neutralise an undue effect on Qantas' profit and loss account—would result in an excessive recapitalisation of Qantas, a special `one-off' dividend payment or a refund of capital to the Commonwealth could be sought from Qantas before the sale is finalised.

Alternatively, if the net recapitalisation effect of the debt assumption by the Commonwealth is not sufficient, new Qantas shares could be sold (along with the Commonwealth's existing shares) or the general share subscription provisions in the Bill could be used to meet this need.

It is important to emphasise that any recapitalisation of Qantas that is effected by the Government during the sale process will be fully recouped in increased proceeds from the sale of the Commonwealth's equity in Qantas.
There will, therefore, be no net impact on the Budget from these debt and recapitalisation provisions over time.

SPEECH.PARA: Terms and Conditions of Employment

PARA.TAB: The Government is committed to the protection of all airline employees' rights which accrue during the period of Government ownership, especially in cases where these rights accrue as a result of Commonwealth legislation.

To this end, the Bill provides for a number of "savings" provisions in respect of a variety of Acts, such as the Long Service Leave (Commonwealth Employees) Act and the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation (CERC) Act. These provisions will ensure, in particular, that employees of Australian Airlines do not lose the benefits that they will have accrued prior to the sale of at least 50 per cent of Qantas.
In general, other rights not conferred by Commonwealth legislation will not be affected by the sale.

Regulations will be separately introduced under the Superannuation Act 1976 to ensure that employees of Australian Airlines who are currently members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme do not lose the superannuation benefits that they will have accrued under this scheme prior to the sale of 50 per cent of Qantas.
Necessary `savings' and `transitional' provisions relating to other Commonwealth Acts in respect of matters which are underway at the time of sale are also contained in the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: General Legislative Provisions

PARA.TAB: As part of the Government's commitment that Qantas should operate within a fully commercial environment as soon as possible, the airline is to be freed from all legislative constraints which apply generally to Commonwealth business enterprises, once a sufficient amount of equity in Qantas has been sold. Provisions for this are largely contained in the Schedule to the Bill.
Employee-related legislation aside, the proclamation to effect the cessation of such legislation will be made when sufficient equity in Qantas has been sold.
As noted previously, the application of special employee-related legislation to Qantas will not be removed until at least 50 per cent of its equity has been sold.
These provisions necessarily lead to special commencement arrangements. Details are contained in the Explanatory Memorandum.

Members should not be concerned on public accountability grounds at the prospect of the Commonwealth being in the position after the trade sale of retaining a majority shareholding in Qantas (pending the ensuing public float) but having removed most of the Government administrative controls and legislative provisions currently applying to Qantas as a Commonwealth Government business enterprise. For so long as the Government retains a majority shareholding in Qantas, it will require specific articles to be included in Qantas' articles of association in order to discharge its responsibility to the Australian public for its continuing, but transitory, majority ownership of Qantas.

The Government would in any event have the reserve power, which would only be exercised in very limited circumstances in the transitional period prior to full sale of using an ordinary resolution at a general meeting to protect the community's investment in Qantas in the lead-up to full sale.

SPEECH.PARA: Stamp Duty Exemptions

PARA.TAB: The sale of Qantas and, in particular, the anticipated public float could leave purchasers of equity in Qantas liable for certain State and Territory taxes.

In the absence of other action, this would depress the expected returns to all taxpayers throughout Australia from the sale of Qantas and benefit taxpayers in a particular State only. It would also complicate the sale process. To avoid these difficulties, the sale or issue of shares in Qantas and related transactions, as well as all transactions entered into in relation to the necessary debt and capital reconstruction of Qantas prior to sale are to be exempted from most State and Territory taxes and duties.

SPEECH.PARA: Conclusion

PARA.TAB: Mr President, this Bill puts in place a sound legislative framework for the sale of Qantas, against a background of major aviation reforms. It will enable the Government to cater for a number of possible eventualities and to finalise the sale of Qantas in due course in a manner which will maximise the financial advantages to taxpayers generally.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not got any further comments to add.

—I can only conclude that it was, as I said at the time, another example of the use that we have seen made over recent years of the Advance to the Minister for Finance for special payments to special States without public announcement. My understanding is that there has been no public announcement of that payment; I may be incorrect, but perhaps the honourable senator could direct me to where such a public announcement has been made—if it has—other than its being contained in the Budget Papers and buried with everything else.

—As we said at the time, it was made public in the Budget Papers and in the tabling of the AMF from time to time. It would have been made public in the appropriate tabling paper. Those are the two circumstances, as we outlined in the Committee.

—So there was no separate announcement of this payment. From what Senator McMullan is saying, I assume that one would have to look at the Budget Papers in detail or one would have to look at what for most people is a totally arcane document—the Advance to the Minister for Finance—and its surrounding documents. They do happen to get tabled in here but without any public coverage, other than people commenting on them as they wish when they are tabled. They are very poor substitutes, I would have thought, for public announcements of decisions of this nature involving taxpayers' money. Is Senator McMullan saying—and I think he is; I am just seeking his confirmation—that in addition to those inclusions of the payment there was no actual announcement of this decision?
—It means what I said.

—I will pursue this a little further. I wonder whether Senator McMullan feels that the procedures for the public disclosure of payments of this nature and, more generally, the use of the Advance to the Minister for Finance are sufficient to ensure that there is adequate public knowledge of decisions that are taken by the Government in these areas. We are, of course, talking about the use of taxpayers' funds, often a very considerable use. This one happened to be $17m; to most people that is a lot of money but there are many other decisions which are much larger than that. Is there the need or scope for a greater disclosure and, therefore, greater public accountability of the use of the AMF for these purposes? —If I understand the question correctly, and if I am being asked whether I am satisfied with the arrangements as they stand, yes.

—That is a fairly categoric answer. I just have to say that in my view and in the view of the coalition it certainly is not adequate. There ought to be much greater accountability and public disclosure of the use of public funds for this matter. Perhaps if there were a greater accountability we would not have seen the deals and other matters of a financial nature over recent years that have caused so much concern to the general community and to financial markets generally. That is an issue which will be taken up in other places and perhaps taken up here later today.

PARA.TAB: I direct Senator McMullan's attention to paragraphs 41 and 42 on pages 7 and 8 of the Committee's report. Paragraph 41 reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee raised the issue of AMF payments described as being for particular State purposes but actually being used for different purposes. The Department confirmed that there were cases documented over a number of years of this practice which it regarded as not a practice that either the Commonwealth or States would normally countenance.
We had some discussion on that yesterday. Paragraph 41 continues:

It indicated that the whole nature of accountability and responsibility was to ensure that the moneys appropriated for particular programs were spent on those programs. That provides the basis on which any subsequent evaluation or assessment of how well the program had performed would be based.
Paragraph 42 reads in part:

When questioned as to what sanctions could be taken, the Committee was informed that if there was an indication that moneys for particular purposes were not being spent, the relevant Minister would normally be advised when that information became available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, I am at some disadvantage about yesterday's discussion, because I was not here. It will not be an easy process to get all that information together, but that process is under way, as I understand it. My understanding—of course, it is second-hand—is that the information Senator Button is getting for Senator Short relates to a different question.

The first one was whether the moneys appropriated under Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4) have been expended yet. The second question on which I understood him to say he would attempt to provide data by this afternoon was on payments to States but used for other purposes. PARA.TAB: I do accept that it was a provision to be looked at this afternoon rather than this morning, although I did give notice that if this information were not available before the Department of Finance appropriations have been considered by this Committee I would wish to reserve my position as to the need to defer final approval of those appropriations until the information was available. TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is there is no prospect that the second lot of information will be available today. It will take longer. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just come back to paragraph 42, where, as I repeat, the paragraph says:

SPEECH.PARA: When questioned as to what sanctions could be taken, the Committee was informed—
by the Department of Finance—
that if there was an indication that moneys for particular purposes were not being spent,—
in that way—

TALK.START.PARA: —I think we discussed this. I would not swear it was this set of estimates with regard to this particular point—it may have been on a previous occasion. I am advised, and I have to say it is a cause of concern to me, though it is not something over which the Commonwealth has any control, that at least some of the State Auditors-General—who in my view should provide certification that the money has been spent in accordance with the requirements—have indicated that they are not prepared to do that. PARA.TAB: During an Estimates committee or two ago, I think Senator Short and I had a discussion about this. I find it unsatisfactory but that is the fact with which the Commonwealth has to deal. TALK.START.PARA: —So it would emerge in the monitoring by the Commonwealth departments. TALK.START.PARA: —I think this relates to one of the two outstanding questions on which I am seeking information, but let me just confirm that. The Department of Finance at the moment is doing a hunt to find examples, if any, going back over the last 10 or 20 years, of situations where payments made by the Commonwealth for one purpose, ostensibly, have been used for others. PARA.TAB: What I am now a little confused about is what seems to me to be a conflict between that situation and the advice which we received in the Estimates Committee and which is contained in the report, at paragraph 42, that the relevant Minister would normally be advised when that information became available. Is the Minister saying that there are no such examples of a Minister having been advised when information indicating a misspending or a changed spending of these funds has become available? TALK.START.PARA: —I may have had a bad night or something, but I have to say that I do not understand the logic that has been pursued through that rather tortuous question. I do not understand why Senator Short thinks it is unusual that one could say, `This is what the normal process would be for dealing with the problem, even if the problem has not arisen'. That is a fairly normal process of having decision making and administrative processes in place: `This is how one would deal with this problem if it arose'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I understand that, but Senator McMullan does not seem to quite understand my point in relation to paragraph 42 of the report, which is based on the discussions that we had in Estimates Committee B on 22 September. I understand the point he is making, but the report says—and I am sorry to have to repeat it again:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Committee was informed that if there was an indication that moneys for particular purposes were not being spent, the relevant Minister would normally be advised when that information became available.
Then the next sentence of the paragraph says:

An exchange of Ministerial correspondence indicating concern over the issue would be expected, probably resulting in debate over differing judgements as to why the particular funds were originally provided.

There does not seem to be in existence at the moment—certainly I am not able to be provided with it—one example to show that that is normal procedure. What I am saying is: either show me some examples that that is normal procedure or explain to me, in the absence of such examples, how one can possibly say that it is normal procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard of much ado about nothing, but of course one gets into trouble by quoting Shakespeare in this place, so I will not do it any further. But this is a classic example, if the Committee does not mind my saying so. As I understand it, a very senior officer who had a recollection of something which may have taken place a very long time ago, in seeking to provide information to the Estimates Committee, gave an indication of his or her recollection. For something to be normal, it means that that would be the expected procedure: that is how we would expect, in the normal course of events, a person to respond. It does not necessarily mean that this has happened on any particular number of occasions. It is the process that would be expected. If, in the summary of the evidence given to the Committee, the Committee itself, in summarising and providing that information, has used a word that is causing the honourable senator some confusion, that, I would have to say, is not my problem.

—Senator McMullan might have had a bad night last night—I do not know what he did last night—but, with great respect, he seems to be singularly obtuse this morning. What he is trying to say, it seems to me, is that there is no inconsistency between paragraph 42 of the report and the fact that he cannot actually give me examples—there was an allusion to one, but no material has been provided—to demonstrate the normality of the procedures that, according to paragraph 42, are purported to be normal. I understand that it is a very difficult problem because of the question of disclosure by State governments and the like.

PARA.TAB: I am not trying to buy a fight on that. I am simply trying to get at whether the procedures for financial management in this aspect of government are satisfactory or not. I would have to say that the evidence available and the discussions we have had to date raise some very considerable concerns with me, as I think the honourable senator has acknowledged. We have had similar types of discussions on other occasions and I think the honourable senator has himself acknowledged today that matters are not satisfactory in this area.

What I am trying to get clear is the basis for the wording in paragraph 42 of the report that there is any normal type of procedure available to ensure proper accountability of government use of taxpayers' money for payments in the area which we are now discussing. I would much prefer the honourable senator to accept the proposition, if this is the case, that there are in fact no normal procedures. For heaven's sake, he should tell us that. I accept the point because of the complexity, but it cannot be both ways. The honourable senator cannot have paragraph 42, which talks about the normal procedure, but at the same time not be able to give me one example of the application of the normal procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only thing I agree with the honourable senator about is that one of us is being obtuse. I really have nothing to add. It is better if we refer back to the original program in the Hansard rather than the Committee's summary. I am not criticising the Committee. It has done its best to summarise it accurately. I do not think there has been any attempt to mislead.

PARA.TAB: In making his comments, Mr Barrett was giving a general view about what would happen if an indication arose and what he would expect. That is outlined there. The only thing I would say with regard to the adequacy of the processes is that, to the extent that State Auditors-General do not provide certificates to the Commonwealth in the way that I would prefer, I think their procedures are deficient. The Commonwealth cannot resolve that so I think without that piece of information—and it is not a uniform problem, but it does arise from time to time—the Commonwealth has adequate second-line procedures to cope with it. It would be better if the States provided the audit certificates, but if they do not we cannot make them and we have an adequate second line of procedures whether it is AMF or otherwise. I have nothing else to add.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We both agree that there are some significant problems in this area and in ensuring proper accountability by State governments over the use of Commonwealth provided funds. We have seen that par excellence over recent years in my own State of Victoria with the financial disasters and scandals that have occurred there. Indeed, there was the absolutely incredible situation in the recent dying months of the Kirner Government where the Victorian Auditor-General was actually refused access, as is his legal entitlement, to the accounts of the various Victorian Government departments and agencies.

PARA.TAB: That is an example—a stark one but not an unusual one—of the absolutely disgraceful way in which the Victorian Labor Government under Joan Kirner mismanaged the finances of that State. I must say, on many occasions it used funds provided by the Commonwealth to the States. Therefore, `disgraceful' is probably too light a word to use for the mismanagement and misuse that was made by the Kirner Government of those funds.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me move just briefly, if I could, to paragraph 43 of the Committee's report, which simply says:
The Committee discussed at some length economic forecasting and figures contained in the Budget Papers relating to economic growth.

There is a Hansard reference—pages 135-141. I do not wish to pursue this at any great length here with the Department of Finance. It is probably more a matter for the Treasury. There was discussion of the economic growth figures, and the Department of Finance very helpfully provided material and estimates of GDP growth over the next few years. Those estimates that were provided were questioned—I guess that would be the right word, but `contradicted' might be a better word—by the Department of the Treasury when it gave evidence here in October before the Estimates Committee, not to any major extent in terms of difference between the growth estimates but there certainly were some differences between the two estimates.

PARA.TAB: I would like to ask Senator McMullan whether the figures provided by the Department of Finance during our hearings on 22 September are still figures to which the Department adheres, or were those figures, in fact, incorrect in so far as the Government's forecasts were concerned and were the Treasury figures the correct ones in the Government's assessment.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short says correctly, this is a matter we should pursue in the Department of the Treasury. In fact, I think we caused a slight problem for ourselves by bending over backwards to try to provide information through this Department when we should properly have refused and said, `No, let us raise it under the Treasury heading'. In an endeavour to be cooperative, the officer concerned did some calculation derived from the Budget Papers and said quite clearly, `If you do these computations from these documents you get this answer'. That is an accurate arithmetic process, but the figures were not designed to be alternative forecast figures to those of the Treasury. They were merely providing information to the Committee about the outcome of certain computations in which members had expressed some interest.

PARA.TAB: The economic forecasting figures and the basis for them were provided by Treasury and are in the normal course provided by Treasury, and the detailed discussion of them should arise in relation to that Department. We really had somebody bending over backwards to help here and providing, as I say, simply some arithmetic calculations for the Committee, which we were grateful for but into which we should not try to read things that do not fit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that. I certainly publicly acknowledge here that the Department of Finance was attempting to be as helpful as possible and, in this particular instance, was bending over backwards to provide the Committee with material and with forecast estimates. What concerns me, though, is the implication behind that. Again, this is a matter we have discussed on other occasions, but I would like to see whether there have been any developments since it was last discussed in detail, which, I think, was a year or so ago. I refer to the implication that the Department of Finance does not have access to the forecasts that the Treasury does in so far as, in this case, the GDP forecasts are concerned.

PARA.TAB: We have had similar examples in other years. We found out last year that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, I think it was, was devising what it termed its own `crude modelling' because there was not access to the material available within the Treasury on forecasting. I accept, as I say, that the Department of Finance was doing this in an effort to help—and it was very helpful—but does it, in fact, show that there is any lack of necessary exchange of data and, particularly, forecasts between Treasury and Finance which led to this situation in the first instance?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am sorry for the delay, but I wanted to pursue a point in somewhat more detail because we have two circumstances here which, if run together, might create a misleading impression. Because it is not a Department of Finance responsibility, the officer before the Committee on the day did not have that data before him at that time. I refer to the Treasury assessments. In making the decisions and determining the figures on the outlay side which, on behalf of the Department of Finance, go into various Government documents, particularly the Budget, officers do have access to all the Treasury information that is necessary to provide that information accurately.

PARA.TAB: I do not suppose there have ever been two entities that had to communicate with each other that would say they never had a problem in the process of communication. Normal human constraints would apply to any two organisations working together. Two individuals, whether they happen to be front bench members of the same party, members of the same sporting organisation or whatever, will always have the potential for some communication problem. I do not want to paint the picture that any situation within a department or between departments can be perfect but, subject to those human constraints, the information that the Department requires in order to provide accurate information in the Budget is provided by Treasury on all occasions, and that is the basis on which the material goes into the Budget. It was not material that the Department of Finance had available to provide to the Committee in Estimates hearings, for the reason we have discussed, which is that it is not actually the responsibility of the Department of Finance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take it from what Senator McMullan is saying that, leaving the human factors aside, the procedural arrangements for the necessary exchange of information between the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance are, in his view and therefore presumably in the Department's view, satisfactory and that there are no areas where there is a need, so far as the Department of Finance is concerned, for improvement in terms of the access to Treasury and material provided by Treasury. Can Senator McMullan confirm that that is what he is saying?
—That is my understanding.

—It is getting on for a couple of months since we had the Estimates hearing with the Department of Finance, which was on 22 September. Is the Department in a position at this stage to provide any more updated information as to the forecasts for expenditure—for which it has responsibility—for the 1992-93 financial year in the light of the fact that we are now more than a third of the way through the year? I presume the Department constantly monitors the figures. Is it in a position to be proposing revisions to those figures, and, if so, in which areas?

—The only information in the course of regular provision of such information, I think, is at the moment in the category of advice from the Department to the Minister. There is nothing I can provide publicly to Senator Short with regard to that.
—Is the expenditure pattern for this year to date, on the figures that are available, in line with the expectations of expenditure at the time of the Budget?
—I regret to say that I think that is covered by my previous answer: there is nothing I can provide on that.

—I think the first answer was in response to a more disaggregated or detailed question. This is more an aggregated question to which the first answer may not equally apply. Is Senator McMullan saying that he is unable to tell the Senate whether the pattern of expenditure to date, in this financial year, is in line with the Budget Estimates for this year?

—I do not want to get technical. I will give such information as I can but I do not think this is really the forum for it. If this is taken literally, I do not think there is actually a reservation that covers this area; I do not want to pursue that technicality, however, on the assumption that we are not going to discuss this matter for very long. I have to be very general. Such information as there is, is in the nature of advice from the Department to the Minister and therefore is not something that would be provided in any forum, Estimates committee or otherwise, reservation or otherwise. My understanding is that in the generality it is on track but I do not want to go any further.

—On the present pattern and expected pattern of expenditure—and, for that matter, revenue, but in this case expenditure—when is it anticipated that the Supply Bills Nos (1), (2), (3) and (4) will run out? In other words, in the absence of the passage of these Appropriations Bills, how far will Supply take the normal funding of government?

—That is always very difficult to predict precisely. We have discussed the unpredictable nature of the calls to some extent; I do not want to create a sense of crisis either. Notwithstanding that there was a year in which somebody thought 11 November was the year in which critical decisions had to be made because otherwise Supply would run out—but that person was wrong for other reasons as well—I do not think there is—
—The Australian public did not think so.
—I think it did. It made a decision on another matter also which I regret but which it was entitled to make, but I do not think it was endorsement of the dreaded Sir John, late and unlamented—
—Highly respected knowledge, Sir John.

—Sir John Kerr has the capacity to arouse passions even in regard to the Department of Finance estimates. That is another negative legacy of his, and there are many. I apologise, Mr Chairman, for dragging in an aside but surely you cannot blame me for finding it very hard to resist. I promise not to raise Sir John again. I do not want to create an air of crisis—I do not think there is a problem tomorrow or next week—provided the Senate passes the Appropriations today, as I understand is its intention, we will all be okay.

—I understand it is the Government's wish that the Appropriations be passed today. We will see how things go. If they are not passed today, when does the fact that the Appropriation Bills have not been passed become a major problem for the funding of government?
—Quite honestly, I do not think that this falls within the Committee's report but, if Senator McMullan wishes to comment, he may do so.

—Mr Chairman, with respect, I think it does. At least in my view, it does, because I think it relates very much to the question of the Budget forecasts for this year as far as the expenditure side is concerned, and that is the responsibility of the Department of Finance. We also had lengthy discussions in the Estimates Committee, which were repeated to a much lesser degree yesterday, in relation to Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4) which add to the Supply capacity of the Government. We are still in the dark as to why those Supply Bills were actually required. One of the ways of taking us out of the dark on that would be for us to have more information than is available now on how far the existing Supply will carry the Government. So, with respect, Mr Chairman, I think it is relevant and it is covered in the Committee's report and the reservation.
—Senator Short, you have not convinced me, but I said that I would allow Senator McMullan to respond if he wished.
—I think your ruling is right, Mr Chairman. I do not intend to hide behind that but I have nothing to add.
—When is the next Public Service payday?
—I know when mine is.
—Everybody who lives in Canberra should know that. I did not, but I am advised it is Thursday of next week.
—That is 19 November. Am I right in presuming that Supply is available to meet that payday?
—I expect so. As I say, I am not trying to paint a picture of crisis. I do expect that that would be possible.

—The next Public Service payday after that would be 3 December. Do the Supply provisions cover the 3 December payday as well? When Supply was being estimated earlier in the year, was it planned to do so?
—We could go right through until 31 December.

—With respect to Senator Short, he is not going to get in small bits what I was not prepared to give him in a large lump. So I really do not have anything to add to whether it will or not. That is a matter that is a bit too far ahead to project and there are too many variables. But, no, I do not think it was intended so to do.

—As I understand it, when the amounts to be included in the Supply Bills are being estimated in March, April and May of the previous financial year, instructions are given to departments as to how far down the track and as to which Public Service paydays ought to be taken into account when calculating their Supply requirements. I presume those instructions are not secret. What instructions were given?

—I can actually answer that. I think my recollection is accurate about the information we gave on Supply Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 4). They were predicated on the passage of the Appropriations before the end of November. I am advised that Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2) did include meeting the pay of 3 December in their calculations.

—Is there any indication at the moment as to whether the Supply Bills will not carry the Government through for the period on which the original Supply forecasts were based? In other words, is there any suggestion that the 3 December payday would not be met in the unlikely event that the Appropriations were not passed by then?

—Senator Short, you are testing the patience of the Chair. I am not worried about Senator McMullan. You are testing the patience of the Chair because I have had a look and I do not believe that this matter is covered in the report of Estimates Committee B nor do I believe it is covered in the reservations. I am prepared to allow the questions to continue, but I think under the circumstances the questions should not go very much further.

—I do not have anything to add. I knew there was a payday on 3 December when I said there were too many variables to predict that far ahead. I still know there are too many variables. I cannot predict and I do not think it is properly before us.

—I do not want to pursue it much longer. On the basis of what Senator McMullan has said, my understanding is that Supply Bill (No. 1) and Supply Bill (No. 2), which are the essential Bills, were formulated on the basis of Supply running beyond the 3 December payday. What Senator McMullan has said in response to other questions this morning does not lead me to any conclusion that the Budget figures are sufficiently off target to imply that the 3 December payday could not be met. So my conclusion from Senator McMullan's comments to us this morning, for which I thank him, is that the passage of Supply would cover beyond the payday of 3 December. From his previous comments, he is not going to comment any further on that. That seems to me to be the inescapable conclusion from the comments he has made. I thank him for them.

—I have some questions relating to the local capital works program on which a reservation has been made. Can I draw attention to an article which appeared on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Prior to making that comment, in view of the comments Senator McMullan made about Sir John Kerr, I would like to say that the views that Senator McMullan and some of his colleagues have on Sir John Kerr are certainly not shared on this side of the chamber. I personally regard Sir John Kerr as a very great Australian and I have the greatest confidence that history will record and mark the courage of this great Australian, Sir John Kerr. I am sorry the persecution of Sir John Kerr has continued on some 17 years, even after his death. I think it is a very sad thing that a man who acted in good faith, who did what he saw to be his duty, should have been subjected to such constant and unceasing attacks. Senator McMullan is a man who at times has shown he can rise above the party line. I think it is a pity that he has stooped to take a cheap shot at a man whom I regard as a very great Australian. I wish to record that in the Hansard. I am sorry it was raised by Senator McMullan, particularly in view of the current issue on loans affairs. We had a loans affair in 1975 and we have a loans affair today, and it is a great pity that Senator McMullan has drawn that issue in.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Kemp, we are discussing the local capital works program.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wanted to respond to an earlier remark that Senator McMullan made which was the sort of remark that we are concerned about on this side of the chamber. We are not going to allow that sort of comment to go unchallenged. Now I draw Senator McMullan's attention to a story which appeared on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald today, which is headed `Govt settles for quick fix on jobs'. This refers, as he will know, to the lack of progress that has been made under the One Nation statement and the apparent approach of the Government to attempt to funnel more of these funds into the local capital works program which we are discussing here. I wonder whether the Parliamentary Secretary has seen that story and whether it is correct in its assessment that the Government will be spending more on these local capital works programs as a result of the problems which have emerged in the One Nation statement, particularly in relation to the major capital works programs on the railway.
—I am not about to make an announcement about Government policy here.
—Is it correct that the forecast spending under the major capital works program of One Nation is not on target and, in fact, is substantially under target?
—The senator should ask whoever represents the Minister for Transport.
—Is it correct that the Government will be spending more on its local capital works program?

—That is a policy matter which, if it has been decided—as reported by the Sydney Morning Herald—I cannot confirm for reasons that we are all familiar with. I am not a party to that decision. But if there has been such a decision, the Prime Minister or the Minister responsible will announce it in the appropriate place—and this is not it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I say I do not think the appropriate place is the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald. The story by Bernard Lagan clearly is a very well sourced story. It appears that some of Senator McMullan's colleagues have already announced it to the public. I wonder whether the Parliament could have the courtesy of being informed whether there is substance to this story, which relates directly to the local capital works program. I say `directly' because the money which is going to be spent as a result of the failure of yet another element of the One Nation program will be funnelled, according to this story, into the local capital works program. So it is directly on the issue; it is before the chamber at this very moment; the Parliamentary Secretary is in the chamber; the advisers are here. The issue has been announced in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning. Could the Parliament not be informed whether the Government will be spending more on the local capital works program than was forecast in the Budget? Could I have a clear statement on that, please?
—No.

—I do not know what one can do. Apparently the announcement has been made on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald and has been sourced to the Government. We learn, quite dramatically, that the capital works program in relation to the railways has collapsed, by and large, and—Madam Temporary Chair, you will be particularly interested in this—Government sources can speak to Bernard Lagan but Government sources cannot tell honourable senators in the chamber. However, for the benefit of the Parliamentary Secretary, I read the relevant part of this article:

PARA.TAB: Government sources confirmed last night that a major reason for the lagging of the rail spending was the cost blow-out in the plan to build a dedicated freight line from Campbelltown to Enfield in Sydney's inner-west.
The cost of the project, estimated in One Nation at $71 million, has jumped to $250 million and it has now been deferred.

SPEECH.PARA: Earlier in the article, Bernard Lagan tells us:

PARA.TAB: It is expected that the Government will announce this week that at least $50 million in One Nation funds intended for major rail projects will instead by spent on immediately boosting subsidies paid to employers who hire the long-term jobless.
As much as $50 million more, also from funds intended for major railway projects, will be diverted to local councils for spending on quick projects to ease unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: These are Government sources. The Government has a senior Parliamentary Secretary in the chamber at the moment. The Government has briefed Bernard Lagan but apparently it has not briefed Senator McMullan. Is that correct? Senator McMullan has not been briefed about this?

TALK.START.PARA: —The first source of this good advice, I am sure, goes back a long way. Senator Kemp should not believe everything he reads in the newspaper.
—Is the article by Bernard Lagan wrong?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—There is no answer to that question, Senator Kemp.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the article by Bernard Lagan correct?
—I do not have anything to add to whether it is right, wrong or otherwise, but it is not a matter about which any announcement will be made by me at any time, and certainly not in the Committee.

—I accept that Senator McMullan apparently does not know about this. Whereas we may differ on major political issues, I am not a man to doubt Senator McMullan's word, so I assume he does not know. Can I politely suggest that Senator McMullan turn to his advisers, who are in the box, and ask them whether the front page article by Bernard Lagan in the Sydney Morning Herald is correct. Then we can move on.

—I have not said whether I knew or not. I said I have no intention of making an announcement about it here, and that remains the case. It does not matter how many times Senator Kemp asks, that will remain the case. His colleague Senator Teague will come running in soon and raise a point of order with Senator Kemp about tedious repetition.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Kemp, I think Senator McMullan has more or less put his case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think he has put any case at all, with respect.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—In other words, I do not think he will provide you with any further information.

TALK.START.PARA: —The ruling from you, as usual, Madam Temporary Chair, has much wisdom. I think it probably is correct that we will not get any more out of Senator McMullan on that issue. However, could Senator McMullan indicate how the current spending is progressing under the local capital works program? Has all the money been allocated? This is the nub question, while Senator McMullan is with his advisers: can he indicate how many jobs have been created?

—That is properly a question for the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The officers do not have that information, but I know that at least one round of announcements has been made, and at that stage—and this is quite some time ago—letters had been sent offering contracts to the various local authorities to implement those round one announcements. So I know that that stage was reached, but that is the last time I had any information, and that was made public at the time. It might even have been when the Estimates Committee was meeting or on another occasion. Beyond that, on that level of detail about the administration of a program and its consequences, it is not a Department of Finance program, it is a Department of Local Government program.
—But I think the Department of Finance can tell us whether the spending under that program is on target. I think it is possible to obtain that information.

—It just seems palpably stupid to have a lengthy review about something that can better be done in detail somewhere else. I am happy to give what information I can, but it will not be very helpful, and I have a terrible feeling we will do it all again somewhere else. My understanding is that in so far as the Department of Finance is advised about expenditures that are not its direct responsibility—Senator Kemp is right that ultimately the payments are made by Finance as the custodians of the money—when last reported, the program was on track in terms of expenditures. In terms of outcomes, Senator Kemp will have to ask elsewhere, of course, because it is not a Finance responsibility.

—I suppose that all of us are a little concerned, in view of this report on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald which we cannot discuss any more because Government sources can speak to the press but they cannot speak to us. Can Senator McMullan give the Committee an assurance that the failure of the Government's major capital works program—one could almost say the virtual collapse of the major capital works program—will not in some ways be matched by a failure of administration in relation to the local capital works program? Can the Parliamentary Secretary give us an assurance that, as far as the Government is concerned, that program is fully on target and the Government does not anticipate any problems either with the quality of the projects or the total overall spending?

—I have no intention of pursuing Senator Kemp's ramblings about railway expenditure. If he wants to ask the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins), I am sure he is perfectly capable of coming in and doing that, assuming that somebody has made a relevant reservation where it is appropriate.

PARA.TAB: My advice, in so far as it relates to the Department of Finance, which is to a very limited extent—it mainly relates to the Office of Local Government within the relevant Department—is that the program is proceeding as envisaged and is on track. There is nothing further to say. If Senator Kemp wants the detail, he will have to ask somewhere else. If he wants to invent other facts about it and make assertions and seek to have me comment on them, I will not.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Kemp, perhaps you will be able to further investigate that when these other estimates come before the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to conclude, I did not plan to get up and speak again, but Senator McMullan seems to be getting more and more tetchy about this subject. I wish to record that it is not a matter of my ramblings about the major capital works program in relation to railways. All I am doing is reading Bernard Lagan's story, which is apparently sourced to Government Ministers. All I wanted to do was to seek some guidance on that. I have not received guidance; all I have got is some rather tetchy comments from the Parliamentary Secretary.

PARA.TAB: On the specific issue of the local capital works program I did make a reservation. I am rather surprised that the Minister and the officers here—I do not wish to draw on the officers because the Minister is clearly not all that willing to consult with them in detail about this program—do not have the information on hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following on from Senator Kemp's reservation, I would like to ask a couple of questions of my own on local government capital works. The sort of reply that Senator McMullan has been giving to Senator Kemp is the standard reply one gets from a hospital when one rings up to see how someone is going. One is told, `As well as can be expected'. I refer to the allocations for local government capital works in Western Australia. I would like to know—because, after all, the Department of Finance holds the key to the bank in the final analysis—how the programs are going. Are they all going fairly evenly? For instance, there is finance allocated to the city of Stirling—an effort to save the Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives. The allocations to local government there were made in direct proportion to the margin that Labor members held. Is the finance flowing to those projects evenly, or is it accelerated—for want of a better word—in places like the city of Stirling?

—Senator Kemp's reservation with regard to the local capital works program cannot make those things which are not the responsibility of the Department of Finance the responsibility of the Department of Finance. It is a legitimate reservation in so far as it relates to Finance's responsibility with regard to this matter. I have indicated on a couple of occasions that, in so far as it is the responsibility of the Department of Finance, which is to make a bulk payment to the Office of Local Government to meet its requirements under this program, the expenditure is proceeding essentially as expected when the program was originally envisaged.

PARA.TAB: With regard to particular projects, to the extent which any Commonwealth agency has the information—and I suppose they have, but I am not responsible and do not know—it will be the Office of Local Government, whose estimates are still to come before us. It is up to Senator Panizza whether he wishes to pursue it with those people. They will know what information they can provide. All I can provide on behalf of the Department of Finance is the information which it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the bulk allocation of finance from the Department of Finance for local government done when the programs start—and then sits in the coffers of the Office of Local Government—or it is done as the jobs are acquitted?

—The payments of the Department of Finance are paid in response to advice from the Office of Local Government in accordance with contracts it has entered into with local authorities. But certainly at the moment there is not any information I can provide for the honourable senator about particular projects. I do not understand why Senator Panizza is trying to pursue it in this very circuitous way here when there is a department that is actually responsible to come before us. I am happy to provide what information I can. There is no secret about it. I cannot tell the honourable senator about particular projects, but the scheme overall as far as I know is going quite well. It is doing what it was intended to do, which is creating jobs for Australians. So I am very pleased about it. But if the honourable senator wants to know detail, this is the wrong place. I cannot provide it to him. This is not the department that has it. It is a very back-door method of trying to get detailed information.
—At present I am getting detail of the mechanics and not of how that particular program is going.

—Senator Panizza, I am not quite sure whether I can be helpful, but under this reservation you cannot get details of how individual projects are going. You would have to ask for that through the appropriate department, and Finance is not the appropriate department.

—Mr Chairman, I think for once you have misunderstood what I am asking for. I said that I was pursuing detail of the mechanics of the way the Department of Finance hands over finance to the Office of Local Government and then on to local government projects.
—That certainly was your last question. I thought you were reverting to the former.

—It is not to be confused with what I asked before. The Minister told me that finance flows to the Office of Local Government as per contracts. I ask further: does the Finance total amount—lump sum—to cover the contract go immediately to the Office of Local Government, or does it go to local government when the job is acquitted, or completed?

—I do not have all the details here. If Senator Panizza wants some more detail and lets me know what it is I will try to find it for him. My recollection, which is confirmed by the officers, is that the general nature of the contracts is that, once the project is approved and the necessary contracts entered into, some payment is made virtually immediately. If my recollection is correct, there are then two other payments during the course of the project.
