I do not have immediately available to me information about what triggers from the Office of Local Government an indication that the subsequent stages of payments under the contracts are appropriate to be paid. It would have some internal procedure for doing that. I do not have it immediately available to me. But there is a series of payments. It is not all paid at the end. There is a payment at the beginning and, I think, two other stages of payments.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary for that reply. I am not asking him what the Office of Local Government is doing. I am still pursuing what the Department of Finance does. The Secretary did say that the Department of Finance puts forward some upfront money, for want of a better term, with the contract. I ask again: when further payments are needed, does each payment go back to the Department of Finance?
—I am not sure I understand Senator Panizza's question. Is he asking whether the Office of Local Government has to come back to the Department of Finance for each stage of the payments?
—Yes, that is my question.
—Yes, that is my understanding. Not on a project by project basis, but in a bulk way. Senator Panizza should put down all the information he wants in writing and I will get it for him.

—Having said that the Office of Local Government comes back to the Department of Finance each time it needs project money as contracts are proceeded with, why is the Department of Finance not in a position to tell me what stage it is at regarding spending this local government grant money?

—I cannot remember how many questions ago it was—it seems a lot to me at the moment—that I indicated that it is not funded on a project by project basis to the Office of Local Government. There are bulk payments made in response to the contracts that the Office of Local Government has been authorised to enter into. There would be a number of them. It would have the detailed information, not the Department of Finance. If there is any further information I can get that would be helpful, I would be happy to provide it.

—I thank the Parliamentary Secretary. We have now ascertained that money goes from the Department of Finance to the Office of Local Government, as requested, in bulk by the Office of Local Government. Can the Parliamentary Secretary, representing the Department of Finance, tell me what percentage of that total allocation has been paid out? It is a simple, straightforward question.

—The information is publicly available. We can get it for Senator Panizza and provide it but I do not have it with me and the officers do not have it here at the moment. There is no big crisis about providing it; I will seek it and provide it to Senator Panizza when I get it.
—When can I expect to get it?
—Very shortly after I do.
—With respect, I thought that was a rather smart alec answer. I still ask: can I have a definite time when I can have that figure?

—I do not see any problem making the information available today, but the problem is that I do not absolutely know what is involved in getting it, so I am not going to give Senator Panizza a definitive answer as some indication of my view when I do not have all the data. At the moment it does not seem that there should be a particular delay and I should be able to get it to him today, but if there is a problem I will let him know during the day.

—I wish to follow up some of the questions that Senator Kemp asked earlier, although they are of a slightly different nature. I understand that Senator McMullan will neither confirm nor deny, apparently, the Bernard Lagan article in the Sydney Morning Herald this morning which says that key Ministers have taken a decision that the spending and job targets set out by the Government in One Nation to build roads and railways have fallen seriously behind. That does not surprise me; everything in One Nation seems to have fallen seriously behind in some shape or form.

PARA.TAB: The question I want to put to Senator McMullan is in relation to the procedures and finances of government. If the story is correct, at least $50m which had been intended for major rail projects will be spent instead on immediately boosting subsidies paid to employers who hire the long term jobless. Another $50m will be switched from major railway projects to local councils. An extra $40m will be switched from road construction to fixing highway accident black spots. As well, there appears to be a switch to boost spending on the repair of heritage buildings so that make-work jobs can also begin there quickly. It goes on in terms of switching funds from one stated purpose to another.

I want to ask the Parliamentary Secretary about the funds allocated for these rail projects. What is the procedure, in terms of financial administration, for switching those funds to totally different purposes, as outlined in this article?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I ask Senator McMullan to respond, I ask Senator Short on what reservation or part in the report he is basing his question.

—It is under several issues, including the area of economic forecasting and economic growth figures. These are matters set out in the report itself. To some extent, it is under Senator Kemp's reservation regarding the local capital works program. There are others as well.
—I have my doubts, but if Senator McMullan has anything to add, I will let him do so.

—I think it is outrageously outside the material we have before us. It is just a fishing expedition, as if we had nothing better to do with our time. I only have the most general of things to say because I will not comment on whether the story is right or wrong. If there is to be a transfer of government money from one purpose to another, it depends on the nature of the original appropriation for the first purpose and the appropriation for the second purpose as to whether money can be transferred without the requirement of further legislation. Some would require legislation; some would not. It depends upon the terms of the original appropriation and the terms of the legislation which underpins the purpose for which the moneys were to be transferred. That is a statement in the generality, but I have no intention of commenting on any particular proposals that some journalist has hypothesised about, particularly when I think it is not properly before us.

—Before I ask whether there are any further matters in relation to program 1, I would like to point out to the Committee that I have a responsibility to guide these Estimates through the Committee. We have completed consideration of the report of Estimates Committee A and we are now on Estimates Committee B, but we still have to consider Estimates committees C, D, E and F. I would like to ask honourable senators to be specific in directing the matters that they wish to have raised to the actual reservations or the matters in the report. Are there any further matters in relation to program 1?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand your comments, Mr Chairman. I believe, for the reasons that I have just outlined, that this relates to matters in the report. It relates, amongst other things, to the discussions we were having earlier this morning about the use of Commonwealth moneys for programs for which they were originally intended. It also relates to the whole question of financial management, which is covered quite specifically in the Committee's report. Perhaps it is in the next program, but it relates to the whole question of resource management framework in program 2. If you like, Mr Chairman, I will take it up under that. It is quite clear that the point that I want to make—I do not want to belabour it too much—is relevant to the report.

PARA.TAB: I understand Senator McMullan's refusal to confirm or deny the report in the Sydney Morning Herald. Following the helpful comments he has provided in response to the last question, if funds are to be switched from a major rail project to quite different purposes—job creation schemes in other areas or other departments, many of which would be under DEET—or if funds are to be switched from rail projects to the repair of heritage buildings, et cetera, what is the provision and the scope for that switching to occur? Would not new legislation be required? I am trying to determine the extent to which these funds can be switched.

I think that is a very important question because, as Senator McMullan may or may not be aware, the unemployment figures for October have just been released. They show that unemployment has now jumped to 11.3 per cent, an increase of one-half of one per cent since September, the highest rate ever recorded by the survey. We have a situation where the trend estimate of the unemployment rate continues to increase—it increased further this month—and where the trend estimates of full time employment continue to decrease.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short, can you get on to your question?

—What the Government is apparently talking about is switching funds to try to get a few of these unemployed people off the books via quick make-work schemes. What I want to know is: what are the requirements that the Government would have to fulfil to enable the—
—Senator Kemp, I would advise you to read standing order 185, paragraph (3).
—I am sorry if I was disturbing you, Mr Chairman.

PARA.TAB: On a point of order, Mr Chairman, I draw your attention to the gentleman standing up there at the back, and I ask why you chose to single out me, who was not talking at all, and did not speak to your colleague on your right hand side.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because I saw, Senator Kemp, that you were in breach of the Standing Orders.
—Very selective; very selective indeed.
—You will withdraw that remark, Senator Kemp. That is a reflection on the Chair.
—Can I seek your guidance—
—You will withdraw the remark.
—The—
—Senator Kemp, you will withdraw the remark.
—The remark is withdrawn. If I could please speak, I will withdraw it.
—No, I am asking you to withdraw it.
—I have withdrawn it.
—Right. Now take your seat.
—I take a point of order.
—What is your point of order?

—Can I seek your guidance as to why you chose to single me out when one of the Labor senators was in exactly the same position, doing precisely the same as I was doing, but happened to be talking, and he was not singled out?
—Because I did not see him. I saw you because you are on my left and my attention was drawn to Senator Short, who was speaking at the time. I call Senator Jones.
—Just on the point of order, Mr Chairman: Senator Maguire was standing around where the advisers stand and I think it is quite legitimate for a senator to talk to an adviser in that area.
—I do not know what he was doing because I did not see him. I call Senator Short.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I was drawing attention to the tragic increase in unemployment that has occurred in October, to the highest rate ever recorded by surveys in Australia—
—What is your question?

—If Senator Tate would just allow me, I will get to that. I do not need his help on that. It is a postwar record of 11.3 per cent, with unemployment trend estimates continuing upwards and with the trend estimates for full time—
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman, can I draw your attention to Senator Jones and Senator Faulkner, who were standing up talking?
—Yes, you may. I call Senator Short.
—On a point of order, on what grounds then did you speak to me and choose not to speak to those two gentlemen?
—Senator Kemp, if you continue to be insolent towards the Chair, I will deal with you. I call Senator Short.

—I was pointing out that the trend estimates for full time employment have continued to decrease. The Government seems now to be in a massive panic mode because it has not been able to get its projects for major rail funding off the ground. As I understand it, there has not been one new job created as a result of these much vaunted, but never on, One Nation statements. Instead, the Government is proposing, apparently, to divert funds from those earlier announced projects into quick-fix schemes of the most dubious nature. I ask Senator McMullan: what are the legislative requirements that will be involved in enabling such a diversion and switching of funds to occur?
—I do not think it is in the reservations.

—Mr Chairman, I do not wish to dispute your rulings but, with respect, we are talking here about the core of the activities of the Department of Finance, which is Government expenditure. I find it absolutely incredible that Senator McMullan refuses to answer questions which go to the whole core, to the essence, of the department whose appropriations we are considering. It is all about financial management. It is all about the use of taxpayers' funds. It is all about whether a government, because it cannot manage to get one project off the ground and employ one more person, is able, without major constraints and at will, suddenly to switch funds from that project to areas absolutely divorced from that original purpose of the funding. There must be, presumably, legislative requirements involved in that. What I am asking, as a question of very considerable importance indeed, is: what is required for that to be achieved, if indeed that is the Government's purpose, as it appears to be?
—I cannot find anything in the reservations, Senator Short, nor in the report which covers the question you are asking. Are there any further matters in relation to program 1?
—Yes. I draw your attention, Mr Chairman, to paragraph 43 of the Committee's report. Paragraph 43 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee discussed at some length both economic forecasting and figures contained in the Budget Papers relating to economic growth.

This matter is all about economic growth, because the Government claimed in its One Nation statement that it was allocating funds to a whole range of projects—unfunded, I might say—including, in particular, one of its showpiece announcements in relation to One Nation, the major projects relating to the rail system in Australia. That is an essential part of the item covered by paragraph 43.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question being asked does not have anything to do with economic growth; it has to do with something else, therefore it is not in order.

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I wonder whether I could put to you the question of why expenditure on major rail projects, which the Government said in February this year is all about economic growth, is not in your view about economic growth?

—Your question was not about economic growth; your question was about switching finances from one area to another, and that has nothing to do with economic growth. It might be as a result of economic growth, but the matter in the report spoke about economic growth, not the results of economic growth.

—Let me then phrase my question in a slightly different way. If the Government is unable to spend the money on the major rail projects to the extent that it had budgeted for this year and which it had trumpeted in its One Nation statement and on which its economic growth forecasts for this year were importantly based, if that expenditure is not going to occur, what impact will that have on economic growth this year and what impact will it therefore have on the expenditure side of the Budget?

—That also does not relate to paragraph 43. When we actually dealt with that reservation we correctly dealt with the issues that were raised, which were the nature of the figures that were provided by Finance and their status. They were the matters that were dealt with. The answer to the question is not necessarily any.
—Did I hear Senator McMullan correctly when he said that the inability of the Government to spend funds—

—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman. In my view, the original question was out of order and therefore it is not possible for a follow-up question to be in order. There is nothing in these reservations that goes to the question of the process of the allocation and transfer of money, nor is there anything about the general question of the Government's economic performance because, to the extent that there is any department that questions can be asked about, it is Treasury.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short is trying to tag it on to paragraph 43 of the Committee's report, which is merely a description of some questions Senator Short asked and to which the officer responded. They relate to the way in which certain figures were calculated and the relationship with certain figures provided by the Treasury. It in no way opens up the whole question of the meaning of life, the nature of economic growth, or what would happen if certain hypothetical concerns that Senator Short raised might or might not be correct. It is in no way properly before us and therefore a supplementary question following up on it cannot be properly before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I am concerned, the last couple of questions have been out of order. Let us try another one, Senator Short.

—I really do find it quite extraordinary that Senator McMullan is trying to hide under the cloak of technicality in this Committee to prevent legitimate questions being asked on the whole question of the financing of government and government expenditure when, for the major time this year, we have the Department of Finance in front of us in this chamber.

—Order! Senator Short, we could ask all sorts of questions in relation to the economy, economic forecasting, economic growth, but what we have to do in this Estimates procedure is confine our remarks to the parts in the report which highlight areas of concern and to the reservations. One cannot use those as a bridge to go even further than what is in the reservations or in the report, and that is what is being done at the present time. I would ask you to confine your remarks to those reservations and to the parts in the report. The parts in the report, of course, do not necessarily mean that what went on during the Estimates Committee was in order either. In some of those cases, those parts in the report cannot be used. I have allowed them to be used so far, but I am not going to allow them to be used to such an extent that we have an extended debate about all matters relating to the Department of Finance. That is not the role of this Committee at all.
—I do not want to protract this unduly but it is a very important matter. Let me just ask, if I may, a couple more questions.
—It might be an important matter but it has to be an important matter in relation to the report and the reservations.

—I asked earlier, in a question which was not ruled out of order, whether the expenditure pattern to date this year would indicate any need for change in the expenditure estimates for the year. If my recollection of the answer is right, Senator McMullan said, in essence, no, there was no need for change. I ask whether that answer took into account the fact that the Government apparently will now be unable to spend all but a very small proportion of the amount included in its expenditure figures for this year on major rail projects. If Senator McMullan's answer did take that into account, how is it that he could give the answer that he gave before? If he did not take it into account, because he may not have known of his Government's decision of a couple of nights ago, does he wish to revisit his earlier answer? Prima facie, on that basis, it would seem to require some correction.
—The answer to the last part of the question is no.
—Are there any further matters in relation to program 1?

—I will not pursue the matter further at the moment in view of the other issues that we have to deal with in the course of the day. I would just like to put on the record my extreme concern that the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer and the person handling the Finance appropriations in this place is unprepared to answer questions—very legitimate questions—going to the whole heart of the financing and the expenditure programs of the Government in this chamber, on the occasion of the one debate in the year which, above all other debates in this chamber, is designed to permit the probing of these matters.

PARA.TAB: It is typical of the concealment and the deceit that the Government has been entering into for a long time now in terms of the true state of the finances of this nation. We have seen what has happened as a result of that deceit in such States as Western Australia; my State, Victoria; and the basket case State of South Australia. What we are seeing here, exercised by this Government at the Federal level, is exactly the same sort of deceit leading down the same sort of road as we have seen in the decay of previous governments. The most spectacular was the Whitlam Government in 1975, when concealment of the facts was the cause of the undermining of the fabric of that Government and the fabric of our economy. We are seeing today, through Senator McMullan and his cohorts in government, precisely the same pattern. I think that it is a matter of the gravest concern that he adopts this approach on behalf of his Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, on program 1—

—Before we pursue that I will say that, in this position, especially during Estimates, I lean heavily towards the Opposition because it is the Opposition which is making most of the running on the Estimates. I would point out in relation to the last comment that I suggested to Senator McMullan that certain questions should not be answered because they were not within the purview of the Standing Orders.

—I would like to conclude my comments on this program by endorsing what Senator Short has said. I had a very specific issue, a reservation on the loan capital works program. I have to say that I was absolutely astonished at how unforthcoming Senator McMullan was with answers on that program. Whatever the debate about Senator Short's comments and some of the wider issues, there can be no debate that there was a very specific item here—the loan capital works program—and there were some specific questions which clearly had to be asked. The Government clearly made a major statement to at least one journalist about this program, and it appeared on the front page of the Sydney Morning Herald.

PARA.TAB: We had advisers there from the Department of Finance—a very eminent department. Senator McMullan appeared to be quite incapable of responding effectively, and with appropriate information, to the questions I put to him. I express great concern that when a senator puts down a specific program, and says that he will be pursuing questions on that program, he comes into the chamber and finds that the answers are not forthcoming. Mr Chairman, I do not know what you can do about this, but I would certainly like to record my concern about the behaviour of Senator McMullan and his lack of ability to answer questions which are clearly in the public interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp, when you were making your remarks I was having a well-earned coffee break. When I went back to have my coffee break I did not put the television on, so I am not sure what your questions were. I did point out, when Senator Panizza was pursuing an issue, that one can ask questions in relation to reservations about global aspects of the local capital works program but one cannot ask questions about the individual capital works program under this particular reservation. There being nothing further on program 1 and nothing on program 2, we will turn to program 5.

—I want to ask some questions in relation to the asset sales task force and to pursue some of the matters that may have developed since the discussion in Estimates on 22 September, which, as I said earlier, is now getting towards a couple of months ago. We discussed a range of asset sales at the 22 September hearing. The one that attracted most discussion was the sale of Qantas. We have since then had the introduction into the Parliament of the Qantas Sale Bill. Other than that, can Senator McMullan update the chamber on what has happened since 22 September so far as the sale process of Qantas is concerned?

—Apart from those things which the honourable senator has referred to already, the buyers have continued their examination of the documents. The task force has written to the prospective buyers recently and they will be required to forward binding offers by early December.
—That means, does it, that what was described as the investigation phase, which we were told in September should be completed by mid-November, has been completed?

—Obviously it is well advanced, but there is nothing that precludes people continuing to investigate, up until the early December date, for the binding offers. Some are likely to wish to continue to do that; some are probably in a position to make their offer now. The key date, which is more concrete than that general one given to Senator Short, is the early December binding offer date.
—In other words, binding offers have to be submitted by a date in early December? Is there a specific date?
—By 9 December.
—Assuming that he does get some binding offers by 9 December, is the Secretary able to intimate whether he expects to receive binding offers?
—I will take my courage in my hands: yes, I do expect to receive some.
—When does the Secretary anticipate that a decision would be made?

—The final outcome will depend on the nature of the offers, whether they are qualified and conditional, and, therefore, what response we need to make to those qualifications and conditions. The indication to the buyers is that we have an aspiration of choosing a preferred purchaser in response to those before Christmas. We cannot, of course, be certain that that will be the case because it depends upon the nature and terms of the offers. But that is our aspiration, which we have made clear.
—The Qantas Sale Bill seems to be a reasonably standard Bill. However, it includes a number of options for the sale. Does that mean that the final sale procedure has not yet been decided?
—I have nothing to add. We do not want to debate the Bill here—I know Senator Short is not trying to—but beyond what is in the Bill I would have to say that it depends on what is in the offers.

—I assume that the fact that there are options means that, as we discussed in September, the Government could still contemplate the possibility of a 100 per cent trade sale or a lesser amount. Is the situation still seen as entirely flexible?

—Provided such an offer for a 100 per cent trade sale respected such things as foreign ownership requirements, that is at least a theoretical possibility. I do not want to go beyond that, but there is nothing in the law or in the announced statements of the Government to preclude that, subject to the things that are in the Bill like the Australian ownership requirements. Whether any offer is likely to meet those is an entirely different question. I know that Senator Short was not asking it and I just want to make sure no-one gets a misunderstanding that I am speculating that it might happen. He was asking whether it is theoretically possible. Subject to the Bill, it is theoretically possible.

—I would like to ask a similar theoretical question. If there is a 100 per cent trade sale to a foreign airline—given that, as I understand it, our foreign investment rules so far as airlines are concerned allow a maximum of 35 per cent foreign interest—does a 100 per cent trade sale to a foreign airline, with a proposal by that airline for a sell-down to 35 per cent, pose any problems in relation to the current foreign investment policy?

—No, the option of exceeding the limit set in the Bill and then selling down is not open. It would not conform with the Bill to have more than 35 per cent or more than 25 per cent with one foreign purchaser. That would not conform with the legislation. It is not like, perhaps, a normal FIRB situation, about which I am not expert but where I understand that sometimes it is possible to say, `Perhaps if you sell down, XYZ can happen'. The law says that a purchaser can have only 35 per cent and one person can have only 25 per cent, and we have to conform with the law.

—I would like to make sure I understand that correctly. Is Senator McMullan saying that it is not therefore possible within the law for a foreign airline to bid initially for more than 35 per cent of Qantas? Is it not possible for a foreign airline to bid 100 per cent and say that it will sell down to 35 per cent after a given time? I am just wanting clarification.

—That is correct. So there is no misunderstanding, I will say that the only way there could be a 100 per cent trade sale in which a foreign airline was involved would be that it established a consortium which did meet the requirements—that is, that the other 65 per cent was Australian and all the other requirements. It could be the lead partner in that consortium but it could not itself buy 100 per cent.
—At any time?
—That is right.

—Since we last discussed this matter in Estimates I understand that one of the possible touted purchasers, British Airways, has purchased Dan Air and another small carrier to consolidate its European operations, and has also sought to purchase a 44 per cent stake in a United States airline. I ask Senator McMullan whether that is correct. I understand that it is.

—Those statements have been on the public record and, as far as I know, nobody has contradicted them. I cannot comment on any potential purchaser's views or anything it has said or done because that would open it up to speculation, which the honourable senator and I know we should not do. As far as I know, those comments are on the public record and are uncontradicted, so I expect that they are correct.
—I assume from what Senator McMullan has said that he has no indication from British Airways one way or the other as to whether that affects its interest in purchasing a stake in Qantas.
—I cannot comment on that.

—Another purchaser that had been mooted at one stage, I think, was Lend Lease. That was at a public meeting, anyway. I think that company has since advised publicly that it was withdrawing from what was a bidding group. I am not seeking in any way to embarrass the sale procedure but, given those circumstances and the fact that those things are on the public record, is the honourable senator in a position to tell us anything about how many interested parties are still in the ring?

—It is a complex question to respond to. Let me go back a step. I think I can perhaps provide a little more information than I did before. I was perhaps being excessively cautious for exactly the reasons Senator Short indicated. I can say that British Airways has confirmed that those purchases do not in any way impair or reduce its interest in Qantas. It continues to be interested. Any more than that, I cannot say. But British Airways has apparently said that quite clearly to the Government.

PARA.TAB: There are four parties, as has previously been discussed—three airlines and one associated party—that have been actively pursuing this question. The question is a bit more complicated because I am advised that a number of other financial institutions have entered into confidentiality agreements so that they also can look at the documentation and then have discussions with those airline parties. It is not for me to say why, but one would speculate that it is quite possibly to enter into some sort of arrangement or procedure jointly with them. That is not something we will know until the close of the bids, and we really should not speculate. I was just trying to inform the honourable senator that a number of people are examining the documents but they may well not all be lead parties. Some of them may be institutions that are going to be secondary parties in consortiums or whatever. At this stage, that is not for us to speculate about. It will all be known fairly soon.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan for that. At the Estimates Committee hearings I think Mr Heinrich advised the Committee that the sale proceeds from Qantas would be—I think I quote him accurately—somewhere between $2 billion and $3 billion. Is that right?
—I think we were as general as that before and I think it is reflected in the Hansard, although I do not have it with me.

—Yes, I think that is right. Given that the share market has fallen in Australia quite significantly since that time—I believe we are now down to a two-year low—and given that the world aviation industry certainly looks set for difficult trading conditions as the world economy does not look too bright over the period ahead, have those developments had any impact on either the planning or the estimates of sale proceeds?
—Nothing has occurred to make us think that we should change those estimates, if that is the nub of Senator Short's question. The range, we think, is still about right.
—There has been recent instability both in the share price and the management structure of TNT-Ansett, particularly Ansett. Has that had any effect at all on the Government's processes?
—I really cannot comment on that. I am sorry, but the honourable senator would understand that it is very sensitive.
—Yes. I will not pursue that at the moment. Is it correct that the only bank that was prepared to finance Qantas's purchase of Australian Airlines was the Commonwealth Bank?
—I am told that it is not correct.
—That sounds a pretty categorical denial of that report.
—My advice is that it is not correct, yes.
—Can I conclude from that statement that other banks were either approached or expressed an interest in financing the arrangement?

—We do not have the details in front of us, but the recollection on which I am basing my advice is that there was certainly more than one bank interested and that there was not a problem relating to bank support with regard to that matter.
—Finally, I want to ask a couple of questions about ANL and the sale there. Has anything further happened since we met on the ANL proposed sale?
—There has been more work on it, but no definitive new stage of the process has been reached.

—In September—and I refer to paragraph 53 of the Committee's report—it was said that the scoping study being undertaken in April had been concluded, its report considered, and a draft Cabinet submission is currently being examined by the Ministers involved. That was getting on for two months ago. Is the Parliamentary Secretary saying that there have been no developments since then?

—The honourable senator will understand the difficulty of getting too far into what has even gone to Cabinet, let alone its deliberations. Without trying to be evasive, no significant new stage in the process has been reached but, beyond that, I would start to enter into what is going on inside the Cabinet, which I cannot do.

—Given that it is almost a couple of months down the track since we discussed this, does that mean that the prospects of a consummation of the sale of ANL this year are not looking as optimistic as they might? What prospects does Senator McMullan seriously have of consummating this in this financial year?

—I was not sure whether Senator Short said `calendar year' or `financial year'. I do not expect it this calendar year, but the financial year option remains open. I cannot speculate about how likely it is because I do not know what the Cabinet decision will be, but it is not impossible.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, how did the $430,000 purchase by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of a half ownership in a piggery company turn into a shareholder's equity worth $4.2m within six weeks, or are the official company returns that show this simply false? If they are false, what is the Prime Minister doing to correct these false returns, or is he prepared, as a half owner, to endorse them? The Prime Minister can no longer hide behind personal abuse of me for daring to raise these matters of substance which he continually refuses to address. Detailed examination of the accounts of his half-owned piggery group show there has been continued flouting of the corporations law and breaches of Australian Securities Commission requirements which have had the effect of concealing the true financial position of Mr Keating's half-owned piggery group from the public and from the many people with whom it does business.

PARA.TAB: I hereby call on the Chairman of the Australian Securities Commission to require urgent corrections to the mass of false declarations and details made and included in this group's returns to the Australian Securities Commission; to impose penalties or other sanctions on the group for flouting its reporting requirements, and, if it has already done so, I would like to know what these penalties or sanctions have been; to enforce ASC requirements that the group meet minimum reporting standards, particularly as to timeliness; to require the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd to file proper, full audited accounts for 1991, particularly in view of the false nature of the 1990 annual return's key financial data as established by the full 1990 accounts; to require the provision of audited reports for all the non-consolidated subsidiaries of the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd for 1990 and 1991; and to establish whether the directors of Euphron Pty Ltd and Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd have committed offences under, inter alia, section 276 of the corporations law by failing to prepare proper consolidated accounts. If no action has yet been taken, I ask the ASC to advise me why not, and when such action will be instituted.

The background to this matter is that the Prime Minister's family company, Pleuron Pty Ltd, paid $430,000 to acquire a half interest in a piggery holding company, Euphron Pty Ltd, on 15 May 1991, while he was Federal Treasurer, giving him half ownership of the Brown and Hatton group of companies, of which former Labor Minister John Brown was a previous half owner and whose $100 of non-voting J class redeemable preference shares were redeemed at par on 10 August 1991.

This group has entered into an $80m joint venture agreement with the Danish Danpork Group to produce pork based on Brown and Hatton Group's Parkville piggery in the Upper Hunter area of New South Wales. Mr Keating's declaration of interest to the Parliament made on 7 June 1991 simply said that he had acquired shares in a company with interests—in fact, it was a 100 per cent interest—in a piggery and refrigeration business but that he did not have control and was not a director. In reality, he has nominees as directors and he has never declared his interest in the multimillion dollar, multinational joint venture.

The basis of the huge rise in the Prime Minister's equity to $4.2m is an unexplained extraordinary increase in assets outlined in the annual returns of the piggery holding company, Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd, which are grossly inadequate, open to serious question and in flagrant breach of the Companies Act. Mr Keating must come clean on whether he endorses his half-owned piggery group's annual returns that state his equity at $4.2m or whether, in his view, they massively overstate it, as his answer to Paul Lyneham on ABC television indicated last month. As no audited accounts have been filed with the Australian Securities Commission to support this extraordinary valuation, in breach of the corporations law, although they were due almost a year ago, the Prime Minister has an obligation as a half owner of this group to ensure that such audited accounts be filed and to either endorse or deny them.

At present the only documentation available for public scrutiny is an inadequate, misleading, brief exempt proprietary form of annual return which reveals only key financial data and which was filed in May of this year, six months late. This showed a $10m, or 50 per cent, rise to almost $30m in total assets of Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd from 1990, but only a $3.7m, or 20 per cent, increase in total liabilities to $22.2m on the other side of the balance sheet, providing a totally unexplained $7.8m discrepancy following an operating loss of $1.5m during the year.

This unexplained rise lifted shareholders' equity in Mr Keating's half-owned piggery holding company, Euphron Pty Ltd—which consolidates the Brown and Hatton Group—to a stated $8.4m. This inexplicable rise is despite the fact that the group's directors certified in May 1991, within six weeks of the end of the financial year, that nothing likely to affect significantly the group's state of affairs had arisen since June 1990.

So what happened from mid-May 1991, when Mr Keating acquired his half interest, magically to increase the net worth of this group? Perhaps Mr Keating would like to explain the apparently unexpected increase in the group's assets that gave the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd the appearance of significant substance by lifting its net tangible assets—from minus $3.1m in 1990, when it was technically insolvent, to $2.9m by June 1991—and lifting 1990's stated shareholders' equity of only $1.3m, which included goodwill of $4.5m, to a stated $7.5m in 1991.

The absence of fully audited public company accounts for the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd for 1991 is of major concern in view of the false nature of the 1990 accounts of the group, as established by a detailed examination of them which I now seek leave to table.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would rather look at that first.
—I will be glad to show it to Senator McMullan if he wants leave to be deferred.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is particularly disappointing that, although the group's annual return to the Australian Securities Commission for 1991 indicated that it was a public company for all but six weeks of the financial year, the Australian Securities Commission appears to have allowed it to get away without filing full audited public company accounts as the law requires. The misleading, brief and inadequate `exempt proprietary' style of accounts appears to have been accepted as the only accounts available for public view. I now ask the Australian Securities Commission to correct this situation.

PARA.TAB: Whenever the facts of the Prime Minister's $4.2m stated equity in a piggery group have been raised in this chamber, going back to my first revelations five months ago, the Government's usual response has been that I have been `muck-raking without a shred of evidence'. This week Senator Button claimed once again that I was totally wrong and accused me of a `total misrepresentation of everything'.

Last month, when Prime Minister Paul Keating was asked by the ABC's Paul Lyneham whether he did or did not know that the book value of his pig farm increased by 10 times in six weeks, his answer—which, for some extraordinary reason, was excised from the official Prime Minister's transcript—was, `No, no'. His only explanation was, `Look, well, the thing is, you've got to know how to read a set of company accounts'. When asked by Mr Lyneham, `Given the innocence of this business venture of yours, why don't you prove it by opening the books?', the Prime Minister responded, avoiding any substantive answer, by saying, `Don't tell me you're picking up this muck, Paul'.

There would be no need for the books to be `opened up' if only the Keating piggery group would cease its consistent and flagrant breaches of the corporations law by its pattern of false and misleading company returns—or failure to submit them—to the Australian Securities Commission. Just meeting the legal requirements would do.

However, those returns that have reluctantly and belatedly eventually been filed with the Australian Securities Commission raise some serious questions about the financial integrity of the group. All these returns were filed after Mr Keating became a half owner of the group, although he himself has not signed any of them. Nearly all of them were submitted to the ASC only after my initial criticism five months ago of the group's failure to file returns with the ASC.

The simple issue that the Prime Minister cannot avoid by bluster or abuse is that the public has a right to know how its Prime Minister could purchase for $430,000 or $43,000—depending on which of the company's various returns is correct—a half share in this piggery and refrigeration group, which is reported by the company itself to be represented only six weeks later by a shareholders' equity of $4.2m. The public is entitled to know whether the Prime Minister bought his half share at an incredibly cheap price or whether the group's accounts deliberately overstate their real value.

As the Prime Minister—judging by his answer to Paul Lyneham—does `know how to read a set of company accounts', perhaps he can explain which of these two options is the right one. This is apart from the general question of the Prime Minister's failure to declare his interest in an $80m multinational piggery joint venture which depends on governmental approvals for its development, along with his admitted failure to advise the Foreign Investment Review Board of his involvement when approval for a draft joint venture was sought last year.

The Prime Minister's main response to my past revelations has been by way of personal pressure on editors—including telephone calls to their homes—and to journalists not to print my evidence and to blackguard me as a purveyor of unsubstantiated muck. This has had some success, with one journalist describing me in these terms in an article with his newspaper, the Sydney Morning Herald, not being prepared to carry my letter in response. Another falsely claimed on radio I had produced not one shred of evidence.

I now invite the Prime Minister to address the substance of today's detailed examination of the annual returns and accounts of this group of which he is the half owner and to advise the Australian people whether he has in fact acquired a $4.2m shareholders' equity in the group for $430,000, or whether the group's annual returns falsely and misleadingly overstate its real worth. I wonder whether the Parliamentary Secretary has had the opportunity to give us an indication of whether he accepts the tabling of that document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had a chance to read it. At some other stage I may be prepared to, but not now.

—If there is a prospect that it will not be accepted, we will read the matter into the Hansard. It is beyond belief that a half owner of a group that has $29m of stated assets would not have some idea of its real worth, even if he did not himself sign the accounts. At least we know that he knows how to read a set of company accounts.

PARA.TAB: In view of the pattern of false statements, breaches of Australian Securities Commission requirements and massive `mistakes'—all of them putting a beneficial gloss on the groups' returns—Mr Keating has a duty to advise the Australian people whether he endorses his half owned company's returns or whether the group has massively overstated his shareholders' equity at $4.2m. Either he has been given, as I said at the beginning, a half interest in this group at an extraordinarily favourable price—and we will not here go into the question of where he got the money to buy it in the first place—or else its value is not as stated in sworn declarations. I await a substantive answer from Mr Keating, with, I admit, little confidence. Instead, I expect only the normal tirade of personal abuse. The Australian people will be able to make their judgment accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Baume, at some later stage you might be able to seek leave when the Parliamentary Secretary has looked at it. There will be no problem if you come back to us.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak for a few minutes on the alleged superannuation swindle in the Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund. I want to read, in the first place, from a summary of the Towers Perin draft interim review. In doing so, I am aware that press reports today say that more information has come to light to render this interim review incomplete. One might wonder whether it is incomplete or not, reflecting the desires of those who are awaiting the outcome of this review. The focus of this review was: have extraordinary withdrawals occurred from this fund? Is the structure of the fund such that it is operating correctly? Has the structure of the fund been changed and, if so, on whose initiatives?

PARA.TAB: A summary of the overview of findings is that extraordinary withdrawals have occurred with financial advantages to two former members, and that these financial advantages did not reduce past members' accumulated benefits but would have reduced the level of the reserve fund which was distributed on 1 March 1992. The initiator of extraordinary payments is unknown but all trustees should have been involved in the decision to transfer benefits. The fund has not operated in accordance with the trust deed and there is no other documentary evidence to support the trustee's actions. There have been breaches of the occupational superannuation standards which could cause loss of tax concessions for the funds. These are extremely serious findings.

I want to refer to the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, Safeguarding super, and what we had to say in our recommendations 4.7 and 4.9. Precisely because of this possibility we recommended that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission be able to impose a range of civil penalties and institute criminal proceedings against trustees and directors of corporate trustees. We recommended that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission be given power to institute civil proceedings against trustees and directors of corporate trustees on behalf of members. We recommended in recommendation 4.9 the right of members to be clearly identified in legislation, including the right to information about proposed changes to the trust deed.

So much of this case hinges around an alleged backdating of a change to the trust deed in a way which disadvantaged some members. I think there is quite clearly a case for intervention by the ISC in this alleged swindle, but the Insurance and Superannuation Commission does not yet have the teeth. I will be contacting the Commission today to ask what it can do about it and to put my case to it. There could even be a case for the Queensland police to ensure that no crucial documents are shredded, as has happened in a previous important case in Queensland. These findings, and the way in which they are being handled in Queensland, underline the importance of this Senate, and the Superannuation Committee in particular, as watchdogs for Queensland people affected in this case and, beyond that, people who do

SPEECH.PARA: not have the benefit of the proper checks and balances of an upper House in Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The issue of the multimillion dollar Danish pig joint venture project of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, has had a most extraordinary path since raised by me, Senator O'Chee and Senator Baume in the Senate on 3 June this year. It has seen the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, tell the Senate that there have been no ministerial talks in the importation of live pigs and pig genetic material. It has seen a reputable Government department, the Australian Quarantine Inspection Service, write letters in most definite terms, only to correct them months later when questions were asked in the Senate. It has seen AQIS ministerial briefings corrected many months after they were written, after questions were raised in the Senate. It has seen AQIS officers in Estimates deny the veracity of their statements in ministerial briefings. It has seen the Prime Minister issue a denial in the Age newspaper on 16 September that his joint venture project did not intend to import any pigs or breeding material from anywhere, and that it had not been the subject of any ministerial talks.

PARA.TAB: At the same time there existed a cablegram which referred to higher priority being given to imports of Danish genetic material because of the joint venture being forged between 1991 and 1992 and a ministerial meeting recall note stating that Minister Crean told the Danish Agriculture Minister that he was pleased with the progress of the pork joint venture. We also know that the industry has requested imports of genetic material from Ireland and the UK. All requests have been refused.

In April 1989 representatives of the Federation of Danish Industry and the pig industry visited Australia. On 2 May 1990 a meeting was held between FDI and Australian Government departments, including AQIS, to discuss quarantine issues. The other mission also was seeking out possible interested parties. Meanwhile, several months earlier, AQIS had sent out a circular for comments on a review of the importation of pigs and embryos, using Denmark as a model. There was reaction from the industry bodies, the industry and some State quarantine officers, questioning whether it was related to one proposal and warning of endangering the whole Australian pig herd. On 16 April, the European journal Agra Europe published an article which I will table, if I may.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Is leave granted?

TALK.START.PARA: —What is it?
—I will send over two documents. The Agra Europe article was headed `Joint Danish-Australian Pigmeat Venture' and made three important statements: Firstly, it said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian Prime Minister is among the investors in a large Danish-Australian joint venture to establish a pig slaughterhouse in Australia.
Secondly:
In preparation of the launch Keating has held several meetings with Danpork's MD Rene Madelaire and board chairman, Ole Jacobsson. . .
Thirdly:
The Danish-Australian deal was finalised during the recent visit of Denmark's minister for agriculture Laurits Toernaes to Australia.

Remember that the date of this article was 16 April 1992, and we now know that there was a meeting on 8 April 1992 between Mr Crean and Mr Toernaes and that Mr Crean's recall note said that he was pleased with the progress evident in the joint venture. Mr Crean stands by his recall note, and I have sent that note over to the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) for him to give permission for it to be tabled. I ask that it be tabled.

PARA.TAB: Senator Button, in reply to questions by me on 3, 16, 17, 18 and 19 June, said that there had not been any ministerial discussions on the importation of live pigs and/or genetic material. Senator Button always replied that the only discussions that had taken place were on 20 May 1990 between the Federation of Danish Industries and Australian Government departments, including AQIS and Primary Industries and Energy. He also said that two people who were later to become members of the Danish joint venture had been present at the meeting. Senator Button always maintained that this was the only meeting that had ever taken place, and never at ministerial level. Yet AQIS ministerial briefings to Minister Griffiths dated April 1992 and 23 June 1992 clearly stated that there was a ministerial meeting on 8 April between Minister Crean and the Danish Agriculture Minister, Mr Toernaes, and that pig semen had been discussed at this meeting.

We were told in Estimates that media coverage forced AQIS to correct the AQIS briefing note on 15 October 1992—four months later. On 3 June, AQIS wrote a letter in which it stated, under the heading `Live Pigs', that access for live pigs had been first raised in the mid-1980s but in the 1990s had re-emerged as an issue at prime ministerial level in the context of a joint venture between Danish and Australian pig breeding and processing interests. The same letter referred to `having regard to government to government discussions over the years and recent Minister to Minister discussions, it will be necessary to give some priority to the longstanding Danish request'.

Six weeks after the original letter and after the Senate question to Senator Button and a freedom of information application by me, on 21 July AQIS wrote a letter saying that the 3 June letter incorrectly advised that the issue of possible live imports from Denmark re-emerged at prime ministerial level in April 1990. However, the reference in the 3 June letter to `recent Minister to Minister discussions' was not referred to or denied. When asked at the Estimates how the reference to the Prime Minister came into the letter and whether they often threw in the Prime Minister's name when he had nothing to do with the issue, the officer could not explain, despite the letter having been written by a committee of three senior and professional AQIS officers.

This was not the only time AQIS officers had written important documents stating that events occurred, in most definite terms, on which months later they were corrected. It has happened on at least six occasions. In April, AQIS wrote a return briefing to Minister Griffiths in which it stated that Danish authorities had recently renewed with Minister Crean long-standing demands for consideration by AQIS of imports of Danish-origin unprocessed pig meat and pig semen. In fact, AQIS sent us two copies of this letter under freedom of information. The second one we received the day before the last Estimates hearing. The first, which had been sent months earlier, had `pig semen' totally blacked out. At Estimates Minister Cook exclaimed `Oh, come on', when it was suggested that the blacked-out words were `and pig semen'. The acting AQIS head, Mr Gascoine, said that the letter he wanted us to have was the one without the blacking-out.

This AQIS briefing paper was only one reference to pig semen being discussed at the ministerial meetings. The other is in a briefing to Minister Griffith, with a copy to Mr Crean dated 23 June 1992. In this briefing, AQIS stated that the Danish Minister for Agriculture would raise the matter of uncooked pig meat and pig semen during discussions with Mr Crean in April 1992. This briefing took place after the April ministerial meeting. Despite a copy going to Minister Crean, who was actually at the meeting, the veracity of the briefing paper was never questioned.

That was so until 15 October, when we were told at Estimates that the Department, prompted by media reports, on 23 June 1992 sent to Minister Crean a correction of the Minister Griffiths briefing note. This correction was signed by an acting director in AQIS, Mr Gascoine, and specifically corrected the 23 June briefing headed `Importation of Pig Meat and Pig Genetic Material from Denmark'. The correction said that the reference to pig semen was incorrect and the recall note of the meeting prepared by an officer of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy made no reference to the importation of pig genetic material.

At Estimates, when the AQIS officer was asked why he put in the words `pig semen', he said that he recollected a phone call with Minister Crean's office, named an officer as probably Mr Roberts, and then contended that his recollection of events was incorrect—another definite assertion in important correspondence which months later has been said to be incorrect and has been corrected. Despite a request for a copy of this minute, it has not been received and it was not included in the FOI material, despite our asking for it.

First there were the discussions at Prime Minister level on live pig imports, then the Minister to Minister discussions, now the reference to ministerial discussions on pig semen, which, despite its being in two separate ministerial briefings, AQIS now says was incorrect. There are others. The reference in the 23 June briefing paper to Minister Griffiths stated that the joint venture ultimately would include Danish pig genetic material. Yet, when questioned at Estimates, despite this appearing in an official briefing paper, the AQIS writer said it was only speculation.

There were further issues which we were not able to cover at the Estimates, such as Mr Crean's background briefing paper dated 9 April, where AQIS stated that it understood that Danish interests might use Australian genotypes, thus:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . delaying imports of more suitable Danish genotypes until the quarantine control infrastructure is in place and the political climate is more favourable.

What would be AQIS's answer to this? Did it mean what it wrote, or is it once again writing things so they can later be corrected? Here is an AQIS officer commenting on the political climate and the political sensitivity of a matter. Even the AQIS cablegram categorically stated that higher priority was until recently being placed on these tasks, as imports of genetic material were linked to a joint venture proposal between Australia and the Danish industry that was being forged during 1991-92. The present Prime Minister was in office then.

PARA.TAB: At the first Estimates hearing AQIS said that the words in the cablegram really meant that the new officer in Brussels was just seeking clarification of why we were giving priority to the issue at the time. One could understand that AQIS could possibly make one or two mistakes—they would be straws in the wind—but when the mistakes start adding up to half a dozen they start to look like a haystack. What are we meant to think? Senator Button told the Senate that Mr Keating had discussions with his joint venture partner, Mr Jacobsson—this would have taken place around 8 April 1992—when Mr Jacobsson was part of a delegation with the Danish agriculture Minister, Mr Toernaes. As told by Senator Button, Mr Keating said it was a private matter, but it is a matter of public importance. Here was the Prime Minister discussing with his joint partner a project which, on Mr Crean's assertion, was being mentioned at Minister to Minister talks. Mr Keating's joint venture fits the category of pork joint ventures, and Mr Crean told Mr Toernaes he was pleased with their progress. All this took place around 8 April, before AQIS was formally advised of the joint venture.

Mr Keating insists in his Age denial that the joint venture had no intention of importing pigs or breeding material and had not been the subject of ministerial talks. Mr Keating may not have been pushing for importing genetic material but his joint venture partner and its government were. If we are to believe the AQIS letters and ministerial briefings, the Danish authorities were pushing for it. The end result is still the same: the Prime Minister's joint venture company benefits. Joint ventures do not just happen; they need lots of preparation.

How could the Prime Minister, when Treasurer, get himself involved in a project that needed so many government decisions and government-led changes? How can a most relevant government department, AQIS, on a most relevant issue for the success of the joint venture—importing pig genetic material—make not one, but six, major mistakes that need correcting from assertions of prime ministerial and ministerial discussions on genetic materials connected to the joint venture that are backed up by international cablegram and senior ministerial briefings?
I seek leave to table the documents I have handed to the Parliamentary Secretary.
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Do you agree to their being tabled, Senator McMullan?

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly agree to Minister Crean's letter being tabled. That is obviously public. The letter is obviously a letter from Mr Crean to Senator Boswell. If the honourable senator is happy to table it, there is no problem. I am not quite sure of the status of the other document.
—The other is virtually the equivalent of Country Life or The Land in Europe. It is a public paper.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I ask the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) whether he agrees to the document referred to by Senator Baume being tabled.
—No.
—The document referred to, which the Parliamentary Secretary has refused to allow to be tabled, reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: A Detailed Analysis of the Returns Filed by the
Euphron-Brown and Hatton Group
A detailed analysis of the returns filed by companies in the Euphron-Brown and Hatton Group reveals consistent breaches of the Corporations Law and Australian Securities Commission requirements by:-

.the failure of the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd to file its detailed public company accounts for 1990 until forced by request from the ASC to do so in July 1992—more than a year and a half after the due date of December 1990 and after the Group had belatedly filed an inadequate and false statement of key financial data in its 1990 annual return on 10 January 1992.

.By filing for public view an annual return for 1990 containing a statement of key financial data that was significantly false in that it overstated by at least $23 million the net tangible assets of Brown and Hatton Group Limited and two of its subsidiaries (the remaining subsidiaries were not consolidated, nor were full accounts filed for them); this overstatement was probably by another million dollars or so in view of further false declarations within the return; the $19.85 million that it stated to be the net tangible assets of the Group in its key financial data return was subsequently revealed in the full return to be, instead, the total of gross assets which, after deducting $18.54 million in liabilities, gave net assets of only $1.3 million—and when intangible assets of $4.45 million were deducted (being owed for goodwill to Mr John Brown's company), the real net tangible assets position deteriorated to a negative $3.14 million. So instead of being almost $20 million as claimed, net tangible assets were at least—$3 million and probably much worse making the group technically insolvent. This false return does not appear to have been questioned by the ASC despite its seriously misleading nature. To this time it has not been corrected and is the return provided by the ASC in response to public enquiry.

.The detailed public company 1990 accounts, eventually and reluctantly filed on 10(th) July 1992 (eighteen months late and signed on May 20 1991, six months late) are themselves false and misleading in several material particulars and have not been audited, in breach of ASC requirements.

PARA.TAB: a)The statement that net profit for the year was $842,999 "after income tax" is clearly false, as is the Director's declaration that no item, transaction or event between balance date of June 30 1990 and the belated signing of the accounts on May 20 1991, would significantly affect the Group. This emerges from the fact that:-

TAB.TAB: i)Note three to the accounts states, "no provision for income tax is considered necessary as the interest expense payable on loan funds received from Rincraft Pty Ltd (an associate but not consolidated company) amounting to $11,495,000 will ultimately exceed any taxable income generated".

ii)No present or future interest liability is stated in the accounts although it must have been established for tax purposes prior to the Group's tax return and certainly before the Director's declaration that the accounts were "complete and correct" was made in May 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result either the net profit should have been reduced by the interest charge or a provision for the interest charge should have been created, further diminishing the Group's net tangible assets position.

PARA.TAB: b)The accounts do not represent a true and fair view of the company's financial position and the information is not "complete and correct" as required by the ASC in the relevant officers' declaration in the annual return in that depreciation of assets, which the notes to the accounts claim has been charged "over their estimated useful lives commencing from the date of acquisition" has not been accounted for at all, with the piggeries being shown at the acquisition cost of $7 million and other property, plant and equipment at cost, so overstating the profit and assets position of the company.

c)A device has been used to give a false impression of the liquidity position of the company in that the $11.5 million "non current loan" due to Rincraft Pty Ltd (an associate company 100% owned by the Brown and Hatton Group's parent company Euphron Pty Ltd) is financed by short term borrowings (ie current liabilities) by Rincraft. These Rincraft current liabilities totalled $23.2 million and long term liabilities only $1.6 million at June 30 1991; at last enquiry there were no accounts yet filed by Rincraft for 1990 in clear breach of ASC requirements, but the same deceptive device to transfer short-term borrowings by the Group into apparent long-term liabilities is evident in those 1991 accounts that have been filed for Group companies.

d)Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd directors have either made a false declaration or committed another offence in respect of the date of the company's annual meeting at which the 1990 accounts were claimed to have dealt with. They signed full 1990 accounts on 20(th) May 1991 yet the annual general meeting is claimed, in the Company's abbreviated return to the ASC dated 30(th) December 1991, to have been held on 20(th) March 1991. This is in breach of ASC requirements (and of the previously existing Companies Act in New South Wales) in that a public company's accounts must be presented to the annual general meeting—which in this case is claimed to have taken place two months before the accounts were signed.

e)Despite stating in the financial statements filed with its Group 1990 annual return that a full set of accounts for subsidiaries not included in the consolidated accounts have also been prepared, these have not been filed with the ASC which received only brief key financial data statements for the following subsidiaries for both 1990 and 1991: Jensay Pty Ltd (which bought the Group's Marrickville property for $2.1 million) had an unexplained rise in total assets from $2.67 million to $3.5 million in 1991 and a negative shareholders' equity of $21,159 in 1990 and $21,202 in 1991, with liabilities of $2.7 million all due to Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd in the 1990 accounts rising to $3.5 million for 1991; Olympia Refrigeration Sales Pty Ltd with total assets of $2.6 million in 1990 rising to $2.8 million in 1991, total liabilities rising from $2.8 million to $3.8 million and net tangible assets of minus $476,289 worsening to minus $1.3 million in 1991 after suffering an operating loss for the year of $343,548; Olympia Interiors Pty Ltd with total assets of $34,960, liabilities of $160,819 and a shareholders' equity of minus $125,858; Olympia Industries (Mfg) Pty Ltd with total assets of $0.5 million, liabilities of $1 million and a shareholders' equity of minus $454,478. On the face of it, the Olympia companies' deficiencies ( all of which were falsely declared to have positive shareholders' funds) mean that they are technically insolvent, requiring Directors to be satisfied that debts can be met as and when they fall due. As a result, the Brown and Hatton Group's 1990 real net tangible assets have been overstated by at least $500,000 as a result of their non-consolidation into the Group.

These failures to consolidate are worsened by the further failure to meet the ASC requirement that the accounts of non-consolidated subsidiaries should be in the same form (ie full public company form in these cases) as the holding company accounts. The ASC requirement for companies to file consolidated accounts that give a true and fair view of the profit and loss and state of affairs of the company entity has been ignored, particularly the requirement that non-consolidated accounts be accompanied by a note specifying why consolidation is impractical and outlining how the Group accounts are significantly affected by any transactions and balances between Group companies.

SPEECH.PARA: .The 1991 annual return of Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd involves further significant breaches of ASC requirements.

PARA.TAB: a)No full audited public company accounts for the Brown and Hatton Group have been filed and they are now 11 months overdue. An inadequate exempt proprietary form of annual return was submitted to the ASC on May 22 1992 (six months late) despite the requirement that a company must be exempt for the whole of the financial year to avoid the need to file full public company accounts, yet the Brown and Hatton Group did not revert to proprietary status until 16(th) May 1991. Although the annual return to the ASC indicated the Group was not an exempt proprietary company for the whole of the financial year, the ASC appears to have accepted this inadequate return as meeting its requirements.

b)The 1991 key financial data of Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd shows a $10m or 50 per cent rise to $29.8 million in total assets from 1990 but only a $3.7 million or 20 per cent rise in total liabilities to $22.2 million on the other side of the balance sheet, despite an operating loss of $1.5 million during the year. There is no explanation given for such an extraordinary $7.8 million discrepancy that lifted Euphron Pty Ltd's shareholders' equity to $8.4 million, particularly as the Brown and Hatton Group's Directors certified in May 1991, within six weeks of the end of the financial year, that nothing likely to affect significantly the Group's state of affairs had arisen since June 1990. It is this unexplained and apparently unexpected increase in the Group's assets that gave the Brown and Hatton Group Pty Ltd the appearance of significant substance with its reported shareholders' equity of $7.5 million indicating far greater strength than 1990's $1.3 million and with net tangible assets of $2.9 million against minus $3.1 million in 1990. These significant rises cannot simply be explained by the apparent consolidation of previously unconsolidated subsidiaries such as the Olympia Refrigeration Group into the 1991 accounts.
