SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the first time today my colleagues in the Senate have brought together the pieces of a mosaic which constitute a very serious case to be answered. Senators Baume, Boswell, Reid and Knowles have raised matters of the utmost importance which go to the heart of the integrity of the democratic process and which require an immediate and detailed explanation from the most powerful office holder in the land. In an era of corporate successes or excesses, when we are still recovering from the avarices of the white shoe brigade and its various manifestations, it is critically important that all public office holders should not only act scrupulously and honourably but be seen to do so.

PARA.TAB: Above everyone else, a Prime Minister has a unique obligation, like Caesar's wife, to be beyond reproach and to set the highest standards of propriety. Prime Ministers are not above the law, neither are Treasurers—ask Red Ted Theodore; nor can they skate around the edges of the law or hide behind the corporate veil by making technically true answers to issues which constitute highly misleading statements.

It is one thing for a Prime Minister to have a set of passive investments in blue chip stocks or to establish a blind trust for family interests; it is another thing altogether to be actively involved in an inherently speculative exercise requiring government approval, to fail to file up-to-date and relevant information on its corporate activities, and to achieve what, on its face, would appear to be an investment success beyond the wildest dreams of every corporate entrepreneur. Eyebrows would be raised if an ordinary citizen had the success which the Prime Minister would claim to have had from the documents which have been filed. It is imperative that the business of running the country should not be compromised by the business of making a big quid on the side.

The fact of a capital gain or otherwise is certainly an issue, but the paramount issue for the Parliament is what to make of the investment in relation to the offices of Treasurer and Prime Minister. Has it involved the Prime Minister, either in his present office or as Treasurer, directly or indirectly, in any conflict of interest or, what would be more serious, in any impropriety or offences, even if the latter are merely technical? It is well said that justice must not only be done but be seen to be done. If Parliament does not address an issue of this kind seriously in due course and in proper time, we have the recent instances of WA Inc. and the Fitzgerald inquiry to remind us of the consequences.

The Prime Minister and his family company and a Mr Constantinidis and his family company now appear to be the effective co-owners of the Brown and Hatton Group of companies, and thus to be the Australian partners of the substantial Danish company Danpork in an $80m joint venture based in New South Wales. The Prime Minister's nominee, to be responsible for managing his and his family company's half share in the Brown and Hatton Group, is a Mr Coudounaris, who is the secretary of the Prime Minister's family company. Mr Coudounaris and Mr Constantinidis reportedly were the ones who travelled to Denmark to seal the joint venture arrangements with Danpork, Brown and Hatton having been earlier chosen by that company as its Australian partner. The joint venture was publicly announced in April this year.

The public records so far available relating to the holding company of the Brown and Hatton Group, Euphron, and its wholly owned subsidiaries show a complex web of interests and financial flows, including borrowings. What we find leaves us with a clear impression that statutory reporting requirements have not been properly met and, indeed, that offences may well have occurred.

Looking at the wider context, we find that the joint venture announced in April this year has in fact been some years in the making and goes back perhaps to the beginning of 1989. Two developments march side by side. There is, on the one hand, the restructuring of the Brown and Hatton Group of companies, its purchase of piggeries, the buy in by the Prime Minister's family company, the withdrawal of the original owners—Mr John Brown and Mr Vince Hatton—from the group and, finally, the setting up of Danpork Australia as a joint venture between the Brown and Hatton Group and the Danish interests.

On the other hand, there has been a series of high level visits to Australia by Danish interests, including ministerial visits beginning in April 1989, the purpose of which was to bring about a joint venture and to equip this with Danish technology and pig reproductive material—that is, live pigs or pig semen from Denmark. The latter aspect involved approaches by the Danish joint venture partner for a revision of Australia's quarantine requirements, and lengthy discussions with officers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service.

It is not clear at what point the Danish interest Danpork set its sights on Brown and Hatton or vice versa. There are grounds for thinking a link may have been in existence by the first half of 1991. The name `Danpork Australia' was registered on 1 July that year. In April 1991 a new holding company for the Brown and Hatton group, Euphron, was registered. A month later the Prime Minister and his family company, Pleuron, made a $430,000 investment in Euphron. Pleuron had been registered towards the end of 1989. From the time the Prime Minister's family company was registered in November 1989 until it acquired its share in Euphron in April 1991, and thus a stake in the Danish joint venture, nothing is heard of it. Indeed, the Prime Minister's declaration of interest in January 1990, when he was the Treasurer, described it as inactive. However, this period—the year 1990—was a period of considerable activity by the Danish interests to obtain approval to import live pigs or pig breeding material, and thus involved directly the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. It is therefore of particular significance that an officer of that Service, writing on 3 June this year, should have claimed that pig imports had re-emerged as an issue `at Prime Ministerial level in the context of proposals for a joint venture'.

The Prime Minister has had ample opportunity, including when questioned on national television, to clarify his role and that of his family company in this whole matter. For reasons best known to himself, he has chosen not to do so. As Treasurer and as Prime Minister he has been in a privileged position generally as regards access to information, particularly information as to Danish interests and details of their position. He was in a particular position of privilege as Treasurer in relation to the Foreign Investment Review Board and the Commonwealth Bank, and each of these agencies played an important part in securing developments which advantaged his investment.

The Prime Minister, in notifying his family company's investment, claimed that neither he nor his family members exercised any control; yet his nominee, Mr Coudounaris, clearly has a 50 per cent interest. He appears to have failed to notify the Registrar of Members' Interests of Brown and Hatton's redemption of their J class shares which left the Prime Minister with an effective 50 per cent control. Indeed, the issue of the Prime Minister's disclosure of interest is a critically important matter. Every member of parliament is required to notify the Registrar of Members' Interests when his or her assets change significantly. In accordance with this requirement, Mr Keating wrote to the Registrar on 7 June 1991 to advise of his investment in the Brown and Hatton pig business in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: I advise that on 15 May 1991 my family company Pleuron Pty Limited and I made an investment by way of acquisition of shares in Euphron Pty Limited, a company which has interests in a piggery and a refrigeration fabrication business.

The interests acquired by both Pleuron Pty Limited and me in Euphron Pty Limited do not constitute a controlling interest in that company, nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship of that company.

This statement is misleading to the point of dishonesty. A company is controlled by any person who can carry a vote at a meeting of shareholders. In fact, in certain circumstances control can be exercised with a minority shareholding, a fact recognised in legislation governing media cross-ownership and the review of foreign investments.

PARA.TAB: At the time Mr Keating and his family company acquired the shares in Euphron, John Brown and Vincent Hatton still held 100 J class shares. Those shares have no voting rights, thus Mr Keating and his family company acquired 50 per cent of the voting shares in Euphron and hence he exercised 50 per cent of the voting rights of Euphron. The other 50 per cent of the voting shares are held by Constantinidis and his family company, with corresponding voting rights.

While it is technically true that Mr Keating's interest is not a controlling interest in the sense that it does not give him majority control, it is clear that if he does not have a controlling interest then neither does Constantinidis or anyone else. In fact, Mr Keating shares equal control of the company. It follows that the claim by Mr Keating that `the interests acquired by both Pleuron Pty Limited and me in Euphron do not constitute a controlling interest in that company' is grossly misleading. Mr Keating immediately proceeds in his letter to bolster his assertion that he does not control Euphron by stating: `nor do I or any member of my family hold a directorship of that company'. This was strictly true at the time, and remains strictly true, and yet it only compounds the deceptive effect of the message conveyed by the letter.

At the time Mr Keating acquired shares in Euphron, that company had three directors: Brown, Hatton and Constantinidis. On 10 August 1991, three months after Mr Keating acquired his interest in Euphron, Brown and Hatton resigned as directors of Euphron. On that same day Coudounaris was appointed a director. Constantinidis remained a director. His family company had also bought $430,000 worth of shares at the same time as Mr Keating. Coudounaris and Constantinidis have continued to remain the sole directors of Euphron. Coudounaris is a solicitor with the firm Gadens. He holds no shares in Euphron or in any other Brown and Hatton group company. Coudounaris is, however, the company secretary of Mr Keating's family company, Pleuron.

It is clear from documents lodged with the ASC on behalf of Pleuron that Coudounaris undertakes Pleuron company business from time to time, which is hardly surprising for a company secretary. Coudounaris does not hold any shares in Euphron or any company in the group. These facts give rise to an irresistible inference that Coudounaris is Keating's representative, if not legal nominee, on the board of Euphron, the company that controls the Brown and Hatton pig business. It is inconceivable that the formal changes of directorship that occurred on 10 August 1990 and the redemption of the shares held by John Brown and Vincent Hatton were not in the contemplation of the parties at the time Mr Keating and Constantinidis each acquired $430,000 worth of shares on 15 May 1991. Indeed, it is likely that those changes merely gave effect to an agreement of which the purchase of shares was but a part. It would strain to the limits the credibility of a reasonable observer to suggest that the appointment of Coudounaris, or some other Keating nominee, as director was not contemplated by Mr Keating as at the date of his letter to the Registrar of Members' Interests.

To return to the statement about directorship of the company, true it is that neither Mr Keating nor a member of his family holds a directorship in Euphron. However, he has not written to the Registrar of Members' Interests to advise that his representative is now one of the two directors of Euphron. He has allowed the letter of 7 June 1991 to stand as an indisputably misleading description of the position that now obtains and has obtained since 10 August 1991, a position that was undoubtedly in contemplation at the time he wrote to the Registrar of Members' Interests on 7 June. These matters can no longer be ignored. A Prime Minister who does not hesitate to pour venom and scorn on anyone who crosses his path has now been presented with a very detailed and powerful case to answer. The character issue will certainly be a vital aspect of the forthcoming election. The Australian public will certainly await his reply with interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the question of Queensland Government superannuation. On two previous occasions I have raised the matter of the funding of the Queensland Government's employee superannuation. The Senate Select Committee on Superannuation has also been interested in the matter of the extent of funding of superannuation. Twice it has expressed its concern about the mounting levels of public sector debt. In its second report, Super Guarantee Bills, the Committee noted that Queensland was the only State to have full funding. The Committee reached this conclusion as a result of evidence given at hearings in Brisbane. Until recently I was also of that view. However, I am fast approaching the conclusion that Queensland, along with the Commonwealth, other States and Territories, has a very high degree of unfunded superannuation debt and that the Committee may have been misled.

PARA.TAB: Last week I raised my doubts and even ventured to place a rough estimate on the level of debt. If my speech had contained ill-informed or poorly reasoned analysis, I am sure the Queensland Government would have refuted my claims with expedition and force. The only public revelation that has occurred on the matter was made in the Australian Financial Review on Tuesday, 10 November, in the article headed `$278m hole found in Qld Police super scheme fund'. I seek leave to table the Financial Review article.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first paragraph of that article reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Qld Government has been deeply embarrassed by an actuarial report which has found a $278 million deficit in the State Police Superannuation Fund.

As for the whole of the fund's actuarial assessment, that does not seem to have been done since about 1985, and there is even some doubt about the extent of that. If that is true, then the Queensland Government cannot claim to have fully funded superannuation. Its defence, according to the Financial Review article, is that the deficit is more than offset by the `substantial surplus' in other funds. There cannot be reserves within a consolidated revenue fund of a State.

PARA.TAB: The next question posed in the Financial Review article is: how substantial is that surplus? The Queensland Treasurer was unable to answer that question because, according to the article, the next actuarial report on the major combined fund is not due until next year. To my knowledge, no actuarial reports on the various public sector superannuation funds operated by the Queensland Government have been published in the last few years. How could he then have claimed that full funding occurs? Would a more appropriate answer to the Senate Select Committee's questions on unfunding not have been, `We are not sure on whether we are fully funded as no recent actuarial or audit investigation has been carried out, but we will tell you next year or some time in the future'?

If the Queensland Government is unable to provide an adequate rebuttal to the various serious points that have been raised in relation to the position of their employee superannuation, and it still maintains the position of full funding, I suggest that perhaps it should be seeking the services of some independent experts—say, our own Commonwealth Auditor-General, or even the Auditor-General from Tasmania, who recently reported on the position in that State in terms of the need for some sort of standard to be applied to public sector superannuation.

This case highlights the need for Commonwealth and State governments to convene a summit on public sector superannuation debt, and to come to an agreed position about the definition of public superannuation debt and the methods of measuring it, and the ways and means of reducing it. This is absolutely essential. To my knowledge, South Australia, Western Australia and Queensland are prepared to come to the party and address the problem as part of a national initiative. It is time the Commonwealth and the other States were of the same inclination.

If the Queensland Government is unable to point me in the direction of a fund which contains assets equal to all its superannuation liabilities for both present and previous employees, and if it is unable to point to actuarial and audit material which validates its claim regarding full superannuation, then it is highly likely that the Committee on which I sit, the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, has been misled. Misleading a Senate committee is an offence under parliamentary privilege, but more importantly, it seriously undermines the public perception and confidence in the work of parliamentary committees if agencies seeking the truth are not given correct information. I look forward to receiving a response, preferably from the Queensland Treasurer, to the issues I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition is not opposing this Bill, which deals with a number of Bills and amendments to them which we support. I have some notes in relation to each of them which set out the reasons why we are supporting them and I seek leave to incorporate those comments in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: CRIMES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Coalition is not opposing the passage of this omnibus Bill, which makes amendments to a number of Acts. I will confine my comments to the main provisions of the Bill.

Part 2 of the Bill deals with amendments to the Cash Transactions Reports Act, most of which have been recommended to the Attorney-General by the Ministerial Advisory Group on the Operation of the Cash Transactions Reports Act.

Pursuant to these amendments, the account verification scheme will be modified to make it more flexible. The amendments in proposed new section 21A also make special provision with respect to certain specified groups of people who have changed their name. These groups are—
people who change their name on marriage;
people who revert to a former name, having previously been known by the name of a spouse;
people who change their name to protect their personal safety, having been victims of violence or threatened violence; and
people who are Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander, and change their name to a traditional name.
People in these circumstances will be able to use a referee procedure to become a signatory to an account without having to meet the usual requirements in relation to documentation.

These amendments have been made in consultation with the cash dealing industry, and the Opposition is supporting them. We note the Minister's statement on the financial impact of this Bill that the changes to the account verification provisions may reduce the costs of compliance to cash dealers.

In its amendments to the Crimes Act 1914, Part 3 of this Bill introduces a penalty unit scheme into Commonwealth legislation, as recommended by the Gibbs Committee's Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law. Presently, maximum fines for offences against Commonwealth legislation are expressed in terms of dollars. Over time, inflation tends to render the amounts of the prescribed fines unrealistic; and the only way to remedy the problem has been to amend each individual provision.
These amendments set the value of a penalty unit at $100.

Future legislation will prescribe the maximum number of penalty units for a particular offence. The Bill also provides a simple formula for converting certain penalties expressed in dollar figures in existing legislation, to penalty units.

In future, to reflect any change in the value of money, all pecuniary penalties for offences against Commonwealth legislation will be able to be adjusted, through a single amendment to the value of a penalty unit in the Crimes Act.
The penalty unit scheme will not apply to section 76 of the Trade Practices Act, or national scheme laws under the Australian Securities Commission Act.

This Bill also amends section 15B of the Crimes Act, in relation to the time of commencement for prosecutions. At present, prosecutions may be commenced at any time if the offence attracts a maximum period of imprisonment of six months or more. In respect of other offences, prosecution must commence within one year of the commission of the offence.

However, this has obvious shortcomings when the offender is a body corporate, as periods of imprisonment are not prescribed for offences which can only be committed by corporations. Prosecutions, irrespective of the seriousness of the offence, must always be commenced within one year.

The proposed amendments to section 15B provide that prosecutions of corporations may be commenced at any time if the maximum penalty for the offence is a fine of 150 penalty units—$15,000—or more. Where the penalty is less than this amount, prosecutions must be commenced within one year of the commission of the offence.

This Bill further amends the Crimes Act as recommended by the Gibbs Committee's Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, by limiting the circumstances in which a court is restricted in imposing prison sentences by section 17A of the Act. The present provision, criticised by the committee as too general, is that where a person who has not previously been sentenced to imprisonment is convicted of an offence relating to property or money whose total value is less than $2,000, the court is not to impose a sentence of imprisonment unless there are exceptional circumstances.

Pursuant to the amendments in this Bill, this limitation on the court's sentencing power will only apply to offences against a limited number of specified provisions of the Crimes Act, and prescribed provisions of other federal laws.

The Bill inserts a new part IV into the Crimes Act, relating to piracy. These amendments were recommended by the Australian Law Reform Commission in its report on Criminal Admiralty Jurisdiction and Prize, in which serious shortcomings of present piracy law were identified. Principal among those shortcomings is the fact that the piracy law in Australia is presently dictated by a number of outdated Imperial Acts, such as the Piracy Act 1670. A list of these Acts to be repealed is in Schedule 2 of the Bill.
In the amendments, "act of piracy" is defined as in the 1958 Geneva Convention on the High Seas, to mean:
an act of violence, detention or depredation committed for private ends by the crew or passengers of a private ship or aircraft and directed:
(a) if the act is done on the high seas or any coastal sea of Australia against another ship or aircraft or against persons or property on board another ship or aircraft; or
(b) if the act is done in a place beyond the jurisdiction of any country against a ship, aircraft, persons or property.

The limitation to acts committed "for private ends" has been criticised in the past, because it is capable of being read as excluding some acts of politically motivated terrorism. However, the Law Reform Commission took the view that such acts would in any case be covered by the hijacking-related offences in the Crimes (Aviation) act and the recently-passed Crimes (Ships and Fixed Platforms) Act.
The amendments to the Crimes Act in this Bill seem to us sensible and timely—in some cases well overdue—and we are supporting them.

Amendments to the Customs Act 1901 provide for the Commissioner of Police or a Deputy Commissioner of Police to make decisions about the disposal of narcotic goods and narcotic-related goods. Further amendments enable the Court, on the application of various parties, to direct the Official Trustee to pay a pecuniary penalty from property held under a restraining order.

The Bill also amends the Director of Public Prosecutions Act 1983. It broadens the power of the Director to grant indemnities in respect of proceedings under the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, Division 3 of Part XIII of the Customs Act 1901, and forfeiture of goods under the Customs Act.
Further amendments relate to appearances by and on behalf of the Director of Public Prosecutions, delegation by the Director and service of process on the Director.

The amendments in Part 9 of the Bill to the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Act 1987 will enable Australia to comply with the Council of Europe Convention on Laundering, Search, Seizure and Confiscation of the Proceeds from Crime. The Minister advised in his speech on the second reading of this Bill that Australia is likely to accede to this Convention.

Specifically, the amendments provide that documents are admissible in evidence if they are provided by a party to the Money-Laundering Convention, where the proceeding arises from a request made by a foreign country for international assistance in a criminal matter.

The Coalition also welcomes the extension of the definition of "proceeds of crime" in the Proceeds of Crimes Act 1987. Currently, not all foreign offences are covered only those which are narcotic related. By this extension of the definition, other serious foreign offences will be covered, such as arms trafficking and kidnapping.

This Bill also makes minor amendments, which the Coalition is supporting, to the Crimes (Aviation) Act 1991, the Crimes (Biological Weapons) Act 1976, the Crimes (Superannuation Benefits) Act 1989, and the Australian Federal Police Act 1979.
In conclusion, the amendments in this Bill are not controversial, and the Coalition is supporting its passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the cooperative spirit in which that very expeditious process was undertaken, I thank the Opposition and the Senate for their support of this legislation and wish it the speedy passage it deserves.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The respective agreements under the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1992 cover the various forms of income flows between Australia and Indonesia, Australia and Vietnam, and Australia and Spain. The coalition concurs with the Government's view that the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment and wider relationships between Australia and the treaty partners. Relief from double taxation is desirable, for without it the expansion of trade and the movement of capital and people between countries could be harmed. In addition, the Bill clarifies the taxation position of income flows between the various countries.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make specific reference to the agreement with Vietnam because it is a regional partner and a neighbour of Australia. It is emerging as a country not only with considerable strategic importance to Australia, but also with increasing economic importance. In particular, the level of trade and investment indicates Vietnam is emerging as one of Australia's major regional trading partners. Such major contracts as a 25-year contract between BHP and Petro-Vietnam for the exploration of oil and gas reserves over the central east coast of Da Nang as well as the granting of a banking licence to the ANZ Bank are some of the many examples that are available.

Vietnam is increasingly being viewed as a predominantly untapped market for trade and investment. There has been a steady rise in both exports and imports over the past few years. One of the major factors contributing to this economic relationship is the current US trade and aid embargo which has precluded US and Japanese trade and investment. This has presented Australia with a window of opportunity to strengthen the economic position in Vietnam.

Coupled with this advantage has been the factor that since 1987 Vietnam has been actively pursuing a policy of reconstruction which is an attempt to introduce a capitalist economic system as rapidly as possible while maintaining the socialist political system. It is stated in the country's constitution that foreign investment and cooperation is encouraged and that foreign enterprises will not be nationalised. Therefore, along with the Government the coalition is pleased that Australia is the first country with which Vietnam has entered into a double taxation agreement.

Further, the coalition is pleased that a feature of the agreement with Vietnam is to provide tax sparing credit relief by Australia for tax forgone by Vietnam under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment. I think there is a need for me to stress that Vietnam should become a recognised tax treaty country having comparable tax status, which I think is very important if we are going to allow this trade to develop on a proper basis. In view of the time, I seek the leave of the Senate to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, today I rise to comment on the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1992. This Bill will amend the Income Tax (International Agreements) Act of 1953 to give the force of law in Australia to three comprehensive agreements for the avoidance of double taxation and the prevention of fiscal evasion with respect to taxes on income.
The respective agreements cover the various forms of income flows between Australia and Indonesia, Australia and Vietnam and Australia and Spain.

Any taxpayer who for the purposes of the agreements are residents of one of the two countries party to that agreement and who derive income, profits or gains from the other country will be affected by the agreements in the Bill.

The agreement with Indonesia was signed on 22 April, 1992; the agreement with Vietnam was signed on 13 April, 1992; whilst the agreement with Spain was signed on the 24 March, 1992. This bill before us today is the final stage in the necessary constitutional processes to give the agreements the force of law. These agreements generally accord with the other comprehensive taxation agreements concluded by Australia in recent years.

The Coalition concurs with the Government's view that the agreements will contribute positively to the strengthening of trade, investment and wider relationships between Australia and the treaty partner countries. Relief from double taxation is desirable for without it, the expansion of trade and the movement of capital and people between countries could be harmed. In addition, the Bill clarifies the taxation position of income flows between the countries.
Of the three countries—Spain, Indonesia and Vietnam—who have signed this agreement with Australia, the Coalition has a number of comments to make with regard to Vietnam.

Vietnam, a regional neighbour of Australia, is emerging as a country with not only considerable strategic importance to Australia, but also with increasing economic importance. In particular, the level of trade and investment indicates that Vietnam is emerging as one of Australia's major regional trading partners. Such major contracts as a 25 year contract between BHP and Petro-Vietnam, for the exploration and exploitation of oil and gas reserves over the central east coast of Da Nang as well as the granting of a banking licence to the ANZ Bank, are but two of the many examples available.

Vietnam is increasingly being viewed as a predominantly untapped market for trade and investment and there has been a steady rise in both exports and imports over the past several years. One of the major factors contributing to this economic relationship is the current US Trade and Aid Embargo which has precluded US and Japanese trade and investment.
This has presented Australia with a window of opportunity to strengthen its economic position in Vietnam.

Coupled with this advantage has been the factor that since 1987, Vietnam has been actively pursuing a policy of `reconstruction' which is an attempt to introduce as rapidly as possible a capitalist economic system while maintaining the socialist political system. It is stated in the country's constitution that foreign investment and co-operation is encouraged and that foreign enterprises will not be nationalised.

Therefore, along with the Government, the Coalition is pleased that Australia is the first country with which Vietnam has entered into a double taxation agreement. Further, the Coalition is pleased that a feature of the agreement with Vietnam is that it provides for `tax sparing' credit relief to be extended by Australia for tax forgone by Vietnam under specified development incentives for the encouragement of foreign investment.

Consequently, where income derived by an Australian resident taxpayer has benefited from the development incentives to be nominated under the agreement, a tax credit will be allowed by Australia for the Vietnamese tax forgone under those incentive measures. The Government believes that by this means the development incentives will retain their attractiveness for Australian firms and allow them to compete for business in Vietnam on favourable terms with investors from other countries.

Although the Coalition welcomes this move, it believes that the Government has not gone far enough. It needs to go one further step if it is going to encourage this aforementioned mine of trade and investment. This step is one where the Government not only has this double tax agreement, but also recognises Vietnam as a comparable tax country.

By recognising Vietnam as a comparable tax country, the onerous compliance burdens currently imposed by Australia's complex rules for taxing foreign income would be removed. These rules currently act as an impediment to the already mentioned significant trade and investment by Australia into Vietnam.
This Chamber should note that in terms of authorised foreign investment capital, Australia was, as at June 1991, the second largest source (behind Taiwan) of joint venture investment in Vietnam.

This Bill today verifies that the Australian Government already considers Vietnam's tax system to be comparable to that of Australia. At the time of the introduction of the foreign source income provisions, it was stated that listing of a country as having a tax system comparable to that of Australia requires its tax system to meet certain indicative criteria. Vietnam now meets these criteria as stated in the document entitled `Taxation of Foreign Source Income Information Paper'—April, 1989. In particular,

PARA.TAB: 1direct taxation is levied on income or profits;
2the corporate tax base is comprehensive in that it includes any income accruing from the business activities of an enterprise; and thus includes income from the disposal of capital assets;

3any tax incentives provided by Vietnam Government do not facilitate international profit shifting. Incentives are only provided to specific business projects, which have to be formally approved and carried out in Vietnam; and

4the standard corporate tax rate for foreign investors is 25% (except banking, oil and gas and rare resources, where it may be higher than 25%). Any reduction in this rate is designed to attract active business activities on a similar basis to the other tax regimes within the region which are listed.

SPEECH.PARA: Therefore, since Vietnam already meets the requirements set for listing as a comparable tax country, this Government should not hesitate in listing Vietnam as a listed country on Schedule 10 for the purposes of Part X of the ITAA and give Vietnam not only double tax status, but comparable tax status.

It is worth noting that all of Australia's other double tax treaty partners are listed countries for the purposes of Part X of the Act. When one considers that the Australian Government has already publicly recognised and supported the need to implement measures to position Australia to take advantage of the growth in the Vietnamese economy, the Coalition can only query why the comparable tax status has not been granted.

I would like to remind this Government of what the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, Mr John Kerin, stated following a visit of Australian Business representatives at the second annual meeting of the Joint Trade and Economic Co-operation Committee in Vietnam. Mr Kerin said and I quote:

Vietnam . . . is of considerable strategic importance to Australia and will become a country of great economic significance to Australia as well . . . I am aware of the need to position Australia to take advantage of the anticipated growth in the Vietnamese economy once the US trade and aid embargo has been lifted and large-scale multilateral bank lending resumes.

Therefore, if Vietnam was listed as a comparable tax country, compliance burdens imposed by the Controlled Foreign Company (CFC) would no longer act as a significant impediment to Australian investment in Vietnam.

Therefore, Mr President, although the Coalition supports the bill before us today, it requests that the Government re-examines its view towards listing Vietnam as a comparable tax country for foreign source income measures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Watson for his support for the Income Tax (International Agreements) Amendment Bill 1992. It is always important that these Bills get dealt with expeditiously but nevertheless sensibly. They are never the most earth shattering pieces of legislation before the Parliament, but they are very important to Australian taxpayers and they are very important to Australian businesses. They have a significant capacity to ensure that Australian businesses can continue to operate in a competitive manner in countries that are important to us.

PARA.TAB: Last night at an OECD forum I had the opportunity to discuss these issues about double tax agreements, their tax significance and their significance for our trade position, with a number of representatives from other countries, many of whom are seeking to enter into new international agreements with Vietnam as we are.This is legislation that it is important for the Parliament to pass; it is important that we do not dwell on it and waste the time of the Parliament but it is also important that we acknowledge the very good work of the officers who were involved and thank the officers concerned for their cooperation. I commend the Bill to the Parliament.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Leader of the Government in the Senate to today's disastrous official unemployment figures, which reveal another record for this Labor Government—the record rate of unemployment at 11.3 per cent, or 980,000 people unemployed. Since the Keating Government's economic manifesto One Nation was released, unemployment has risen by over 70,000, and the unemployment rate has risen from 10.5 per cent to 11.3 per cent, rather than falling to 10 per cent as was predicted in that statement. I therefore ask the Minister to address two specific questions: first, does the Government still hold to the view that the recession ended long ago; and secondly, does the Minister rule out the possibility that unemployment could rise further?

—The unemployment rate which Senator Hill refers to is, of course, a tragedy. The rate increased not because people lost jobs but because more of the people without jobs said they were looking for work or—
—Oh!
—That is true. The unemployment rate changed because of an increase in the participation rate, and these figures vary from month to month—
—Why are they doing that?
—Well, a couple of months ago, Senator, fewer people were looking for work and the participation rate, of course, fell and the unemployment rate fell.

PARA.TAB: Employment actually rose by 25,800 people in October. I do not pretend that the rate of increase of employment has the capacity at this stage to absorb new entrants to the labour force and reduce the number of unemployed in the economy. This will happen as recovery improves.However, at the moment, despite trend growth in employment for the past seven months, the unemployment rate is yet to respond.

Senator Hill asked me a question in two parts. In relation to the second part, monthly figures in relation to employment and unemployment vary. The unemployment figure is up for this month of October; the employment figure is also up for this month of October; and that is a trend which has been followed for the past seven months. Insofar as the first part of the question is concerned, about the ending of the recession, as I have said on a number of occasions in this place, the consequences of the recession are not over—I have said that in the last month or so—and the major consequence is in terms of unemployment.

I should just make the point that the Budget forecast for 1992-93 was based on an assumed growth in OECD major trading partners of 2 per cent. The OECD growth rate was already factored into the Australian growth rate forecast, and that is why the Treasurer yesterday confirmed the 3 per cent growth forecast for 1992-93. There are a number of reasons why we can grow faster than a number of other economies in the OECD, and that is encouraging in the medium term.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I find that an astonishing explanation. The Minister seems to be trying to explain away this tragedy by arguing that more people in Australia want work, as if there were some inherent evil in that. But, as I read the statistics, they say that unemployment has increased by a further 52,200 since last month and is now the highest level recorded by the survey. I ask the Minister: in the light of these terrible figures, does the Government plan any change in its economic policies, or can a very depressed Australia expect more of the same?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —That issue is a matter of great difference between us and the Opposition. In terms of government expenditure on unemployment, job creation and so on, the Opposition has a completely different view from us. The OECD has just remarked that countries should postpone any plan to tighten fiscal policy and that there is scope for further monetary easing in a number of countries.

PARA.TAB: Mr Ferguson, the Chief Executive of BT, a very respected banker in this country, said yesterday:

ANSWER.PARA: Cutting deficits . . . would force down profitability in the private sector. . . It will force people to shed labour and that's shedding consumers as well, and it will be a self-defeating process. . .
That is precisely what the Opposition is committed to doing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are offering more of the same.
—And not worse, as the Opposition is offering.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I ask the Minister: what is the Australian Government doing to assist those Australians reported to be stranded in Bulgaria because of the extended delay in the departure of their charter flight to Australia?

—There has been a degree of concern expressed about this situation in a number of quarters. Let me describe what is happening. Some 200 Australians have been stranded in Bulgaria since last Thursday because of financial difficulties allegedly being experienced by the air charter company, JES Air—Jupiter Electronic Services. That figure could swell if the delay continues because of travellers expecting to connect with another JES Air flight scheduled to depart Sofia today, 12 November.

PARA.TAB: Our Embassy in Athens has been watching developments closely. Until yesterday, we were satisfied that JES Air was taking appropriate measures to at least accommodate and assist the inconvenienced passengers. Concerns that JES Air will no longer be able to do that due to continuing financial difficulties, coupled with an increasing concern that it will not be able to provide an aircraft at all, prompted the Embassy to dispatch two officers to Sofia. An Australian consular officer and a locally engaged assistant are scheduled to arrive in Sofia later today to assess the extent of consular assistance required. The consular office has been given flexibility to provide immediate financial assistance to those affected. I expect a report from them shortly after their arrival.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Given that this Government, in accord with the trade union movement, has delivered record postwar unemployment to Australia, will the Minister demand that his partners in the trade union movement call off their national day of strike action on 30 November?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The closest economy to what the Opposition wishes to introduce in Australia in industrial relations is the United States economy. It has a low level of union membership, individual work contracts and no access to an arbitration commission for the imposition of fair outcomes in industrial disputes. As a working model, it is an economy which has had very low—in fact, almost zero—economic growth during the whole period of Reaganomics. So I would not want to stand on the Opposition's proposal, which is a doctrinaire industrial relations proposal from another age that is no longer appropriate.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Yet again we are being treated to a dissertation from this Minister which has absolutely no relevance to the question asked. What the Australian community wants to know is whether this Minister will call off the action proposed by his partners in the trade union movement regarding national strike action. His answer has no relevance to this question whatsoever.
—Order! There is no point of order. However, I ask the Minister to relate his answer to the question that he was asked.

—I was replying to the point in the first part of the question about the Opposition's industrial relations policy. However, in answer to the question, I would think the signal act which would bring Victoria to a position in which it could return to the comparative industrial calm it enjoyed up until now would be for Mr Kennett to indicate that he is prepared to withdraw his Bill, sit down and negotiate a genuine industrial relations regime in that State, rather than act as he has. In those circumstances I think Senator Chapman is best directed—since he is in the same party as Mr Kennett—to mediate with him to do that and overcome the problems in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: In the case of the trade union movement, I have made it clear that the most sensible course of action is to fall in behind the initiative that I have taken on behalf of the Government and back proposals for an amendment to Federal industrial law to enable those covered by State awards to escape the jurisdiction of Kennett and come into the Federal arena.

I notice that the ACTU is proposing that and today a major union has indicated that it will support that. That would remove any of the contention in Victoria and enable workers there to have a genuine industrial relations commission and proper and fair award protection.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question to the Minister was quite specific. It related to the proposed national day of strike action on 30 November by his partners in the accord, the trade union movement. We heard a lengthy answer from the Minister which in no way dealt with that question. I simply ask by way of a supplementary question: will the Minister answer the specific question I put to him, that is, where does he stand in regard to this national day of strike action and will he ask his partners in the union movement to call it off?
—It is a simple question.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a flawed question because it does not accurately deal with what is the case. The case is that the ACTU has asked for a national day of protest. If the honourable senator had watched the news last night he would have seen members of the New South Wales Labour Council declare that for them that will mean an educative campaign and not industrial action.

PARA.TAB: I would hope that the educative campaign will spread throughout Australia and people really do clearly understand the threat to their liberties and the threat to their wages and incomes that the Kennett legislation poses.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to a statement by the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations, Mr Howard, that he will not release details of the coalition's `Jobsack' policy as he does not have the assistance of a parliamentary draftsman. I ask the Minister, in the spirit of bipartisan cooperation, has or is the Government prepared to offer Mr Howard access to parliamentary lawyers so that the Australian voter will be able to judge the merits of the Government's best and fairest individual industrial policy? Does the Government support Mr Howard in his veiled attack on Mr Kennett when he said the eventual legislation `would not contain things that weren't disclosed in the campaign' and that he regarded the restoration of trust in politicians as `being very important to the political process'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say that any politician in Australia who simply stands up and says `trust me' without any explanation is courting disaster and is in the same league as the snake oil and used car salesmen who peddle themselves under the dubious title of `honest' as a prefix to their own names. I have here, and now table, a Bill which was proposed by Senator Chaney as the shadow Minister for industrial relations in 1990.
—Mr President, I rise to a point of order.
—You don't like this, do you?

—I am tempted to let the Minister continue because he is making such a fool of himself. His policies have contributed to a million people being unemployed. The point of order is that Question Time is for the Minister to answer for his administration—that administration which has helped to contribute to a million people being unemployed—not to question whether Mr Howard needs the assistance of some draftsman from Senator Cook's office or to reproduce a Bill of Senator Chaney's. What relevance has that to this Government's mismanagement of the economy? With a million unemployed, he should stand up and justify that.
—Order! That is a matter for debate, Senator Hill. The Minister is entitled to respond to matters which come within areas of his responsibility. I ask him to do that.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. Just how does the Opposition's policy come within the Minister's responsibility? Could you make that clear to the chamber, or else Question Time breaks down into a ceaseless attack on the Opposition's policy by the Government.
—Senator Kemp, I do not know whether you heard me, but I reminded the Minister of what he should do at Question Time.

—I must say that I am surprised that the Opposition does not think that a Bill on industrial relations has anything to do with the portfolio of industrial relations. I table this Bill produced by Senator Chaney in 1990.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. As I understand the Standing Orders, the Minister is entitled to table material which is ministerial material. However, this is a former shadow Minister's private member's Bill over which he has no care or control and, as such, he would need leave to table it. I for one will not be granting leave.
—Order! The Minister is in order in tabling whatever document he wishes.

—I table as well a press statement by Senator Chaney at the time of proposing his Bill. I note for the record of the Senate that on 16 August 1989 Senator Chaney introduced the Industrial Relations (Directions to Stop Industrial Action) Bill 1989. When Mr Howard was making this plea to `trust me' he said that `the Opposition has never produced a Bill'. That is a misleading and incorrect statement. Here is a Bill, and here is a reference to a Bill, actually introduced into this chamber.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. Again, this is an abuse of Question Time. This is not a Minister standing and accounting for his administration at all. This is not what Question Time is supposed to be about. It is not an examination of Opposition policy. The Minister can come in after Question Time and we will have a debate on Opposition policy.
—What is your point of order?
—I have just told you. Why don't you listen?
—Order! There are too many interjections from both sides and I cannot hear the Leader of the Opposition.

—The Minister must answer questions relating to the administration of Government programs. This is not the time for debate of Opposition policy and, Mr President, you should draw the Minister to order. All he has done so far is table a whole series of Opposition documents which are irrelevant to his portfolio.
—Order! He is perfectly entitled to table the documents that he has tabled, but I would remind Senator Cook to answer questions that relate to his areas of responsibility.

—The Government did not support Senator Chaney's Bill in 1989 and it would not have supported his Bill in 1990, although Senator Chaney, as the shadow spokesman for industrial relations, on both the occasions I have referred to did actually produce a Bill. Mr Howard has said that no such Bill was produced by the Opposition. That is not true. This is the politician asking to be trusted. It is not true. He is caught out in an untruth. I ask him now to produce his Bill because the Premier of Victoria, Mr Kennett, was able to produce a Bill three days after the election, but not before the election so the citizens of Victoria could see what he had in store for them.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Firstly, does the Government accept that today's figure of 980,000 Australians unemployed requires urgent short term measures as well as a total rethink of long term policy? Secondly and specifically, will the Government give consideration to the Australian Democrats' proposal for a temporary 1.25 per cent Medicare-style jobs levy to fund 150,000 real jobs in new infrastructure, community service and environmental programs?
—Why not put it up to 10 per cent?
—I thank the honourable senator; he should do that. Thirdly, will the Government also abandon free market ideology in favour of a comprehensive program to revive and develop Australian industry?

—There were a number of questions there but, as I indicated in an answer to Senator Hill earlier, the Government has provided a degree of fiscal stimulus and a consequent increase in the deficit which has been much opposed by people in this community, including the Opposition. Our proposals are considered by the OECD and other commentators to be the most appropriate proposals to deal with high levels of unemployment which are prevalent here and also in countries in North America and Europe. As I say, there has been some criticism of that fiscal stimulus, but the Government believes that is the most appropriate thing to do.

PARA.TAB: I regret that I was not aware of the Democrats 1.25 per cent levy proposal; I would like to see it in some detail before commenting on it. In regard to the free market ideology which Senator Coulter refers to, there is no free market ideology operating anywhere in the world to the extent, for example, which the Opposition would wish it to happen. There is no free market ideology operating in international trade; there is no level playing field in international trade—and this Government has never taken the view that there has been, as distinct from the Opposition.

On the question of short term measures, I would indicate that the Treasurer will be announcing tomorrow a speeding up of some spending under the One Nation program and bringing forward funds which are not being spent fast enough. That will include the design of packages to encourage employers who take on a larger number of currently unemployed people. That is a measure of the Government's ability to make a flexible response to this situation without being weighed down by ideological baggage of the kind referred to by Senator Coulter in the third part of his question, and it is well illustrated by the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his preparedness to consider our 1.25 per cent jobs levy, but point out to him that his Government has presided over increasing inequity in the Australian economy and that we have one of the lowest tax rates in the world. Is it not appropriate, therefore, that those who can should live more simply so that the rest may simply live?
—I have said that if I were given a copy of the proposal by the Democrats, I would then respond to it at an appropriate time. I do not want to take the answer any further than that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Can the Minister advise honourable senators which person said the following:

QUESTION.PARA: It was one of several experiences of that term which emphasised to me the importance of bringing adversarial parties together to make real change happen instead of polarising people and choosing up sides, which often results in paralysis of government programs and not progress.
Does this quote accurately reflect the Government's strategy for cooperative and consensual labour market reform and a high skill-high wage economy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It does accurately reflect the Government's approach to labour market reform—to not polarise the parties, to bring the parties together, to not force them to choose sides, but to encourage, within a framework of cooperation, generating higher levels of productivity and sharing the rewards of that equitably between the shareholders, the customers and the workers who have helped generate it.

PARA.TAB: The author of that quote is not Jeff Kennett, of course. He has pursued in Victoria a confrontationist, divisive policy that has created socially divisive behaviour and threatened the democratic rights of Victorians. He is not the author of that quote. It is not Bob Hawke, although Bob Hawke as the Prime Minister in 1983 brought Australia back together to reconcile the divisions of the Fraser years and to heal the rifts that had been dividing this country. Neither is it John Halfpenny, as I heard Senator Alston interject a moment ago. It is in fact Bill Clinton, the President-elect of the United States, who made that observation in a speech when he was a candidate.

During the US presidential elections, President-elect Clinton campaigned on the fact that consultation and cooperation are the keys to successful change. He also heavily campaigned on the fact that under the unfettered market labour policies of Reagan and Bush, large and growing sections of the labour force were becoming low wage and low skill. These are the policies of Reagan and Bush that we see echoed in Fightback and Jobsback, the policies of the Opposition. Bill Clinton campaigned against that and for consultation and cooperation. He said that the low wage and low skill outcome in the United States was causing growing poverty, deep social unrest and a low productivity outcome for that country.

President-elect Clinton's model focuses very much on improving worker participation in the production process. He has said that he will set up best practice centres. We of course in this country initiated the best practice program. He will now imitate that with best practice centres with a particular focus on worker participation. Mr Clinton's advisers have said that they will work cooperatively with unions in the United States. They will not fight them; they will work with them. They will talk about an `enterprise compact' between unions and corporate managers and some, including Professor Tom Kochan of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, are proposing to the incoming Clinton Administration an accord based along the lines of what we have done in Australia.

What we have here is an incoming President of the United States keen to heal the divisive, reactionary and destructive policies of ultra-conservatism. Yet we have in Australia contesting for electoral approval an ultra-conservative policy from the Opposition—out of time, out of date and out of office.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. It relates to the One Nation statement, which has been long dead but which was buried today. Nearly $1 billion was allocated to road and rail projects.

—One billion. Why does Senator Ray not listen? Is it a fact that hardly any of these projects have come to fruition? —Fortunately for Senator Kemp's conservative State and Territory colleagues, those assertions just made by Senator Kemp are false. —Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Collins is always abusing the privileges of this chamber, but I suggest that he withdraw that slur. It really is unnecessary.

PARA.TAB: I will explain to the Senate, if I am given the opportunity, why some of this slippage has occurred. Now that the Victorian election is over, and as a result of some decisions—

You were in full flight, trying to say something, when Senator Collins, in his typical rude, arrogant style, cut you off. Could we please have a ruling on Senator O'Chee's point of order.
