—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I guess the Minister's answer shows just how careful the planning was under the One Nation statement. One wonders what else will slip because of other people's failure.
—Order! Ask the supplementary question.
—I ask the Minister whether he can tell us precisely how much of the money which he promised to spend this year will not now be spent.
—That information, in the detail that Senator Kemp wants it, cannot be provided in the 60 seconds which is now allowed to me.
—Oh!

—Just wait. All of the information will be provided for Senator Kemp—and I am sure the Manager of Government Business will join me in this—hopefully, in the committee stage of the debate on the estimates for Transport and Communications later today. The facts are that the road spending is on track. But I point out the obvious to Senator Kemp again: all of the road and rail spending which is done by the Federal Government—any Federal government—is done in cooperation with six State and two Territory governments. The matter is being progressed. It is a difficult issue but, despite the difficulty, this Government will press on with it and succeed with it.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Evans. Is the Minister aware that an Australian, Mr David Blyth, has recently attained the honour of being elected as President of the World Blind Union, the peak body of organisations serving the world's estimated 45 million blind people? Is the Government prepared to provide financial assistance to enable Mr Blyth to fulfil his obligations as President of the World Blind Union?
—It is always very important for Australia's image and reputation overseas when a distinguished Australian is elected to head a key international organisation.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure the members of the National Federation of Blind Citizens of Australia, whom Mr Blyth has represented so ably for the past seven years, will be impressed to hear the jeering that is going on as I am trying to give this answer! Mr Blyth, I am sure, will serve his four-year term as President of the World Blind Union with exactly the same distinction that he brought to his presidency of the Australian body.

PARA.TAB: I understand he himself was blinded as a teenager in an accident with explosives. Since then he has acquired a great reputation in the community for his tenacity and his ability to organise, which has been of great benefit to the million or so print-handicapped people in this country. The Australian Government congratulates Mr Blyth on his election and is certain that he will represent Australia very well indeed in that important world forum, the focus of whose activity over the next four years will be human rights and consumer focused services.

As to the last part of Senator Aulich's question, I am happy to be able to announce that, in recognition of Mr Blyth's outstanding achievement, the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, has decided that the Government will provide Mr Blyth with $30,000 a year to offset expenses for the four-year term of his presidency. That money will be provided through existing allocations available in the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. To help alleviate today's disastrous official unemployment figures, will the Government abolish its restrictive three-mine uranium policy, particularly now that the socialist Saskatchewan Government in Canada has reversed its longstanding anti-uranium policy? Does the Minister know that Australia, with 30 per cent of the world's low cost uranium reserves and only 10 per cent of the market, now lags behind Canada which has 10 per cent of the reserves and 30 per cent of the market? Is the Minister aware that Australian uranium producers have identified a market window of opportunity from the middle of the decade; if so, will his socialist Cabinet have the guts to reverse the ban in order to signal to the world nuclear power utilities that new mine development is now politically permissible?
—Order! The time has expired.

—The question was too long and became unintelligible. Senator Tambling is in the same camp as his shadow Minister for industry, who invents jobs around the place—looks at particular industries and invents jobs in them, such as food processing, by waving some sort of magic wand from the electorate of Barker—totally based on falsehoods. As far as the three-mine policy is concerned, if the Government at any point changed its mind the appropriate Minister would make an announcement about it. But there is no proposal to change the policy, and there is no proposal to change the policy because it is not believed, amongst other things, that the sort of scenario which Senator Tambling tried to project in his question is a valid one.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Minister's answer shows a lack of fortitude on the part of the Prime Minister and the Government and merely indicates that they are obviously captives of the ideologically outdated socialist left, can the Prime Minister or the Minister not accept the reality that we need to create wealth in this country before it can be redistributed and refocused on social change? I also ask the Minister to comment on the fact that the uranium producers in Australia have identified a window of opportunity. Is he not aware of that in his ministerial portfolio?

—It has nothing to do with my ministerial portfolio and should be directed to the appropriate Minister. Having exposed that particular false premise in Senator Tambling's question, let me say that this Government in its history has been quite prepared to accept a lot of realities which were never accepted by previous governments. If it were a reality, as Senator Tambling put it, we would certainly look at that, but there are no plans to change existing policy.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security. What is the Government doing to rectify the drop in income of British pensioners in Australia which has occurred as a result of the significant fluctuations in sterling over the last two months?
—Senator Zakharov raises a question which is quite dramatically affecting the income of some 110,000—
—Tell us what you are going to do about the unemployed.

—Does Senator Macdonald not want to know about something that really affects people out there? One hundred and ten thousand British pensioners have a vital interest in this, so I would appreciate Senator Macdonald keeping quiet while I give an answer that is of interest to them. There is a problem affecting the pension of some 110,000 British pensioners living in Australia. That problem emanates from the present exchange rate volatility in the pound sterling, a currency which has fallen dramatically and precipitously in value against the Australian dollar in recent weeks.

PARA.TAB: The decrease has been so great and so volatile that it has outstripped mechanisms in the social security legislation which are designed to set exchange rates for purposes of calculating pension entitlements. There are two basic mechanisms in the legislation: one provides that the department sets the exchange rate four times a year, each time setting it for a three-month period; and the other trigger mechanism is designed to provide for sudden and dramatic changes in exchange rates, but this mechanism has proven to be inadequate to cope with last month's volatility in the pound sterling.

At present the exchange rate is $A1 to UK39.14p. There are two problems emanating from that exchange rate valuation: first, the average valuation varied from it during October 1992 by 11.2 per cent; and, secondly, the variations do not reflect the trend for sterling, irrespective of the volatility. Given the failure of the trigger mechanism, we have decided to intervene in the process and to set a new exchange rate based on $A1 to UK44.85p. This rate is based on the average Commonwealth Bank rate during the last two weeks of October and the rate will apply from 19 November.

As I said at the outset, this is an issue of vital concern to some 110,000 British pensioners who live in Australia. Without this intervention there would have been no exchange rate variation until the middle of December. This new exchange rate will increase markedly the value of Australian pensions which top up British pensions paid to so many people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, representing the Treasurer. To what extent does the Government or its Ministers have any influence over the lending policy of the Commonwealth Bank, in which the Government is a majority shareholder and has a controlling interest? Can the Minister guarantee that any such influence has not led to favourable treatment, as against normal terms and conditions and normal processes, being extended by the Commonwealth Bank to persons or companies associated with the Brown and Hatton Group?

—The Commonwealth Government is in no position to exert influence over the Commonwealth Bank in respect of its lending policies. I see the Commonwealth Bank in exactly the same situation as other banks in terms of its lending policies. Some banks are slightly more restrictive than others but they are in exactly the same position.

PARA.TAB: In so far as the question of favourable treatment to any particular company is concerned, the Government is not in a position to influence that situation. Of course, the innuendo in the question is in pursuit of Senator Baume's reputation as being the failed shadow Minister for 100 portfolios.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a supplementary question. Does the Minister's answer mean that the Government has no access whatsoever to information as to whether there are any loans by the Commonwealth Bank to persons or companies associated with the Brown and Hatton Group being in arrears? If so, have normal procedures been adopted as for normal non-performing loans?

—It is not a supplementary question. But let me say that the Government has no access to information from the Commonwealth Bank about individual customers' arrangements with the Bank, and it should not have—nor should it with any bank. The implications of all of the Opposition's questions are, over a period of time, that the Government should interfere between a taxpayer and the Tax Commissioner, that it should have that capacity; and that the Government should interfere between a bank and its customers. That is the sort of grubby behaviour the Opposition would no doubt indulge in if it ever got across to this side of the House.

PARA.TAB: Senator Sowada having addressed a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training—

Senator Hill—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In this instance we have the Australian Democrats requesting that the Minister comment on Opposition policy. I suggest to you that that question is out of order.
Senator Robert Ray—For once I support Senator Hill. I think he is absolutely right.

Senator Sowada—On that point of order: I have asked a question of the Minister related to the issue of a mandate, which has been a very important one debated in this place over the past week or so. The Prime Minister has raised this as an issue in the House of Representatives. I think the Australian public and this Parliament have a right to know exactly where this Government stands on the issues that are of concern to the Australian public. I think the question is in order and I ask the Minister to answer it.

Senator Robert Ray—On that point of order: the honourable senator has asked a question on Opposition policy and then a hypothetical question to a Minister about what he would do in opposition. How that comes within government purview, I simply do not know.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the question was concerned, I thought the only part that was in order was the last part about how the Minister would vote on the issue. I think the question should be re-worded and perhaps re-asked in another way. I uphold the points of order.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to the collapse of the talks on the Cambodia peace process last weekend in Beijing where the Minister attended and to the urgency of the coming Security Council meeting next week. I ask: firstly, what precise proposals will Australia make and present to the Security Council next week? Secondly, what changes in the UN's military role will there be in Cambodia and how will this affect Australia? Thirdly, for how long will Australian troops be required to remain in Cambodia? Finally, will the Minister at long last accept the Opposition's assessment that no trust should be given to the Khmer Rouge, and has he written off any prospect of the Khmer Rouge abiding by last year's agreement?

—As I have said a number of times in answers the other day, and in much more detail in an Estimates committee debate the night before last, it is a false assumption that talks collapsed last week in Beijing. That is premised on the assumption that there was some expectation that something might have come of out those talks which would revitalise the process and deal with the continuing problem of Khmer Rouge non-cooperation.

PARA.TAB: I do not think there was any expectation by anyone going to those talks that that particular issue would be resolved in that way—that the Khmer Rouge would change their position. I think everyone is now proceeding on the working assumption that it is more likely than not that the Khmer Rouge will not come back into the process before the April/May election next year. The planning is proceeding accordingly on the basis of going ahead without them.

TALK.START.PARA: —So Senator Hill was right from day one.

—Senator Hill was not right from day one because, as I have said on a thousand occasions, the whole problem about an attempted solution which sought to exclude the Khmer Rouge from the outset—the so-called tripartite solution which had the other parties grouped together with the support of the international community to somehow isolate the Khmer Rouge—is that it did not deal with the fundamental problem of external support for the parties concerned.

PARA.TAB: A Khmer Rouge isolated but with continuing military and other support from the Chinese Government in particular and others playing a supporting role as well, was a very much more dangerous proposition than a Khmer Rouge isolated without that support. That is the situation we have at the moment: the Khmer Rouge isolated within a continuing process to which the rest of the international community is wholly committed. The international community—those of them represented at the meeting in Beijing last week—made that commitment abundantly clear, and that was the most heartening thing, I believe, about those talks.

As Senator Teague said, the matter is going to be dealt with in the Security Council, probably next week. Australia is not a member of the Security Council so we will not, as such, be putting proposals to it. But, as I said in answer to a question the other day, we have been actively involved in Beijing in particular in seeking to move the discussion forward as to the contents of that resolution. As I said at great length in the Appropriations debate the night before last, I am not in a position publicly to go into any great detail about the content of those discussions at the moment. Considerations of confidentiality must apply.

But as to the specific question Senator Teague asks on the military issue, the situation in a nutshell is this: the current peace settlement was premised on the assumption that the military would be able, to a significant extent, to be drawn down—the 15,900 of them that are there at the moment—about now on the basis that a considerable amount of demobilisation would have been achieved under the peace plan. In the absence of that demobilisation that is not now able to happen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has failed to give any specifics in his answer. I ask him again: what new requirements will there be of the military commitment of Australians in Cambodia? How long will they be required to remain there? I ask the Minister whether he is, by the vagueness of his response now, in the Appropriations debate on Tuesday and in answer to Senator Loosley, repeating his helplessness as expressed last Tuesday to the Sydney Morning Herald when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: The main thing is to accentuate the positive, find the common ground, keep working away and keep our fingers crossed.
What more is the Minister doing than `keeping his fingers crossed'?

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister, by the care with which he is expressing himself on this occasion, is behaving with the diplomatic responsibility that he normally shows when involved in high level negotiations with an obligation of confidentiality attached to them. I do not expect Senator Teague to understand that but I hope he puts it away for future reference because it is a relevant, ongoing consideration. Had I had the time that the three-minute time constraint allows and that the supplementary one now allows me to deal with the matter for a little longer, I would have said just a little bit more about the military situation. I will do so in the time available.

PARA.TAB: The peace plan was premised on the assumption that some battalions would be returning about now. So far as the Australian contribution was concerned, that was never part of our understanding. We were always, because we are a key logistic communications unit, going to stay there for the duration, that is, until after the election process is complete. That will continue to be the case.

The present assumption is that in the absence of Khmer Rouge cooperation, in the absence of a complete demobilisation or a 70 per cent demobilisation as provided for under the plan, it will not be possible for any battalions to return home; it will certainly not be desirable. That is a matter that I do expect to be addressed in the Security Council resolution next week. If that is not precise enough for Senator Teague, I cannot help him.

TALK.START.PARA: —While my question relates to the ban on homosexuals in the ADF, I am asking it of the Minister representing the Attorney-General because of the human rights aspects of the issue. I refer to today's Age newspaper article where it is reported that some senior Government figures believe there would be `adverse electoral consequences' if the ban was lifted. I ask: what are the `difficulties in getting agreement' to which Mr Duffy refers? What are the `adverse electoral consequences' that seem to be perturbing key Government figures? Are they saying that the community in Australia has no respect at all for the advances that have been made over the past decade in the areas of human rights, equal opportunity and anti-discrimination? Are these powerful forces within the Government saying that in Australia in 1992 it is a negative thing to fulfil this nation's human rights obligations? Why are we so different from Canada, where the ban has recently been lifted, and the United States, where President-elect Clinton intends to remove the ban?

—I believe this is an important issue, but I think that Senator Powell has put it quite wrongly, both in the premise to her question and in some of the content of it. It is not that anything particularly dramatic is being undertaken, except a proper and due process within the Parliamentary Labor Party and within the Executive Government in order to come to a good decision in relation to this matter. The fact that it has taken a little longer than some might have anticipated is simply a tribute to the consultation and deliberation which are being undertaken in order that that proper decision be eventually made.

PARA.TAB: It is also important to refute the suggestion within Senator Powell's question that there is any embarrassment that we as a government should bear in relation to remarks about our record on human rights, equal opportunity and anti-discrimination over the past decade. In fact, in the last decade in Australia, this Federal Government has been at the forefront of coming to this Parliament time and time again with legislation advancing those matters.

I remember Senator Susan Ryan in this chamber being absolutely crucified, even driven to distraction, by honourable senators opposite over the Sex Discrimination Act, which is now regarded as one of the great pieces of legislation passed into the statute book of this Parliament. So, over the past decade, there has been nothing but extremely good progress made by this Government in all those areas. It is on the basis and the foundation of that well demonstrated and well illustrated commitment that I believe that a proper decision will be arrived at after due deliberation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services to his statement yesterday regarding his commitment to the ban on tobacco advertising. I ask the Minister how he can explain the inconsistency of the Government allocating $413,000 in this year's Budget for tobacco growing research while at the same time 20,000 Australians die prematurely every year from diseases due to smoking. I also ask: why the delay, when the cost of treating tobacco related disease exceeds sponsorship by a factor of 40 to one?

—In so far as the question relates to support for a particular pastoral industry of the farming sector within Australia, that is a matter for the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, and I am not briefed on this matter. But in so far as the Government has a commitment to breaking the nexus between allurement and tempting advertising and the nexus between sport and cultural events and tobacco use within this country, we are absolutely committed. I believe that the deferral that has taken place to allow further discussion on some of the minor matters within the Bill that was proposed is simply that—a deferral. This Government will achieve its objective, which is shared by all members of the Government.

PARA.TAB: I believe that what is important is not simply a negative approach—breaking, as I say, the nexus between the allurement and attraction of this wedding between sport and cultural events and the promotion of tobacco—but a positive approach. For that reason, for example, drug offensive ambassadors have been appointed.

Stephen Hawkins, the Olympic gold medal winner from Tasmania, has visited 30 Tasmanian schools over recent weeks to talk to youngsters about the perils of indulging in smoking tobacco products. He has pointed to his great success as being dependent on saying `no' to the use of that legally available drug. I believe that he is having a dramatic impact because, of course, youngsters look up to sporting heroes as role models, allowing them to be influenced in a way which would not occur if they just received sermons from politicians, medical luminaries from the AMA, police commissioners or whoever.

So I believe that this needs to be approached in a comprehensive way. Under the drug abuse and drug offensive programs of the Government under the joint jurisdiction of the police and health Ministers, there is a comprehensive strategy in regard to the use of tobacco products in Australian society. I believe that we are doing much to reduce the incidence of disease and death which is occasioned by tobacco use.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In light of the Minister's statement about a deferral, can he give us an assurance that the Manager of Government Business in the other place will put the Bill on the Notice Paper in a position which will ensure its passage this year?
—I am not in charge of government business in the House of Representatives, but I will certainly pass the suggestion to the Manager of Government Business there.
—Order! In calling Senator Sowada I point out that it is the Government's turn for a question.

—I ask the Minister for Employment, Education, and Training: has the Labor Government adopted a policy position related to upfront, full cost fees and further restrictions on Austudy, such as those which were contained in the Budget? If not, how does the Government explain Austudy changes in the recent Budget which partially implemented the Fightback package and further moves to deregulate fees for postgraduate degrees by course work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to answer this rephrased version of the earlier question. The Government has answered the question on its commitment made by the Prime Minister on the consumption tax proposal of the Opposition. Senator Button has done that several times in this chamber and drawn carefully the delineation between Supply and tax Bills.

PARA.TAB: In terms of the Opposition's proposal on higher education—which is a fees and voucher proposal and a proposal which reduces access to higher education and favours those who are wealthy in society—the Government would not be disposed to pass that legislation. We would need to see it, but I think we would not be disposed to pass it and I do not think that what the Prime Minister meant the other day referred to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. I refer him to the Prime Minister's address to the Small Business Forum when he committed $4m over two years to promote Australian made products. In that address the Prime Minister gave a commitment to fast track legislation to have clear definitions of the terms `made in Australia' and `product of Australia'. Will the Government give an undertaking to include in that legislation an increase in country of origin size of labelling from 1.5 millimetres to three millimetres as requested by food processing firms under section 17 of the National Food Authority Act and rejected by the National Food Authority? Is the Minister also aware that two million kilograms of Canadian pork have been sold in Australia without country of origin labelling? Can the Minister also include in the legislation a requirement for unpackaged meat to join the category of unpackaged fruit, fish and nuts which carry country of origin labels of 4.5 millimetres at the point of sale?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the question of the proper labelling of foods available to Australian consumers is very important. The fact that their origin may be from within Australia or outside Australia, either in a simple form or as an ingredient, ought to be made known to Australian consumers so that they can make choices which we would hope favour Australian farmers, fishermen and the like.

PARA.TAB: In relation to packaged foods, where it is a requirement that a country of origin statement or label be attached, the National Food Authority recently rejected some applications to increase the size of the label from 1.5 millimetres to three millimetres. I was surprised at that and I note with pleasure that the Prime Minister asked Premiers and Chief Ministers only two or three days ago, on 9 November, to take part in working groups to ensure a solid, universally applicable basis for assessing whether something is in fact Australian made.
Within that there is an accompanying press release from the Minister for Consumer Affairs, Mrs McHugh, which states:

ANSWER.PARA: The Prime Minister is asking Premiers and Chief Ministers for ideas on how country of origin labelling can be made more effective and informative.

I believe that to be effective and informative one has to have a legible and clear indication. Whether that requires questions about background colouring, differentiation and prominence, which are in addition to or different from the question of the size of labelling, would be a matter for proper discussion.

PARA.TAB: Senator Boswell also asked about unpackaged meat and meat products generally coming into Australia. It is true that when I was Minister for Consumer Affairs we required that unpackaged fish, vegetables, fruit and nuts have a label attached of 4.5 millimetres in size indicating the country of origin. I believe we need to go beyond particular categories. It would not be much to add meat, because then some other category would require some particular labelling. We need a consistent declaration of country of origin on all foods, especially ingredients, and I understand that the National Food Authority has been instructed to look at this and will take submissions up to 2 December.

The honourable senator's question and any related material ought to be put to that Authority to enable it to come to a consistent decision on labelling across all foods so that we do not go through this process of adding various products to the list from time to time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I address a question to the Minister for Justice in both that capacity and as Minister representing the Attorney-General. I draw the Minister's attention to a media release of the Law Council of Australia dated 3 November 1992 which expresses concern about the proposed abolition of the Accident Compensation Tribunal of Victoria, apparently without provision for appointment of the judges to a replacement body. Does the Government agree with the principle on which the Law Council relies for its position, namely, the need to ensure the principle of the independence of judicial and semi-judicial bodies.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I ask how long the Government intends Question Time to run today, or is this a special privilege for a friend of the Leader? In other words, can we get some more questions, too?
—I indicate to the President when Question Time is going to end. I will be indicating it shortly.

—I believe that proper deference ought to be shown by executive governments and parliaments to the principle of judicial independence. Particularly when old courts are abolished I think there is a very grave obligation on governments and parliaments to ensure that no suggestion can be made that the abolition took place in order simply to remove troublesome judicial officers. It is extremely important that that principle be maintained.

PARA.TAB: As to the particular case raised by Senator Cooney, I am not in possession of the Bill, which I understand has been or will be introduced into the Victorian Parliament either yesterday or today. But there is no doubt that there would need to be proper provision for the judges who have been displaced or who are about to be displaced, either by appointment to a suitable alternative court or jurisdiction or by some proper compensation which would not leave them impoverished as a result of the abolition of their livelihood. This is an important principle. Otherwise it could be said that decisions were made in fear and in peril of having judicial status removed and no monetary compensation offered. Therefore, the prospect of that could influence decision making. I believe it is most important that appropriate provision be made for the future of those members of this tribunal in order to secure judicial independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. I draw your attention to a ruling that was given by Sir Magnus Cormack, a former President of this Senate. It tackles the issue that Senator Button just raised, which is whether he determines the length of Question Time or whether the Senate determines the length of Question Time. In the Senate Hansard, volume 49, page 1094, it was ruled by the President of that time that it is for the Senate to decide the duration of Question Time; it is not for Senator Button.

—Order! In order to do that, the Senate would have to pass a motion. I am also partly responsible for the confusion that occurred. When I called Senator Sowada I pointed out that it was the Government side's turn for a question. Time had elapsed. Senator Boswell stood and the Minister, Senator Button, was talking. I allowed Senator Boswell's question and then Senator Cooney was allowed a question.
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) in response to a question without notice asked by Senator Cooney this day relating to the Accident Compensation Tribunal of Victoria.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle that Senator Tate spoke to is one that I think is essential for the proper government of this country. It is a very bad principle that an executive government should in any way interfere with the proper processes of the judicial arm. That is a matter that has been upheld by both the Victorian Bar Council and the President of the Law Institute of Victoria, acting on behalf of their members.

PARA.TAB: What we must avoid in this country is the exercise of arbitrary power. If the executive government is going to be in a position where it exercises all the powers of the land, where it has the ability to overshadow, overawe or overbear the judicial arm or the legislative arm, then we are in trouble.

When this question was being answered, an honourable senator called out that Mr Justice Staples was dismissed. I think that was a bad thing. I think Senator Alston, who was on a committee with me at that time, will agree that that was a bad thing. It should not have happened, and what is happening in Victoria now should not happen.

I put the proposition that the judicial arm must be protected if we are going to have any ability to have a decent sort of government. Of the three arms of government, the legislature—which I must say has failed largely in its duty to carry out proper government—and the judiciary should be protected, and the executive should be properly restrained.

It is a most worrying feature of our government landscape in Australia that this has happened in Victoria without there being a proper protest made in this House. I hope sufficient protest is made in Victoria, I hope sufficient protest is made in this House, and I hope that what has been proposed is drawn back from so that that precious principle of separation of power continues.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter. I do not want it to be thought that our side of the chamber concurs with the views expressed by Senator Cooney who in many respects deserves the `credit', if that is the word, for the current system of workers' compensation in Victoria. Given the enormous difficulties that have flowed from the Cooney report, I would have thought that we would have to concede that it is within the rights of a sovereign government to say that enough is enough; that that system has got completely out of control; that the way in which it is operating needs fundamental overhaul—
—It costs an arm and a leg.

—Yes, absolutely. Senator Cooney's mates—Holding, Redlich and all these other types—will be making about $30m a year in legal fees. Senator Cooney and I had to earn a quid at the Bar; those blokes used to chalk up a couple of thousand before lunch.
—What did you chalk up?
—It took me the full day to get to that sort of money. I did not sully my reputation by going down to the workers compensation tribunal, I can tell you.

PARA.TAB: The distinction that has to be made is that Senator Cooney is quite right in saying that we cannot put people out of a job arbitrarily and ignore the fact that their livelihood has been cut short. Therefore, I think it is reasonable to suggest that there ought to be appropriate compensation packages put in place. But it is another thing altogether to say that somehow, because a tribunal is in place, that ought to be allowed to continue indefinitely. Indeed, I heard Senator Hill say yesterday that in South Australia Senator Cooney's mates are in the process of doing precisely this. In other words, they are scrapping—

TALK.START.PARA: —A bad principle in that case.
—Maybe—I do not know. I am just saying that it is within their sovereign power.

PARA.TAB: As Senator Cooney would know and expect, I am an advocate of the common law system. So I am not in the business of closing down common law rights. But, nonetheless, it is perfectly proper to say that a tribunal ought to be put out of business if it is not doing the job. It is not a reflection on individual judges. If it were, I would agree with Senator Cooney—and that is the point of Staples and Dunphy. But this is closing down 11, the entire outfit, and replacing them with some other system. I would have thought that we have to acknowledge that it is proper in certain circumstances. As long as the decision is taken on the merits—

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with the position of the Bar Council and the Law Institute?

—I can understand the Bar Council and the Law Institute being concerned at any suggestion that anyone might be curtailed or cut down in the prime of life, but all I am saying is that one has to acknowledge that there are higher powers and one of those is a sovereign government. Given the litany of disasters we have had in that jurisdiction over the years, I would have thought that the workers have not done terribly well out of it either. One jumps through all those hoops and has all those summary hearings and all those excuses for making money for nothing. It is a jurisdiction that should have been closed down long ago. So all I say is that proper compensation for the office holders is one thing—
—Why don't we close down lawyers altogether?
—That is outrageous.
—No, it's not.

—Senator Sherry has been having too many lunches with Senator Schacht if he does not recognise the virtues of having someone to uphold one's rights, to come to one's defence. If one happens not to have an ability to speak English terribly well, does not understand the system terribly well—
—If they can pay for it.
—Of course.
—You put them on an employment contract and make sure that continues.

—Indeed. Senator Button is also acknowledging that there must be lawyers. The question of what they are paid is a separate issue. The suggestion that somehow lawyers must be put out of business might appeal to Shakespeare in a moment of pique, but I do not think it really makes very much sense in this day and age.

—I was not surprised by Senator Cooney asking a question on this matter of principle about government or parliaments in relation to tenure of appointments to semi-judicial tribunals. Of course, removal of appointees cannot occur under our Constitution in relation to courts because Parliament cannot in fact sack properly constituted judges under our Constitution.

PARA.TAB: As I said, I am not surprised that Senator Cooney raised this issue of principle because he was a member, as I was, of a joint select committee of this Parliament which put down a report which agreed with that principle applying not only to judges properly constituted under the Constitution but also to judges of administrative type tribunals with judicial status and powers.

What did astonish me was the answer in support of this principle by the Minister for Justice, Senator Tate. The question was raised in relation to a semi-judicial tribunal in Victoria, the composition of which I am not particularly familiar with. But Senator Tate got onto his high horse about how wrong it was for the Victorian Government to take this action and to remove people who had hitherto thought they had judicial status and a judicial career.

Senator Tate was and still is a member of a government which, in 1988, proposed and passed through this Parliament, with the support of the Democrats at the time, a Bill which abolished the Industrial Relations Commission of that day and established a new body called the Australian Industrial Relations Commission which totally replaced the jurisdiction, functions and all the rest of it of the former commission. That Bill did make some major reforms to the Industrial Relations Act, but that could have been done simply by amending the Act.

But the Government went a step further. This Government, of which Senator Tate was and is the Minister for Justice, abolished the commission entirely and then when it set up a new commission appointed all the former deputy presidents except one: Mr Justice Staples. This was not a case like that which Senator Alston has just mentioned where Parliament might have wanted, for good reasons perhaps, to abolish a function altogether. In this case the Government deliberately abolished the existing commission, set it up again and reappointed all the other members of it except one—and it was all done to get rid of Mr Justice Staples.

Senator Tate had the effrontery and hypocrisy to stand up and enunciate a great principle about how this should not be done in Victoria. He was, and still is, a member of the Government. Senator Cooney will remember that we did not get a very satisfactory response from the Government to our report and the proposal that the Committee made. I just remind the Senate of the hypocrisy of Senator Tate today in seeking, in his answer to Senator Cooney, to make political capital out of something that had been done in Victoria. Why does Senator Tate not resign if he believes that is the principle?
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) and the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) in response to questions without notice asked by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) and Senator Chapman this day, relating to unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: A number of questions were asked in Question Time in relation to the appalling level of unemployment at 11.5 per cent, as shown in the figures released today. It has been noted that when Senator Button is asked these sorts of questions, as he has been over a period, he gets up and talks about `the tragedy of unemployment; isn't it terrible', and makes no comment whatsoever about who caused the unemployment.

PARA.TAB: The Hawke-Keating Government has been in power for nine years and is now presiding over the worst level of unemployment since the Great Depression, and it is being sustained, with no light at the end of the tunnel. Never has Senator Button got up in here and said, `I apologise to the people of Australia'. I remind him of these words used by one of his colleagues nine or 10 years ago: `Any Government which has presided over 11 per cent unemployment is not fit to govern'. Does anyone remember who said that? It is a quote from Question Time. Mr Hawke said that during a short period of unemployment that occurred in 1982-83, not the sustained level which has been going on for the last two or three years with, as I said, no light at the end of the tunnel.

Who caused the unemployment? The Labor Government of nine years presided over by Mr Hawke, and now Mr Keating—although Mr Keating would like to claim credit for the whole period. Honourable senators might recall Mr Keating's remarks: `We pull the levers. I can do anything with the levers'. He talked about bringing home the bacon. The only bacon he has brought home is the tragedy of unemployment and the social dislocations that inevitably come from it.

In response to a question from Senator Chapman regarding the failed accord, Senator Cook went on about the ACTU being involved in a national day of protest in an educative campaign. It is worth referring to Paul Kelly's book called The End of Certainty. In this book he claims:

SPEECH.PARA: The Hawke government was sufficiently divorced from vested financial interests to deregulate the financial system but was unable to deregulate the labour market because of its vested ties to the trade unions.
The critic of that book was one Senator Peter Walsh, who said in his critique that he agreed with that statement.

PARA.TAB: This is the nub of the problem in this country. This Government is prepared to put its vested interests against the interests of every Australian; against the interests of youth unemployment in this country; and, probably more tragically, against the interests of those people on the middle level who have a home, a few children at home and a mortgage. They have become the forgotten people of this country. Yet on the other side, we have people who know in their own hearts that, to get this economy back on track, we must introduce a flexible system within the industrial relations policy. They cannot and will not do it, as has been said by Paul Kelly in his book, because of the vested ties to the trade unions. Senator Cook and everyone else on his side is prepared to capitulate to the power-hungry people in many of the trade unions—not all—rather than correct this economy by adopting the coalition's industrial relations policy.

I think it is worth mentioning the basis of Fightback. It has only one basis, and that is more real jobs, increased productivity and increases in real wages. Fightback is about freedom of workers to pursue work practices which are in their interests and those of the organisations with which they work. The problem with this inflexible system is entrenched work practices. I have said time and time again here that it has nothing to do with wages. The level of wages here is half that of Japan. It is productivity and restrictive work practices that cause the damage. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting Senator Parer in his motion to take note of answers given by Senator Button and Senator Cook, one is always amazed at the excuses given in the answers about the current position. Other amazing statements have been made today about unemployment by the Premier of Western Australia, Carmen Lawrence, and the Minister for unemployment, Mr Beazley. They have blamed the number of underemployed for the increase in unemployment because they are taking up the extra work hours. Maybe it is about time this Government showed a little honesty in the matter. We in this country now have 1,784,000 people—that is one-fifth of the work force—underemployed above those one million people who are unemployed.

PARA.TAB: In answer to a question today from Senator Chapman, Senator Cook flatly refused to take any action against the unions, which are causing chaos in Victoria. Let us have a look at what Victorians think about the situation. A survey was conducted into the strike and various other aspects of the events in Victoria on 2 and 3 November. The article carrying the survey is headed, `More unions back strike'. The survey itself shows what the people of Victoria think. After all, they are the important part of the Victorian scene. To the question, `Strikes and other industrial action only after a secret ballot of workers', 65 per cent approved, 59 per cent of whom were union members and 72 per cent were not.

The next question is interesting and flies absolutely in the eye of the Minister's refusal here today to answer the question and come out and do what is right and proper. The question was asked: `$50,000 fines on unions for unlawful strikes and other industrial action'. Fifty-nine per cent of Victorians said that that policy should be put in place. So much for the critics when they turn around and get stuck into Mr Kennett for what he is doing. He has the support of the Victorians for his policy.

The survey showed that 64 per cent approved of the abolition of compulsory unionism. A little further on in the survey, 55 per cent supported the statement, `Negotiated contracts lasting no more than five years'. The next statement concerned the immediate abolition of the 17.5 per cent holiday loading to public sector workers, of which 59 per cent approved. There are a number of further questions in the survey.

These Ministers here—Senator Button has come into the chamber—refuse to acknowledge the real cause of these figures. As Senator Parer said, one of the prime causes of the problems in this country today is our rigid industrial system. When Ministers stand in this place and talk about the importance of how they have made the system flexible through certified agreements, we find that just over 4 per cent of the work force are operating under certified agreements. There has been plenty of opportunity for the Government to make the system more flexible. If the system was more flexible, more attractive and was getting more people back into the work force through lifting productivity, then the resulting figures would have been much higher.

Consistently, Senator Cook espouses the virtues of these certified agreements. If certified agreements are as good as they are supposed to be, the whole of the Australian work force and the employers would be flocking to them at 100 miles an hour; yet in this Victorian survey, referring to workplace agreements—the policy we are espousing, the policy that Mr Kennett is putting in place in Victoria—55 per cent of all Victorians support them. This Government has failed totally to address the issue of unemployment in this country as a result of its economic mismanagement and the archaic industrial system that exists in this country. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly on this matter because Senator Parer made some remarks which reveal him as the intellectual Rip Van Winkle of this place, as he is. Senator Parer came in here and articulated all these prejudices that are about 25 years old.

PARA.TAB: The point I want to make in response to Senator Parer on this issue of unemployment is that many countries are confronted by these difficulties at present. It is because of that that the OECD, as a pre-eminent organisation in which many member countries suffer from the same problems as we do in relation to unemployment, has made some pronouncements about that. The OECD has said that a policy of fiscal contraction is the totally wrong policy to adopt in this environment, but that is precisely the policy adopted by the Opposition.
Let us look at this question of the recession and its effects on employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you trying to tell us your policies are working? Is that what you're saying?

—Senator Crane should just listen for a minute. I listened to him; he should listen to me. Senator Parer, a drop-out from small business, comes in here making his 25-year-old prejudices manifest. I wish to make this point. Right through this recession the Opposition has consistently made the point that the measures taken by this Government to get out of the recession are as follows. The six first cuts in interest rates—the first six loosenings of monetary policy in this country—were opposed publicly by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) as a wrong course to follow. No economist agrees with him.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, we will not as a Government be cutting $7 billion out of the Budget, as the Opposition advocates. That is what the Opposition is committed to doing. That is the relevance of the policies which it espouses. It is totally in contradistinction to the view offered by the OECD. Thirdly, we will not be abolishing tariffs in pursuit of some mindless ideology. Fourthly, we will not be stopping unemployment benefits after nine months.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that members of the Opposition do not like all this, but they have to face up to it. Fifthly, we will not be going about the country wrecking industrial peace, which we have had at a record level because we had a wages policy, which the Opposition does not have. When we came into office there had been two years in which this country was sent on to the rocks. There was double digit inflation, double digit unemployment and double digit interest rates. Those opposite comprised the first government in the history of Australia ever to achieve those three things in one hit. That was all done by the absence of a wages policy, which the Opposition still does not have. Those opposite should not come in here lecturing me with this pious crap from 25 years ago and all their prejudices from that time. They should try to get with it a little and understand the sad realities of this matter, instead of the mindless rhetoric in which they are indulging.

—The debate in relation to these questions of which notice has been taken has taken a new turn with the entry of Senator Button into the debate. He accused the Opposition of having criticised the Government's policies which it initiated in an effort to get us out of the recession. He accused us of failing to support those policies. The reason for our failure to support those policies ought to be clear to any disinterested observer. The fact is that those policies have not worked. The Opposition's critique of each of those policy initiatives has been entirely correct.

PARA.TAB: What have we had? Over the last 18 months we have had three major policy statements, three major supposed new directions on the part of this Government to get us out of the most disastrous economic circumstances that have transpired since the Great Depression of the 1930s. We had two statements last year from the former Prime Minister, Mr Hawke: one early in the year and one late in the year. Then the new Prime Minister (Mr Keating) initiated another statement early this year. All three of those statements have failed abysmally to get us out of the recession in which we have been engulfed for so long.

What we see today is yet another record broken by this Government, with unemployment reaching the massive and sad level of 11.3 per cent. More than one million people are unable to get employment in this country—this country of supposedly good opportunities. We have a record foreign debt of the order of $160 billion or $170 billion.

Despite these three major policy statements, there has been no real plan on the part of this Government to get Australia out of this disastrous situation. That is the issue and that is why the Opposition has consistently criticised the proposals which this Government has put forward.

In contrast, the Opposition has a very detailed plan which will get us out of those difficulties. The most detailed proposition ever put forward by an Opposition in the run up to an election—the Fightback package—will reduce costs on business, reduce the costs of production in this country, get the country moving and enable business to develop demand and create jobs.

Yet what did we see in one of the answers, or non-answers, from Senator Cook earlier today? He asserted that the Opposition now ought to produce legislation in relation to its policy package. We have produced the most detailed policy package ever put forward by an Opposition; now those opposite want the legislation. When did the Labor Party in opposition ever produce a package of legislation it proposed to introduce when in government?

Let us remember 1983. What was the policy of those opposite in 1983? It was `Love me, trust me'. That was what they put to the Australian people. There was no detailed policy or, God forbid, any legislation put before the Australian people. It was just a simple `Trust me'. The Australian people did love them and trust them for a little while. What have the people got in return? They have the worst recession since the 1930s. That is what this Government has delivered to the Australian people. The people certainly do not love and trust those opposite any more.

TAB.TAB: This Opposition has put forward a detailed package of policies which will get this country out of the disastrous situation into which this Government has directly put it. It is not the international climate that has put Australia into recession; Australia led the world into recession because of the policies of this Government. The rest of the world followed us. So those opposite cannot blame international circumstances for the situation in which we find ourselves. It is a direct result of the failed policies and the failed management of this Government. Only a change of government and a change of direction, which Fightback offers, will get us out of the mess we are in.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues on this motion. Senator Button does not seem to understand the essential facts, which again I draw to his attention: this Government has created record unemployment. Rumpole Snr and his Government have been in office for 10 years and have created record unemployment—11.3 per cent and rising. Over these 10 years the Government has actually cut wages and salaries. What a magnificent achievement—Senator Button conceded this yesterday—for a Labor government!

PARA.TAB: Was it not an amazing thing to hear Senator Crowley's question to Senator Cook suggesting that Mr Clinton might take up the policies of the Labor Government? This Government certainly has one of the worst records of any Federal government in Australian history. Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw to your attention the question of whether, in the interests of good relations between Australia and America, Mr Clinton should take up the policies of the Keating Labor Government in Australia. The unemployment rate in Australia is 11.3 per cent: the unemployment rate in America, according to the copy of the Economist that I have before me, is 7.5 per cent. Why would a country with 7.5 per cent unemployment pick up this Government's policies? Senator Button must be truly joking.

Let us look at some other figures. In Australia the prime lending rate is around about 10 per cent. In America, the prime lending rate is around about 6 per cent. Why would the Americans pick up this Government's policies? Let us look at the stock market. Again we can compare just how business is performing and how shareholders are assessing it. According to the figures that I have in front of me, the stock market in Australia over the last year has fallen by 16.5 per cent and in the US it has gone up by 7.3 per cent. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said often in debates in this chamber on the wool industry—and it seems there have certainly been a number of them in recent years—Australia has ridden on the sheep's back for years. The wool industry over time has provided much of our export earnings. Until the troubles of recent years the industry had been Australia's greatest earner of export dollars. This report says on page 5:
The year 1991-92 was a period of `bedding down' for the new corporations.

Those new corporations to which it refers were the result of the upheavals in the industry which peaked in the previous year. That year, 1990-91, saw the end of an era in the history of the Australian wool industry—a year when the reserve price scheme, the foundation of a wool marketing scheme that served the industry well for 20 years, was abandoned. Indeed, on page 4 of this report the Council notes that:
The termination of the reserve price scheme and increased market unpredictability which followed resulted in much entrepreneurial activity to investigate alternative selling systems.

To call the aftermath of that period `increased market unpredictability' is to understate in some ways the havoc which was foisted on this industry. As I said, 1990-91 was one of the most difficult years in the history of the wool industry. The depressed demand, due largely to the withdrawal of China and the USSR from the market, coupled with large wool supplies put the reserve price scheme under increasing pressure.

PARA.TAB: While the decision by the then Minister for Primary Industries, John Kerin, to lower the guaranteed minimum floor price to 700c in May 1990 was intended to stimulate demand, it failed to do so, and speculation on the future of the reserve price scheme persisted. Indeed, Australian Wool Corporation purchases reached record levels, accounting for 50 per cent to 70 per cent of weekly offerings, with stocks purchased through the scheme reaching 4.7 million bales by the end of January 1991. Then on 11 February, on the board's reluctant recommendation, the Government suspended the scheme.

The scheme operated successfully for all but the last 18 months of those years, providing price stability for growers and the wool textile industry alike. This in turn helped to position wool as a leading textile fibre, made wool-growing a profitable farm enterprise, and earned vital export income for this nation. The combination of adverse world economic and wool supply factors, the equal of which had never been seen before in the industry's history, put unprecedented pressure on the capacity of the scheme to cope. However, as many in the industry know only too well, it was the surrounding debate and continuing speculation about the sustainability of the scheme that ultimately killed it.

Indeed, the wool crisis was brought about by a series of events here in Australia, overseas in our markets, and in government. It was in no way connected with the management and structure of the AWC, which had been carefully developed by commercial exports over many years.

As I said earlier, this report starts from the period when, under legislation introduced in June 1991, the Australian Wool Corporation was replaced by three bodies: the Australian Wool Realisation Commission; a new Australian Wool Corporation; and the Wool Research and Development Corporation—effective from 1 July 1991.

As I have told the Senate in a number of debates on this issue, nowhere had it been demonstrated—as distinct from being asserted—that were the offer price for Australian wool to be lowered, there would be any kind of direct and significant demand response. Further, and more importantly, it had not been shown that any such response would ensure that gross income to the industry would increase or even be maintained.

One very wrong thing the Government did was to lower the floor price. That was just one of the numerous actions for which the Government must be held responsible. The sad situation is that this has been a lesson for the Government—an experiment which has impacted adversely on the livelihoods of many farmers.

The Government may have wanted to make the industry more commercial, and it may have wanted to allow the industry to have more say; but, in fact, right now it has achieved the exact opposite, whereby the industry more than ever has been at the mercy of the Government. I hope that this Government takes note of the recommendations made by people active in the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was your coalition's policy on the floor price, Senator?
—I feel quite sure that the policy of the coalition would be the very best policy that one could get—better than the Government's.
