SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Watson and on behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 320th report of the Committee, entitled Review of six performance audits. I seek leave to move a motion in relation to the report.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short speech on behalf of Senator Watson.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT 320—REVIEW OF SIX PERFORMANCE AUDITS.
Introduction

Under the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951, the Committee is required to examine all reports of the Auditor-General, including reports of efficiency audits. In Report 320 the Committee examines six reports of the Auditor-General, covering two efficiency audits and four project performance audits. These were tabled between May 1990 and April 1991.
These Auditor-General's reports cover a variety of programs and departments, including :

PARA.TAB: .the Department of Defence;
.the Department of Veterans' Affairs;
.the Department of Social Security;
.the Attorney-General's Department; and
.the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: Departmental Responses to the Auditor-General's Recommendations.
The responses by departments to the Audit reports and recommendations were encouraging, with most of the recommendations being accepted by auditees.

However, in its review of projects in all the departments considered in this report, the Committee observed common problems with information technology projects. The management, control and coordination of the projects were areas in which all departments had encountered difficulties. These included inadequate prior planning, failure to monitor changes in cost-benefit ratios, loss of sight of the original objectives of projects, failure to undertake post implementation review, inadequate training of staff in using new IT systems, and failure to prepare adequate system documentation and user manuals.

The Committee also draws attention to specific failings by the Department of Defence in its implementation of an appropriate information system for monitoring maintenance and utilisation of aircraft and some other equipment.
The Committee makes recommendations in the Report addressing these issues.
Conclusion

Mr President, the most important focus of Report No.320 of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, which reviews six of the Auditor-General's performance audits, is on increasing the accountability of government agencies to the Parliament. I commend the Report to Honourable Senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present to the Senate the proceedings of the super consumer seminar that was held at Parliament House, Canberra, on 4 November 1992.

PARA.TAB: Ordered that the document be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: The seminar, whose proceedings I have just tabled, was organised by the Select Committee on Superannuation in conjunction with the Trade Practices Commission and the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, and was held in the Main Committee Room on Wednesday, 4 November 1992. It drew over 100 key participants in the personal superannuation industry.

PARA.TAB: The seminar occurred at a most opportune time in that it allowed the Committee to focus its mind on the issues which relate to two of its outstanding terms of reference—namely, the level of fees, charges and commissions; and the level of information available to members of superannuation funds. The Committee has had a longstanding interest in the matter of the disclosure of matters relating to personal superannuation products.

On a previous occasion, the Committee reported to the Senate that it had not received the full cooperation of the insurance industry in its endeavours to gather in camera evidence on the structure of fees and charges in that industry in the personal superannuation area. Since that report, the Committee has received the assistance that it required and, in addition, has convened a productive, private hearing with representatives of the Life Insurance Federation of Australia to explore the matter further. Further, the Committee prepared an issues paper entitled Super Charges, which it tabled during the week of the 1992 Budget.

It would be an understatement to say that the Committee's work in this area has been both intensively and extensively reported by the media. It appears that the matter is one which excites the interest of many who have made decisions, possibly ill-judged, to participate in non-occupational superannuation. In fairness to the life insurance industry, whilst there has been a significant number of poor decisions, the majority of consumers, according to two surveys reported at the seminar, are satisfied with their particular superannuation products.

The advent of the superannuation guarantee charge has meant that over 800,000 Australian employees who do not come under award superannuation need to decide where their superannuation entitlements should be deposited. The new focus is not only on employees. No doubt many thousands of small business operators in the environment of increasing super coverage will decide to purchase new super plans or increase their level of contributions to existing schemes.The fact remains that long term superannuation growth will occur only if the industry—and here I embrace both superannuation funds and superannuation products sold by insurance companies—operates in a climate of competitive efficiency.

Most of the consumer concerns relating to superannuation have centred on the sale of roll-over and regular premium personal superannuation products. The consumer concerns—and this was borne out at the seminar—have their origins in the extent to which agent commissions are `front-end loaded' and whether these were disclosed at the time of sale. The lowering of returns on funds invested has contributed to consumers of these products subjecting a greater scrutiny on the performance of their respective super funds and, consequently, expressing disenchantment. At the super consumer seminar, these matters received the undivided attention of over 20 speakers and panellists from the full range of parties interested in personal and roll-over superannuation.

Whilst I would like to say that the Committee or the Parliament dominated proceedings, on this occasion it was a triumvirate of the electorate, the executive and the judiciary that prevailed. Fortunately, their combined intercessions and interventions were in the interests of improving the lot of superannuation consumers.

The conference chairman, Justice Paul Stein, in his excellent summing-up, expressed the nature of the task confronting the Committee as it winds up its inquiry into consumer aspects of superannuation. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It seems to me that we have now come to a crucial pass. All the major players, including the agents, the life offices, the Government and the consumers need to be locked into change by adopting a true partnership model of reform. Each stakeholder must be prepared to be flexible about the detail of change and its implementation.

However, I must stress that the changes must not compromise basic consumer rights which must be enhanced in the process. If they are, we all profit and so will the nation. Conversely, if they do not, we have a bleak future. As I said in my opening remarks, we must get it right. We must get it right now. We must not be in the position of picking up the pieces later. The respective parties need to demonstrate to each other the utmost of good faith.
I am sure that the Committee will follow the spirit of Justice Stein's words as it deliberates on its recommendations on disclosure, fees and commissions.

PARA.TAB: I thank my fellow Committee members for supporting the super consumer seminar. Thanks should also be recorded for those from the Trade Practices Commission and the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs who assisted in organising the seminar, not to mention those in the Committee Secretariat who played a role in compiling this record of proceedings. The seminar occurred at a time when the Hansard resources of the Parliament were stretched to the limit. It would be unfair if I did not acknowledge the fine work of the team of Hansard and Sound and Vision Office staff who turned around these proceedings in such a timely way. I commend this report to the Senate.

Before closing, I will share with fellow senators some thoughts and impressions arising out of my recent stopover in London where I was able to meet key players in the superannuation industry in the United Kingdom. I will also share these thoughts with seminar participants because they go to the heart of consumer concerns—namely, the security of savings placed in the hands of trustees and fund managers.

No doubt most members of the Senate and the Australian community would have heard something of the Maxwell superannuation fraud. Whilst in the United Kingdom, I had the opportunity to talk to many of the main players—the regulators—in the superannuation industry, representatives of the members of the Maxwell superannuation funds, the chair of the House of Commons social security committee and Professor Goode, who is chair of the pension law review committee. For those of the Senate who are not familiar with it, the Maxwell fraud involved #800m of moneys that were stolen from seven Maxwell pension funds in a variety of Mr Maxwell's companies.

It appears that perhaps some #400m will be recovered, although there can be no final figure because it will take perhaps three to four years for the courts of law to determine who owns some of the assets that were stolen. At best it appears that some #400m, about half of the money stolen, will be recovered.

There are some 32,000 pensioners in the Maxwell pension funds. Needless to say, my discussions and meetings with their representatives disclosed a grave concern amongst the pensioners in the funds as to what will happen to their pensions which are being paid from the funds.

The Maxwell fraud is interesting in a number of respects. Clearly the sheer size of the looting that took place is quite staggering. What was also interesting is that the House of Commons social security committee was in fact carrying out an investigation of the Maxwell superannuation funds. Whilst this investigation was being carried out and persons were giving evidence to the House of Commons committee, literally hundreds of millions of pounds were being removed from the superannuation funds.

We have to ask ourselves: how could it happen? How could #800m be stolen from superannuation funds? It is a particularly important question to ask, because much of the regulation in the United Kingdom is dependent upon so-called trust law. Much of the regulation in the United Kingdom is carried out by a number of regulatory bodies, which in some way reflect what occurs in Australia.

Unfortunately, if it can occur in the United Kingdom, it can certainly happen in Australia. There appear to be five main reasons why #800m could be stolen from the Maxwell superannuation funds. First and foremost is that the United Kingdom, like Australia, relies on so-called trust law. Trust law is not codified. It has its origins in seventeenth and eighteenth century British law where trustees were appointed to handle usually the supervision of property or estate. Trust law was not designed to handle the supervision, management and investment of major proportions of the accumulated savings of the economy, and particularly in the form of pension funds.

Whenever attempts in the United Kingdom were made to codify trust law, various members of the superannuation industry vehemently opposed any codification of trust law. This was the major flaw that allowed the pension funds from the Maxwell funds to be stolen. The various pension fund trustees were totally dominated by Maxwell. His will prevailed absolutely. In fact, when only one trustee, a Scotsman—who, unfortunately, I was unable to meet and who was a union nominee—dared to question what Maxwell was doing, he was removed from the trusts and also lost his job.

What Maxwell did was to ask and obtain the permission of the various trustees who were administering the various funds to place the handling and investment of the assets in his own investment company. He had delegated to him from that investment company—along with members of his family who are to face trial—absolute power to invest those moneys. That is how he was able to steal the moneys.

There are four other reasons why he was able to get away with this. The second reason is that the Occupational Pensions Board, which is required to receive annually reports from the various pension funds, did not, we believe, receive sufficiently detailed audited reports. This then leads us to question the role of auditors. What were the auditors of the funds doing when reports were being handed on to the Occupational Pensions Board which were giving the various pension funds the okay?

The other regulators include an organisation called the Investment Management Regulatory Organisation. It was supposed to be regulating and supervising Maxwell's investment company. It has admitted itself that it was not doing the job it should have done for a variety of reasons, not least of which was that it did not have sufficient power or sufficient staff.

The fourth reason for the Maxwell fraud was the diverse regulatory regime in the United Kingdom. If we think things are complicated in Australia, we should realise that a vast array of different laws and government organisations are responsible for pension supervision in the United Kingdom. There is the Pensions Scheme Office, the Department of Social Security, the Occupational Pensions Board, the Treasury, the Security and Investment Board, the Investment Management and Regulatory Organisation and the Pension Ombudsman. The Inland Revenue and the EC also have some involvement. If we think things are complicated in Australia, where we have the Insurance and Superannuation Commission, the Reserve Bank, the Trade Practices Commission and the Industrial Relations Commission, we must remember that things are certainly a lot more complicated in the United Kingdom. There were diverse regulatory organisations which, frankly, were not doing a terribly good job.

The fifth reason for the Maxwell fraud was that there was poor reporting to the members of the funds. Unlike in Australia, in the United Kingdom they do not have the requirement for very detailed annual, and in many cases six-monthly, reports to members which are mailed to the members and outline where moneys are being invested and a variety of other issues. They are the five reasons why the Maxwell fraud occurred.

Interestingly, when I was in the United Kingdom some two weeks ago, it was the first anniversary—if, indeed, we can refer to it as an anniversary—of the Maxwell fraud. In that last year there has been a massive turnaround in the attitude of the superannuation industry to regulation. Even whilst I was in the United Kingdom at a number of seminars and conferences, the industry itself admitted that self-regulation has been an abysmal failure. It has called on the Government to act and introduce a variety of regulations to regulate superannuation funds.

Unfortunately, the mess of the Maxwell fraud will take some years to sort out. Again, this highlights the difficulty of resolving disputes over superannuation in the courts of law. As I mentioned earlier, it will take three to four years to find out who owns hundreds of millions of pounds stolen from the funds and, secondly, it will cost a lot of money to do that. Already the legal and administrative bill for sorting out who owns what in the Maxwell pension fund is #30m. It has cost over $A60m so far to determine who owns some of these Maxwell funds. There are another three or four years of court proceedings to go, so I do not think it is being too imaginative to claim that it will take perhaps $A100m to $A200m to sort out who owns what in the Maxwell pension funds.

While all this is going on, not only is it costing a lot of money, but also the 32,000 pensioners who have lost at least half of their moneys have to wait and wait until they find out what their final pension payment will be.

What has been the response of the Government in the United Kingdom to this absolute disaster? There have been two responses. I would have to say that one of them was fairly quaint, and if it were not such a serious situation, it would be half amusing. The British Government appointed a lord—and I forget his name—to go around to the financial community to voluntarily collect moneys to assist in making up the #800m that was stolen. It is a rather quaint response, because at the last count he collected some #6m. I believe credit should be given where credit is due, because the collection of #6m is a good effort in the circumstances. But to rely on this sort of procedure to compensate persons whose superannuation moneys have been looted when #800m is needed, clearly will not be a sustainable way of compensating persons who have had money stolen in the event of theft and fraud.

The second response of the conservative Government is to establish a committee known as the Pension Law Review Committee, chaired by a Professor Goode. I had the opportunity to visit Oxford University, where the professor is based, and to speak with him about his Committee's work. Interestingly, the terms of reference of the Pension Law Review Committee encompass many of the terms of reference of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. Professor Goode is extremely interested in the reforms being carried out in Australia and will be visiting here next February to talk to a variety of people, including regulators, about the recent announcements and the various changes that have been made in Australia.

In my conversations with the various members of the industry in the United Kingdom—much of it was confidential because there are ongoing court cases and disputes over this case—I learnt that there has been a movement away from self-regulation towards the industry itself calling for appropriate safeguards to protect fund members against theft and fraud. In one year there has been a massive turnaround in public sentiment and industry sentiment. The changes that will be made will be based on the Goode Committee's recommendations, which should occur by the middle of next year.

This case highlights the dangers in Australia with the massive amounts of pension funds flowing into pensions. At present the figure is some $150 billion. It will rise to some $600 billion by the year 2000. One of the reports of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation involves safeguarding superannuation. I have not had the opportunity in the Senate to speak on this issue since I have returned. The Government, to its credit, has picked up many of the recommendations in that report. I will not go into that in detail today because there will be legislation in the future picking up the Government's report. Suffice it to say that the Government has recognised the fundamental flaws that existed in trustee law and is proposing to codify much of trustee law.

The Government is beefing up the powers of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to make it into a single, effective regulator. It is providing additional staff for the Insurance and Superannuation Commission to do its job. It is beefing up the requirements of trustee supervision. It is also ensuring that auditors perform their role properly. It has ensured already, through other mechanisms, that there is effective reporting to the members of superannuation funds. Finally, the Government has announced that it will provide a compensation mechanism in the event of theft and fraud.

So the lessons have been learnt in the United Kingdom. We are very fortunate that we have not had the same level of fraud in Australia. This Government—credit where credit is due—has accepted most of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee and will make superannuation a much safer and more reliable investment mechanism for Australian citizens. That is only as it should be, given the huge funds that are flowing into superannuation following the passing of the superannuation guarantee levy legislation earlier this year.

I commend the superannuation seminar that was held by the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation. The report is well worth reading. There were some very interesting and controversial suggestions about how to deal with consumer issues. I believe, together with my colleagues on the Senate Committee and in the Secretariat, that it is yet another very useful paper that has come from the Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: The National Board of Employment, Education and Training--Schools Council

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave of the Senate to split the order of the day so that I may speak to the first document, The National Board of Employment, Education and Training—Schools Council—response to the report of the taskforce on a broadbandeded equity program—today and have the other document, Higher Education Council—achieving quality, listed for another day because these documents have been incorrectly listed as one document.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

I rise to speak in response to the National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Schools Council to the report of the task force on a broadbanded equity program. In November 1991 the Government requested the Schools Council to provide advice on the shape and structure of a broadbanded equity program for schools. The Schools Council was to advise on the possibility of amalgamating several programs into one broadbanded equity program. These programs were the special education program, the country area program, the disadvantaged schools program, the English as a second language program, and the hostels for rural students program.

The case for the amalgamation of these programs relies on the benefits which are seen to flow from giving school systems and/or schools the ability to determine their own priorities within an agreed framework. A broadbanded equity program, it was said, could reduce submission writing and focus attention on the overall progress of the disadvantaged groups. In this document, the Schools Council notes that schools around Australia are seeking in various ways to combat the negative effects of poverty and other forms of disadvantage on learning and the school experiences of many students. It is unfortunate that these schools are really combating the failed economic policies of this Labor Government, which continues to create poverty and disadvantage, placing a greater burden on schools and making equity programs even more vital.

This advice to the Minister from the Schools Council also mentions the great contribution that is made by individual parents and teachers who are strongly committed to a variety of programs. It says that this contribution is of central importance. Why then does this individuality and flexibility, which is working so effectively, need to be centralised under one administrative body or protected by continuing government controls over the allocation of funds to these programs?

The Council also notes that it feels this could best be resolved through the careful allocation of roles and responsibilities between schools, school systems, authorities and the Commonwealth. Unfortunately, the Council does not outline what form these roles and responsibilities should take or how these responsibilities are to be defined. The Council notes in this report that the concept of monitoring and reporting for the programs requires the commitment and cooperation of all government and non-government school authorities. What could easily happen is that we could just end up creating more bureaucracy and wasting resources.

The Council says that it wants to provide more flexibility for schools to develop their own strategies while at the same time more easily meshing their approach with the Commonwealth's equity program. They say that they want a strong, national approach. However, if they succeed, they will choke and stifle the fine individual efforts made by the very parents and teachers whom the Council has complimented for their dedication.

The main direction of the policy advice in this document is to propose a centralised solution to a problem that needs solutions generated at the school level by those who know best—the parents and the teachers. It would seem logical then that the Council should recommend decentralisation rather than the formation of more centralised bureaucracy, as proposed in this response to the Minister.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am happy to support the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1992, which was introduced by Senator Walters. Senator Walters, who has long been a champion of this cause, introduced a similar Bill in 1988. I supported the original Bill and I am pleased to be able to support her again on this issue. As a mother and grandmother, any issues which affect women and families are of the highest priority. This issue should be of the highest concern to all women and families throughout Australia. The decision by this Government three years ago to defeat Senator Walters's proposal was a blow to women and families not only in Canberra but also throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: I believe that this Government has made a sham of looking after families. It has given in to yet another minority, the pedlars of pornography—an industry which makes money out of exploiting women and which caters to the more perverse elements in society.

Honourable senators opposite talk about civil liberties, the rights of people to do what they wish and to pursue a normal successful life to the best of their ability. I ask honourable senators: what could be a greater infringement on the rights of the majority of average Australians than the sort of dangerous material we are talking about today? What could be more harmful to the pursuit of those aims?

What we need is control over the distribution and content in X-rated, R-rated and M-rated videos. Senator Walters's Bill deals with the prohibition of the importation, sale or hire of X-rated videos and the reduction of violence in R-rated and M-rated videos. Decent families, church groups, women's group and many other organisations have been crying out for firm action to be taken to stamp out this smut.

Only last month I made a speech during the adjournment debate on this very issue. That speech was the result of representations made to me as a matter of urgency by a number of parents in the Toowoomba region. They are concerned about the increasing use of pornography in our electronic media. Members of St Theresa's parish council in Toowoomba wrote to me and said that they had had complaints from people of all ages who felt that primarily the Australian electronic media was acting to destroy all forms of decency and morality. There is no doubt that this is a real problem. It is something that we really need to be very concerned about.

In 1988 the Joint Select Committee inquiring into video material tabled a report containing about 30 recommendations. There were two areas of particular concern to the Committee regarding content: firstly, the strength of the violence in videos and, secondly, that X-rated videos were degrading to women and should be abolished.

Following the tabling of the report, Australian Attorneys-General met and, as a result of that meeting, a unanimous agreement was reached between the State Attorneys-General. It was agreed that most Australians wanted X-rated and excessively violent videos to be outlawed and that the way to accomplish this was to have a national approach on the issue. This was necessary because, while all the States had for some time banned the sale or hire of X-rated videos under their jurisdiction, the Commonwealth had refused to do so in the Territories. This resulted in the free trade of these videos being carried out between the States and Territories, so thwarting the States' legislation.

However, the Federal Government refused to abide by the combined decision of the Attorneys-General from the various States. The situation still exists where, because the Australian Constitution allows free trade between the States and the Territories, the various States' legislation is overridden. As a result, X-rated videos are freely available for distribution and sale from Canberra. There is evidence readily available to show that these types of videos have a detrimental effect on our society.

We are here for the good government of the nation and if we are not doing that we should not be here. I dispute the spurious arguments put by the Government that a ban on X-rated videos will drive them underground. That is a hoary argument put up by people who deliberately do not want the best for the community. We should remember that murder is done in private. Does that mean that we should legalise it so that it can be brought into the open? As a society, we closely follow what we legally permit to be viewed on television and videos. There is concern amongst many people that what is privately viewed today by adults in their own homes will ultimately be shown in public.

Many of us here today are parents. We realise that as parents it is difficult to control what our children watch and see during their daily activities. I am very concerned that many young people watching explicit sexual material as well as violent material may come to believe that such behaviour is acceptable. Indeed, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has raised his concerns about the problems of violence on television programs and the difficulties faced by parents in deciding whether programs are suitable for their children. Of course, this is more or less what this whole Bill is about and I believe it is something we should all be very concerned about.

I believe that we do not want to spend too long on this Bill in view of the fact that we still have to deal with Appropriations, but certainly I hope senators will support this Bill. If it is defeated, it will be a matter of effectively pushing the pornographic industry onto the 99 per cent of Australians who do not want to view these films.

I am certainly concerned at the proliferation in today's society of what could only be described as anti-family behaviour and material. I have stood up for the family many times in this chamber, but I do not think I have ever been more worried about the future of families than I am today. Families are the cornerstone of society. They form the basic structure on which we build our lives. In order to maintain our way of life, health, safety and order we must protect the interests of the family.

Those who oppose this Bill can only stand condemned for their weak-kneed position—a position which is no good for women, no good for families, no good for children and no good for Australia. This Government abrogates its responsibilities to the community when it relies on Senator Walters to introduce this Bill instead of taking action when it could. If we truly support the concept of families as the basis of society, we will protect and preserve them by voting for this Bill.

I commend Senator Walters sincerely for bringing this Bill into the Senate. We will vote to reduce the violence in M and R rated videos and to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of X rated videos. I indeed commend the Bill to all honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lees Sen M.H.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to begin today by saying that I believe the basic intention of what Senator Walters is proposing is reasonable. Indeed, I think she should be congratulated on persisting with this issue and for spending many years particularly on the violence issue. It is one that is now to the fore in the media. I do not think there is anyone in this place who has the slightest doubt that the community is getting heartily sick and tired of violence, is demanding some action and some changes.

PARA.TAB: The community will now no longer tolerate sexual violence, particularly on television but also on film and video. I think it is also fair to say that the classification system being used for this type of material is far from satisfactory. Certainly the system we have at the moment does not provide a reasonable guide to the actual content of the material. Parents have great difficulty in knowing whether a film is suitable for their children to see simply by looking at the classification.

It is certainly very healthy to see this debate back on the political agenda, in particular the aspects involving sexual violence. It is also now back on the political agenda. As we saw yesterday, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) are trying to outdo each other in their calls for controls over violence.

The Chief Censor has agreed that research shows that the community is concerned about violence in the media and that their main concern was directed towards violence on television. There is also a legitimate concern about the links between violence, particularly explicitly sexual violence, in film and video material and violent crime. Despite some exaggerated claims from both sides of the argument, the research that has been done needs to be noted. There is certainly evidence that viewing such material directly triggers violent behaviour, specifically in those people with psychiatric and other problems. It seems clear that sexually explicit or violent video material can generate aggression.

Even if such direct links can never be conclusively verified, I think we do have to acknowledge the debilitating cultural and social effects of incorporating these sorts of violent and degrading images into our mainstream media. We then need to make decisions about whether or not we censor television programs and film and video material and, if so, what sorts of standards we want. What sorts of guidelines should we be putting in place? What sort of protection in particular should we be offering our children—not just children but teenagers in very sensitive years? What sort of material should we be accepting as suitable for them?

There are some very forceful arguments put by the anti-censorship lobby, especially in relation to film and video, but as a community we have already made a decision. We are going to censor; we already have a censorship system. So really the debate has gone beyond whether to censor or not to censor and has moved to the realms of how we censor, the actual level of censorship, and the way in which the categories are to be stipulated and set out.

Before talking further on censorship, I want to look at the three distinct types of material we are talking about. First, there is violent material. This sort of material can emerge in varying degrees in virtually every classification we now have, from G through to R; though I fully agree with the Prime Minister and others who have identified high levels of very realistic violence in M rated films as the greatest cause for concern.

Secondly, there is material which is sexually violent. It is this material which, rightly, is of the greatest concern to the community. Strictly speaking, depictions of sexual violence are only permitted under the R classification which is restricted to adults over the age of 18, in theory at least. It certainly seems to me that some M rated material is a cause for concern in this area. Explicit or unjustified depiction of sexual violence against non-consenting persons supposedly led to this type of film or video being banned altogether, but obviously this is not the case.

So far as I can see, part of the problem seems to lie in the fact that we have no fixed legislation or definition of what is unjustifiable or contextually justified. I believe we should move towards eliminating sexual violence altogether from film and video material altogether. Unfortunately, Senator Walters's Bill does not do this, but this type of violence certainly should not be turning up on television in M-rated films or on videos.

Thirdly, there is sexually explicit but non-violent material. This sort of material is the subject of a great deal of hysteria and moral judgment dressed up as argument. When I have reread some of the letters I have received from people on this matter, I have found that clearly they do not understand the difference between the X classification and R. Indeed, in some cases they believe that X classification automatically means sexual violence. This is not the case.

They seem to suggest that X is automatically worse than R and that X is our major problem. Indeed, one writer went to the point of saying that they understood that sexually violent material was in the X classification. I remind honourable senators that that is simply not the case. X rated material, which is restricted to adults over 18, covers `explicit depictions of sexual acts between consenting adults and mild, non-violent fetishes', to use the exact definition.

It is important to note that no depiction of sexual violence, coercion or non-consent of any kind is permitted under the X classification in contrast to what the current `R' classification is where depictions of sexual violence are acceptable if they are `necessary to the narrative and not exploitative', whatever that means. This is where the heart of our problem lies. It is pretty obvious that X rated material is not generally especially tasteful and much of it does not put forward positive images of women, or men for that matter. But no matter how personally repugnant we find certain aspects of it, let us be very clear about it: it is not violent.

It is simply not the case to say, as some have said, that the feminist movement is 100 per cent behind attempts to take out that X rated classification. Both here and overseas the feminist movement is divided on this issue and not all are opposed to this particular type of video or film. There are many women involved with and supportive of the feminists against censorship movement who have allied themselves with free speech advocates. Their arguments are that the feminist anti-pornography message is being used to restrict and distort female sexuality and that conservative morals campaigners have co-opted anti-pornography feminists to make their agenda more `modern', and so more acceptable to the general public. We can probably argue about that for decades and it certainly is not the item before us today, but let us not have this continual misrepresentation about the women's movement being unanimously behind the anti-pornography movement.
Joyce Sanders, writing in the Canberra Times on 18 April 1992, I believe, hit the nail on the head when she said:

I've never entered so willingly into a debate where black is so white and white is so black. Could it be that the local family video store is peddling the violent smut while the restricted adult shop provides the non-violent sexual expression between equal adults?. . . Could it be that the corner newsagent can sell to any age child a motorbike magazine extolling gang rape along with magazines with ads for Big Bird products on the back and young women with their legs spread on the front, while magazines depicting two adults engaged in the natural non-submissive sex that we all aspire to are restricted to over-18 shops with blanked-out windows in industrial areas?
In other words, when did what I thought was normal, everyday run-of-the-bedroom sexual activity become prohibited, and that which I thought would have been banned 20 years ago become the norm?

SPEECH.PARA: Joyce Sanders goes on to describe how she hired three R rated films, one of which she had difficulty in understanding how it could ever have been classified at all, as it contained considerable sexual violence, mostly against women, and with a very graphic death.

PARA.TAB: Miss Sanders put in a call to the Film Censorship Board. She found that what gets an X rating is sex with no violence and, as she said, the normal body parts that we all have in action. What gets an R rating, and can then appear in the local video store is, in her words, all the perversion of sex, enhanced by death and mutilation.

The censor assured Miss Sanders that sexual violence was only allowed when it was an integral part of the plot, and here we come back to the problem; this, indeed, brings us full circle. We do not have an adequate classification system which gets specific about what level of sexual and other violence we will allow on television and in films and videos. I stress again that, unfortunately, Senator Walters does not cover this in her Bill—this issue is not properly addressed.

What we need is just one classification system for television, film and video. It has to be a system that is easily accessible to the general public; a system that is easily understood by parents and, indeed, adults when they wish to make a choice of the sort of film or video that they want to watch or hire. Perhaps now would be an appropriate time to move our amendment to the second reading. Accordingly, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add ", but the Senate notes that:
(a)the classification systems for television, video material and cinema films need a thorough overhaul; and

(b)as part of that process, the classification systems must be co-ordinated so they are the same for all television, video material and cinema films, and classifications must be designated to ensure easy community understanding".

We need a specific set of guidelines and criteria. They need to be far more specific than those in this Bill. I cannot see this Bill having any great effect on the content of film and video material. Firstly, despite what is said, particularly in the explanatory memorandum, the Bill does not change all that much as far as violence goes. Secondly, the Bill perpetrates the current problem of vague language, and I will be more specific.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters's new M rating is not permitted to include sexual violence, and that is already the case with the present M rating, although it is not as clearly spelt out. Her new R rating could imply moderate sexual violence only to the extent that it is necessary to the narrative and is not exploitative. Current R rated material may depict sexual violence only to the extent that it is necessary to the narrative and is not exploitative. The difference is between the words `imply' and `depict' and I presume we are to leave it up to the censor, and maybe the courts, to finally decide what the difference is between `imply' and `depict', and what is necessary to the narrative. As Joyce Sanders found out, if the plot is one of sexual exploitation, then almost anything fits that plot, and this is where the problem lies. It is very hard to separate out sexual violence if that is an integral part of the plot. Despite its good intention, I do not think this Bill advances the cause of removing or restricting sexual violence on television, cinema or video material.

In relation to the Bill's efforts to ban X rated material, I am most concerned that as it is presently drafted it goes well past that stated intention. By defining explicit depictions of sexual activities so broadly, this Bill sets up a situation where material including virtually all depictions of sexual activity between consenting adults is banned. I find it extraordinary that it is really saying that it is okay to imply sexual violence in an R rated movie that may, in fact, still have a very violent connotation, as long as it fits in with the plot.

As we come to the committee stage of this Bill, I have to ask Senator Walters whether that is the agenda. I do not believe it is, but I think we do have a major drafting problem with this Bill as it stands. I do not believe the majority of people in the community support the final draft of this Bill as presented to us today. They certainly support the intention, but we have to be very clear, as we put legislation through this place, that the intention is clearly and precisely documented in legislation.

As far as the Government is concerned, I think it is most unfortunate that this has been left up to Senator Walters to pursue. I would have hoped that by now the Government would have moved. After all, as Senator Bjelke-Petersen has said, it is many years that Senator Walters has been pursuing this issue. I hope that very shortly, particularly after the meeting of heads of government in December, there will be rapid action by the Government to limit violence—in particular, sexual violence—in all areas of the three media. My final comment on this Bill is that in its present form it does too little in one area and goes too far in another.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak on the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1992 because I regard it as dealing with a most important matter. The question of the regulation of material that may be seen on television and in videos, and in films that may be seen in a cinema, has had a renewed life as a legitimate and proper question to be asked in the Australian community.

PARA.TAB: This is not just a question of small or vociferous lobby groups trying to put their points of view. It is a question where now, quite clearly, there are grave misgivings within the whole Australian community about the adequacy of, and information purported to be given by, the various classifications and symbols which should enable people to make a fair judgment about the material which they hire or go to a cinema to view and—although it is not dealt with in this Bill—that they might see on television at various times.

A survey has been done called Exploring attitudes towards film, TV and video classifications. It is a marketing research report prepared for the Office of Film and Literature Classification and the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal by Frank Small and Associates. When one reads it one sees that there is certainly a recurring theme. Even on the first page one reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The research has identified some opportunity to further maximise the usefulness and relevance of film and video classifications by making greater distinction between the upper and lower end M material. For sensitive people, in situations the broad range of material within the category works against the maximum potential usefulness of the scheme.

I find the editorialising about sensitive people quite gratuitous. The fact is that anybody is entitled to a clear definition, and fairly predictable content, of a category which is offered, particularly when one has the guidance of children by parents and guardians as a primary concern. That is part of what is meant to be achieved by the M category.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has also spoken about the broad M category. I am quite sure that he would find much to commend on page 21 of this report which, once again, speaks of the broadness of the M classification. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: It is clear that the broad range of material currently qualifying for M is working against the maximum helpfulness of the classification scheme. Material at the upper end of M can be at odds with the public's perception of the expectation of M. At this upper end there is some blurring between what the public sees as M and R.

Once again, it is cast in a way which I do not believe does justice to the reality, as the upper end of M does shade into R. There are many instances where those in the community—for example, viewing Silence of the Lambs—would say, `I saw that film, I thought it was a very good film, but to think that it was properly categorised as M was stretching that category to its maximum'.

PARA.TAB: I noticed that in today's Telegraph Mirror John Hinde, the ABC's leading film critic, when asked how he would classify some of the recent blockbusters, of Silence of the Lambs, which is presently M, said:
This movie terrifies many adults, not just young people. I liked it a lot but I know many people who really hated it because of the explicit violence in it.
It should be classified an MA—

SPEECH.PARA: that is, A for adults—
because even adults need to know that the violence—which even includes cannibalism—is of an extreme nature. It isn't a movie for children at all.

I fully agree with John Hinde in that regard. I believe that Senator Walters has indicated in her Bill that the division of the M category to more clearly define the lower and upper ends of that material, in the way that she has approached the matter, is coherent with the research that has been undertaken.

PARA.TAB: As I say, the Prime Minister, in recent weeks, has been speaking of the violence portrayed on television—this is not directly related to the Bill—in timeslots when he as a parent would hope that his children could sit down and watch a film at 8.30 p.m. or a quarter to nine and not be presented with the sort of horrible violence which led him, as he told the Caucus recently, to turn off the television and have to deal with the usual trauma that follows when a parent does that. This led him to say that he would be consulting with the various players in the television industry to ask them to deal more sympathetically with this matter by moving the more violent type of material into 9.30 p.m. and onwards timeslots.

However, we are dealing with the classifications for videos at the moment. I believe here again that what the Prime Minister said yesterday to the National Family Summit, convened by Ita Buttrose, is important. Amongst other things, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that all of us should be able to have confidence in the classifications system so that we are not taken by surprise by the contents of a film or a video.
This is important to us as adults who want to decide what kind of entertainment we are paying for, but it is quite critical when it comes to choosing movies or videos for our children [to] watch.
For the past three years the Office of Film and Literature Classification has enhanced the classifications by providing consumer advice for all films and videos.

I interpolate there to say that what we are confronted with now is not merely a need for publication to enhance community understanding of what the various categories stand for; it is also not good enough that we rely solely on the injunction of the Attorneys-General as censorship Ministers, delivered in Cairns in July last year, when they indicated to the classifying authorities that they thought that in relation to violence there should be more stringent application of the top of the M category. Whilst it is said that those categories have been tightened up at that end, I believe it is no longer simply a question of tightening and more stringently applying present categories. There is merit in the suggestion that categories themselves need to be rethought. I am quite sure that lies behind the Prime Minister's remark that the M classification is far too broad—in fact, he called it `absurdly broad'. The Prime Minister went on to say:
I find it difficult to accept the utility of a system which brackets "Crocodile Dundee" and "Cape Fear" in the same "M" category.

He said also that the M category was not even good enough to help identify violent films. He was also concerned, as are many parents, about coarse language or depictions of sex or drug use, which can also feature in the M category, and he suggested that there should be two levels in the present M category—the milder end and the more realistic or graphic end depicting violence.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister also made the suggestion, which is reflected in some elements of Senator Walters's Bill, that the purely advisory nature of the M category has exhausted its usefulness; that there needs to be, certainly in the upper end of the M category, a situation provided for where those who are selling or hiring videos or those who are running cinemas need to do so within a legal structure. This would mean that it would be mandatory to prohibit the availability for viewing or hiring of the upper end of M videos, or films in the case of cinemas, by youngsters, except perhaps in particular circumstances: for example, going to a film accompanied by an adult, which has been suggested.

These are difficult issues. There is certainly a need to deal with the categories—that is the merit of Senator Walters's Bill—but I am not convinced that the way in which Senator Walters proposes to do so will be an adequate response to the problem. I am not even talking of matters of definition that might be argued about in relation to one clause juxtaposed against another or against the present system, although there would be much to ask in that regard.

I believe that not sufficient attention has been paid to the need within Senator Walters's Bill to recognise the very real function of the States and other jurisdictions in relation to these matters. That is why I do believe it is important that on the question of the concurrence and support of the State jurisdictions, the role of the States in the devising of any further and better categories of classifications has to be recognised and time given for the discussions and deliberations which have been foreshadowed by the Prime Minister.

The fact is that the Prime Minister yesterday stated to the National Family Summit that he was proposing to ask his colleagues, the State Premiers and the Chief Ministers, to agree to list film and video classification as an agenda item at the meeting of the Council of Australian Governments to be held in Perth on 7 December. I believe that is very important because at the moment the classification system rests on the foundation of an intergovernmental agreement between the Commonwealth, States and Territories and is oversighted by a ministerial council—the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers—which, generally speaking, consists of the Attorneys-General.

The laws relating to the exhibition of films and the enforcement of conditions placed on the exhibition of films lie within the legislative control of the States and the Territories. In relation to videos, the intergovernmental agreement, under the Standing Committee of Censorship Ministers, deals with the classification of videos by recognising the ACT ordinance, except that the States do not recognise X. Once again, the laws relating to distribution and enforcement of conditions relating to distribution are uniquely within the legislative powers of the States and Territories. Whilst certain steps can be taken by the Commonwealth with regard to classification, I believe the actual implementation, enforcement and adoption of the various classifications will fall to the legislative powers of the States and Territories.

The existence of those very powers therefore requires that the matter be fully debated and discussed by the Prime Minister, the State Premiers and Chief Ministers in Perth on 7 December within the forum of the Council of Australian Governments. This is an important and proper step to be taken. It needs to have the highest possible political consideration within that forum. Therefore, I believe that this Bill is premature in regard to that discussion.

The Bill has a principle underlying it which can command concurrence and can be accepted, the major one being the difficulty of seeing the blurred difference between films and videos classified as M or R. To that extent, the Bill deserves commendation, but overall it has come at a time which is out of kilter with the proper discussion that has to take place with the other Australian jurisdictions which have a very real role in relation to these matters.

I also note that Senator Lees has circulated a second reading amendment indicating that the classification systems for television, video material and cinema films need a thorough overhaul, that as part of that process the classifications systems must be coordinated so that they are the same for all television and video material, and that cinema films and classifications must be designated to ensure easy community understanding.

The first part of that particular addition to the second reading motion unquestionably is correct and deserves support. The second part could also be supported, though once again that has to tie in with so many complex questions of timing and viewing schedules and slots within the television presentation that by itself the simple adoption of similar or identical classification would not necessarily answer the question whether we were doing the right thing by the community. There has to be a very close wedding of the classifications to appropriate timeslots, which will be the subject of the discussions by the Prime Minister next week with the television authorities and, I think, proprietors and managers of the major television networks.
The second reading debate is a useful one and I look forward to hearing further contributions to that debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what I believe is the intention of the Regulation of Video Material Bill. I also support Senator Walters's concern about the influences of the visual material which is freely available within our community. I also know that the community is confused about the M, R and X categories. Senator Tate spoke about the stretching of categories, the blurring at the edges of categories and the alterations which people such as Mr John Hinde would like to see or would argue for. I am also confused about those things and I would not pretend to have the capacity to debate one way or the other the M, R or X classifications, what they meant and where they ought be. I think categories are necessary as guidelines for potential viewers, whether they be young people or adults.

PARA.TAB: I heard Senator Tate speaking about the film Silence of the Lambs. I saw most of that film; it was on our television while I was painting the lounge room. In between trying to get everything right, I glanced over and had a look at it. I found it to be a very complex film, one on which one had to concentrate to understand its context. The word `context' has been used a fair bit here already. I dare say that it will be used considerably more before we resolve this problem. The visual images with which the viewer is presented when watching that film are nonsense unless the viewer had concentrated on the film and followed why certain things were taking place.

A film which I paid a great deal of attention to—my wife and I actually went to the cinema to watch it—is called Fried Green Tomatoes at the Whistlestop Cafe. Another honourable senator recommended that I take myself along and watch it for relaxation. I cannot remember what category it fell into. It was certainly not rated R or X. Whatever category it was in, very early in the film I was quite shocked by a very violent incident. A young man had his arm taken off by a train. Another man was killed by a train. I found that shockingly violent. It disturbed me and my wife while we were watching it. The context of that scene explained much of the rest of the film. Without seeing that particular event, much of the rest of the film would have been nonsense, or at least subsequent events would not have made sense easily.

I also found parts of that film to be quite sinister. Although the film itself was shot in what I believe was the sunny south of the United States, a fair bit of it took place in the dark. There were some mysterious figures moving around committing violent murder and escaping detection for much of the rest of the film. In fact, the mystery was not solved at the end. There were hints at what the solution might be. While it was not sinister, there were scenes in that film which could have been disturbing without understanding the context.

I know that the film was not rated R or X. I do not know whether it was the upper shade of M, as Senator Tate talked about, or whether it was more appropriately called something else. It also had humorous events in it and it was very complex. I would have found it difficult to decide whether my 15-year-old daughter should watch it. All in all, the enjoyment that I got from the film—my wife shared this with me—was such that I would have made my own category. I think a paragraph would be required to explain what the film contained, what would be particularly important to look for and which bits we had to make sure we watched so that we could make sense of it. Of course, we cannot include a paragraph from individuals alongside every film to give it an accurate rating, but this shorthand that we have devised has become quite inadequate for the purpose of recommending that people of a certain age go to watch films.

The point that I am trying to make is that the present categories are inadequate, as has been outlined by Senators Lees and Tate already, and that I agree with Senator Walters that those categories need a jolly good shake-up and revision. How we do it and what comes out the other end is a very complex matter. I hope as a parent that the young people who are guided by us can be guided by our interpretation of the ratings. At the moment, I find that those ratings give me very little cause for confidence.

So really I am not much help in this area and, as a parent, I find myself feeling quite inadequate. There are many other things which have to be added to this debate. My own experience is probably something that is not worth very much at all. However, I can recall—perhaps not all the way back to when I was four years of age—my first experience at the theatre; it was a terrifying experience.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you carefully prepared your speech?

—Senator Kemp asks whether I have carefully prepared this speech. This is a matter which has to be addressed from the heart; it is a matter which should not be cynically crafted. Personal experiences deserve to be given a place in the debate. Senator Kemp might be amused by the recollection of my first experience at the theatre. I do not know whether it was when I was four, five or six years of age, but it was a fair way back. I remember it as being a terrifying experience.

PARA.TAB: I was taken to see some cartoons in which some characters I had never seen before in my life were hitting each other over the head, getting beaten up and dying. All sorts of images with which I was not familiar were taking place. It has been quite a joke in my family ever since that I was dragged out of the theatre bawling my eyes out as a result of this first theatrical experience. I refused to go near the place for another five years.

I was worried about the violence in the cartoons—I am still worried about it. I think cartoons are ridiculous things to have on children's shows. A parent has to go through a preamble to explain that the figures on a video screen or a theatre screen are not real and that they are not really killing each other or cutting each other's heads off. It is an entirely inappropriate way for our society to behave. Not that it seems to impress my children—they have worked it all out a long time ago.

A lot of film critics and eminent psychologists and experts in the science of learning and the area of education have worked out that young people these days—those who have been exposed to television and a variety of films—have a greater sophistication at an earlier age than did previous generations. These young people of today are able to understand the techniques of the film world: the fading and the misty edges for recollections, the back flashes and the dream times.

The symbols and conventions of filming are well understood and easily accepted by young people who have seen these techniques displayed on television for many years. They have dealt with these images virtually since birth and now have a literacy in these visual arts which surpasses the literacy which is held by those of us who have been trying to catch up for 20 years. They certainly far exceed the literacy that I have. Having been terrified of cartoons for the first 10 years of my life, perhaps I was a bit slow to become literate.

I do not think that is all good. I think the innocence of children is worth preserving. Senator Kemp will be interested to know that I have thought about this matter to the extent that I recall the very first speech I made in this place, and I will stick to the theme which I raised on that occasion. The innocence of children is a guidance to us; it is something which we should treasure. The great poet, Wordsworth, was able to detect this theme and make it a very important component of his work. It is not simply the assertion or the belief he had that the child is father of the man. Rather, as children we are innocent of the world's terrors and the world's garbage. As adults, in acquiring maturity, we acquire some of the blackest garbage that mankind has been able to assemble and perhaps we are better off without some of that because it does obscure our vision; it reduces our capacity to see some of the beauty that is around us.

I have received several dozen faxes from various groups who had made decisions about Senator Walters's Bill. I do know the basis on which they had made their decisions; perhaps they did so after communication with Senator Walters or perhaps after a lengthy analysis of the Bill. Several dozen people chose to send me messages yesterday or a couple of days ago. I was amused, pleased and somewhat bewildered to receive a flower arrangement to which was attached a nice little card which read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: To Senator Bell,
Please protect the beauty in human nature. Support the Regulation of Video Material Bill.

There was no signature, but that does not really matter; I was affected in the way that I think the sender of the flowers wanted me to be affected. I would suggest that what I have said already would indicate that I have enough sensitivity to appreciate why it would be sent. But I wonder whether it is necessary to go to such lengths to impress members of Parliament who are about to consider this Bill.

PARA.TAB: I believe that we do not come to this place on our own to make an individual decision. As I said in my earliest speech in the place, I am very conscious of bringing here the values of my elders and betters, the values of those who are younger than I am and the values of my contemporaries. This responsibility should not require us to sit down and craft monumental amounts of oratory; we should be able to come in here and speak with the authority given to us by those we know we represent. We are representing values. This is very much a value judgment. This is very much a matter where we are asked to put on display those things that we believe in and the values which we think are important to preserve and to do something about.

Context is so important when we are dealing with film classifications; context is also very important when dealing with matters such as this. Senator Tate mentioned a context which was to do with timing and other matters and events which are taking place. I do not agree with Senator Tate that this Bill is premature and that it should wait until after the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) talks with the States. I do not believe that this Bill is out of kilter with any community discussion; it is in fact at the heart of community discussion right now. I do not think, because of those considerations, it should be held up; the community discussion should catch up with this Bill. This community discussion was brought to us over the last few days via our fax machines and our mail boxes, and also, in my case, via my flower arrangement.

The debate is happening—it has to take place. We have to look at this Bill and what it is trying to do. It is important that this debate be conducted; we should not be distracted from it. There is the urgency of government legislation. There is the urgency of any number of things. But to me, as a parent, and as an individual, this matter has waited long enough. The Bill is here, we need to discuss it and we need to keep on discussing it until we get it right.

I agree with Senator Lees that it is a matter for which Senator Walters has had responsibility for some time, but I do not think Senator Walters should guard this responsibility and keep it to herself. I do not think that is what she intends. I do not think she should be saddled with the responsibility of incorporating all the fine nuances of the debate into this Bill. But—and here is the but—the Bill itself needs the consideration of this chamber. We have it before us now and we should look at what we can do to ensure that this event occurs. Senator Lees has moved the second reading attachment as an amendment. I thoroughly agree with that, and I think that is precisely what should be done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend Senator Walters for her expressed concerns about the levels of violence and for her concern about sexual violence in particular. We have worked together on the Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies. I like to think that perhaps, in at least an indirect way, the work of that Committee has assisted in helping to educate and to alert the community to the general levels of concern that exist about violence in media, film and video.

PARA.TAB: However, in considering the Regulation of Video Material Bill, we have to be careful to ensure that we get our facts right about what material is in particular classification areas. While I support Senator Walters's explanatory statement that there is a need to reduce the level of violence in M and R rated videos—wherever violence is debated, I think Senator Walters and I will be in agreement—I remain to be convinced about the second part of her Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . to prohibit the importation, sale or hire of "X" rated videos.

There is a lot of misinformation about X rated videos. I suppose this is because many people know about X rated videos but they do not view them because that is their choice not to be involved in the mail order system. I get a lot of letters from people saying that they want X rated videos banned. Perhaps if we were living in a perfect world, I might agree with them. But we live in a far from perfect world and, while X rated videos are not something that I want to involve myself or my family in, I am not convinced that banning them is the answer.

PARA.TAB: At this stage it might be worth reading into the Hansard record the precise definitions of the three categories that we are referring to. The classification of M states:

SPEECH.PARA: M Mature (Recommended for mature audiences 15 years and over)

Material which is considered likely to disturb, harm or offend those under the age of 15 years will be classified `M'. While most adult themes may be dealt with, the degree of explicitness and intensity of treatment will determine what can be accommodated in this classification.
Language:
Crude language may be used, but not when it is excessive, unduly assaultive, or sexually explicit.
Sex:
Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be discreetly implied or simulated.
Violence:
Realistic violence of medium intensity may be depicted, but violent depictions with a high degree of realism or impact are acceptable only if contextually justified.
Other:
Drug use may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Supernatural and "horror" special effects usually warrant an `M' classification.

On reading that definition of M, I think that we would all agree with Senator Walters that there is a need to re-examine the degree of what receives an M classification. I support the notion of having two categories within the M classification so that we can highlight the violent material and that can be separated, particularly for the sake of children.

PARA.TAB: Let us next look at the R classification, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: R (Restricted to adults 18 years and over)
Material considered likely to be harmful to those under 18 years and possibly offensive to some sections of the adult community warrants an `R' classification.
Language:
There are virtually no restrictions on language in `R' films.
Sex:

Sexual intercourse or other sexual activity may be realistically implied or simulated. Depictions of sexual violence are acceptable only to the extent that they are necessary to the narrative and not exploitative.

I do not accept that at all. Again, I agree with the intention of that section of the Bill. Who decides that sexual violence is acceptable? Who decides whether that sexual violence is necessary to the narrative? Who decides whether it is exploitative?

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters, Senator Harradine, others in this chamber and I have debated this issue with the Office of Film and Literature Classification on a number of occasions. We have questioned who is making these determinations on the basis of the selection of the board members and whether they are truly representative of the Australian community. The R classification further states:

SPEECH.PARA: Violence:
Highly realistic and explicit depictions of violence may be shown, but not if unduly detailed, relished or cruel.
Other:
Drug abuse may be depicted, but not in an advocatory manner. Extreme "horror" special effects usually warrant an `R'.
In regard to those two areas, I certainly see there is a need to fully examine the classification system.

PARA.TAB: Now let us look at that very controversial area of X rated material. I certainly would not want it to be suggested that I am endorsing X rated material. I find some of the X material that I have seen offensive, but I am not convinced that banning it is the answer.

Let us look at the X category and what it actually involves. It is not violent. It may be offensive. It may be morally concerning to many people in the community—and I respect their views. But I want to say again and again that X rated material is not violent. The X classification states:

SPEECH.PARA: X (Restricted to adults 18 years and over)

No depiction of sexual violence, coercion or non-consent of any kind is permitted in this classification. Material which can be accommodated in this classification includes explicit depictions of sexual acts between consenting adults and mild non-violent fetishes.
In actual fact, I would prefer X rated material to be categorised as non-violent erotica. Then we would all know what we are talking about.

PARA.TAB: Many people in the community, including myself, are not accepting of non-violent erotica or wish to see it. But I do not believe that banning non-violent erotica is the answer to the fundamental issue that we are all concerned about in the community—and Senator Tate detailed surveys that show that it is violence that the majority of Australians are concerned about.

I will re-emphasise what is refused classification, because I still get letters from people saying that this sort of material is somehow classified by a wicked Federal Government; it is not. Any film or video which includes any of the following is refused classification: first, depictions of child sexual abuse, bestiality or sexual acts accompanied by offensive fetishes or exploitative incest fantasies; secondly, unduly detailed and/or relished acts of extreme violence or cruelty and explicit or unjustifiable depictions of sexual violence against non-consenting persons; and thirdly, detailed instruction or encouragement in matters of crime or violence, and the abuse of prescribed drugs. So those areas are off the agenda and are refused classification.

I endorse some of the comments of Senator Bell in speaking today on the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1992. I am glad that we have a sensitive new age man in our midst. I liked his comment that the innocence of children is worth preserving, and I noticed everyone in the chamber nodding in agreement. It is our concern for children that has motivated this debate; certainly it has motivated Senator Walters. I believe that it is the fundamental issue upon which Australians are seeking our action in protecting our children or, as Senator Bell so admirably put it, preserving the innocence of children.

I believe that the Australian community has demonstrated in recent extensive surveys that its major concern is the culture of violence. I support the personal efforts of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in focusing attention on limitations on violence shown on television, and especially the screening of adults-only material after 9.30 p.m. I certainly hope that he is successful in persuading the network chiefs to rearrange their programming so that adults only material will be shown after 9.30 p.m. It seems perfectly logical to the majority of people who are concerned with family viewing.

Furthermore, I welcome the Prime Minister's identification of the fact that there is such a broad range of films and videos acceptable within the M category. At the National Family Summit yesterday, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I deplore the amount of violence on television able to be watched by children but I am also aware that the problem of unsuitable programs for children is not confined to television. There are also films and videos, many of which contain material relating to sex or drugs which I regard as unsuitable for children to watch.

The Prime Minister has acknowledged that the present classification system is much too broad—Senator Tate, Senator Walters and others have identified this—and has pointed out that, since the setting of these classifications is a Commonwealth-State matter determined by the Attorneys-General as censorship Ministers, he will be listing film and video classification as an agenda item when the Premiers and Chief Ministers next meet on, I believe, 7 December.

PARA.TAB: Senator Walters can take heart from the fact that there is considerable cross-party support in relation to violence. I will now elaborate a little on this culture of violence and where it comes from. My comments may be regarded as offensive to the United States, but so much of our media is dominated by the culture of American violence. I am sure that honourable senators could identify material from other countries, including Australia, that is also excessively violent, but one would have to agree that America has an addiction to make-believe violence. It is an addiction; it takes more and more to accomplish less and less.

An article from Newsweek identifies the fact that, in 1987, in a film called RoboCop 32 people were killed throughout the film, but by 1990 a sequel served up 81 corpses. The makers of Die Hard 2 in 1990 really outdid themselves. The number of people killed rose from 18 in the original film to a body count of 264.

We are all familiar with this excessive picture of violence from so many American film-makers. I have said before, without much success, that we often talk about quotas in other areas of government activity.
