I wish that we could put quotas on the amount of violent American film and video material that is coming into this country. This would mean not, as Senator Walters says in the second part of her Bill, banning it but putting quotas on the amount of violence that this country will accept. Perhaps we could even debate how much of the same American rubbish that is pornography should come in.

According to the same Newsweek article, the director of Silence of the Lambs straddled the old and the new by taking a gruesome plot and filming it with a certain amount—according to this article—of discretion and taste. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: "We wanted to exploit people's endless fascination with scary stories—
I think I could write a few scary stories that did not go as far as Silence of the Lambs—
and provide them with a tremendously powerful version of a scary story, but we didn't want to upset their lives," he explains.
The article continues:

PARA.TAB: But people are upset by the assault of brutal imagery on radio, TV, in the theatres, in best-selling books. It is not any one film or program that is singularly disturbing; it is the appalling accretion of violent entertainment. It is the sense that things have gotten out of control. And there is legitimate alarm at what all this imaginary violence might be contributing to an increasingly dangerous real life.

SPEECH.PARA: There are numerous other references to this culture of violence and the violence that is dominating so much of the American culture that we absorb in Australia.

PARA.TAB: For instance, a newspaper article quotes a Mr Robert Ressler, who is now retired from the FBI's violent criminal apprehension program. He claims that society—and he means American society—has an infatuation with violence and human annihilation and with breeding monsters, such as confessed mass killers and mutilators. This is the sort of material that we are allowing to proliferate within Australia. Perhaps if we were a little more regulatory in the amount of Australian material that is shown on television and in our theatres, we could at least partially overcome some of this obsession with violence.

A newspaper headline on Tuesday, 8 September 1992 reads, `Bishop condemns US obsession with violence'. The heading of another newspaper article reads, `US violence the ``worst on earth''.' This article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The United States is "the most violent and self-destructive nation on earth," the US Senate Judiciary Committee said in a report released yesterday.

PARA.TAB: The report depicted Americans killing, raping and robbing one another at a furious rate, surprising every other country that keeps crime statistics.
The nation's citizens committed a record number of killings in 1990—at least 23,300, or nearly three an hour—and a record number of rapes, robberies and assaults . . .

SPEECH.PARA: The article says further on:

PARA.TAB: Violence against women in the US was even more pervasive, the committee said.
The rape rate was eight times higher than in France, 15 times higher than in England, 23 times higher than in Italy and 26 times higher than in Japan, according to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Walters points out in her explanatory notes, Australia cannot derive any comfort from where it stands in relation to rape statistics. The point I want to make relates to how Australians are influenced by this domination of American culture in this country. I believe—although Senator Walters may regard this as a little outside the scope of the debate—that this is an issue that we should seriously address.

PARA.TAB: There is something radically wrong with our classification system. I am quite amused that it has taken John Dickie some time to come to the opinion that is reported in today's News Digest where he has decided to give approval to the Prime Minister's proposals for a new classification system. With every respect to John Dickie, I ask: where has he been for the years that this debate has been going on? Where was he when we banned a suicide book? Yet we continue to allow into Australia the kinds of videos that reflect an American lifestyle and an American preoccupation with violence and opposition to gun control. What is the Office of Film and Literature Classification doing? It is banning Fatal End, a book on suicide. Clearly, there is a double standard there.

In my remaining 10 minutes I wish to address the issue that I thought Senator Lees raised in a very responsible way. There are people who are really not prepared to seriously address the question of pornography and whether it is harmful. I do not know the answer. I wish I did. Debating these issues and deciding legislation and film classifications would be made much easier if only that vexed question could be answered.

I will quote from a paper presented by Dr Thomson at the Victorian Criminal Justice Council Symposium which was held last year. Sections of the paper raise a number of issues which Senator Walters has indicated she is concerned about. The paper does not come down on one side or other of the debate, but it does show that it is very difficult to pinpoint precisely what pornography does. The paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: Pornography is a subject which elicits deep moral and ideological divisions within our society. There are those who believe that pornography corrupts the minds and morals of the viewers and is responsible for an upsurge in sex offences and violence against women. Many who hold this belief argue that it is appropriate and justifiable that pornography should be banned or at least severely restricted.
I guess I would come into the latter category; it should be severely restricted. The paper continues:
There are others who hold that no link between pornography and violence has been established—
although clearly the other side has not established that there is not a link between pornography and violence—
and that in the absence of this link greater violence is done to society by restricting an individual's right to read and view what he or she wants.

Dr Thomson outlines the conclusions that he draws from the findings of different kinds of research. We know that researchers like statistics because they can prove whichever their particular point of view is, depending on which research or statistics they quote. Dr Thomson tries to be objective in this paper and tries to determine whether pornography is harmful and how harmful it is. He says:

The conclusion I draw from the findings of the different lines of research is that pornography is causally related to sexually violent behaviour. Whether or not sexually violent behaviour is initiated after pornography is viewed depends upon the following circumstances:
(1)The attitude of the viewer to women.
(2)The extensiveness of exposure to a significant level of pornography.

PARA.TAB: (3)The degree of empathy the viewer has with other people.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)The extent of moral constraints or inhibitions possessed by the viewer.
(5)How quickly the opportunity arises to act out sexual activities.
(6)The degree of violence depicted in the material.
As I have already said when outlining what X contains, there is no violence in X. Dr Thomson goes on to say:

Perhaps the only conclusion that can be drawn with any degree of confidence from these studies is that pornography depicting sexual violence sexuality arouses violent sex offenders more than non-sex offenders and non-violent sex offenders. Various researchers have found that a significant predictor of sexual violence against women was the degree of hostility held about women. The effects of pornographic material were found to interact with the degree of hostility towards women.
One might ask: where does this leave us—to ban or not to ban? I believe that prohibition has never solved the problems that arise in a democratic society.

PARA.TAB: I can sympathise with those who say this behaviour and material and these videos ought to be banned. I can sympathise with that view, but clearly there is no evidence that prohibition solves society's problems. It is a bit like saying, `Let's bring back capital punishment and these despicable crimes of violence will be eliminated'. There is no evidence that that is so.

In summing-up: this Bill is very important, because it raises the issues and debate on them. The Prime Minister has indicated that the classification system does need an overhaul and I welcome that. I welcome John Dickie's final recognition of that fact. I certainly hope that in that reclassification we will also get a more representative group of people making assessments about some of the material which has been categorised in the past.

In relation to the second part of Senator Walters's Bill, I cannot support a total prohibition because I am not philosophically convinced that prohibition is the answer. I am certainly interested in anything that keeps us looking at ways to reduce violence. That is the focus of the Australian community and it should be the focus of this debate, rather than being distracted into talking about sex and X rated material, which I again emphasise does not contain violence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish in this debate to address the Regulation of Video Material Bill 1992 which has been introduced as a private member's Bill by Senator Walters. It is a considerable disappointment mainly because it conveys to me a dreadful confusion between matters of sex and matters of violence. To pick up on the last comment made by Senator Reynolds, it has always been difficult to try to convey to the community that the X rated category separates violence from sex. It is absolutely imperative that people understand that, although it has been very difficult to get that vital message through to the community.

PARA.TAB: Yet in Senator Walters's Bill that confusion between sex and violence is not clarified or removed but indeed, it seems to me, is made worse. In addressing the issues of sex and violence in this Bill, Senator Walters has quite clearly in the early classifications watered down the amount of violence but not removed it. In fact, she has retained words like `sexual violence'. I find it surprising that Senator Walters, who has been such a strong antagonist in these matters, consistent and clear in her view, has produced a Bill that contains a confusion. In fact, so far as I am concerned, these classifications only further muddy the waters.

Senator Walters has always had a very clear view as conveyed in this chamber and other places. I am surprised that she retains in her Bill some of those descriptions or `descriptors' that seem to me to perpetuate precisely the sorts of things that I understood she opposed. I would not want to say that this confusion is mischievous, but I might perhaps wonder about that since the categories as drafted in this Bill appear to muddle up the two issues of sex and violence.

To the extent that the Bill minimises or reduces violence in the classifications M and R—a point that on the face of it I would want to agree with; but it very much depends on how those classifications are drawn and exactly what the terms are—I cannot take any comfort from the Bill's classifications. I would have no trouble at all in standing or voting to support a further reduction of violence and a clarification of the classifications of violence. But at the same time I have all the trouble in the world with the banning of X rated movies, videos and films. Again there is this confusion.

Many of us would want to support a reduction in violence, but a lot of us do not see any evidence at this stage to lead us to vote against X rated material—even though we may be totally turned off by it or quite unpersuaded by its virtues. So for both reasons, both within the definitions and within the broad thrust of this legislation, I think Senator Walters has managed to confuse two issues to the point where I could not support this Bill.

In case I read anywhere that anyone takes this as meaning that I am a wild protagonist of pornography, I make it absolutely clear that he or she has got it wrong. The reason I would support an X rated classification is an understanding I have about respecting the rights of people who have different views. If they want to look at material like that and if it is clear that that is not going to damage society or them or other people, then I will not stand in their way. I may not like carrots, but I cannot stop other people eating them—at least until we find out something else about carrots.

Again, I think I heard Senator Reynolds saying that the evidence of the impact of pornography on people who watch it is very difficult to establish precisely and exactly. So for a variety of reasons my view is that, while I do not like it at all, I will not move to ban it.

I would also go on to say that if I were serious about doing something about this, then I would not want to vote for a private member's Bill, particularly one that is unlikely to pass in the House of Representatives, and particularly one that will not therefore effect any changes. It will allow debate on the issues, but it will not make any difference in the world.

What I do support is what this Government is doing. I refer to the stance taken by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), the statements he has made about this issue, and the quite clear commitment by Government to have discussion about what sort of violence will be shown in films on our television and at what hours that material might be shown. If we look at breaking the M classification into subheadings and make quite clear to the film and video industry the restrictions on who can see those different new classifications of violence, then I think that will make the sort of difference that this legislation, if passed, might purport to be making. So that is another reason that I do not support this Bill.

I do not want to use words like `political stunt', although I believe that other people have in other places. As I said earlier, Senator Walters has always been consistent in her position. What I think people might regard as a political stunt is that she would want to effect a change by way of private member's legislation. This Bill will not make any difference, but what the Government is doing will make and is making a difference. First of all, the media release today—is today the twelfth, Mr Acting Deputy President?
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Aulich)—I believe so.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.
—You are wrong on everything else; you might as well be wrong on the date.
—How nice to find Senator Harradine in the chamber.
—You are wrong as regards sexual violence which is allowed in R, and my Bill only deals with sexual—

—When Senator Walters gets her time to reply, we will hear from her what she wants to say. This is a time, according to the rules, when I can have a say. Having discovered that today is 12 November, for exactness, as honourable senators will understand, I can now read this media release put out today—I just wanted to check that it was not put out yesterday—from the Film Video Coalition. It is a statement by the Film Video Coalition, representing the major film and video distributors, in response to the Prime Minister's censorship initiative. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The members of the Film Video Coalition have been invited to respond to the Prime Minister's censorship initiative and a detailed response will be submitted in time for consideration at the Council of Australian Governments meeting on 7 December.
It goes on:

In general, the Film Video Coalition is pleased to see the legitimate concerns about censorship being addressed at the highest level of government and the community for the first time in many years. The Film Video Coalition is also aware of the problem of the M classification and agrees with the Prime Minister's assessment that the classification is too broad. Consideration has been given to the way in which comparable countries, including the UK, the US and New Zealand, deal with this issue. The objectives of the Film Video Coalition and the Government are broadly the same—that is, to maintain the integrity of the censorship classification system so that the community can be confident that movie theatres and video stores are safe, responsible family entertainment centres.
That is a press release in support of the Government's initiatives and the Government's action that I think a lot of people might not have expected. In other words, such support was unlikely.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, the Film Video Coalition is saying that it welcomes the legitimate concerns to address censorship at the highest level of government—and by the community. We know that the community has grumbled along and, from time to time, led the debate and discussion on this issue of concern to it. But at the highest level of government—that is, our Prime Minister—there is a commitment to seeing something happen, to seeing some change, to seeing some clarification of the issues of a new breakdown of the M classification and of a restriction of 15 years in that area. These are the sorts of things that will only assist the Film Video Coalition because it will be able to be clearer and it will be more confident that when people come to purchase or hire its members' wares, there will not be any confusion or doubt about what they might find there. I think one would have to say that that is a very heartening media release from a quarter where, as I say, people may not have expected to get that support.
The next thing I would like to read is a press release from, again today, the Telegraph Mirror under the heading `TV violence'. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have always been a tolerant race opposed to heavy-handed censorship, but the increasing depiction of gratuitous violence on TV and in films, often linked with explicit sexual scenes and drug abuse is causing many parents to question previously liberal attitudes.

PARA.TAB: The effect of such scenes on young children can only be guessed at. Certainly society is hardly becoming less violent because of them. Prime Minister Paul Keating gets high marks for keeping the issue in the public spotlight. It was heartening to see most of his concerns echoed by the Federal Opposition. State and Federal leaders have the ideal opportunity in their December meeting to standardise film, TV and video classifications. The community has a duty to protect vulnerable youngsters from any danger whether it is on the screens or on the streets.

A headline from the Telegraph Mirror of Friday, 6 November read `PM hits TV movie violence' and another in the Canberra Times of Friday 6 November read, `PM tells TV networks: spare our children'. A headline in the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November read, `PM to keep adult films from teen viewers'. This headed an article supporting the steps taken by the Government, led by the Prime Minister.
Mr Keating draws attention to the problem of exactly what is film classification. This article from the Sydney Morning Herald of 12 November reads:
Earlier in the day, Mr Keating said he had no confidence in the film classification system and believed the mature audience category for 15- to 18-year-olds should be split into two sections.
The category was `absurdly broad' because it included films ranging from family entertainment movies such as Crocodile Dundee to violent thrillers like Cape Fear. . .

SPEECH.PARA: I think all of us would say that if both of those movies can be put into the one classification, we are talking about an extraordinarily broad range. I think it is quite clear that the community makes a very clear distinction between those movies. One does not need some particular expertise, although one needs some clarification of the definitions. The community is quite able to make those distinctions, but, unfortunately, not until they have seen the movies they relate to. If people want to be guided, particularly in regard to what their children might see, they need that advice before the film is shown, not after they have seen it. So we need a classification system that is consistent and that does make a distinction between such films as Crocodile Dundee and Cape Fear.

PARA.TAB: I think the particular area emerging that the community is so concerned about is violence. The Australian of 12 November reported: `The PM wants violent M-rated films banned for under-15s'. Again, the Canberra Times reports the lead by Prime Minister Keating on this issue. One can be sure that the Prime Minister's promises will be carried out.

If honourable senators want to see action in this very important area, they will back what the Prime Minister is doing, rather than support this private member's Bill, particularly as it contains the confusions I alluded to first of all.

Let us be quite clear, too, that the Prime Minister has the support of the community in making this stand. I am not going to read all of the letters—or even a significant sample—that have been flooding the Prime Minister's office since he made his statements about this matter, but one of the letters reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Dear Prime Minister,

I am writing to congratulate you on your forthright comments regarding violence on television and young children's exposure to it. I too have noticed the trend towards more violence in movies and series on television, especially on the commercial channels.

One particular which aspect I find distasteful is violence towards women. Your proposal for the ABT to require violent material to be screened after 9.30 p.m. will go some of the way towards addressing the problem of children being exposed to violence on television. I hope it also includes advertising material.
I believe commercial channels do not take their responsibilities seriously. They have the power to influence social attitudes and behaviour.

Like you, I am a parent of four children and I have always monitored their viewing, especially during school holidays. Thank you for voicing the feelings of, I believe, the majority of responsible parents.
Yours sincerely
Another letter reads:
Dear Mr Keating,

My husband and I have just watched and listened to you on the 7.30 Report. We want to congratulate you and back you concerning violence on TV. We agree wholeheartedly. We have four children ourselves plus I am a year one teacher in a Catholic school. In both cases, 1: parents have an uphill battle convincing children that violent shows are not suitable. 2: I am aware of children in my class who are six years old and who stay up and watch some of the movies, for example Police Academy, because in this less than perfect world there are parents who allow their young children to do so. Well done.
Yours sincerely

Phone calls have also been coming through—messages that can be summarised essentially as follows: `would like to express appreciation to the Prime Minister as a parent in regard to your statement on the programming about violence in TV'. The community support is there; the political will is there; the Prime Minister's commitment is there. We have the film and video industry's commitment to cooperation and response. We have a very clear understanding that the time is right for a clarification of the classifications for making distinctions in that M classification that is at the moment, I think, too embracing by including films over too wide a range of violence in particular. I think with all of that coming together at this one time, we have an opportunity to see very significant changes.

PARA.TAB: Again, I say that I do not believe that supporting this private member's Bill, confused as it is, will in any way effect any change, let alone the sort of change that will happen through supporting what the Prime Minister and the Ministers Council will able to achieve later this year. That is not to say, of course, that this opportunity to debate the issue is not a useful contribution to a range of views on this topic.

Senator Walters seemed to want to disagree earlier with my claim that her M classification would not include depictions of sexual violence of any kind. But clause 5(6)(c) states `may include simulations of moderate levels of violence if, and only if, contextually justified'. I know that those are the words that are in the current Bill and I have to say that, whether they are in Senator Walters's Bill or the current Bill, I do not know exactly what `contextually justified' means, but it is open to a very broad understanding. If it has a special in-house coded meaning then, of course, the legislation is not open to ordinary reading by ordinary citizens.

TALK.START.PARA: —(c) doesn't apply to M, you galah.
—Have I got the wrong Bill? This is Senator Walters's Bill—Regulation of Video Material Bill 1992.
—It doesn't apply to M. You don't understand.

—I am certainly advised that paragraph 6 does. If it does not apply to M, what is it doing bracketed with `may not include depictions of sexual violence of any kind'? Is Senator Walters establishing a new category? Or have I got the wrong piece of the Bill here? I will read it:

PARA.TAB: (6)Subject to subsection (8), video material classified as the category under paragraph 5(1)(f):
(a)may discreetly imply sexual intercourse;
(b)may not include depictions of sexual violence of any kind; and

SPEECH.PARA: (c)may include simulations of moderate levels of violence if, and only if, contextually justified.

If I do not understand correctly that those are to be categorised together, I would like to know why not. Any ordinary reading of (a), (b) and (c) under the one number would suggest that they were of the one category. My good colleague Senator Lees nods that I have a fair and reasonable understanding of that point.

PARA.TAB: I will say again, the point at which Senator Walters jumped in and took issue with me was when I used the words `contextually justified'. They are open to enormous interpretation. Contextually justified—that can be used to justify just about any violence one likes. Do we want to say that a war film would show violence because it is in the context of a war, and that within the context of war we can show all the other violence within that film? Contextually justified—it is a very loose classification. Indeed, it is exactly the sort of problem that has led to the problem under M at the moment. It is very difficult to be clear about what `contextually justified' means.

As I understand it, if one takes (c) in Senator Walters's Bill, she has actually watered down the amount of violence that may be shown, contextually justified or not. If she means to say that she does not want gratuitous violence, violence over the edge or out of the blue, and that whatever violence is there must be within context, I take that as an acceptable point. But `contextually justified' is also open to the interpretation that if the context is set up, one can justify the violence, and that is the concern that a lot of us have and have always had. As I say, I think Senator Walters would have much more support if she had left out the concern about X rated and sex, and devoted more effort to what is the very strong message in the community about reducing the violence.

There have been any number of questions to Minister Tate on violence in our community—a huge inquiry into violence. We also understand just how very extensive domestic violence is. Yet until very recently we have not addressed how some of those things in society—for example, the violence which is shown on our televisions, videos and film screens—may be part of a web.

I do not believe any of us can say that it is directly causal because I do not believe that evidence is there. It is true that most people who watch that violence do not go out and commit violent acts, but it is also true that it creates a climate where violence becomes acceptable. That is one of the things that certainly worries me a huge amount. I would like to see more messages that say to society that violence is not acceptable. Violence is the way of resolving any kind of problem when one cannot think it through or talk it through. It is the action of the inarticulate. I do not believe that, even without arguing causal contribution, we should be encouraging that climate of violence in our society which, inadvertently perhaps, but quite clearly, allows a tolerance of violence.

It is not without relevance that the rules of rugby code removed a lot of violence from its sport. I love it when the rugby sports people say, `There has never been any violence in rugby, we have removed it all'. That is one of those lines that rugby people have to say on occasions, and I think it indicates that they know there was an unacceptable amount of violence in their sport. They have made huge efforts to remove it. We see that violence has very much dropped out of that sport. I am not able to say, because I was not watching it too much a decade or two ago, but I am advised that there is a very much reduced amount of violence in that sport. I do not know that one could say there was none left, but those in the rugby code themselves knew that what was happening in that sport was no longer acceptable, not even on the sporting field.

To have people who could step on to the field of sport and thrash and bash each other, and then come off the field and be told that violence was not acceptable, was sending very confused and mixed messages. Our sporting organisations know that violence in the sporting arena may contribute to that climate of violence. They are taking steps to minimise or reduce it. It seems to me to be perfectly consistent that our video, television and film industries should also be contributing to reducing that climate of violence on our screens.
I turn to what Senator Walters's classifications are. Paragraph (7)(b) says:

SPEECH.PARA: may imply moderate sexual violence only to the extent that it is necessary to the narrative and is not exploitative.

I am stunned that Senator Walters, who has given me to understand that she does not like the depictions of X rated material at all—was absolutely appalled at the mixture of sex and violence—is, in her draft Bill, including those words in a category under paragraph (7)(b):
may imply moderate sexual violence only—

TALK.START.PARA: —You obviously don't know what is in R.

—Well, it is in R now, I can tell Senator Harradine. If Senator Walters is introducing a Bill to modify, minimise or reduce it, but she has consistently said she opposes sex and violence together, then I am saying, merely for the record, that I am surprised to find that she has left those words as a category within this Bill. Senator Walters may well argue that that is because she is a reasonable person, and is not into total banning. Let her explain it.

PARA.TAB: I am very concerned about the implication of sexual violence in Senator Walters's Bill. It is one of the problems that concerns many of us who are concerned about increased violence. I have just read a letter from one of the citizens in this country written to the Prime Minister. The letter says that one of the things the writer particularly dislikes is the portrayal of violence against women and, for the large part, sexual violence in our films and on our TV screens is against women. I have to record my amazement that Senator Walters has allowed this continuing classification in her Bill.

All in all, it is useful that we have the opportunity to debate this issue in addressing Senator Walters's private member's Bill. The debate has turned out to be very timely because of its relationship in time to the initiatives taken by the Prime Minister. I hope I have made it clear that I cannot support this Bill because of what I see as a real confusion within it between sex and violence within both classifications and the Bill.

Finally, I cannot support it because if I were serious about being effective and effectual in getting changes in our society to this climate of violence, all I would have to do is support the initiatives—the moves already taken—and the stance by the Government and its commitment to see that the M classification and the 15- to 18-year-old requirements are changed. Those will happen. They will make the sort of difference that I think Senator Walters properly is aspiring to in this private member's Bill. I do not need the Bill, I will support the Prime Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have rarely heard a more confused contribution in all of the time that I have been involved in the consideration of this matter—and that is some considerable time, including on the Senate Select Committee on Video Material and then about three or four years on the Joint Select Committee on Video Material—than the one we have just heard. Senator Crowley has the effrontery to suggest that this is a political stunt by Senator Walters. That is an affront. I know the work that Senator Walters, together with other honourable senators from both sides of this Parliament, has done on this issue, and it is a disgrace to suggest that it is a stunt and meaningless and doomed to failure.

PARA.TAB: Is Senator Crowley saying that if the Regulation of Video Material Bill passes this chamber, not one of the Labor members in the House of Representatives will vote for it? Is she saying that not one of the Labor members of the House of Representatives will vote against X rated videos? As for videos classified as X, clearly the confusion is in the minds of Senator Crowley and, I beg to say, Senator Lees. There is considerable confusion about this.

I refer honourable senators to the contributions that I have made in respect of this matter. All they need to do is to put the key words into their computers. I invite them to consider those contributions in the areas of violent material, PG, M and R material. I will not bother the Senate at this time with the questions that we have asked constantly of the Film Censorship Board and the Office of Film and Literature Classification about tightening up the guidelines. Despite all the cries throughout the community, those guidelines have, in effect and in most cases, been loosened and not tightened. I invite honourable senators, if they are interested, to have a look at the questioning of Mr Dickie and Mr Haines from the Film Censorship Board and the Office of Film and Literature Classification during the deliberations of the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies.

Let me come to X rated material. This debate is not about taste. It is important that we are clear about the nature of the video material—X rated video material—which is the subject of this debate. It is not typically material which is simply gratuitous in regard to sexual matters to the extent that it is crude, tasteless and vulgar rather than pornographic. Nor is it video material which includes simulated dramatic depictions of sexual acts in the development and treatment, whether serious or humorous, of themes involving human sexuality which in context and intent are not pornographic.

The video material with which this debate is concerned can properly be described as non-violent, degrading pornography. In fact, it is hard core pornography because X rated video material is described officially by the Federal Government, in its explanatory memorandum to the ACT ordinance, as hard core pornography. Although that ordinance has gone over to the ACT Assembly, it is still hard core pornography. That is what this Government described the material as—hard core pornography.

In the words of the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, X rated videos treat women `as sexual commodities to arouse the sexual desires of its target audience' and `reduces persons to objects or occasions of sexual pleasure'. The Film Censorship Board's bland description of material contained in the X classification fails to convey the exploitative and degrading nature of X rated material which promotes sexually promiscuous behaviour.

Evidence cited by the majority of the Joint Select Committee shows that such material engenders a `sexually calloused and manipulative orientation towards women'. It mediates in the minds of the habitual viewer a perception of women in general as being highly promiscuous and available.

It is interesting to note that at least four behavioural scientists whose research was submitted to the Committee saw non-violent pornographic videos as more harmful in this regard even than the violent explicit pornography which has already been banned. The Joint Select Committee on Video Material stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Women are often depicted as sexually malleable for the purposes of satisfying male sexual desires. This is sometimes manifested by themes involving workplace sexual favours.

Of considerable interest to me, as one dedicated to upholding civil liberties and human rights, are the observations of Emeritus Professor Zubrzychi, previously of the ANU, in the Canberra Times shortly after our report in July 1988. He said:

Pornography functions quite similarly to anti-semitic or racist propaganda: it serves as a tool of anti-female propaganda . . . The intent of all three is to distort the image of a group or class of people, to deny their humanity, to make them objects of humiliation, to use them for whatever purpose.

Every time that Senator Walters—or, indeed, the States—does something, this Government says that people are confused out in the community about the nature of X rated videos. The fact is I am not confused; Senator Walters is not confused. I invite anybody up to my office at 6.30 and I will show them what X rated videos are, and I will ask them whether they do not agree with the comments I have just quoted from the Joint Select Committee.

PARA.TAB: I now come to the rub. Senator Tate says that this is not the appropriate time; the States have to be consulted. What did the Government do in November 1988, after the meeting of the State Attorneys-General and the censorship Ministers with the Commonwealth censorship Minister? The States in fact said that they did not want X rated videos. The Government decided to establish a working party on videos. That was a sham because it never met. It was a public exercise to camouflage the Federal Government's continued legislative support for the hard core porn industry. That was against the express and unanimous wishes of all the States of the Commonwealth and the majority of the Joint Select Committee which had studied the matter over a period of three or four years.

The decision then was an insult to all the State Ministers. The excuse by Senator Tate tonight to Senator Walters is, `Don't go ahead with your Bill because we are having a meeting of the States with the Prime Minister'. This issue of X rated videos is not even on the agenda. The Attorneys-General and the censorship Ministers have already said that they oppose X rated videos. All the States have said that. The proposed meeting of the Prime Minister with the States is not an appropriate and reasonable excuse for voting against this measure.

Let me come to the indication by the Prime Minister that certain things will be on the table at that meeting. I agree that these matters should be on the table. They emerge from concerns expressed about the nature of material that was coming over television at a particular time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of sitting for dinner, I had indicated that there was clearly a great deal of confusion amongst Government senators—and Senator Lees—about the nature and content of video materials in the X category. I had invited senators up to my office so that I could indicate to them the nature of this material. I got up there shortly after half past six and nobody was there.

PARA.TAB: In November 1988 the Government stated that it was going to set up a Caucus committee to resolve the confusion. Confusion is what we have here. I do not wish to extend this debate, but I would like to say a bit about the up-coming meeting. I hope the Prime Minister is not conned in these particular areas. I will certainly be looking at the matter.

Senator Lees indicated that the Bill does not do anything in regard to television. I moved an amendment to the Broadcasting Services Bill 1992 so that this Parliament could do something about that when the codes of practice were developed—so that they would come back to us for consideration. This is where the review should take place. That is implicit in what Senator Lees says. I will certainly be moving that amendment again, or a similar amendment, the next time the Broadcasting Services Bill comes into this place, and I hope I get support for it.

There are so many women's organisations that I say to Senator Lees: let me know the group of feminists who are opposed to the Bill. Senator Lees told us of Joyce Sanders. That is one woman. PARA.TAB: All the evidence which came before the Senate Select Committee on Community Standards Relevant to the Supply of Services Utilising Telecommunications Technologies and all the evidence that has come before us in the past says that people become desensitised by a continual diet of violence. When we see it day after day, we all become desensitised. We all know that; it has happened to all of us. We know how well it happens to all of us with language. I do not at all doubt that the evidence that was given before the Committee was perfectly accurate.

We have been told that there must not be as much violence shown on the television news. I agree with that. If this Bill is passed, a message will go to the television stations and they will have to start looking at the amount of violence they presently show. Evidence has come before us that one in five men in Australia think it is all right to use physical force against their spouse. In my second reading speech I referred to a case presided over by Judge Mathews. It was a tragic case involving a dreadful murder committed by a 19 year-old youth who, prior to committing the murder, had been watching a very violent, but M rated, video—one that, according to the Government guidelines, is meant to be suitable for 15 year-olds to watch. Judge Mathews said:

SPEECH.PARA: I am not in a position to suggest any measures which might have been taken to prevent this tragedy or which might be taken to prevent a similar one in the future. Clearly, a free and open society requires that there be freedom of communication. On the other hand, I cannot help wondering what benefits society can derive from having such a mindlessly violent film as this generally available to be viewed by anyone, no matter how disturbed he or she may be. The potentially devastating effects can be seen in the events of 27 February.
I do not think anyone in this chamber disagrees with that sort of suggestion.

PARA.TAB: The Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has suddenly become interested in the matter. I do not say that in a cynical fashion. Senator Tate said that the Prime Minister walked into his home one night and found his children watching something very violent. If the previous Prime Minister in 1988 had allowed his Party to vote in favour of my Bill, Mr Keating would not have had to turn off television in his home last week. It is as simple as that.

The party to which Mr Keating belongs refused to allow my Bill to pass this Senate in 1988-89. That party refused to acknowledge how much violence there is in the community. The Prime Minister has now suddenly become interested in it, but he is only interested in what children are viewing. He is not interested in what is available to adults in the R rated category or the upper violent sections of M rated material. Indeed, he said in his speech at the National Family Summit:

SPEECH.PARA: We are not trying to restrict what adults can watch.
Yesterday during Question Time he said:
I am not about telling Australians what they can watch; I am about seeing it categorised properly and having the proper timeslots on television.

So the Prime Minister is only interested in what children watch, not in what adults watch. Indeed, a little later in Question Time he said that Dr Hewson had suddenly become interested in the subject. We know that members of the Opposition have been interested in this subject for a long time.

PARA.TAB: Senator Lees said that she had hoped the Government would move. So did I, and I am disappointed that it has not done so. A trends and issue paper released by the Institute of Criminology contains an international survey which shows that Australia ranks the highest of 14 other jurisdictions with similar justice systems in the categories of assault using force, burglary, car thefts and minor sexual assaults. We were third highest in respect of rape.

According to Senator Reynolds, the blame lay in the influx of American material into Australia. I do not agree with her. There is something wrong in our country and it is time we did something about it. Senator Reynolds said that she does not believe in X rated material being banned. She said that prohibition has never worked. I know Senator Reynolds very well. I have sat on a committee with her for so long that I know she does not mean that. I am quite aware that she agrees with the prohibition of child pornography. I am well aware that she would be horrified to think that we did not have a prohibition on child pornography. Yet she says that prohibition never works and that that is why she does not want X-rated material prohibited.

We all know that prohibition never totally works. But at least if access to this material is prohibited, our young will not be able to go down to the supermarket and pick up this stuff. The majority of them would never dream of dealing with the black market, which would be the only way they could get it.

Senator Tate and Senator Lees both know that one cannot stop an eight-year old boy viewing an X rated video. His mother can stop him. But when he is outside of her control, no-one can be sure that he will not be able to view that X rated video. Does Senator Lees believe that that sort of introduction to sex will lead to happy relationships in his later years? I do not believe that it possibly could. It would give him a very distorted view. My time has almost expired, so I will finish on that note.

SPEECH.PARA: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1992
This Bill will amend the taxation laws to implement a further measure outlined by the Prime Minister in his "One Nation" statement of 26 February 1992.
The offshore banking measure will promote the development of a viable offshore banking centre in Australia.
In addition to this "One Nation" initiative, the Bill will amend the capital gains tax provisions to clarify the operation of subsections 160M(6) and 160M(7) of the income tax law.
The Bill will also reduce the rate of late payment penalty in the taxation laws to reflect lower market interest rates.
The Bill also proposes to extend eligibility for a rebate of income tax to recipients of a textile, clothing and footwear special allowance.
It also proposes to make minor technical amendments in relation to the tax treatment of disability support pensions, special needs disability support pensions and bereavement payments.
I turn now to a more detailed discussion of the major measures.
Offshore banking units

In the Prime Minister's "One Nation" statement the Government announced its intention to tax income derived by offshore banking units (OBUs) from borrowing and lending to non-residents at a concessional income tax rate of 10%.
After extensive consultation with the Banking and Finance industry, the Government has decided to extend the scope of the activities, the income from which will attract the concessional tax rate.

Industry strongly argued that viability of an Australian offshore banking regime depended on Australia's ability to compete on an even footing with other countries in our region that already provide a broad range of concessions.
The Government is in general agreement with this view, subject to certain measures being introduced to ensure that Australia's domestic revenue base is protected.
The OBU activities that will be subject to the new rules cover all significant transactions sought by Industry and the Government believes that they will be well received.

Most of the concessional activities can be classified as either financial intermediation between non-residents (including foreign branches of Australian residents) or the provision of financial services to non-residents in respect of business that would not ordinarily have a connection with Australia.

Mr. President, the Government is confident that this measure will promote the development of a viable offshore banking centre in Australia at a time when such activities are likely to be shifted from Hong Kong to elsewhere in the Asia-Pacific region.
Development of offshore banking in Australia will also help to integrate Australia more closely with the Asian-Pacific growth economies by becoming an expanded financial centre of the region.
The direct cost to revenue of the measures is likely to be around $30 million in a full financial year from 1993-1994.
It is possible, however, that additional revenue from business which is not presently conducted in Australia will offset this cost to some extent.
Capital Gains Tax

The broad scheme of the capital gains tax (CGT) provisions is that capital gains made upon the realisation of assets are included in assessable income and subject to tax. However, subsections 160M(6) and 160M(7) of the Income Tax Assessment Act are intended to assess certain capital payments not received in respect of the actual disposal of assets.
The subsections have been the subject of much comment since their introduction, and have recently been considered by the courts which have not sufficiently clarified their meaning and application.
The Government recognises that their application needs to be clarified and has decided that the law should be amended.

The amendments are designed to clearly state the manner in which the new provisions will apply. Due to the extent of the commentary on the existing provisions, a draft of the amendments has been discussed with tax representatives of the legal and accounting professions with the view of ensuring the desired clarity is achieved.

In particular, the amendments will set out a scheme for the taxing of capital payments not received in respect of the actual disposal of assets. Where a taxpayer creates an incorporeal asset (such as a right under a restrictive covenant agreement) in another person, any consideration (less incidental costs) received by the taxpayer for creating the asset will be a capital gain to that taxpayer. Subsection 160M(7) will have a residual operation to tax payments not received in respect of the disposal or creation of assets.
The Bill will also make some technical amendments associated with the operation of subsections 160M(6) and 160M(7).
These amendments are not expected to have any significant impact on revenue and will broadly apply to transactions entered into after today.
Penalties for late payment of tax and related penalties

As announced in the Treasurer's Press Release of 26 May 1992 on improvements to self assessment arrangements, penalty for late payment of tax is to be reduced to reflect lower market interest rates. The Bill will reduce late payment penalties from 20% per annum to 16% per annum, with the lower rate to be effective from 1 October 1992.

This amendment will complement changes in the law made recently by the Taxation Laws Amendment (Self Assessment) Act 1992. That Act split late payment penalty into penalty and interest components but does not take effect until tax in respect of the 1992-93 year of income is overdue. The amendments being made by this Bill will reduce penalty rates for earlier years of income.
Textile, clothing and footwear special allowance

The Bill proposes to extend eligibility for a rebate of income tax to recipients of a textile, clothing and footwear special allowance. The purpose of the allowance is to encourage retrenchees of the textile, clothing and footwear industries to undertake training provided under the Textile, Clothing and Footwear Labour Adjustment Package.

At present retrenchees from these industries who derive the allowance are not eligible for a rebate of income tax whereas other retrenchees of these industries who derive similar benefits under Formal Training Assistance are eligible for a rebate. The amendments, which will not significantly impact on revenue, will remove this anomaly.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum which contains more detailed explanations of the provisions of the Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1992
The Bill deals with three matters:
first, the re-introduction of sales tax on swimming pools that are constructed in situ;
secondly, a 12 month extension of the exemption from sales tax of ultra high frequency transmitters; and
lastly, a number of minor amendments to the new sales tax laws due to come into effect on 1 January 1993 to ensure they operate as intended.
In situ swimming pools
Earlier this year the High Court held that legislation purporting to impose sales tax on swimming pools constructed in situ was of no effect.
A result of this decision is that manufactured pools that are goods are subject to sales tax, while no tax is payable on pools constructed in situ.

In conjunction with the other Bill in this package, the Sales tax Imposition (In Situ Pools) Bill, the Bill will remove the inequity by re-introducing sales tax on swimming pool, spa pool and hot tub shells that are constructed in situ.

A pool builder or owner-builder will be liable for sales tax immediately after construction of an in situ pool shell is completed if, in the case of a builder, the pool contract was entered into on or after 1 January 1993 or, in the case of an owner-builder, construction of the shell commenced on or after 1 January 1993.
Ultra high frequency transmitters
To ensure that the broadcasting equalisation program is fully implemented, the Bill will extend the availability of the sales tax exemption for UHF transmitters to 1 January 1994.
Minor changes
Mr President, the Bill will also effect a number of minor changes needed to bed down the new law.
These changes are explained in more detail in the Explanatory Memorandum circulated with the Bill.
Mr President, I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
SALES TAX IMPOSITION (IN SITU POOLS) BILL 1992

In conjunction with the other Bill in this package, the Bill will re-introduce sales tax on in situ pools by imposing sales tax on swimming pool, spa pool and hot tub shells that are constructed in situ.
Mr President, I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill and commend the Bill to the Senate.
NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL 1992
The Bill proposes a significant amendment to the National Health Act 1953.

There are two main parts to the Bill. Firstly, a fundamental change to the payment scheme for Commonwealth nursing home benefits is proposed, to enable the recovery of overadvanced benefit. Secondly, the Bill proposes the introduction of a series of measures designed to further protect the rights of the Commonwealth and of purchasers when a nursing home is sold or transferred.

The nursing home funding system has always embraced an element of cost-reimbursement. That is, funds are advanced to proprietors during the year and then at the end of the year that advanced funding is acquitted against the costs actually incurred by the proprietors in providing nursing home care.
This means that, where a proprietor spends less on providing nursing home care than was advanced during the year, the amount of unspent or overadvanced funding must be repaid to the Commonwealth.

By virtue of the existing legislation, such overadvanced funds are not legally characterised as debts to the Commonwealth and can only be recovered by an offset or "negative fee loading" to the approved daily nursing home fee and, by extension, the amount of Commonwealth benefit otherwise payable each month.

That amounts of overadvanced benefit are not recoverable debts has caused some difficulty. For example, where a proprietor accrues a liability to the Commonwealth for overadvanced funding and then sells the home, that proprietor cannot be pursued for the money after sale. Rather, the Commonwealth is obliged to recover the money from the benefit paid to the purchaser.

The industry is well aware of such arrangements and makes appropriate provisions in contracts for sale. Further, following an amendment to the National Health Act 1953 in the Autumn 1992 Sittings of the Parliament, financial information about a home can be disclosed to potential purchasers without having to rely on the co-operation of the proprietor to obviate the secrecy provisions. Purchasers are, therefore, generally protected and able to make informed decisions when buying a home. Nonetheless, problems still occur.

The proposed amendment changes the nature of the funding system so that the person who accrues the liability can be pursued for the money—overadvanced benefit will be legally characterised as a debt to the Commonwealth and will be recoverable through the Courts.

However, this Bill only changes the system prospectively. Benefits paid prior to the introduction of this change are not subject to its provisions and the existing system of recovery by fee loading will continue to exist in respect of benefits paid up to 1 July 1993 and until proprietors' claims for funding for those earlier periods are finalised.
There are some other aspects to the current scheme which offer problems for both the Commonwealth and purchasers when a nursing home is sold or transferred.

There is, for example, no real requirement for notice of sale to be given by either party. Where the Commonwealth gets any notice at all, there may be little time in which to finalise funding for the home, determine overpayments, ensure that prospective purchasers understand the funding system and are as far as possible able to make an informed decision about their purchase and to do those other things to ensure a smooth transition in ownership.

Further, the amount owed to the Commonwealth is not able to be recovered at the point of sale, but must be recovered from the purchaser after sale, although this will be partially addressed by the proposed changes to the benefits payment system already described.
This Bill introduces a mechanism for the sale or transfer of nursing homes which addresses these problems.

Proprietors, the vendors in the transaction, will be required to give notice of sale and will be deterred from completing the sale within 90 days of giving notice. Purchasers will also be required to give notice of their intent.

The period of notice will enable the vendor's claims, books and records to be scrutinised so that, prior to completion, a fair estimate may be made of any overpayment and any anticipated fee loading which relate to the period up until sale.

Prior to or at completion of the sale, the purchaser will be required to pay to the Commonwealth from the purchase price the amount of the estimated overpayment. Such payments will be deemed to be paid to the vendor as consideration under the contract of sale.
If the amount paid by the purchaser is less than the estimated overpayment, the vendor will be required to make up the difference.
Any amounts paid by the purchaser or vendor prior to completion will be held in trust by the Commonwealth pending final determination of the overpayment.
The amount of any anticipated fee loading will be advised to both parties so that appropriate provisions can be made.

Immediately after completion of the sale, the actual overpayment relating to the period up until sale will be determined. Any amount held in trust by the Commonwealth will then be acquitted against the actual overpayment. If a greater amount is held in trust, the balance will be paid to the vendor. If a lesser amount is held, the outstanding amount will be recoverable as a debt.

This mechanism is also flexible enough to address varying circumstances. Three separate approaches are provided for three different degrees of notice of the sale: more than 90 days, less than 90 days and no notice.

In addition to imposing statutory obligations on both parties to a sale, as well as the Commonwealth, the amendments provide for the imposition of penalties for failing to comply with certain obligations.

These changes afford greater protection of the rights of the Commonwealth to money owed to it, and the rights of purchasers to information about the home they are buying and to a home unencumbered by liabilities accrued by the previous owner.
I commend the Bill to the House.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
MIGRATION REFORM BILL

On 5 May of this year, during the debate on the Migration Amendment Act 1992, the Minister foreshadowed to the House that he would be recommending a comprehensive program of legislative amendments to ensure that our migration law is the best mechanism available to deal with current issues and needs.
The Labor Government has already been the author of significant reform of immigration policies and laws.

In 1989 the Minister's predecessor, Senator Robert Ray, took a major step towards legislative implementation of the recommendations of the CAAIP Report. In spite of the 1989 reforms, a major issue confronting the Government is border control.

There are people who are intent on bypassing the established categories of entry into this country. Some do this by trying to avoid immigration processing altogether by arriving in Australia without authority. The boat people are a good example.

Owing to weaknesses which have been inherent in our migration laws for many years, these people are often successful. Many manage to stay here even though they do not fall within the specific visa categories, which is the only lawful way to enter and stay in Australia. At the very least, many manage to delay the substantive decision on their case and, as a consequence, their departure, by using the courts to exploit any weaknesses they can find in our immigration law.
This must stop.
In the Migration Reform Bill currently before the Senate the Minister proposes a range of measures to enhance the Government's control of people who wish to cross our borders.

The Bill sets out more effective means of regulating entry, detention and removal of people who do not establish an entitlement to be in Australia. The reforms are complemented by an enhanced scheme of independent merits review rights.

Mr President, a primary objective of the Migration Act is to regulate, in the national interest, the entry and presence in Australia of persons who are not Australian citizens. The Government views it as essential that all provisions and policies under the Act be interpreted in a way which furthers this objective. An objects provision will be inserted in the Act to remind the community, the administrators and the courts of this intention. Under the reforms, a non-citizen will require a single authority—a visa—to travel to, enter or remain in Australia.

All non-citizens will be brought within the one visa system. However, limited categories of non-citizens, in particular New Zealanders, will still be able to travel to Australia without a visa and enter with the same degree of convenience as at present.

Upon arrival, all persons, including Australian citizens, will be required to present themselves for immigration clearance. Australian citizens will be required to use their Australian passport or other acceptable evidence of Australian citizenship when leaving or entering Australia. These measures will streamline identification of non-citizens entering Australia and will reduce the prospect of evasion of immigration controls.

At present, we have an array of laws which govern detention and removal depending upon how a person arrived in Australia. This is confusing to the public and administrators alike. The Bill will provide for a uniform regime for detention and removal of persons illegally in Australia.

Non-citizens who are in Australia without a valid visa will be unlawful and will have to be held in detention. Unlawful non-citizens who satisfy prescribed criteria will be able to acquire lawful status and release from detention by the grant of a `bridging visa'. Bridging visas will not be available to people who arrive in Australia without authority. Depending on their circumstances, they will be immediately removed from Australia, or will be subject to detention until any claim they wish to make has been resolved.

When a person who is in Australia unlawfully has exhausted all available application and merits review entitlements, the law will require that person to be removed as soon as practicable. Deportation will only apply in relation to the current "criminal", "national security" and "certain serious offences" categories.
Mr President, the measures that the Minister has announced so far will lead to greater precision in our efforts to control the border.

Under the reforms, decision-making procedures will be codified. This will provide a fair and certain process with which both applicant and decision-maker can be confident. Decision-makers will be able to focus on the merits of each case knowing precisely what procedural requirements are to be followed. These procedures will replace the somewhat open-ended doctrines of natural justice and unreasonableness.

The Reform Bill proposes significant extensions to the current system for review of migration decisions. Credible independent merits review will ensure that the Government's clear intentions in relation to controlling entry to Australia, as set out in the Migration Act, are not eroded by narrow judicial interpretations. Under the Reform Bill, the following people who are adversely affected by a decision will be entitled to independent merits review:
.on-shore refugee claimants
.on-shore cancelled visa holders except those cancelled at the border
.on-shore applicants for a visa except those detected at the border, and
.an Australian sponsor of an off-shore applicant for a visa
As now, people off-shore will not be entitled to merits review.

A specialist Refugee Review Tribunal will be established to provide independent and determinative merits review of on-shore refugee status decisions. The Tribunal will be non-adversarial, operating along similar lines to the IRT, with power to hold hearings and record its decisions in writing.
I would like to briefly explain why the Minister is introducing these changes.

Throughout his political life he has believed that government, working in partnership with the community can bring about change—change for the good and changes which make a difference to our society and how we view ourselves.

For instance in 1990 the Minister consulted widely with community organisations on the new refugee determination procedures particularly the inclusion of a community representative on the Refugee Status Review Committee and the new natural justice procedures. At the time this decision was widely applauded. However, when we started seeing negative decisions coming out of the committee the goal posts suddenly moved. The Committee was branded as an arm of government, the Government was criticised as having a fixed view and the system was declared as being unfair.

Similarly when the Government acted quickly to introduce fast tracking of new refugee cases this was believed to be a good move. The fast tracking system has been a success and we are starting to see results. Amazingly, however, the Minister is now being criticised for processing some cases too quickly. The Minister rejects totally such claims about the Committee and the fast track processing.

Nearly three years ago the Minister also met with a group of people who claimed to support the Cambodian asylum seekers. They were lawyers, local politicians and community workers. They went to the Minister and said they were concerned with the way that the Department had processed these people's applications and asked that they be done again.

They also wanted the asylum seekers to be given access to legal representation. The Minister agreed to this request because he believed that it is better to make sure that the decision making is beyond reproach and open to scrutiny. In the spirit of that partnership the Minister allowed the community to be part of that process. But what happened? In some cases it took 18 months for applications to be lodged for these asylum seekers. While more boats arrived. And still the support groups asked for more time—and while they were doing this what of their clients? They continued to wait in the processing centres waiting.
Enormous energy was put into making wild and fantastic statements about Port Hedland—often by people who had never been there.

The tragedy is that people have continued to be housed in Port Hedland and Westbridge—unable to get on with their lives. At the same time some of those who are supposedly supporting them are more interested in making their reputations as human rights campaigners rather than assisting in a speedy resolution of their cases. During this period what sort of advice did they give their clients?—The Minister can't presume to know but wonders if they ever were honest with them, if they gave them realistic, practical advice or whether they were simply fodder for a noble crusade.
Some lawyers employed by the Refugee Council of Australia cared about their clients so much that they put up a sign on the door of their interview room which said:
"Suicide is just one step away—you might as well jump now".

What sort of irresponsible, non-thinking person could in the first instance dream up such a slogan and secondly display it on the door of a room which was to be used by people who were going to seek that person's advice.
The Minister's primary responsibility is to make sure that asylum seekers are treated with dignity and fairness. They have a right to expect their cases to be handled fairly and quickly.
Mr President, the Minister cannot be held responsible for the actions of those who provide them with false hope and tempt them into taking drastic and futile measures such as hunger strikes.

We must have a system that is clear, predictable and fair and that applies equally to all asylum seekers in Australia. Clients should know what is happening to them and should be able to make informed decisions about their claims and options.

The proposals dealing with refugee processing contained in this Bill further strengthen the procedures in two ways. They provide a fair system for the applicants and at the same time provide the necessary protection for the Australian community.
In the general migration area, the Immigration Review Tribunal will handle the expanded jurisdiction.

In a small number of IRT or RRT cases where an important principle of general application is involved, the Principal Member of that Tribunal will be able to refer the case to a Presidential bench of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The AAT will provide guidance for primary and review decision-makers dealing with similar principles in other cases without the disadvantages of delay and expense associated with court appeals.

These changes to the migration merit review system broadly accord with views which I have received informally from the Committee to Review the System of Review of Migration Decisions. The Minister established this Committee, chaired by a former Immigration Minister, the Honourable Ian Macphee, to consider the effectiveness of the merits review system introduced in 1989.

As the Minister has indicated, the Government wishes to make the application of the legal concepts of migration decision making predictable. Judicial review rights for decisions on the grant or cancellation of a visa will be set out in the Migration Act. Judicial review will only be possible after the applicant has pursued all merits review rights, or where merits review is not available.

Grounds for review will include failure to follow the codified decision-making procedures set out in the Act. As the codified procedures will allow an applicant a fair opportunity to present his or her claims, failure to observe the rules of natural justice and unreasonableness will not be grounds for review.

Mr President, another feature of the Bill should be noted. The Migration Act currently allows a visa to be issued to an accused person who is being extradited to Australia. This Bill introduces a broader scheme to permit entry of not only these people, but also others, such as key witnesses, who are needed before the courts. The scheme will also ensure that law enforcement agencies have made adequate arrangements for these people while they are in Australia.

Mr President, the reforms set out in the Bill will ensure that the Government retains control of Australia's borders, whilst providing a review system at a reasonable cost. The measures will not only make the enforcement of Australia's migration law more effective, but will ensure that individuals are treated fairly and are not subjected to unnecessary restrictions or inconvenience.

Establishment of the RRT will cost $3.2 million in 1992/93. However, the RRT will provide credible independent merit review, with an anticipated saving of approximately $72 million over the next four years, from the expected costs for the existing refugee determination system.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to the Bill.
MIGRATION (DELAYED VISA APPLICATIONS) TAX BILL 1992

The Migration (Delayed Visa Applications) Tax Bill is part of the migration legislative reforms which will provide more effective measures to detect and remove non-citizens who are unlawfully in Australia.

A tax will be imposed on an application for the grant of a visa or entry permit to a non-citizen who has been unlawfully in Australia for 12 months or more. It must be paid before the visa or entry permit may be granted.

The tax is intended to serve as an incentive for persons to come forward at an early stage to regularise their status, rather than remaining unlawfully in Australia indefinitely. The tax will be $3,000 for each complete year of unlawful presence in Australia. This amount will be indexed for applications made after the 1992-93 financial year.

Persons recognised as refugees will be exempt from the tax. The Bill also provides for the Minister to exclude the tax where the Minister determines that payment of the tax would cause an applicant extreme hardship.
The prime objective is to deter people from remaining in Australia unlawfully, rather than to raise revenue. Thus it is expected that the Bill will have a minimal financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the House and present the Explanatory Memorandum for the Bill.
