TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a couple of brief comments on the modelling unit about which I have a reservation in the report of Estimates Committee B. The remarks I would like to make relate to the debate which we have now had over two sets of Estimates committee hearings—additional Estimates in April and the one which has just concluded.

PARA.TAB: My reservation relates to the use by the Government of the Public Service. It is not my intention at this moment to recap the debate we had in the recent Estimates Committee, but merely to put on record something which I believe is of great concern in this country and which I hope the Public Service, in the coming months and perhaps in the next year or so, will look very closely at. That question relates to what I would term the politicisation of the Public Service, what the appropriate role of public servants is and how that role can be kept in line with the best traditions of the Public Service and be protected from what I see as the growing politicisation of the Public Service.

We have seen in Victoria and Western Australia that an independent public service, a public service which has a public service ethic, is of fundamental importance to the good governance of this country. Whereas I would not at this stage suggest that the Federal Treasury has reached a stage where we can see wholesale politicisation of this great Service, I believe that the experience of the modelling unit which was established under Dr Preston raises very grave concerns.

Last October, the head of the Treasury, Mr Cole, issued a press release saying that he wished to assure people that the Public Service was very conscious of the need to maintain its proper role and to avoid public servants being involved in political activity. That, to my mind, was a sensible and important statement. But the issue I believe people will have to address is whether Mr Tony Cole, Dr Preston and Dr Henry really complied with the spirit of that press release and with the traditions of the Public Service.

An important aspect of maintaining confidence in Australia is confidence in the Treasury—confidence in its capacity to produce objective figures and its capacity to give fearless advice. My concern is that I believe that, in establishing the modelling unit under Dr Preston and run by Dr Henry, the Treasury tipped over into involving itself in a party political activity and not a traditional Public Service activity.

Senator McMullan and I will differ on whether the behaviour of that unit was proper and in line with the best traditions of the Public Service or whether some serious errors of judgment were made, both by the Government and particularly by the guardians of the Public Service ethic, in this case Mr Cole and Dr Preston. I happen to think that a very serious error of judgment has been made and I hope that the Public Service, in its seminars and in debates that may occur over the coming period about issues concerning politicisation of the Public Service, will look very closely at whether Mr Cole and Dr Preston suddenly involved themselves in activities which were not in line with the best traditions of the Service.

I believe that if a unit in the Public Service acts like a political unit, is staffed like a political unit and does the work of a political unit, then it is a political unit and is not a public service unit. I have laid down in a number of speeches now some of the serious errors of judgment which I believe were made. I do not intend to add to those at present, but I believe that this is a very significant development in the history of the Australian Public Service. If the modelling unit, especially established under Dr Preston and now disbanded after its work has been done, represents the new standard of conduct of the Public Service, I believe that something serious has happened in this country.

In summary, I believe that there was a need for the Government to hide behind the great authority, tradition and prestige of the Treasury in order to mount an attack on the Opposition of an absolutely unprecedented level in terms of involvement of the Australian Public Service. I certainly accept, and it is a matter of record, that in the past the Public Service has provided briefing notes to governments on Opposition policies. Never has a special unit been established to attack an Opposition policy. And not only have briefing notes been provided but also this modelling unit has had assumptions ceaselessly fed into it by the Government to try to create results which will add weight to the Government's case. Public servants of very high standing and very high salaries were involved in this work and I believe that if this becomes the standard of conduct of the Public Service, Australia has lost a great deal.

I believe that Mr Cole and Dr Preston should look very closely at their conduct. It gives me no great pleasure to involve public servants in public debate, but if public servants decide they wish to, at the bidding of political masters, get out of the trenches and start firing shots at the political opponents of the Government, it is absolutely inevitable that those people will get caught up in the cross-fire. They cannot get out of their trenches, fire shots at the political opponents of the Government and then say, `Don't fire at me; I am a public servant'.

What we have, I believe, is a very serious occasion where not only have the public servants made serious misjudgments as to their role, but also the Government has made serious misjudgments involving the public servants in this role. I suggest to public servants and the Treasury, and perhaps younger Treasury officers who may at some stage read these remarks, that they look at how often the Government, in mounting its attacks against the coalition, has said, `The Treasury says this', `The Treasury says that', `The Treasury has estimated such and such' when the reality is that the tables and figures which have been produced have resulted from government assumptions being fed into a Treasury model.

I wonder whether Mr Cole and Dr Preston at any stage expressed concern to the Government along the lines of: `Whereas we have produced these figures we are worried that you are directly involving us in political debate'. I have noticed that Mr Dawkins, Mr Keating and Senator Button in this chamber—I do not know about Senator McMullan; I will have to look at the record—have stood up and said, `The Treasury has said that under Fightback such and such will happen' or `The Treasury has said that under your wages policy such and such will happen' when a close examination of the record shows that the Treasury has said no such thing.

It is not only for the public servants to closely examine their conduct in this whole rather sordid matter; it is also for the Government to examine its conduct. Let me tell the chamber that if this is the new rule for the Public Service, an incoming government will inevitably trade off the precedents which have become accepted and established.

It is not my intention this evening to enter into a debate, but I hope that in the coming months and years, when we talk about politicisation of the Public Service, we will take up the issue which has been presented to us—the modelling unit established by Mr Cole and Dr Preston, and relentlessly used by Mr Dawkins and Mr Keating. I hope we will ask ourselves, `Is this the appropriate behaviour for the Public Service in this country?'. I believe that when it is judged in this light, Mr Dawkins, Mr Keating, Mr Cole and Dr Preston will be judged somewhat harshly by those who come after us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot allow those remarks to go unresponded to, although like Senator Kemp, I do not wish to rehash a debate that we have had several times before and at great length. I accept that for the most part, while we have had some fiery clashes in the past, on this occasion Senator Kemp has sought to express his position in terms of the principles and objectives. I want to take up one point where I think he lapsed below that higher standard which he set for himself in this contribution and, in my judgement, at other times where we have clashed a little—he will not agree with that. I thought that on this occasion, in the main—with one exception when he phrased himself, at least, unfortunately and made it necessary for me to respond—he did try to put things in terms of the principles as he saw them.

PARA.TAB: I fundamentally disagree with his assessment of the legitimacy of the role, function and activities of the officers to whom he referred and my ministerial colleagues as well, but I think none of them will feel desperately in need of my springing to their defence in response to that attack. While I make that comment for the record, I will not worry about defending their position any more; they are quite capable of doing that for themselves.

The behaviour of the micro-economic model, its establishment and activities, have been proper and orthodox within the Public Service. Other modelling units have been set up in other departments, the work of which has been leapt upon with enthusiasm by the Opposition, as has the work of the Treasury in analysing Fightback. I am often in here debating Senator Macdonald, who often—as do others, I am sure—chooses parts of the Treasury analysis. I am not saying they misuse it—they selectively use it; but that is not a hanging offence. They say, `The Treasury says such and such', because that part of the analysis suits them.

Senator Alston does it about the Treasury's assessment of superannuation. He says, `The Treasury says such and such', because it is a very authoritative assessment. With regard to the comments that Senator Alston was making, at the very least, he is saying the Treasury says it on the basis of a Treasury analysis based on what the Treasury itself said it thought, and which I certainly considered to be very flawed assumptions. Nevertheless, it is true that the Treasury said that and Senator Alston quotes it.

He is entitled to quote it. He should quote it more comprehensively. But he does quote it. Senator Macdonald does so. Others do so. It is a part of the debate that goes on. It is a comment on the respect and integrity of the Treasury and the figures that it produces that all sides of the debate fall upon the figures it produces which can be claimed, at least in part, to support their case. That is all I want to say about that.

I want to respond to one particular phrase which Senator Kemp used which I found most unfortunate and most unfair. He was criticising the role of the unit. I disagree with him, but he was expressing his view and, in a democracy, we are all entitled to do that. He then said, `This is staffed like a political unit'. That is very unfair to everybody involved. It is very unfair to all the officers who made the decision, who implemented the decision and who were discharging their lawful instructions from their Minister properly and in accordance with the normal processes.

That was an unfortunate phrase and I want to say quickly that I think it was unreasonable. Tony Cole, Alan Preston, Ken Henry and any of the other officers involved will, should the unfortunate circumstance ever arise that the now Opposition becomes the government, serve that government very well as public servants, as they have served this Government well, because they are competent professionals. I think it was unfortunate that it was expressed in that manner. Beyond that, this is a debate that we have had before. We have both put our positions on the record before, we have said it again tonight, and I am sure we will do it again on a few more occasions, but I hope we can now get on to other parts of the Estimates.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to ask two or three quick questions about the national prices network. On the one hand, Senator McMullan has ministerial responsibility, given to him by the Treasurer, for the monitoring and accountability of the national prices network and, on the other hand, he is the politician who advocated the instigation of the NPN, and who lets the NPN work out of his electorate office. Prima facie, at least, there would appear to be a major conflict of interest for him between his duties as Parliamentary Secretary responsible for the proper use and audit of taxpayers' funds, on the one hand, and on the other hand, his role as a key player in an organisation which is the recipient of a grant which he has been instrumental in having given.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Parliamentary Secretary how he resolves that conflict of interest. Can he build a Chinese wall or something like that within himself? Certainly there does appear to be a very significant conflict of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to all other senators for taking up time when it will be late at night before they can deal with the matters that they think important, but I have to respond to this because, apparently, Senator Short thinks this is important.

PARA.TAB: Senator Short has it back to front. It is because I am Parliamentary Secretary, and the then Treasurer asked me to look at the national prices network and enable the 1987 decision of the Government to have continuing effect, that I initiated the network. It was not as some disembodied person separate from my function as Parliamentary Secretary. When the people who had carried out the function for the Government from 1987 were no longer prepared to do it for a price we were prepared to pay, I set out to find a way of achieving, with proper accountability requirements, the objectives of the Government as publicly articulated, and established a bona fide unit to independently discharge that operation.

I do not go and tell that unit what to do or interfere with its operations. It was not some person other than the Parliamentary Secretary who set it up. I did it because I was the Parliamentary Secretary and because it was a mechanism for enabling the objectives, as outlined by Prime Minister Hawke, for providing assistance to consumers to be achieved. That is why I went out and set it up. It was the sensible, most cost-effective way of achieving the objective. If my memory serves me correctly, in the process we managed to get the function done for at least $60,000, and perhaps $100,000, less than was the alternative proposal.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not pursue that further other than to say that I presume Senator McMullan's electorate will be the judges as to whether there is a conflict of interest there. I have one final question on NPN. I notice we have now had a response to a question that Senator Bishop left with the Treasury at the Estimates Committee hearings. That response is to the effect that the drafting of the NPN constitution was carried out jointly by the Treasury and the Attorney-General's Department. What earthly business is it of the Treasury or the Attorney-General's Department to be involved in the drafting of what is said to be essentially a community organisation, and was payment made to either the Treasury or to the Attorney-General's Department for the work involved?

—It follows logically from my previous answer that, as Parliamentary Secretary, I decided that the establishment of this body was the most cost effective way of achieving the Government's objective. Accordingly, I set out to achieve the objectives of the Government in the most cost effective way, with the appropriate departmental advice from Treasury and the Attorney-General's Department, to make sure that what we did was consistent with proper process and audit and that the legal requirements were properly discharged, as would be my normal obligation. It would be the normal function of any department to advise the Parliamentary Secretary or Minister in such a matter: the Attorney-General's Department would advise on the most appropriate way to proceed within the law to discharge the objectives of the Government. That is what I did. I sought the normal departmental advice that anybody in my position would, and I received it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —At this stage of the evening I will not pursue that matter other than to say I find it quite extraordinary that, for an exercise which is no more than an Australian Labor Party exercise, the use of taxpayers' money and resources is used by the Treasury and the Attorney-General's Department—of all departments—in this way. I find it quite extraordinary and very distasteful indeed.

PARA.TAB: I ask a final question on program 1 relating to the provision by the Department of reports on the inflationary impact of indirect tax mix switches. The GST tax mix switch was the one I was particularly referring to. Amongst the articles that the Treasury has provided—and I thank it for that—is an article which makes use of a study by Alan Tait of the IMF. The article concludes:

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the most important conclusion to be drawn from the discussion here is that there seems to be nothing inherently inflationary about the use of the VAT.
It also says:
While some commentators have associated VAT rate changes with inflation, the weight of evidence seems to be against it. Indeed, practical commonsense suggests the opposite.

I thank the Treasury for that material. If that indeed is a view that is shared by the Treasury—there is no indication that it is not—I ask Senator McMullan why the Government is continuing to misrepresent the inflationary impact of the GST proposal, which of course is nothing other than a value added tax. Why does the Government so continue to misrepresent that inflationary impact?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not the time to start a political debate with Senator Short.

SPEECH.PARA: So can I just restrain myself from starting an attack upon the inadequacy of the policy framework within which the Opposition will be implementing its GST, which is why we think the price effects will last beyond one year, and say that Senator Short asked the Treasury if it was aware of any evidence, studies or articles and it provided some articles. It did not endorse the articles or otherwise. He asked for some and it provided them. It is not reasonable to impute a view to the Treasury from that, and I am sure Senator Kemp would be very cross with Senator Short for doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does that mean that you have a different view on the inflationary impact to that provided by the Treasury?
—If Senator Short had listened to the answer, he would know the answer.
—I was slightly distracted. Perhaps the Minister could put it on the record again.

—Once again, I apologise to our colleagues, but Senator Short asked me the question and I have to answer it. Senator Short asked the Treasury for articles, not for its view. The Treasury provided articles. It did not necessarily endorse them. I indicated clearly that I was going to refrain from reiterating the debates we have had here on numerous occasions about why I think the policy framework within which the Opposition is proposing to implement a GST is flawed, which will mean that the price effects will last beyond the one year envisaged. But Senator Short disagrees with me on that, and this is not the place to have that debate; I will restrain myself. The material that has been presented is not the Treasury's view; it is the Treasury's response to a request for any articles about the subject.

—There being no further questions on program 1, we move to program 2. Are there any matters to be raised? Are there any matters to be raised in programs 3, 4 or 5? There being no matters, we therefore move to program 6.

—I want to pick up on a couple of points I asked about before on the program relating to the Treasury which should have been more properly directed to the Tax Office. However, I will give way to Senator O'Chee, who has some questions. I will follow mine up later as appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions in relation to questions placed on notice on 16 September. I refer to a question in which I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Have any audits been undertaken into the tax compliance by overseas inbound tour operators receiving commissions for shopping by tourists they brought into Australia?
The answer I received to the question was:
An audit project was undertaken in Townsville on the Tax residency of tour guides lodging returns in Australia.

I have pointed out to Senator McMullan that this was not an answer to the question asked. There is a distinction between the tour guides, who may be resident in Australia, and the inbound tour operators. The tour guides are employees or contractors of the inbound tour operators. I commence with this question: have any audits into tax compliance by overseas inbound tour operators been undertaken?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that part 4 of that answer is simply a misprint. It in fact refers to tour operators, not tour guides.

—Is it then correct that the answer to question 5 also relates to inbound tour operators? If so, that means there were 320 inbound tour operators—which seems a rather large number—in the North Queensland area.
—I am told the answer is yes.

—Given that I am at a bit of a loss to find 320 inbound tour operators in the North Queensland area, perhaps Senator McMullan could clarify the situation by indicating what the Australian Taxation Office considered to be inbound tour operators.

—I understand they are people involved in the provision of organised packages for incoming tourists. On the face of it, it seems to be a fairly straightforward definition, although it is not my particular area of expertise. That is my understanding.

—I put on the record that, in the general parlance of the tourism industry, people who are involved in the provision of services are not in fact inbound tour operators. Inbound tour operators are the people who contract to bring in the tourists. There is a difference between the people who bring in the tourists and the people who actually provide services to those tourists once they have arrived in Australia. Of the 320 files audited, how many of the audits related to persons or companies who were involved in contracting to bring in tourists from overseas?
—I do not know the answer to that question. A sub-categorisation of this is not available.

—One of the problems is that the answer is very imprecise. When one refers to inbound tour operators, one refers to people who contract to bring in tourists—that is, people who actually provide the package tours rather than people who provide components of the package tours. People who provide components of the package tours, for example, would not be eligible to be members of the Inbound Tour Operators Association. Through Senator McMullan, I request that the Department provide me, as soon as possible, with a detailed answer in relation to the people who are inbound tour operators under the definition I have provided. I hope that would be able to be provided to me fairly quickly—certainly before we return, because the answer that has been given really does not answer the question at all. In particular, it does not answer the question about tax compliance in relation to commissions.

PARA.TAB: Even if one accepted the argument that these people were what the Australian Taxation Office believed to be inbound tour operators, the answer does not relate to audits in relation to commissions. I ask Senator McMullan whether he would be willing to undertake to provide me with an answer in relation to tax audits of people who contract to bring in tourists from overseas. More specifically, I ask for an answer to the question in relation to those persons or companies receiving commissions for shopping undertaken by the tourists they have brought into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will undertake to do that.
—Is Senator McMullan in a position to indicate whether that would be available by the time we return?

—I am not in a position to do that at the moment, but I will certainly let Senator O'Chee know how long it will take and any other details as soon as I can. During the recess, I will certainly give Senator O'Chee what information is available and tell him what the timetable will be thereafter.

—I thank Senator McMullan for that. I am a little concerned that the questions which were placed on notice took about six weeks to be answered. I hope this will not take that long. In relation to the answer given to question 5, I understand that of the 320 files audited, 200 have been finalised and adjustments have been made to 44 per cent of those audited. How does that compare to audit adjustment rates in other categories of occupation?
—It is actually lower than the usual average which I am told is in the low 60s.

—Part (a) of the answer to question 5 says that of the 88 adjustments, 27 were adjustments relating to wrongly claimed tax residency. Could the officers advise what is meant by `wrongly claimed tax residency'? Does it mean that people were claiming to be non-resident when they were resident, or does it mean something else? If so, what does it mean?
—I understand that, in the main—if not in all cases—it was people claiming to be residents when they were non-residents to take advantage of the tax-free threshold available to residents.

—I thank Senator McMullan for that answer. Part (b) of the answer to question 5 indicates that there were 61 other adjustments that were other offences detected by the audits. Perhaps the officers might be able to advise Senator McMullan and, via Senator McMullan, the chamber, what sort of offences those were.
—Rather than rely on someone's memory, I will provide Senator O'Chee with a breakdown of those within a few days.

—I thank Senator McMullan for that answer. The reason why I asked for those further particulars is that I do have a little concern that `other offences' could mean all sorts of things. It could mean something fairly minor; of course, it could mean something more substantial. My particular concern about tour guides relates to the receiving of commissions. I understand that the receiving of secret commissions could also be categorised as understating income if the commissions are not declared. So when the officers are preparing the answer for Senator McMullan to provide, perhaps they would be kind enough to prepare the answer with a view to addressing those issues, as well as the broader issues of what other offences there were.
—That is possible. We will do that.
—I thank Senator McMullan. I do not have any further questions in relation to this matter, although I do have questions in relation to Aust-Home investments under subprogram 6.1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a number of questions relating to information that was sought at the Estimates hearings. Questions were taken on notice and information has subsequently been supplied. I might echo Senator Short's earlier comments about the manner in which this material has been supplied—the drip-drip nature. It was finally put together in a booklet as late as this evening. This is unsatisfactory. Nonetheless, I will turn to some of the answers that are provided.

PARA.TAB: I might say that the manner in which some answers have been provided is unsatisfactory as well. I will give an example. I asked this simple question:

SPEECH.PARA: We had the figures for the number of people who were prosecuted for the year ending 30 June 1991 for failure to lodge tax returns.

Senator McMullan will know that I am particularly interested in this because Mr Keating got special treatment and last year 10,800 ordinary Australians were prosecuted. So I asked this year for the figures. I asked:
Could you give me the figures for the year ending 30 June 1992?
I would have thought that was a straightforward question. The answer reads:

1. The number of taxpayers convicted for failure to comply with the requirement of the Commissioner in 1992 was 6,821 and the number of charges that went through to conviction was 8,069. Some taxpayers have multiple charges to answer. The bulk of these prosecutions relate to failure to lodge tax returns.
What on earth is meant by `the bulk'? I asked a simple question. Is Senator McMullan telling me that the Tax Office no longer keeps those records? If it does not, why not?

TALK.START.PARA: —There was some confusion because, in terms of the scheduling of things, as I understood it this comes under subprogram 6.1. I expected this question to be asked when that was properly before us. My advice is that all the 6,821 relate to failure to lodge tax returns. I do not know why that last sentence was phrased that way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the only thing that is wrong with the expression. It says, `the number of taxpayers convicted for failure to comply with the requirements of the Commissioner'. That could be a myriad of things. I would like to know why the Tax Office is unable to give a straightforward answer to a straightforward question.

PARA.TAB: In order to save a bit of time, I will go to the second part of the question, which was also answered in a similarly poor vein. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Would you tell me the percentage of them that dealt with a tax agent and the percentage that did not?

I would have thought that that is fairly significant, since during evidence I was told from time to time that the Tax Office used to have one system for dealing with agents and another for dealing with individuals. The answer given says:

There is no complete set of figures at present indicating the percentage of them that dealt with tax agents and those that did not. However, the ATO is now in the process of setting up such a measure, and will be able to report on this in the future.
Is this part of the record keeping problem that the Tax Office seems to have?

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that every circumstance in which the piece of information that a particular individual wants is not correlated in the way he wants could in one sense be interpreted as a problem of record keeping. But I am advised that this is a record that has not been kept in the past. As far as I know, it is not a recent phenomenon, but it will be in the future. Any time anybody wants to know in the future, we will be able to provide an answer.
—In order to recap: 6,821 ordinary Australians, as distinct from the nearly 10,800 last year, were prosecuted for failure to lodge a tax return in the way that Mr Keating was not; is that correct?

—I do not want to get into debate here and waste the time of the Committee about whether the circumstances were comparable, because we have had that discussion before. Senator Bishop does not accept the distinction—that is her right—and I do not know why not. I am advised that 6,821 is the number of people who were convicted for failing to lodge a tax return. That is my advice. Mr Chairman, in the interests of orderly procedure, I request that we deal with those items that are under program 6 before we go to subprogram 6.1.

—Mr Chairman, I seek your guidance with regard to what you will interpret as being the way to proceed. I am dealing with matters arising out of questions that were taken on notice, many of which were not answered at the time the report was lodged. But it is almost impossible to tell which is which because of the manner in which the material has been dealt with. I recall that Senator McMullan quite cleverly prevented some answers being given at the Estimates by using this little ploy. I do not want it to happen again.

—Most of the matters are just listed as being under program 6. There are only two matters listed under subprogram 6.1: the Aust-Home group of companies—treatment of investors; and unanswered questions.

—Mr Chairman, in my reservation, which I understand was in the correct form, I wrote `Department of Treasury, program 6, Taxation Administration' and I listed a number of things. As I said, I am dealing at present with questions that were taken on notice by the Tax Office and which, under the terms of the report put in by Estimates Committee B, are perfectly correctly dealt with under program 6 in a general manner, as I understand it.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

INTERJECT.PARA: That matters raised in this report and all questions taken on notice, as recorded in the list attached to this report, may be further examined by the Senate.
That has been accepted. It would seem to me that there is so little overlap between program 6 and subprogram 6.1 that it might be worthwhile not to try to dichotomise them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Chairman. I would like to return to questions which were taken on notice. I refer to page 163 of the additional information supplied and to my concern that a number of people who had been convicted of criminal offences were employees of the Australian Taxation Office and were still employed by the Tax Office. In other words, we have criminally convicted people acting as employees in the Tax Office. I understand there were three of them.

PARA.TAB: I asked the nature of the crime. The answer came back that two officers were convicted of criminal offences against the Tax Office and remain in the Tax Office employment. In both cases the offence was theft and disciplinary action was taken under the Public Service Act. That was the first part of the answer.
I ask: are those people still employed in the Tax Office because of the agreement with the Public Sector Union which forbids compulsory retrenchment?

TALK.START.PARA: —No, that has nothing to do with it.
—Would you kindly tell me why we employ thieves in the tax department?

—The law is the same for the tax department as elsewhere. Depending on the nature of the offence, employees in various areas of public and private employment continue to be employed. There is nothing in public or private employment that says that once people are convicted of a criminal offence they can never be employed again.

—The Australian Taxation Office is tantamount to a law enforcement agency. It is highly irregular that thieves are employed there. I asked the nature of the crime. I was told that it was theft. I want to know specifically what it is that was stolen.
—I understand that in one instance there was a theft of a piece of video equipment and the other involved some minor items of office stores.
—I am not quite sure what `minor' is and I do not know how big the video equipment was. What disciplinary action was taken?
—I cannot provide all the information about both cases. If Senator Bishop would prefer to put the question on notice, I will get the information for her.
—I point out that I did put it on notice. I asked the nature of the crime. I was given a glib answer. Perhaps it is, once again, not getting the truth at the first ask.

PARA.TAB: The second part of the answer states that a third officer is known to have been criminally convicted, the offence being the possession of cannabis; but this was not associated with his employment in the ATO. I thought that might have provided us with the answer as to why the Tax Office gets its forecasting wrong: everyone is smoking cannabis. Is that person still employed?

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as I know, yes.
—So we have a cannabis smoker and two thieves still employed. Do we have any more felons?

—I point out that at least in one State the cannabis smoker and possibly also the thieves would be eligible to stand for the Senate. I am not quite sure why they would not be able to work in the Tax Office.

—Not if they had had a criminal conviction of one year, which is exactly the position that the Tax Office has placed Mr Smiles in by choosing to prosecute under the Crimes Act and putting the coalition Government in New South Wales at risk. That was a very smart answer, Senator McMullan.

I am not aware of any question being asked to the ATO. If Senator Bishop can point it out to me, I will try to find the answer. My understanding is that it was asked of the Treasury.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Does this belong to the unanswered questions section?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it does. All these questions were taken on notice. The reason I am relating it to Tax at this stage is that, having asked for the report, the answer that came back was:

PARA.TAB: The trip report is mostly recorded of confidential discussions between Australian officials and New Zealand officials and of discussions in confidence with New Zealand business representatives and academics. The report covered a trip to New Zealand between 16 September and 18 September 1991 to study the modelling of that country's goods and services tax and various compliance costs, administration costs and other issues. TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to get into a debate. It would be inappropriate as colleagues want to get on with other business. It is still my understanding that the only question on this matter was a question to the Treasury. I do not think any question was put to the Tax Office. I cannot find a record of one. My recollection is that the question was to Treasury.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —There was also a question to the Australian Taxation Office, and I think it can be found in the Hansard of 20 October. Nonetheless, I want to move on because of the pressure of time to another topic. I refer to questions asked of Mr Highfield concerning the questioning we had about the shortfall in money to pay salaries. Honourable senators will recall that I said that the Tax Office, if it were a corporation, would have been placed in receivership because, quite frankly, it would run out of money in 1992-93 because it had approximately 1,000 people who were surplus to the collection of the revenue and who had to stay on the payroll because of the Public Sector Union agreement entered into as a competing agreement by the Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: I asked some questions of Mr Carmody first. Mr Carmody is going to be the new Commissioner of Taxation. I asked him about the 1,000 people who were surplus and Mr Carmody said:

SPEECH.PARA: We require 1,000 fewer people to do what we were charged to do under the resources we had at the time . . . There have been no compulsory retrenchments from the organisation.
I asked:
Does the Public Sector Union agreement with the Australian Tax Office preclude anyone being retrenched?
Mr Carmody replied:
There is a guarantee of no compulsory retrenchment as a result of modernisation.
I then said:

So, indeed, the undertakings that were made to the Department of Finance cannot be met. The Department of Finance will meet the situation by simply giving you less money in your appropriation, will it not?
Mr Carmody replied:
It has given us less money in the appropriation because we have found the efficiencies from the implementation of the projects.

that being over a three-year period. Mr Carmody replied:

I then said:

Mr Highfield said:
The $115m is composed of $78m of salary. In fact, it has absolutely nothing whatsoever to do with the current staffing position of the ATO.
I said:

Mr Carmody said:
We are paying more salaries.
Mr Highfield asked me to repeat the question, and I said:
Are you going to have a shortfall in money available to pay salaries in the Australian Taxation Office without that $115m being made available to you?
Mr Highfield said:
There is no shortfall.

I now turn to information that had been asked for and prepared as a result of a question from Senator Short. A live telephone broadcast by Mr Boucher entitled `The ATO's Staffing Situation', which was made in March, reads as follows:
Good morning.

This is Trevor Boucher speaking to you all from my office in Canberra. I have an important message, which I want to put to you direct. There is simply not enough time for me to get around to all Branches in person. We have a problem which we must work on straight away.

PARA.TAB: More people are staying in Tax than ever before. This is partly due to the recession. It is also a reflection of our successful efforts to make Tax a better place to work.
The outcome is that we have a budget which in 1992/93 will not cover all of our salary needs.
This is the budget shortfall you will hear people talking about.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the one Mr Highfield said we did not have. Mr Boucher continued:
So I would like to talk to you for the next five or six minutes about our planned actions.

PARA.TAB: It is good that people talk about the issue, because I know that we are all concerned about problems which affect us and our organisation. It shows we are pulling together even better.

The budget shortfall is not a happy situation. But it is there, and we must work to solve the two main challenges it creates for us. First, the fact that too many staff for the budget have been allocated.
The second that we all have too little salary money.

At my level the answer is simple: As your Commissioner I must ask you to help us close the gap. In the next few months I would like you to have worked together to figure out ways in which you or your staff can contribute to generate savings. Or, for some people, by taking opportunities to work elsewhere, part-time, or take leave without pay.

SPEECH.PARA: A wonderful way to solve the budget shortfall! The speech continues:
By generating savings, we'll be able to pay our extra people while we continue to come up with ways for our numbers to drop to a manageable level.

PARA.TAB: Some people say `let's have packages, just like other organisations'. However, those organisations have generally offered packages because of the disappearance of functions. We feel we have a different problem and we're looking for a different solution.
What I am asking you is to examine your present spending to see if there are some extra savings you could make over the next few months and into next year. Every bit helps.
At the same time though, throughout Tax, putting in place a whole range of practical strategies without hurting productivity, or forcing anyone to leave.

SPEECH.PARA: [Pause]

PARA.TAB: I guess you are asking `How did this staffing budget shortfall come about?'

SPEECH.PARA: This is the one Mr Highfield told us we did not have. Mr Boucher continues:

More people are staying in the Tax Office than ever before. In the past, something like 8 to 10 per cent of our staff in any one year would have moved onto other careers or retired. If you look around you, and that means it is in other years, up to one in any 10 of you would have moved from Tax.

PARA.TAB: Last year fewer people left. The 8/10 per cent is down to 3 per cent, and we have recently observed that staff who were on unpaid leave have been returning. We are also a younger Tax Office and fewer people are retiring.
You'll all recall my promise not to retrench people or do away with jobs. I have kept that promise.
But our numbers have kept up.
And with so many staying in Tax, earning normal salary increments, even the normal salary requirement has grown.

We have reduced recruiting to a minimum, as you know. And we have begun programs to make it easier to transfer to other Departments, and to take positive action to reduce our extra staff load. But the effect of fewer people leaving, especially during the past couple of years is still with us. Our budget shortfall is around $20 million out of a total salary and administrative budget of some $825 million. If we did nothing, we would for 1992/93 effectively have 600 people over our salary budget. 350 of these are not actual people, but the extra salary to cover increments—and I have asked the Department of Finance to increase our running cost funds to cover this unexpected increase.
But this still leaves us with a gap in the budget, equivalent to 250 people.

SPEECH.PARA: [Pause]

PARA.TAB: Knowing as I do that Tax people will rise to the challenge, I ask for your interest and help. Where and how we can save. Are there people who would like to work part-time, take unpaid leave, or even work in another agency?
I spoke with each of our DC's and Program Heads, last Thursday. I asked them to take you into their confidence and see what we can do.

I have asked them—and I ask each of you—to see if there aren't some economies, some savings you might contribute in your area, until such time as our numbers drop back to levels to match available funds. Your senior people will be able to answer any particular questions. I have asked them to make sure everyone gets a chance to participate.
Remember it is not a large problem in dollar terms, but it is one we must turn to straightaway.
I should add this. As always we do have an obligation to make sure that everyone who works in Tax is productively employed. Staff themselves want to contribute.

For some people this will mean being productive in new ways, especially in our Modernisation improvements make it possible to do much more of our old work with many fewer people. Which allows us to turn attention to all the other things that now need attention.
For some people it will mean finding new ways to become economical in their budgets—finding savings which can be used to pay for the people who choose to be in Tax.
Thanks for listening and good luck with your discussions.

SPEECH.PARA: What an absolute disgrace! Would Senator McMullan ask why Mr Highfield mislead the Senate Estimates Committee and told it quite simply an untruth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop's assumption is fundamentally flawed. I wish to comment first on the ridiculous waste of 10 minutes of the Committee's time on a document that is already on the record and that could have been incorporated, in which case it would have been presented accurately instead of in the way that Senator Bishop read it.
—I read quite accurately, thank you.
—I am not going to bother with the minor errors in it, because they were not relevant to the central core. But 10 valuable minutes would have been saved had they not been wasted just then.
—We needed to know that there was a shortfall.

—I am sure that is very exciting for the senator. Can I explain that that speech, made in March, outlined a problem that would have arisen had no subsequent action been taken. This speech was part of a strategy to deal with the problem that might have arisen. It was a successful strategy, such that there was not in October, when the senator asked the question, a continuing shortfall. That is the reason for the answer. It is not reasonable or appropriate to lightly throw around accusations about people which are inaccurate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We had several instances where the Tax Office had to change the record. It fixed it all right. It converted $61m of money for administration into salary money and borrowed another $19m. Mr Mobbs, who is with us tonight, gave us a delightful presentation. He gave us a presentation which was called `Is the ATO bankrupt: the borrowing picture'. That is an interesting document. He said that back in 1989-90 the Tax Office had a borrowing that was repaid; in 1990-91 it did not have to borrow anything and in 1991-92 it borrowed $3m, which was repaid. Then he showed us the line which said that in 1992-93 $19m was borrowed and $18m repaid. The trouble was that it was not.

PARA.TAB: We found out after rather lengthy questioning that Mr Mobbs had told us something that was not true. In fact, what had occurred was that he, the Tax Office, Mr Boucher or somebody had got the Government to promise that next year it would forgive $18m of the $19m borrowed. That was correction No. 1 that we had to make.

We went on to look at the further allocations. In the current year, 1992-93, there was a change in the rules from Finance and you could forward borrow up to 6 per cent, instead of 3 per cent. Mr Mobbs showed us that in 1993-94, 1994-95 and 1995-96 he could go on borrowing up to $41m, $40m and another $40m. When I asked him on a subsequent occasion whether this was why it thought it could scrape through, he said, `Yes, that would be right'. The only trouble was that Mr Mobbs had not read the Finance regulations properly.

Very simply, one may not borrow in two consecutive years without having a special arrangement with the Department of Finance. The Department of Finance gave evidence that there was no such agreement in place. The evidence that Mr Mobbs gave us that he could continue to borrow for the subsequent years was also not true. He had to admit that he was embarrassed and he apologised for that.

I felt sorry for Mr Mobbs because he had been placed in an untenable position. He was the man who was supposed to prove that the Tax Office did not need the $114m, which quite clearly it did. When we go to back to Mr Boucher's opening statement in evidence in October—bearing in mind his speech in March—we find that in a very high-minded way he said:

SPEECH.PARA: These views that Senator Bishop is putting are significantly damaging to the Tax Office . . . They are so potentially damaging that I would like the Committee, as I say, to hear and consider what we have to say.
That is, what Mr Mobbs had to say. Mr Boucher continued:

Then, in due course, my request is that the Committee should as a committee formally disassociate itself from what I believe are extravagant claims in those respects—that is, I am asking that the Committee pass judgment on this issue, being confident of the outcome.

In other words, he was trying to say that the ATO did not need the $114m and that it could get by without it. Very simply, it could not. We will go back to Estimates Committee hearings in a moment and we will see how the $1.7 billion was found at the same time as the Tax Office got the extra $114m. If we look at the figures, we see that there is to be a payment of $42.3m to be given to the Tax Office in the next calendar year, but no revenue is to be collected until the year after the first payment is made.

PARA.TAB: We have the fascinating system whereby the forecasts for collection of the revenue were down by $3.4 billion—in other words, it got it wrong. Mr Boucher admitted in March that salaries could not be paid. By the time the Tax Office came to give testimony in October to the Estimates committees, it made no mention of the fact that it had such a shortfall. It purported to give evidence that showed that it had forward borrowings available to it, which it did not. The Tax Office purported to say that it had repaid money, which it had not. Quite frankly, when Mr Highfield said there was no shortfall, that is what was meant, and yet only a month before Mr Boucher had said it was there. Now, testing the information given to Senator McMullan, I want the Tax Office to outline chapter and verse precisely where the savings—every little bit that Mr Boucher refers to—were found. I repeat: chapter and verse.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a ridiculous proposition that Senator Bishop should come in here at this stage in the Estimates proceedings trying to get these answers. We had days of dealing with this matter in Public Accounts Committee hearings, where Senator Bishop got answers that she did not like. She tried again in the Estimates and got the correct answers that she did not like, so now she is coming back and trying a third time.

PARA.TAB: I am not going to start a massive, resource intensive task to provide all that welter of detail that Senator Bishop has requested. There have been strategies in place entirely consistent with the speech that the Commissioner made and with the information, as I understand it, that has been provided to Estimates and to the Public Accounts Committee. These relate to savings in administration expenses, reductions in salaries concerning part time work, the reduction of overtime, people going on leave without pay and the transfer of officers to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. Those strategies have successfully enabled the Tax Office to meet its obligations. I must tell Senator Bishop that the proof of the pudding will be in the eating.

TALK.START.PARA: —The proof of the pudding will be in the eating when we start to look at figures such as the administration budget that was saved in the area of the Child Support Agency. That Agency, so severely criticised by the Ombudsman, only partially spent its budget. In other words, if it had more adequately handled its funds, it could given a better service. That is a different area.

PARA.TAB: I am very conscious of the fact that the Government, because it does not handle its business well, is trying to force through all the Estimates hearings tonight. Therefore, I will curtail the sorts of questions that I intend to ask tonight. But that does not mean to say that I will not demand the answers. Mr Highfield told us that there was no shortfall and Mr Boucher told us there was. There is not a sufficient explanation between the two statements as to where this money mysteriously came from, unless it is the money tree depicted in advertising commissioned by the ATO that indicates its philosophy.

Mr Highfield and Mr Carmody both gave evidence on 20 October that they were commissioned and asked to do the work regarding the $1.7 billion—that was subsequently found in the strategy that Mr Boucher brought forward and that Mr Dawkins adopted—only one week after the Budget. That strategy was sent to Mr Dawkins on 16 September. In other words, all the work was allegedly completed within less than three weeks; that is just not possible. Any reading of the Estimates record will show that that work is inaccurate and that the figures cannot be substantiated. To put it mildly, it is sloppy.

When we look at the amount of evidence that was given and was then—to put it politely—corrected and when we look at the perfectly proper questions that Mr Boucher refused to answer relating to why he is leaving the Tax Office, we find that these matters impinge very much upon the Estimates hearings with regard to the sudden finding of this $1.7 billion. In all the reading of the evidence that is before us, the question remains unanswered as to why we are sending someone who is on a salary of $120,000 to Paris to replace someone who is a band 2 SES officer earning between $70,000 and $81,000 and the perks that go with it. Those are questions to be asked in another place.

The real question before us today in relation to the questions that were taken on notice concerns the fact that, quite clearly, the evidence that was given that tried to cover up the fact that the Tax Office needed the $114m came out of this supplementary evidence that was given, and the fact that without that money the Tax Office could not have met its bills, plus the very important—
Consideration interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. I am sure you are aware of standing order 185(3). I am sure you can enforce that.

—I am well aware of standing order 185(3). I think that a number of other senators are not. But I think they are resuming their places. Would those honourable senators standing please leave the chamber if they are not staying in the chamber or take a seat, preferably their own. The Committee is considering program 6.

—Mr Boucher said in a speech he made to the Tax Office at the end of March 1992 that there was a shortfall in revenue of approximately $20m. Mr Highfield told us in October 1992 that there was no shortfall. At no stage did anybody at all give evidence, despite close questioning in both the Public Accounts Committee hearings and the Estimates hearings, that at any stage the Tax Office had admitted there was a shortfall and that it had to take certain precautions.

PARA.TAB: I simply cannot see, on the evidence that has been presented over days, that there is anything to suggest that any savings were made that could fill that hole. In fact, the $19m forward borrowing could well have filled that hole for that current year. But that would stop the Tax Office borrowing forward and it would need, as I said, part of that $114m the following year, and it would need that $114m over the three-year period.

I asked the officers to take this matter on notice, to go away and bring back chapter and verse in every detail where they allege that $20m was saved, bearing in mind that Mr Highfield told the Estimates Committee—when he was asked about the strategy on which he and Mr Carmody had worked for less than three weeks to produce the one that was subsequently adopted by Mr Dawkins—that, indeed, that document read at its face value would suggest to the reader that it was meant to pay for 630 new employees. He admitted in those hearings that in fact there was nothing in that document that really necessitated those employees to be new employees, and that it was money that would be used to pay existing employees.

Quite frankly, we have seen an admission by Mr Boucher of the shortfall and what I can only describe as a cover-up after that to try to say that the Tax Office was in good shape. The $1.7 billion which is alleged to have been found, quite frankly, if it was able to be identified, should have been being recovered then and there—not waiting until the year 1993-94, which is what is proposed. To say that the Tax Office is mismanaged is, I think, a very fair comment.

On the record we have a thousand people redundant or surplus to the needs of the Tax Office; 3,000 people promised to be no longer employed by the Tax Office under the agreement with the Department of Finance; a Public Sector Union agreement which precludes anybody being compulsorily retrenched—and, therefore, the Tax Office finding itself in the situation described by Mr Boucher in March and denied any knowledge of in October. It will be interesting to look at whether some of the evidence which was given amounts to perjury in the terms of the Public Accounts Committee Act. Then we have the blow-out in the figures where there was a shortfall in projected revenues of $3.4 billion. The record is one of mismanagement.

When we add to that the Auditor-General's report that the Australian Tax Office keeps inadequate records and we read the report that came down on electronic lodgment where no work has been done to remedy the faulty legal structure that is in place, despite the fact that it has been in operation since 1990, I think there is a very good case that the Tax Office is going to have to lift its game. If Mr Boucher's leaving is going to facilitate that, then perhaps even the price of a ticket to Paris is going to be justified.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I do not want to delay the Committee very long. Like Senator Bishop, I am a member of the Public Accounts Committee and, like Senator Bishop—or perhaps unlike Senator Bishop—I have read all the evidence. In fact, I have read all the Hansard transcripts and I cannot, as yet, come to the conclusion that, to quote Senator Bishop, `the Tax Office is mismanaged'. She describes that as a fair comment.

PARA.TAB: We sat on that Committee together week after week with Senator Watson and others. We looked at the evidence, we heard various groups coming before us and there was a great deal of questioning of Mr Boucher and his officers. I think that the processes involved in an inquiry like that conducted by the Public Accounts Committee are that we hear the evidence; we then make a judgment on that evidence; then, as a committee, we make a judgment; and our report is then presented to the Parliament. That is especially an appropriate process if, for example, anything in the report reflects in any way at all on individual officers.

So the point I want to make tonight is, first of all, that there are many people, I would say the vast majority of people on the Public Accounts Committee, all the members, who have not yet made a judgment about the Australian Tax Office. We will not make that judgment until we have read all the transcripts and presumably until we have spoken as a committee. Today we made a decision at our meeting, at which Senator Bishop was not present, that we would in fact hold some judgments over—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. The meeting of the Public Accounts Committee subcommittee this morning was a private meeting and it would be a contempt for Senator Aulich to discuss what transpired at it.
—I am not sure that Senator Aulich is discussing what has happened at the meeting.

—Mr Chairman, I have in no way discussed what was decided at that meeting. What I am saying is that the processes of that Committee are, in fact, still going on, as they should be. It is a very complex matter. It is the first major inquiry into the Australian Tax Office. I believe we, as committee members, ought to be fair and impartial about the evidence that was brought before us. Every member of that Committee so far has approached that problem of trying to work out what should be done, what recommendations we ought to make, in a fair and impartial manner. I find it extraordinary that Senator Bishop, in her enthusiasm to pillory not only Mr Boucher but also other people in the Tax Office, should come in here tonight and make judgments about issues that have been before the Committee in the way that she has. The question of Mr Boucher's appointment to the OECD is not an issue we should be discussing here tonight.
—We are not.

—Senator Bishop says that we are not. She raised it. She once again did what I regard as a totally unacceptable thing; she has made a connection between the appointment of a particular officer to a very important position in Paris—and if she does not believe that the OECD position is important, she should say so now—and certain things that were done with the budget of the Australian Tax Office and its capacity to collect revenue. I do not think that that connection is an appropriate one. I think it is only fair that, as a member of the Public Accounts Committee, I make my views known here.

PARA.TAB: Honestly, I have applauded Senator Bishop on occasion for the tenacity with which she goes about her questioning. I have no problems with the fact that she will go on and on until she finds what she wants; or maybe sometimes she even finds the truth—and they are not always the same. The problem is that on the way there she happens to shoot the stage coach driver, the Indians on the side of the road, she burns the general store and she probably opens the gate to the fort to let the outlaws in—but at the end of the route she has got there. But it is the Bishop search-and-destroy method. We have burning villages left behind in her wake as she moves towards this ultimate goal of discovering the `truth', according to the Bishop—the Bishop truth. The Bishop truth sure enough sat around for 2,000 years in Rome, but it was not always right—and Senator Bishop is not always right.

I think it ought to be on record tonight from at least one member of the Public Accounts Committee, so that the press in this place starts to understand, that we do not make judgments about very complicated issues, about people's reputations and we do not make connections between a post being given and revenues gained for government. We do not make those connections. If the press wants to make these connections because Senator Bishop is the most entertaining member of the Committee, that is fine. That is up to them; they can make those decisions. But I for one want to be on record tonight, as I was in the appropriate public hearings, as saying that when we—that is, most of the members of that Committee—make a judgment, it will be on the basis of the evidence and we will take time over it. I will not be rushing into this chamber to jump to conclusions and to cast aspersions on the reputation of an officer who has served the Public Service well.

I cannot go into the report. It is unfair for Senator Bishop to talk about some of the issues, to anticipate some possible recommendations of the Committee, some possible comments in the way that she has approached the subject tonight. I do not like to detain the Committee any longer at this time of night, but it must be put on the line that there are a number of approaches that can be taken in this inquiry by the Public Accounts Committee. There is an approach that should be taken in Estimates and the subsequent examinations that occur in this chamber. I do not think Senator Bishop has been taking the appropriate approach.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make two or three quick points. First, I was not at the private meeting this morning because I was at a meeting of the Select Committee on the Functions, Powers and Operation of the Australian Loan Council. They were competing meetings. Secondly, the material I have dealt with tonight is on the public record and in no way foreshadows recommendations the PAC may bring down. Indeed, I brought Senator Aulich to order in saying that he must not discuss what was dealt with in that meeting this morning.

PARA.TAB: Thirdly, Senator Aulich was not in the chamber when I brought to the attention of the Senate the speech made—it had been supplied in the material which only became available today in any form whatsoever—in March 1992 by Mr Boucher. In that speech he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The outcome is that we have a Budget which in 1992/93 will not cover all of our salary needs.
For Senator Aulich's information, it is the same speech that said:
Our Budget shortfall is around $20 million out of a total salary and administrative budget of some $825 million.
I then dealt with the evidence that had been given by officers from the Tax Office in public hearings under oath and where they had to change what they said because it was wrong.

PARA.TAB: Senator Aulich can interpret whatever way he will the making of a wrong statement under oath to a committee, as indeed will other people. The fact of the matter is that when one looks at the shortfall in revenue, $3.4 billion; when one looks at the shortfall in amounts of money for budgeting to pay salaries; when one looks at the shortfall in the budget for 1992-93; when one looks at the $1.7 billion suddenly being found at the same time as $114 million was found, allegedly to pay for new staff which Mr Highfield admitted were not necessarily more staff at all; and when one looks at the conjunction of someone who was appointed for a seven-year term being not willing to answer questions about meetings that took place in Perth on 5 September, a series of meetings where these things were discussed, claiming executive and crown privilege, then I think there are many conclusions that can be drawn.

Let us bear in mind the many ordinary Australians who experience the host of the bureaucracy coming down on them. For example, I refer to the 6,000 Australians who were last year prosecuted for failure to lodge their tax returns, when Mr Keating did not receive the same treatment. I refer to the same Australians who find that they have no redress and no money to fight matters through the courts—to people like Mr Clark who mortgaged his house to take the matter all the way through the Federal Court to finally win, but who will still be out of pocket. These are ordinary Australians—like the widow who could not find the money to pay income tax on her late husband's estate. Those are the sorts of people who find the might of the Tax Office oppressive and who want to see it accountable.

I would recommend to Senator Aulich that he read the Western Australian royal commissioner's report, which said that it was the Parliament that failed in its job and allowed that cosy relationship between the Executive and the bureaucracy to result in the scandalous fraud that happened in Western Australia. People blamed the Westminster system. I say to Senator Aulich: do not blame the Westminster system; blame the people in it. It will not happen here because there are people in the Public Accounts Committee on both sides who will be very sure that it will not. I am not foreshadowing a finding in a committee report, but I regard it as reasonable to want to look personally at the evidence that is on the record, and to draw conclusions from that about the mismanagement of the Tax Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —I apologise to colleagues for having to do this at this late hour, but several people have had their reputations sullied and I will be very brief in trying to clarify the position.

PARA.TAB: Firstly, I had the pleasure last night of meeting representatives of the OECD, who were delighted with the appointment by the Australian Government of its new Ambassador. In view of the importance of tax issues before the OECD, those senior officers of the OECD felt our new ambassador could make a significant contribution in enhancing the tax deliberations of the OECD, which is one of its most important functions for Australia.

Secondly, Senator Bishop refuses to accept—I thought for a long time she failed to understand it, but I do not want to underestimate her; I suspect that is not the case—that there was a shortfall, that arrangements have been made to cover it and that the enforcement strategy was not necessary for the Tax Office to deal with its salary funding over a number of years. I believe it has been adequately demonstrated that the Tax Office was in a position to manage the situation, to deal with the difficult situation that all large Australian Government entities who have had a dramatic reduction in staff turnover have had to manage.

I think it is just not helpful to throw around allegations of perjury and implications of other improper conduct without, in my view, having the evidence to lay the foundation for it. But the PAC will make its report. That will then be the appropriate time for the Senate to debate it, not 11 o'clock tonight in the Estimates.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to the unanswered questions in this area, and in particular to a question on notice that I placed before the Estimates Committee on 4 September to which I only received the reply in the last day or so. The question I asked with regard to the Australian Tax Office read:

SPEECH.PARA: In respect of the Northern Territory, Christmas Island, Cocos (Keeling) Island and Norfolk Island:

PARA.TAB: 1. What is the expenditure in 1991/92 and 1992/93 on:

SPEECH.PARA: (i)capital works; and
(ii)recurrent expenditure . . .
2. What are the details of all consultancies in 1991/92 and 1992/93. . .
In the answer to the first question, second part, `what is the expenditure on—(ii) recurrent expenditure?', I received the following answer:

The ATO incurred recurrent expenditure in the Darwin and Alice Springs offices. This was for maintenance and totalled $288 for Darwin and $366 for Alice Springs. We anticipate spending $310 in Darwin and $450 in Alice Springs in the 1992-93 financial year.

What about some salaries? What about the rest of the expenditure of the Australian Tax Office? Recurrent expenditure, I think, under any departmental definition, includes the entire administration of that particular arm. I am insulted that I get the petty cash items for repairs and maintenance and nothing relating to the recurrent expenditure of an office which maintains a very significant and proper role. I ask: where is the balance of the recurrent expenditure of the Australian Tax Office?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say to Senator Tambling that it does not seem to me to be a very satisfactory answer either. The contradiction between the question and the answer had not previously caught my attention. When I skimmed it as an answer, it seemed okay to me, but having read in detail the question and the answer, I accept that it is not a proper answer to the question which Senator Tambling has raised. I will make every effort to give him a very prompt and comprehensive response.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan. I refer to the second question regarding the administration of the Australian Tax Office. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: What are the details of consultancies?
The answer was:
The Northern Territory contributed $518 towards a $3,184 consultancy by C.J. Crow in November and December 1991. This consultancy was for the provision of functional analysis workshops.
What are functional analysis workshops?

TALK.START.PARA: —Functional analysis is part of the process of audit relating to transfer pricing—how you go about doing an analysis of functions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am almost as confused as I originally was, but I will accept the point. Given that this was a contributory consultancy, who else was involved in that consultancy? The Tax Office obviously only paid about one-sixth of the costs, what other departments or agencies were involved, and why?
—I am advised that the balance of the funds was provided by the Adelaide Tax Office I assume because, as Senator Tambling knows, the Northern Territory office is a branch of the Adelaide Tax Office.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 16 September I placed on notice a number of questions relating to the taxation treatment of investors under the Aust-Home group of companies. Whilst it is not disputed that the management of the Aust-Home group of companies was unsatisfactory, from a corporate or regulatory point of view, I have a number of concerns in relation to the treatment meted out to the investors by the Australian Taxation Office. In particular, I have some concerns about the manner in which the Taxation Office has answered the questions that I placed on notice to it.

PARA.TAB: Starting with question No. 3, I asked how the Commissioner was alleging that no income producing assets were ever acquired, because the receivers of the Aust-Home group of companies were proceeding to realise the assets held by those companies. Quite clearly, there were assets held by the companies because the receivers were appointed to the assets of the companies by the Federal Court upon the application of the Australian Securities Commission. There is no doubt that there were assets held by the companies. That has been upheld by a court case and the receivers are now proceeding to realise those assets.

The assets are also subject to charge. The mortgagees clearly recognise that the assets were acquired by the companies. Although they had a charge over those assets, the mortgagees clearly recognise that there is a beneficial interest in the assets—an equity of redemption—which is available to the receivers of the companies pursuant to the court order. I am disturbed that the answer given by the Australian Taxation Office is as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commissioner does not agree with the view that the investors acquired an interest in the underlying property.

What I would like explained is how the Australian Securities Commission can apply to the Federal Court for a receiver to be appointed to the assets of these companies, for the receiver and the mortgagees to proceed to realise the assets of those companies, and yet for the Australian Taxation Office, in the face of all that, to arrive at the conclusion that there was never any interest in the property in the first place. It is quite simply a nonsense. It is also, of course, contrary to the decision of the Federal Court.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not pretend expertise, but I am somewhat familiar with the issues because I have had a number of representations from my colleagues Mr Hulls, Mr Wright and others about it.
—And myself.
—I am not aware of any letters, but certainly Senator O'Chee has raised it in the Parliament, in the Estimates Committee and again here tonight. So the matter has come before me in the past.

PARA.TAB: In general, there are difficulties in providing much detail on the matter for reasons which Senator O'Chee will be perfectly aware of and which he would not, I know, expect me to cut across. Firstly, there are some fairly substantial secrecy provision constraints that limit the amount of information which I can even obtain, let alone pass on. Nothing Senator O'Chee raised would imply that I have to transgress that. I am not suggesting he did, but it does constrain our capacity to have a lengthy discussion on this.

Some of the matters are in dispute in the Federal Court. We do not want to get into a legal debate here about different interpretations of the law as it applies to given facts, let alone where the facts themselves are challenged. I will not enter into a debate about the legality of the matter and how this might subsequently be determined, but nobody doubts that assets existed. There is some argument about whether the investors acquired an interest in the property. There are two separate questions. There were some assets in the hands of Aust-Home. Whether the investors had an interest in those properties is another question which I do not think the Senate is the place to resolve.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that Senator McMullan is attempting to address the issue, but I think he should be very careful in answering in the fashion that he does. It is not that I am suggesting that he is trying to mislead the Senate, but merely that the answer he has given could be interpreted in a number of fashions. I think it is very appropriate that we go through the answer and, in particular, that we get to the nub of the answer that has previously been given by the Australian Taxation Office.

PARA.TAB: The Federal Court has already ruled that there are assets of the companies. The Federal Court has also ruled that those assets of the companies should be subject to the appointment of a receiver to protect the interests of the investors. That was the basis of the order made by Mr Justice Northrop when he put these companies into receivership.

It was quite explicitly stated that that was the basis of the order because at common law—it was an application at common law—it would be impossible for him to appoint a receiver on many other grounds. It was the basis of the submission to the Australian Securities Commission. It was the basis of the order given by Mr Justice Northrop. Clearly, both the Australian Securities Commission and the judge felt that there was an interest in that property which resided in the investors and that the interest was best protected by the appointment of the receiver. Therefore, how is it that the Commissioner can form the view that the investors had not acquired an interest in the underlying assets? The basis of the appointment was to protect the interests that resided in those investors at the time that the order was made.

TALK.START.PARA: —The primary point that I was trying to make is that the Commissioner has an obligation to form a view of the law on the facts before him and to apply that view of the law. If some other people have a different view, that is a fact to take into account, but the Commissioner cannot change the view which he holds and apply some other view. He has no right in law to do that, as Senator O'Chee knows. That is what he is doing.
