PARA.TAB: I do not wish to get into the argument that Senator O'Chee was putting forward other than to say that there is the capacity to distinguish between someone being a creditor of a person and someone having an interest in the assets of a person. They are not, for the purposes of the matter before us, necessarily identical things. Senator O'Chee is entitled to a different view, but this is not the place to try to argue that matter, and I do not intend entering into that sort of debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator McMullan knows, there are very clear provisions resident in the corporations law which deal with protecting the rights of creditors of the company. Those provisions allow for the creditors of the company to make an application that the company be wound up. In this case that did not occur. What happened in this case was very different. The Australian Securities Commission made an application to the court that the company be placed in receivership to protect the interests of the investors. The court has already ruled that receivers should be appointed—and it has appointed receivers—to the companies to protect the interests of the investors.
—Receivers or liquidators?

—Receivers, appointed upon the application of the Australian Securities Commission. It is not a case where liquidators were appointed to the company—that is, it was wound up to protect the interests of creditors. I may be wrong, but my recollection is that there is no provision in the corporations law to appoint a receiver to wind up the affairs of a company on behalf of unsecured creditors.
—That is why I asked the question.

—Senator Watson is spot on. If one appoints a receiver, one is appointing a receiver on behalf of persons who have a beneficial interest in the assets of the company or on behalf of the contributories of the company, if they have an interest which is different from—
—Those who allegedly own the asset.

—Yes, if that is an interest different from those who allegedly own the asset. I am not talking about a view that the Commissioner may arrive at. I am talking about a factual situation which has already been determined by a court of law. The question is not should the Commissioner change his mind and reassess facts—because we should discuss that at another time—but by what right does the Commissioner of Taxation decide that a ruling of the Federal Court is incorrect. Under what power of the Income Tax Assessment Act is the Commissioner of Taxation given the right to disagree with a factual situation which has already been determined in a court of law by a justice of the Federal Court of Australia?
—I indicated that I was not prepared to enter into this debate any further. That is Senator O'Chee's view of the case. It is not shared, but there is nothing further I can discuss in this forum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —That dismays me distinctly. However, there are other aspects of this matter and other questions that I have placed on notice that have been treated with a traverse by the Tax Office which I do intend to discuss. I am sure that Senator McMullan will recognise the need for us to discuss those matters this evening. The Taxation Office has suggested that the investors did not acquire an interest in the underlying assets.
—Did the court make its decision prior to or otherwise?

—I acknowledge the interjection of Senator Watson as to whether the court made its decision prior to the Commissioner or otherwise. It is my understanding, in answer to the interjection, that the Australian Taxation Office formed the view in relation to the taxpayers after the appointment of receivers.
—But after the Federal Court decision?

—After the Federal Court decision would be the answer to the further interjection by Senator Watson because, of course, it was the Federal Court decision which gave rise to the appointment of the receivers. I asked in question 9:

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commissioner of Taxation accepted that an investment had been made in the underlying assets of the Aust-Home Group of Companies, why does the Commissioner allege that the periodical payments made which lead to determination of the amount of deduction allowable to each individual investor would not be a revenue nature?

I am concerned that the Commissioner said that his view of the facts does not support this argument. The question asked why and the Australian Taxation Office has clearly not answered why, other than to say that it disagreed. In other words, the answer has been a traverse. I would therefore ask Senator McMullan whether he could elucidate the basis upon which the Commissioner has formed that view. That was the nature of the question asked. A question is put on notice so that the Commissioner can provide a full and proper explanation, and I am very dismayed that the answer should be a traverse to that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator O'Chee is putting forward his legal opinion. He is entitled to his legal opinion, but I do not intend the Estimates to be a court of appeal with regard to individual cases or to provide legal opinions on behalf of the Commissioner who is an independent officer obliged to form that independent opinion. There is no way in which I will start providing my version of the Commissioner's reasons for making decisions under the tax Act. I think it is highly inappropriate.

—I am not asking Senator McMullan to provide his version of the Commissioner's view of what happened under the tax Act. The purpose of these questions was to ask the Commissioner to provide the basis on which he has formed that view. It goes to the nature of the investigations that the Australian Taxation Office may or may not have done. I know that Senator McMullan is a man of honour so, obviously, he is being misled by the officers who are advising him because the question asks for the Commissioner to explain the basis of his decision.

PARA.TAB: We are not asking for Senator McMullan to provide his view or his version; we are asking for the officers to provide the basis of the decision as determined by the Commissioner of Taxation. That goes right to the heart of the operations of the Australian Taxation Office—whether in fact it did a decent investigation of this matter. If it did a decent investigation of this matter, then the officers would be able to provide the answer to that question. But if it did not, then of course we might expect that the Australian Taxation Office would attempt to not answer the question. We are not pre-judging the issue.

This is not a legal matter; this is not a question of law. We are just asking: on what basis did the Commissioner of Taxation form that view? It is a very simple question about how the Taxation Office has operated in relation to this matter. I do not believe that Senator McMullan, upon due reflection, could form the view that I am asking him for a legal opinion. I am asking: what was the basis upon which the Commissioner of Taxation formed that view?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to go into too much detail, but I can assure Senator O'Chee—and I have just confirmed it—that senior officers in the Tax Office conducted extensive investigations into the affairs of these companies; that is the process they undertook. They formed a series of views about the facts and the laws that applied to those facts. As I said at the start, we are all constrained as to what we can find out in these areas—as we should be because none of us should have access to the private taxation affairs of taxpayers—but within those constraints—
—None of us should.

—That is right, none of us should and none of us do and nobody is implying that that should change. There is a constraint on the extent to which I can investigate these matters. I have had representations—I think first from Mr Hulls; now from Senator O'Chee—from a number of members of Parliament who have raised this issue with me on behalf of their constituents. I have sought to assure myself that the people concerned have not been treated unfairly, that there has been assiduous attention to this matter, with assistance provided where possible and willingness to entertain reasonable responses to the requests of these taxpayers for consideration of their affairs. In that generality, to the extent that the relationship between a Minister or Parliamentary Secretary and the Commissioner of Taxation allows, I have assured myself of those facts. There is not very much more that I can add, however often I am asked.

—I am grateful to Senator McMullan for advising the Senate that he has assured himself that detailed investigations were made. Does that mean that the assessments, which were issued to investors generally, have not relied upon the Australian Taxation Office deeming the liability of certain of the investors? The basis of this scheme was that people were ostensibly paying money, by way of interest on loans, to acquire a beneficial interest in underlying assets. That led to those individuals claiming a variation of their PAYE deductions. That is a fairly simple to understand concept.

PARA.TAB: In one case, I am advised of a gentleman who, for the life of the scheme—which I think was around about two years—claimed and received a PAYE instalment variation of $20 per week. Notwithstanding this, the gentleman in question has received a tax assessment requiring him to pay, I believe, in excess of $100,000 of tax and penalties thereon. I think it may even be as high as $200,000. I do not wish to go into the individual's case but, unless my mathematics is gravely flawed—and I am sure that if it were you, Mr Chairman, would pick me up, being the kind-hearted soul that you are—I am at a loss to understand how a person could claim and receive an instalment variation of $20 a week. Over two years, that works out at roughly $2,040 or $2,080 in instalment variations. The individual then ends up with a tax liability in excess of $100,000 for those PAYE instalment variations.

Quite clearly, if that is the case, all the Taxation Office has done is deem that individual's liability. I do not want to go into the individual case in question—although I know the gentleman concerned would be happy for me to do so—because this is not the place to do it. But it is inconsistent with the argument that the Taxation Office has issued its assessments based on detailed investigations. For that gentleman to have a tax liability in excess of $100,000—if one disregarded penalties, which could not accrue at more than 20 per cent per annum anyway—he would had to have been claiming almost $1,000 in instalment variations a week. That just could not be the case. I ask Senator McMullan to advise what percentage of assessments has been derived by way of deeming the liability and what percentage of assessments has been arrived at by actually calculating the liability with reference to the instalment variations received by the taxpayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a ridiculous extent of detail to expect to be pursuing here. If there is any information that I can provide that would be useful to Senator O'Chee, I will provide it.

—I assume that is an undertaking by Senator McMullan to take the question on notice. To clarify exactly what I am asking, my question is: of the assessments which have been issued, how many have relied upon the Commissioner deeming a certain liability? I am sure Senator McMullan will be able to instruct the officers to provide that information at fairly short notice; it does not require an examination of an individual case. I now ask Senator McMullan for clarification of a further matter. In relation to this scheme, how could people fall under the anti-avoidance provisions of section 82KL and part IVA of the Income Tax Assessment Act? What would be the general basis upon which the Taxation Office would form the view that people have become subject to section 82KL or part IVA of the Act?

—That is not a matter about which I am in a position to give any advice. I do not quite understand how Senator O'Chee thinks the Estimates committee is the place to start dealing with that sort of issue. I have no capacity to provide any information with regard to it. I am not sure that, even on inquiry, I will be in a position to provide any information, but I will have a look and see what I can provide.

PARA.TAB: It is extremely difficult to balance the competing public and private interests—the legitimate interests of the taxpayer and the legitimate public interest—that are involved in this matter. I do not think that it is a proper Estimates committee matter when examined in this degree of detail, but I will see what I can provide. It may turn out that I will write back and say that I am sorry that I cannot provide anything, but I will undertake to do what I can.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan. I note that the advisers seem to have a copy of the Act. Perhaps Senator McMullan could advise the Committee what the provisions of section 82KL generally are and whether I am correct in understanding that the basic thrust of part IVA is to strike down an arrangement when the primary purpose for which it was entered into was to avoid liability for income taxation.

—I have part IVA of the anti-avoidance provisions, but I have no intention of reading into the record at 11.30 p.m. things that are already on the public record. We have had quite enough of other people doing that tonight.

—I am genuinely ignorant of the provisions of section 82KL. I would have thought that, in order to expedite the matter, it would be easy to advise me here and now. Otherwise, I have 15 minutes available to me. I hope that we can conclude this by Senator McMullan advising of the basis of section 82KL in the Act.

—The degree of detail that I started to get into in attempting to go beyond that which I have given Senator O'Chee just makes it absurd for me to go on providing that. If he wants some explanatory material about the operation of that section, I will provide it to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Chee Sen W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McMullan. As I said, I understand that part IVA of the Act is designed to strike down arrangements which were entered into for the primary purpose of avoiding liability for income taxation. In answer to question 1, the Tax Office has suggested that the investors generally may fall foul of the provisions of section 82KL and part IVA. Yet in answer to question No. 11, the Tax Office said:

SPEECH.PARA: The ATO is of the view that many of the Aust-Home investors did not understand the full tax implications of the arrangement. To this extent, it is accepted that they did not have the intention of deliberate tax evasion.

In one answer, the Tax Office says that these people entered into a scheme for the purposes of avoiding taxation. However, further on in the answers, the Tax Office then says that these people did not have the intention of deliberately evading taxation. The two answers are quite contradictory. Obviously the Tax Office has not given proper consideration to these issues, because if the answers had been properly prepared, they would not contradict themselves within the space of 11 paragraphs.

PARA.TAB: I am trying to assist Senator McMullan by pointing out that there are very real doubts about the degree of proper examination that the Australian Taxation Office has given to this matter and the way in which it has formed the views it has and arrived at the answers. There are very proper concerns about the manner used to raise assessments against individual taxpayers.

I know that it is very late, and I am sorry that we had to go through it in this detail, but all those things alarmed me greatly upon receiving the answers to the questions on notice. In conclusion, I hope that Senator McMullan and the Australian Taxation Office will go back and review the matter from the first issue that I raised this evening through to the last. The Australian Taxation Office clearly has flaws in its methodology and the basis on which it has arrived at the assessment.

I do not believe that the Australian Taxation Office has properly investigated these matters. I believe that the consequence of that failure to properly investigate has brought a great degree of hardship upon many people which the Taxation Office admits did not enter into this scheme with the deliberate intention of avoiding taxation.

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 6.1, we will move to subprogram 6.4, which is headed, `Child Support'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief in making plain what I think of the administration of the Child Support Agency. If it has no discretion but to deal with this matter other than as it has, it is high time that we amended the Act. In fact, it is high time that we amended the Act for a whole range of other reasons, which I shall not go into tonight.

PARA.TAB: What prompts me to speak particularly is the letter that I received from the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) dated 30 October 1992 in response to two letters that I had written, dated 26 June 1992 and 4 September 1992. It would be tempting to go through the 50 pages of advice and correspondence, et cetera, that this constituent has had with the Child Support Agency. The first letter, which is dated 3 July 1990, relates to her difficulty in getting any support at all, any support for money that was owing to her and any real enforcement of maintenance against her former husband, who gave up his job. That is the situation to which I specifically refer. The Parliamentary Secretary said in his letter to me:

SPEECH.PARA: In a free society such as ours, a person cannot be compelled to remain in employment against his or her will.

I do not disagree with that. But what benefits is the husband now being paid as a result of him having decided that he will not work when he had a perfectly good job in a bank and because he does not want to pay his maintenance? I take issue with Senator McMullan over that statement when this man is allowed to give up work and not pay his children but get other benefits.

PARA.TAB: This man deliberately walked away from supporting his children. I recognise that if he is not earning, maintenance cannot be further enforced against him. But the fact is that, prior to that, he had paid maintenance. As I said, I shall not go through the 50 pages which show what he had not paid earlier on. But Senator McMullan is now asking this constituent to repay a sum of money because, by some absurd formula, the Agency says that this man had paid more than he was supposed to.

The amount he had paid over more than two years would not have fed or clothed a child or done anything for it. Now she gets this letter supported by the Parliamentary Secretary saying that she should repay some money to him. The Registrar explained it to her and she has been requested to repay an amount of child support she received because an overpayment resulted when Mr Fawcett's child support liability for 1991-92 was reduced on the basis of his estimated low income.

He paid almost nothing during 1990 and now she is expected to take away from feeding her child $105 to repay him. If I have anything to do with it, she will not repay it. The authorities can put her in gaol and do what they like, but any system which has been put down by this Parliament in that form ought to be amended as a high priority, and well ahead of a lot of this other legislation that we have before us at present.

The documents from the Agency itself prove beyond doubt that this man did not intend to pay for his child's maintenance; he did not pay. Now and again he was forced to pay a bit and, because this absurd formula now works it out that over a whole year he paid $105 more than he had to, she has to find that money from goodness knows where and repay it. The Parliamentary Secretary said in his letter:

SPEECH.PARA: The Registrar assured me that the Agency will reassess Mr Fawcett's child support liability if it is found that his actual income exceeds his estimated income. He suggested that Mrs Berger could inform the Agency if she has any further information regarding Mr Fawcett's employment or financial position.

He is still sponging off the system and refusing to pay for his child. Yet he wants $105 back from the amount that was paid at a time when he was not fully paying what he should have been paying to support his child.

PARA.TAB: I shall not go into this matter further and if Senator McMullan does not understand what I am saying, I will be very surprised. I want an assurance that no action will be taken against this constituent to get $105 from her to pay back to Mr Fawcett, who very clearly has indicated not the slightest intention of trying to support his child whom he is legally obliged to support.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most difficult cases that all of us find as constituency representatives, and which I find also as Parliamentary Secretary, are matters to do with the Child Support Agency. Passions run very high with regard to that issue. Usually the real conflict is not between the individuals and the Agency; it is between two individuals with competing claims upon the Agency.
—They are not too impressed with the Agency either.

—I get a lot of complaints from people who say that they do not want to pay and who complain very hard when they are required to pay, and from others who complain that we do not enforce the payment rapidly enough. Sometimes it is about the same case. People write to me on one side saying, `You have taken too much', and the other side saying, `You have not taken enough'. It is particularly hard in those circumstances to satisfy all one's complainants.
—What do you say in these circumstances?

—I thank Senator Vanstone for her assistance, but I was merely trying to agree with most people here who know that this is an extremely difficult area. One of the most difficult relates to the circumstances which arise when overpayment occurs. Under the law as it stands the Commonwealth has to seek repayment of that money. There is no option in that sense and it can be an invidious position.

PARA.TAB: It is hard for me to understand this matter just on the basis of the evidence as I have heard it. I realise that Senator Reid was being concise in consideration of the hour and I appreciate that. If the non-custodial parent had underpaid his obligations, it is hard for me to understand how there could be an overpayment and a refund applying. That does not seem to me logically to fit the facts. I do not know all the facts of the particular case, even though the person is a constituent of mine. If the person is a constituent of Senator Reid's—
Senator Reid interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, she cannot be a constituent of Senator Reid's without being a constituent of mine as well, but I do not remember the details of the particular case. I always pay particular attention to ones that come up in my own electorate.

PARA.TAB: It is very hard to see how such a circumstance could arise. If a person had underpaid his obligations, it is hard to see how in that case there could be an overpayment. If there is more detail that Senator Reid wants to draw to my attention so that I can review the examination of the case, I would be happy to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have the letter and undoubtedly the matter can be pursued. There are problems with the Child Support Agency and the Act. In my view, the formula needs to be reviewed. Its present operation is grossly unfair to a number of men when a woman is earning and has other assets which are not taken into account. There are also cases where maintenance is not being enforced properly and a woman is being disadvantaged. I agree totally that there is difficulty in both instances. However, I think of a situation in Perth that I have written about—and there are others—where the actions of the Agency have caused real problems between the parties. It is not just between former husbands and wives.

PARA.TAB: My final point on this matter is that the Agency busily wrote a letter saying it wanted $105, but unless the arrears are in the vicinity of $5,000 the Agency will not lift a finger or a pen to enforce them because it says it is not worth it: the sum is not large enough. How is it that the Agency cannot, or will not, enforce a payment unless the sum is large, yet it will take off after this women for $105? It does not add up to a sensible situation.

I have details in my office right now of another case where the arrears are presently $1,500 and the woman has been told that until the amount is $5,000 the Agency will not pursue it. She will have to wait another few years for that to happen. In the case that I have referred to the amount is $105. I want an assurance that this woman will not be chased for this sum.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I will tell Senator Reid is that no-one should be told—and it is entirely contrary to the policy—that we will not pursue $1,500, that it is not enough, and that we will wait until it is $5,000. There are these types of debt management strategies in the Australian Taxation Office proper but they are not supposed to operate in the Child Support Agency. That is what I would be concerned about. It is difficult for me to understand the underpinning of the $105 concern, but I would be very concerned with a case in which the Agency was saying that it would not pursue an outstanding matter because the amount owing was not sufficiently large. That is not acceptable to the Government and it is not the policy of the Agency. I am aware of a number of instances where amounts smaller than that have been pursued, and properly so. I assure the honourable senator that the problem lies not in the $105 but in the $1,500. When the honourable senator draws it to my attention I will be making darned certain that the $1,500 is pursued.
—That concludes the examination of the estimates for the Department of the Treasury.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Zakharov, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee D.
—On behalf of Senator West, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have protested once about the abysmal handling of the program by the Government. I do not know whether the Senate wants to hear it all again at this time of night. We have said that we will sit when the Government requires us to sit. Because the Government has got the program into such a mess, the Government is now requiring us to sit an extra week, which will obviously make an enormous mess of everyone's program.

PARA.TAB: We very much regret that it seems impossible for this Government to engage in proper programming. It seems impossible for Ministers to work out which Bills they seek passage for within a parliamentary session. At the end of every session, we get an enormous stack of legislation which requires urgent passage. It means that the chamber cannot properly fulfil its scrutiny function. Through no fault on our part, we are embarrassed by not doing the job as well as we otherwise would seek to do it.

We protest as vigorously as possible, but, nevertheless, in accordance with the practice that we have adopted over many years, we accept the timetable that the Government sets down for the sitting of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on the record some of the things that I think ought to be discussed in any wider discussion of the Government's handling of its legislative program. I agree with the Opposition that we have an incredible number of Bills before us, but I will not agree that it has no part in why we are, at this point in the legislative program, behind schedule. We have not found a balance in this place between the right of people to speak and what is reasonable. I would ask what is reasonable about having 23 senators speaking for 30 minutes each on Bill after Bill after Bill. That is not reasonable. We have not found a sensible way to cooperate on achieving a legislative program in this place, and it is not for the want of trying.

PARA.TAB: The Democrats, in an attempt to avoid putting on a guillotine—do not take this as any signal of the fact that a guillotine is pending—have tried to achieve a cooperative resolution with both the Government and the Opposition by sitting down and talking about time limits that we ought to have in place; not a guillotine, but some sort of restraint on how many people ought to speak and for how long each speaker ought to be able to speak. There should be some sort of prioritising of Bills and some sort of due regard paid to what is a reasonable use of the time of this chamber.

We have to ask the question: is it reasonable to spend as much time as some individuals do at Estimates committees; is it reasonable to spend as much time as some individuals do in the committee stage of Appropriations? I do not think we have found that balance of reason. We ought to exert some discipline, and balance the rights of individuals with the collective right of this chamber to get on with its business.

I regret that together the Government, the Democrats and the Opposition have not been able to find a cooperative way through. I regret that we have to have an extra week. I regret that, if we still cannot find a way through, we will have to have more late nights. That is not a sensible way for us to run this place. It is not a sensible thing for us to do to our health, but it is something that we will continue to face until we are prepared to sit down together, to stop playing games and to start saying, `On the first occasion, the Government has a right to at least put forward its program for consideration'. It does not have a right to passage, but it has a right to consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —And proper accountability.
—Yes, and we have to have proper accountability. Sure, but how many hours does that involve?
—As many as required.

—This opens up a much wider debate about how we use this chamber. I do not think we have found that balance. I want that to go on the record, and I want to appeal to the Opposition to have another go at sitting down, putting aside the fact that we have had to negative the adjournment tonight, and working out a way in which we can get through the program sensibly.
—I do not think we can leave that contribution go unremarked because, unfortunately—
—Waste more time.

—There is a lot of time wasted in various ways in this place. There seemed to be no recognition on the part of Senator Kernot that we are in the position we are in because the Government has been dilatory in bringing its program into this place. We could have had the Appropriations debate start earlier than it did. We could have had a lot of Bills brought into this place days, if not weeks, before they ultimately came in.
—Who kept the Estimates going?

—The point is that it is the Government's program. No-one obliged the Government to introduce 73 Bills into the House of Representatives last week, and yet Senator Kernot is basically condoning all of that and encouraging it. Senator Kernot's job is supposed to be to keep certain people honest, yet she is encouraging people. Senator Kernot is doing that by not applying any sanctions. She has said, for reasons that escape me—
—And there are no sanctions applied to you either.

—There is a certain discipline that can be injected by setting time limits, and we are happy to consider that separate and apart from this exercise. But I do not understand the rationale for Senator Kernot saying on the one hand, `We are very concerned about our collective state of health', and on the other hand, `We will go on until breakfast time if necessary'. For what purpose? Is it so essential that the Government get its program through? It is not out of money. It is not as though it needs the dough. All we heard was their current leader—
—Why should we come back and do this for another week?

—Why should we come back at all? Senator Kernot might as well be back here debating the Appropriations as debating the other legislation about which they have not felt a sense of urgency until last week. If the Government gets itself into that situation, why should Senator Kernot accommodate it and encourage it to do this again and again, as it has done year after year? All her silly leader can say is, `We have got some sort of obligation to help them to get the program through in a managed way'. But that is all nonsense.

PARA.TAB: What is it about? Does Senator Kernot somehow think that she has a keen interest in seeing the Government get the legislation through so that it can decide on an early election or something? I would have thought that today's 11.3 per cent unemployment figure put paid to that. Even if it has not, what obligation does Senator Kernot have to encourage the Government to go on in this way? Yet here she is giving it carte blanche. She should not stand up here and say that somehow we are the ones who ought to have been reasonable and had sensible discussions beforehand. You can have that debate at another time.

TALK.START.PARA: —We asked you to.

—Okay, but that has nothing to do with deciding to let the Senate run on till 8 o'clock in the morning, has it? It has nothing to do with whether we sit till breakfast time. Senator Kernot can have discussions about what is reasonable and who ought to spend what time in Estimates, and we can all agree that there is scope for cutting back.
—But you're not interested.

—We are interested. But I cannot see how Senator Kernot can make this link and then suddenly, in effect, throw in the towel and allow the Government to get away with everything on some specious basis that it ought to be able to manage the program. It is the Government that ought to be required to manage it, and Senator Kernot should not be in the business of assisting it not to.
—I would like Senator Kernot to tell us when there have been 20 speakers from this side on a Bill, except maybe the Appropriations.
—Superannuation.
—I doubt whether there were 20 speakers on that. If there were 20 speakers on that, then surely it is the right of anyone in this Parliament to speak on the Appropriations.

PARA.TAB: The mistake started when we went away for the winter break and then came back and sat for less than a week—a lousy three days—and then the Government went out to try to sell its Budget. Instead of staying here and getting on with legislation that was maybe carried over from the last session, or starting what was necessary, the Government had to go out after three days and sell its lousy Budget. We all know how well it sold the Budget. Its wheels have fallen off.

TALK.START.PARA: —They could not give it away.

—The Government could not give it away. Then, after two weeks off, we came back for two weeks, and how many Bills were dealt with? We had to fill in time with everything else because there were no Bills through from the House of Representatives.
—That is not true.
—It is not true? Senator McMullan should check his facts.
—Not one minute.

—Senator McMullan says `not one minute'. We could have done a lot more in that time, but the Bills were just not coming through. We had to come back for those two weeks and fill in time. Then we went away for another two weeks and then the Bills came on.

PARA.TAB: The Estimates did not run over very much because they were finished off in non-sitting weeks, if people care to remember back that far. Now we come to the end of the year, as usual, and all of a sudden the House of Representatives comes up with, as Senator Alston said, 23 Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —Seventy-six.
—Sorry, 76 Bills. It is the same every year. Can the Government tell me how this Senate could have done any better than it has with those Bills arriving just now?
—Some of those Bills we still haven't seen.
—That is right. We still have not seen some of those Bills. The attendants are piling up our desks with these Bills every minute of every day.
—They were asking us today how long we want on a particular Bill and we haven't even seen it.

—We have not seen them. Senator Kernot made some excuses tonight. A dirty deal has been done with the Government by the look of it. Senator Kernot is making excuses for the guillotine that is about to come on the next time we come here. We have had a guillotine at the end of every year. This is my fifth year here now and in that time we have never missed having a guillotine, and it is coming again. The deal has been done across the chamber. And Senator Kernot has the hide to get up here and start making excuses for the guillotine which is to come.

PARA.TAB: We will accept that the deal is that we sit here, because we have to; it is our duty, but we will have the guillotine. I am prepared to sit all night. I am prepared to sit until tomorrow afternoon. If we are that far behind, we should just roll on and get on with it. But let us not make any excuses. The Prime Minister still has time—and Senator Kernot should know it—to dump all of this by next Monday afternoon and call an election. So the whole lot of us might be getting het-up for nothing because, if the Prime Minister thought he had a chance of winning the election, he would go next Monday for an election on 19 December.

Of course, he knows what the situation is in Queensland, New South Wales, Victoria—and Senator Reynolds need not think he can hang on to that bit of publicity he got last week—South Australia and Western Australia. He knows that he has no chance of winning an election so he will not go on 19 December, but he still has time to call one.

I suggest that we now get on with business. I have worked all night and day before in business and in other places, and I am prepared to get on with it. So let us stop listening to excuses from the Democrats who have done a dirty deal with the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —My colleague Senator Panizza is quite correct. Let us get on with it. But just wait until I make a few brief remarks.
—That is what has happened to every Bill in this place.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Vanstone)—Order! Senator Kernot, you have had your shot. Senator Kemp has the floor.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remarks my colleagues have made cover most of the issues pretty well. As usual, when the debate gets a bit hot, Senator Kernot walks out. But Senator Kernot and her colleagues have brought this on themselves. Year after year the Government has brought in Bills and they have been guillotined through. The Government has held up these Bills until the very last moment and then suddenly, knowing it can rely on the Australian Democrats, it has brought in these Bills in a rush and in the end the Democrats will guillotine them through.

PARA.TAB: The problem with the Democrats is quite simple: this new lot of Democrats has no concept of what this Parliament is about. Why should senators not come into this chamber and carefully debate the Bills, in some cases for very long periods of time? These are very important Bills. They affect the lives of millions of people. Why should we not expect to come into this chamber and carefully consider these Bills so that the Government is put to the test? I would have thought that `accountability' was the key word for the Australian Democrats. They have often told us over the years that their job is to keep us all honest. An essential part of honesty is making sure that the legislation the Government brings down is examined carefully.

There may be a few Democrats in their rooms who are not sleeping at the moment and who are listening to this debate. Why is it so essential to get these Appropriation Bills through today? Why is it absolutely vital that this be done? The answer is: the Government wants it done; the Government wants to keep its options open to call an election on Monday. This program, which was so essential and which we had to rush through this chamber, will then be junked in one minute. That is what this is about. The Australian Democrats should get back to their roots, have a good think about what their philosophy is, and demand more accountability from the Government rather than demanding that the coalition rush these Bills through.

TALK.START.PARA: —I only rise to conclude this debate because a couple of inaccurate things were said which I felt I needed to correct. Senators have indicated that they will support the legislation, so I will not delay the House at this late stage. But there has not been one minute during this session when the Senate has not had legislation to deal with. There have been hours when it has declined to do so and has engaged in 5 1/2 hours of flagellation about things which have been said about it. There have been certain very repetitive contributions and people have gone over and over things. We have had the refusal by the Opposition party room to go along with the unanimous view of the Procedure Committee about ways to expedite proceedings. But there has not been a minute when there was not legislation for the Senate to deal with. For that reason this backlog—
—You can always wheel in the rubbish as padding.

—If it was so minor, those opposite should not have taken so long talking about it. There was no time when we did not have legislation to deal with; not one occasion. Irrespective of when the legislation had been introduced we would still have had this backlog.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Beahan, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is that the report of Estimates Committee B be adopted.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Short) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Cook) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The first Department to be considered is the Department of Transport and Communications. Again, we will follow the running sheet as we have done with the previous two Estimates committees. The running sheet starts off with non-portfolio specific issues in relation to GBEs and scheduling of witnesses. If there are no questions on that or in relation to the reservation by Senator Bishop on page 17, or on the section headed `All Programs', we will move to program 1, aviation; subprogram 1.2, investigation for safety.

—A question was answered regarding the investigation of the near miss of a BAE 146 at Meekatharra. I believe the question was, `Was the pilot Australian trained?' and the answer was, `Yes, he was'. I would like to follow on and ask a question about the same area. There was a hoax report that a 146 had crashed some time back. This false report was reported by the ABC and also GWN at the time in Western Australia. I would like to know what action, if any, the relevant section of the Department has taken with the ABC for reporting such a would-be disaster as a crash of a 146 supposedly carrying 100 passengers without having been in contact with the organisation one is supposed to contact in such matters—the Civil Aviation Authority?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant statutory authority in this case is the ABC which, I understand, carried the false report of an aircraft accident. If I recall, Senator Panizza may have asked this question of Senator Collins in Question Time at about the time of the Senate Estimates Committee's hearing. I think he obtained a reply from Senator Collins which was incorporated in Hansard at the end of a Question Time. I think Senator Collins took it on notice and replied later.

PARA.TAB: As far as the Civil Aviation Authority is concerned, it was not in any way involved in any hoax. The Bureau of Air Safety Investigation, which is the agency covered in these Estimates and which would investigate an accident if one occurred, is not involved in any hoax. So no authority is implicated in the hoax call under these Estimates. It seems to me a problem for the ABC, which received and broadcast something. I do not know what the answer to Senator Panizza's question was that Senator Collins tabled, but I am sure that has answered it. In short, we cannot, on behalf of the CAA or BASI, comment on that, because it is not something that falls within the purview of those operations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not saying that the Department had anything to do with the hoax. I take on board the Minister's statement that I got a reply from Senator Collins, which was relevant at the time. I can remember what he said. I thought that since then the Minister's Department might have taken it up with the ABC—even had a friendly chat on the telephone, for that matter—to make sure that it did not happen again. I was astounded that such a false report could have been broadcast. One might expect this from some downtown commercial broadcasting outfit or televising outfit, but when it comes to the almighty ABC, I just cannot understand it. I thought that the Minister's Department and the departmental section might have taken it up with the ABC just as a matter of interest, which would have followed on from what Senator Collins told me at the time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The relevant authority here would be the Civil Aviation Authority. As the Senate would be aware, the Civil Aviation Authority is a commercialised government business enterprise. It therefore registers its corporate plan with the Government. The Government exacts from it a dividend and appoints its board, but allows its operations to be managed by the board consistent with the corporate plan and the realisation of the dividend. I have no ability in these proceedings to talk about operational matters within the purview of the board. I am not responsible for those; the board is.

PARA.TAB: I can advise Senator Panizza, since he has raised this matter, that I understand that when the Civil Aviation Authority became aware of the hoax broadcast it contacted all media outlets to advise them that, to the best of its knowledge, it was a hoax. I understand that the Civil Aviation Authority has also suggested to the ABC how situations of this sort could be avoided in the future.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have several matters that relate to this particular issue. The first one relates to the airline tenancies and concession arrangements for the air terminals in Darwin and Alice Springs. I asked a series of questions in the Estimates on 8 September, and several of the questions were taken on notice at that particular time.

PARA.TAB: There has been a saga of events around the relocations of the new terminals and the small business operators in the general aviation areas at Darwin Airport. I am very pleased to note the assurance of the Government that there have been absolutely no changes in any of the proposed leases from those originally offered at the Darwin terminal. I received a one word answer to that—the word was `no'. Given the history of the initial development of the Darwin and Alice Springs terminals, I would be very concerned to learn at any stage that any of the leases or concession arrangements at either the Darwin or Alice Springs airports had in fact been changed from those indicated at the Estimates Committee some time earlier.

Answers came back with regard to the Darwin aviation club and its relocation and also the relocations of various general aviation operators from the south side to the north side of the Darwin Airport. The original date for relocation to the north side was March 1992. That was extended to September 1992 and the arrangements are now in place for operators to complete relocation prior to December 1992, with the possible exception of one or two operators whose construction completion dates may extend to January 1993.

Can I, therefore, seek an assurance from the Minister that there will be no operators or concessionaires operating on the south side of the Darwin airport after January 1993, that all locations of operators will be facilitated by that date, and that all locations on the south side of the Darwin airport will revert to the Department of Defence as at that date?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just make one aspect of this clear from the beginning. The FAC, like the Civil Aviation Authority, is a commercialised government business enterprise, and it is managed by a board appointed by the Government, expert in the management of business. It is a GBE which registers with the Government its corporate plan and we approve that. The Minister for Finance is the responsible Minister in that action, in consultation with me. We exact a dividend from it. But we are not in a position to direct the FAC as to the manner in which it carries out its commercial responsibility.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tambling said he was pleased to have had an assurance from the Government with reference to a question he asked. I think what he probably meant to say was that he had an assurance from the FAC, because I am not in a position to give an assurance of that nature. It is for the FAC to say.

I now have a question before me from Senator Tambling asking for the Government to say something. I can refer Senator Tambling's question to the FAC to see whether it is in a position to answer. I think I may have some advice from it. If I am right in understanding this—this is the FAC's advice and I am a mere conduit—the advice is that the aeroclub at Darwin is to move to the north side on 21 November this year. Some construction works may extend beyond January 1993 due to construction delays which are not FAC delays. That may go to the point of the assurance that Senator Tambling wants. I indicate again that this is FAC advice. I make an offer that if there are detailed questions on how the FAC intends to manage its operational responsibilities, perhaps we can arrange for Senator Tambling to meet with the FAC and have those questions pursued.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the offer from the Minister and I will no doubt take that up. The Minister answered in respect of the Darwin aviation club. My question was more specific in that it affected all general aviation operators currently operating on the south side of the airport. I would ask him to qualify that particular point. I do see an involvement of the Government because of the nature of the arrangements on the south side of the airport which will revert to use by the Department of Defence. Given that there has had to be considerable liaison, I would ask whether the Department of Defence is planning, in conjunction with the FAC, to take over and facilitate any of the building works or the remnant buildings on the south side of the airport.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a quite specific set of questions. As I indicated before, I am not briefed and do not have responsibility for the day-to-day management and the arrangement of the commercial affairs of the FAC, so I am not in a position in which I can answer. As I do not have a brief, and I do not know the answers, I will refer those questions, if it would suit Senator Tambling, to the FAC and obtain an answer for him.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer now to the answer that was given to my question relating to art and art collections for use in FAC airports. The answer that I received was specific in relation to two airports: $226,150 for Alice Springs and $270,220 for Darwin. It was acknowledged that an art program is being implemented for Sydney airport within a cost budget and approved by the Corporation.

PARA.TAB: Given that my question did not relate specifically to Alice Springs or Darwin, what is the extent of the art program that is being implemented at Sydney airport? What is its cost budget? Also, what art has been provided to other FAC terminals throughout Australia? That was the intent of the original question. In respect of Alice Springs, Darwin or any other terminal, what are the fee arrangements or the amounts of money that have been paid to any art advisers or consultants used by the FAC?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be delighted to pass those questions on to the FAC, if it is in a position to answer them. As I said earlier, I am not in a position to answer them. As they are detailed, I do not know whether I am in a position to extract an answer, even if there is one available, now. But if it would suit Senator Tambling, I would be delighted to pass the questions over.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have suited me better if the answer had already been provided, given that the question was asked on 8 September and has not been adequately or properly answered. I am therefore disappointed that the Minister is not able to provide that information.

—I want to refer under subprogram 1.5 to the item I noted for reservation in the report of Estimates Committee C which relates to joint venture business operations at airports operated by the FAC. In relation to the matter that was raised in the Estimates Committee hearings to which subsequent answers have been provided, can I ask the Minister whether under the FAC Act he is required to give his assent or to approve the involvement of the FAC in a joint business venture located at an airport controlled by the FAC.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I am not required to give my assent to any joint venturing by the FAC. The FAC is obliged under, I think, section 10 of the Act to advise me. Because it is a commercialised venture and it is to trade commercially and succeed in delivering the dividend, it is not in a position to obtain from me under its Act assent to do certain commercial things. It is expected to use normal commercial judgment and business acumen in order to make the right decisions within the ambit of its Act. But it is obliged to keep me informed. It is not a question of me, as a Minister, imposing on it a Public Service obligation of some sort in this manner.

—The issue that was of concern to me on this matter was what I regarded at that time and still regard—and what others regarded—as a potential, if not actual, conflict of interest in the FAC being both a concessionaire and the body which awards concessions at its airports. The matter under consideration was the Airport Fine Foods operation. At the hearings and also in the supplementary answers that have been provided, the FAC continues to assert that there is no conflict of interest because it claims that it is not in fact a concessionaire, even though it was approached by Australian Fine Foods to take part in that operation.

PARA.TAB: I note from the subsequent answer that has been provided that, in fact, the FAC holds some 52.5 per cent of the shares in Airport Fine Foods. As Senator Bishop says, that, in fact, indicates that it is the majority shareholder in this business operation. It seems to me that the further argument which the FAC uses in denying that there is a conflict of interest is that it bought into the business as a going concern, so there seems to be some convoluted argument that the concession had already been given to the business before the FAC became involved and, therefore, there is no conflict of interest if the FAC subsequently becomes involved in such a business. I find that argument unacceptable and I believe it is simply not acceptable for the FAC to be involved in businesses at a location which it itself controls, particularly when those concessions are not put out to tender.

The other matter of concern which I want to raise is that when I asked these questions on 8 September, the FAC indicated that it was not aware of any concern from other concessionaires about a conflict of interest; yet its subsequent answer to those questions taken on notice indicates that only two weeks later, on 23 September, it admits that it had become aware of some concerns about the tender process for concessions. So, I think that also raises questions about the FAC's handling of this particular matter, that within that relatively short period, it suddenly became aware that there were concerns about the tender process for concessions and it was aware that, in fact, there was a view among other concessionaires that there was a conflict of interest involved in this matter.

So I would really simply seek a more substantive explanation and argument to convince me that there is, in fact, not a conflict of interest involved in this particular matter when the FAC indeed owns some 52.5 per cent of a business that is located at its own airport, an airport where it has control of who the concessionaires become.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take that as a question. If the FAC had been a privatised government business enterprise, it would be, of course, a private company and all of the questions that have been raised by Senator Chapman would not be questions that could be directed at the FAC, unless it was in some investigative role in terms of its own commercial conduct.

PARA.TAB: The FAC is, of course, a commercialised business of the Government and, as I have explained before, it is not a business over which the Government has any power of direction in the conduct of its commercial business activities. If it contravenes any law or legislation, well, it ought to be dealt with just the same as any other business that has contravened any law or legislation. The FAC Act—and this was made specific in the second reading speech to the Bill at the time—states that it was envisaged that the FAC would compete in the private sector; that the FAC could form partnerships and establish subsidiaries under the Act; and that this is, in fact, similar to what occurs at airports in other countries, where they are under commercial management. I will draw Senator Chapman's observations about the FAC's conduct to the board of the FAC. It may well be that the board would be delighted to chat with him further about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has drawn attention to a further concern of mine with regard to the FAC and that is, as he has described it, its commercialisation. It is still, in effect, a government owned instrumentality. By this process of so-called commercialisation, it has this quasi-business status, but it does not have the status of a real commercial operation. If, over a period of time, the FAC racked up a series of losses, and even went to the extent of becoming bankrupt, then it would be the taxpayer who would pick up the tab for that.
—It would be called a contingent liability.

—As Senator Panizza said, it would be a contingent liability. It is still a government instrumentality. It is not to be equated to a fully commercial operation of a private business. Again, this gives rise to my concern that my question about how much the FAC had invested in this particular business was not fully answered. That question was not answered by the FAC on the grounds that it is commercial-in-confidence. That simply highlights the discrepancy that we find in these sorts of operations. Whenever they do not want to answer a question, they claim commercial-in-confidence. Yet the bottom line is that this organisation is still, in effect, a government instrumentality and it is still the responsibility of taxpayers.
—The same bureaucrats.

—As Senator Bishop says, it is largely run by the same bureaucrats. I simply believe that that is a completely unsatisfactory situation. If we want to have the commercial operation of our airports, let us properly privatise them, have them operated by the commercial sector with private ownership and private shareholding. That is the way to go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —On page 28 of the Senate Hansard of Estimates Committee C, I asked how much Compass owed the FAC when it went into liquidation on 18 December 1991. Mr Thompson answered that it owed approximately $4m. I also placed a number of questions on notice, including: `How much did Compass Mk 1 owe the FAC when it failed?'. The answer I was given was that that was commercial-in-confidence; however, the Corporation submitted to the liquidator Compass's statement of claim for the total debt. In one case I was told it was $4m, and in another case I was told it was commercial-in-confidence.
—Ha, ha!

—Senator Bishop can read it for herself. It is in Hansard; I have it here. As Senator Chapman pointed out, the FAC is a GBE and also a privatised corporation. As I interjected, I maintain that it is a corporatised GBE, but there is still a contingent liability. If the FAC were to go into liquidation, run up a lot of debts, there is no doubt that the taxpayer would pick up the final tab after the liquidation of whatever assets it had. I cannot understand being told that the information was commercial-in-confidence when I had already been told that the figure was $4m. The reason I asked that question was to compare Compass with Ansett. When I asked how much Ansett owed the FAC in December 1991, Mr Thompson replied:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is fair to say that all the people who operate on our airports owe us money. Nobody is exactly up to date.
We do not expect it to be at least 30 days behind. I said:
No, I am not talking about the 30-day sort of money. I am talking about those who were well behind in their payments.
Mr Thompson answered:
Again, I will get that detail for you.

Once again, the Department's reply to my question on how much Ansett owed in December 1991 was that this was commercial-in-confidence. One could be excused for using that reason for Ansett because Ansett is completely private, but the FAC is a contingent liability of the Government and I believe I am entitled to know how much it was owed. I am trying to find out whether Ansett owed the same amount of money as Compass and why no action was taken to retract the money that was owed. I want to make the comparison.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Thompson, who appeared before the Estimates Committee, is the General Manager, General Aviation, at the FAC. I suppose that is industry jargon or code for saying that he is in charge of the light aircraft area of the FAC's operations. I am not surprised that when he answered he was careful to qualify what he said about Compass. He said that it owed approximately $4m. He was not in a position to give instant figures, should they have been open to him to give. I have a copy in front of me of the three questions that Senator Panizza asked, as recorded in Hansard at page C28 and the three answers supplied to him. I do not think I am in a position to elaborate.

PARA.TAB: I am advised that the arrangements between the commercial operators—Ansett and Compass—and the FAC are matters that are, as can be seen from the answer, commercial-in-confidence. In the case of Compass, the FAC has put a claim to the liquidator of the Compass airline operation. The details of that claim are also commercial-in-confidence. I am not in a position to reply on those matters. I am not quite sure of the status either or whether there will be a time in the future in which it would be appropriate to reply, but if that is the case I will obtain an indication from the FAC and advise Senator Panizza accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not agree—I think we could argue this all night, so I will not belabour the point; neither of us will give in—that the Department can claim commercial-in-confidence. In the final analysis the Minister must admit, and the lawyers in this place will back me up, that where the Government has a contingent liability—no-one has denied for a moment that there is a contingent liability—anything can be commercial-in-confidence. I would like the Minister to assure me that, when Compass went into liquidation on 18 December 1991, Ansett did not owe anywhere near the figure that Compass owed on that date.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I hate to be pedantic, but we are talking about precise legal obligations and precise organisations. So I should observe that this is not a matter for the Department; it is a matter for the FAC, which is formed under an Act and is a commercialised government business enterprise.
—Pushed off budget.

—I acknowledge the interjection of Senator Bishop. It is off budget. That could raise a whole philosophical debate as to whether it should appear in the Estimates at all, since there are no estimates here that are necessary for its operation. All I can say is that I will pass on Senator Panizza's requests. If the FAC is in a position to answer, I am sure that it will.

—In conclusion, I will be specific about what I am asking. Firstly, I am assuming that the Minister denies that the Government has any contingent liability in respect of the FAC. I want to specify that exactly so there will be no doubt about the answer that he may eventually give me. I do not think that information as to whether Ansett owed any more or any less, or an assurance that it did not owe as much, is commercial-in-confidence; it is just a comparison. I want to know exactly what that figure is to ascertain that Ansett owed no more than Compass on that day—or to ascertain that it did not even owe that much—because Compass was shut down and the others were allowed to fly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Ansett pays its accounts within the guidelines of the FAC. To that extent, it may help the inquiries of Senator Panizza. I am not in a position to compare or contrast the financial responsibility of Ansett at any one time compared to that of another airline. However, I am advised that it does abide by the FAC's guidelines on payment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up the point raised by Senator Chapman and the points contained in the additional information dealing with the joint ventures and takeovers of concessionaires. I asked whether the FAC is contemplating a joint venture with Downtown and what criterion the FAC uses when entering the AFF joint venture. I also asked how much money the FAC will make out of AFF. The answer that was given was:

SPEECH.PARA: No. The Corporation is of the view that it has the ability to enter into joint venture arrangements at any time based on commercial considerations.

It refused to give any particulars of the projections of profit from AFF because it was commercial-in-confidence, yet over the page we have another commercial enterprise entered into—a concession with KSA—and it was quite happy to project what the revenue is. Could the Minister explain to me why one is commercial-in-confidence and the other is not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asked by Senator Bishop to differentiate between two arrangements that the FAC has made. I am not in a position to make that distinction. As I have tried to explain, the FAC is a commercial entity in its own right, set up under its own Act to trade commercially. It is in a position of being able to enter into commercial arrangements.

PARA.TAB: Where there are private parties involved in that, doubtless the issue of the rights of the private party in partnership with the FAC arises. If that private party does not want its affairs broadcast, I think it is entitled to insist in the partnership arrangement on commercial-in-confidence. It may be that that private party in its own right would be prepared to answer questions of the character that have been put to the FAC, but it may not be. I am not aware of what Senator Bishop has asked about the basis of differentiation between Downtown and the other company she referred to and Kingsford-Smith Airport.

I have just been given some further advice. The figure given for the Kingsford-Smith Airport is a global figure of total earnings. We cannot distinguish the individual affairs of a particular company; therefore, a global figure can be given. Each one of the first examples is a distinct entity with a commercial personality, and the arrangements would be identified under Senator Bishop's question. I think that is the appropriate answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think that answer makes out Senator Chapman's point very well. That is classic gobbledegook. Senator Chapman made an excellent point. The FAC is simply a function of government which has been hived off in a corporate structure. The people who were previously bureaucrats have been told to go out and play being businessmen. We do not make a manager by saying, `Tomorrow you will be one'. There are people heading up this organisation who, quite frankly, have the sort of background that would not earn them that job in the private sector.

PARA.TAB: The fundamental difference between a private sector organisation and this hybrid character that this Government has created is, simply, that shareholders in the private sector are free to invest their money or not invest their money in that corporation as they see fit. If they do not like the way that corporation is run, they may take their money out and leave that corporation. Things in the public sector are funded by the compulsory acquisition of funds by way of taxation, which people are not permitted to opt out of. The Government decides where taxpayers' money is put and then the bureaucrats administer it. The FAC is a public sector entity, and as such is subject to public sector criteria. It is simply not an answer to pretend by some sort of legal fiction that it has become a private sector enterprise.

The day it is sold off and has shareholders and directors who are answerable to those shareholders, instead of this quaint practice of the Government being the shareholder, that is the day we can say it is truly a commercial enterprise. In the interim, as Senator Chapman aptly pointed out, if the FAC goes to the wall, the taxpayer picks up the tab. Therefore, it is indeed in the taxpayer's interest to know the way in which this body conducts its affairs.

One of the things that concerns me and an enormous number of people who are truly private sector businessmen is the manner in which the FAC has become renowned, if not notorious, for litigation. I turn to that section in the answers given concerning legal actions that I asked for. To say that these answers would mislead a reasonable man reading them is to put it mildly. My question, as recorded on page 345, was:

SPEECH.PARA: How many legal actions were the FAC involved in last year?
The answer was:
During the 1991/92 year, the Corporation was involved in 7 significant legal actions including: . . .
I did not ask that; I asked how many actions it was involved in. The answer continued:
. . . the defendant in three significant civil claims (over $100,000) for damages (there have been only three such claims since 1988) . . .

The major complaint against the FAC is not that it is very often the defendant, but that it is all too often a plaintiff. I will give honourable senators an example of the nature of the litigious action the FAC indulges in. It was a plaintiff before the District Court, and I have a list covering the year 1991 of a total of 25 cases which were listed before that Court. The District Court is not a small debts court but a court of significant jurisdiction.

PARA.TAB: The FAC appeared as a plaintiff before the Supreme Court of New South Wales in 1991. One case dated from 1990 and it was a plaintiff in one case and a defendant in two cases. The FAC was a plaintiff before the Commercial Division of the Supreme Court and a plaintiff before the Equity Division in a case in 1992. It was a defendant in one case and a plaintiff in two others, and it appeared before the Court of Appeal. The FAC has appeared in a total of nine cases before the Supreme Court of New South Wales since 1988. It has cases before the Federal Court of Australia dating from 1988 to 1992—a total of 13 cases.
The bottom line is that the answers far from reflected the truth. I note that when we come to the question of Multicon Engineering the following very quaint answer was given:

SPEECH.PARA: During 1991/92, approximately $2.2m was expended on legal actions. Most of this amount was expended in defending one claim against the Corporation for $9.5m by Multicon Engineering Pty Ltd.

As I understand it, the claim was in the vicinity of $26m and the company has made every endeavour to settle that claim. At every turn there has been obfuscation by the FAC which has resulted in a quasi arbitration proceeding being dragged out until the judge concerned had to haul it over the coals to bring it to some sort of sense.

PARA.TAB: The estimate of the industry as a whole is that the FAC is a highly litigious organisation which settles at the court date after millions of dollars have been wasted in legal fees, even where settlement has been negotiated and there is an overriding factor by the board. Quite frankly, for the Minister to say that the FAC is at arm's length and he has no responsibility when it is the taxpayer who will pick up the tab if these people fall over, simply is not good enough. I ask the Minister to go back to his officers and ask them to give me a proper answer to the questions I asked and a proper estimate of the money they spent last year on legal actions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bishop has raised a number of matters. Taking them in sequential order, I start with Senator Bishop's observation about the management of the FAC. As I have said in my earlier answers, the FAC is set up under an Act of parliament and is a commercialised government business enterprise. It registers its corporate plan with the Government, pays a dividend and is governed by a board with considerable commercial expertise. To characterise it as a body of bureaucrats is probably unfair to bureaucrats.

PARA.TAB: For the record, people with private sector experience constitute something like 70 per cent of its managerial structure. I am never quite sure how precisely bureaucrats are described in their daily functions, but one would expect bureaucrats to have a management role and one would expect that public sector bureaucrats ought to be able to manage with the same level of competence and expertise as private sector bureaucrats in large organisations.

The FAC is run not as a Public Service department, but as a commercial company. It has an AA-plus rating on the credit market. It does not have loans that are guaranteed by the Government. It is a very sound organisation. It pays its own taxation to the Government. I understand that $150m worth of its bonds were sold in 30 minutes to the private sector capital market. That is some sort of indication that, in private sector eyes, this is a worthwhile organisation to buy bonds from and in which to put money. To characterise the FAC as some poor commercial relation is not fair at all. It is a well conducted and respected business in a truly commercial sense.

I now move to the issue of litigation. I am not quite sure what the point of these questions is. Any business conducting itself on the scale that the FAC does—particularly as the FAC is a major client of building companies—is embroiled in litigation from time to time. The FAC owns, operates and constructs where necessary additions to airports. If one travels around this country—and all of us in this chamber do—one will see that there is not a single airport that currently does not have a wing under construction. That is some indication of the amount of construction that the FAC contracts construction companies to undertake.

I think it is also fair to say that anyone in the business of building is usually embroiled in contract litigation of some form or another at some time or other. A characteristic of the building industry is the tendency to have a higher level of litigation over contracts compared with other industries. Nothing can be drawn from whether or not the FAC is a defendant or a plaintiff in a particular case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The distinction is quite important.

—There is nothing to be drawn from that. If people are engaged in commercial practice, their commercial interests are being injured at law and they do not exercise their rights to take action, they could be regarded as negligent in their responsibility. If people were the subject of action and did not defend themselves they could be considered equally negligent. I do not find that there is any particular ministerial responsibility as to whether or not the FAC conducts itself properly in defending itself. Its reputation is certainly that of a well run organisation.
