PARA.TAB: We turn now to the last matter that Senator Bishop raised: Multicon—I think that is what the name of the company was. I have no particular knowledge of this case. But I do not know in what role Senator Bishop rises in this chamber to allege certain things about the FAC's conduct toward Multicon. I do not know whether she believes that there is a case here that Multicon is right and the FAC is wrong and she is advocating Multicon's cause. I do not understand why it is—

TALK.START.PARA: —I know you don't understand! God help us—bring back Bob Collins!

—I do not understand why it is that Senator Bishop should seemingly assume that the FAC is in the wrong here and that something terrible is transpiring. But the matter is before the court. As I understand Senator Bishop's description of it, the case is before the court, and that has to be the right place for a determination to be made as to who is right or wrong.

PARA.TAB: While the Senate may editorialise about which side may be in the right, which side may have conducted itself properly or improperly in negotiations and whether a particular judge in a certain proceeding at a given time had a view—that is all fascinating, and I am delighted to hear about it—I do not know that it relates at all to the Estimates before the chamber or, indeed, to my ministerial responsibility. They are matters of commercial judgment and the FAC seems to me to have conducted itself in a proper way.

TALK.START.PARA: —One really does wish that Senator Collins were back on the job. The reason I rose to speak about, in particular, the Multicon issue is that I have here a document called Sydney Airport International Terminal stage 1 expansion structural steel contract TC08 settlement presentation—in other words, in every endeavour to settle this matter which is wasting millions of dollars.

PARA.TAB: It is a document which I think has been sent to me out of some form of desperation by parties. I have had senior businessmen from many areas come to see me because simply they find that the new form of contract which the FAC has drawn up for itself, which is different from the one that is in operation internationally, has resulted in it being interpreted by the FAC in a highly litigious manner. If one compares the actions of the FAC with those of any other corporation, one finds that they are way outside the manner in which any other organisation operates.

The really interesting thing about the complaints that have come to me concerning the litigious nature of the FAC is that they have not come from one source. They have come from a whole area of sources—all very senior people; all with genuine complaints. I refer to complaints concerning the awarding of a contract. I have asked previously the question about the way in which expressions of interest are registered whereby, under the way things are operated, one gets the situation where one can simply ask one's first best friend, one's second best friend, someone who is hopeless and someone who is an international and does not meet the ANZ Australian criteria, and guess what: the first best friend gets the job.

There are so many areas where the procurement process—the operations—need to be subject to scrutiny. The thing that is so wrong with regard to the Federal Airports Corporation, in particular—and there are others as well—is that it is quite powerful because it has the monopoly; it has the ability to make and break corporations. It is acting in a way which the general business community considers to be unacceptable, and yet it is all overseen and backed up by the taxpayer.

It does not matter what funny legal fictions we have put in place; that the Government is the shareholder; that it gets a dividend from its operations that is paid into Consolidated Revenue—all of those things do not matter. At the end of the day, if the FAC gets it wrong, even if the Government has been standing at arm's length, if it louses it up and goes broke, it is ordinary Australians that pick up the tab and have to pay out the creditors.

That is why the FAC is subject, or ought to be subject, to scrutiny and accountability. But, at every turn, while we seek to ask about the manner in which the tender process or the expression of interest process is used, the manner in which the FAC enters into so-called joint ventures because it looks like somebody might fall over, the way it issues a contract and then deals with variations under a contract which it has drawn up for itself all by itself and which is not shared in common with any other country, all these quaint practices which the FAC has developed for itself, under the Government's rules, say that it is not subject to scrutiny.

That is not on. As I said, the test is: if it falls over and they get it wrong, Joe Blow, the taxpayer, is the one who pays. And it is a monopoly; it is powerful; it has the ability to keep people out; it has the ability to determine the way things occur. Very simply, in our system of democracy, if this Parliament is not vigilant and insistent upon answers, the sorts of answers that Senator Chapman was asking for earlier, that Senator Panizza has been asking for and that the business people have come to me for because they feel it is just not being handled correctly, have to be answered. If the Minister is just going to be a puppet and stand up and say, `I am sure they are doing it nicely, because they are independent; they are jolly good managers', and if that is his idea of accountability, then we are all in trouble.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask a few questions in relation to the FAC, on behalf of some small business people. My understanding is that as from December the FAC will be taking from the hire and drive operators at Hobart Airport something like 11 per cent of their turnover. Is that accurate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the FAC has released a discussion paper about arrangements for private hire car companies at its airports. The matter that Senator Newman has referred to is one of the issues raised. It is not the only issue. The FAC is discussing with particular client companies—the industry, in a sense—the proposal about how hire should be managed based on its discussion paper. Nothing has been resolved at this point.
—Is it incorrect that new charges will be levied in December this year?

—I understand, as I have said, that a draft paper has been released. I am advised that that draft paper has led to some very helpful and positive suggestions about future contract arrangements. The document has been extensively revised to take those comments into account and a further draft has been circulated for consideration by the car rental industry. Further meetings and consultations are being held with industry to finetune the arrangements as far as possible.

PARA.TAB: I think I can also say that as a result of the consultations the Corporation is considering a fifth tier—I am not quite sure what a fifth tier is; there is a series of tiers here, one to four, worked out on the basis of access fee, turnover percentage, car space and desk space—where very small operators, with less than 3 per cent of market share of airport business, would pay a small access fee and a flat fee of $5 per rental contract day and utilise the car park.

I understand from all the advice I have given Senator Newman that nothing has been finalised. I observe a vigorous nodding of the head from the advisers box, which reaffirms my belief that nothing has been finalised, ergo the proposal to operate a set charge from a certain date is not finalised.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister, but I would like more certainty than that in the answer. I specifically asked: will something be introduced in increasing fees in December? If the Minister knows anything about the tourist industry, he will know it is pretty important to recognise that December is a pretty crucial month. At that time of the year in Tasmania, we have been going for a long time without cash.
—It is my understanding that the FAC does intend to introduce a revised charge by the end of the year, but at this stage it is not finalised and the date of operation is not clear.
—I thank the Minister. That means yes, it will be introduced in December. There is no other interpretation of the Minister's answer.
—I suppose if you want to be pedantic, there are a few days left in this month, but you are probably right.
—The Minister said, `by the end of the year'.
—Yes.
—Did the Minister mean that he could have introduced it in late November?
—No, but I am not going to argue that point. I think you are right, Senator.
—Very well. I thank the Minister. Can the Minister tell me how much notice, if any, is required under the existing arrangements to be given to existing operators in FAC terminals?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the issuance of a discussion paper is an indication of notice and concern to involve operators in a consideration of how the commercial interface between the two parties to a contract is managed. But I am advised that existing contracts expired in October and the matter is open for renewal.

—But on what basis was the renewal of the existing contracts envisaged when they were signed? Was there no provision made for extension or review? Are we in the middle of the review process, or have they just been allowed to expire and that is all there is to it?

—No, they have expired, but they have been carried over on a month-by-month basis until the review was completed. As I have said earlier, it is the intention of the FAC to finalise the matter before the end of this year, and the discussion paper process, the debate and analysis have been part of that.

—Can the Minister explain why there was not a notice given prior to the expiry of the contracts? When was the discussion paper released and, under the previous contracts that have now expired, was there no process for renewal?

—I cannot give Senator Newman a precise date. I have no advice from the FAC of a precise date when the discussion process started. But I understand the Trade Practices Commission had some concern about the contracts and, as a consequence of that concern, the discussion paper was developed and the matter has proceeded from then. But as to the trigger or operative date, I cannot provide Senator Newman with an answer for that now. I will inquire of the FAC to see whether it can provide her with an answer and obtain one as expeditiously as possible.

—I thank the Minister. The Trade Practices Commission is not the only one who is concerned about the operations of the FAC in airports. I have expressed my concerns for quite a while in one form or another. Can the Minister tell me whether the FAC has tried to do any assessment of the effect on these businesses of the increased charges it is proposing?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the record I should say, in view of the comments that Senator Newman has made, that the Trade Practices Commission is now well satisfied with the situation. The purpose of the discussion paper is an effort by the FAC to come to grips with the issue of the effect on business. That is why I suppose it has taken the amount of time that it has. It has taken on board the comments it has received and is in the process of now finalising its response.

—I thank the Minister. I mentioned the timing of this before, and it appears to me that the FAC is not quite as commercial yet in its outlook as it might be. Perhaps it is not aware that the Tasmanian tourist industry has had I think the worst year it has had for years and years and that people are still on the verge of going broke. I say that very advisedly. My family is in the tourist industry so I know only too well, although it is not involved in car hire. Right around the State people have been suffering very badly.

PARA.TAB: The timing of an introduction of increased charges seems to me quite incredible. The major supplier, if you like, of tourists to Tasmania has been Victoria. I would have hoped that the Minister would have understood by now that people in Victoria have either lost their jobs or are terrified that they are going to. They are not taking holidays, and they have not been doing so for a year or two.

For the FAC to suddenly come in, having the monopoly over the facility, and start jacking up prices to hire car operators in a very depressed market strikes me as stupid in the extreme. People in that position should be looking to carry their small business contacts for as long as they can afford to do so—I recognise they are meant to be commercial—if they want the whole business to survive. We have already a year or two ago seen a disastrous business bust in the hire car industry in our State. We do not want to see more and I would have thought that this was a very inopportune time to suddenly turn around and hoist a whole lot of new charges on the industry.

I am glad the Minister has said that perhaps wiser counsel may be prevailing. However, from what the Minister has said I do not have enough detail to know whether in fact it is very wise counsel. I do not know how much gentler the FAC is going to be on its small business operators, but it certainly has not shown much nous in the way it has approached this issue at this time in a very sensitive industry.

I hope my words are being taken with some seriousness because they are not said lightly. The FAC might be in fact killing the goose that will eventually, some day, lay a golden egg. Right now it is not laying a golden egg for anybody and if the FAC keeps it up there will be no eggs for anybody—golden or otherwise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —The development of the FAC's discussion paper is to take account of precisely the concerns Senator Newman has raised. Nothing has been finalised, although it is the intention of the FAC to deal with the issue of the ongoing terms of contracts by the end of the year rather than continue to roll over the contracts that were expired in October.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I should also say that if the FAC were privatised, as is the Opposition's policy, it would be operating on commercial lines and it would doubtless be going through the same sorts of contract renewal discussions as the FAC in its commercialised form. I would hope that the FAC, having the Government as the shareholder, does consider weightily the impact on its local commercial partners or its lessees in terms of airport operation. But I think there is an obligation on it, too, to distinguish its commercial operation from a community service obligation.

If there is a community service obligation plea being entered here—I am not sure there is and I am not necessarily inviting one, but I take on board the seriousness of what Senator Newman has said—then I think that should be distinguished because I think it would be unfair to say to the FAC, `Operate commercially, but observe at the same time some community service obligation'. That would mean it could not take commercial decisions in the case of the smaller ports.

The point I am making is that this is a horse of an entirely different colour. I also point out that if the Opposition's privatisation commitment were honoured by a government, there would be no dimension or consideration for a community service obligation in a case like this.

Finally, I do appreciate the difficulties in Tasmania. We only want to see that the best happens in that State, that the tourist industry is revived. I am sure it is true, as Senator Newman has said, that Victorians, Tasmania's major supplier to the tourist market, are worried at the present time. If I were in Victoria at the present time I would be worried. I certainly would like to take a holiday in Tasmania, but I am not sure I would get away with it if I did not have an annual leave loading.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister still has a ministerial salary—for just a little bit longer. It would probably be best if he came now while he had more to spend—before the election. We could do with the money.

—I do intend to visit the Apple Isle before the election, assuming that the election will not be before Christmas. I intend to come down and greet the Sydney-Hobart fleet and return with one of the yachts.

—I want to put on the record that in fact I was not making a plea for a community service input here. I was suggesting that, in business, often enlightened self-interest encourages businesses, such as the FAC should be, to take a longer term view for the sake of better returns in the long term. This is one of those occasions where, if they kill off the small operators, there might not be much left when times change, if they do before long.
—It is a well-made point, Senator. (Quorum formed)
—We will now turn to subprogram 1.6—the Civil Aviation Authority.

—I note that there has been reservation in relation to the subprogram entered by Senator Panizza. I notice that my colleague has come into the chamber. Hopefully we will be able to dispose of one matter very briefly. I have been trying for some time now to elicit an indication from the Minister's office of when we can expect the Macphee report to be handed down and the reasons for this report not having been presented to date.

PARA.TAB: This is a long running saga. It was originally promised that the report would be available in August, then September, and then October elapsed. In spite of many requests to the Minister's office, he has persistently failed to explain to the Senate what the cause of delay is. This is not an issue which we seek to politicise; it is an issue that we are very concerned about having some good management and some proper accountability.

One of our concerns is that we have received no explanation of what is going on with the report. I know that the Minister has said on previous occasions that Mr Macphee is conducting an independent report, and that is quite correct. But Mr Macphee is not the person who is accountable to the Parliament; it is the Minister. The report was initiated by the Executive. What we seek on this side of the chamber is some indication from the Minister as to when the report will be available and the reasons for the delay in the presentation of that report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of fact, the report that Mr Macphee has been commissioned to complete—a genuinely independent report, as has been said—is one that has been commissioned by the board of the Civil Aviation Authority and not by the Executive—the Executive in this case I take to mean the Cabinet or the Ministry. It is not a report that I am responsible for commissioning. It is a report that the board of the CAA is responsible for commissioning.

PARA.TAB: The board has consulted me about issues such as terms of reference, the reporter and access to information, and I have been kept thoroughly briefed. Indeed, I have from time to time said things on behalf of the board on the public record. The board will make the report available to me as soon as it is available to the board. I have indicated that when that occurs, at the first opportunity, I will release it and table it in this chamber.

My understanding is that the report has been found to be more complex and time consuming than originally imagined. Certainly there was a concern at the beginning of the inquiry that the terms of reference be wide enough to anticipate any matters that might be generally brought forward under the rubric of the inquiry. That has meant that there has been a very thorough canvassing of a wide range of issues relating to the radar contract.

In conducting the inquiry it has been necessary to go back and check matters after subsequent information has been found to have raised further questions that initially were not anticipated. There has been quite a bit of toing and froing as well. I understand that the report is in the concluding stages. I am advised by the CAA that it expects the report to be made available to me by about the end of this month.

It is not a report or an inquiry that this Senate has raised. It is not one that the executive in this case has raised. So I do not think it is reasonable to say that I have an obligation to report to the Senate. I interpret my responsibilities, though, as being to keep the Senate informed, and I trust I have always done that reasonably. I am aware of Senator O'Chee's interest. I have noted the conscientiousness with which he has pursued information about the release of the report. I hope that my remarks now might set his mind at rest.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. We seem to be making some progress here; maybe we can tie this up even faster. When the report is produced to the Minister by the board of the CAA, does the Minister then intend to table that report in Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank God for Senator O'Chee's question because I am reminded that I made a slip in my own accuracy a minute ago in the answer I gave. It is true that the CAA board has commissioned a report. It is responsible for the appointment of the inquirer, the terms of reference and so on, but the report will be made directly to me and I will table it. I did indicate before that the report would be made directly to the board and the board would pass it on to me. I am now correcting the record: it will be made directly to me.

—I thank the Minister for that answer, which seems to clarify the matter substantially. Can the Minister advise how long it will take between his receiving the report and it being tabled in the Senate?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to sit on it. I think there is a considerable deal of public interest in this inquiry. The worst possible thing that can happen in government is for a government to receive a report and there to be a delay before the report is made available. That gives rise to unhealthy speculation, rumour and anxiety. So it is my intention to have the report tabled as soon as possible without delay. If there are then comments, I would certainly listen to them, and I am sure so would the board of the CAA.

PARA.TAB: It would help my consideration of the findings—I am certain it would help the consideration of the board of the CAA too—and enable both of us in discharging our respective responsibilities to reply in a more considered way, with our ear cocked to the public comment that might arise from the recommendations. But to answer the specific question: as soon as possible and without delay.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister give an undertaking to advise the Senate—I think the last week of November is a sitting week—at that stage whether he foresees any further difficulties or delays that may emerge between now and then? If he could give that undertaking, that would be much appreciated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, this is not an inquiry the Senate has given rise to, and I have not interpreted that I am responsible to have to keep the Senate advised step by step of the changes. I will be delighted to keep Senator O'Chee advised and, if it is appropriate, I will certainly notify the chamber. I do not think it is appropriate for me to make an ironclad written commitment in the form that Senator O'Chee seeks. Had it been an inquiry, the Senate would have been bound to. I will do all I can to observe the niceties and the decorum necessary.

PARA.TAB: It is the Government's view, and my view, that there were raised by rumour and innuendo and direct accusation a number of charges about the matter that is being inquired into sufficient to encourage the board to want an inquiry so that what has happened is open and clear. That inquiry has taken longer than anticipated. But there is, on behalf of all of us, I think fairly, a commitment to have this out open and clear, deal with whatever arises from it, benign or not, whatever the case may be—I have no indication, nor should I have, what it will be—and get onto the business of ensuring that the operations of the CAA continue to serve the public of Australia to the same high standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had a number of questions to ask about this program. Unfortunately, because of the time and in deference to my colleagues, I will not be pursuing most of them. However, I do want to say how disgusted I am with the way the Government has handled the program and the way the Democrats have agreed with it. I shudder with embarrassment every time I walk out of the door and see the number of public servants sitting in offices at this time of the night waiting to assist the Ministers. It is an absolutely disgraceful situation. I mention it only on the basis that the more people who draw attention to it the more likely that the Government, should it be in power at the time of the next Estimates Committee—I am sure it will not be—will not do the same thing again.

PARA.TAB: I refer briefly to the defamation proceedings which officers of the CAA are taking against certain newspapers. In the Estimates Committee we did obtain some information from the officers and since then I have received some responses in writing which do clarify the matter for me. I am concerned with the position where taxpayers' money is used to support some legal claim. It makes me wonder at times what sort of encouragement there is, when it is not that person's own money that is being used, to deal realistically with the program.

I acknowledge from the material that has been given to me that there is some supervision, but I wonder whether the Minister is in a position to update me on the claim being taken by Mr Baldwin against, I believe, the Sydney Morning Herald. How have things changed since 8 September? Is the Minister aware of whether the other legal proceedings which Mr Baldwin was contemplating at the time have in fact been taken and, if so, what is their status?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should comment on the first point. I would be delighted if what Senator Macdonald is foreshadowing is a proposal that we set particular times and keep to them in which each of these committee Estimates would be heard. That would enable us to schedule the attendance of public servants for a particular time, rather than have them wait until we move sequentially and, I might say, without reflecting on the Senate, move laboriously through our list. They could turn up, be dealt with and go home. That would be a great advantage to all of us.

PARA.TAB: I should say that there is no taxpayers' money involved in any legal actions being taken by officers of the CAA with board approval. The CAA, as we have been discussing with the FAC, is a commercialised operation responsible for paying a dividend. The actions that have been taken have, I understand, been sanctioned by the board. In the case of the first matter that was raised by Senator Macdonald, my understanding is that it is before the courts now. I cannot comment any further than that.

In the case of the second matter, am I aware? I was not aware. There is no reason why I should be aware. It is a decision for the CAA and I think I am not really in a position to comment any further on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to whether it is taxpayers' money or not, I think Senator Schacht pointed out in the Estimates Committee hearings that if the CAA runs out of money, who picks up the bill? It is quite obvious that it would be the taxpayers. Mr Chairman, I wonder if Senator Cook could possibly obtain the information that I sought that he was not able to give and possibly let me know later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information here. As I said, it is a matter for the board to determine. In the case of legal action, it is doing so on a step by step basis. In the case of the second case, it is my understanding—I hope I have this right—that it concerns the New Zealand media and not the Sydney Morning Herald and that the officer in this case, Mr Baldwin, is responsible for his own costs. I will refer Senator Macdonald's question to see if there is any other information that can usefully be provided. I will put that to the CAA and pass on its response to him.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Reid) put:

SPEECH.PARA: That progress be reported.

PARA.TAB: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications. Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 1.6 or subprogram 1.7? There being no matters, we will move to program 2—broadcasting. Are there any matters on subprogram 2.2?

—For what it is worth, I want to make some very brief comments about ABC regional radio services. Again I make the point that those officers who are waiting outside have only the Australian Democrats to blame for this appalling misuse of their time. If the Democrats had any thought for the parliamentary institutions they would not be trying to make us work through a number of very serious matters at this hour of the morning, keeping those officers waiting around. It is an absolutely disgraceful and atrocious display from a group which was supposed to be here to keep parliament operating honestly. It is no wonder that their vote is as low as it is.

PARA.TAB: I would like to refer the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Collins) to some answers that were given to me in response to my questions on notice about the value of different properties in the north of Queensland. I refer the Minister to some of the properties which the ABC has bought, apparently in line with reducing its costs or in order to use resources more efficiently.

In 1986 the ABC bought some land in Cairns for $300,000 and put a new building on it at a cost of $772,000. It sold some of the surplus land. I am told by the ABC that the current value of the whole site is $764,000. If one adds the first two figures together, one will see that the ABC paid more than $1m for a property that is now worth $764,000. It certainly has not been a very good commercial deal. Similarly, in Mount Isa the ABC upgraded the studios for $336,000 and the land was valued at $32,000. Even adding just those two figures together, that is a $368,000 investment in the Mount Isa studios which are currently valued at only $327,000. Again, that was a fairly poor investment by the ABC.

That sort of supports the point that I am trying to make, which is that there seems to be some lack of management ability in the ABC in commercial areas. Most of the commercial radio stations lease premises because they find that commercially most attractive. But for some reason, this does not seem to apply to the ABC.

I note the answers given in writing which suggest that it is difficult to move and that there is a lot of equipment in the studios. I again say that leasing is good enough for the commercial stations and one wonders why it is not good enough for the ABC. One then wonders about the ABC protests about a cutback in funds. Should not more be directed at the lack of real commercial management in the way that it operates rather than a lack of funds?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand the point that is being made here. I am sure that the ABC will take note of Senator Macdonald's opinion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Minister the following question on notice:

SPEECH.PARA: In regard to the ABC's new radio outdoor broadcasting equipment being upgraded, have you got a program of where it is going and when it is going in?

I asked that question because of the fiasco we had in broadcasting the AFL games from different parts of Australia, especially Melbourne, where it was shocking. The commentators had to finish up broadcasting over a normal telephone line rather than through a mike. The answer to my question is:
ABC Radio Sport ordered the new "Outside Broadcast" equipment earlier this year and the equipment was delivered in July.
By mid July most of the equipment had been tested in Melbourne and issued as follows . . .

It then lists the number of sets given to each State. In the case of Western Australia, when was the equipment installed? To my knowledge, it certainly was not in in July, and I do not know that it has been installed yet.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have that degree of detail with me about particular installations of particular radios in Western Australia in the consideration of the Estimates in committee. But I will inquire of the officers if they have that information. There are more effective avenues of pursuing that kind of detail. Senator Panizza is correct; the answer has been provided to him. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: ABC Radio Sport ordered the new "Outside Broadcast" equipment early this year and the equipment was delivered in July.
By mid July most of the equipment had been tested in Melbourne and was issued—
to Western Australia, South Australia, Victoria, New South Wales, Queensland, the Northern Territory and Tasmania. It continues:
Tasmania holds two spare sets of equipment to be allocated on a needs basis.
The sets have already been used in some States such as Victoria and South Australia.
I just do not have any more detail to add than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite capable of reading the answer, even at 10 past 2 in the morning. But the answer says that the equipment has been tested and issued. To my knowledge, it has not been installed. It might have been issued somewhere along the line but, to my knowledge, it has not been installed in Western Australia. So I want to know whether it has been installed and whether it is working. Furthermore, I find the attitude of the Minister quite surprising, because it is a legitimate question. It adds to questions that were put on notice and which were answered rather late.

—Senator Panizza has been provided with an answer which I think is reasonable under the circumstances. The equipment has been provided in Western Australia. I do not have any information in the brief in front of me as to whether this set of broadcasting equipment has been used in Western Australia since it was installed in July. The officers that are present also do not have that degree of detail. But I can assure Senator Panizza that I do not anticipate there being any difficulty in getting that information to him later today.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Are there any matters on subprogram 2.3, the Special Broadcasting Service?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again raise with the Minister the fact that the SBS does not broadcast into the Townsville or Cairns regions. I have received an answer in writing, part of which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The decision to include Darwin in the program of SBS TV extensions for 1993-94 ahead of Townsville and Cairns simply reflects the fact that Darwin is the only capital city without SBS TV.

I would hope the fact that the Minister comes from that area has nothing to do with that. I put to the Minister that both Townsville and I think Cairns have populations well in excess of that which would be served by Darwin SBS.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't have the ethnic mix of Darwin.

—I put to the Minister that the number of potential listeners is a far more legitimate way to order the priorities than the fact that Darwin is the only capital city without SBS. I ask for the Minister's comments on that.

—I join my colleague Senator Tambling in expressing my outrage at that suggestion. What I can say to Senator Macdonald with absolute truth is that the very first representation that I ever made as a Northern Territory politician, then a member of the Legislative Assembly, to a Federal Labor Minister—
—I don't want your life history.

—Senator Macdonald wanted the answer, and I will give it to him. I am answering his question; he should let me answer it. It will only take a minute. The very first representation I ever made to a Federal Labor Minister in this Government as the then Leader of the Opposition in the Northern Territory was for the installation of SBS in Darwin. Mr Duffy had been sworn in as a Minister on Friday and I was in his office on the following Monday making those representations. That was 10 years ago.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is, comprehensively, that I reject the assertions that Senator Macdonald has made that this is some sort of private perk that I have organised for Darwin because of my position as Minister. The provision of SBS to Darwin, which is something the SBS itself has long wanted, has been in progression now for at least a decade. It will be very welcome when it arrives in Darwin. Townsville is on the agenda for 1994. We are constantly seeking, within the constraints of the global budgetary restrictions, to advance whenever and wherever we can the extension of the SBS network—and that includes to places such as Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek your indulgence, Madam Temporary Chairman. I forgot to ask a question on the ABC, under subprogram 2.2. I suppose I could ask the question under SBS. I will ask it anyway, and you can rule it out of order if you think fit.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—The honourable senator should relate the question to the subprogram it refers to.

TALK.START.PARA: —It comes under subprogram 2.2. The Minister would certainly have heard of the problems with the Aboriginal radio stations in the Kimberley. There is one in Kununurra, one in Halls Creek, one in Fitzroy and one in Derby. In fact, there is a delegation at Parliament House today. They are running out of funds at this stage. These four stations are operating approximately 10 hours a week. It seems to me that the argument concerning the funding is between ATSIC and the radio stations, because ATSIC obviously gets a global budget and broadcasting is under that. Not long ago I spent a week in the area, which was when I first heard about this matter, and I spoke to those concerned again today.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to give me a solution to this problem. If he is interested in listening, I will give him my own solution. I believe there should be an ongoing radio service to promote Aboriginal culture and spread the health message. I know that the radio stations need approximately three-quarters of a million dollars in extra funding to see this year out. This Government will not be in office at the time of the next Budget, but if we were unlucky enough to still have a Labor Government, would it be possible to take an amount of money out of ATSIC's budget and put it into the Department of Transport and Communications to permit an ongoing funding for those radio stations? I think there are three FM stations and one AM station in the area. Perhaps it could be cut back to only two AM stations. They could then have an ongoing budget and would know what to do in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The indigenous broadcasting services that operate in Australia do provide a very important service, and there are many of them. The Federal Government currently funds Aboriginal broadcasting to the tune of $12m a year. A great deal of support is given to it. The ultimate solution is simply more money, and it does not really change the position whether it is taken out of DOTAC and put it into ATSIC, or whether it is taken out of ATSIC and put into DOTAC. At the end of the day it comes fundamentally from Consolidated Revenue.

PARA.TAB: I am very aware of the situation of the Kimberley broadcasters. In a general sense, ATSIC has recognised the problem itself and has set up a specialist group to advise it on broadcasting. In fact, I will be meeting with the chairman of that group when I open a broadcasting conference in Albury tomorrow.

The fact is that ATSIC does have to set priorities in terms of its spending, and those priorities do have to be balanced as any other organisation has to balance priorities. I am advised that one of the difficulties is at regional council level. Some of the regional councillors do not place as high a priority on broadcasting services as they do on the provision of other services such as housing, health and so on. The Federal Government is anxious to assist in this process, and at the moment we are looking at what can be done in the interim for the Kimberley broadcasters.

In my view, the solution at the end of the day is the one that ATSIC itself has adopted; that is, it has recognised the growing number of Aboriginal broadcasters who are proliferating around Australia at the moment and the fact that there needs to be a cohesive national policy for ATSIC to structure the funding for them. At the end of the day those priorities—rightly, in my view—have to be set by the ATSIC commissioners. I know that the primary purpose of the delegation's visit to Canberra is to discuss these issues with the ATSIC commissioners.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was told that the extra funding ATSIC was looking for was to be used to assist in the training of announcers and researchers. I think it was looking for an allocation of $530,000 for that project. Would it not be better—especially in the coming year or so—for the ABC to assist in that training? Perhaps the ABC has personnel who are not being utilised fully, or perhaps some other form of help could be provided through DEET or something like that.

—I thank Senator Panizza for his positive interest in this area. But I think it may be more helpful to Senator Panizza, and indeed to the Senate, if we had a discussion about this matter outside of Estimates. Senator Panizza knows full well that I am happy to see him whenever he wishes. As he would recall, the last time he came to see me he received a positive result.
—In three minutes.

—It was a very effective representation and very good service from my office. I suggest to Senator Panizza that if he has a real interest—which I welcome—in the area of Aboriginal broadcasting and if he wants to have a more detailed discussion about this matter, I would be more than happy to discuss it with him.
—Thank you.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—That is an excellent idea, Minister. It will help us to move along. We had reached subprogram 2.7, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to questions which I asked in relation to the Channel 9 Sex program that were taken on notice by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The first of those was in relation to whether any X-rated material was included in any of the broadcasts of that program. I note that the response from the Broadcasting Tribunal was:

SPEECH.PARA: To the best of the Tribunal's knowledge, having viewed the program and made inquiries of the OFLC, Sex did not contain X rated material. TPS13 requires licensees not to show motion sequences from X rated films or video at any time.
The last sentence of that answer gives rise to the question: did any still sequences which may have been taken from X-rated films or video make up part of that program?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not in a position to add anything to the answer that has already been provided. The first sentence is certainly—if I dare use the word—explicit. It says that the program did not contain X-rated material, and, to the best of my knowledge, it did not. I think the two sentence are not connected. It then goes on to quote the licensee requirements under the regulations. The first sentence says quite clearly, `To the best of the Tribunal's knowledge, having viewed the program . . . it did not contain any X-rated material'.

—The other question that I put on notice concerned the number of complaints the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal received with regard to this program. I note the answer provided was 1,332 complaints. I assume that this program had a three-month run. Can the Minister advise me as to how long the program actually ran on television?

—I personally do not know. I did not actually see any of the programs that were broadcast. The officers have told me that they think Senator Chapman's guess that the series ran for three months is about right.

—Given that those 1,332 complaints, we assume, related to a program which ran for three months, the second part of the answer provided by the Tribunal indicates that for the 12-month period 1991-92 there were 7,407 complaints which, averaged over a three-month period, would be about 1,800 or so. Effectively, using that averaging which would be more or less accurate—it is obviously not 100 per cent accurate—the complaints in relation to this program equated to an average of more than two-thirds of the complaints received during that three-month period.

PARA.TAB: As I recall, during Estimates committee hearings the Tribunal acknowledged that the number of complaints received was extremely high and, in fact, the highest it had ever received. Yet, despite this record number of complaints which, as I said, we now find equates to more than two-thirds of the complaints which may have been received in a three-month period, the view of the Tribunal is still that the program did not sufficiently offend for any action to be taken on the part of the Tribunal or for it to regard any breach of standard to have taken place.

I find it quite incredible that, despite this massive number of complaints in absolute terms and a massive proportion of the total number of complaints, which clearly indicates a very high level of community concern about this program—and for any reasonable person I think it would not be unreasonable to reach the conclusion that it did breach accepted community standards on the basis of those complaints—no action was taken.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, it is such a subjective matter. I hear what Senator Chapman says and note it; he has expressed that view. Indeed, there were a very large number of complaints. Of course, the other side of the coin was that it was a provocative program. The program was designed to be provocative and stimulating, and as well as generating an enormous number of complaints it generated an enormous number of viewers. I simply put that in for balance.

PARA.TAB: One of the other reasons it generated a lot of complaints was that it also had very high ratings and many, many thousands of people, according to the ratings, were watching it. Senator Chapman was simply canvassing the facts, and I can do no more than agree with him on the facts: there were a lot of complaints.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another issue that was raised with the Tribunal was raised by Senator Harradine with regard to the length of time that members of the Tribunal have been on the ABT Board, their curriculum vitae, what family they have, the number of children they have, and so on. In the supplementary answers there is an attached response to those issues, which includes a partial CV of each member of the Tribunal. But I note the Acting Chairman, Mr Peter Webb, in his response to the Minister in the fourth paragraph, says:

SPEECH.PARA: As to the family details of Members, however, I take the view that it is inappropriate for Senator Harradine to be provided with such information.

Senator Harradine is not here this evening, and he has not raised this issue with me, but just having looked through that response I regard that as an unsatisfactory response. I believe a member of this Parliament, in the execution of his duties, has the right to be provided with that information if he regards the information as such that it is essential to the work which he is undertaking as a representative of the community and of his constituents.

PARA.TAB: I do not believe that the provision of the information requested by Senator Harradine is at all unduly intrusive with regard to the affairs of those individuals. Indeed, most curricula vitae published, whether published in the form of Who's Who or other suchlike biographies, generally have the family details of the individuals concerned. I think it was quite a reasonable request on the part of Senator Harradine, and I ask whether those details could be provided for him.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Chapman asked me a question, prior to being interrupted by the quorum call, and the answer is that Mr Webb, in the letter that accompanied the CVs, declined to provide the answer as to the number of children that each member of the Tribunal had. I personally know a number of members of the Tribunal who were on the Tribunal at that time and, indeed, know that they are parents, but Mr Webb in fact declined to provide that information—not the Government. I fully understand why he did: I am sure that it was the context in which that information was sought. I found it offensive, and I am sure that Mr Webb did also.

PARA.TAB: I think it is wrong to make value judgments about a person's capacity to be a fit member of a body rated by the number of children that that person has. I do find that offensive. Indeed, Senator Harradine, who asked the question, would have to concede that, if that was a standard that was applied fairly, then the Pope certainly and everyone of his clergy throughout the world, who, in my view, rightly and often express views on these subjects, would be struck in an instant and would not be qualified to express any view on these matters. As Senator Chapman and Senator Harradine know, the Catholic bishops of Australia, the Pope himself and many of the Catholic clergy in Australia, who are celibate, regularly and routinely and, indeed, topically at this moment, express many views, a lot of which I agree with, on this subject.

The assertion that only people who have children are capable of expressing an opinion, I do find offensive; and I reject it. I have to say that, if Senator Chapman has a look at the CVs that are provided for the people who did constitute the Tribunal at this time, he will see that they are people highly qualified to discharge this duty; and the question of how many children they have should be irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further matters on subprogram 2.7, the Committee will move to subprogram 3.2.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to refer to the questions on notice that I asked with regard to consultations between the Civil Aviation Authority and the Department regarding the use of the CAA tower in Alice Springs, which is now used for transmission services. I have received two very lengthy answers to a series of questions and, of course, the Minister would be well aware that this has been a saga that has now extended for some considerable period of time—in fact, a number of years. I think I started raising it 12 or 18 months ago in the Estimates committees, as a result of representations from the then Mayor of Alice Springs, Mrs Leslie Oldfield, who was extremely frustrated, as a member of the National Advisory Council of the ABC, at not being able to get the adequate and proper services that ought to have been extended to the Alice Springs community.

PARA.TAB: The lengthy answers that I received are very comprehensive but basically they come down to the line that there has been a degree of technical problem which has resulted in considerable delays in getting an interim solution. I received in my Canberra office yesterday a fax from the National Transmission Agency dated 9 November 1992. The General Manager of the NTA advised me that the proposal for a multichannel antenna mounted on the CAA tower has been approved, subject to its not imposing any restrictions on the CAA's use of the facility, and that the facility is currently scheduled for completion by August 1993 at the latest.

Firstly, given the qualification in that letter, that approval is subject to its not imposing any restrictions on the CAA's use of the facility, I would like to ascertain what may arise in regard to that qualification and whether we are going to see a continuation of the problems of the last couple of years in that regard. In the final paragraph of Mr Jones's letter of 9 November the statement is made that, in the meantime, FM transmissions of ABC Radio National commenced in Alice Springs on an interim basis on 28 September 1992 and the commercial radio station 8HA-8SUN also commenced interim transmissions on the same date. I would like to ascertain on what basis the interim transmissions will be continued and whether they are likely to be subject to any interruption, cancellation or interference.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question with respect to the CAA is simply one of potential radio interference. We all hope that that will not occur, but that reservation has to be made. I might add that these things are not unusual and routinely have to be sorted out. Indeed, the only remaining obstacle to the commencement of the SBS service in Darwin is negotiations over the location of the transmission tower. There is no question that the CAA was correct on this. At the original site it would have interfered with wet season landings at Darwin Airport. It would have required a very high percentage of the aircraft to use instruments to land, which would have delayed services at Darwin. On this occasion, it is a question of potential radio interference from the signals that are operating. In respect of the interim transmissions, I am advised that they will be allowed to continue until there is a permanent resolution of the transmission problem.
—If there is nothing further in relation to subprogram 3.2, we will go to subprogram 3.3.

—I asked a question on notice about the criteria for the installation of mobile phone base stations in regional areas. The answer I got explained amongst other things that remote areas are hardly the place for mobile phone cells. I was also told that, in considering the expansion of mobile phone coverage, each area is considered on its business merits. The major factors are population density, customer demand, volume of traffic and the cost to install the necessary base stations. I thought I would get a figure on what the population density has to be within the coverage area, what the volume of through traffic has to be, and an estimation of the cost to install the necessary base station to provide coverage in that area. I thought that if those three criteria were met, they would be justified in spending the money and providing the service.

—Because of the various disparities that exist in topography and so on, we can only give a ballpark figure. I am advised that, in rough terms, the population density, for an area to be able to be serviced by mobile phones, would be about 250,000 to 500,000 people. All of the other matters that Senator Panizza raised, about customer demand and so on, flow from that figure.

—On those figures, can I presume that a very productive and active town of 1,500 people, with a shire of 5,000, and a highly productive gold mine, will never be considered? How can Northam in Western Australia, with a town population—and this will have to be off the top of my head; it is on the board as you go into the town—of about 5,000 people and, say, 6,000 in the shire, have the service?

—I will correct the figure that I have just given Senator Panizza. The officer misunderstood the question that I asked and I misunderstood the reply. The figure that I just gave was in fact a dollar figure for the average cost of the installation of the service, and that is between $250,000 and $500,000. The officer has advised that, again in rough terms, the sort of town that would justify, commercially, such a service, would be a town about the size of Alice Springs—that is, about 25,000 people. In terms of these smaller centres, I have also been advised that, as the network is rolled out in a particular area, it is possible to pick up those smaller communities. The cost of the provision of the whole service to the area then becomes marginally, on a unit basis, cheaper. I also make the obvious point that this is a highly profitable and rapidly growing service. I would like to assure Senator Panizza that one does not need to give the slightest encouragement to the people fiercely competing for this business to provide the service, if there is a demand for it.

—I think there was a program started a couple of years ago to beam, if that is the right word for it, all of the major highways of Australia by the year 1993. Am I right in saying that there was such a program, and, if there was such a program, how is it going and are you continuing with it?

—I am advised that most of the major arterial routes in eastern Australia are effectively covered by transmissions. It is not commercially possible to extend that to the more sparsely populated areas of Australia, at the moment. It is essentially a commercial decision for the people who provide this service. As I said before, in the answer to the last question from Senator Panizza, if a commercial opportunity exists for the provision of these phones, they will soon be provided.

—That begs the next question. When the Minister says most of the major highways—and I think that was the term he used—of eastern Australia, can I ask why the major highways of Western Australia in the higher population areas are not covered by the same service?

—I am advised—and again this is consistent with the previous answers that I have provided—that in Western Australia those areas where there is a population density that justifies the provision of the service are covered. But I am also advised that this is likely to expand very rapidly indeed when the satellite delivered services that will be coming on-stream in the next few years become available. Indeed, it could well be that the provision of transponders placed on satellites for things like telephony is probably likely to be a lot more lucrative than, dare I say it, pay television.
—If there are no further matters in relation to subprograms 3.3 or 3.5, we will move to program 4, subprograms 4.1, 4.2 or 4.3.

—Senator Collins may be aware that I asked a question in Estimates about the alleged cheating regarding the sending of containers by underdeclaring the weights from one side of Australia to the other. I asked what percentage of containers between Sydney and Perth would be check weighed and the answer was that all containers which originate at Islington are weighed by AN. Most other interstate traffic is also weighed by the originating system. Only in Western Australia is a substantial proportion—70 per cent—of container traffic weighed when received from another system, that is, a destination.

PARA.TAB: The Minister told me that he was commencing an investigation into the matter of alleged cheating that I brought to the attention of the Estimates Committee. I wonder whether he has started an inquiry, and what does he know to date?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any detailed advice at this point to provide to Senator Panizza, but could I just say in a general sense that the point that was made at the time in Estimates, and the point that is made in the detailed answer that has been given to Senator Panizza and the subsequent advice I have received from officers, was that, when you consider the extent to which containers are check weighed, any widespread rorting of the system is highly unlikely. It would be detected very soon considering the very high percentage of containers that are check weighed.

PARA.TAB: Could I issue Senator Panizza with the same invitation, which was that we would find it extremely useful and helpful, if Senator Panizza does have actual indications of where this is occurring, if he could provide the information to me. I will ensure that the proper authorities carry out an investigation. But on all the evidence that is available to me and in consideration of the very high percentage of containers that are check weighed, I am advised that it is highly unlikely that any widespread abuse of this kind is occurring.

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly will take up that invitation of the Minister's in due course. I did have other papers that at this late hour of the night I cannot find in my office. For the present moment I would rather table them in this place than, say, give them to a Minister who is somewhere else at the present moment. He should know what I am referring to there.

PARA.TAB: One of the questions that I asked at the time was whether AN has received any complaints from road-hauling companies about underdeclaration of container weights. At least two road freight forwarders have told me—without naming them at this stage—that they have complained; but the answer was that AN advised that it has received no formal complaints of this kind. Therefore, I ask whether you have received any informal complaints.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think Senator Panizza should read into that statement something that is not there. I think that the answer is prudently drafted, the way that it is. There have been no formal complaints; and obviously, if people were seriously concerned about specific allegations, then those complaints would have been formalised in some way—either by insisting that the organisation have them noted, or by putting them in writing. The officers are not aware of any informal complaints, either; but I cannot take the information that I have provided already to Senator Panizza any further than that. The officers present are not personally aware of any informal complaints, and the information that has been provided to Senator Panizza indicates there have been no formal complaints.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Knowles) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering the estimates of the Department of Transport and Communications. We were on subprogram 4.3. Have we concluded?
—Before I finish off on 4.3, we slipped past 4.2 pretty quickly and if advisers are still here from 4.2—
—I am not quite sure if I slipped past it quickly, but we did get past it. We will go back to it if you want to, Senator Panizza.
—On the rail one, we will leap at the present moment and I will take up the offer of the Minister for—
—Hold on. It might be better if we finish 4.3 before we go back to 4.2. Had you finished 4.3?
—Yes, I have no more questions on 4.3.
—All right. In that case, we will go back to 4.2.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I had a question on notice asking why the estimate for expenditure on the road safety improvement package increased by 110 per cent, and I have got the answer. The answer included the fact that the Federal Government allocated an additional $70m to the Federal blackspot program in its February 1992 One Nation package. An amount of $25m was expended in 1991-92 and $60m is in the 1992 Budget. What is the progress of spending of that $70m in this blackspot program, and what increase has there been in employment due to that program?

—To this point the spending of all of that $70m funding has been approved, with the exception of $2.3m in Tasmania and part programs of Queensland and Western Australia amounting to $3.4m. The Tasmanian and the balance of the Queensland programs were received in the last week. I dare say that approval is not far way for that. Could I say at this juncture that I join the Minister for Land Transport (Mr Robert Brown) in congratulating the Government of the Northern Territory in being able to spend this money faster than any other government in Australia.
—Did it go on roads?
—How dare the honourable senator suggest that Mr Fred Finch would not have spent it on roads!

—I did hear the Minister say that the whole of that $70m, or whatever it was, had been allocated, but `allocated' and `spent' do not have quite the same meaning. The idea of allocating it was not only to cut down the number of blackspots but to improve blackspots. To my knowledge this year—speaking for Western Australia, anyhow—there have been a record number of fatal accidents to date. I was wondering not only whether it has been allocated but whether it has been spent and how many jobs have been created. The idea in the One Nation package was to create extra jobs, and I would like to know whether extra jobs were created for the unemployed or whether the money merely went to contractors that had people employed anyhow.
—In rough terms, about 25 jobs are created for every million dollars that is expended on road construction.

—I recognise that the Minister said that the money has all been allocated but, as I said, `allocated' is different to `spent'—actually being on the road. He did say that the Northern Territory Government has spent all of its allocation, presumably on roads. I believe the Northern Territory Government is the most efficient maker of roads. We were told when we were up there that the Northern Territory is 35 per cent more efficient than any other State. I would like to know how much has been expended on roads, as against how much has been allocated.

—I have just mentioned the Northern Territory, but the officers who are present have indicated that Victoria and South Australia have actually expended in excess of 90 per cent of the money that has been allocated to them for 1991-92. We do not have any further detailed information on what has been expended elsewhere, but we can obtain that information for Senator Panizza.
—(3.07 a.m.)—What was the formula used for the allocation of the moneys for the various States and Territories?

—(3.08 a.m.)—I am advised that it was a combination of using a basic road funding formula that is used in regular consultations with the States and using the road safety records of the States, particularly in respect to things such as the black spot program—that is, particular roads that have high levels of fatalities and accidents. The third component, as is always the case with these allocations, was extensive consultation with the relevant State governments.
—So it was not simply on a per capita basis? That was not the formula?
—No.

—There being no further matters, that concludes the examination of the estimates for the Department of Transport and Communications. We will move to the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. (Quorum formed) The best way to go with the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories is to do as we did with other departments and go according to the running sheet. I notice that in this running sheet there are several matters listed before program 1. We will deal with those matters now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to raise a few general matters relating to the report—in particular, the question of witnesses appearing before the Committee. Although it is not listed on the running sheet, it is a matter raised in the Committee's report. I understand that we are entitled to discuss here questions raised in the Committee's report. I particularly want to express my concern about the manner in which the Senate treats its departmental and agency witnesses. It is totally unsatisfactory. Tonight is a classic example of a degree of arrogance in the way the Senate has determined, on the vote of the Democrats with the Labor Party, to keep members of the Public Service here for hours like this. It matches the arrogance the Senate shows to witnesses by having them attend Estimates committees at all sorts of ludicrous hours of the night and having them sit around for hours awaiting their call. Officers from this Department have been here tonight, for example, since 9 o'clock.

PARA.TAB: If the Government, which has the support of the Democrats in determining this ludicrous behaviour, cannot determine to deal with its employees—many of them highly paid and highly skilled—in a better way, the Government should examine its own absolute incompetence in this matter. I suggest that it would be much more rational in the operation of Estimates committees to set specific appointment times for particular departments or agencies and, if the end of that appointment period—be it a two-hour period, for example—is reached without the matter having been finalised, then set another appointment date and time.

That would be a reasonable procedure for those departmental officers who are resident in Canberra, rather than the sort of arrogance displayed by the Government here tonight in keeping these people here and the sort of arrogance displayed by the chairmen of Estimates committees in keeping public servants waiting until ludicrous hours of the night in Estimates committees, when a simple mechanical procedure involving set times for dealing with people—if the time is run over, then another appointment is set—seems such a simple thing to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —The most effective and simple mechanical procedure to shorten Estimates committees would be to guillotine Senator Bishop.

—I find that interjection not only offensive but as irrational as I would expect at a quarter past three in the morning from someone who is under heavy pressure. That is the problem: people are likely to say and do particularly stupid things at this hour of the morning.
—Why don't you get on with the Estimates, Senator Baume?
—Order! Senator Baume has the call and I would ask honourable senators on my right to allow him to make his presentation.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I must say that I am also disturbed by what appears to be some lack of communication at times between the Estimates committees and the departments. Interstate officers from this Department were called unnecessarily to Canberra, at a direct cost in terms of transport of something like $5,000 on one day, when it was clear that there was no prospect whatsoever of their being called as witnesses. It is simply not acceptable.
—Not true.
—The interjection is that it is not true.
—As the secretary of the Committee explained to you.
—I will again ask honourable senators on my right to allow Senator Baume to proceed. Senator Baume, if there are interjections, you could try to ignore them.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. The letter from Mr Blunn, the Secretary, says:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Department was advised that attendance at the previous hearing would not be required on Tuesday 15 September, only at about 9.45 p.m. on that day. At that time my officers were informed that it had been decided the portfolio would not be examined.

That is okay, but the key point was that, as I understand it, the officers of the Department had only been given an indication that they may well not be called, not that they would not be called. I will read it exactly as it is:
Earlier that day—
said Mr Blunn—

a member of the Committee Secretariat had in conversation expressed the view that it was extremely unlikely that the portfolio would be reached, a suspicion we had previously reached, but could not of course commit the Committee.

It just seems to be a ridiculous waste of money. It was evident earlier in the day that there would be no need. We just have to firm this sort of thing up. We have to be much more practical, coherent and rational—which, as I said, it is a bit hard to be at this hour of the morning—about the way we behave with our senior bureaucrats. If one had the choice of deciding how many hours a senior bureaucrat would be in active employment, one would not propose that it was a good idea to have him from 9 o'clock, for example, tonight until quarter past three this morning sitting outside, waiting on the Senate's pleasure. I find the whole thing absolutely abhorrent and I think we do not do ourselves any good by taking that approach.

PARA.TAB: The other thing I wanted to say was that in the general report there was a matter relating to the presentation of information. I am glad to hear the departmental Secretary's response: he agreed with the points I was making about the unexplained changes in many of the figures presented to us.

The Secretary undertook to raise this issue with the Department of Finance which is responsible for the guidelines governing the content of program performance statements. Has any result emerged from that? I am grateful for some of the responses that I have had from various sections and authorities within the Department about what the figures really mean.

For example, I am interested to see that out of the $60m-odd that the Australia Council gets, only something like $48.3m actually ends up going to arts organisations or arts people. For many of those organisations the creation of new funding mechanisms like creative fellowships has in effect meant—and perhaps the Minister could establish whether this is so or not—a reduction in the amount of grant money available to the traditional recipients of those grants. That is simply an eyeballing situation; it may well not be true, but that is what it seems from the break-up of these figures that I now have. I might leave it there at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am advised that the fellowships were in fact new money and that this did not result in any reductions in grants. Briefly, in response to the earlier points made by Senator Baume, there is no senator in this chamber keener than I am to ensure a more efficient operation of Senate Estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: I still recall with horror my first experience of them in the old Parliament House, with the rafts of public servants that Senator Baume referred to pacing the corridors in the early hours of the morning. I am going back six years now to what occurred in the old Parliament House. I can still recall my horror, at the very first Estimates committee I ever attended, that four officers from a small government department who had been waiting on our attendance since 2 o'clock in the afternoon finally appeared before the Estimates committee that I sat on for the very first time at 11 o'clock that night and were asked no questions.

I simply make that point to assert, as Senator Baume knows full well, that the difficulty of having bureaucrats, very senior and experienced officers, here in large numbers until all hours of the morning is not a unique thing that has happened as a result of any activity of this Government. It has been a feature of Estimates committees for as long as they have operated in the Senate.

I think Senator Baume would acknowledge that things are one hell of a lot better than they used to be. Senate officers do try very hard indeed to balance the convenience of witnesses against the legitimate requirement of senators to have them present because, again, I have been Minister at the table when this has happened. Senate officers cannot make firm statements like, `This will not be dealt with tonight'. They can only make guesstimates as to how things are going during the day.

As Senator Baume again knows, at times it is very difficult to predict, when things seem to be going very well, whether one will suddenly get someone with a particular interest in the subject that locks the thing up for two hours on one particular item. Indeed, the correspondence Senator Baume quoted from is correct.

The secretary of that Committee, an experienced Senate officer I must say, did his best to juggle those demands. But when people are sent home and told they are not required and we then move faster than we thought we might and he needs them, he then gets vociferous complaints from senators that the officers are not in attendance; and I have had both. So it is just a question of trying to balance the procedure. I conclude by saying that Senator Baume also knows full well the expeditious procedure of Senate committees is not something in the hands of the Government; it is a collective responsibility of all senators who are part of the process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I simply remind him of the fact that the Government, with the Democrats, has a majority in making decisions about how things are done. The decisions that are made in some instances are damned silly. This is one of them. The way things are conducted at the moment is just simply unsustainable and unreasonable. Having us here at this hour of the morning is unsustainable and unreasonable. Using interstate officers as the flexible group who may or may not be reached on one night is absolutely absurd when there are local officers who could, in fact, much more reasonably occupy that short call position. It is just nonsense for the Minister to throw up his arms and say, `Look, I think it is terrible. I am terribly concerned but I have done nothing to fix it'. That is my concern, Minister.

PARA.TAB: I had asked whether the Secretary of the Department had yet had the opportunity to raise with the Department of Finance these guidelines and whether in fact any progress had been made on improving the quality of the figures that we are getting, particularly as I noted that in many instances it seemed that administrative expenses were being included in the program grants, which boosts the appearance of grants to organisations and diminishes the appearance of administrative costs. I must say I found that totally unacceptable.
