I was interested to see, when I got the actual figures from the Australia Council, that, for example, $800,000 was effectively the administrative cost of peer assessment, and that had previously been included in grants to arts organisations. In sports, there has been a significant moving around of program costs with the Australian Sports Commission. In that case the Commission was saying that the administrative costs were being overstated because of the requirements of the Finance Department. I hope that, whatever negotiations have taken place with the Department of Finance, we are going to get more coherent, rational and better informed documents, or documents that present the position much more accurately than they have in the past, using clear criteria about what is administrative cost and what is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am advised by the Secretary that those consultations have indeed occurred and that the necessary amendments can and will be made.
—I thank the Minister for that, and I thank the Department and the Secretary in particular for taking action on that matter.
—We will move to program 1 and consider subprogram 1.2—Arts.

—In the Senate Estimates Committee I failed to deal effectively, because I did not know what the facts were, with the national performing arts touring program. This matter concerns me a little. There had been many rumours and even scuttlebutt around the place that this proposed national arts tour program was going to end up under the chairmanship of Mr Simon Dawkins, as indeed it did. The point made strongly to me by some arts organisations was that a separate bureaucracy appears now to be in the process of being established under this new chairmanship of Mr Dawkins, who I understand provided the basic input to the report from the Australian Performing Arts Centres Association, which had provided the strongest pressure for creating this organisation.

PARA.TAB: It has been put to me—I would like the Minister to assist me on this—that the split-up of the $2m in funds in the current financial year is to be $1m to the Arts Council of Australia and APACA; $500,000 split between the Opera, the Australian Chamber Orchestra and the Australian Ballet; and $500,000 on new or other work. The program is administered by the committee set up by the Minister but run by DASET, specifically the arts branch. I wondered to what extent the creation of this committee would involve a set of expenses; what those expenses would be; whether there would be any additional bureaucracy apart from the expenses of having the committee involved; and to what extent it would diminish the amount of money available for distribution to the arts.

Also, is this a way of providing additional funding to APACA and the Arts Council of Australia so that it, rather than the Department itself, will then have greater powers of determining the touring? For example, is there any way to ensure that this money will go entirely to touring and not to assisting any proposal to build a $12m headquarters in Barton called Arts House? No matter what the merits of it are, and I am not going to enter into those now, I want to make certain there will be no administrative costs being creamed off the $1m which I am told is to go to the Arts Council of Australia and APACA.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that none of this money will be spent on such a project; that all of it will be spent on touring; that the committee that is being set up to include membership from the Commonwealth, the States, the Australia Council and so on, has a small secretariat; and that, out of the $2m, the administrative costs are $200,000 and $1.8m will be spent on the programs themselves.

—I thank the Minister. I would now like to deal very briefly with Arts Action. In the printed response to my question about whether or not Australia Council funds were involved in Arts Action's project for printing 20,000 postcards for delivery to Parliament House, the reply was that Arts Action uses some of the funds provided to it by the Australia Council for the National Arts Week national promotional campaign. I wonder whether the Government is content with the use of arts money in that way and whether it intends to provide funding for that kind of purpose. I understand that Arts Action's funding has been reduced, in the sense that it is no longer going to be running the particular program called Arts Week. I wonder whether any of the funding that is going to Arts Action this year—I understand there is going to be some funding—will be used for that kind of purpose and whether the Government is content that it should be.

—I am advised that the 1993 funding has not yet been announced. I am also advised that, as I am sure Senator Baume knows, this organisation is funded and controlled by the Australia Council, which is at arm's length from the Government. Frankly, I think Senator Baume would be far more aware of its activities than I am. I had a discussion about the organisation this morning and, for the first time, found out what it did. I know that it does involve a number of prominent Australians, whose names were mentioned to me this morning, who are actively engaged in the role of promoting the arts in Australia in a positive advocacy sense or lobbying sense, and that it does an effective job of that. I presume that the postcards delivered to Parliament House were advocating the cause of the arts to politicians. I assume that is the case. The fundamental point I am making is that this is an agency that is controlled by the Australia Council, which monitors and takes care of its operations.
—If there is nothing further on subprogram 1.2, we will move to subprogram 1.4.

—The National Australia Day Council has been going through a period of some disarray. The Government has taken an extraordinarily long time to replace its Chairman. Last week or the week before, Mr Phillip Adams was appointed Chairman of the National Australia Day Council. A new Council has also been appointed, including Merv Nixon, who used to run the South Coast Labor Council in Wollongong and with whom I have had many a stoush in the past. I have no comment on the merits or otherwise of Mr Nixon or on whether or not he is a supporter of the concept of Australia Day, but I am very concerned to see—as I understand it—that not one of the chairpersons of the State Australia Day councils is represented on the National Australia Day Council.

PARA.TAB: Last year we had a total breakdown of communications between the State organisations—which actually do the work and try to make Australia Day worth while in each State—and the Federal organisation, involving a series of particularly unpleasant letters from the national body to at least one of the State bodies. If there is any need for reconciliation, it is in this area. The National Australia Day Council has the job of selecting the Australian of the Year, the Young Australian of the Year and the Australian Achiever Awards for Australia Day over the next two years. I am not overwhelmed with the composition of this Council. There may be some very good people in it, but I had hoped that these appointments would have been aimed at trying to resolve what has been a difficult problem. I have been concerned about the nature of correspondence that has been sent to the ACT from the Australia Day Council. I wonder what the policy is. Is it not to have State chairmen on it, or are there some State chairmen on this Council?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that there are State chairmen on it. The chairs of the South Australian and Western Australian councils are on the Council. I am further advised that two other State chairs were offered places on the Council but declined them, so potentially four chairs were offered positions. Two accepted and two did not. But I am further advised—and I think Senator Baume would probably agree with this—that a deliberate decision was taken that the national body would simply not be a compilation or reflection of the State bodies, but would have some new blood. I have personally spoken to Phillip Adams about his role in this body and I commend the amount of effort that he is putting into it. He is personally committed to the job. He has a reputation for giving 100 per cent to everything he does. He must have been chairman of almost everything in Australia by now. He did say to me that he is determined to revitalise the organisation. I can do no more than wish him well in the task.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Knowles) put:
That progress be reported.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just raised the matter of the Australia Day Council. There is concern on this side of the chamber about the Government's attitude to the Australia Day Council and to the concept of Australia Day. There seems to be a growing preparedness to treat Australia Day as some kind of embarrassment about which we should feel some guilt because the colonisation of this nation resulted in the dispossession of the land from the Aboriginal people.

PARA.TAB: I am not one of those of the view that that should diminish our preparedness to celebrate our national day and our proudness of that national day as citizens of Australia. I got very little comfort from the fact that the Australian Government took so lightly the membership and chairmanship of the National Australia Day Council and that that position remained vacant from February until this appointment was made just the other day in November. It does not seem to suggest that the Government takes this organisation or, in fact, Australia Day, very seriously.

I am under the impression that at least one of the people who chose not to take up an offer of membership was concerned about what I am certain he felt to be the lack of commitment by the Government to the concept of Australia Day. Looking at the members of the Council, I do not know the extent of their commitment to and strength of support for celebrating Australia Day as I would hope that we as Australians would.

I noticed in Senate Estimates Committee D that Mr Dempster from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories said that he believed the major celebrations next year would be on 26 January rather than on the Monday of the long weekend. I hope we develop that system of celebrating Australia Day on 26 January, the day chosen to be Australia Day.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be brief. I strongly support the celebration of Australia Day and, to the best of my knowledge, so does all of the Government. I do believe I am correct in saying that the Northern Territory was the first political entity in Australia to insist on the day being celebrated on the day, rather than over a weekend. That was strongly supported by me as the then Leader of the Opposition. I conclude by saying that there is another day that I am also very keen to celebrate, and that is Christmas Day, and I do hope that I am there to do it.

—I rise to support the remarks of my colleague Senator Baume. I must confess to the Minister for Transport and Communications that I was a little surprised at the appointment of Phillip Adams. There are aspects of Phillip Adams's work which I admire and enjoy. But I think I am right in saying, and correct me if I am wrong, that the chairmanship of Australia Day generally involves people who are comfortable with our national symbols, our history and the institutions of this country. I would like to feel that this Committee will not be in any way down-playing national symbols and the institutions which have brought Australia to where it is today. I think it would be a great pity.

PARA.TAB: We have had a recent attempt by Mr Keating to divide Australia on the issues of national symbols. I think the Minister would agree that, as the election approaches, Labor Party polling has shown that Mr Keating's attempting to change the flag has been decisively rejected by the people. I would like the Minister to give us an assurance, but I do not know whether he is in a position to do that. I am not quite sure what the relationship of the Government is to the National Australia Day Council. I would like to hear a very clear statement from the Minister indicating that he would expect the Committee to show the great enthusiasm that the vast majority of Australians have for their national symbols and to perhaps quell any fears that some might have that this may well be yet another attempt by the Government to bring in a new agenda.

TALK.START.PARA: —To be perfectly frank, I am not particularly interested in pursuing at any length this very interesting philosophical matter on Senate Estimates committees at 4 o'clock in the morning. I am sorry that Senator Kemp is surprised at the appointment of Phillip Adams. I am interested to hear that there are some things that Phillip Adams does that Senator Kemp admires and supports. I am sure that, if he provides Mr Adams with details of what they are, he will probably agree to cease them immediately.

PARA.TAB: The one thing that I can say about Phillip Adams, and it would be supported by everybody who knows him, is that he gives 150 per cent to everything he does. I can only repeat—and I am sorry that Senator Kemp was not here to hear it—what I said in an earlier response to a question from Senator Baume; that is, I have personally spoken to Phillip Adams about this new role and he is strongly committed to revitalising and energising in the best possible way he can the activities of the Committee to promote our national day. Again, I wish him well in his endeavours. (Quorum formed)
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—We will move to program 4, subprogram 4.2, facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, a fair proportion of the facilities program—a program which, by the way, is listed under sport—goes on items or projects that are not in fact sporting. I did actually get a response on this matter, which I just cannot put my hands on, but I understand that something like $2.5m is involved in this program on non-sporting matters. As this program is done entirely out of the Minister's office rather than through the Institute of Sport or, as I understand it, through the Department—and it is certainly not done through the national sporting bodies—I wonder whether the Minister gets advice from any other departments relating to the non-sporting element of this program.

—I am advised at this point that the decision was taken to expand the ambit of the program to include the facilities that Senator Baume has referred to, although in some cases, I am advised, they are in fact joint use facilities—they are used for cultural and sporting purposes. The amount of money is quite small, around $2.5m, and for administrative convenience or efficiency it was decided, because it is such a small amount of the total that is spent, to retain it within this general facility rather than set up a separate structure. I am also advised that consultations on the provision of these grants are held with State governments and local governments on occasions as well.

—I thank the Minister for that information. I imagine that when the Minister says consultations have taken place these would be in addition to the requests and recommendations made by local government and State governments to the Minister's office for particular projects. The reason I make that point is that I would imagine it would be natural for local government and State governments to support the proposition that they should get a slice of this $10m being made available through the Minister's office.

PARA.TAB: The provision of sporting facilities based on criteria which are not necessarily those of the sporting organisations—the national sporting bodies, for example—may well mean that sporting facilities and other facilities are located in places based on criteria other than sporting criteria. If decisions are taken in conjunction with State governments and local governments, is there any consultation with national or State sporting organisations in determining these grants?

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that is not the case. From my own personal knowledge of where some of this money has been spent, I do not think that these would necessarily be the most appropriate bodies to provide particularly useful advice about the expenditure of these relatively small sums spread out across Australia. I have certainly made routine personal representations, as I think most members of parliament have, for certain things. Particularly in the Northern Territory with our very bad incidence of skin cancers, I know that shades are often sought after for swimming pools and so on. I have to say my own hit rate has not been all that brilliant in terms of actually securing the wish lists that I put in.

PARA.TAB: Quite often I think local government in particular is probably more tuned in to the needs of scouting organisations, swimming clubs and so on in local areas than a national peak body necessarily would be. This list might be useful for senators and it will take me less than a minute to read it out. These are the guidelines for the program in terms of the priorities indicated: residents in new suburban areas, residents in inner urban areas, youth in rural areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, communities with high unemployment and communities with migrant populations. These are some of the criteria that are used to determine where the money is allocated.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will move to subprogram 4.3, Australian Sports Commission, and the employment of coaches by the AIS.

—As I recall, in the report itself we got a fair amount about coaching, and there were concerns expressed by several coaches about payment and other matters in the Estimate Committee hearings. A suggestion was made that one of these coaches, a Mr Arnold, was receiving some benefit from the Queensland Sports Institute. Mr Arnold has written to me, having seen the Senate Estimates Hansard, and has told me that he was not in receipt of such funding. I just put that on the record.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crowley)—We will move to subprogram 4.4, Australian Sports Drug Agency.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Customs Service recently prepared a report, which thus far has not been released, which demonstrated a growing increase in illicit importation of anabolic steroids. In fact there were a number of occasions where human growth hormones were found on ex-athletes coming into Australia. Can the Minister tell me what steps are being taken to monitor whether it is a problem, because to my knowledge there is no clear way of identifying this with normal testing of human growth hormones.

—I am advised that Senator Crichton-Browne's information is correct and that at this time arrangements are being made for a meeting of all of the relevant Commonwealth agencies to discuss how best this problem can be addressed.

—Thank you. I trust I am not jumping ahead of events, but is the Minister able to advise me whether or not the Customs Service has learned that there is in fact a dedicated process in Australia for the distribution and direction of anabolic steroids towards young people?

—My advice is that there is a general awareness in the agency that there is some distribution network at work, but at this point there is no detail available about that. As I said before, currently a meeting is being organised among all relevant Commonwealth agencies to discuss how best this problem can be attacked.

—An article written by Madonna King in the Courier-Mail suggested that there was a sophisticated and organised network in Australia of drug distribution and a whole range of other illegal activities amongst young people. What knowledge does the Government have of that, and what has been done about it?

—I am advised that in fact the author of that article is being followed up in the inquiries that are currently being made about this matter. She is involved in the investigation and plans that are currently being made to address the problem.

—At the risk of being persistent, is the article in a general sense correct when it talks about the report of the Customs Service on the storage industry being riddled with other crimes like bashings, standover tactics, break-ins, armed hold-ups and weapons offences? I am quoting Madonna King.

—I simply have to repeat the information that I gave before: the authorities at this point in time do not have any hard evidence. They know in a general sense about these allegations but they do not have any hard evidence about those allegations. But I am advised that the author of this article is involved in the investigations that the agencies are currently conducting.

—Following the recent Olympic Games, is the Minister in a position to tell me whether or not the Australian Sports Commission has reviewed its position on athletes being trained in Canberra and on providing facilities for the various institutes outside Canberra in the various agencies in the various capitals?

—I am advised that that is a matter that is constantly kept under review and discussion in a cooperative way between the organisation and the relevant State bodies and that it is a cooperative arrangement between the various State sporting authorities and the Institute here in Canberra.
—When I came back into the chamber I was told that we were on program 4.4.

—Perhaps I could assist in that matter. The Temporary Chairman read the next point under 4.3—we had only dealt with coaches—and mistakenly, I believe, took the view that testing for drug use in sport, the second item under subprogram 4.3., was the Sports Drug Agency matter.
—I was told that we were on 4.4. I saw Senator Crichton-Browne turn the page and I wondered whether we had finished with 4.3.

—There is a whole series of reservations under 4.3, such as the growth of the AIS bureaucracy and so on. The previous occupant of the Chair had not, in fact, gone through all of those. I must say, I was confused. I thought she was talking about the second reservation when she was referring to the Sports Drug Agency.
—If they are all listed under 4.3, they may be taken in any order.
—I see.
—Is there anything further under 4.3?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am grateful for the explanation given by the Australian Sports Commission about the extent to which its funds are in fact allocated directly to sport. As I mentioned in my general concerns about the figures available to the Estimates Committee, it was difficult to establish exactly how much of the Sports Commission's funds did in fact go to sport.

PARA.TAB: The written reply is that 69.8 per cent of ASC funds are allocated directly to sport and other funding which is totally sport based, and goes indirectly to sports such as Aussie Sports, Women in Sport, Aussie Able, Athletes Support, Australian Coaching House and National Sports Information Centre. The reply indicates that 22.2 per cent of Sports Commission funding is allocated indirectly to sport and the balance of funding—8 per cent—is allocated to the administration of Commission programs and so on. It would be useful if that sort of information did not actually have to be asked for in future. I think it is important information and should be available in the appropriate documents.

I also wanted to mention that the name I gave the Minister earlier about the gentleman who said he had not received funding from the Queensland Academy of Sport was Mr Ian Finlay. I beg his pardon—I did not have the document in front of me.

TALK.START.PARA: —The other one didn't ring a bell.

—No, I am sorry. I remembered the Ian bit and made a mistake, but I now I want to correct that error. The other matter I want to raise relating to the Institute of Sport is that over the last two years there has been a considerable increase in administration. The Australian Sports Commission staff numbers have increased from 167.1 to 234. Once again, I thank the Sports Commission for breaking up for me where this additional staff has gone.

PARA.TAB: I must say it does cheer me up a little, in a sense, to see a recognition that there has been an increase in staff. This administrative staff does not include coaching staff. As I understand it from the response, this does not in any way involve an increase in coaching staff. It does underline the fact that not all the people at the Institute of Sport are in fact directly involved in sport. Even though it may be unpleasant and uncomfortable to contemplate some administrative efficiencies, it does appear to be possible—as I had originally suggested—to cut funding without in fact cutting grants to sport.

Of course, this was proposed as part of the Fightback package. The intention was clearly stated that there would be no reductions whatsoever in total funding to sporting organisations. I am grateful for the response, which clearly indicates that that objective can very easily be reached.

I thank the Department for a response to a question I asked about the number of people—Government officials, the Minister and so on—at the Barcelona Games who were not members of the Australian team but were funded by the Government. I should outline that response to the chamber. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: A total of approximately $100,000 will be met by the Commonwealth for the attendance at the Barcelona Olympic Games of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, her husband, a member of her staff, the Secretary of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, his wife and the Executive Director of the Australian Sports Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the shadow Minister?

—The shadow Minister regrettably did not get invited. But according to this reply, those six people ended up costing about $100,000. I raise that question only because an athlete at the Games had asked me to do so and I feel I should place that on the record.
—Are there any further matters in relation to 4.3? If there are not, we will go to 4.4. Are there any matters in relation to 4.4?

—At the Estimates Committee hearing I drew attention to the potential for duplication of bureaucracies in this area. I also raised questions about the lack of protection against legal action. I must say that I still feel concerned that there is a real risk in respect of various arms of the Department having an involvement in the drugs matter. The three arms are the Department itself, the Australian Sports Commission and the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I believe that there is a need to ensure that there are no overlaps. I just make that brief point.

PARA.TAB: I now want to deal with the question of the exposed position that sporting organisations are left in by the Government when they implement governmental policy and suffer the risk of legal action as a result. I raised this in Senate Estimates. As I recall it, I provided to the Department a letter, which officers had not seen, from the Director of the Office of Legal Aid and Family Services to Mr Sumner of the cycling association, in which he knocked back the request for legal aid. I was under the impression that, when I asked whether anything could be done about this, Mr Blunn, the Secretary, was going to have a look at it. I just wondered whether he had had the opportunity to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have been given is that the letter was located and that the gentleman that Senator Baume has referred to was connected with the New South Wales League of Wheelmen, which was not party to the action and therefore was not entitled to legal aid.

—I thank the Minister for that. As I understand it, that issue was not raised in the letter, but does that mean that the Department is still of the view that sporting organisations should rely entirely on their capacity to gain legal aid to protect them? The reason I ask the question is that their concerns about this matter have encouraged them in some instances to go into settlements which were totally unacceptable, I think, and which the Sports Drug Agency itself finds totally unacceptable. It has encouraged them to fail to make an appearance in a recent court action in which a drug taker was allowed—
—A drug cheat.

—I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. A drug cheat was allowed, as a result of court action, to get back on the circuit and the judge said that, had the cycling association been present at the hearing—in other words, if it had been able to afford to be there—
—Had he been presented with arguments.

—Yes; had he been presented with arguments, which quite frankly the association could not afford to present, as I understand it from the association—it might have been the League of New South Wales Wheelmen but I cannot remember which one it was—he may well have come to a different conclusion.

PARA.TAB: I thank the Department for it but, despite that technical situation that emerged—that, because the association was not party to this, it was not entitled to legal aid—I must say that I am surprised that the matter should be let rest there. As I recall it, the League of Wheelmen is either the same as or similar to the professional cyclists association or is a constituent member of the Federal body. I thought the New South Wales League of Wheelmen was the New South Wales structure of the federal body and that there was disagreement about which one of them had the right to either endorse or throw out the person.

I do not feel that it detracts from the general point: is the Government happy to leave it rest in a situation where sporting organisations run the risk of being bankrupted as a result of legal actions when they implement government policy that results in action being taken against them by a sportsman? Martin Vinnicombe, for example, has already cost the Australian Sports Drug Agency about $73,000 in legal expenses. Provision is made, on current estimates, for another $240,000. That should be going to decent sports people, rather than to fight legal action against a self-confessed drug cheat. If the paralympic people, the disabled sports people, could get $240,000 they would be very happy indeed.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 12 scholarships.

—Yes. I mention the Australian Sports Drug Agency to dramatise the massive costs that people can become involved in. If the Government is fair dinkum about wanting sporting organisations to implement Federal Government anti-drug policy, it should back them up in any legal problems they have, rather than leaving them exposed to the vagaries of legal aid.

—I am advised that the processes of obtaining legal aid have to be followed and that, if it appears that the processes that are followed are not sufficient to address the problem of drugs, then action will be taken. But it has also been pointed out to me that one can hardly qualify for legal aid if one is not a party to the action that is being heard in the court. Senator Baume raised the Vinnicombe case. I have been advised that the Australian Professional Cycling Council did receive legal aid in respect of the Vinnicombe case.
—What is the status of clembutorol in respect of the banned substances list?
—I am advised that it is on the IOC list and, therefore, it is a banned drug.

—In that case, do I take it that, as Mr Quigley—who was recently tested positive for clembutorol as an Australian athlete and who was also subsequently found to have human growth hormones in his possession in a fridge in his home—claims that clembutorol is not a proscribed drug, athletes in Australia will not be able to argue that it is not on the proscribed list and, therefore, they do not have a defence against his claim?

—I am advised that the case mentioned by Senator Crichton-Browne is still under investigation and that, at the time that claim was made, this particular substance was not a proscribed substance but that it now is.

—That really does get to the heart of the difficulties of these matters. I do not want to get into unnecessary technicalities at 4.40 a.m. but some will argue that clembutorol is a substance used by asthmatics. Interestingly, people like Mr Quigley never used it as a spray; they used it in pill form. Can I have an assurance that in the event that Mr Quigley, if I have the name correct, takes Athletics Australia to court, that Athletics Australia will not find itself in the same situation as a number of other sporting bodies? It cannot afford to run the risk of defending the action for the sheer sake of cost.

—I am advised that the matter referred to by Senator Crichton-Browne is complex and detailed. There was a question, apparently, as to whether the substance was covered, although the substance itself was not specifically proscribed; but it was covered in a general class of steroids. I am also advised by officers that there will be no difficulty at all in providing Senator Crichton-Browne with a detailed briefing on this matter should he wish to have one.

—I am very grateful for that answer, but I am more concerned that there is a defence for an action which may be instigated by Mr Quigley, that clembutorol was not a proscribed substance at the time that he was detected positive with both an A and B sample.

—I am advised that indeed the opportunity is available for an application in this case to be made for legal aid, but it is then a case as to whether under the criteria for legal aid they would qualify for it. But the opportunity is there to apply for it.

—I do not want to labour this point. Only the least subtle would miss the point that has been made that athletes such as Krabbe from the previous East German Federation who have claimed a defence on the basis that at the time it was not a proscribed drug would recognise that it is being mounted as a defence.

PARA.TAB: What disturbs me is that sporting organisations might have to fulfil criteria before they can seek legal aid. It is hardly an incentive for not only amateur organisations but also professional organisations to contest legal actions by athletes who are financially well-equipped, if the criteria for legal aid is the normal criteria, that they have to, by definition, demonstrate they do not have funding or a capacity to defend the action before they are able to fulfil the criteria.

While clembutorol is recognised now as having a capacity to enhance one's anabolic performance, and while in the past it has been recognised as a stimulant, it simply means that these organisations will not, frankly, confront the Martin Vinnicombes of this world who have hundreds of thousands of dollars at their disposal to contest these court cases. At what point is the Government prepared to stand by its in principle criteria?

TALK.START.PARA: —We have provided Senator Crichton-Browne with detail as to the complexity of this particular case and I have given him an indication of the complex legal arguments that are involved in it. In view of the fact that the investigation of this particular case is still continuing and that I have provided to Senator Crichton-Browne detail on the availability of legal aid, I cannot add any more information to the question Senator Crichton-Browne has asked, except to reiterate the point that he himself has made—that this is a very complex issue and that a detailed briefing on these issues is readily available to him, should he wish it, from officers.
—I do not propose to pursue it, other than to ask: what is the in-principle position of the Government in respect to these matters?

—I have stated it three times, but I will state it again. We believe that the processes which are involved in obtaining legal aid in this country and which have been successfully pursued by sporting bodies—indeed, legal aid, as I have just mentioned, in one particular case has been granted—are satisfactory. If it is demonstrated that these processes are not adequate in terms of combating the drug problem, the Government will review this and consider what other action is necessary. At this point in time we believe that access to legal aid—and complying with the criteria that govern that—has proven to be satisfactory.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Senator Crichton-Browne) proposed:
That progress be reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be agreed to. Those of that opinion say aye; to the contrary no. I think the noes have it. A division is required. Ring the bells.
—On a point of order, Mr Chairman: you cannot call a division unless there are two voices and there was only one.

—I called that the noes have it, so if anybody wants a division those who said yes should ask for the division. It was not for the noes to ask for a division, and there were certainly more than two who said yes. A division is required. Ring the bells.

PARA.TAB: Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, pursuant to the notice of motion standing in my name, I seek to suspend Standing Orders in order that I might move a motion that the Committee condemn the Government and the Australian Democrats for conspiring to force the Committee to sit through the night unnecessarily, at significant risk to health, at enormous cost, and with no consideration of the well-being of public servants. What is occurring tonight is an absolute disgrace.

—Order! Before you go any further, you may move a suspension of Standing Orders, but not a contingent suspension of Standing Orders, because we have an item of business before us at the moment. Please proceed.
—I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion to condemn the Government and the Australian Democrats for conspiring to cause the Senate to sit unnecessarily through the night at significant risk to health, enormous cost and with no consideration of the well-being of public servants.

SPEECH.PARA: The urgency of the motion is that the Senate's sitting at this ridiculous hour of 5 a.m., to deal with a matter that it is unnecessary to deal with at the moment, is not only at enormous cost to the public; it is an unnecessary risk to senators' health, to the health of public servants who are waiting out there, and to the staff of the Senate who have had to sit here all night. There is absolutely no reason for the Senate to be doing this except for the obstinacy of the Australian Democrats, who have conspired with the Government to get the Government's Appropriations through tonight. Why should that be necessary? Nobody knows. Apparently the funding is not necessary. There is no urgency for the Appropriations to be dealt with tonight in the way that the Government and the Democrats have agreed should occur. We find ourselves here at 5 o'clock in the morning, halfway through the Appropriations, with no indication other than that the Government and the Democrats think that the Senate should sit through the rest of the night, tomorrow, and perhaps the weekend as well. It is an absolute disgrace.

PARA.TAB: There is no possible justification for what is occurring. We know that the Government's program is a shambles, but why should senators, staff and the public have to suffer as a result of the shambles of this Government? Why, on the very day—now the following day—that the Senate in fact resolves to sit for an extra week in order that it might deal with the shambles that the Government calls a program should the Government, pursuant to its deal with the Democrats, require the Senate to sit throughout the night?

No case has been made out at all for this appalling treatment of individuals by the Government, this enormous waste of public money, this incredible ill-treatment of public servants. No case has been made at all by the Government for this farce that is occurring tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is time that someone on the Government side got up and said what is going on, how long is this going to go on for, at what cost and at what risk to health.
—Mr Chairman, I will be brief, as I have been through all of the Appropriations this evening. In respect of that sanctimonious and tendentious humbug that we have just heard from Senator Hill—

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: I know the moment is late, and the temptation to be intemperate is brisk, but it seems to me that that is an undue reflection upon Senator Hill and ought to be withdrawn. It is not helped by the sanctimonious interjection by the Minister for Justice.
—Order! It was a debating point.
—I think earlier in the evening Senator Kernot covered quite adequately the performances of Opposition senators in Senate Estimates committees, and I will not go over that ground again.

PARA.TAB: In addition to that, this evening we have seen a series of totally unnecessary quorum calls and equally unnecessary and even more time wasting divisions. As I have said on a number of occasions, and Opposition senators knew perfectly well that I was telling the truth, we were making good progress until we were forced by the Opposition to report progress. What we have seen tonight, in the face of this sanctimonious humbug from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), is tedious repetition. We are having interesting philosophical discussions about the observance of Australia Day at twenty minutes to five in the morning. It is very interesting stuff. It is hardly relative to Senate Estimates committees, but much of the debate never is relevant to Senate Estimates committees.

Why are we doing this? We do not need the money. It is the middle of November. As I said earlier this morning, we would all like to be home to celebrate Christmas if we can. There are still something like 70 Bills to be processed by the end of the year. The Government intends to process those Bills. To answer Senator Hill's question about where we are going and where we are at, I am advised by the Manager of Government Business that we intend to proceed with the Estimates proceedings today until we finish.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The matter is far more serious than Senator Collins has led us to believe. I am constrained to stand as I did on 5 May this year when I observed for the first time the bizarre behaviour that occurs in this chamber. On that occasion we sat until 3.40 a.m., and then we went until midnight that night. We saw the behaviour that occurred on that occasion. What concerns me most is not the behaviour of senators, because I think that some of their behaviour is not worthy of comment. I refer to the annual report of the Department of the Senate. This has occurred primarily in the last two years. The report states:

SPEECH.PARA: In the great majority of cases, the system of checks is such that most errors in schedules of amendments or third reading prints are detected in the course of their preparation and printing. The pressure of frequent sittings past midnight in May and June 1992 took their toll at the end of the autumn sittings, however, when an incorrect schedule of amendments to the Superannuation Guarantee (Administration) Bill 1992 was transmitted to the House of Representatives and circulated in the House when it agreed to the amendments made by the Senate. A consequence of the error was that the legislation was not assented to in time for the proposed starting date of 1 July 1992 for the new superannuation scheme. Remedial action will be taken at the beginning of the 1992 budget sittings including additional procedures to prevent recurrence of errors . . .
That is just one point. I refer also to late sittings, which are mentioned in the annual report of the Department of the Senate. It states:

The occupational health and safety implications for staff working long hours caused by the Senate sitting late into the night are being monitored. In the past financial year the Senate continued to sit after 11 pm on 33 of the 78 sitting days, including 17 days where the Senate sat beyond midnight. This represents a total of 42 per cent of sitting days where staff were required to work beyond 11 pm. These staff generally begin work at 8.30 am each day. In 1990-91 the Senate sat after 11 pm on 40 days out of 83, including 19 after midnight (that is, on 48 per cent of sitting days). Comparative data for the last two parliaments, that is, from 1987 to June 1992, are included at Figure 1 in the Table Office. Some officers regularly work more than 12 hours on sitting days and, on late sitting nights, particularly at the end of a period of sittings, can work for 15 hours or more, as work is required to be completed in preparation for the next sitting after the Senate adjourns.

I spoke about that in May. The effect was remarkable. I had staff coming to my office from all over Parliament House, not only from the Senate side but also from the other side, telling me about stress breakdown and work practices that led to that occurring. I received a letter from Dr Tony Adams, the Chief Medical Adviser, which said:

I am becoming increasingly concerned about the amount of stress being placed on politicians, their staff and portfolio public servants and the subsequent health effects as the direct result of daily work habits and practices.

This reflects on all of us, Mr Chairman. I was outside and I saw senior public servants asleep in their chairs at 5 a.m., having worked all day, and we expect there to be no carryover of this. I know there was a full moon a couple of days ago, but that is no excuse; and it is Friday the 13th today. It is reflected in the behaviour of people such as Senator Evans, who said, `I will quietly, deliberately, walk across the chamber and garrotte her'.

PARA.TAB: This was the same day when the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, was appealing for adults-only behaviour, violent behaviour, to put on after 9.30 p.m.; and that occurred at 5.30 in the afternoon. Not only does this lead to behavioural disorders related to stress, it can lead to insanity. I predict that it will lead to death—if not of politicians, of their staff—if this sort of behaviour is allowed to continue. I make that statement confidently in the light of what I have seen in the two years that I have been here.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always these sorts of debates that bring out the most unctuousness in the Opposition. For any realistic assessment of the process we have been going through in the Committee of the Whole, no objective observer could say that this chamber is meeting the precepts of the reform brought in two years ago. When I was Manager of Government Business we set up a committee, I think under your chairmanship, Mr Chairman, to try to put a bit of rationality into the procedures of the Senate. At the time there were all sorts of checks and balances put in. One of the great concessions of the Government was to say, `Yes, we do agree to setting up a reference of Bills to committees for greater scrutiny'. That was, I have always thought, of greater advantage, on balance, to Opposition scrutiny than it was to the Government's interest.

PARA.TAB: But one of the trade-offs for all this was that we put some rationality, some decency and some structure into the Committee of the Whole. If there is one process in this Senate that has been disgracefully abused by both sides of this chamber over the years, whether in opposition or government, it is the Committee of the Whole. The reason initially was that any senator could contribute any amount of debate on any number of occasions, which gave him an absolute infinite potential to create mischief, if so minded. That was the problem.

Mr Chairman, your committee said that an Estimates committee would have matters debated here in the Committee of the Whole only if they were reported in the Committee report or by way of reservation. For how long did the decency of that deal last with those changes brought in? With the very first Committee of the Whole, hundreds of reservations were put in or there was total generality of reservation, giving the opportunity that we have witnessed in the last three days for any matter to be gone over repetitiously time and time again and for wasting the time of this Senate.

I do not allege that we have had a filibuster here, but what we have had is a total lack of discipline and a complete abrogation of what this chamber agreed to do two years ago. One of the more sensible suggestions I think we could make at this time of morning is for the Manager and the Whips to sit down and say, `If it is the Opposition or anyone else who is mindful to shoot through, what sort of guarantees do we have that you are not going to spend another two weeks on the Committee of the Whole? If you are not willing to do that, then we will bat on. If you are willing to do that maybe some rationality can prevail'.
I do not think anyone would challenge Senator Herron's point of view that it is not a healthy practice for senators and especially the staff. Our destiny is in our own hands; theirs is not.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no tea and coffee out there for the public servants.

—No tea and coffee; we will put up with that. I notice that at least one Opposition senator is not showing the same concern as the rest of them; and at least I cannot accuse her of hypocrisy. If we reflect on this Committee of the Whole process, we can see that it is a total shambles. It is totally exploited by senators in this chamber and no leadership whatsoever is shown to try to put any structure into it at all—none whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was exactly the same when we were in opposition. Every attempt that we have made to reform the Committee of the Whole process has failed, and it has failed because those opposite have not lived up to the sorts of promises that were made when we put the package together. They have exploited it and they have turned this place, as I have said on other occasions, into an anarchistic swamp which we cannot get anything through. And we are just wasting our time.

—As I recall the motion that Senator Hill indicated that he wanted to move, it contained the assertion that there had been a conspiracy between the Democrats and the Government. I reject that word, on behalf of my colleagues. It has no truth whatsoever; there is no conspiracy. What we have in front of us is an example of what happens when we allow anybody in this chamber to make up, on the run, words to fill in spaces while there is a struggle going on to find something relevant to say. We have several times tonight witnessed honourable senators coming into the chamber, knowing that they had something to say but really struggling to find a relevance to the topic being discussed.

PARA.TAB: When the actual subject was recalled and discovered amongst the papers, we found a question that could properly be placed on notice, which is what I have done, and that, I suspect, had probably been asked and addressed in similar vein during the actual Estimates hearings. I contend that what we have here is very much what Senator Ray described to us: a situation which could easily be prevented and which very little effort has been made to prevent by those who took the time of the chamber to continue it. I listened with very great care to the words that were used by Senator Herron. I even listened before, in May, when he raised the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish.

—I reject Senator Panizza's assertion that that is rubbish. If he would like to say that what Senator Herron said is rubbish, he can say it to Senator Herron, but he should not use this place to suggest that it is rubbish. I agree with Senator Herron. If Senator Panizza wants to suggest that it is rubbish, he will have to have that out in private with Senator Herron. What I have done is to take questions and place them on notice when I think they are important. I have not wandered in here and spent hours of the valuable time of this place personally criticising other members of the Senate without foundation, as Senator Macdonald has done.

PARA.TAB: I do not take any responsibility whatsoever for the performance of this place tonight. I have not contributed to the wasting of time by the perpetration of questions which could easily have been addressed in another manner, in another forum and at another time. This is the first time I have spoken on this, and it will be the last.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my intention to pursue this debate longer than is necessary—
—You have been provoked.
—I have been provoked and I am now moved to make an observation. The reason this motion has been moved is that it is 20 past the hour of five—
—In the morning.

—It is in the morning, and it is an obscene hour for anybody still to be working, not least, those who came to work at 8.30 or 7.30 this morning. We are here now not because of filibustering, not because of procrastination, not because the Opposition has felt it necessary to fill in time, but because of the incompetence of the Government, firstly, in getting its legislation program through and, secondly, in answering fundamental and simple questions on the items before us. We have something like 70 Bills to be introduced in the next two weeks.
—That is today's lot.

—Yes, that is today's lot. On the basis of my understanding, some pieces of legislation running into hundreds of pages are set aside for an hour's debate. At the end of the day one has to ask whether this process is meant to be real or whether it is some sort of facade and reflection of the Government's House of Representatives.

PARA.TAB: I am happy to stand aside for a moment, Mr Chairman, while the Government works out whether it has got the numbers to call for a division on this matter. I just want to record my disapproval of Senator Collins's comments. I do not know how long he has been in the chamber this evening but he will know that, in respect of the programs under Estimates C, there are a number of questions in respect of those items that have not been asked. He will know that there have been very few questions and it has not been as a result of our procrastination. He will know, better than anybody, the reason that we are here now is the incompetence of the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Senator Faulkner is interjecting but not from his own seat. Would you call him to order and ask him if he is going to interject at least to do it from his own seat.
—I have called him to order.

—Mr Chairman, I do not want to interrupt any Caucus operations that are going on in the far left of the chamber, nor do I want to be part of any manipulative arrangements by the Government in collaboration with anybody else; I just want to complete what I began to say. I want to say to Senator Collins that, if there is a serious injury to somebody's health in this chamber, the Government can feel fully responsible.

—First of all, let us take up the point that Senator Ray mentioned earlier on, that we have been here filibustering. I know that every question I have asked tonight, and I am sure it is the same with all my colleagues, has been from reservations about questions I have had on notice. I defy anyone, including Senator Ray, to tell me that was not the fact. Furthermore, I believe that is the same for my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: A grubby decision to carry on was made this evening between the Australian Democrats and the Government. I would like to ask the Democrats where they stand. The Democrats always say that they stand for accountability and that they believe they can keep the bastards honest. Let us take those two points. Let us talk about accountability first. I believe that, if you want to keep anyone honest, you have got to be honest yourself—

TALK.START.PARA: —And participate.
—Yes, and participate.
—You might as well give up now.
—That is what they have to be. Is Senator Collins saying that I am dishonest?
—Are you saying that we are, Senator Panizza?
—I did not say that those opposite are at all. I said that the ones who are keeping the bastards honest should be honest themselves. If the Democrats want me to go into that, I will.
—You have got three minutes.

—I have got more than three minutes. How can we have full accountability if we are going to rush these Appropriations through? It is no good worrying about the public servants now. When the decision was made at 8.30 last night, everyone knew that we were going to be here until all hours this morning. Everyone knew that, because we were going to make sure that the Government was accountable for its Budget.

PARA.TAB: What did the Democrats do? They thought we were going to cave in. Unfortunately for them, we have not caved in. They expected us to do it, but we did not. The only reason we are here with the deal done tonight is that I still believe the Government wants the Appropriations passed tonight because there is to be an election called next Monday. I can assure honourable senators that we have not caved in. Despite what Senator Lilywhite up at the other end had to say, we have not caved in and we are not about to cave in now.

Mr Chairman, I believe that we should get on with the accountability of the Government. We are here at twenty past five. I can assure honourable senators that the Budget will be passed eventually, if the Government and the Democrats do not cave in. We are not caving in. We are going to stay here until we find the Government fully accountable. We have many more portfolios to deal with. Let me say on my own behalf and on behalf of my colleagues that, if we are still here at twenty past four tomorrow morning, we will keep going.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, it is interesting that Senator Panizza is not bright enough to disguise his real motivation. He has just identified—
—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. That is a reflection on Senator Panizza. I ask Senator Coulter to withdraw that reflection on another honourable senator.
—If we are asking for that to be withdrawn, we are becoming far too sensitive.
—Stop playing the man and play the issues.

—Senator Kemp talks about playing the man. He should talk! Talk about the pot calling the kettle black! Senator Panizza has just indicated that he is very concerned about the possibility that the Government will call an election and he has identified that what the Opposition is on about is that it is not ready for an election. Let us assure Senator Panizza that we are very ready for an election. The point about the Australian Democrats—and I have made this very clear to Senator Hill—is that we believe there should be a reasonable opportunity for the Government to have its legislation at least attended to. It need not necessarily be passed, but it should be attended to.

PARA.TAB: Any dispassionate examination of the Hansard of the proceedings of this evening will show that most of the debate that has occurred has been entirely spurious and with no substance whatsoever. I have been watching it on the monitor. I invite people to have a look through the Hansard for tonight and to make a judgment for themselves as to how important this debate has been. The Opposition goes on about the long hours. I agree with Senator Herron entirely that it is stupid, but I believe that it is the Opposition that should do something about it, and Senator Panizza has identified what it is doing. It is filibustering because it does not want this legislation to pass. It is as simple as that. We are not going to be party to that absolutely obscene process.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I seek your indulgence. I note that both Senator Kernot and the Deputy Whip of the Labor Party, Senator Faulkner, are out in the annexe doing another deal. We have had the Labor Party sitting in the Democrats' corner for the entire duration of this debate—at this hour of the night—holding the Democrats' hands, issuing instructions, carrying out this and that. It just proves that the Democrats are nothing more than another faction of the Labor Party—doing a special deal at this late hour of the night.

—Mr Chairman, I take a point of order. The assertions that are being made are not within the capacity of the honourable senator to determine. He does not have superhuman qualities of hearing. He has no idea what is being discussed. I suggest that what he is asserting is offensive.
—Order! There is no point of order.
—Mr Chairman, I also take a point of order. I ask you, Mr Chairman, whether you called Senator Tambling. I understood that he just stood in his place and spoke without being called.
—I called Senator Tambling.

—I think it is important to place on the record that the reasons these sittings go on long into the night is, very simply, the Government's mismanagement. It does not provide sufficient time to deal with the business that needs to be dealt with. There are a number of important questions to be asked—
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, it being nearly a quarter to six in the morning, I move:

PARA.TAB: That progress be reported.
Question put.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —We were dealing with subprogram 4.4. Had you finished, Senator Crichton-Browne?

—Mr Chairman, it is with a great deal of trepidation that I ask two questions. I was going to pursue the question of clenbuterol. Could I raise two matters? Can I say, with respect—and I want this recorded in Hansard—that I resent the fact that at 25 minutes to six in the morning I feel intimidated—
—Fourteen minutes to six.
—I am sorry—it is only a quarter to three where I come from.
—For God's sake tell us what you are intimidated by.
—I would suggest that we look at subprogram 4.4.

—This is what one would call a peroration. It is very difficult to ask detailed and sophisticated questions at such an hour. One is very unlikely to get sensible answers from the Minister. In fact, it is almost inappropriate and obscene to be asking questions. But to the extent that I have some steel and resolve, and with the goodwill of the Committee, I will ask a couple of questions.

PARA.TAB: To the extent that the Australian regime which is encapsulated in the Australian Sports Drug Agency legislation is probably the most restrictive and most effective in the world, what steps is the Government taking to ensure that our athletes are not disadvantaged by that regime as compared with testing procedures in the rest of the world?

TALK.START.PARA: —We will continue to enter into international agreements to ensure a degree of parity. We are also anxious to ensure that the very high standards that Senator Crichton-Browne has rightly referred to are adopted by other countries. But if I can take the question to its logical conclusion, I certainly do not think Senator Crichton-Browne, knowing the public stance that he has taken on this issue—I served with him on the committee that investigated this—would be suggesting that we should relax our strict regime on drugs or drug testing and put ourselves on parity with countries that do in fact have lax regimes and provide the opportunity for people to use performance enhancing drugs, some of which I could probably do with myself as I speak. I am sure that Senator Crichton-Browne would like us to place the proper emphasis on this, which is to maintain the very strict standards we have in Australia and at the same time continue to negotiate and work with countries around the world to adopt similar standards, which is what we are doing.

—I understand that we have some bilateral arrangements. I think Canada is one; I think we also have a bilateral arrangement with the UK. My question is: what dent is the rest of the world making on those nations which matter—to wit, China, Germany and Japan? I do not want to be seen as hopping up and down and asking one-off questions. My understanding is that—forgive me for not knowing the description—the athletics federation in America, for instance, has been thoroughly uncooperative in coming to a bilateral, trilateral or unilateral relationship. Quite frankly, it is almost tragic to have athletes from America running as they did in the sprints at the last Olympics, gassed to the eyeballs with anabolic steroids or clenbuterol—and one might want to suggest that that is not a steroid.

PARA.TAB: I will give an example. As I recall, the young Australian Darren Clark was placed fourth in the 400 metres at the Olympic Games before last in Seoul. Every athlete ahead of him has since tested positive. So it might well be that he would have been a gold medallist and not fourth.

In the same way, that brilliant young Australian cyclist who got a silver medal at the recent Olympics Games would not have even been going if that cheat had not been picked up. He would not have been there if it had not been for a regime of Australian testing. Given that Australia has socialised sport, what are we doing to ensure, as best as is possible, that our athletes are competing on some sort of reasonable playing field?

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek clarification in relation to the question just asked. I remind honourable senators that we are dealing with the Appropriation Bill. In the context of the debate that we have just had, what relevance does that particular question have to the appropriation of money for the running of government? I ask you, Mr Chairman, to make a ruling. I have great difficulty in seeing any relevance whatsoever; therefore, it may not even be a relevant matter for this Committee to consider at 10 minutes to six in the morning.
—I raise a point of order, Mr Chairman.
—The honourable senator did ask me a question.
—Was he speaking out of order or was he seeking to make a point of order?
—No, I am seeking clarification.
—He could not have done it without leave, with respect.

—Of course he can. Anybody can stand in the committee stage of the debate and get the call. Senator Coulter, one of the agencies which will receive funds through the Appropriation Bills is the Australian Sports Drug Agency. Certain questions were asked about that and reservations were made. It is sometimes quite difficult for the Chair to determine whether or not a question is relevant. But it has not happened only in this particular case; it has been going on for I do not know how many hours now in the debate on Estimates committees A, B and C. I should imagine that it will go on in the debate on Estimates committees D, E and F. I should not speak from the Chair for too long, but Senator Robert Ray raised a short time ago the fact that the reservations are not specific enough for the Chair to be able to determine whether a question is relevant. Under those conditions, I have to allow the question to proceed.

—That is absolutely correct. These general reservations fundamentally defeat the very purpose, unfortunately. I and a number of other senators supported what I thought was an excellent initiative in trying to cut down the amount of time that was spent in the debate on the reports of the Estimates committees, when most of that debate has been covered at very great length during the Estimates committees.
—You are a tired old government. You need plenty of scrutiny. There are so many errors in your Bills.

—I do not know that any have been pointed out to me tonight, Senator Bishop. In respect of providing further accurate information to Senator Crichton-Browne, I advise him that the three countries with which Australia has the bilateral agreements—
—Eighteen thousand pages of legislation.

—I wonder whether Senator Bishop could stop her persistent interjections so that I can provide Senator Crichton-Browne with the information that he is seeking. It might help to save some time. Senator Crichton-Browne wished to know the countries with which we have bilateral agreements. Those three countries are Canada, the United Kingdom and Norway. I know the problem that Senator Crichton-Browne went on to describe is a very real one. But, by definition and logic, the only way that one could address that—and I know that Senator Crichton-Browne is not advocating this—would be to relax our own drug regulation to the point where it is as lax as perhaps it is in some other countries, thereby giving the same, if you like, unfair competitive advantage to our athletes. We are not prepared to do that. I think it is true to say that there is widespread support in the Australian sporting community—at least that is what I have picked up—for the stringent restrictions that we currently have.

PARA.TAB: I think it is also fair to say that there is growing international support for a drug free sport environment. We will continue to maintain the same strict standards as we currently do; we will try to extend the bilateral agreements that we have beyond the three countries with which we currently have them; and we will continue to lobby where we can in all of the world bodies for the same stringent drug testing process that we have in Australia to be applied worldwide.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am sure that I do not need to point out to you that Australian taxpayers last year contributed $67m to sport in this country and the anticipated figure this year is almost $83m of taxpayers' money.
—Are you arguing that the appropriation should be larger?

—Senator Coulter asked a good question. He asked me whether I am arguing for more or whether I am arguing for less. I am simply arguing for the truth. I am arguing, if we are going to use argumentative terms, for the facts. I am sure that Senator Coulter does not mean to be absolutely impertinent by suggesting it is obscene for me to be asking how the funds are being spent. To the extent that we spend that sort of money—for instance, the Australian Sports Commission's estimate for 1992-93 is $59m—it is not unreasonable to ask whether those funds are being spent appropriately.

PARA.TAB: In that context I was asking what the Government is doing to ensure that our athletes are competing in a fair and reasonable way. Senator Collins simply repeated what I have already said—that we have bilateral arrangements. I am asking: to the extent that we now have socialised sport in Australia, what steps is the Government taking to ensure that other nations are complying in the way we are? For instance, has it thought about using UNESCO as a forum for raising this question? My understanding is that it is not irrelevant for a forum such as UNESCO to be considered in this respect. We can all piously stand here—this applies to me more than to anybody else—and say that we have cleaned up drugs in sport in Australia, but the ultimate question is: what are we doing to ensure that our athletes are not disadvantaged by the regime that we have put in place? To the extent that we have put it in place—and I do not need to make the obvious observation that we all support it—what are we doing? What is the next quantum step we are taking as a society to ensure that our athletes have an opportunity to compete in a fair way?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am loath to attempt to add much more because, if the same question is asked repeatedly, I will get into tedious repetition in my response and I do not want to do that. I want to give one piece of information, and that is to add New Zealand to the list of countries. There are, in fact, four countries with which Australia has bilateral agreements—Canada, the United Kingdom, Norway and New Zealand. The Government has under consideration using our good offices in organisations such as UNESCO to advance this matter, but Senator Crichton-Browne knows as well as any other senator in this chamber the very difficult problems that arise in terms of the various attitudes exhibited to drug testing by some fiercely competitive countries around the world. I state the obvious by saying that there is and always will be, of necessity, a limit to the amount of influence that a country such as Australia can have if a country with which we are competing insists on not applying strict drug standards or treats them with a wink and a nod, as some countries obviously do.

PARA.TAB: I can only conclude by saying again—I have said it many times in the last 15 minutes, but I will say it again—that the only way of providing that totally inaccurate expression `an even playing field' for our athletes in respect of performance enhancing drugs would be to relax the restrictions we have in this country to put them on a par with other countries—to give our athletes the same edge. We are not going to do it. We have four bilaterals in place. We will continue to pursue the negotiation of bilateral agreements with the countries with which we compete in the sporting arena.

Senator Crichton-Browne knows that it is a very difficult business. He has already named one country that he claims is being obdurate in this regard. We will continue to press this matter, and yes, the Government is considering—as well as the representations that were made where it really matters, in terms of peak sporting body to peak sporting body—using international organisations such as UNESCO to pursue these aims.
Progress reported.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) put:
That the sitting of the Senate be suspended until 2 p.m. on Monday, 16 November 1992.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Sitting suspended at 6.11 a.m. (Friday) until 2 p.m. on Monday, 16 November 1992.

PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Hill.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill—Are you going to read prayers, Mr President?

TALK.START.PARA: —No.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill—I think that is disappointing. I cannot remember an occasion in the last 11 years when you have not read prayers when we have come back, Mr President.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion for Question Time to be held immediately.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, I move this motion in order to give precedence to a motion to provide for Question Time to be held forthwith. Why are we back here today? We are here because at 6 o'clock on Friday morning, when the Government had failed to push through its Appropriations, despite sitting the whole of the night, it decided that it needed to come back here the following Monday morning, notwithstanding the fact that earlier that day the Senate had agreed to sit another week, which meant that the Senate would be sitting four weeks in a row between now and Christmas. It was not necessary for the Government to get its Appropriation Bills through on Thursday, nor is it necessary for it to get them through today. It has time to consider these Bills after the Senate comes back, according to the timetable that had been agreed to earlier on that last sitting day; that is, Thursday and the early hours of Friday morning.

PARA.TAB: The only logical reason for the Government to have called the Senate back today is that it wanted to preserve the option of a December election to the last possible moment. Now it seems that that has been abandoned. So why has the Senate been called back today? It is certainly not to deal with the Appropriations because, as I have said, there is still plenty of time to deal with the Appropriations. Therefore, if we are here, we should carry out the functions which are normally assigned to us. One of those functions, as far as an Opposition is concerned, is to question Ministers on the conduct of their Departments and their portfolios. In the normal way—the normal responsibility of accountability that an opposition therefore has—we are moving to suspend the Standing Orders in order that we have the opportunity to question Ministers. We are going to have a problem because it seems that half the Ministers are not even here today.

Presumably, the Australian Democrats will support this motion. Senator Robert Ray, who I understand is the Acting Leader today, as the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and the Deputy Leader (Senator Gareth Evans) are overseas, will get up and tell us what the ministerial arrangements are for today. We want the right to ask questions. We ought to have the right to ask questions when there are a million Australians out of work, when we understand that about 20 per cent of Australians are either unemployed or underemployed, when we look at Labor's heartland and we see that youth unemployment is in excess of 50 per cent and when we look at my State and see that unemployment is over 11.6 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what do you want to do about it?

—What do we want to do about it? We have put down an alternative program to provide jobs, which is more than the Government has done. What the Government has said to the Australian people so far is more of the same. What Mr Keating is offering Australia so far is nothing more than the program that it has at the moment, which has produced the recession and the growing unemployment that has flowed from it to the tragic levels that exist now, the highest they have been since the 1930s. That is the Government's alternative. It has nothing new to offer Australia at all, except a Prime Minister who is interested in only one job—that is, his own—and a Prime Minister who will try every trick in the book rather than debate policy.

PARA.TAB: We have had the courage to put the policies down on the table—policies that will reduce taxation to provide some incentive in this country; policies that will free up industrial relations because the Government has the most rigid industrial relations system in the world; and policies that will improve infrastructure and give businesses a chance and an opportunity to expand and provide jobs. Fightback is all about providing jobs and the Government offers no hope for Australia in relation to jobs.

This motion for a Question Time will also be a test of the Australian Democrats. The Australian Democrats say that they are here to keep the bastards honest. In recent times their only interest seems to have been to attack us also. Who did the deal to sit through Thursday night so there would not be a proper debate on the Appropriations? It was the Australian Democrats. Was there any consultation? No. At 6 o'clock in the morning who did the deal with the Government to come back here the following week to get the Appropriations out of the way? It was the Democrats. Who does not attend Estimates committees? The Democrats. Who is not interested in the Appropriation debates in this place? The Australian Democrats.

Let us see whether the Democrats are prepared to join with us today to at least give us the opportunity to call Ministers to account for their administration. This motion will give them the opportunity to vote with us for a Question Time to put Ministers back on the map where they should be. Or will we see the Democrats again over there with the Labor Party—as the fourth faction of the Labor Party, which is the way they seem to have behaved in recent times?
