I have moved the suspension of Standing Orders because it is vitally important that the Senate has the opportunity today to question Ministers on the failures of their administration and the terrible state in which we now find Australia, the worst position that it has been in for 60 years. If ever there were a time that this Senate should be questioning Ministers, it is now. That is the reason I have moved this motion of suspension.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you will be as surprised to know that the Government is not supporting this motion as we all were that Senator Hill moved it. It was absolutely predictable. Let us get the facts of the situation clear: it was quite distinct in the motion carried by the Senate on the sitting Thursday—although it was acknowledged well into Friday—that this is not a new sitting day. It is absolutely clear from the Senate Standing Orders that it is not a new sitting day. So why are we here?
—It is still Friday, is it?
—No, it is still Thursday. Why are we here? We are sitting here because last week we sat for a week and did not get halfway through the Appropriations.
—What about the packages of legislation?

—It has got nothing to do with those packages, and Senator Hill knows it, because we did not deal with any of them. Those opposite were going on and on about the Appropriations. That is why we are here. We are here this week to do the Appropriations and to make sure that, whatever it takes, we pass those Appropriations. When we come back to deal with the legislation that we have to deal with, we are not going to allow those opposite to take another week or more to finish the Appropriations. In the extended week we had last week, we did not get halfway through the legislation.

PARA.TAB: Why are we having an extra week? The reason is that we need it to pass the legislative program. Opposition senators said that we did. Those opposite said that we did not have enough time set aside to deal with all the Bills; now they are saying we do not need any extra time, we can afford to take up a week on the Appropriations and we will pass the program in a week less than envisaged. Let us be a little consistent. Last week those opposite were saying we needed a week extra; now they are saying we can do with a week less.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—It is true; it is absolutely right. Those opposite know that, with all last week, we did not get halfway through the Appropriations. Why would they think that in another week we would be confident that they would pass it in a day or half a day, when in four sitting days we did not get halfway through? That is the reality; that is why we are here. It is the fault of those opposite, and they know it. Senator Short has been putting out all sorts of silly press releases trying to whip up a crisis that, fortunately, everybody laughed at, as it deserved. We will pass the legislative program, we will pass the Appropriations this week, however much the Opposition filibusters. The Government at least will be here every day that it takes to pass the legislation, which the taxpayers pay us to do.

PARA.TAB: It is true that there is no crisis about the passage of the Appropriations. I said to Senator Short last week, and it is correct—I have never equivocated about it—that it is not a question that, if we do not pass the Bills today or tomorrow, the Government runs out of money. That is not the case; I have never pretended that it was the case.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you have.
—I made it very clear to Senator Short that that was not the case, and when I got the agreement—
—Why did you call us back?

—For the reasons I have just outlined. When I got the agreement from Senator Hill that he would seek to cooperate to pass the Appropriations last Thursday, and when Senator Hill agreed with me to seek to pass the Appropriations by last Thursday, it was not on the basis of any perceived crisis, it was on the basis of orderly management of the program.

PARA.TAB: All I can say is that if the Opposition's performance last week sought to guarantee the passage of the Appropriations by last Thursday, it was a very poor performance indeed. We had that agreement. We were naive enough to think that Senator Hill, whom I regard as a person of integrity, would not only try to implement it but also that he would have the capacity to get his supporters to cooperate with him. I only got one out of two. I am sure that he sought to cooperate.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a good line.
—The only alternative is that the Opposition did not seek to cooperate.
—We were ahead on the Appropriations. We were already a day early and we had plenty of business.

—That is right. We had plenty of business. We did not have the Appropriations because the Opposition's reservations in the reports were not ready, and Senator Hill knows that is the case. If the Opposition had had its reservations in on time, we would have started a day earlier and, on the Opposition's track record, we still would not be finished. This debate really is about the fact that everybody knows that the Government is obviously tempted because the polls are looking so good for us and so bad for the Opposition. I have to say that, as a matter of arithmetic, that is true. (Time expired)

—We have put on the record, very clearly, that we will not be party to blocking Supply. What we have here is the slow strangulation of Supply, with no guarantee whatsoever that, if we do not get on with this legislation, it will not still be here in a fortnight's time when the Government will indeed run out of money.

PARA.TAB: The point that was just made a moment ago by Senator McMullan, regarding the four weeks for Appropriations, is absolutely correct—there was an agreement that Appropriations would be finished by last Thursday. We have had over 30 hours of debate in the committee stage of Appropriations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I've never seen you at an Estimates committee.

—That accusation is totally untrue, and I give as a specific example my extensive questioning in relation to the Magnetic Quays development in Queensland—an issue which is still being proceeded with. So that accusation is simply untrue. In relation to Estimates D and C on this occasion, there was extensive questioning by me. So it is simply untrue to say that we do not legitimately use this process. But we will not illegitimately use this process simply to filibuster and waste time.

PARA.TAB: It is perfectly true, as I have said repeatedly, that the Opposition is to be praised for putting down its program, Fightback, well before the election. The Opposition deserves praise for this. It was very courageous and very correct of the Opposition to do that. But now, as Senator McMullan said, clearly the polls are not in the Opposition's favour. If the Opposition wants to charge that the Government wants the opportunity for an election now, the charge that the Opposition does not want an election now can equally be laid on its side.

The process should be the fair and proper consideration of the Appropriations. Thirty hours of debate on Appropriations is a totally reasonable amount of time. Yet we are still here, still with a great deal of potential filibustering to go on. Surely, having come back to an adjourned debate—and I stress that point because it is relevant to the criticism that was made of you, Mr President, in relation to prayers—specifically to deal with Appropriations, it is totally inappropriate for the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) to attempt to filibuster still further by demanding Question Time when this is a day we would not normally have had in any case. It is an additional day, one which has been provided specifically for the purposes of the Appropriations. For those reasons, we will not support the suspension of Standing Orders.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has just shown us again the colour of this bunch of Democrats. Once again they have gone to bed with the Government to give the Government just whatever it wants to achieve in this place—at great cost to the taxpayers of this country.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Short has just suggested that we went to bed with the Government. Given your rulings on those issues in the past, I ask you to ask Senator Short to withdraw that remark.
—Order! There is no point of order. I do not regard the remark, in the way it was made, as unparliamentary.

—Thank you, Mr President. I did not just say that the Democrats had gone to bed with the Government; I said that the Democrats had gone to bed with the Government yet again. This hearing today is an absolute disgrace. It is costing the taxpayers of Australia between $250,000 and $500,000. It is an absolutely unnecessary sitting. As Senator McMullan told me last week—and it was confirmed again today—the Government does not need these appropriations passed for something like another three weeks.

PARA.TAB: What we are seeing today is the result of an attempt made over the weekend by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to keep some options open for a run to a 19 December election, which he would have to announce today. We knew that he was unlikely to do that because if he went to the polls on 19 December he would be slaughtered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—If Senator McMullan does not believe it, why does the Government not call an election today? So what does the Prime Minister do? He has his acolytes over there on the Government side, supported by the Democrats, get the Senate to come back here today absolutely unnecessarily—at great cost to the taxpayer; at great inconvenience to both senators and their constituents alike—simply for that sleazy purpose. What the Prime Minister wants to do now is rush straight into a continuation of the Appropriations debate, ignoring all the normal parliamentary procedures of normal parliamentary business.

PARA.TAB: One of the most vital aspects of the sitting of this Parliament is the conduct of Question Time. Why are we not having Question Time today? The basic reason has nothing to do with filibustering; it has nothing to do with getting the Appropriations passed—it has everything to do with the Government wanting to do everything it can to conceal the fact that there are one million unemployed persons and another million who are underemployed in Australia today. The Government is running totally scared of the prospect of that matter being further debated and probed throughout Question Time today. That is why we are not having Question Time. It has nothing at all to do with the wish, as I said, to get through the Appropriations.

As for the Democrats, they rarely, if ever, appear before Senate Estimates committee hearings. It is a great tragedy that we lost Senator David Vigor from parliament. David Vigor at least was a Democrat who had the proper parliamentary processes in his heart. He was a real terrier in Estimates. What do we have now? We have a bunch of wimps who do not even turn up to Estimates hearings but who then expect the Government to get its way on everything it wants to do in terms of the Appropriations.

This is an absolute disgrace. Both the Government and, more particularly, the Democrats stand condemned for this absolutely disgraceful waste of taxpayers' money and prostitution of the proper parliamentary procedures.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have heard it all today. I would have thought that at 6.30 on Friday morning the Opposition would have worked out the significance of our suspending the sitting of the Senate rather than adjourning it.
—We did.

—Those opposite have shown no evidence in their speeches of any preparation for this particular event. It is as though they got together today at about a quarter to two to compile their notes. Why should we as a government reward the Opposition when it has deliberately filibustered the Supply Bills through a complete perversion of the Committee of the Whole? We brought in new guidelines for the Committee of the Whole less than two years ago—and what are these old recidivists up to? Those opposite are up to their old tricks again, with their mindless repetitive speeches not talking about the reservations and not talking about what is in the Estimates committees, but going up every dry gulch they can find and boring everyone in this chamber absolutely witless.

PARA.TAB: We will notice that the moment we go back to the Appropriation Bills, the gallery will clear out because people will not be able to stand the boredom and the mindlessness of what they are seeing. So why should we reward those opposite with a Question Time? It is a privilege we extend to them, and we do not intend to extend that privilege today.

Senator Hill says that we have some hidden agenda, and that we need to get the Supply Bills through because we are going to an election. Everyone knows the Senate does not have to be prorogued. Everyone knows that the term of every senator here goes through at least until July 1993. Therefore, even if we called an election today, we could get the Supply Bills through over the next couple of weeks. What a load of nonsense.

Then the big card is played. They say that the Government cannot have a Question Time today because it has Ministers and they ask, `Where are they?'. All absent Ministers are absent for a good reason. I should put that on the record. The newly instituted and very valuable ministerial forum in Jakarta has taken Senator Button and Senator Evans there, and so they should do their duty at this important forum. Senator Collins is not well—most people in the chamber knew that last week—and, therefore, is not back here today. So it is nonsense to say that we seek to avoid a Question Time because there are not Ministers here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a Question Time.

—Why should we reward the Opposition? Senator Hill should behave himself and show some leadership. Ever since he has been elected to that position he has shown no leadership in this chamber. He lets his backbenchers wander off on any exercise they like and he does not have the intestinal fortitude to discipline them and show some leadership. Everyone else knows that. His whole back bench knows that. He is just a patsy sitting there in the Leader's chair. Even when Senator Hill addressed us in his five minutes, he spent three minutes on a mini policy speech. He could not even get five minutes on this particular question. He had to go off on a romp of mini policy.

PARA.TAB: We would not normally care whether there is a Question Time today, but if the other side were to show some discipline and wanted a reward for that discipline, then we would have a Question Time, but not before.

The most dissembling, hypocritically outrageous remark ever issued in the history of this Senate is that of Senator Jim Short wanting David Vigor back here. If anyone put questions on the record just to set records, if anyone put irrelevant and obstructive questions on the record, it was the former Senator Vigor—so much so that on election night in 1987 I spent five minutes congratulating the electors of South Australia on removing him and electing, I think, Senator Coulter.

Let us get to the point—this is always the interesting part of the debate. These coalition people are just Dr Jekyll and Mr Hyde. Whenever the Democrats do not agree with them, the Democrats are in bed with us—to use the coalitions's terms—they are terrible people. But watch those opposite slime up to the Democrats when they want them to support an amendment or when they do not want them to support some piece of legislation. All the abuse disappears. Butter would not melt in their mouths when they are approaching the Democrats to get their results. But as soon as the Democrats stand up on something and say, `No, no. We believe in another course', then they are simply the fourth faction of the Labor Party, and are there to be abused as the patsies of the Senate.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Listen to them. Away they go.
—Sit down, you mug!

—Senator Panizza is very grumpy at having to come back. After this motion is disposed of, we will see whether they are serious in debating the Estimates committee hearings properly or whether we will get a whole series of absolutely repetitive and shallow speeches like we got right through Thursday night and right through Friday. Why should we reward this rabble with a Question Time when they are not earning their money?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support Senator Hill's motion to suspend standing orders. I certainly support the strong leadership that he has shown as Leader of the Liberal Party since his election. He has certainly pulled the team behind him and he has done a great job. Senator Ray's criticism only goes to prove that Senator Hill is getting under his skin and he is doing a great job. Today we have all been forced to come back to Parliament at a huge cost to the taxpayer.
—What about sugar? We want to know about sugar.

—Senator Sherry should just calm down. Question Time is the pivot point of the whole Parliament. We have come back today at a cost of $250,000. Surely members of the Government are not so frightened that they are not prepared to take on an hour's Question Time! They are running scared. They do not want to talk about the million people who are unemployed, the millions of people who are looking for jobs, and the absolute destruction of the rural sector that they have presided over in the last 10 years.

PARA.TAB: If they were not frightened to take on the issues, they would take Question Time and let it ride through. But today they are diving for cover. They are not prepared to be questioned on their failed package that they presented to the electorate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Packages.
—There is a series of eight packages that they have presented to the electorate that have failed one by one. They are not prepared to take Question Time, and they are just going to use the numbers.

PARA.TAB: I am very disappointed with the Democrats. I thought that they would support us on this issue. We have been told that we slime up to them when we want them on side. I cannot remember when they have been on side. If they have ever voted for us, it has been on very rare occasions.

Members of the Government are abrogating their responsibilities today. They are running scared. They are not winning any points in the electorate. They are just being seen as showing cowardice in the face of the enemy because they are not prepared to stand up to an hour's probing Question Time that would probably result in their policies being exposed as a fraud once again.

Question Time will be avoided, no doubt, because the Democrats will not stand up, not for us but for the people of Australia who paid for us to come back today. The people of Australia want to know what is going on. One of the ways that they can find out what is going on is by our having a Question Time.

If Government members want to be proved to be a mob of cowards, let them just run away from Question Time. Let the electorate make its own judgment about their not being prepared to stand up to an hour's probing at Question Time. It is obvious that Government members are not prepared to have a go. They will be condemned by the electorate because they are not prepared to stand up to Question Time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very reluctant not to vote for this motion because I believe that unless there are very special circumstances there should be a Question Time each time the Senate meets.
—And prayers.

—Yes, and prayers. I say that because Question Time has always occurred in the Senate except for very unusual circumstances. For example, we did not have Question Time on the day we held a debate on the outbreak of the Gulf war, on the election of the new President and the swearing in of senators in August 1990, on the day of the condolence motion for Billy McMahon on 12 April 1988, on the inaugural sitting of the new Parliament House in 1988, and on the opening of the sixty-third session in 1987. I do not know what was so special about the opening of the sixty-third session, but we did not have a Question Time then. None of those situations is before us today. There is nothing special about today as far as I know, not thus far anyhow. I would like to see a Question Time.

PARA.TAB: There are serious matters which need to be canvassed, including the reallocation of the $174m from the infrastructure programs to job programs. We need to question those matters. I certainly will be questioning Senator Cook as Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training if we do have a Question Time.

There are other aspects involved. For example, questions have been raised about Australia's efforts in regard to refugees; very firm statements have been made that there is a culture of rejection by the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. I am going to ask those questions at the appropriate time in the Committee of the Whole. If I am denied answers, I should imagine that there will be some problems. Irrespective of all that, there have to be very special circumstances for the Senate not to have a Question Time, and there are no special circumstances today.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only reason we are not having a Question Time is that the Australian Democrats and the Australian Labor Party say that we have been taking too long to pass the Appropriations. We have to take a long time to pass the Appropriations. Would the people of Australia trust the Labor Government with money? Would they trust any Labor government with money? Would they trust Burke with money? Would they trust Cain with money? Would they trust the South Australian Government with money? Would they trust Dawkins with money?
—Order! The time for the debate has expired.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to condemn the Government for the high level of unemployment, as reflected in the figures released on 12 November 1992, which has resulted from the continuing failure of the Government's economic policies.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Hill, you are not in order in moving another contingent motion.
—Why? It is a different subject matter.

—It does not matter. In rulings that I gave on 3 and 5 December 1991, I pointed out that by means of contingent notices of motion which have been used in recent years, the business of the Senate could be completely disrupted by a continuous series of motions to suspend Standing Orders. I then ruled that a contingent notice of motion to suspend Standing Orders could be employed only once on any occasion. Those rulings were partly based on the fact that the Senate had agreed to a limitation of time for debate on a Bill and that there was an obligation on the Chair to ensure that that determination of the Senate was not subverted.

PARA.TAB: A similar rationale applies to this occasion. By suspending its sitting on Thursday last, the Senate determined that it should continue today with the Government business on which it was engaged on Thursday. A continuous series of motions to suspend Standing Orders could also subvert that decision of the Senate, and I therefore rule that only one motion pursuant to contingent notice to suspend Standing Orders can be moved on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, as I recall it, the decision that you made in the past was based on the guillotine. You said that a series of contingent notices of motion used in succession had the effect of defeating the guillotine—the guillotine being to curtail debate. But in this instance there is no guillotine. No motion has been passed by the Senate to limit the time of debate. On the face of that, I can use every contingent motion that is on the Notice Paper as many times as the Senate will allow me. I respectfully ask that you give further consideration to your ruling, which seems to me to be quite wrong.

—by leave—Mr President, I not only support what Senator Hill has said, but also want you to include in your response to this request from the Leader of the Opposition whether the Deputy Leader of the Opposition could move a motion pursuant to a contingent notice of motion. I do not believe that would be out of order or against any precedent of the Senate. We would then not only have the case of there being no guillotine before the Senate but also the case of another senator seeking to move the suspension on the basis of a contingent notice of motion. Mr President, I ask that you also take that into consideration in your response.

—by leave—Mr President, I raise the same issue that I raised with you on the last occasion. As I recall it, on that occasion I indicated that it would be somewhat incongruous, perhaps bordering on the unfair, for those of us, other than the Leader of the Opposition and Opposition senators, who have contingent notices of motion if the Leader of the Opposition, by moving a motion pursuant to his contingent motion, were to deny me the right to move a motion pursuant to my contingent notice of motion—which may be, now or later, for example, a motion to condemn the Opposition or whoever. For the Leader of the Opposition to move a motion subject to his contingency motion and deny me the opportunity of moving a motion contingent on my notice of motion which is contrary to the Opposition, I suggest is a bit ludicrous.
—by leave—Mr President, I recall your ruling, but I do not have as good a recall as some. As someone said, this ruling applied only during a guillotine procedure.
—The argument made sense under the guillotine.

—But maybe not otherwise. I do not have firm views on this matter. It seems to me that if the Senate as a whole could be given a guarantee that contingent notices of motion would not be simply disruptions—and I do not accuse Senator Hill of wishing to do that through his motion—that is where we would draw the line. At some stage, Mr President, the Procedure Committee had better look at this subject, because it leaves you in a very awkward situation. The first issue is whether Senator Hill can move two contingent notices of motion in a row to suspend Standing Orders.
—On different subjects.

—I concede totally that they are on different subjects. Mr President, if you were to rule that that is not the case, what would happen if Senator Short were to get up and move a contingent notice of motion on a different subject? How would you inhibit his rights? Therefore, even if it were not an Opposition member—for example, if it was Senator Harradine, a member of the Government or a member of the Australian Democrats—are you impinging on his or her rights? Is whoever gets up first the lucky one in terms of being able to move a contingent notice of motion?

PARA.TAB: Mr President, you will have to think about those issues when you rule today and look for a confirmation in the Standing Orders as to how we will handle these matters in future. I ask you to think about whether these circumstances are different from a guillotine. But the Opposition might assist us in our deliberations on the matter. Will there be three, four, five or six of these motions today, or is this the second shot in the locker?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quite happy to clarify that.

—No, I just think it would help, when one of the things in the present mind is: will there be a whole series and is it a disruption? Or is it, yes, we want a Question Time, yes, we want a virtual MPI, which is a separate matter again.
—Because we say that it should be treated as a normal sitting day.

—We are not under guillotine at the moment. Mr President, I think there are a lot of problems in this area of ruling. The Government cannot respond and advise you one way or the other, other than to point to some of the difficulties. I think commonsense is the key rule that this Senate should apply.

—by leave—Mr President, there are two points I wish to make in relation to your ruling, both of which would lead me to seek you to reconsider your ruling as to whether Senator Hill or another senator can today move a second contingent notice of motion.

PARA.TAB: My first point follows from what Senator Hill said, and in fact endorses what he said. When you last ruled that Senator Hill or another senator was not able to move a second contingent notice of motion on the same sitting day, Senator Hill correctly reminded you that that was when the Senate was under a guillotine. The rationale for that ruling was that Standing Orders would otherwise be used simply to defeat a specific motion of the Senate, and we would therefore be in some sort of non sequitur: deciding one thing and then, by using the Standing Orders, totally defeating what we had just decided. That would make the Senate look as if it did not know from one minute to the next what it wanted to do.

I put to you, Mr President, that that is not the situation now. If Senator Hill or someone else were allowed at this moment to move a second contingent notice of motion—second for Monday, not second for this sitting day; after all, one was moved on Thursday—it would not defeat any specific motion of the Senate. The motion on the Friday morning of the late Thursday sitting was that the sitting of the Senate suspend. It was not a substantive motion dealing with what the Senate then ought to do. We are in the process now of deciding what the Senate ought to do.

I put to you, Mr President, that you should allow sufficient motions for the Senate to decide what it wants to do, because all it decided on Thursday night—or Friday morning; call it what you will—was that it would suspend. That motion does not dictate what should happen today. It might have been in everybody's minds that we would come back and go on with the Estimates, but it was not contained in the motion. The motion was simply that we would suspend and then come back and go on as though we were continuing with a normal sitting day. An additional contingent notice of motion in no way defeats that motion that was passed at 6.15 on Friday morning. Therefore, I put it to you that it is a completely different situation from that of contingent notices of motion being moved when the Senate is under a guillotine.

My second point is that, as I understand it—you may be able to help me here, Mr President—there was a contingent notice of motion moved on Thursday. In that case, what are you doing telling me and other senators here on one occasion that it is not acceptable to move two contingent notices of motion on one sitting day when you have just allowed a second one to be moved? Did you think one thing when we came in here at 2 o'clock and another now that it is 10 to three?

What rationale is there for allowing Senator Hill to move the first one today? Mr President, you cannot say to me, `But it is a different day', because we have just been told by Senator McMullan that, as far as the Senate is concerned, it is the same day. If you want it to be the same sitting day—and you have allowed one contingent notice of motion—you might like to explain, Mr President, why you allowed one contingent notice of motion, came in here, allowed another one, and then said in the next breath, `You can't have two on one sitting day'. Frankly, I do not understand your ruling.

TALK.START.PARA: —The key word, as I understand it—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. Senator Baume has actually picked up my point of order. I was not planning to stop him speaking, but simply to say that we cannot have this debate going on forever. People do need to seek leave. We will give him leave. I was not proposing to do other than that, but people have been going on at length and I wanted to get things in order.
—I seek leave to make a short statement.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. The key word in your ruling, as I understand it, was the word `frustration'. You said that you could not have a matter which involved the frustration of the Senate's decision.

PARA.TAB: There is no prospect in this motion of any frustration of the Senate's decision, which simply was to continue Thursday's sitting—which continued into Friday morning—today. This contingent motion moved by Senator Hill involves no frustration, nor the capacity to frustrate, because in fact there is no time limit set for the sitting. We have simply resumed the sitting. So, on a strict basis of fact, Mr President, your ruling is unsustainable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—On the basis of the assurance given by Senator Hill, in response to Senator Ray's question, that his intention is to do this only on two occasions for the purpose of pursuing this matter, and in the interests of—
—You can't guarantee it.
—That is an indication which he has given.
—This is called grasping at straws.

—Hallucination over there is wonderful, but they should check what Senator Bishop is putting in her water. Notwithstanding the fact that we supported your ruling in December, Mr President, and share your concern about the potential for disruption to today's proceedings which led to your considered ruling today—and if put to the vote we would support that—I suggest to you that, taking Senator Hill at his word, and in the interests of the smooth running of the Senate, on this occasion you should allow Senator Hill to move this motion and refer the whole matter to the Procedure Committee for consideration. But I make it clear that, if somebody else leaps up to move a third motion after we have had this particular debate, we would hope that you would give the ruling again, Mr President, and we would certainly support you.
—If the Senate agrees with the suggestion made by Senator McMullan, I am sure that it can be carried.
—The first question is whether we treat your previous comment as a ruling, Mr President. I take it that for the sake of the good order of the Senate you will withdraw that ruling.

—No, I am not withdrawing the ruling. I am quite prepared to do what Senator Ray said and refer the matter to the Procedure Committee. A lot of the comments that were made by senators when speaking to points of order were wrong and, if necessary, I will still stick by the ruling I made. The suggestion has been made by Senator McMullan, and if you agree to it, and the Senate concurs, we can go on with our business.

—There are a couple of separate questions. That is an awkward, informal arrangement, with respect, Mr President. If you were prepared to withdraw your ruling for consideration by the Procedure Committee, that would make sense, I would suggest. However, if you wish your ruling to stand and then we enter into some agreement, I would move dissent from your ruling, because I think it is wrong and it is wrong that it stands on the books.

PARA.TAB: Mr President, we are not interested in filibustering. What Senator Ray said in the earlier debate was quite untrue. If Government members go back and check the hours of debate, they will probably find that to get to this stage of Estimates in the committee stage in the chamber has taken less time in this instance than in the past. The Government's answer to that would be that we have filibustered in the past. That is not a satisfactory explanation.

The committee stage of the Appropriations debate is one of the principal opportunities that we have to question Ministers on their administration and, with the state of the nation as it is at the moment, we should have that opportunity and play out our role fully. It is our responsibility to do our job. If Government members want to call it a filibuster, that is up to them, but the facts do not support them.

That brings us up to today. What did we want to do today? We believe that the Government's attempt to avoid accepting the normal functions of Ministers today was a disgrace. The Government should have come in here and been prepared to accept a Question Time, as always happens except, as Senator Harradine says, in exceptional circumstances such as the Gulf war. Such is not the case today. It is basically a normal continuing day of debate, and Ministers should have been prepared to cop Question Time. The Government was not prepared to do that.

Secondly, if it is to be a normal day, we would have the responsibility to put down an urgency motion or a matter of public importance—and that is what we would have done. The way the Government and the Democrats did their deal at 6.30 on Friday morning was such that we do not have the opportunity to put down an MPI or urgency motion today and therefore seek the opportunity to debate the economy, which one would have thought was only reasonable in the circumstances with one million Australians out of work. We have no other option but to seek the suspension of standing orders in order that that might be debated. That is what we have sought to do.

The Opposition has simply carried out the function today that the Australian people would expect of an opposition: to come in here, demand the right to question Ministers as to the failure of their administration and seek to debate the most important issue facing this nation at the moment—the appalling state of one million Australians out of work. That is why I am seeking to suspend Standing Orders.

I think the situation now is that the Government is agreeing—I have to come back and ask you, Mr President, whether your ruling will stand, but that might be dealt with later—that I should have the right to seek that suspension, although presumably the Democrats are not prepared to debate the economy in the same way as they are not prepared to ask Ministers questions. Is that what I am allowed to do, Mr President? Can I go back to where I was before and argue a case for suspension?

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the ruling is concerned, I will not regard it as a ruling at this time if the Senate agrees to the suggestion that was made by Senator McMullan. I will refer it to the Procedure Committee.
—Are you going to tell us why you ruled it out in the first place?

—In reply to some of the interjections, I was asked whether it was the same occasion. I point out to Senator Vanstone that, by coming out of the Committee, that made it another occasion. That was one of the points of order that was taken. When we are dealing with the same contingent notice of motion, any item to rearrange the business or to do anything else but to deal with Government business has to be the same contingent notice because the Senate agreed by resolution to continue on Government business. That is the reason I made the ruling and that is what I would stick to. However, because of the suggestion that was made by Senator McMullan and the points made by Senator Hill, I said I would not regard it as a ruling at this time. If the Senate agrees to the suggestion made, Senator Hill will be able to move a further suspension and the matter can go to the Procedure Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —That seems to be a sensible resolution, Mr President, and I thank you for your cooperation. I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Hill) moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely, a motion to give precedence to a motion to condemn the Government for the high level of unemployment, as reflected in the figures released on 12 November 1992, which has resulted from the continuing failure of the Government's economic policies.

SPEECH.PARA: I am seeking suspension of Standing Orders in order that the Senate can debate the major issue facing this country. The motion that I wish to be debated condemns the Government for the massive and tragically high level of unemployment as reflected by last Thursday's figures, which revealed that nearly one million Australians do not have a job as a result of the continuing failure of the Government's economic policies. As I said, it is the No. 1 issue in this country.

PARA.TAB: Whenever the issue of unemployment is raised, the Ministers walk out; those who bothered to turn up for today's sitting walk out. Senator Ray, who was apparently on the record last week as referring to his leader, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating), as a clown, gets up and walks out. Senator Cook, who is responsible for industrial relations in this country and who in turn has played a significant part in this terrible unemployment picture that we face, gets up and walks out.

This Government is not prepared to face up to the responsibility it should bear that one million unemployed are basically unemployed as a result of the failure of its policies. We should never forget that this Prime Minister, Mr Keating, said that this is the recession that we had to have. This is his recession that he deliberately brought on with his high interest rate policies because he wanted to dampen demand in order to try to solve the balance of payments problems. He pushed up interest rates to a level that meant that not only poor business but also good business went bankrupt.

Day after day we came back into this chamber and said, `The rates of interest you have in this country at the moment are destroying business, particularly small business. They are going bankrupt by the dozens'. The Minister for Industrial Relations and the Prime Minister, the then Treasurer, said, `No, we know better'. Mr Keating always knows better. Mr Keating has to cop the responsibility for this because, as I said, there is no one person in Australia more responsible for the terrible plight of one million unemployed and another one million underemployed than the Prime Minister; and he has to cop the penalty when we get to this next election.

Why I particularly wanted this matter debated today was to address the question as to what happened to the magic One Nation statement. One Nation was going to be the Government's answer. What did Mr Keating claim would be achieved from One Nation? How many jobs were going to be achieved from One Nation? When he put down the One Nation statement he said, `Labor's plan for the next four years will create over 800,000 jobs'. What has happened to the jobs? He said there would be major infrastructure development that would provide a new competitive edge to Australia. What has happened to the infrastructure development, the railways and the roads? They have not gone ahead because the Government could not do a deal with its unions. The Government—this political arm of the trade union movement—was unable to do a deal with the unions to enable these infrastructure projects to go ahead and thus produce jobs.

The Minister for Industrial Relations should stand condemned more than any other Minister for that. He comes in and talks to us about this social contract that he has with the labour movement, the ACTU, but when it comes to sitting down and doing a deal with the labour movement so that we can get infrastructure in this country up to scratch in order that business can be competitive, in order for it to grow and employ he cannot do it, he cannot deliver. This is the type of industrial relations situation in Australia that he applauds. This is what he said Australia needs. He says that this is a special relationship that only the Labor Party has with the union movement.

When it gets thrown out by the people and it cannot cop the industrial relations reforms that are brought in, what does this Minister and his Prime Minister do? They endorse mass industrial action such as occurred in Victoria last week. Victoria is a cop case. One quarter of a million Victorians are out of work. What Victoria needs more than anything else is to get people back to work. What do this Minister and his Prime Minister do? They endorse massive industrial action and a State-wide strike. They are now going to lead the country into a series of rolling national strikes just because they cannot accept the democratic will of the Victorian people. The Victorian people threw out the Kirner Government because it failed in proportion almost beyond precedent. The Kennett Government has come in and implemented change. Instead of this Prime Minister getting up and saying, `We need jobs and the last thing that would create jobs is mass industrial action', he and his Minister endorse it.

These issues have to be debated today because this nation cannot go on with the formula that it has had from this Government for the last 10 years that has resulted in such tragedy. There is nothing new on the table from this Government for the people for the next period. Apparently, it wants the Australian people to accept more of the same. The Australian people have had enough and we should be able to debate it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought Senator Hill was pursuing the motion in order to get a debate about unemployment. He has chosen to make it a debate about industrial relations, which is a debate which the Government is more than ready at most times to accommodate, but when the Senate is suspended and resuming after an interregnum of a weekend this is not an appropriate time.

PARA.TAB: Before I turn to the question of unemployment, I set a few things straight on the record. It is clear that the Liberal Government in Victoria lied to its own community. That is a well-established fact. It said before the election that no-one would lose a cent. After the election it proceeded to rip off people's annual leave loading and to do a number of other things—to remove penalty rates without due process, without access to arbitration and without an ability for anyone to be consulted, let alone state their case and have the matter determined on its merits. What we witness in Victoria is a Liberal Premier mugging many of the people who voted for him. It is no wonder there is a massive vote switch going on in Victoria, as reflected in the Federal polls.

TALK.START.PARA: —Resign, you scumbag!
—Order! Senator Campbell, I ask you to withdraw that.
—That's parliamentary.
—Order! I am asking Senator Campbell to withdraw the remark that I consider unparliamentary.

—Mr President, this Minister gets up and blames another government for lying when he is a member of a government that has told more lies to the Australian people than any other government in the history of Australia.
—Order! I have given a ruling and I am asking you to withdraw.
—I withdraw.
—Mr President, on a point of order—
—What is Senator Hill doing? Is he encroaching on my speaking time or taking a point of order?
—Order!
—Mr President, on a point of order: Senator Hill cannot just rise whenever he wants.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—Do those opposite want to hear something or not?
—Order! Senator Hill, do you wish to make a point of order?

—Yes. I am asking for clarification, on a point of order, as to why Senator Campbell had to withdraw when you heard the Deputy Whip on the other side earlier today refer to a senator on this side as `boofhead' and you took no action.

—Order! During the debate earlier today I heard a number of interjections and I chose to ignore them. They came from both sides; one was `boofhead' and the other was `you buffoon'. I ignored them both because they came together. Senator Campbell made a comment that was clearly audible. I asked him to withdraw and he has. I call Senator Cook.
—Thank you, Mr President. I want to turn to the—

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I seek clarification. Senator Cook continually refers to the Victorian Government as `lying' to the public. You have in the past ruled `lying' as unparliamentary, whether it be an adjective describing an individual or a collection of people which makes up a government. I ask: do you propose to allow Senator Cook to continue to refer to people and a body of persons as lying?

—The term that a government has lied or is lying has not been ruled unparliamentary in the past. What has been ruled unparliamentary is an individual, a member of a government or a group of people within a government. Therefore, there is no point of order.

—Mr President, on a point of order: is it therefore okay for me, as I have through interjection, to refer to a group of people within this Government, and specifically the Cabinet, who I claim, during my interjections, to have lied—and repeat that assertion?

—No, it is not. It is a different point of order, Senator Campbell. I said that the term `a government is lying' has not been ruled unparliamentary in the past. Perhaps it should, and perhaps it is something that the Procedure Committee could look at; but it has not been. I call Senator Cook.
—Thank you, Mr President.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order—
—Am I going to be able to address this issue or are Opposition senators going to take continuous points of order to prevent any government speaker dealing with the motion that we are opposing?
—Mr President, I am calling a point of order.
—Is this the beginning of filibustering or what?

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Bishop has the call.

—I wish to ask, on the point of order that was taken previously, whether or not, by saying that the Government was lying had not previously been ruled out of order but perhaps it should be, you are inviting someone to request you to rule it out of order, in which case I am so doing. Would you please rule it out of order as unparliamentary?

—I am not going to alter my rulings. I said it was something that maybe the Procedure Committee could look at. I regard the term `the Cabinet was lying' as unparliamentary, the same as I would regard `the shadow Cabinet is lying'. That is a group of individuals.
—So is `the Government', the same group of individuals.
—Senator Cook's time has expired.

—That ruling makes no sense at all. You know and I know that the Government is the same people as the Ministers, the people who form the Cabinet. Only people who are sworn in as members of the Executive Council, as Ministers, are in fact part of the Government. Therefore, how do you make that distinction?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I know you have chosen not to take this course previously because you want to get the business under way, but if people are going to continually object—and that is what it is—to your decisions, they ought to put that in writing and it would go over to the next day. I call upon you to start enforcing that rule. There have been a series of objections—
—No; questions.

—No, objections; that has been the effect of it. There have been a series of objections to your ruling, Mr President, and they ought to be taken in writing. The fact that they are put in the form of a question, or the fact that they are put in the form of written advice, does not make them any less an objection. We have already been here for an hour and 10 minutes without getting onto what we originally came here for. It is proper that people put their objections in writing.

—If Senator Cook feels that he needs two minutes to explain why the Senate should not be debating unemployment today, as far as this side of the chamber is concerned, we are prepared to let him have that time.
—I seek leave to at least be able to reply to the motion of the Leader of the Opposition.

—Order! I have not replied to the point of order. Obviously, in the past the decision has been made by previous Presidents that the Government is a much wider body than the Cabinet or a group of individuals within the Government. The rulings that have been made today are perfectly consistent with those that have been made in the past.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Mr President, I have sought another three minutes to reply to the motion the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill) has put in this chamber. I had better dispense with this question of the Victorian Kennett Government lying. The evidence for that is that John Howard, on Meet the Press about three weeks ago, said that the Victorian Government had no mandate for what it did and it had misled its own electorate. Peter Reith, the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, said the same thing on the Sunday program.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. In my first point of order, which is not the one I rise for now, I asked you: in the event that a senator rises in his or her place and calls a point of order, the Minister at the time stops in the midst of his sentence, sits down, and does not seek to continue to make the point in defiance of the Standing Orders. I now rise because Senator Cook has now defined `government' as the Kennett Government lying; by definition, he has isolated it to personalities. I am not unmindful of your previous ruling in the context that a government is very often described and considered as something larger than Cabinet, but to refer to `government' as the Kennett Government is referring to the Ministry. To that extent it is clearly out of order and it is not in line with your previous rulings. I ask you to ask Senator Cook to withdraw that claim.
—I was about to remind Senator Cook that he was going very close to offending the Standing Orders. It might be better if that was withdrawn.

—I will withdraw it, Mr President. The point I was making, of course, was that both Mr Howard and Mr Reith are on the public record, on public television, as saying that the Kennett Government promised no-one would be one cent worse off before the election. After the election, before the ink was dry on the returns, the Kennett Government moved immediately to remove annual leave loading and make sure everyone is worse off. On that basis, the Kennett Government misled the electorate of Victoria. That is what the Opposition's leading spokespeople have said. Let me turn to the question on which this matter is—

—Mr President, on a point of order: you would be aware, as is everyone else, that Senator Cook is clearly straying from the motion before the Chair. He was given leave to explain why the Senate should not be debating this afternoon the question of the massive record unemployment in this country, the worst in 60 years, brought to us by this Keating Labor Government. With respect, Mr President, Senator Cook is now dribbling at the mouth about matters taking place in Victoria, from his imagination.

—Mr President, further to that point of order, they are a series of vexatious points of order, taken simply to delay and disrupt the proceedings in this chamber. I ask you to take note of those points of order. On this particular point of order, I am in order. The credibility of the Opposition is at stake if one of its key spokespeople and key governments—its reference government—are found not to be truthful. That is relevant to the question of unemployment. The relevance is: who can we believe when it comes to settling the issue down and getting Australians back to work? It is relevant. The opening was given by Senator Hill proposing the motion in the first place, when he rambled on at great length about industrial relations.
—Order! I will allow Senator Cook to continue. The Standing Orders were altered because of the problem of speaking for five minutes on the suspension of Standing Orders.

—For a long time we have said that the level of unemployment in Australia does not give this Government any joy. The unemployment level is serious but we have moved to address that by providing economic stimulus to the economy in the One Nation statement and, because of a slow flowthrough of some of the benefits of that, we have moved to announce, as the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) did last Friday, a further re-positioning of that stimulus to have an immediate job creation effect. We think that some 20,000 new jobs can be achieved almost immediately.

PARA.TAB: In the One Nation statement, and now in the Treasurer's statement, we have stimulated the economy by investing in public infrastructure development and encouraging employers in the private sector to take on more employees. That is exactly what the Government of Japan did to lift the economic activity in that country. That is exactly what Bill Clinton is promising to do in the United States. It is exactly what we have done. It is exactly what the OECD, speaking on behalf of the most developed countries in the world, has proposed as the way of handling the level of unemployment.

But what does the Opposition propose on that? The Opposition proposes a consumption tax package which does not stimulate the economy. In fact, it has the effect of taking $7 billion out of the economy. The Opposition has proposed, for those people who are unemployed, to kick them off the dole after nine months as if the problem of unemployment is their fault and not something that the wider community should be concerned about. The Opposition has proposed the abolition of a number of skills training programs which were established so that unemployed people could be retrained and re-skilled to take jobs in the emergent economy as the recovery comes through.

While one is concerned about the level of unemployment, and we do not retreat from that one inch, a mark of true concern is how one intends to solve the problem. One can talk down the economy. One can blame this and blame that, and pore over and rubbish every statistic that comes through. If that is done, it will damage the level of confidence in the economy. That may well be what the Opposition wants.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —The substance of this motion to suspend Standing Orders—unemployment—without a doubt is the most important issue that is facing Australia today. That is all age ranges: those who left school one or two years ago who still do not have meaningful employment; those who are about to leave school—and one of my daughters is amongst those who are just sitting for their final exam; right through to older citizens who had planned for their retirement in a few years, and who now find themselves having to eat into those savings just to survive, having absolutely no prospect whatsoever of finding more work.

PARA.TAB: However, we find ourselves here today not to debate unemployment again. We have done that time and time again and, with due respect to the level of debate and the interesting issues that have been raised, we have not found a job for one extra Australian because of debates that have occurred in this chamber. We need to get down to what we are here for and that is to deal with Government legislation. As much as the Democrats wish to oppose a lot of it, we still have the right to have it before us. We still have to make sure that it is on the table and that it is dealt with.

If we want any evidence of what Liberal Party senators are up to, we have only to look back to Thursday night through into the hours of Friday morning—quorum after quorum after division after inane question after nonsense and more and more filibustering. If we want any further evidence of filibustering, we now see what they are up to today. We are one hour and nearly 20 minutes into yet another filibuster, using Standing Orders in every way possible to extend the time that is wasted in this chamber instead of dealing with legislation.

So I ask the Liberal Party senators what their motive is. Are there Bills that they do not want to deal with? Are there Bills that they are hoping never come before us? If they are really about delaying legislation, let us have them actually standing up and saying which Bills they do not want to deal with. Do they not want to deal with the industrial relations legislation? Do they not want to deal, perhaps, with endangered species legislation or the veterans' affairs legislation that will further restrict, if not stop altogether, access for veterans to pensions?

So what is the legislation? Maybe it is the tax Bills.Right now we should be dealing with Appropriations. We are coming up to one hour and 20 minutes of further delay. Everybody in this place knows why we came back today. If we do not know why we are back today, then I suggest some of us should not be here.

I will go over what has been said here today: every time we try to keep this chamber operating, we are charged with making sleazy deals. The minute we agree with the Liberal Party on amendments, which is quite frequent, that is fine, everything is forgotten about. The Democrats are here to make sure that this chamber operates and that we are paid legitimately by the taxpayers. We are not paid to waste time. We are not paid to come back here to listen to ourselves rant and rave hour after hour. We are back here to deal with Appropriations.

I challenge the Liberal Party to put on the table the real reasons why it does not want Appropriations and why it wants to spend two, three or four more weeks dealing with Appropriations, because there is no doubt that, with the way we are handling it today, we could easily filibuster another fortnight without even trying. What is the Liberal Party's real agenda? What legislation does it not want to have to deal with?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quite sensibly, we should be debating the 11.3 per cent unemployment figure which came out at the end of last week.
—Senator Lees didn't even mention that.

—Indeed, she would not have mentioned it because the Democrats did their deal with the Government to keep us here all night and to come back today before that figure was out, which finally torpedoed the option of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) of having an election on 19 December, one year to the day—a celebration—of his becoming Prime Minister.
—You're 24 hours out of time.

—Senator McMullan is in charge of Government Business. As I keep saying, I wish we could have Senator Ray back. Senator McMullan could not even get his motion right on Thursday to ensure that the business that would be dealt with today would be as he supposedly wished it to be. If he would spend a little more time doing some homework instead of trying to abuse other folk, he might do a bit better. Senator Ray would not have done that at all; he had an understanding of the business of the House and it was a much more efficient way of dealing with business.

PARA.TAB: I want to quote to Senator McMullan a remark that he made to the Senate Estimates Committee on 22 September. I was asking a question of Mr Pearson from the Department of Finance and I said:

SPEECH.PARA: Suppose we go to an election before Christmas. It is not anticipated the Appropriation Bills will be through before November. Is that right, Senator McMullan?

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sorry, my attention was diverted.
—Again, as Manager of Government Business, when would you expect the Appropriation Bills to be passed?

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator McMullan

TALK.START.PARA: —At the end of November.

INTERJECT.PARA: That was Senator McMullan's anticipation on 22 September as to when we would be dealing with business in the normal way. I ask: what is the normal way? Last year, for the 1991-92 Bills, we had 40 hours of debate on the Appropriations. To date, we have had 22 hours and 40 minutes of debate. The average, if one takes it over five years, is around 27 to 30 hours of debate. Yet the Government attempted to ramrod that debate when we are spending $109 billion of taxpayers' money.

PARA.TAB: I can tell Senator McMullan that it seems to me that the larger the Government deficit, the longer it takes to debate the Bills here. When the deficit started to rise, the amount of time that was needed to debate the way in which the Government was spending taxpayers' money became more serious and, therefore, greater.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can't trust Labor with money.

—As my colleague Senator Baume says, `You can't trust Labor with money'. Therefore, one must ask questions about why the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) misled the Australian Parliament and the Australian people by not putting in the Budget Papers that he had been informed that the loans accounts of the Victorian Government had been over-raised by $1.3 billion. They are the sorts of questions we need to debate and they are all relevant to the question of unemployment.

PARA.TAB: Why do we have unemployment? Very simply because we have a Government that has mismanaged the economy. What were we talking about earlier? I think it was Senator Cook who likes to talk about people who tell fibs. How about these: `No child will live in poverty'; `There will be no recession'; `There will be a soft landing'; and `No capital gains tax'—that was a favourite one. Again and again we have heard statements from this Government—

TALK.START.PARA: —The recession was over long ago.
—`The recession was over long ago', as unemployment rises, as people start to lose their houses—
—This Government saved Australia.
—Real earnings will increase.

—Exactly, quite right. Again and again, we see the truth and why we need to spend so much time discussing the manner in which the Government flounders and spends in an outrageous manner the sums of money that go to businesses or, rather, fronts for the trade union movement.

PARA.TAB: Over here we have Senator Cook, the Minister for trade unions, a card-carrying member of the BWIU, the man who gives away money to trade unions and then calls in the debt. When, down in Victoria, a new Government is elected and that Government is legitimately acting in the interests of the people, Senator Cook calls in the debt from the trade unions to whom he has given the money and says, `Get out there and riot in the streets and cause more unemployment'. Do those opposite call that responsible government? I call it calling in the debt. How many millions were given; does anyone recall?

TALK.START.PARA: —Forty million.

—Forty million dollars of taxpayers' money was given to the trade union movement and Senator Cook is calling in the debt. They are getting out in the streets trying to thwart the will of a properly elected Government. We know about people like Senator Cook: when they cannot get their way by legitimate means, they bring in the thugs and the bullyboys. Well, the thugs and the bullyboys are not going to stop debate in this chamber today. We are going to have debate whether Senator Cook likes it or not.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I can tolerate most forms of abuse, but I do not think it is reasonable that I should tolerate being accused of bringing in thugs and bullyboys. That is not true; it has never happened. Senator Bishop, who is celebrated for enjoying being vicious and nasty, ought to be made to withdraw that remark.

—Order! In reply to the point of order, Senator Bishop said that Senator Cook brought in the thugs. I do not regard that as being unparliamentary, but it might have been better if it had not been said or if it were withdrawn.
—Is the remark going to be withdrawn?
—Certainly not.

—When we see the very strong support that Mr Keating and Senator Cook have given to Mr Halfpenny, I have to say that there is much merit in the comment made by my colleague Senator Bishop. A number of fascinating comments have been made in the course of the debate. We had the comment that was made earlier today by Senator Ray that Question Time was a courtesy and that, if we behaved ourselves, he may consider at some later date that we should have a Question Time. What an absolute outrage. And for the Democrats to support that—the party that is meant to come in here to make sure that parliaments and governments are accountable—is an absolute outrage. Then we had the other astonishing statement made by Senator Lees that, `Our job is to let the Government get its legislation through'. That is not the job of a parliament.
—Order! The time for the debate has expired. The question is that Standing Orders be suspended.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.

TALKER.NAME: Senator LEES
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp just suggested that I had said in my brief remarks that we had somehow agreed to see all Government legislation passed. Far from it. But we do believe we are here to see it at least dealt with. I make it very plain that the Australian Democrats always reserve the right to amend, in some cases looking extensively at the legislation that is coming up, or indeed not to agree to pass legislation. The only understanding we have is that it is our responsibility in this place to make sure that the legislation of whoever is the Government is at least dealt with.
—I seek leave to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lees just attacked me. I will quote what was said by Maxine McKew on the television program Order in the House on Saturday night. She said that the Government needed to put through 70 Bills and that there was a need for the guillotine in the Senate.
—Mr President, I rise on a point of order. At no stage was this subject debated or discussed in the previous debate. I ask for a ruling as to how Senator Kemp can bring up new material.
—I thought Senator Kemp was making a personal explanation.

—I am explaining why the attack made on me by Senator Lees was quite wrong. I will quote again what was said—this justifies my comments—by Maxine McKew on Order in the House. She said that the Government needs to put through 70 Bills; that there is a need for the guillotine in the Senate; that an extra week of sitting is needed; and that this week a deal was done with the Australian Democrats to make sure that all this happens. That is what was said on Saturday night on Order in the House and that is why I was quite justified in making that comment. This week a deal was done with the Democrats to make sure all this happens.
—I seek leave to comment about the personal explanation of Senator Kemp.

PARA.TAB: Leave not granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a personal explanation as I claim to have been misrepresented.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kemp represented me and my Party as having done something which I claim is not true. He repeated an opinion which had been expressed by a journalist. There is no fact contained in Senator Kemp's repetition of that opinion and I suggest that it does not bear any truth whatsoever.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1992-93 and the motion moved by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, for the report of Estimates Committee C to be adopted. When the sitting of the Senate was suspended on Friday morning, the Committee was considering program 5 of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

PARA.TAB: Senator Michael Baume—Mr Chairman, I rise on a point of order. As I understand it, in fact contrary to the point you have just made, when we adjourned—or whatever it was we did on Friday morning—the Australian Sports Drug Agency was still before the chamber and, as I understand it, Senator Crichton-Browne was speaking.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are quite right, Senator Baume. We will go to subprogram 4.4.

—I ask the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) whether any sportsmen, presently or previously representing Australia, have been apprehended in possession of anabolic steroids, human growth hormones or any other prohibited drugs without the appropriate prescription.
—Not that we are aware of.
—Could the Minister clarify for me the situation with Mr Quigley, who, I understand, was the subject of a raid by Customs and found to have human growth hormones in his refrigerator?
—We are aware of the story, but we are in no position to confirm it and, to that extent, it is not something that is established.

—I will go back to a matter which I began to raise last Thursday evening-Friday morning. Can the Government explain to me what it is doing to defend the opportunities of Australian athletes when they are contesting international events, particularly the Olympics? I do not refer, of course, to what steps have been taken in Australia. We all know about ASDA and we know that that has had the effect of cleaning up sport in Australia.

PARA.TAB: We had the case at the last Olympics where, during the swimming, at least one Chinese gold medallist was not tested. At the time there was a Chinese doctor in charge at the pool. We have seen Primo Nebilio, who is, I think, President of the International Amateur Athletic Federation and a very powerful figure in the IOC Executive, conspire to enable cheating by an Italian athlete at the Rome world championships. We have seen attempts by Professor Donicke, who, I think, is chairman of the IOC Medical Commission, to introduce out-of-competition testing only to meet with violent resistance from the IOC Executive.

We have seen the circumstances where it has now been revealed that East Germany, with the approval of the Government, systematically ran a program of providing anabolic steroids to its Olympic athletes and, to my knowledge, not one East German track and field athlete or swimmer over the 1970s and 1980s when the East Germans were winning gold medals was detected as using anabolic steroids. I ask: what is the Government doing, in a tangible way, to ensure that our athletes are going to clean contests?

TALK.START.PARA: —I sat in here on Thursday night for quite a number of hours and listened to Senator Crichton-Browne ask this question of Senator Collins. I have nothing further to add by way of answer to what Senator Collins had to say in the Senate, which, of course, appears in the Hansard for Thursday night and Friday morning.
—Perhaps the Minister might like to refer me to that part of the Hansard he has in mind.
—All of it, Mr Chairman.

—That is a nonsense answer, Mr Chairman. The question was not asked in those terms. There has been no answer of any satisfaction. Senator Collins at one stage talked in general terms about perhaps using UNESCO and he said that was something that might be considered. But I am asking what this Government is doing, in a tangible way, to ensure that our athletes who go to the Olympic Games are not competing against cheats.
—The question was asked on Thursday night; it has been asked again today. The answer given on Thursday night is the comprehensive one. I have nothing further to add.

—That is why the Estimates are being dealt with today—because the Government is either incapable of dealing with, or not prepared to deal with, Appropriations. I can understand that the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) has not read the Hansard and he has to rely on advice. I have asked him to refer me to the answer in the Hansard. He appears to be unable even to do that. No definitive answer was given to the question I asked. I am asking: what is the Government intending to do for our athletes in terms of ensuring that they are not competing against cheats? I ask that in the context of the funding that goes towards drug testing in Australia.
—Short of getting a white board to explain this to Senator Crichton-Browne, I refer him to the Hansard of Thursday night.

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: I make the comment that, if the Government wants the Appropriations, the Minister not be so obstructionist and try to answer some of the questions of Senator Crichton-Browne and other senators; otherwise we will be here all day and all night for many days.
—That is a point of view; it is not a point of order.
—In that case, Mr Chairman, I will sit down.

—I can only draw the conclusion that this Government is involved in some sort of conspiracy to ensure that our athletes do not contest on an even playing field. It is petrified about the ventilation of the level of corruption, which is well known and well documented, at the various Olympic Games—in which senior officials of the IOC executive personally involve themselves; and on many other occasions when they are not personally involved they conspire to cover it up. This is not ventilated in a proper and appropriate way in the community in Australia and, more particularly, it is not taken up in the appropriate international forums for fear that in some way it may inhibit our prospects of winning the bid for the year 2000 Games in Sydney. In my view, that is what is at the heart of the problem—that is, because of continuing vested interests, there is no legitimate, proper or genuine attempt to ensure that drug taking is removed and eliminated from international competition. I ask the Minister again: what steps is the Government taking? What assurances can he give us that it will take any steps in the future?
—As I have said—and I have said it a number of times, and no matter how many more times Senator Crichton-Browne asks the question the answer will be the same—Senator Collins—
—You don't know; you haven't got a clue, have you?
—I think, Mr Chairman, our proceedings would probably be enhanced if interjections were not allowed. I will leave it to you, Mr Chairman, to take care of that.

PARA.TAB: The other point I want to add is that we have in Australia a body called the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories. That body has accreditation by the International Olympic Committee. It is the only Southern Hemisphere organisation that has such accreditation. It is a body that is internationally respected and very widely respected. It is a body that has been transformed over recent years, and that has been done in such a way that in the last 12 to 15 months it has received that international accreditation.

One reason why that body has that accreditation, one reason why that body is recognised internationally, and one important factor in Sydney getting past stage one in terms of its Olympics bid, would be the presence in Australia of such a body working viably and effectively. This Government is committed to the continuation of that body with government assistance in government hands. It is trusted as such. It has other functions as well, and we can go into those through other portfolios, but we are talking about drugs in sport.

We are committed to maintaining that body in government hands.
