What we on this side of the Parliament are concerned about, especially when it comes to the question of testing for drugs in sport and the necessity for a body in Australia to be internationally recognised, is that in the Fightback package—at about page 220 or so—there is a provision to sell off, to commercialise, to privatise AGAL. We think that is a step that would undermine quite enormously our capacity not only to determine where the drugs are used in sport but also to have our mechanisms within Australia internationally recognised. I think it is fair to say that the international recognition has depended on a body proving itself, and we as a government are quite determined to ensure that this body is not privatised, as the Opposition wants to do, and is not commercialised to any greater extent, as the Opposition would like, so that we do not jeopardise not only our athletes and their competitiveness but also the Sydney bid for the Olympics in the year 2000.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister: what does he see as the significance of having a laboratory in Australia accredited by the IOC?

—It is very significant. It is part of my portfolio, coming within the DAS portfolio area. As I say, the Australian Government Analytical Laboratories are the only laboratories with IOC recognition in the Southern Hemisphere. We are used by other countries because we have that recognition. It gives Australia a focal point for drugs and testing. It gives us respectability in terms of having an important internationally accredited drugs and testing authority within this country. As such, it gives us respectability and it gives us reliability. That means that any bid that we would want to pursue through Sydney would be enhanced. That is the positive part. The negative part is that once we do away with it, once we sell it off, we jeopardise not only the various functions that the body has but Australia's sporting opportunities as well.

—Do I take it that the Minister is saying that, because the laboratory has been accredited by the IOC, that somehow significantly enhances its recognition internationally as a laboratory which can precisely test for and detect drugs that may be used in sport? Is that the significance—the fact that the IOC recognises it? Is that what the Minister sees as significant?

—It is hard to keep a grip on what Senator Crichton-Browne is talking about, but obviously international recognition means international recognition. When a country is internationally recognised, it means other countries can come and use its facilities and the results that the country produces are recognised in other countries.
—What I was seeking to elicit from Senator Bolkus was whether the IOC's recognition of AGAL gives it some pre-eminence.

—It does in terms of its results. It also gives it the capacity to prescribe processes, which is also quite fundamentally vital in terms of the authority that the organisation has. It has been recognised worldwide.

—I think the point is that the IOC is seen as the pinnacle of world sport and when it accredits a laboratory that means that that laboratory has a unique status and standing in world sport. The Minister is quite right; it is the only one in the Southern Hemisphere. The question I am asking is: if the IOC's accreditation of a laboratory is so significant, what is this Government doing to ensure that sporting occasions conducted under the auspices of the IOC are free of drugs? If it is important to acknowledge the status and the standing of a laboratory because it is accredited by the IOC, to repeat my question to Senator Bolkus, what is this Government doing to ensure that athletes who compete in and contest events under the auspices of the IOC are clean of drugs—and I am not talking about just the fact that it accredits laboratories?

—We are going around in circles, and I am sure Senator Crichton-Browne understands that. I said that Senator Collins answered the main part of his question on Thursday night, and did so for a couple of hours, from memory. I was only adding to it. To the extent that the addition that I make does not cover the main point of Senator Crichton-Browne's question, I refer him again and again—and again—to Senator Collins's answers late on Thursday night.

—Which Government departments and agencies have been in communication with either the AOC or the IOC, formally or informally, for the purpose of prosecuting the position that a great deal more can be done by the IOC in respect of out of competition testing? Can that correspondence be made available to the Committee?

—I can answer only in respect of the Department before us at this stage rather than any other department. The Department has made a number of representations to the AOC. Mr Haynes from the Sports Drug Agency is a member of IOC bodies. There were probably two fundamental points to be made to the Committee arising out of Thursday night, and I will not repeat the detail of that.

PARA.TAB: The Government obviously is not happy with the situation internationally and we have pursued, are pursuing, and will continue to pursue representations through the bodies that Senator Collins mentioned on Thursday night to try to bring about a more beneficial outcome. I think that is the answer Senator Crichton-Browne got on Thursday night. As I said earlier, I can only repeat it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can ask questions as long as the Committee is sitting.
—You could ask them under water or red wine.

—Absolutely, I can just stay here to the frustration of everybody but it is not going to achieve an objective. Senator Bolkus leaves me with grave reservations about the question of the Government's commitment to eliminating drugs at the Olympic Games. So far we have pledged $5m of taxpayers' money to the Sydney bid which, in my view, is bound to fail. It is a bid with absolutely no prospect of success, alongside Beijing, for reasons which were, I think, no more than alluded to by the present Premier of New South Wales.
—Should they stop?

—That is not a matter of judgment on which I am in a position to comment. Melbourne contested for the last Games. We are again contesting for Sydney. We have contested for the Commonwealth Games for Adelaide and I think we contested, if I remember rightly, for an Olympic Games for Brisbane. It has cost millions and millions of dollars in taxpayers' funds for absolutely no advantage. Those funds could well have gone into first-class sporting venues in Australia. We could probably be having world championships out here now but we are unable to do that because we do not have the facilities.

PARA.TAB: On the basis of the answers thus far given to me by Senator Bolkus, one could easily draw the conclusion that this Government is not serious about cleaning up drugs in sport because corrupt officials in the IOC may be offended by the pursuit of our endeavours and therefore be inclined to vote against us on the bid for the 2000 Games. I can come to no other conclusion. If we were serious we would pursue with the same vigour the removal of drugs from international sporting events as we have from Australian sporting events. That is something thus far that we have not done.

Effectively, we have guaranteed that it is almost impossible for any Australian to win a gold medal in track and field events where the enhancement of performance by anabolic steroids can be achieved. That is why I am pursuing this question. So far Senator Bolkus's answers have referred me to the Hansard which I have quickly gone through. I found some vague reference to UNESCO. I can find no evidence that this Government has the courage, the commitment or the intention to pursue the matter through other forums.

TALK.START.PARA: —There being no further questions in relation to subprogram 4.4, we move to program 5, subparagraph 5.4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the week following the announcement of record unemployment in Australia of 11.3 per cent and after witnessing the debacle this afternoon of the Government's complete and utter mismanagement of the business of this House, it is probably appropriate and interesting to revisit another example of the Government's appalling mismanagement of an issue which led to high unemployment and a record number of bankruptcies in an area of Far North Queensland.

PARA.TAB: The Committee will be aware of the drama surrounding the World Heritage listing of the wet tropics rainforests several years ago and the establishment of the Wet Tropics Management Authority that resulted from that decision of the Government. Whilst no-one these days is opposed—or ever was opposed—to saving the wet tropics rainforests there was a great deal of debate about the way the listing of the rainforests was managed, the way the boundaries were drawn and the way all things surrounding that action of this Government occurred.

The Wet Tropics Management Authority was set up to oversee the rainforests. That authority came into being at a time when, in the areas of Far North Queensland where the Wet Tropics Management Authority operates, there was a great deal of disquiet; a great many people had been very badly hurt; a number of timber mills had closed; a great number of people had been thrown on the unemployment scrap heap; a number of businesses had gone bankrupt; and a great deal of fence mending needed to be done. Unfortunately, the way the Government, in conjunction with the Queensland Government, entered into the operation of the Wet Tropics Management Authority was the wrong way to mend those fences.

In the course of the Senate Estimates hearings over the last couple of years I have tried to pursue some of the areas where taxpayers' money has been spent on that authority. We are all well aware of the $7m-odd of taxpayers' money that went missing as a result of this Government's mismanagement of funds that were being made available to a timber mill in Ravenshoe. I have been trying to pursue other areas where taxpayers' money has been spent to ascertain that it has in fact been spent wisely.

Back in September of 1991 I asked for some details of a capital works program that the Wet Tropics Management Authority was proposing. I eventually received, in writing, some details of the capital works projects proposed by the Wet Tropics Management Authority, which totalled some $4.39m. Part of the detail that was given to me showed that some of the capital works money was to be used for the purchase of a residence for $250,000.

I subsequently sought some details about that residence. I was told on 16 October 1991 by Senator Richardson, then the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), that he was advised that the residence was for Dr Peter Hitchcock who is the new boss of the authority. Senator Richardson said he would have that checked. He thought the residence was part of the package associated with Dr Hitchcock's appointment, and he was going to get back to me on that. He subsequently did.

I was told in writing that the provision of the house and the rental package constituted part of the conditions of employment of which candidates for the position of director were advised. That was the job that Dr Hitchcock subsequently achieved. The answer then went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: The Wet Tropics Management Agency will not purchase the residence. It will be purchased by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage on behalf of the Wet Topics Management Agency. The residence will be in Cairns, where the director is stationed.
The answer continued:
I am advised that the amount allocated reflects the middle range of house prices across all suburbs in Cairns, where the real estate market values are rising.

I might say that my information is that it was to be purchased at Edge Hill, which is one of the better suburbs of Cairns, and certainly a very expensive suburb. Apparently, this house was to be purchased.

PARA.TAB: I have since inquired about that house and what particularly happened. It appeared from that answer that the house was, in fact, purchased. In following it up again at this Estimates committee hearings, I sought some advice as to what were the arrangements in relation to housing and the rental package. I was told in an answer, which I only received on Thursday afternoon, just before this matter was intended to come before the Senate, that the housing package included in the advertised conditions for the position of director was not availed of by Dr Hitchcock. So, I am wondering, and my question to the Minister is: who is now using the house? Dr Hitchcock obviously has not availed himself of the $250,000 house which, from the answers given to me previously, had, in fact, been purchased.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice—and I think probably the best way to handle Senator Macdonald's question is to put it on notice, unless we can come to some agreement from what I am about to say—is that the Wet Tropics Management Agency was not finally going to purchase the residence. It may have been at some stage contemplated by the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage to purchase it, and it would become the property of that Department. But the advice I seem to be getting now is that no such house was purchased.

PARA.TAB: I want to take that question on notice to ensure that the Queensland departments have done what we have expected or anticipated they may have done. My last information is that the purchase of the residence may not have gone ahead. As I say, if it was going to go ahead—and that was an earlier advice—then it would have remained the property of the Queensland department. It would have been purchased by and become the property of the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage. As to what finally happened, whether it was purchased or not, I will get further information for Senator Macdonald.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand, Minister, the Commonwealth Government and the Commonwealth taxpayers do, in fact, fund the Wet Tropics Management Agency, or part of it, or provide part of the funding for it, in conjunction with the Queensland Government. It is in that capacity that I am interested to ensure that the moneys for the agency provided by the Commonwealth Government are, in fact, properly spent and that we do not end up with the sort of fiasco that we had with other Commonwealth money and other taxpayers' money which was dealt with in relation to the World Heritage listing of the rainforest.

PARA.TAB: Could the Minister possibly confirm for me that the Commonwealth Government does fund the Wet Tropics Management Agency? He might indicate to what extent. I think it is at least 50 per cent—and it is possibly more—but possibly the Minister could indicate that to me. I suspect the Minister is not the relevant Minister and that, of course, raises the issue of what we are doing here today. The Government was very keen to have us back today to answer these things and several Ministers are not available. I am not sure if this is Senator Bolkus's area. If it is, it has not been before. I can understand why Senator Bolkus does not know a great deal about it himself. Possibly he could elucidate for me just what the Commonwealth's contribution to the funding of the Wet Tropics Management Agency is.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the first point, although this is not my portfolio area, the advice that Senator Macdonald was getting and that the Senate is getting is the best advice available to any Minister who would have been here at the moment. So, in respect to Senator Macdonald's previous question, any other Minister would have told him that we do have to get more information for him.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the funding of the Wet Tropics Management Agency, we are in an arrangement with the Queensland Government on a dollar-for-dollar basis. In terms of capital expenditure, we are putting in $10m over three years; in terms of ongoing costs, we are putting in $4m per year over that same period. As I say, it is a dollar-for-dollar basis and the Queensland Government is putting in the same amount.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will await some information on what happened to that house. If it was not purchased for $250,000, I would be interested to see some amendments to the capital budget that I was given last time. It is very difficult to obtain information about this, because it is something done in conjunction with the Queensland Government and, apparently, although the Commonwealth Government funds it, most of the money is actually spent by the Queensland Government. So, where information is sought, it has to be obtained by the Queensland Government. I acknowledge that I do get the information eventually, but it is always vague, it requires further follow-up, and the information never seems to be available within the Commonwealth annals. This is somewhat unnerving, in view of the history of this area and in view of the fact that we are paying 50 per cent of the cost.

PARA.TAB: That brings me to another matter that I am very interested in. Some time ago, I questioned the appointment of staff to this particular agency. The director of the Wet Tropics Management Agency is, as indicated, a Dr Peter Hitchcock. There were some senior positions required and I understood—I might be wrong—that there were four next level positions advertised. These were advertised in April of 1991.

Some time before that, it had been indicated to me, from some information I had received, that Dr Hitchcock's wife was in line for one of those very senior positions. This was long before the matter had been advertised for people to apply for. That was told to me some time before that. Subsequently, in April 1991, advertisements were placed right around the nation at some expense to the budget and the position was offered on a salary range of between $53,787 to $59,342.

As I understand, the job description for one of those jobs was, in fact, drawn by the director, Dr Hitchcock, in conjunction with others, but as Dr Hitchcock was the director, obviously he would have had some say in drawing the job description. There was apparently quite a number of very highly qualified applicants for that position and a decision was subsequently made to appoint a Dr Vicki Pattemore to that position.

That would not of itself have raised any eyebrows, except that it was later discovered that, in fact, Dr Vicki Pattemore is the wife of Dr Peter Hitchcock, the director. Some people in the Cairns area suggested to me that that was fairly inappropriate. That is not in any way saying that Dr Pattemore is not well qualified for the job, but that relationship between the director and one of the next stage of people in that particular authority was thought a bit unusual.

It should be borne in mind that this authority was created in rather unusual and inflammatory circumstances at the time of the World Heritage listing. So it raised some eyebrows, particularly as I had been told some time before the matter was even advertised that Mr Hitchcock's wife would be getting the deputy director's job—although it seems not to have actually happened that way.

I have raised this matter about Dr Pattemore before. In December 1991, when I raised it, I was told that Dr Pattemore had been appointed for a 12-month term on contract beginning on 29 July 1991 and, therefore, terminating at the end of July this year. In this year's Estimates hearings, I sought some information about that. I asked whether Dr Pattemore had applied for that position; whether she had been successful; what was the term of the new contract; what money was being paid to her; and what other fringe benefits, such as car transport, housing and rental packages, would be included in her new contract. Again, the Department could not give me an answer immediately, but referred to the Queensland office to provide an answer. I have just this morning received the answer, for which I thank the Department. It reads as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Officers of the Wet Tropics Management Authority are Queensland Government public servants and are appointed according to the principles established by the Queensland Public Sector Management Commission.

I was then told that these questions had to be referred to the Queensland Department of Environment and Heritage. Based upon the information provided by that Department, I was provided with some information. In relation to Dr Pattemore's position, I was told this:
The position of Manager (Program Coordination)—
which is Dr Pattemore's position—

was originally advertised as a permanent Public Service position. While the original appointment was made on a contract basis for twelve (12) months, this was an interim arrangement as the Queensland Government was phasing out the use of contracts for senior appointments.

That is news to me. That has not been mentioned before when I have questioned this. I always understood from previous information given to me that these appointments were simply on contract, that they were reviewable at the end of the term of the contract and then would be re-advertised and appointments made—maybe to the same person if that person proved to be successful. But there is now new information that apparently the appointment was to the permanent Public Service of Queensland all along. I will continue to quote from the answer that I have received:

Many senior contract employees were advised in August 1991 of their entitlements to translate from contract employment to tenure under present award conditions. On 14 April, 1992 Dr Pattemore accepted an offer from the Director-General, Department of Environment and Heritage to convert her contract to tenure. It thus follows that the position was not re-advertised as no vacancy had occurred.
I asked about both the Director and Dr Pattemore, the Manager of Program Coordination, and I was advised of this:
Neither position is a contract position—
which the previous answer made clear to me for the very first time—

The position of Director, Wet Tropics Management Agency, under approved Queensland Government translation arrangements, became a Senior Executive Service position (Level 2) with standard salary and benefits appropriate to the position.

Unfortunately, I am not very well aware of what those standard salary and benefits are, and I would have appreciated in the answer some details of just what that might be. I ask the Minister whether he can tell me that now. The answer continues:
A housing package was included in the advertised conditions for the position of Director. Dr Hitchcock has not availed himself of the housing benefit.
That is the matter that I mentioned before. It continues:
The position of Manager (Program Co-ordination)—
that is Dr Pattemore's position—
(Level AO8)—
I guess that means something to people who are in the know; it does not mean anything to me—
has the same standard conditions of service which were offered to every Public Servant who translated from contract to tenure.

Again, that might be all very interesting if one is in the know, but I wonder whether someone could explain to me, in language that someone who is not in the Public Service can understand, what salaries both Dr Hitchcock and Dr Pattemore are receiving in their respective positions. What other salary packages do they have? Do I take it that their positions are now permanent and will never be terminated except by their consent or application? I also ask for details of any associated fringe benefits for either of them, such as the provision of car transport, a housing rental package or anything else. I wonder whether the Minister might now answer the questions I have raised, in a way that I and most other Australians can understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —The structure of funding which is in place here is not extraordinary; it applies, and has applied, I suppose, in respect of Tasmania, Western Australia and other States where the Federal Government makes money available to the States. We were involved in the selection of Dr Hitchcock to run the authority. But thereafter, as happens in these sorts of agreements, appointments were made by the Queensland Government in this case, and by Tasmania or wherever, in other similar cases. We do not involve ourselves in the selection process, nor do we lay down the salaries and packages that might be involved in the positions that are the subject of this discussion.

PARA.TAB: What I understand that the Department and the Minister have done here is given Senator Macdonald information which is not even within their province to date. They have obtained it from the Queensland Government and provided it to the Senate. In terms of further details, it is probably best that Senator Macdonald pursue them with the Queensland Government, because they are not within the province of this Department to detail, record or make public. I am sure that they are public. The level AO8 position is one that I am sure is made public through the mechanisms in Queensland. I am sure that the entitlements to it are probably publicly available as well, but it is not something that we can answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find it absolutely incredible that this Government, and I assume this Parliament, appropriates some $14m—$10m in capital works and $4m in ongoing funding—for this agency and that I, as a member of this Parliament, cannot find out how that money is being used or how people are being paid. Surely the Minister is not telling me—indeed, we are discussing this in committee on the Appropriation Bills—that money being paid by this Parliament is being spent in a way that I, as a parliamentarian of the Federal Parliament, cannot follow. Is that what the Minister is saying to me?

—What I am saying is that this is one of a number of areas—in fact, it is quite common when the Federal Government provides funds for State governments—where those funds are supposed to be spent, be they under section 96, agreements or other mechanisms, for the purposes for which they are appropriated. Whether it is this area or a host of others, Senator Macdonald would appreciate that the actual responsibility for the funding, the mechanisms and the staffing are left to the State governments; it is a part of, not new federalism, but federalism as we have known it for decades now—40 or 50 years. Whether it was instituted under the Fraser Government or this Government, those questions of independence and selection, staffing, funding and priorities are left to the State governments to determine and to take responsibility for.

PARA.TAB: I remind Senator Macdonald that quite often I have been involved in proceedings in this place where the independence of State administrations in these areas has always been very keenly protected, particularly by his side of the Parliament. Funding is given to States and their administrations, and the last thing people want is for the details of the funding to be determined by a Federal Government. They are determined by State governments, Territory governments and regional administrations. This is not extraordinary; this is another one of them.

TALK.START.PARA: —This was initially a Commonwealth Government initiative. The Minister will remember the huge Australia-wide publicity that was achieved when Senator Richardson was set upon by angry people—people angry that their livelihoods had been taken from them; that they had been thrown on the unemployment scrap heap; that they would lose their businesses and their houses. It was something that the Federal Government—in direct contravention of the wishes of the then State Government, which the Minister now seems to be holding sacrosanct—at the time rammed through. It overrode the Queensland State Government, took the matter offshore and had some people in South America, I think it was, telling us what we could do with our land within Australia.

PARA.TAB: I do not particularly want to rehash that incident; I only raise it to show that it was something that this Federal Parliament was particularly involved in. I also recall—I do not have the details in front of me, but the Minister would—that this funding was given as part of an agreement between the Commonwealth and State governments. I am confident that that agreement would have had in it some provisions for information to be given and for reports to be made to the Federal Government on where the Federal Government money was being spent.

I have indicated previously in relation to the World Heritage listing and associated matters that there is already a scandal of some $7m being lost—unaccounted for—for which this Government is responsible. It is relevant that I, as a Federal parliamentarian, should make sure that other moneys being put in the same direction are not equally being dealt with. If we pay the money, we must be able to get the information. Were I, as an individual, to write to the Queensland Government and ask for these details, I am sure that I would get a very vague answer, if any answer at all, and that the answer would not come for many months, as is the wont of the Queensland Government when it comes to raising any questions in relation to the wet tropics rainforests in far north Queensland.

Recently, as Queensland senators would be aware, the Tully-Millstream hydro scheme was skilfully delayed by the Queensland Government to get over the State election period. I am quite sure that the same delaying tactics will now be used by Minister Kelly to make sure that a decision does not have to be made before the Federal election. That is part of the whole system. I, as a member of Federal Parliament, insist that the Minister's Department provide me with the answers to the questions I have raised on how money appropriated by this Parliament is being spent.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in the first answer I gave, this is not an extraordinary situation. I think Senator Macdonald referred to the genesis of the Agency and to Senator Richardson's visit to Ravenshoe. The departmental secretary, who is with me, was aware of those circumstances—and so am I. Whether it is a State government department or a joint authority that has been set up like this, quite often it is very much the desire of this Parliament that we do not duplicate administrative functions. We will leave those functions to the States. I think Senator Macdonald can appreciate the need not to duplicate those functions.

PARA.TAB: We take an interest in ensuring that the money is spent in the areas for which it is allocated, but we do not go through the vetting of staff, the allocation of resources, and so on. It is not just with this Wet Tropics Management Agency; it is with a number of similar structures and similar policy areas—and even dissimilar policy areas. If the person were appointed under Federal government provisions and with Federal government entitlements—

TALK.START.PARA: —But you have said you've got a part in it.
—We had a part in appointing the top position.
—I asked for information about that position and the second top position.

—We had a part in the appointment, but that person was appointed in accordance with Queensland provisions. I am informed that we did not have any role in the appointment of the second position or any other in the organisation. It is not within our province. The information Senator Macdonald has received so far has been solicited by the Department in the interests of trying to keep him informed. If it will take him months to get it, we will try to expedite that process. I will put that onto the departmental officers, even though it is not part of their ongoing responsibility. In deference to trying to get this process rolling, I will ask them to do that and to get the information to the honourable senator in a much shorter period.

—I thank the Minister. I was going to be very helpful to the Minister—heaven knows why—in asking him to seek to get that information for me, by telling him the facts of life in relation to this matter.
—It will be a short speech.

—It would not be a short speech because—as I say, heaven knows why I bother to tell him—appointments to this agency and a lot of questions about this agency have raised a great deal of comment in far north Queensland. There are a lot of people asking questions and there are a lot of questions that need to be answered. Were the Minister to ignore my request and simply push it aside, one would have to pursue the conspiracy theory, in that there is something to hide. He has not done that; he has indicated that he will get the information, so I do not have to be helpful and give him that advice—which I have given him, in any case. This matter does require some further attention.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister—I am not sure whether it is a subjective opinion that I am asking for—whether he has any comment about the fact that one of the next senior positions, which now appears to be a permanent position in the Queensland Public Service, to that of director of this Agency is occupied by the wife of that person. I hasten to add again that I in no way reflect upon Dr Pattemore's technical qualifications for the job. But I wonder whether, in view of the circumstances of the establishment of this Agency, if the Minister had been in charge, it is an appointment that he would have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to say, in answering Senator Macdonald's question, that we should all keep in mind a number of considerations, one of which is that Dr Pattemore, I am informed, is a quite well-qualified person in her own right. It is the view of this Government, and I think of most governments, that one should not be deterred in one's pursuit of employment opportunities by the mere fact of marriage to someone who is part of an organisation or structure.

PARA.TAB: Dr Pattemore should not be handicapped by the mere fact that she is married to somebody else in the organisation, albeit the director, if she is appointed in accordance with the procedures and has qualifications for the position. Even from what Senator Macdonald has said, the recognition of her qualifications is well and truly not disputed. We should not draw a presumption that a well-qualified person, if employed in accordance with procedures, should be barred from obtaining employment. I do not think that in this debate anyone has indicated that anything other than proper procedures were followed. I do not think Senator Macdonald does. In those circumstances, I think it would be very unwise for both me and anyone else to criticise Dr Pattemore.

TALK.START.PARA: —The only unusual aspect is that apparently there were—and I will not stand by the exact accuracy of my numbers, but they are in the ball park—about 29 applicants for this position that was advertised Australia wide. I understand there was a short list of equally qualified people—I think it was five—for the job. Bearing in mind that it had been suggested to me sometime before the advertisements were even placed that Dr Pattemore would get the job, it all seemed rather unusual and probably inappropriate that it should have gone that way.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister to consider those things—for example, why, in fact, quite a considerable amount of money was spent on advertising the position around Australia if the decision had already been made? Could the Minister possibly pursue the suggestion that has been made to me that Dr Hitchcock only accepted the job as director on the basis that his wife would be employed? I do not know whether that is accurate, but could the Minister pursue that for me to ascertain through his officers whether there is any truth in that suggestion?

TALK.START.PARA: —The first point I would like to make is that, if one were in a court of law and anyone adduced evidence that a position had been advertised nationwide, it could be argued that because of those advertisements and that process the organisation involved was very serious about canvassing as wide a field as possible for the job.

PARA.TAB: I would be loath—and the Government would be loath—to pursue any person because of an unfounded, unsubstantiated suspicion. It is fair to say that I would be loath to do that if the Government had responsibility for the selection process. If the honourable senator gets some evidence, then he is entitled to some sort of a pursuance of his point.

The other difficulty is that this Government is not responsible for the processes and appointments made in this case. They are very much the responsibility of the relevant Queensland Government department. Not only does the honourable senator not have evidence on which to pursue this individual, but also we are talking about a process that is determined by the Queensland Government and we have no responsibility for pursuing it as well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will pursue that matter and also the question of what this Government's involvement was in this particular matter. I have asked other questions which I will now move onto. It does not appear that the Commonwealth has had the same difficulty in getting information. It all relates to much the same sort of thing.

PARA.TAB: In the Estimates Committee hearings I asked about an incident where a number of trees were felled along a highway through the wet tropics rainforest areas by the road authorities because they were unsafe. There was a widely reported incident where those quite valuable rainforest timbers, having been felled in the World Heritage listed rainforest, were left to rot. This is under subprogram 5.4, if that is the point the Minister is raising.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am trying to elucidate whether in fact this was an area which was reserved. My understanding is that it was not and Senator Macdonald is now embarking upon areas that are not appropriately before us.
—Comments must be kept to reservations or matters in the report.
—Indeed they are, Mr Chairman. It comes within the heading of subprogram 5.4, `Nature Conservation', wet tropics management authority, and those areas which have been reserved in my name.
—The matter has been raised and I must have a look at it. What is the particular reservation?
—It is subprogram 5.4, the wet tropics management authority. You have the running list in front of you, Mr Chairman.

—The fact that the matter is on the running sheet does not necessarily mean that it is correct. I normally take it as correct until it is found otherwise. If it is a matter dealing with Wet Tropics Management Agency, Senator Macdonald is in order.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I did indicate to you previously—and if you have a look at my letter you will see—that I have reserved nature conservation and a number of specific topics as well.

—The fact that you have mentioned them does not necessarily mean that they are in order. In fact, I think one matter is not in order because it is not part of the Appropriations. But this matter is in order.
—They were raised in Committee and reserved and, apparently, they were submitted by the Committee as a reservation.

—If there is no appropriation for a particular item, whether it is raised by the Committee or not, it does not mean that it can be discussed in the Committee of the Whole. The honourable senator is in order on this particular item and I ask him to proceed.

—Without wearing your patience thin, Mr Chairman, I refer you to the Minister's comment in the previous set of answers that some $10m capital and $4m current expenditure has been appropriated for this matter out of the Appropriations we are dealing with.
—Having gone until 6 o'clock the other morning, I takes a lot to wear my patience.

—I can appreciate that, Mr Chairman. I hope that when people talk about the time I have spent on Appropriations they will credit me with the last five minutes. As I mentioned, some trees were cut down by the highway authorities because they were dangerous. There was a highly publicised incident locally where those trees were then dragged back into the forest to be allowed to rot.

PARA.TAB: The information given to me was that the trees which were cut were very valuable and would have had a very high value as sawn timber logs. The information that was distributed publicly around Cairns was that they had been dragged back into the forest to rot because that was part of the cycle of nature, notwithstanding that the value of each of those trees was upwards of $5,000 according to my information.

I did ask about this matter in Estimates. It was suggested to me that in fact I was wrong and that 30 trees were cut on the Palmerston Highway. Apparently, permission was given to commercially salvage the logs felled by the Department of Transport and they were therefore not moved back into the forest. By implication, it was suggested that the information I had been given was wrong.

I assume that the Department would not be playing on words. I should say that it was the Palmerston or Gilles Highway where this widely publicised incident occurred. I would like the Minister to confirm for me the fact that neither on the Palmerston nor on the Gilles Highway were valuable trees cut down and then drawn back into the forest to rot rather than be sold.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Macdonald specifically referred to the Palmerston Highway in his question. That is the information we have sought and obtained for him. If he wants us to find out about the Gilles Highway, we will find that out. It is not as if anyone is being smart here. We were given a question and we pursued an answer for it. Senator Macdonald is referring to a different highway altogether. There is nothing that we know that would indicate that the assertions he makes about that highway are right. But, to be fair to him and to the Committee, I cannot say without checking that it has not happened with respect to the Gilles Highway. We will find out and take the new question on notice.
—Does the Minister confirm that this answer is correct in relation to the Palmerston Highway?

—We are working with an organisation which is in the province of the Queensland Government. This is the answer we were given to a question asked by Senator Macdonald. This is the answer which, to the best of our knowledge, reflects the reality of the situation.

—The answer also shows that the action was consistent with the policy developed by the Wet Tropics Management Authority, which proposes that trees that fall or are felled in areas where it is difficult or undesirable to place the debris back in the forests may be salvaged provided their removal does not further damage this site. I would assume that, regardless of which highway was involved, any trees that fell would have been available for commercial dealing.

—Our best bet is to take the question with respect to the Gilles Highway on notice. Unless Senator Macdonald has any further questions he wants us to pursue for him, I will provide an answer to that question.

—The answer also given by someone—again, I suppose the Queensland Forest Service—advises that the approximate value of the logs was in the range of $2,000 to $5,000. Again, that is a fairly ambiguous answer. Is that $2,000 to $5,000 per log or is it the total?
—We presume it is the total, but if there is anything further to add to that we will make sure that Senator Macdonald is advised.

—I will move on quickly in view of the time. I raised another question in this same general area about a group called the Wet Tropics Community Consultative Committee, which is supposed to be a committee which represents the various sectors of the Far North Queensland community affected by the rainforest. Each member was originally selected, so the answer goes, to represent local government, the scientific community, conservation, industrial unions, educational, recreational, Aboriginal communities, tourism, mining and commerce. That always amuses me because this committee has taken a view in relation to the Tully-Millstream hydro-electricity project which is contrary, for example, to most of the local authorities in that particular region.

PARA.TAB: Apparently, someone on this committee is supposed to represent those local authorities, yet by far and away the majority of local authorities in that area—100 per cent of them, I think, but I may be wrong in one—agree that the Tully-Millstream hydro extension project should proceed. I have information that suggests that there has been some divergence of views upon that committee. I inquired whether any members of that committee had resigned. I was told that one member, Mr Mike Reynolds, the former Labor mayor of Townsville, had resigned upon his moving to this fair city. I was aware of that. I had information that there had been another resignation as well. The information in the answer given to me suggests that that is not so. Before I accuse anyone of misleading the Committee, is it a fact that only Mr Reynolds has left that Committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —If Senator Macdonald has any other name, we will check it out for him, but this is as much as we have been able to elucidate. From my understanding of the Tully area, there might be resignations within the Liberal Party—people are very keen to ensure that the rapids are maintained and saved, whether for tourism or for other purposes. Having gone down the rapids myself, I can quite appreciate why they would want that. I presume that Senator Macdonald is not referring to resignations in the official structure of the Liberal Party in Tully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is the trouble the Minister gets into when he starts giving answers about something which he really knows absolutely nothing about. If he cared to look at it, the Tully-Millstream hydro extension project has nothing do with cutting off the water from the rapids. In fact, the water on the rapids will be enhanced. Whilst there is some early commercial disagreement on the price that might be paid, we will find that everybody is quite keen on the idea that there be a guaranteed supply of water at all times—in drought, in summer and in winter—as a result of the Tully hydro extension scheme, should it proceed. Rather than holding back the white water rafting industry, it will enhance it quite considerably. They are the real facts of the matter.

PARA.TAB: Perhaps I may proceed further in relation to the Tully-Millstream hydro project. I was given a written answer to some of the questions I raised in the Estimates Committee about this delay which I mentioned previously—a delay which I suggest is for political reasons, although the answer suggests differently. The answer says:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of the Queensland Government's decision to investigate all options for the future electricity needs of Queensland, the Commonwealth and Queensland Governments have been discussing processes for conducting further studies to assess the attractiveness of alternatives to the Tully Millstream scheme. The Wet Tropics Management Authority is also involved in these negotiations.
The Commonwealth's involvement relates to ensuring that the World Heritage values of the Wet Tropics of Queensland World Heritage Area are adequately considered in the assessment process.

The Minister would probably be aware—in case he is not, I will briefly recount—that there have already been about four major inquiries, one of which spent in excess of $5m to look very closely at all aspects, including the environmental aspects. When Senator Richardson was the relevant Minister he indicated that there was no problem with the World Heritage rules if it could be shown that the scheme was in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: The Minister may not be aware that there is no suggestion from reputable environmentalists of any damage to the wet tropics rainforest. In fact, there will be added to the wet tropics rainforest a greater area than will be inundated by the scheme. So there will be more coming in than goes out. The Minister may also not be aware that, if the grid which has been spoken about proceeds, the cost to the environment in the area that will need to be cleared in bringing the grid from the south up to Far North Queensland far exceeds the area that would have to be cleared if the Tully-Millstream hydro extension proceeds, creating an enormous number of jobs which are so desperately needed in this time of 11.3 per cent unemployment in our nation.

This decision to assess the `attractiveness' of alternatives to the Tully-Millstream scheme is obviously something that Mrs Kelly is pushing, as has been her wont in many issues around Australia. When is it likely that this assessment might be concluded, bearing in mind that this has all been going on for many years? As one who lives in North Queensland, I share the view of my fellow citizens of that area that we need a guaranteed reliable supply of electricity in that area, which is subject to the dangers of cyclones, floods and other calamities.

This is the best scheme suggested by the experts to ensure that guaranteed supply of electricity for the ever-expanding regions of North and Far North Queensland. In view of that, and in view of the delays that have occurred so far, I ask the Minister: when is it likely that these alternatives may eventually be assessed? There have been so many assessments so far, one would think there would be little left to assess. Possibly the Minister could assist me.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure that the Tully-Millstream hydro scheme, in the manner that you have described it, Senator Macdonald, is part of the estimates before us. I have had a good look at subprogram 5.4 and it is not mentioned there at all. If the Minister has any information, I invite—
—It is a specific reservation of the Committee. It comes from a department for which we are providing moneys and looking at them through this appropriation.

—I do not think you understand, Senator Macdonald. A committee can make any reservations it likes but, if it is not in accord with the appropriations before us, that reservation is not in order. There was nothing in the appropriations which related to the Tully-Millstream hydro scheme. That being the case, it is really not in order. If the Minister has any information, would he like to provide it?

—Mr Chairman, my information confirms your ruling: Tully-Millstream and the proposed studies are not within the province of this Government. They have been proposed and conducted by the Queensland Government and, to that extent, you will not find the funding allocation for them in our estimates. So your point is both quite fundamental and accurate. In speaking to it, I think I have responded to Senator Macdonald's question.

—Mr Chairman, with respect, your ruling may be fundamental; it is certainly not accurate. The Minister as well is not accurate. I refer you to page 179 of the program performance statement. There is a specific item `Payment to Queensland for the management of the Wet Tropics World Heritage Area'. I refer you again to the question I asked and repeat part of the answer I have been given: the Wet Tropics Management Authority is also involved in these negotiations. If that is not a specific reference to the appropriation, I do not know what is. I repeat the question.
—Senator Macdonald has repeated the question. I have already answered it and, in doing so, I supported your ruling.
—Try to answer it again. See if you can give us the same answer.
—Senator Panizza, if you want to speak, seek the call.
—I did not hear the last answer.
—That is because Senator Panizza interjected.
—I don't care why it was, I am just saying that I did not hear it and it would possibly help if I could hear it.

—I spoke in support of your ruling, Mr Chairman, that ruling being that the Tully-Millstream hydro electric scheme project is not before us because there is no appropriation for it. Indirectly, I said to Senator Macdonald that the inquiries he refers to are being conducted by the Queensland Government, not driven by us.
—That is simply not correct.

—Because of that, Senator Macdonald will find no appropriation for the Tully-Millstream studies in the Federal Government's appropriations for this Department. Mr Chairman, I am saying that your ruling is accurate. This matter is not before the Committee and, therefore, reservation in respect of it could not be before this chamber.

—I am just wishing to assist Senator Macdonald in his line of questioning. The Victorian Government has just had to have an advance of $1.3 billion, part of which was related to the Loy Yang power station building. The question which Senator Macdonald was asking bears very much on the fact that some $23 billion worth of debt has been run up by State utilities, which at any time is likely to have to be picked up by the Commonwealth.

PARA.TAB: Despite the fact that Queensland is called the Sunshine State, it has managed to derive only some 6 per cent of its domestic hot water from solar sources, whereas under a different tariff regime Western Australia has managed to achieve some 30 per cent. As I think Senator Tambling will confirm, in Darwin it is an even higher percentage. The Australian Democrats have been arguing for a long time that the Federal Government should take a great deal more interest in this matter. Contrary to what Senator Macdonald was saying, rather than building the Tully-Millstream, perhaps the Government should be looking at greater energy efficiency and alternative sources which could satisfy the needs of the people without necessarily having to build that dam.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is getting into a debate about the scheme itself. I am not trying to stifle the debate; I am trying to do the job for which I am charged by the Senate. The job with which I am charged is to ensure, amongst other things, that the reservations and the comments that are made in the report are in accord with appropriations which are being made by the Bill before us. If they are not there, I am derelict in my duty in not pointing it out.

—Mr Chairman, if your ruling was that it was inappropriate for me to mention it, how you could possibly let Senator Coulter proceed with things that had absolutely no relevance to it at all, I am not sure. That does not matter. I do not wish to pursue that.
—I thought he was getting somewhere.

—I am quite sure that, when it comes to development and much needed jobs for Australians, the Democrats and I have absolutely nothing in common. When it means electricity for the future development and jobs for Australians—
—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: this Committee can go a long way, but canvassing the relationship between Senator Macdonald and the Democrats is probably well out of bounds.

—The Minister raised it. I am only responding to his interjection and making him and everybody else aware that I would never have any common ground with Senator Coulter when jobs for Australians, power for North Queensland and development for North Queensland are involved.
—Did he go to the Committee and give you a hand on Estimates?
—I certainly did not see him there, if he was.
—How about we get back to the matter in hand.

—In subprogram 5.4, under item 7, there is a note `Payment to Queensland for the management of Wet Tropics World Heritage Area' of $8m. I have been given information which shows that the Wet Tropics Management Authority is involved in the process of discussing the attractiveness of alternatives to the Tully-Millstream scheme. I ask the Minister: when is it likely that the further assessment might be available to this Parliament?

—I will give an answer to this—this is probably in contravention of the Chairman's ruling—in order to expedite proceedings. The studies are being conducted by the Queensland Government. They are within the province of the Queensland Government. When they are concluded, we will all know.
—The Minister is obviously not prepared to respond. Can I just say to him—

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I have made it very clear that we are in no position to respond because these studies are being conducted by the Queensland Government. That is why I am not responding.

—Hopefully, by way of elucidation, Mrs Kelly's Department is driving this. That is the information given to me by the Queensland people. It may be wrong. The Minister has the advisers with him. The information I am given from Queensland is that it is all Mrs Kelly's fault. If that is so, the Minister should see his colleagues in Queensland and tell them to leave the blame where it properly lies. I have two very short questions—
—I hope you can explain it to them too.

—I appreciate that the Minister is neither involved nor interested in this process. Again, I make the point that it makes a mockery of bringing the Parliament back here today when the relevant Ministers are not available to answer the questions.

—In response to that comment I reassert the point I made earlier: Senator Macdonald and the Senate are getting the best advice available to government. The relevant department is here. If the honourable senator chooses not to accept that advice, that is his prerogative. In terms of my interest in the Tully area, I think the people up there know very well that I am not only interested in Tully but in Townsville, Cairns, Innisfail and other areas as well, and I will continue to maintain an interest.
—You like the rapids, do you?

—Not just the rapids. In fact, I have some family interests in Innisfail which have driven me there. In fact, I cannot get there often enough to service the constituents that sometimes Senator Macdonald neglects.

—Because I like Innisfail so much, I will not publicise the fact that the Minister has some connection with that area. I never agree with Senator Coulter and it is not often I agree with Senator Richardson, but I did on this occasion. Some time ago in the Senate in relation to a one-off payment to small business people in the Ravenshoe township who had been devastated and many of whom had been sent bankrupt through the loss of money that the Government had allocated, Senator Richardson indicated that the causes I had been espousing for those people since I first came to this Senate `were not helped by the negative attitude of some people in the Department'. Senator Richardson said that he hoped these people would `rethink their position'.

PARA.TAB: I asked recently whether the Department had rethought its position. I received a letter from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories (Mrs Kelly), which was subsequently included in this answer, where she has determined that the unsecured creditors, in her view, were not entitled to any one-off special payment from the Commonwealth. I might indicate that the money involved in doing that and saving some of those small businesses and people's homes could have been paid for merely by the cost it has taken to recall Parliament today; just the cost of recalling Parliament could have meant the difference between a house and no house for many of those families in Ravenshoe.
I ask the Minister: what has happened in the Department to cause Senator Richardson's urgings to look after those people to change under Minister Kelly?

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, Senator Macdonald, you are outside the area of the Appropriations before us, but I will ask the Minister whether he has any comment.
—I have nothing further to add to Mrs Kelly's advice of 6 October.

—I preface this question by saying `finally'. Senator Richardson told me in the Parliament on 9 November that he had arranged for some people from the forest industry with some relationship to the unsecured creditors in the town of Ravenshoe to speak with Mrs Kelly and to put their case to see whether something could be done for them. I did inquire what had happened to that meeting which Senator Richardson had arranged and have since been told, in writing this time, that the Minister did not consider it necessary to meet with those people.

PARA.TAB: Again I ask the Minister: what occurred that changed the arrangement that Senator Richardson had made for those people to speak with Mrs Kelly and to at least put their case to her? Why did Mrs Kelly refuse—or maybe that is too strong? Why was the arrangement that Senator Richardson made not pursued by Mrs Kelly? It was apparently broken by her in that she did not in fact speak to those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Again, I point out that this is not in accord with the Appropriations before us, but I will ask the Minister whether he has any comment.
—I have nothing further to add to the advice of 6 October.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 5.4? There being no further matters on that subprogram, we will move to subprogram 5.9. Are there any matters to be raised here?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise the issue that is listed in the reservations against my name—the provision in 1991-92 and 1992-93 for the control of mimosa pigra, including its control on Aboriginal land.

PARA.TAB: This is a very important issue. I only hope that the Leader of the Australian Democrats, Senator Coulter, can constrain himself from coming into the chamber to speak on this particular issue. A few moments ago he came to Senator Macdonald's assistance on another very important environmental issue—that relating to the wet tropics of North Queensland—and, of course, made a fool of himself. I hope that he will stay out of the chamber while I am addressing this terribly important issue that relates to the Kakadu National Park in the Northern Territory. It is the sort of issue that I would have thought that the Australian Democrats would have been championing during the Estimates hearings and subsequently here in the Senate. But of course, the Australian Democrats do not know anything about money, cannot add up when it comes to Appropriations, and make no contribution.

But that is a bit of a sideline from the important issue: the control of mimosa pigra. This issue has been raised a number of times. In fact, in the 1991-92 Budget the Government provided $2m for the first year of a five-year chemical and mechanical control program for mimosa pigra on the Oenpelli flood plains in the Northern Territory. What happened for the year 1992-93? Someone forgot to put any dough in; someone forgot to remember that there was a second year in a very important five-year program. The Government puts in $2m for year one and then for the second year it completely omits it, loses it and forgets it, and it disappears.

I put a series of questions on notice to the Senate Estimates in early September, and I am afraid I was given what can only be described as very much a round-robin Yes, Minister type answer with which I am not satisfied. In my first question I asked what provisions had been made for the financial years—that is, 1991-92, the first year, and 1992-93? I got an answer that yes, $2m was provided for the first year, and the final part of the answer to that question was, `Consideration is being given to the provision of additional funds for the program'. Whereabouts? It is not in the Budget Papers. There is no provision for $2m this year, and yet that would be the absolute minimum that would be required to maintain this particular program. I ask the Minister to address that very important issue. Is it going into some Supplementary Estimates? Is it coming out of a Minister's slush fund in some area?

The second question I asked was whether the program is subject to a long term commitment—I stress those words—and what will be the consequences to the Kakadu National Park, Arnhem Land and other areas of an uncontrolled mimosa invasion. Again, the answer goes round and round the question talking about the work of CSIRO and talking about the strategically important aspects of containing the eastward spread to Arnhem Land. The final sentence of that particular answer is: `The continued spread of mimosa constitutes a threat to the biological diversity of Australia's tropical wetlands'. What an acknowledgment—a very major important point, but no acceptance whatsoever of a long term commitment. The second year of a five-year program has dropped out. What will happen to years three, four and five if we cannot even get the cash in there for the second year?

The third question I asked was: what arrangements had been put together with the Northern Territory Government for support on this particular program? I got an answer that talked about the Northern Territory Minister for Primary Industry and Fisheries having written to Mrs Kelly on 7 July 1992—just after the financial year started—expressing concern that funding for the Oenpelli project had been discontinued. The NT Minister wrote again on 16 October 1992 indicating that the Northern Territory may be in a position to increase its support for a broadened mimosa control program. I checked with Minister Reed's office today as to whether anything had been developed or further advanced on this issue, and I was told, `No, the matter is sitting in limbo'.

Given that I asked these questions on, I think, 4 September, that they went on notice, that these answers were given to me in October and that we are now into November, where is the commitment to at least $2m in this financial year for the second year of a five-year program? Where is the answer to the Northern Territory Government's offer to be involved in the program? What is the Commonwealth's long term commitment to this very important environmental disaster?

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an issue of which I am very much aware, because my colleague Warren Snowdon, the honourable member for the Northern Territory, has discussed it with me on a number of occasions, even though I am not the portfolio Minister. He does so because he is very keen to lobby Cabinet Ministers, whether they have the portfolio or not, when it comes to issues relating to the Northern Territory.

PARA.TAB: With respect to this problem, he was keen—the Government by its recent decision indicated and reflected that keenness—to take a continuing interest in the problem. As we know, the Commonwealth provided $2m in 1991-92. In doing so, we have intended to embark upon a five-year program, with joint funding, with the Territory Government and the Aboriginal communities involved.

I think it is fair to say that the Territory Government has not been keen to meet us in relation to the program. That is the advice I am getting. To that extent, we have obtained funding by way of additional estimates. That goes back to one of Senator Tambling's questions. We have planned funding for the second year of the program by way of additional estimates. Cabinet decided that in October and we agreed to provide up to $1.046m to continue the program into 1993, subject to details being settled. I am also advised that another $64,000 is coming from another program which will also be used with respect to the same problem.

It is still our intention to embark upon a long term program and to do so in conjunction with the Northern Territory Government. That of course would be the preferred approach and it is an approach that we will pursue. As I said at the outset, Parliamentary Secretary Snowdon has been very keen to keep this issue alive on the political agenda, on the financing agenda, and I am sure Senator Tambling would recognise the work Mr Snowdon has done on this. Senator Tambling would also appreciate that the Government still intends to treat this as a longer term problem, with the cooperation of the Territory Government and the Aboriginal communities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly note Mr Snowdon's interest in this area as put forward by the Minister. It is very interesting to note that there was absolutely nothing in the August Budget, so there must have been some pretty fast footwork after the event to get the $1m then reinstituted as additional estimates.

—Mr Temporary Chairman, on a point of order: that is very unfair. I think Senator Tambling would appreciate that Warren Snowdon does not let issues sleep under rocks. He was alerting people of this even before Parliament resumed, even before the Budget was put to rest. It is a continuing issue for him.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Crichton-Browne)—Senator Bolkus, I think it is rather more a debating point than a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the Minister's point. Obviously the Cabinet chose to ignore Mr Snowdon's earlier advice. However, given that additional estimates have now been provided for year two at $1.046m, how does that vary from the original intent of the five-year program? What in total was in the original Cabinet endorsed submission for the five-year program? What were the phased amounts that were originally intended? How does the $1m now stack up against the $2m for year one and the total component? Senator Bolkus said that he had been looking for contact with the Northern Territory Government. In light of Northern Territory Minister Reed's letters of 7 July and 16 October, when has Minister Kelly or any other Minister or government officer specifically replied in writing and indicated the Commonwealth's firm intention on this matter?

—On the question of correspondence from Minister Kelly to the Northern Territory Government, we will get the dates for Senator Tambling in the Senate. As to the programs themselves, as I mentioned earlier, the initial five-year program was embarked upon in anticipated cooperation with the Northern Territory Government and Aboriginal communities.

PARA.TAB: We spent $2m in that first financial year not only on aerial spraying but also on capital equipment. I want to make it clear that this year it is $1.1m—$1.046m plus $0.64m—and we will be using some of the capital equipment to continue removal through spraying and mechanical means as well, which is part of the ongoing program. Keep in mind that there has been expenditure for capital equipment in that first financial year, which capital equipment will be used in an ongoing program. If there is anything further we can add to that, I will ask the Department to check that and come back to us.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was one point I did ask the Minister to qualify. What was the original submission for the five-year program and to what extent is the $2m first-year and $1.1m second-year commitment consistent with that original program?

—I will give this part of the answer and offer to provide further information if there needs to be any. I think it is important for the Committee to recognise that the initial five-year program was embarked upon with an anticipated expenditure of some $5.086m over three years. To date, as Senator Tambling knows, we have spent $2m and then $1.1m. If there is some difference between that and what might be spent next year, which may or may not get us up to the $5.086m, Senator Tambling wants to know what the difference is between what had been budgeted for and what has been finally met. We will take that question on notice and, if there is anything, come back to Senator Tambling. It may very well be that the expenditure so far has covered the areas that needed to be covered. There might also very well be a revision of that $5.086m which might be justifiable. I do not want to pre-empt any of that, but we will get the information for Senator Tambling.
—I thank Senator Cook and the Australian Democrats for their non-assistance on this important environmental issue.
—Are there any questions on subprogram 5.10, Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority?

—At page 220 of the program performance statements in relation to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority it is indicated that one of the things the authority was looking at was a system of user charges. This idea of what, in effect, amounts to a reef tax has been considered for some time. I asked some questions about it in the Estimates Committee seeking some information on how the new reef tax would be imposed upon operators. I asked whether there was a guarantee to the operators that the money raised would be used for research into the reef. I am told in writing that it would be. I also raised, Mr Chairman—

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: Senator Macdonald might be able to help us, but I cannot find where this has been reserved for the consideration in the Committee of the Whole. He may have it somewhere in his piece of paper, but we have not been able to find it.
—The reservation I have before me under subprogram 5.10, Senator Bolkus, is the Whitehouse report reservation of Senator Macdonald on page 8.
—And the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority—
—That has nothing to do with the issue that Senator Macdonald is raising.
—Senator Macdonald, is there a further reservation?
—I have reserved two matters: firstly, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority as one matter and, secondly, the Magnetic Quays development Whitehouse report.
—That latter one refers to the Whitehouse report with respect to Magnetic Island and the unfinished marina there. I do not know where Senator Macdonald has reserved the first one, Mr Chairman.
—Generally, under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in subprogram 5.10. I refer the Minister to the other reservations—

—Mr Chairman, on a point of order: if you look at that reservation, you will see that it is GBRMPA but it relates specifically to the Whitehouse report, not to anything else that might be related to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority.

—On the point of order, Mr Chairman: I refer you to the reservations that are made right the way through. For example, my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne in talking about reservations simply refers to program performance estimates on the portfolio of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, program 4, Sport and Recreation subprograms 4.3 and 4.4. In other instances, the general reservation is made. What I have done in mine is reserve two things: the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority generally and then, specifically as well, the Magnetic Quays development Whitehouse report. They are simply reservations on the total of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and then as well specifically in relation to the Whitehouse report.

—Mr Chairman, on the point of order: I think it is pretty clear from the report—and if you were to go into the report, it would elucidate this as well—that what the report reserves is that part of that program under GBRMPA which relates to the Whitehouse report. It does not refer to the whole Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority issue; it relates to the Whitehouse report, and that is a distinct part of it. If you go to the Committee's report, Mr Chairman, you will find that is as much as has been reserved, not the whole area of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. I ask you to rule that way, Mr Chairman.

—Senator Bolkus, thank you. My understanding, by way of reading it and from the explanation I have received from Senator Macdonald, is that he was referring to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority as an item and the Magnetic Quays development and the Whitehouse report as another item.
—If you look at the report, Mr Chairman, you will find that he has not reserved both; he has reserved only the Whitehouse report.
—Why do we not proceed for the moment and I will continue to look at it while you are answering the question—
—While I am listening to the question.
—Yes, while you are listening to the question, Senator Bolkus.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I would appreciate you considering it while I complete the question. I am conscious of the fact that the fuel excise tax was originally raised to fund roads. Of course, that was when it was 6c or 7c a litre; it is now 26c a litre. In fact, one of the operators that works on the Barrier Reef raised this very point with me. He said, `Look, we have to pay the Commonwealth fuel excise on all the fuel we use on our boats. We pay 26c a litre for that'. He acknowledged that under this Government some 19c a litre goes simply to the general revenue, but he pointed out to me that at least 6c or 7c of that 26c a litre that this Government extracts as tax did go to roads. He said to me, `We pay the full fuel tax of 26c a litre, including the 6c or 7c a litre for roads, but our boats never drive on a road; they always go on the sea'. He asked, `Why could not that amount of money be appropriated quite sensibly for research into the Barrier Reef rather than be used for road construction and maintenance?'

PARA.TAB: Instead of doing that, this Government chooses to extract the whole 26c a litre from those reef operators as just another tax, giving nothing back, and then, in addition to that, wants to impose a specific reef tax on all those small business operators who operate in that reef area—people who are the most careful with the reef, the ones who protect it because it is their livelihood as well as being a national treasure. Yet this Government comes along and intends to impose yet another tax on those small business people, a reef tax which is intended to again tax small business—tax those in the tourist area.

I have asked the Minister: what are the details of that reef tax; who is going to pay it; how is it going to be collected; and how much is it? The Government has been talking about it for some three or four months now, but I will guarantee to you, Mr Chairman, that you will not get a decision until after the election because this Government, unlike the new incoming Government, is not prepared to be honest about its policies. It is not prepared to tell the people of Australia what taxes it intends to impose, whereas the Liberal and National parties are very open and honest about that. We will tell the people what this is all about, but this Government will hide this reef tax, will disguise it, will keep putting it off—the same as it is doing with Tully-Millstream—until such time as the election is over, and then it will come in and impose yet another tax on small business in the tourist areas.

I ask the Minister: why does he not come clean on that and tell the people up there now what the Government is going to tax them for using the Great Barrier Reef? Its guarantee that it will be used on education, research and management does not wash with the tourist operators, because they look at the example of the fuel excise, which I have mentioned; they do not believe the Government at all. I would like the Government to come out and explain that now before the election so that those operators can understand what taxes they are going to be up for in the unlikely event of this Government being returned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I await your ruling, Mr Chairman.
—I will rule in his favour for the time being, Senator Bolkus.

—You must be a slow reader, Mr Chairman, that is all I can say. Senator Macdonald has received an answer from the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, Mrs Kelly, with respect to this only a few days ago and there is nothing further to add to it. I do not want to debate whether boats travel on roads or sea. I think if we were to spend our time trying to work out whether boats travel on water or bitumen, the public would probably be even more cynical about our process.
