With respect to the fundamental part of the honourable senator's question, Mrs Kelly has given the only answer that is available at the moment, and that is that negotiations with industry are continuing on the final form that the charge will take and we will all be advised as those negotiations proceed.

—Could the Minister just give me some informed advice on whether that is likely to eventuate before an election. Let us not anticipate when an election might be, but is it likely that those consultations and that determination will be settled, say, before 31 March 1993?

—An announcement was made some 35 minutes ago, but Senator Macdonald might just turn on the TV to find out. The announcement is that from 1 July 1993 the Government will introduce fees for the commercial use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I anticipate that any discussions will take place before that date, obviously.
—It is not particularly relevant to this portfolio but, at the urging of my colleague, what did the Prime Minister announce 25 minutes ago?
—I do not know.
—The Minister has indicated those charges will start from when?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mrs Kelly, in her answer to Senator Macdonald, said:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)On 23 June 1992, the Minister for Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories announced from 1 July 1993 the Commonwealth Government will introduce fees for commercial use of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. These charges are to recover part of the cost of providing services and are not a `reef tax'. The final details of the scheme have not yet been settled—
I am sure this answer has already been given to Senator Macdonald—
and negotiations with industry are continuing on the final form the charge will take.
(2)The Minister has given an undertaking that the charges will recover part of the cost of providing service through research, education, and management.
The answer goes on but, as I say, Senator Macdonald already has it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do acknowledge that I have that answer, but it indicates the fees will start on 1 July, which is the date I did not hear the Minister mention a minute ago. He did say it; I just did not hear it. I was wanting to know whether those rules are likely to be promulgated prior to 30 March.

—I hope that by now Senator Macdonald has had a chance to read that report; I suspect he may not have. My advice is that we will have to legislate for these charges. So they will not be done in Victorian style; they will not be done in the dark of the night.

—I will leave that point there, simply with the observation that, true to form, this Government will not give small businessmen the details of that new tax until after the election. That is the way this Government operates.

PARA.TAB: The Whitehouse Report—which, for Senator Bolkus's edification, is specifically reserved—was about an investigation into the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority's involvement in the Magnetic Quays project off Townsville. There was some controversy about that. I have received an answer to some of the questions that I raised. I would like the Minister and his advisers to indicate to me where this now leaves the Magnetic Quays project. Is it to be left in its current state or is it to be dealt with by GBRMPA or anyone else? What is the position of that development and what is likely to happen to it?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is important to distinguish between the issue of the Whitehouse Report and the question of the future of the site. That future is being examined by the Queensland Government and the Authority. It is premature at this stage to try to anticipate any finality to those considerations. I am informed that consideration of the future of the site is separate from the Whitehouse Report which, I believe, went to issues of insurance, assessment and issuance of the permit relating to the site. The future of the site is under active consideration now.

—It is a matter of very great interest to the people of Townsville and Magnetic Island in particular. I had hoped that the Minister might have been able to assist those people by giving some indication of when some finality might be reached with that project.

—I cannot be more definite, but I can say that the last time I was in Townsville it was an issue raised by some people I met there. It is obviously an issue that is of concern to those people and that concern is very much at the forefront of the considerations of this Government and the Queensland Government.

—On the matter of the insurance policy which has been raised by Senator Macdonald, a series of letters were written by the environment officer for GBRMPA in relation to the insurance policy which passed between that officer and the developer in 1988. A letter of 4 August set out eight conditions which had not been met in the draft of the insurance policy. Ten days later we find that the Acting Chairman of GBRMPA was giving permission for the development to go ahead. We now know that the development failed, precisely because the insurance policy was not properly in place.

PARA.TAB: The local residents took the matter before the AAT and those relevant letters were not put before the AAT. It appears as though they were also not put before the Whitehouse Committee. Can the Minister explain why those letters were not put before the Whitehouse Committee? Therefore, the Whitehouse Committee report is not a full and proper report in relation to that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will have to take Senator Coulter's question on notice and come back with a considered answer.

—If the Minister cannot answer this question now, I would be obliged to receive a response at some later stage. I refer to the reallocation of moneys announced by the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) on Friday to a number of programs, including community, heritage and sports facilities. It was announced that the Government had decided to provide $20m for community, heritage and sports facilities. What formula is being used for the disbursement of this money to the States?
—Marginal seats strategy.
—We haven't got any these days.

—I am trying to find out what formula is being used. Will the Minister give a guarantee that the formula used in the One Nation statement involving $20m for the restoration of heritage buildings is not used? I remind the Committee that that formula resulted in Queensland—which has half the number of World Heritage buildings as Tasmania—receiving seven times the amount allocated to Tasmania. If the Minister has the information, I would be obliged to receive it at some stage.

—I would be surprised if the Minister had any information at the moment because we are on subprogram 5.10, which deals with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. It might have come under subprogram 4.2, but we were dealing with that some time on Friday morning.
—I will take it on notice, even though it does not come under this part of the proceedings. I will provide an answer to Senator Harradine.
—It is in the general vicinity of Queensland.
—If there are no further questions on subprogram 5.10, subprograms 6.2 and 6.3 are mentioned together, so we will take any part of those.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a number of questions and issues that arose from the Estimates Committee considerations. I am pleased to see that Senator Coulter is still in the chamber taking a latter-day interest in the appropriations. In view of the very important national parks that are located on both Cocos and Christmas Islands and the very significant impact on those national parks as a result of the Government's proposed expenditure programs, I sincerely trust that the Australian Democrats will take a very keen interest in these appropriations.

PARA.TAB: I think the Government is planning something like $130m worth of capital works and infrastructure program on Christmas Island, some $42m of which has already been committed to the next few years of the first stage of that program. Of course, we see a very expansive annual budget—I think it now exceeds some $30m per annum—in each of these communities. Honourable senators will note, from the reservations that I have expressed and that I wish to take up, that many of these impinge on the environmental aspects of these important islands, whether it is casinos, the way in which freight and stevedoring will operate, or the commercial activities on the islands.

I refer to the first reservation that I have expressed. That relates to the completion date of the Christmas Island casino development. This is an important development that is being developed principally by Indonesian interests. I think the last estimate that I heard for the construction cost of the casino itself was in the order of $50m or $60m. There has been an ongoing saga of construction delays with regard to this project. In early September I put a question on notice, to which I received a reply in October. I asked for now proposed revised completion dates of that casino, the reasons for the delay, and various other police matters that I want to raise separately.

I come back to this continuing moving feast of a saga with regard to the completion dates. I would like to ascertain, given that the date has now moved out and is being suggested in answer No. 1 of the questions on notice to be in approximately April or May 1993, what revision that will require to the estimates of income that have been put forward in the Budget Estimates for this current financial year. What will be the change in the estimates of income that will attribute to the Commonwealth in this financial year?

Whilst one of the answers to questions on notice recognised that there would also be savings to the Commonwealth in costs for regulation of the casino, I would also ask: what will be the savings to the Commonwealth in those administrative areas? So it is both sides of the ledger: to what extent are we going to see income reductions flowing through to the Commonwealth, and to what extent are we going to see less expenditure in the areas of Commonwealth administration?

TALK.START.PARA: —I will take both those questions on notice and give as concise an answer as possible to Senator Tambling. Obviously, we will have to check through records and talk to other people, I presume, to get accurate figures.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed in the Minister's answer, given the extent of the answer that was given to the question on notice which has been before the Government since early September. I would have felt that the Department would have been well-briefed and that these matters would have been well-known to the Minister at this time, particularly as there has been quite a keen interest in the development of this casino.

PARA.TAB: However, I will turn to my second reservation. That relates to Australian Federal Police investigations with regard to this particular operation. I have raised this matter now, I think, for several years in both the Estimates Committee hearings and in the Senate, and I have been very concerned. This matter goes back to 1991. I know that the parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, which was looking into a reference on legal casinos and organised criminal activity, reported to this Parliament in June of 1992. Essentially, in June of 1992, that parliamentary Committee decided to put on hold the determination of its inquiry into casino activity throughout Australia. As part of its conclusions, the Committee stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee emphasises that it is not terminating its inquiry. Early in the next Parliament the Committee will review the decision to suspend its inquiry. In doing so, it will take into account any action by governments in response to the NSW and NCA Inquiries, and whether the Royal Commission has reported and sufficient time has elapsed for its findings to be acted upon.

So, we can anticipate that early in the next Parliament, the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority will again be looking at this matter. Given that I have had questions before the Estimates Committee and the Department and before the Senate since well into early 1992, I am concerned about the answer to my question about what further inquiries were going on. The answer that was given to me was:

The Australian Federal Police is carrying out revised security clearances for all parties involved in the resort casino project. The AFP has advised that its overseas inquiries have been completed and a report is presently being prepared.

Given that that answer was drafted and presented over a month ago, I would now like to ascertain what further reporting has been made to the Government with regard to these Australian Federal Police inquiries. What has been their outcome? How is it going to impact on the operation and the starting up of the casino on Christmas Island?

TALK.START.PARA: —The piece of paper I have been given does not go to that question. The question basically is: have we been advised by the AFP since late September when it was supposed to have finalised its overseas inquiries? The last part goes to revised completion dates and savings. The advice that Senator Tambling has been given is that the AFP has advised that it intends to finalise overseas inquiries by late September 1992. All other inquiries have been concluded. In fact, I might give this whole answer, just to put it in context.

PARA.TAB: Over the last few years checks have been carried out on all the major individuals and companies associated with the casino by the AFP, the Foreign Investment Review Board and the National Crime Authority. Revised security clearances have only recently been completed by the AFP. It should be noted that details of these inquiries are, as usual, confidential to the AFP. However, I am advised that the broad outcome is that during the extensive inquiries, both in Australia and overseas, no evidence indicated that any of the persons or companies involved with the casino were unsuitable.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer that was just given to me is, I think, in similar words to one that was given to me either in the March Estimates this year or the September Estimates last year. I would ask the Minister to confirm that the answer that he has just given is in response to the round of inquiries that, I understand, have very recently been completed by the Australian Federal Police and is not, in fact, a regurgitation of the previous or earlier inquiries.
—My advice is that the statement I just made is the broad outcome of those inquiries that have been completed.

—I thank the Minister. I would therefore ask whether he is in a position now to confirm that the completion date and commencement date for activities of the Christmas Island casino will, in fact, finally be held to the date of April-May 1993.
—That is what we anticipate.
—I want to make a very brief comment. I am fascinated by Senator Tambling's interest in the environment and particularly a rare, threatened and endangered species—namely, Indonesian casino operators.
—I suppose we need a little humour when we are sitting so long in committee on the consideration of the Estimates.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I certainly challenge Senator Coulter to take advantage of his position as Leader of the Australian Democrats and pay a visit to both Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. I am sure that he will find many endangered species there—not just Indonesian operators but ones in which he normally takes a more traditional interest.

PARA.TAB: I placed on notice a series of questions relating to the operation of Indian Ocean Airlines, which is a company that was to operate the air freight and air passenger services to both the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island. I received a series of very comprehensive answers. Again, given that these questions were placed on notice in very early September and answers were received in October, I understand that there have subsequently been a number of changes to this operation.

I understand that Indian Ocean Airlines is no longer operating the service to the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island and that different arrangements have had to be set in place. I therefore ask the Minister: when did Indian Ocean Airlines cease operating to both the Cocos Islands and Christmas Island? What alternative arrangements have been set in place?

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to read a five-paragraph statement that has been forwarded to me, which is information from the Department. Indian Ocean Airlines began operating the air service to Christmas Island and the Cocos (Keeling) Islands in June 1992 under an agreement with the Commonwealth, which Senator Tambling knows about. IOA did not provide the service required under the agreement, in part due to delays in bringing its plane, an Electra, into service. The last service provided by IOA was on 19 September 1992. The agreement was discharged by the Commonwealth on 7 October 1992, and the Department has since been responsible for the air service, which is being provided by Ansett on a charter basis.

PARA.TAB: The options for longer term arrangements are now being considered. The net costs to the Commonwealth for the interim period will depend on ticket sales and freight charges. Given that the agreement with IOA has been the subject of legal action by the Commonwealth—Senator Tambling has played by this rule—it would be inappropriate to comment on the legal issues involved. It would also be inappropriate to comment on the reasons for IOA's inability to provide the service required under the agreement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What alternative arrangements have now been put in place? Are those alternative arrangements at any cost to the Commonwealth?

—I answered part of that question when I said that the Department has since been responsible for the air service, which is being provided by Ansett on a charter basis. The net costs to the Commonwealth for the interim period will depend on ticket sales and freight charges. I am told that two flights a week are being conducted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —That does not satisfactorily answer my question about the anticipated costs to the Commonwealth in a financial year. We are addressing the Appropriations. It is important to ascertain that the Commonwealth has either made provision in these budget items for the provision of this service or, alternatively, will be in a position to seek additional appropriations if necessary.

PARA.TAB: I would certainly not want to see any depreciation of service to the residents of Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. As the Minister is aware, they are part of my electorate, Mr Snowdon's electorate and Senator Collins's electorate. But, more importantly, I know that the isolation felt by the residents of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands and Christmas Island can often be compounded at times when either the freight services or the passenger services are in any way interrupted.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is another area that Mr Snowdon has often talked to me about. I quite appreciate the number of times he goes to Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands, because it means that I do not get my compulsory five phone calls a weekend from him. I always know when Warren is on Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. But it is obviously an issue which concerns him and others in the Territory.

PARA.TAB: My advice is that the Department does anticipate meeting its costs. We also share the concern that Senator Tambling has demonstrated that services not be reduced to the islanders in the meantime. I have some further advice that needs to go on the record. I presume the basis of that is that it does not mean that we may not have to come back for further Estimates because of the time between expenditure and receipt. The basic advice is that the Department anticipates meeting the costs involved.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to note the number of times that Mr Snowdon visits the islands. Coincidentally, it usually happens to be when a RAAF VIP flight visits the islands. Therefore, it draws the comparison with the services that are available to the electors of both Christmas Island and the Cocos Islands. I certainly monitor Mr Snowdon's activities on the islands. He seems to get many more trips to the islands with any Minister who happens to be visiting than I do.

PARA.TAB: By the same token, I put on the record my thanks to Senator Robert Ray, who made available the provision of a VIP flight to me, Mr Bruce Lloyd, Mr Fred Chaney and other members of our party earlier this year for a specific visit to both islands. That again really highlighted to us the inconvenience that is often experienced by the residents of the islands and the degree of the particular service.

I will conclude with a question relating to the issue of freight services and their volumes, particularly to the Cocos Islands. I am aware that this has been a continuing problem with regard to the Cocos (Keeling) cooperative and the allocations of freight volumes, particularly as it affects perishables to both those islands. Have the new arrangements on the charter adequately and properly ensured that all mail, medical supplies, perishables, machine parts relating to island operations and general cargo are able to be transported conveniently to both islands?

TALK.START.PARA: —I understood most of that question, as did the departmental officers. Was Senator Tambling seeking assurances in respect of some of that freight, or was he just seeking a priority list?

—I was seeking to ensure that the provision of services, particularly for mail, medical supplies, perishables for the major supermarkets, urgent machine parts and general cargo are able to be transported conveniently and regularly, particularly without frustration, to meet the requirements of the Cocos (Keeling) cooperative.
—I am assured that that has been the priority since 1 June 1992 and, apart from one occasion, that priority has been met in terms of servicing the people on the islands.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —The final issue relates to the administration of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. Has an appointment been made, or is an appointment imminent, of a new Administrator? Is the Minister in a position to give any details of that appointment?
—My advice is that it is imminent. It has not been made public, but it should be made public shortly. I am in no position at the moment to announce it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek to ascertain whether, in the selection criteria for the appointment of an Administrator, normal and proper Public Service requirements have been met. Or is the appointment one of political patronage?
—Without taking the bait, it is not a Public Service appointment.

—In that instance, I would seek to ascertain what criteria the Minister would use for any appointment outside the Public Service, given that the retiring Administrator was a former member of this Federal Parliament but the appointments previous to that were from within the Public Service. I am also aware that appointments to Christmas Island have tended to alternate between Public Service and outside. I am really seeking to ascertain the basis on which the Minister would make a selection. It would concern me, for example, if an administrator were appointed from a Minister's electorate without due regard to the public ramifications and particular implications.

—I do not think it is a South Australian who has been appointed. I know that the Government's approach is to ensure that we get a sufficiently talented person to act in the job and also to ensure that the islands remain on the important policy agenda for Australian governments.
—Are there any matters relating to subprogram 7.3?

—Interestingly, within the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories portfolio we find appropriations for the National Media Liaison Service, which is colloquially referred to as the aNiMaLS. I raise with some concern the role that the aNiMaLS takes in political matters in Australia. The NMLS is funded by the appropriations within this Department and it seems that often it is used for purely political purposes.

PARA.TAB: In October 1989 Mr Jim Devine from the office of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy wrote to the office of the then Opposition Leader in Queensland, Mr Wayne Goss, and indicated that the National Media Liaison Service stood ready to assist in whatever way was possible during the State election campaign in 1989. He indicated that he was prepared to assist State candidates; and he indicated to where those candidates should direct inquiries regarding cuttings. He also indicated—this was at the time of the 1989 Queensland State elections—that he would seek to expand the monitoring of such issues from the National Media Liaison Service offices in Brisbane and Townsville.

That seems to me to be an entirely inappropriate and improper use of the taxpayer-funded National Media Liaison Service. It also raises questions about its operations in the city of Townsville, where I have my office. I have asked on a number of occasions that, as the National Media Liaison Service is a Commonwealth Government office, I be given the courtesy or afforded the opportunity of availing myself of the clippings services which the Service operates out of its Townsville office.

I wrote to the Minister and to the Service itself and asked whether it was supplying the information out of the Townsville media to both the Minister and to Mr Ted Lindsay, the Labor member for Herbert, and, if so, whether it would be possible to send me a copy of the information as well. It did not seem to be terribly much more onerous, having collected all that information, to send it to me as well as to those other people. I received some vague sort of comment that, when time permitted, when the Service had discharged its duties to the Minister, and if it had any time left over, it would make its clippings service available to me.

I have not heard from the Service since it consented to do this. I ask the Minister: are the appropriations that we are making of taxpayers' money in these estimates properly being used by the National Media Liaison Service? Can I get some sort of indication from the Minister as to whether the National Media Liaison Service was used in the 1992 Queensland election in view of the offer that was made for its use in the 1989 Queensland election?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the occasions that I have found myself in this position I have not had ministerial responsibility for aNiMaLS. It is interesting that Senator Macdonald should go back to 1989. Some of us have worked in this place for a long time—some for longer than others. I have been working either in here or around here since 1974. In fact, 1989 was an interesting year for me. On 15 August 1989 a then prominent, and still prominent, journalist, Laurie Oakes, wrote a piece for the Bulletin. I will quote from this article because I think it is important to have the contextual backdrop in order to analyse what aNiMaLS does and what it should be doing.

PARA.TAB: On 15 August 1989, Laurie Oakes wrote a piece in the Bulletin entitled `People in glass Houses'. He referred to the attack on aNiMaLS by then Liberal Party frontbencher, Senator Robert Hill. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . senator Robert Hill launched a full-scale attack on the aNiMaLS . . .
Robert was not the first one to do that in 1989.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hill.
—My good friend Senator Hill. What Laurie Oakes went on to say was rather interesting and it is worth while putting these paragraphs on record.
—I was asking you, not Laurie Oakes.
—We will get the context right. A little bit of information and a little bit of education will never harm anyone—least of all the honourable senator. This is what Laurie Oakes said:

PARA.TAB: So the aNiMaLS are feared—

SPEECH.PARA: that is because it does a reasonable job—

Because they are feared, they are attacked. And a good argument can be mounted that some of the things they do would be more appropriately funded by a political party than by government revenue. Unfortunately for the coalition parties, however, they are in no position to take the high moral ground because the aNiMaLS simply replaced a similar body which operated under the Fraser government. Peacock and Hill seem conveniently to have forgotten that, in some important respects—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Peacock and Senator Hill.
—I am actually quoting the article. I repeat:

SPEECH.PARA: Peacock and Hill seem conveniently to have forgotten that, in some important respects, the Fraser version—
the Prime Minister Fraser version—
called the Government Information Unit—was more blatantly party political than the Parks group is.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was that?

—`Parks', of course, refers to the former director of aNiMaLS, Mr Col Parks. That is the first point that Mr Oakes makes. Rather than read the whole lot, I seek to incorporate this article in Hansard and then refer to a couple of points out of it.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The article read as follows—

On the first day of his mock election campaign, federal Opposition leader Andrew Peacock publicly accused one of the senior journalists covering the event of being under the influence of the "thought police". This is Peacock's new name for the National Media Liaison Service (more commonly known as the aNiMaLS) which embarrasses the coalition from time to time by distributing transcripts of silly, contradictory or indiscreet statements by leading lights of the Liberals and Nationals. The journalist had discomforted Peacock by quoting one of his statements made months before.

Then, on the final day of the electioneering dry run, Liberal front-bench senator Robert Hill launched a full-scale attack on the aNiMaLS—alleging that the organisation, funded by taxpayers, had been politicised. Since former journalist Colin Parks who heads the aNiMaLS has never claimed his role is anything other than political, it was hardly a breathtaking revelation. Hill accused Parks and his staff of taking minute differences between Opposition spokesmen and "blowing them out of all proportion". It seems not to have occurred to Hill that it is political journalists and their editors—not the aNiMaLS—who determine how material in any transcript is interpreted and whether it is played up, played down or ignored.

The Opposition's paranoia about the Parks operation is not hard to understand. The Liberals have had a healthy respect for the power of the transcript and the monitored quote since the 1980 election campaign. They are convinced that an undisciplined comment about capital gains taxes made in a remote part of Australia by Labor's Senator Peter Walsh won that election for the coalition. Walsh's comment was picked up through a media monitoring operation organised by Liberal federal director Tony Eggleton. With the opinion polls showing Malcolm Fraser losing, the transcript provided the basis for a desperate but successful coalition counter-attack in the final week.

So the aNiMaLS are feared. Because they are feared, they are attacked. And a good argument can be mounted that some of things they do would be more appropriately funded by a political party than by government revenue. Unfortunately for the coalition parties, however, they are in no position to take the high moral ground because the aNiMaLS simply replaced a similar body which operated under the Fraser government. Peacock and Hill seem conveniently to have forgotten that, in some important respects, the Fraser version—called the Government Information Unit—was more blatantly party political than the Parks group is.

New evidence to illustrate this is in a document found in a file left by the GIU staff when it was disbanded by the Hawke government in 1983. Classified "confidential" and dated December 1978, the document sets out duties of GIU liaison officers to be stationed in each capital. One aspect of the role was "to monitor, analyse and report on television and radio current affairs and comment programs as they affect the Commonwealth Government in any way". That could serve just as well as a summary of the monitoring activities of the aNiMaLS. More significantly in this context, each liaison officer was to "maintain close contact with party officials in the state, keeping them fully informed of developments on the federal scene". That party was not Labor.

In April 1981, Labor's John Dawkins tabled in parliament leaked Liberal Party documents which showed how closely meshed the GIU was with the Liberal organisation. The documents were minutes and agendas of meetings at the Liberal secretariat to plan the party's 1980 election campaign and they contained references to the GIU. They showed, for example, that GIU head Vincent Matthews attended a meeting at the secretariat to plan the party's media monitoring operation—the very operation that caught Walsh out on capital gains. According to the agenda, the GIU was to liaise with Liberal campaign headquarters over monitoring. GIU officers in each state were to collaborate with state Liberal Party directors in the preparation of "political climate" reports. The GIU was to be asked to report on placement of campaign advertisements. And so on.

In November 1982, minutes of a Tasmanian Liberal Party campaign committee meeting tabled in the Senate showed that the GIU's Hobart-based officer Bruce Montgomery had attended. The meeting was to prepare the Liberal campaign for a state election. And then there was the Arnis Verbickis memo, which led to Labor allegations that the GIU was not only an appendage of the Liberal Party but engaged in a dirty tricks campaign as well. Verbickis, working for the GIU in Melbourne, penned a note on how Derryn Hinch should be handled when he interviewed Fraser or other Ministers on radio. Someone, Verbickis advised, should remain outside the studio to talk to and "disturb" Hinch's producer and researcher who would otherwise feed questions and follow-up points to him through headphones.

Peacock, of all people, should be under no illusion about the GIU's political role. In May 1982, having resigned from cabinet and preparing to challenge Fraser for the leadership, Peacock held a news conference in Melbourne. A GIU officer attended with tape recorder so that Fraser could be informed immediately of everything Peacock said.

When it was closed, the GIU had a staff of 19 and was about to increase its size to 21 by opening an office in Darwin. The aNiMaLS full-time staff totals 21. The GIU's budget for 1982-83 was $1.4 million. The cost of the aNiMaLS operation in 1986-87 was less than $1.1 million. The aNiMaLS staff members are not public servants; they are employed under the act covering ministerial staff, as were those who worked for the GIU.

So the coalition parties are in no position to throw stones. The Hawke government simply pinched their idea, though Parks' operation is without doubt more effective. There is no point in senior Liberals whingeing. If they genuinely think it is a bad thing, they can set an example by leaving all such activities to the Liberal Party organisation when they return to office. But, somehow, I think the temptation to have the taxpayers subsidise such activities will continue to prove irresistible—no matter what they say now.
The bottom line is that if shadow Ministers and senior party officials did not make silly, contradictory or indiscreet statements, the aNiMaLS would not be a problem anyway.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Oakes then goes on to look at the way that the Government Information Unit in the days of the Fraser Government not only acted in a more blatantly party political way than the current group is acting but also involved itself in intraparty fighting. He quotes an instance where, according to the agenda—the agenda which had been leaked and found after the 1980 election campaign—the head of the GIU was to liaise with the Liberal campaign headquarters over monitoring. He then goes on to refer to the GIU in Victoria and states:

SPEECH.PARA: And then there was the Arnis Verbickis memo, which led to Labor allegations that the GIU was not only an appendage of the Liberal Party but engaged in a dirty tricks campaign as well. Verbickis, working for the GIU in Melbourne, penned a note on how Derryn Hinch should be handled when he interviewed Fraser or other ministers on radio.
I suppose that note would be useful to us all now. Oakes makes the point that the GIU was involved in this level as well. He makes another interesting point in the article when he states:

Peacock, of all people, should be under no illusion about the GIU's political role. In May 1982, having resigned from cabinet and preparing to challenge Fraser for the leadership, Peacock held a news conference in Melbourne. A GIU officer attended with a tape recorder so that Fraser could be informed immediately of everything Peacock said.
In the second last paragraph, Mr Oakes draws the following conclusion:
So the coalition parties are in no position to throw stones—

alluding to the headline about people in glasshouses. Senator Macdonald went back to 1989, but unfortunately, without adequate resources or the memory that some of us have, he forgot the 1989 article written by Laurie Oakes which draws a very good and clear comparison between the roles of aNiMaLS now and the GIU then.

PARA.TAB: The other thing that Laurie would not have been able to write about then, but it is worth putting on the record now, is that, in comparison with the Fraser Government's GIU—which also employed some 19 staff—it spent some $2.25m or a massive 39.9 per cent more in 1992-93 dollar terms in its final year of operation. I am informed that this aNiMaLS operation spent some $1.354m in 1991-92. The GIU, in 1992-93 dollar terms, spent some 39.9 per cent more than that—$2.25m.

I make those two points because an organisation such as this has been a feature of government in this country for the duration of two governments—if not the Whitlam Government before that. I cannot remember that far back, although I was working here at the time. It was very much a characteristic of the Fraser Government and it involved itself in activities which, as Mr Oakes says, were blatantly more party political than the activities of the current organisation. I put that on the record for a start.

On Senator Macdonald's specific question about the 1992 election, I am informed that aNiMaLS did not involve itself in any way in that State election. On the further question Senator Macdonald raised about Mr Lindsay, my advice is that no arrangement exists with him that is outside part 8 of Senator Richardson's answer, which is the one Senator Macdonald referred to. I quote that as well:

SPEECH.PARA: Services available to yourself or to Mr Lindsay are in accordance with this paragraph:

PARA.TAB: `Neither NMLS or MMG staff provide a systematic clipping and media coverage service along the lines of services provided by commercial agencies. However, clippings are sometimes made in the course of coordinating the provision of accurate and timely information on Government policies and programs. Copies of such material can be made available to Members and Senators upon request, where ministerial obligations have been met, the material has been retained, and is known to be not readily available from other sources.'

SPEECH.PARA: My advice is that there is no special arrangement for Mr Lindsay. If he were to receive anything, it would be in accordance with that paragraph and with what is available for others across the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the unlikely event that I wanted Mr Oakes's opinion on the question, I would have asked him. I find it curious that when I ask the Minister for an answer he quotes Mr Oakes. Does that say something about the way this Government operates, interesting though Mr Oakes's opinions are?

PARA.TAB: The question was addressed to the Minister and not to the Press Gallery. My point is that, having been caught out in the 1989 election in Queensland when the Labor Party was offering the services of a taxpayer funded organisation to a Queensland political party for a Queensland State election—nothing to do with the Federal Government—in the Minister's knowledge, not Mr Oakes's opinion, was there an indication that the same was done during the 1992 Queensland State elections?

As I understand the Minister's very long answer, which was mainly irrelevant, the Minister said in the final part that the answer was no, it had not been used. If that was the Minister's answer, I thank him for telling me that in such a long-winded way. The journalists with whom I come into contact suggest to me that that was not the case and that in fact the National Media Liaison Service did play a part in the Queensland election. That is something I shall pursue. But I am interested in the Minister's commitment that that did not happen. I am sure that Minister Bolkus would not be a party to a misrepresentation of the position.

I raise a question about the Service in Townsville. I have asked it for copies of transcripts and radio interviews that it has taped which I cannot get from other sources. As I recall, I have a blanket request in to it, but I have not received anything at all. Is there some way I can avail myself of its services?

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice I have is that, apart from that blanket request by way of a letter to which I have referred, there has not been any specific request thereafter. If there has been, or if there is to be some request in the future, it should be made specifically to the organisation. My advice is that there was one blanket request by way of that correspondence I referred to earlier. Senator Macdonald received a reply to that, which basically said that if his requests could be accommodated within those guidelines they would be met.

—Could the Minister provide to me copies of all of the transcripts done by the Townsville office of the National Media Liaison Service for the six weeks before 19 September 1992, the date of the Queensland election? No doubt these transcripts have been done, so the provision of that information would not involve it in any time, effort or money. It would be very helpful to see which stories it was covering in that six weeks prior to 19 September.

—My advice is that we do not know what transcripts were done or have been retained. I refer Senator Macdonald to a letter from aNiMaLS to him dated 15 September 1991, with particular reference to the eighth guideline. My understanding is that that refers to current instances of material which might be sought and to providing them in certain circumstances. The advice I would give Senator Macdonald is that he have another look at paragraph 8 and make a request in accordance with that guideline.

—Given that the statements have been transcribed already and they would still be on file, it would cost very little to photocopy them. There is no postage involved; I can send one of my staff around to pick them up. Accepting this, what would be the objection to the organisation letting me have copies of those statements?

—I refer you, Mr Chairman, and also Senator Macdonald, to the established guidelines for this organisation. We can understand from those guidelines that there is limited access to the organisation for backbenchers—government, opposition or even Democrat. Any operation of the organisation is within those guidelines.

PARA.TAB: In respect of those guidelines, I refer Senator Macdonald to the role and functions of the organisation. There is a specific role which prohibits representatives from working with `local or State party branches and will not be involved in party programs or electoral campaigning'. It is an important limit which goes very much to the heart of the question which Senator Macdonald raised in respect of the 1992 State election.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister can understand why I do not take much notice of that. Certainly in regard to the 1989 election there was quite specific evidence, in the form of a letter, suggesting something to the contrary. So he can understand why I am somewhat sceptical of that.

PARA.TAB: Again, could the Minister indicate why it would not be appropriate for the organisation to pull out the transcripts it has done? I am sure it has the time—we have been through this before—as it has about three people in Townsville to do a job which I have indicated to the Minister my office girl does in the way of the clipping service. It seems to have plenty of people there. But if it was very busy in the lead-up to the next election, I would quite willingly let my staff go out and do the photocopying so it would not cost the organisation anything. What would be wrong with doing that? It is a publicly funded organisation. It does not do anything that is political. It only does things that are on the record.

If the Minister were to let me look at those documents it would dispel the suspicion that I have, which comes to me on advice from the media around the place, that it was in fact being used in the 1992 Queensland election campaign. If the Minister could let me have those statements maybe that would clear the matter up once and for all and would enable me to apologise for the suggestion. It would not cost anything. Sure, the guidelines are there, but why? Possibly the Minister could answer that question.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are guidelines for the organisation. The organisation is expected to work within those guidelines. I would not ask it to do other than that. I am sure the organisation will pick up what Senator Macdonald is saying in the context of this.

PARA.TAB: I should also say that the last time I was in Townsville—and this did not come from the National Media Liaison Service at the time—there was some concern in the town that Senator Macdonald was blaming aNiMaLS for dissemination of information that he might have wrongly used his resources and facilities as a senator for political purposes rather than for the purposes for which they are allowed. Maybe aNiMaLS was being blamed for the media discovering that. That came from non-aNiMaLS sources. I would hope that any attack on this organisation is not motivated by any false premise that it may have been out to get him on that basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can assure the Minister of that. I think the Minister will find that it came from the office of Mr Hulls.

PARA.TAB: Progress reported.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator West, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee E.
—On behalf of Senator Beahan, I table additional information received by Estimates Committee F.

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1992-93 and the motion moved by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, for the report of Estimates Committee C to be adopted. When the sitting of the Senate was suspended before the dinner break, the Committee was considering program 7.3 of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. The question before the Chair is that the report of Estimates Committee C be adopted. Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 7.3?
—I ask the Minister when the Audit Office last audited the National Media Liaison Service and when it is scheduled to do it next?

—That is probably a question best directed to the Audit Office in terms of when it might choose to audit the National Media Liaison Service next. My information is that it was last audited in 1989. That can be corrected if it is not right.
—Is it usual that it does not happen for three years?

—I am advised it is normal, but if the Audit Office has anything further to add then I am sure it will let us know. It is very much Audit Office processes that Senator Macdonald is inquiring about. From my understanding, no-one has told the Audit Office not to. The Audit Office operates in its normally independent way and would do so in its normal course.

—Possibly some of the questions I asked earlier would be satisfied if the Audit Office were to conduct another audit of the National Media Liaison Service. For what it is worth, could I suggest to the Audit Office that it might be an appropriate time to have another look at the National Media Liaison Service as part of its routine audits.
—I would like to ask a couple of questions about the National Media Liaison Service as we are approaching, at some time in the next few months, a Federal election.
—I wouldn't be sure of that.

—Well, the next few months, unless the Government is going to have a dictatorship, which I suppose is on the cards, and abandon elections. My understanding of the official role of the National Media Liaison Service is to disseminate government information. What I mean by that is information in respect of what the Government does in the Parliament, disseminated to the public. Does it have a role and, if so, what is that role in respect of tracking information that is disseminated by the Opposition? For example, in the event of shadow Ministers or the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson, giving a speech of some magnitude, is that transcribed and is it then sent around to all the Ministers or to the press secretaries of the various Ministers?

—I suspect this question has been answered and is very much on the public record. One of the roles of aNiMaLS is to monitor local media to provide media summaries. In terms of its roles and functions, it is spelt out that monitoring, however, is secondary in importance to active information dissemination. I think it is fair to say that if Dr Hewson, the Opposition, the Government or the Democrats make some assessment, amongst others, of government policies and programs, then the monitoring process comes into play.
—Could the Minister spell out for me and for the Committee the role he would perceive for the National Media Liaison Service during an election campaign?
—I expect that the organisation would act in accordance with its roles and functions. In respect of that earlier question Senator Parer asked about—
—Answer that question. That is a key question.

—It would act within its roles and functions, and those roles and functions are on the public record. In terms of dissemination of government policies and programs and in terms of the secondary role of monitoring—that role is, within its roles and functions, secondary to the role of providing accurate and timely information of government policies and programs—we would expect aNiMaLS to conduct all those roles.

PARA.TAB: I should ask Senator Parer to note, though, in respect of Dr Hewson and whether he was to make some statement or whatever, that in normal circumstances we would find that there would be no need to transcribe statements by Dr Hewson because his office would normally do everything. It would box any appearances that he makes for the press gallery in general. Of course, there are the odd occasions when its transcriptions are not up to scratch, and there has been at least one of those in recent days, but normally Dr Hewson's own staff would do the transcription.
I ask Senator Parer not to let us get precious about this. As Laurie Oakes said in that article some years ago—

TALK.START.PARA: —He is asking you, not Laurie Oakes.
—He is asking me and he is getting the answer I am giving him. The point I am making—
—He is not an apparatchik.
—We do not even know how to spell `apparatchik' in the Labor Party these days.
—Not only do I know how to spell it, I was one and very proud of it.

—The role and functions of aNiMaLS is well and truly on the public record. Its activities can in no way be hidden because they are to interact with the community, and particularly the media. So I do not know what point Senator Parer is trying to drag out of all of this. As I have said, the role of a body such as this, both in the time of this Government and for some eight, nine or 10 years beforehand with previous governments, was always recognised as being one that was legitimately funded by government.

—It was common knowledge in previous elections that the National Media Liaison Service saw as its major role the monitoring of remarks made by various members of the Opposition during an election campaign and the reporting of where there had been a slight difference of policy between the remarks of those various spokespeople.
—That would keep them busy.
—Senator Faulkner, we have a long night ahead of us.

—I want to know whether we can expect that procedure to be followed in the next election, which is obviously at odds—there is Senator Faulkner chuckling away. Those opposite are using taxpayers' money for absolutely incorrect purposes. We are trying to bring them back on the straight and narrow, and he sits there and chuckles. The question I am asking—
—I am laughing at you.

—Senator Faulkner is laughing at us because we are trying to keep those opposite honest. Senator Faulkner would not know the meaning of that word, coming as he does from the party machine of the New South Wales Labor Party. There is a perpetual battle going on between the Right and the Left—and he represents the Left. It is a pity the National Media Liaison Service did not monitor that lot.
—When you lose the next election, you should become a comedian.
—It is going to be a very long night if we go along this way. Quite honestly, after finishing at 6 o'clock on Friday morning, I am not looking forward to another long one.

—Thank you very much, Mr Chairman. I am pleased to hear a bit of commonsense coming from the Chair—do not misinterpret that remark. I want to get a clear statement from the Minister that the sorts of things we saw in the past, which were definitely at odds with the intended role of the National Media Liaison Service, will not be repeated in the coming election campaign.

—As I have said, let us not get too precious. The aNiMaLS has a role of dissemination of information. It also has a secondary role of monitoring. No-one is suggesting that what it has done there is anything unprecedented. Let me also put it in some degree of context for Senator Parer because it is very easy to feign indignation and stand on moral rights and take a high moral ground. But we are talking about the function that has been performed for some two decades now by governments of all persuasions.

PARA.TAB: But also, I pay the bills, I suppose. I am in charge of paying for services and functions of members of parliament. Although the point I am about to make does not come precisely within this Department, it relates very clearly and directly to the role of aNiMaLS. I received some correspondence a few months ago from Dr Hewson asking for a huge addition to his empire of staff of some 30 or 40—I am not sure what the numbers were, but I would have run out of fingers and toes in counting how many extra staff he needed. But we gave him some extra staff and, through that, we have set up an organisation called the coalition media unit. Do those opposite know what that organisation does? In the context of the law and order campaign, one of the many campaigns that has been set alight—

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't have an office in Townsville.

—No, but that is Senator Macdonald's problem. If he were effective in his shadow ministry, then he would ensure that that organisation did have an office in Townsville; he should lobby sufficiently through his Leader to ensure that that is done. But the coalition media unit for some reason on 4 June 1992—in the context of that law and order campaign that was about to be started here in which we on this side of parliament were going to be blamed for all sorts of things—boxed an article entitled, `Mugger preyed on elderly, court told'. Laurie Oakes said that people in glasshouses, et cetera. The only point I make is that if Senator Parer wants to come in here and stand on moral indignation, let me say just one thing to him: coalition parties are in no position to throw stones.

—I would like to take up some of the important issues that Senator Bolkus has raised with us this evening. So that we can be up-to-date and make sure that we have the latest information on the roles and functions of aNiMaLS, could Senator Bolkus incorporate that information in the Hansard record, Mr Chairman?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only will I do that, Mr Chairman, but also I will seek to have incorporated in Hansard the role and functions of aNiMaLS and the advertisements for a media assistant for the coalition media unit—to indicate that we are not just talking about one side of parliament having government resources available to it. I will also incorporate an article by Tony Parkinson and one by Michael Gordon referring to the sorts of functions conducted by the Opposition media unit. I seek leave to have those incorporated.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: For the purposes of Section 13(1) of the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act 1984, members of the Ministerial Media Group (MMG) are employed under an agreement in writing by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories as if they were a member of the staff of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

In fulfilling the role and functions approved by the Government to be undertaken by the National Media Liaison Service, staff of the National Media Liaison Service on a day-to-day basis shall be subject to the direction of the Director of the Ministerial Media Group.
(a)To provide accurate and timely information on Government policies and programs to the media throughout Australia as well as information on policies to interest groups within electorates.

(b)Representatives in each of the State capitals, Darwin and Townsville, should co-operate with Ministerial staff to co-ordinate media arrangements but not have direct responsibility for arranging itineraries.
(c)State representatives are to provide local members of all Parties with details of Government programs.
(d)Representatives will not work with local or state Party branches and will not be involved in Party programs nor electoral campaigning.
(e)To co-ordinate the distribution of detailed information on Government policies and programs from the information units of various departments to the local media.
(f)To monitor local media to provide media summaries. Monitoring, however, is secondary in importance to active information dissemination.

PARA.EMPHASIS: Office of Dr John Hewson MP

SPEECH.PARA: Coalition Media Unit
ASSISTANT
The Coalition Media Unit services the media requirements of the Shadow Ministry and assists Shadow Ministers and Coalition Senators and Members with media liaison.

The Unit requires the services of a highly motivated person to assist with the day-to-day activities of the Unit and to support the media liaison officers. The duties of the vacant position will include:
.Typing and transcription duties;
.Assistance with the circulation of media releases;
.Assistance with the flow of information between the media, Shadow Ministers, and the Media Unit;
.File management and other administrative duties, as directed.

The Unit is located in Dr Hewson's Parliament House office and the successful applicant will work as part of a small team. Officers of the unit work in close co-operation with Dr Hewson's media staff.

The position would suit a person with a keen interest in media relations and with good organisational ability. Word processing skills are essential and previous experience with transcription work would be an advantage.
Applications should be made in writing to:

Parliament House

PARA.EMPHASIS: Hewson admits his staffers planted `dirt file'

SPEECH.PARA: by TONY PARKINSON

THE Leader of the federal Opposition, Dr Hewson, confirmed for the first time last night that coalition staffers were responsible for distributing anonymously documents aimed at supporting Dr Hewson's accusations about the Labor Party's NSW Right.

In his first step backwards since the furore over his remarks comparing the NSW right to the Mafia, Dr Hewson said it had been a mistake to attempt to circulate the so-called "dirt file" on the activities of members of the NSW right last Friday.
Until yesterday, Dr Hewson had denied all knowledge off the thick wad of documents left mysteriously in the mail boxes of the parliamentary press gallery in Canberra.
But last night he told the ABC's Lateline program he had since established that "enthusiastic staffers" were responsible.

Acknowledging how this could be seen as an orchestrated smear campaign against the faction to which the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, belongs, Dr Hewson described it as a "silly exercise" and denied it was part of Coalition strategy.
It was during a censure motion against the Speaker, Mr Leo MacLeay, over his conduct of proceedings in Parliament last Thursday that Dr Hewson attacked.
Yesterday, Dr Hewson was still refusing to withdraw his accusations, in which he had said the NSW Right stretched from "our jails in certain parts of the country right through to the top office".
Mr Keating has challenged Dr Hewson either to withdraw the allegations or repeat them outside Parliament so Mr Keating and other members of the faction would have recourse to legal action.
But in interviews yesterday, Dr Hewson again refused to do either.
Mr Keating had used Parliament to make otherwise defamatory remarks: "He has called me a supporter of apartheid in South Africa, a cheat and a fraud.
The Opposition accused Mr MacLeay of bias and said this had become more noticeable since Mr Keating became Prime Minister.
Last night, Mr Keating staunchly defended Mr MacLeay, despite a belief even on the part of some within the ALP that the Speaker's performance had been inept.

Mr MacLeay's performance was "as impartial as it ought to be". Mr Keating conceded the NSW right had been subjected to allegations of bashing "but so what in terms of all the good people that are part and parcel of the Labor Party in NSW".
A MORGAN Gallup Poll to be published today shows the Federal Government continues to narrow the gap in public support between itself and the Coalition.
The poll, to be published in Time, shows support for the Government rose half a percentage point last month to 40 per cent. Coalition support fell 1 to 44.5.
The approval rating of the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, rose 1 more point to 40 per cent. His disapproval rating fell for the first time since February, from 48 to 47.
Dr Hewson's approval and disapproval ratings stayed 50 and 35 per cent.
On who would make the better prime minister, Mr Keating fell 1 point to 42 per cent. Dr Hewson stayed at 44.
But another poll, by AGB Australia to be published in The Bulletin this week, shows the federal Coalition increased its lead over the Federal Government.
The AGB poll shows support for the Government has fallen 1 point to 43 per cent while the Coalition has climbed 1 to 44.SUNDAY AGE (VIC)
April 5, 1992

MICHAEL GORDON

The press office of the Opposition Leader is also a single-issue publishing house. Barely a day passes without the release of at least one weighty new title, well-documented, illustrated with tables and graphs and usually including an appendix of primary and secondary-source material.
This week's official publications included `Documenting the risks, III', the third in an uncompelling series called `Where is the money coming from?'. It sank without trace.

If politics is a war and press releases are the bullets, then the Opposition is perhaps the most heavily armed, but least efficient, unit in history. Like Iraqi Scuds, its missiles tend to fall short of their target. `Dad's Army' had a better hit rate.

While Paul Keating has been stripping the political debate to its barest essentials—crudely and often unfairly reducing Dr Hewson's 800-page Fightback strategy to the impost of a new tax and an assault on unions—the publishing unit has been tackling such accessible concepts as unfunded sales tax concessions to small business.
But, according to one well-placed observer, "it just hasn't hit. No one understands `net endogenous imports' or the `GDP price deflator'. Everyone understands sleaze.

So it was that this week, after surrendering the parliamentary ascendancy to one who relies on raw political instinct more than any other PM before him, John Hewson decided to hit back and opt for sleaze.
His "Mafia" description of the Prime Minister's faction, the New South Wales Right, was no top-of-the-head rhetorical flourish.

It was planned in advance as a kind of if-you-can't-beat-them-join-them response to a Prime Minister who, according to one on the coalition's side, has lately appeared "virile, aggressive and powerful".
It was followed, coincidentally, by the release of an unofficial publication, a wad of material on the faction's past deeds, material dropped into the boxes of the parliamentary press gallery.

The bulk of it was made up of press clippings, but in my own case (and probably the case of others) it included confidential documents including the police record of an interview with Peter Baldwin, now a federal minister, after his bashing in Sydney in 1980.
Then a state politician, Mr Baldwin had been investigating alleged corruption in some ALP branches.

Dr Hewson's office has distanced itself from the release of material, but sees political capital in Mr Keating's membership of the faction and has no concern about pursuing the matter when Parliament resumes.

In stooping to the parliamentary invective he railed against on his arrival as Liberal leader, Dr Hewson is doing more than sullying the image of the political cleanskin, an image that was slipping anyway as he established himself as an adept performer on the hustings.

In an immediate sense, the effect has been to dull the impact of an extraordinary, and justified, attack on the partiality and competence of the speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Leo McLeay, a factional ally of Mr Keating who is seen by a number in his party as an embarrassment in the position.
In a broader sense, Dr Hewson allowed Mr Keating to again divert attention from the main game: the economy and the level of unemployment.
The attack was seen by Labor strategists as a massive mistake by a thin-skinned and increasingly brittle Opposition Leader.

But there is also danger for Mr Keating, whose disproportionate response guaranteed a bigger spotlight on the remarks (and the record and reputation of the faction) than would otherwise have been the case.

The escalation of bitterness between the two leaders carries the danger of diminishing the public regard for both sides, but things are likely to get more intense, not less, in the final days before Saturday's Wills byelection.
As one in the Hewson camp was heard to remark of Dr Hewson's Mafia jibe: "I think it's the smartest thing he has said in months.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first department to be considered is the Department of Administrative Services. There being no questions on matters before program 1, we will move to program 1—commercial services.

—I refer to the report of Estimates Committee D. The Committee noted that some DAS business units had attracted criticism from competitors in the private sector. Could the Minister spell out to me what those costs are that do not exist in the private sector?

—There are a number of costs which DAS services have to meet, which costs are not those that are normally met by the private sector. For instance, there are the costs of accountability through mechanisms such as this; costs of accountability to Ministers; costs of meeting occupational health and safety provisions, EEO provisions and provisions pertaining to the public sector in general; and costs of superannuation. For example, we pay award rates and conditions in the Commonwealth car area where our competitors, more often than not, are private contractors. So there is a whole host of costs that add up to at least 5 to 8 per cent of running costs when one calculates the actual level of them.

—I thank the Minister for that response. I would be the first to recognise that this has become prominent in recent years, when the various departments in government have been untied from DAS, and that three or four years ago, for instance, a lot of the work that is currently going out for tender would have automatically been done by DAS, and this is part of the commercialisation process. I do recognise that. But the argument put by the private sector is that the commercial operations in DAS do not pay things like sales tax, fuel excise on the Department's vehicles, or payroll tax. One area that is of some concern—and I will come to it later when we come to Comcar—is the degree, if any, to which the commercial operations of DAS comply with State laws.

—I will take the tax aspect first. Following on from the previous question asked by Senator Parer, not only does the Department have those extra costs, but also it should be recognised that the degree of non-Commonwealth work carried out by DAS is, under the Constitution, limited to the exhausting of surplus capacity resulting from the servicing of the needs of the Commonwealth. I think it was Senator Parer in the Estimates committee process who said that in this area we are talking more about a problem of perception rather than reality. There were a couple of quotes to that extent during the committee process which I think basically summed up and reflected the situation pretty well.

PARA.TAB: Not only do we talk about market rates, but our guidelines require that we meet the provisions of the Trade Practices Act. As a general policy, DAS meets relevant Commonwealth sales tax, customs duties or excise when undertaking non-Commonwealth work. There are some exemptions when the level of work involved is insufficient to warrant such payments. In those circumstances, our market rates prevent any unfair advantage.

In respect of State tax and charges, I have decided that where DAS groups undertake non-Commonwealth work an amount equivalent to the relevant State taxes should be set aside so that these costs are reflected on each business's bottom line. We are in the process of making arrangements to implement this change at the moment.

With respect to other laws of States, we are in the same position as any other Federal Government department, and that is that we have no legal obligation to meet the requirements of State legislation. There was a case recently which was settled before it went to the High Court. As one of the terms of settlement, I agreed that we should pay a pro rata amount to the New South Wales Government in terms of the Commonwealth car fleet and its operation to the extent that it does private work in New South Wales. But I think, as a general rule, the Commonwealth has always accepted the fact that, when it comes to provision of car parking or whatever, we are immune from the levying of State requirements, and that comes from the Constitution.

PARA.TAB: The basic point is that we do not have to comply with State requirements. It would be very difficult for an organisation such as ours that has been around for a while operating nationally to be precluded from using a name because of an isolated operator in one part of Australia. I will take on board the point that Senator Parer raises and see whether there is any way we can prevent this in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —The remark I made was, in fact, made by the organisation itself. I think the plumbing service said that, because of the confusion, it received some sort of tender papers meant for Asset Services. Of course, we have had the growth of the commercial operations in DAS encroaching into the private sector, which is causing some concern.

PARA.TAB: But, rather than dealing with a problem as it might occur in the future, we are dealing here with a person who in good faith has operated an organisation by that name and, if my memory is correct, well before the term `Asset Services' was used by ACS, going back to 1984 or 1983. Even though, constitutionally, I would have to agree with the Minister that the Government is immune and is entitled to ride over the top of that group, having gone down the track of commercialisation, I wonder whether he could address that issue and perhaps have some discussions with this operator with a view to solving what is a problem for him and his wife.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will do that. We will take the issue on board. I suggest to this operator in the meantime that he does not tender for work that we expect we might be tendering for. We will obviously talk to the people involved and see whether there is any way of resolving the issue.

—I will follow the running sheet. Although the matter I want to raise could well be covered in subprogram 1.2 or subprogram 1.3, I will raise it now under the reservation noted in this part. The Minister has touched on market price. I asked in the Estimates Committee hearing what was meant by market price. It was fairly obvious then that there was not really a great understanding of what `market price' is except `the price we need to quote to get the business'.

PARA.TAB: During Estimates the remark was made, `Yes, quotations are made of marginal costs at times when there is surplus labour available'. I would be interested to know the extent of that. One of the great dangers of any commercial operation is that if the habit of quoting at marginal cost grows, that becomes the norm rather than the exception. It is the quickest way for organisations to go broke. We have heard numerous reports about that.

Only about a week or so ago I was told of a tender by Asset Services in Wagga Wagga to the New South Wales housing department. Tenders went out, and a price came in at $8,000. Subsequently, the successful tenderer was advised that he had been unsuccessful because DAS had come in with a price of $4,000, which would have covered only the electricity and the plumbing. These examples are growing. To what extent, and on what basis, are these quotations being made?

The Minister will recall during Estimates that we gave the example of the Lavarack Barracks. The figures quoted for work—plumbing, electrical and so on—were below the award rates of pay in Queensland. The Department was embarrassed when it said that the figures were a bit low. We talked earlier about perceptions. That is the sort of perception that must be responded to by the Department.

TALK.START.PARA: —To the extent that I do not answer Senator Parer's question, I will come back with further information. I can remember the part of the Estimates Committee hearing when the question of marginal costs arose. My understanding is that we cover direct costs plus we provide for an allocation towards profits that we have to meet.

PARA.TAB: In the case of Lavarack Barracks, my recollection is that the evidence given at that stage might have been a bit contradictory. On the one hand, it was made clear that we were already in place there. It would have cost much less for us to do the work than, I suppose, competitors, because we had people stationed there already and there would not have been costs related to transport and those sorts of things.

The officers then went on to say that we were talking about marginal costs; that is my recollection, and I think it is also Senator Parer's recollection. The general rule is that we cover direct costs plus a profit margin. Senator Parer is basically asking to what extent that is not operating. To the extent that it is not, I will come back to him. But as a general rule applied almost universally, that direct cost assessment is the way that we are going.

A number of assertions have been put to me about unfair competition from Administrative Services. I see that very much as a question of perception rather than reality, although all instances are being closely scrutinised. In this context—and Senator Parer was gracious enough to make the point at the start—whereas some two, three or four years ago all the work that we are talking about now would have been conducted by Administrative Services or its predecessors, some 70 per cent of the work we now do is open to competition. By the end of this financial year it will be as high as 95 per cent.

There are now massive opportunities for the private sector that were not there before. I say that for two reasons. First, it gives the private sector opportunities, and I wish it would take them up rather than expend energy grizzling about them. Secondly, I see this process as being a successful one in that, as Senator Parer knows, it has led to massive savings to government over recent years—some $200m or so per annum. The imperative of competition is being applied to work that was previously tied work. As an experiment, it is working well. I throw out the challenge to the private sector to go in and compete with us, because through that competition both the private sector and the public sector will develop.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and I accept what he said. I am pursuing this line of questioning because the private sector wants to determine whether it is worth meeting the cost of quoting if the quotes submitted by DAS do not reflect its cost or the market cost. I would be interested in the response, which I do not want now but at some later date, as to what percentage of work done by the various commercial sectors of DAS would be considered to be in accordance with the description the Minister gave, which was costs plus mark-up or reasonable profit—whatever he likes to call it.

PARA.TAB: I have another question relating to the whole commercial area of DAS. Some 600 or so people who are superfluous to the commercial operations of DAS have been transferred to another section of DAS. There is provision within the Estimates of either some $50m or $70m to cover those people; I am not too sure whether that would be for redundancies or continuing salaries. I would be interested to know what sort of work the people who have been transferred out of the commercial sector are currently doing. I will give the Minister my reasons for pursuing that line of questioning.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Parer's question might be a bit premature. We are still going through that process of identification of staff in different areas of the Department. As yet, they have not been transferred out of the business units. As that process continues, not only will those people be identified but also the areas to which they go and the work they do will be identified.

—I thank the Minister.
