Presumably because there is provision within the Forward Estimates of the Budget to cater for those people, the various commercial sectors of DAS no longer have to provide within their own budgets for the costs associated with those people whom they believe will be superfluous. This could be construed as a fairly artificial way for one of the commercial services, be it Asset Services, Project Services or any other commercial operation, to reduce its costs of operation. They can do so by transferring staff across to another part of DAS where they sit waiting for some agreement to be made with the Public Service union.

—In the meantime, Senator Parer might acknowledge that we might be inflating the costs of those businesses by having staff who may not be fully utilised. The businesses will be charged for the staff until those staff actually leave the business areas. So the costs will be maintained and carried until that takes place. I think Senator Parer's concern is not valid.
—If there are no further questions on program 1 as a whole, we will move to subprogram 1.6.

—I have a brief question. Removals has been one of DAS's more successful operations. I am raising this issue now because it was reported to me recently that there is a battle royal going on between Removals and Distribution Services. Distribution Services is attempting to take over the role of Removals and do its work. If successful, this would be to the detriment not only of the budget of DAS but also the many private sector operators who have done work for Removals over a number of years. I would like the Minister's comment on that, because it relates to my reservation.

—My understanding was that we had already given an answer in respect of this. The answer I have does not go specifically to the question. What Senator Parer wants to know is whether Distributions and Removals have been merged or will be merged.
—Is Distributions trying to take over Removals, which is a fairly successful operation, and make it fairly unsuccessful?
—No, Distributions is not trying to take over Removals.
—Does Removals know that?
—I suspect it does now.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Burns)—Are there any matters on program 2, Quasi-commercial Services, subprogram 2.4, Comcar?

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister, firstly, why he has changed Comcar numberplates from C plates to Z plates.

—For a number of reasons, the main one being that security-wise it is better that cars are not as identifiable. I think that one of the reasons why we have historically had a system of Commonwealth cars which ensured transparency in terms of the nature of the car, its colour and numberplate was to have some sort of vetting process on those who may have been driving the cars to ensure that the cars were as actively engaged as possible.

PARA.TAB: With the introduction of the new computer system, there is no need to have that sort of enforcement basically by chance. We now have a computer system that ensures that we know where drivers are, where cars are and to what extent they are used. That has given us a bit more flexibility in reducing the level of identification of the cars involved and, as a consequence, has increased the opportunity for security over identification considerations.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am sure that if anyone were out to do some damage to someone it would not make any difference whether the car had a C plate or a Z plate. I understand that the new computer system's first day of operation around Australia was supposed to be today or yesterday. The cost of the computer system was $5.7m.
—What is the cost of the numberplates?
—It is peanuts compared to the computer system. What is the cost of changing to Z plates?
—I am informed that the cost is zero. We already had Z plates available and it was just a matter of taking some off and putting some on.
—I understand that today was the day it was supposed to go to the computer system.
—Not today in Canberra.
—Apparently they put in the wrong chip and they had to go around and pull them all out. Has the Minister heard that story?

—I am not trying to be provocative—not to Senator Parer but to the network that seems to envelop Comcar and the methodology and the bushfires that are often set, not weekly, not daily, but hourly, in that organisation—but I am informed that the right chip is in place.
—It is nice for me to be able to give the Minister information. If he goes outside, he will find that they have all been pulled out.

—When organisational change such as this is brought in, there are teething problems. What we are talking about here is its introduction into Canberra. It was introduced in Adelaide a few weeks ago and we had the same sorts of problems that have been reported all over the place. I have been talking to drivers there in recent days and they are happy with the way it is operating. I think we have teething problems with all these things.
—I understand that Mr Pocknee was contemplating the position of General Manager of Comcar, but he has since left. Has that position been filled and, if so, by whom?

—Mr Pocknee has left. I think his passing should be noted, in that he did a great job while he was with Comcar. In doing that, he had assistance from some very capable people, both in the Department in general and the Comcar organisation. One of those people before the Estimates Committee with him was Tony Robinson, who has taken over the position of Acting General Manager of Comcar. I suppose that is as much as can be said for the moment, other than that they both worked together in implementing change. I for one feel confident that Mr Robinson can continue the direction that has been developed by both him and Mr Pocknee.

—The other question, which was touched on earlier, is the movement of Comcar into the private sector. In arranged discussions I had with Mr Pocknee—the Minister might recall we arranged them through his office—he pointed out to me that it was the aim of Comcar not to chase prices down but to maintain and expand if possible its business with the Government, operations which I did not dispute, and that it had no intention of getting into the private sector.

PARA.TAB: Subsequently, because of numerous reports that came from around the countryside, people were complaining about Comcar moving into the private sector. As a result of that, I understand the New South Wales Government mounted a High Court case. The Minister referred to this earlier and said that some arrangement had been entered into between the Commonwealth and the New South Wales Government which meant that the New South Wales Government withdrew its case. I would like to know what that was, because the Minister made a remark before which I found somewhat disturbing that the arrangement was that when Comcar engaged in private work it would pay a pro rata fee. If my memory is correct, hire cars in New South Wales pay an annual fee of about $15,000 per car. If they are going into that business, they do not pay a pro rata fee; they pay a fee of $15,000 and take their chances on the amount of work they will get. What is the scheme of arrangement between Comcar and the New South Wales Government in regard to its doing private work in New South Wales or anywhere?

TALK.START.PARA: —Comcar subcontracts some 19 per cent of its work to the private sector. In return for this, in the 1991-92 financial year, we received only 0.2 per cent of our revenue from private sector work. For the September quarter of 1992, private sector work has risen to just one per cent of our revenue. So we off-load some 19 per cent of our work onto our competitors and we pick up some one per cent. Under constitutional restraints, Comcar will be able to use only its excess capacity and we will not be able to go into the market wholesale; nor would we want to. That proportion of 19 per cent of our work to the private sector and one per cent of our work from the private sector is worth keeping in mind.

PARA.TAB: The New South Wales Government took us to court. We did not proceed to a hearing; we did not proceed to judgment. We came to an agreement with the New South Wales Government. Although the amounts to be paid are confidential under that agreement, I think I can say that we will be able to operate in New South Wales. We will be able to get New South Wales Government work. We will be able to obtain private sector work. We will pay an amount of money ex gratia to New South Wales equivalent to a proportion of the licence fees that might have been payable had Comcar been subject to the State legislation.

For instance, we will not have to register every Comcar in New South Wales and pay $15,000 or whatever for each one but, to the extent that we do private sector work there, we will be paying commensurate with the work that we do. The difference between this situation and the private sector is that basically hire car companies are in the private sector and they do pay.

We will be meeting our costs in respect of New South Wales by way of an ex gratia payment to the New South Wales Government. I should also say that we are approaching all other States with a view to putting similar arrangements in place if we can reach agreement. There are other conditions to the agreement as well, but I do not know that they are sexy enough for this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister to clarify some things that were raised in the Estimates Committee about the amount of private work undertaken by Comcar. The Minister said during Estimates that it was only 0.2 per cent of the overall work, while the then General Manager, Mr Pocknee, stated that it amounted to 0.8 per cent in Perth and was worth $20,000. Assurances were given that, in effect, Comcar was not competing with the private sector in the traditional taxi market and that there were no known instances of offers being made to private firms of $150 per day.

PARA.TAB: I would like to draw the Minister's attention to the fact that, even though at that time in Estimates hearings it was said that no known offers were being made to private companies, in the latest edition of the New Era Taxi, put out by the Western Australian Taxi Operators Association, is printed a copy of a letter to the Secretary of the Association from a director of Barron Films Ltd in Perth. His company was one of the recipients of an unsolicited offer. The article stated just that, because Comcar had approached his firm and outlined a range of services. One of these `certainly did overlap with traditional taxi services'.

It is for this very reason that taxi operators, not only in Perth but all around Australia, object to competition from an organisation that is heavily subsidised by the Australian taxpayer and which tries to conceal the fact that it is seeking work at the expense of taxis. Many people are genuinely concerned about this unsolicited type of approach and also the fact that operators in the private sector are paying a lot not only for their vehicles, on which they pay tax whereas Comcar does not, as well as for their plates, whereas Comcar does not, but also for insurance and many other items.
In view of what Barron Films and many other companies are now saying, would the Minister be kind enough to explain to the Senate what the current situation is?

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said in answer to Senator Parer a few minutes ago, in 1991-92 the overall Comcar revenue received from the private sector work was 0.2 per cent. For this financial year, for instance, in the September quarter, it has risen marginally to just on one per cent of revenue.

PARA.TAB: As I said, it will always be incidental; it will be Comcar attempting to use up excess capacity. To the extent that we do that, we will have private sector customers and obviously approach private sector customers. But it is very much our intention to keep that as an incidental part of our work.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was it—an excess capacity? I missed it, sorry.

—It will be incidental to our main object of existence, that being to provide services to government. As I say, it is one per cent for the September quarter. The figure the honourable senator quoted earlier of 0.8 per cent relates to WA. That was the level of private sector work done by Comcar in WA for 1991-92, but overall across the country it was 0.2 per cent.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make two extra points that need to be made. I preface my remarks by stressing that we are talking about Comcar using our excess capacity and finding the strategic private sector customers to utilise that excess capacity only. The New South Wales High Court case ensures that some State fees and charges will be paid, and I have taken measures to ensure that that occurs—despite the fact that not only do we have the 5 to 8 per cent extra costs operating across the board to government services through DAS because of obligations we have to meet that are not met by the private sector but we also have award rates and conditions to pay whereas our private sector competitors do not. I am assured that whatever State fees and charges are not payable will be extracted from the organisation to level out the playing field once and for all.

The other point I make is that, quite honestly, I do not know where the attack is coming from. On the one hand Dr Hewson says he will not use Comcar because it is too expensive and on the other hand we have criticism saying that it is unfairly competing with the private sector because we reduce our prices. It is fair to say that we are having, and will have, only a very minor part of private sector work. We are not going out into the marketplace to take over the private sector. We are providing an elite service and charging those sorts of prices. We will continue to do so. My aim is to ensure that the organisation operates efficiently without detriment to not only the private sector, but also the public purse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could the Minister explain the 5 to 8 per cent increase in costs that the private sector does not incur?
—I did that some half an hour or so ago in answer to an earlier question.
—I obviously missed it. Would the Minister care to go over it again?
—It is best to refer Senator Knowles to the Hansard.

—I agree that Comcar is too expensive, and that is part of the problem. I am trying to highlight the fact that the private sector—whether the Minister wishes to accept it or not—is very concerned. Just because I happened not to be on duty at that time, the Minister is now too bull-headed to explain to me what the situation is. We are now back to where we were at a quarter to four this afternoon when the Minister was refusing to answer questions.

PARA.TAB: Undoubtedly, Comcar is far too expensive. That is not the drivers' fault; it is the Minister's fault and a result of his mismanagement. That is what I am trying to get at. To say that the Minister is trying to run a service is probably the under-statement of the year, but the Minister will not explain to the committee, the drivers or the taxi industry what he is trying to achieve.

Again at Estimates we heard assurances that Comcar will not put on additional vehicles for private sector work. Tonight the Minister has just said that it would be picking up the slack. He cannot explain to us how it is picking up the slack and how it is known when the slack will occur. In Estimates hearings I raised the fact that a Budget minibus with a Comcar banner and driver was seen operating around the Parmelia Hilton Hotel in late August and early September. It was admitted that Comcar quotes at a commercial rate for such services and that buses will be hired if necessary.

The answer given to me at that time was that it was obviously used to carry an entourage from Thailand around. That is fine. There is an answer. But surely once again that is work that could have been done by the private sector. What we are trying to do is get some information. Commonsense would tell us that the use of a bus in this way can only take work from private operators who have to pay registration and licence fees, sales tax on their vehicles, 26c per litre in fuel excise, payroll tax which applies to their cooperative and everything else—which, incidentally, would all go under Fightback.

I am trying to find out from the Minister why he continues to pursue this line of trying to take away the business of private sector vehicle operators at this time. We need the private sector to be buoyant and we need to have the private sector employing people; yet we need the security within Comcar. However, we have neither at the moment. Those Comcar drivers do not know whether they have a job from one day to the next, but we still cannot get answers. We have a classic example of a government agency which continually runs at a loss and tries to recoup some of this loss by unfair competition with the private sector. There is far too much anecdotal evidence that undercuts the assurances that were given in the Estimates Committee.

I cannot understand how the Minister can sit there and quite blindly say that Comcar can continue to run at a loss, which it does year after year. The Minister has that pained expression on his face; he may like to take leave from here.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sit down and I will give you an answer.

—Well, why is Comcar continuing to run at a loss? What is the Minister going to do about it? How will he stop this invasion of the private sector work? How will he give the Comcar drivers some security?

—Senator Parer has been through this step by step. I apologise to him, if to no-one else, for taking a few minutes to explain this. Comcar has gone through major restructuring. Comcar has had management consultants from the private sector brought into it. Not only did they do an assessment of Comcar's structure, but also they were kept within the organisation to implement change. That change has meant not only a restructuring of the organisation but also a reduction of some 26 to 29 management positions. It has meant a wholesale new approach to the driving side as well. It has also meant that, as an organisation that was losing a lot of taxpayers' money, through the introduction of changes to the management side, the drivers' side and the technology side, Comcar is now in a position where, within 18 months to just a bit longer than that, we will be turning it around and making a profit without an increase in charges. That is an important aspect of it.

PARA.TAB: It has been a fundamental change. It has been a change which those in the Department who have been working on it ought to take a great degree of credit for. It is a change which has meant that, for instance, from the release of the Fightback package in November last year to the time of the next election, we will have achieved some $11.5m in savings to the Commonwealth, when a promise of $10m savings would have been achieved in Fightback. That record is not only a good one but is also one which we can build on.

We have achieved the savings of Fightback. We have done so with the assistance not only of the public sector organisation that we are talking about but with the best of advice from the private sector. The Australian taxpayer will benefit as a consequence of it. We have also done so without enormous rupture to the organisation and without enormous sackings and with the cooperation of the Transport Workers Union. It is an organisation that will have saved $11.5m by the time of the next election, whenever that might be next year, but growing thereafter. It has outmatched the savings that Dr Hewson might have anticipated in his Fightback package.

TALK.START.PARA: —Parer was too conservative.

—I think Senator Parer took an approach which was commendable but we took another one which, in the spirit of the debate that we have going between us, is also recognised by Senator Parer as one that has produced results.

PARA.TAB: I will finish on this particular point. We are doing one per cent of our work in the private sector at a time when we are contracting out 19 per cent. So for every dollar we get—maybe it is not as accurate as this—maybe we are paying $19 or $20 to the private sector to do the work that Comcar could otherwise be doing if we were to expand the organisation. We are not going to do it. We are going to make the organisation run efficiently. That is what is happening. We will make sure that as the Constitution determines, we will only be doing an incidental proportion of our work in the private sector.

I have explained this a number of times at Estimates committees and I do not know what else I can do. If Senator Knowles wants a briefing to go through this at some other stage, we can organise that, without wanting to unfairly subject some of the officers involved.
Progress reported.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I declare the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1992-93, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1992-93 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1992-93 urgent Bills and move:

PARA.TAB: That the Bills be considered urgent Bills.
Question put:
That the Bills be declared urgent Bills.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That the time allotted for consideration of the Bills be till 3.30 p.m. on Tuesday, 17 November 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose the motion. It is different on every occasion—subtle differences. The one thing that is common is that we can be sure where the Democrats will be. Where are the Democrats? Despite all their pledges, on every occasion there they are in the Labor camp—locked in.
—Where have they been all night?

—Doing the deal. That is where they have been all night. Has there been any consultation with this side of the chamber? No. The deal has been done again between the Labor Party and the Australian Democrats to restrict debate in this chamber on perhaps the most important part of our business, and that is dealing with the Appropriations, dealing with public expenditure.
—Would you trust the Labor Party with money?

—As Senator Baume says, no. I would be more comfortable if the Democrats stayed over the other side, I think, rather than come back. I wonder whether we could rearrange the seating in this chamber so they could stay over there forever. As Senator Baume says, `Would you trust the Labor Party with money?'. The answer is no. Should we trust the Democrats not to do a deal with the Labor Party? No. It happens session after session, time after time. Despite all the promises and pledges of the Australian Democrats to the contrary, when Senator McMullan calls them in and says, `It is now time to roll over', they roll over and debate in this place is curtailed again. How can that be consistent with their pledge to the Australian people at every election that they will keep the Government honest? Of course, they are not interested in doing that, because at the end of each session they are put to the test and they join with the Government to guillotine debate in this chamber.

PARA.TAB: I would have thought the Democrats would have been sufficiently embarrassed by this afternoon's events not to come back for another serve tonight. This afternoon they decided, in the most unusual circumstances, to join with the Government to ensure there was not a Question Time in the chamber. We have been trying to check out the records on that. We have found that, in circumstances where there has not been agreement around the chamber, it has not happened in the last 10 years. In fact, there is some suggestion that it may never have happened. But it certainly happens with this new breed of Democrats when the Australian Labor Party goes to them and says, `Join with us because we do not want a Question Time today'. What does Senator Coulter and his folks say? They say, `We agree; no Question Time today'. When we said this afternoon that we should have the right to debate the most important matter in this nation, the Democrats went to the Labor Party again and said,`We don't wish to debate unemployment today'. We had their spokesperson, Senator Lees on this occasion, get up and say, `We do not want to debate unemployment because we do not think debates in this chamber have actually led to more jobs'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where is Senator Lees?

—Senator Lees is not here. Perhaps she is embarrassed about what she said this afternoon. Of course debates in this chamber do not lead to jobs in themselves. Debate in this chamber makes the Government accountable. Ultimately, the people make the decision and, hopefully, they throw the Government out and put in another team that will provide jobs. This country needs jobs.

PARA.TAB: So twice the Australian Democrats have embarrassed themselves today according to the standards that they advocate to the Australian people, yet deep at night again they have come in here, with no warning at all, having conspired and joined with the Labor Party again—Senator Tate nods; he knows how they operate—to put this guillotine on so that debate on the Appropriation Bills tonight is restricted.

They should be ashamed. Former Senator Chipp would be embarrassed by the way they have acted today. Even former Senator Haines would be embarrassed. Once upon a time they came to this place with some principle that they would not on every occasion join with the Government to help it with its program. This group of Australian Democrats is different. All the Government needs to do is nod. All Senator McMullan needs to do is nod and Senator Coulter says yes. If Senator McMullan says jump, Senator Coulter says, `How high?'. That is a disappointing thing for the Australian people who voted for the Australian Democrats on the last occasion. It is not surprising that when they were last put to the test in the Victorian election a month ago they got about 4 per cent of the vote or less—a pitiful vote. The Australian people have now realised that they serve no worthwhile purpose in the Australian political process. If ever we were given another demonstration of that, it is tonight.

It is disappointing that this Government is again restricting debate and not letting this chamber fulfil its proper function. But it is not surprising that we get that from this Government because it has a lot to be embarrassed about. Still to go tonight on the Estimates is the health debate, the social security debate—

TALK.START.PARA: —Primary industries.
—Primary industries, I am reminded by Senator Panizza.
—Employment.

—Employment. It would not want to debate employment because there are a million Australians out of work at the moment and another million Australians who are underemployed. There is also the Attorney-General's debate. It does not want to revisit the Burke matters, Western Australia Inc., South Australia Inc., Victoria Inc. and the loans affair. Of course, this Government wants to restrict debate because it has a lot to be embarrassed about. That, therefore, does not surprise us. What is particularly disappointing, however, is that the Government can so easily whip the Australian Democrats into line yet again.

PARA.TAB: There is only one side of this chamber that is interested in seeing this place function in the way that it was designed to function, and that is the coalition. We oppose this time restriction that is proposed to be put on this debate. That does not mean that with the proper functioning of debate we may not be finished by that time tomorrow, but honourable senators should have the right to put their case on the most important part of the Government's programs, which is the Appropriations. That is why we oppose this motion tonight in the most strenuous terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a dishonest diatribe we have just heard. If Senator Hill went back and actually looked at the record, he would find that in 1984 those former Democrat senators, whom a moment ago he just disparaged, put on a guillotine which was far more discriminatory and far more restrictive than the one we are dealing with in this motion tonight, which will give another 18 hours, until half past three tomorrow afternoon, for debate.

PARA.TAB: One of the things that perhaps Senator Hill has not told his colleagues—and he should tell them—is that last week on Wednesday and Thursday, through two whole days, we were attempting to negotiate with him to get reasonable times not only for this debate but also for the remaining Bills in this session. We looked as though we had reached agreement, and at 8 o'clock on the Thursday evening Senator Hill said to me, `Yes, we almost have the times; I will see you in half an hour and we can agree on times'. In half an hour he was not ready. The time went on until about half past 10 or 11 o'clock and, when we negated the adjournment, he said, `All bets are off'; he refused to negotiate any further. So I want to put on the record that it is simply totally untrue that we are not prepared to negotiate with the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was after the event.

—That was during the event; that was Wednesday and Thursday. It is simply not true that we are not prepared to negotiate with the Opposition. We will negotiate with members of the Opposition if they are reasonable. But if they are totally unreasonable and refuse to negotiate, we have nobody to negotiate with. To go on to half past three tomorrow afternoon is a perfectly reasonable time and, as I say, far more generous than former Senator Chipp gave them in 1984.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have just seen, particularly from Senator Coulter, must now seriously call into question the role that he has been elected to play as chairman of a special select committee of the Senate. Obviously, if he is prepared to do deals of this nature, it brings into question the entire objectivity that he will bring to bear, and we know very well that this side of the Parliament nominated Senator Sherry, a member of the Government, for the chairmanship of that particular committee. Instead, very obviously, there has been a patsy deal done behind the scenes.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter just got up and said that we had 18 hours between now and 3.30 p.m. tomorrow. Obviously, again he is going to sit here all night to achieve it. Yet Senator Coulter has come in and participated once in this Appropriations debate, and that was when Senator Macdonald raised the issue of the wet tropics. Senator Coulter came in with some ridiculous issue that had nothing to do with the financial side of the Appropriations whatsoever. There have been no other considerations brought about by the Australian Democrats.

If one looks at the running sheets for the three committees that are still to be considered and the very serious issues to be considered by this Parliament, one will see there is no way that, with this deal by the Democrats, the Committee of the Whole can properly carry out the review functions required of it.

We still have a number of unresolved issues relating to the Australian Electoral Commission. We then have the Department of Social Security—and, of course, anyone would think that the Australian Democrats had no sympathy whatsoever for the people who need the services and the proper functioning of the Department of Social Security. As Senator Hill said, we have the Attorney-General's Department and everything that comes with it. What has the Government got to hide under all of the areas that should be looked at in that particular Department, whether it is the National Crime Authority or the war crimes unit? There are just so many to come.

There is the Department of Veterans' Affairs—the veterans of Australia who will not have their issues properly and fundamentally addressed. There is the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. We all know that the Government is currently considering some pretty major changes to immigration. Obviously it has done a deal for Senator Coulter on population policies for Australia, and that must be the trade-off in that particular area.

There is the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. How many issues of that important Department have been raised? There is the Department of Education, Employment and Training; again, there is no sympathy for and no consideration of those important issues that relate and flow from employment. There is the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission where a dozen issues are already identified, such as the important financial implications of Mabo, and I certainly want to participate in that.

In addition, of course, there is the Department of Industrial Relations right towards the end. No wonder the Australian Democrats are ducking for cover and wanting to hide from that. Of course, the final department that is listed is the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We have obviously gone past the environmental considerations. The Australian Democrats did not come in and make any contribution whatsoever in the financial reviews on the environment. Just what sort of consideration are they going to give to the primary producers of Australia or the energy resources of Australia under all of the issues that have been reserved in that particular area?

Senator Coulter and his mates in the Democrats have weaseled out once again and given us no cause for any hope in this Parliament. They very obviously have become nothing more than another wing of the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President—
—Same speech?
—Virtually, I must say.
—Will it go to 10 minutes?

—History is repeating itself a little so I have not much novel to say, other than that I would certainly doubt I would go the 10 minutes. I did say here at about 10 past five last Friday morning, in a rather broad hint to Senator Hill and the rest of those opposite, when we were arguing about when we were going to get up, `Why don't you walk outside and set up a reasonable timetable?'. That did not occur and there have been no attempts since, as I understand it, to set up a reasonable timetable for this debate.

PARA.TAB: Senator Hill did pose a lot of questions, which his back bench answered. I thought that they were all going to say, `The answer is Liberal', but they have obviously forgotten that campaign. Senator Hill complains about there having been no warning. We do not often give any warning when we are about to bring in one of these particular motions—the same as Senator Hill, who consistently gets up and moves contingent notices of motion with no warning to this side. I have complained about that a couple of times. I just have to say, `Fair cop to that', seeing that tonight we have ambushed those opposite on this.

We have had the normal round of abuse of the Democrats. I will repeat what I said earlier today: I just find it a rather dualistic approach. I sit here sometimes when there are Bills up and I watch those opposite all go running around, and butter would not melt in their mouths. They are as nice as pie to the Democrats because they want to get their amendment up. As soon as they do not get an amendment up, they turn nasty. I would not have thought that this was productive in getting future amendments up. I hope it is not, but I guess those opposite will go back to their crawling mode over there soon and go and ask for support for a variety of amendments.

Why have we got to the point of moving a guillotine on this Bill? This really goes back not to this Estimates Committee of the Whole but to many others where those opposite abused the Estimates Committee process in this chamber. I have never complained about the length of time we take in Estimates committees themselves. I think we saw Estimates Committee A a year ago go 60 hours in all. That is fair enough. Sometimes we get tired of it; sometimes we question the relevance of it; but, nevertheless, it goes on.

But those opposite came in here and put up all those filibustering speeches that we heard over Thursday and Friday, repeating points and drifting away from the Chairman's ruling on what can be discussed and what cannot be discussed. On it goes, the same repetitive speeches. But, of course, we all know that once this resolution is carried, as we hope it will be, 90 per cent of those opposite will have a sly grin when they walk out of the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —You tell us this every time.

—That is right, and those opposite agree every time. I delight Senator Panizza every time. Senator Panizza knows he will be on the 4.40 flight tomorrow. When we all go home, why does he not stay to prove me wrong?
—Don't take me up on that.

—The transport officers are listening at the moment. Cancel Senator Panizza's trip back; he wants to stay. We might all kick in to put a Hansard reporter on overtime, and Senator Panizza can go for his life for five or six hours. Not many of his mates will be with him.

PARA.TAB: We had an earlier reference in another debate to saving money. This way, all the public servants will know that they do not have to hang around for another week. That does waste a lot of money.

TALK.START.PARA: —How can you say that when you kept them sitting out there all night?

—Senator Hill kept them out there. Senator Hill's contributions kept them sitting there all night. We will not have to keep them around. I must congratulate Senator Hill and Senator Tambling tonight because this debate is the first one where we have not had the great moral outrage at the guillotine. Normally, they all walk in here and say, `The guillotine is politically unacceptable and morally wrong'.
—Right.
—How many times did Senator MacGibbon vote for a guillotine in the Fraser era?
—Only once.

—We will check the record. I am willing to say right now, an even $10, that Senator MacGibbon voted for the guillotine more than once in the Fraser years. They ran up the guillotine flag and Senator MacGibbon saluted. What about Senator Teague next to him? He always has the grace to say that he did it a few times. What about Senator Archer and Senator Durack? In fact, we have four guillotiners in a row, and if Senator Lewis and Senator Walters were sitting in their right spots, we would have had seven guillotiners in the back row.

PARA.TAB: We only have one Senate guillotiner in the front row—Senator Watson, who is probably away working on the Estimates Committee questions now and not participating in this farce. We also have the three in a row here. Look at them—Senator Short, Senator Tambling and Senator Baume. All three voted for a guillotine—not here, but in the House of Representatives in the Fraser days. They all marched into the green chamber and all sat next to the rest of the Liberals guillotining legislation at will.

TALK.START.PARA: —You'll learn; you'll grow up.

—When those opposite do it to us, if they ever get the chance, I hope I do not squeal as much as Senator Crane. I know he is a bit upset about all of this because industrial relations comes towards the end. He is going to have to convince some of his colleagues not to filibuster it out, so that he can have his fair go.

PARA.TAB: As I was pointing out, we have a lot of direct guillotiners here. The last time they raised the big objection and said, absolutely outraged—I invited them all to sign the pledge—that if they ever win government they will never guillotine. I gave them up to 4 o'clock—an hour or so—to come up to my office and sign the pledge and not one of them came; not one of them bothered to turn up. I know it is a long trip and I know it is a hard office to find. I have almost got lost going there myself several times, so I can understand it.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not surprising at all.

—Let us put it this way: I am not as happy as Senator Crane tonight; we all know that. I ask those opposite: why not come up tonight and sign for no guillotine if they ever win government? They can come up and sign the petition or whatever we have that they will never go for the guillotine. We could actually halt this debate now and get on with the Estimates. I think everyone has guessed the result by this stage, but no doubt we will have the normal recidivists get up, such as myself and others, and waste another hour of the Senate's time. I think that is rather a pity.

PARA.TAB: I only want to mention one other thing. The point was raised that we did not have a Question Time today. We put our reasons down for that; the Opposition put its reasons down. However, if this guillotine passes, we will have until 3.30 to pass the Appropriation Bills; we will be happy to give the Opposition an hour out of its debating time for the Appropriations for a Question Time tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that when I first heard that speech from Senator Ray I thought it was all right; I thought it was quite clever; it ran a few nice lines. We have now heard it three or four times and it does not get any better. It is the same old speech churned out.

PARA.TAB: The issue before this chamber is really the accountability of government. We have a Budget of over $100 billion. We are taking some hours on the Appropriation Bills. The Democrats are a bit tired of it. Those in the Government do not like it too much—they find it a bit boring, a bit tedious having to come here and answer a few questions. They go over and see Senator Kernot and Senator Coulter. They work out a deal and say, `This is all a bit much. The Parliament is actually fulfilling its duty. Questions are being asked about the way the Government spends its money. It is all a bit much; we want to go home' and of course the deal is done.

I was spoken to very severely this morning by Senator Lees because I suggested that a deal had been done on the guillotine. Senator Lees got up and said that a personal explanation was required and that it was not true. And what happened? We had to wait five hours and out it comes. Maxine McKew in Order in the House was absolutely right. The deal had been done. I was right this morning; the deal had been done and here we go again.

Let me put a few facts on the table because I think it is important in the context of this debate. Never have more Bills been guillotined through this Parliament than in the last two years. We have had close to 70 Bills in each of the last two years guillotined through this Parliament. The reason we have another large package of Bills coming up is that the Government knows that the Democrats will roll over and these Bills will be guillotined through. The Democrats were full of a lot of brave statements such as, `We are not going to guillotine anything through now'. We had this line and the Democrats lasted a day and a half—Senator Kernot lasted a day and a half—and then said yes, the deal would be done.
I point out that since the start of this Parliament, the Democrats have voted with the Opposition on divisions on 39 occasions; they have voted with the Government on over 240 occasions on divisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Good.

—I accept Senator Sherry's comment. As far as the Labor Party is concerned it is terrific. No-one would argue that, as far as the Labor Party is concerned, the virtually guaranteed support from the Democrats is absolutely fantastic.

PARA.TAB: This program which is so important—these 70 Bills which are so vital which are coming into this chamber—would be junked within the hour by Mr Keating if he wanted to call an election. It is an interesting point as to whether an election will still be called, and I raise that issue. But let me point out that this absolutely vital program would be junked within the hour if Mr Keating had the guts to go to an election.

These Democrats will roll over; they will fall over themselves to try to force this program through this Parliament. We have seen astonishing behaviour from the Democrats in the last two and a half years. They have resisted every change in relation to Question Time. They have been brought screaming to try to get some reform into Question Time. They object to our taking note of the answers of Ministers for half an hour or an hour. They fought that like hell. They guillotine more Bills through this Parliament than have ever been guillotined through before and we are going to have 70 more Bills which these people are going to—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what the Nazis did—rewrote history.

—I must confess to Senator Coulter and Senator Kernot that never has a minority party in this chamber been so poorly led. The Party that claimed that its role is to keep us honest has resisted every major reform in this chamber. There are many senators on this side who feel they have important questions to ask. The Democrats do not feel they are important questions. They never take part in Estimates—it is not their problem—but there are many senators in this part of the chamber who wish to take part in Estimates. So I put it to the Senate that not only is the fact that the Government does not want its program properly debated a condemnation of the Government, but it is by and large also a condemnation of the Australian Democrats and their behaviour in this chamber.

—I do not know about anybody else, but in the 17 years I have been here I have never voted for a guillotine because I do not think it is appropriate that that be done in this chamber; that is, in the House which is supposed to be a House of review. In particular, I submit, it is not appropriate to vote for a guillotine when we are dealing with Appropriations. I do not know whether anybody has done the homework, but I have a faint recollection—
—What about the TTLC?
—Order! Senator Sherry!
—He has been interjecting from another seat all night, Mr President.
—Order! Senator Sherry, all interjections are wrong, but you should at least be in your correct seat.
—I think there may have been one occasion when there was a guillotine on the Appropriations—
—At least one.

—I have a vague recollection that there may have been. Nevertheless, I wonder why the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) moved this motion. I thought things were rolling along fairly well and that the way we were going we would finish by 3.30 tomorrow afternoon. That is all I wanted to say. I feel that we need to consider a number of things and I thought we were going along fairly well. Certain people who tend to ask more questions than others have not really entered the debate today a great deal. I thought we were going really well, but now we have wasted another half an hour or so and that is a bit deplorable.

—The effort that Senator Kemp made recently has illustrated the role that he has brought to the Senate since his election which seems to concentrate on a criticism of my Party's role in this chamber. The matters of opinion which were proposed by Senator Kemp have very little foundation in fact and make very little contribution on behalf of his electorate.

PARA.TAB: In the time that he has been in this chamber, he has become renowned for the emphasis that he places upon critical evaluation of our performance and his lack of contribution, either in substance or subject matter, in his questions during Question Time. He is renowned for either a point of order without substance, which is very seldom upheld, or a question which is addressed to what a Minister or a responsible Minister may think about various things. Questions are not necessarily addressed to policy, to legislation or to a Minister's activities in the portfolio, but rather to a criticism of personalities.

That is why I am embarrassed to share this chamber with such a tactician because I cannot see the benefit to those who elected the man. I cannot see the purpose of this attack on people. I wish that we would get a little less of this activity and a lot more which is directed at legislation and substance and which produces the result which the electors of the nation require.

We are criticised by this critic for voting for Government legislation occasionally. We believe that there are a lot of things wrong with this country. We believe that things need to be done to address the problems of this nation. We believe that things need to be changed. When legislation is presented to this place, we want to deal with it and change the situation that we are presented with. The way we can do that in this chamber is by looking at legislation and modifying it. We need to deal with the legislation, not the personalities, the opinions or the points of order that do not get substantiated. We should have none of that mumbo jumbo; the legislation is what will change and improve the situation that we have here.

We cannot improve the situation without introducing legislation. We cannot improve the faults that we have in front of us in this country without looking at the legislation. To come in here and give us a tirade about what Senator Kemp thinks the Australian Democrats might be doing is such a dishonest waste of time, such an arrogance displayed toward the electorate, that I cannot see why Senator Kemp does not crawl out of here with his tail between his legs every night in utter embarrassment at what he has done in disregarding the will of his electorate.

To come in here and suggest that the Democrats have done a deal with the Government just because we want to see legislation put before the chamber is entirely dishonest because there has been no demonstration, and there cannot be a demonstration, of a deal. There is a blank piece of paper between us; honourable senators can demonstrate no deal. I defy Senator Kemp to come up with any suggestion that there is a deal. If he does, I will donate $10,000 to his re-election campaign. He will never get it; he will not get a jelly bean.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The real question is not whether there ought to be a guillotine but whether the guillotine is reasonable. This is a reasonable guillotine.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —The evidence we can rely on comes from no less a person than Senator Harradine. Senator Harradine, having been here for 17 years now, said that in his assessment of things we would have finished by 3.30 tomorrow afternoon anyhow. I think Senator Harradine has established that this is a very reasonable guillotine.

PARA.TAB: I think that Senator Bell took Senator Kemp to task. I thought Senator Kemp, in his usual style, put the argument that had to be put to the other side. If I were Senator Bell, I would not take it too seriously. I think that Senator Kemp did what he had to do. He had to put the outrage that the Opposition says it has to have. In fact, it has been a most pleasant debate so far as debates about guillotines go.

The sorts of onslaughts that Senator Bell and Senator Coulter have suffered tonight have been suffered by the Australian Democrats before. It is not unique. In October 1984, Senator Haines had this to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am afraid that I had considerable difficulty in taking Senator Chaney's speech any more seriously than on occasions he appeared to be taking it. I cannot understand how any Bill on which there will be 19 speakers can be considered in any way to have been gagged or how democracy can be impugned in any way by closing that debate. Nineteen speakers on the second reading of Appropriation Bills is quite ample.

The time we have allowed on this occasion is quite ample. Senator Harradine says it is. Nobody on the Opposition side will, I hope, condemn Senator Harradine, who is a most honourable senator—like we are all most honourable senators. But Senator Harradine has put a time limit on this Bill whereby he says that the debate should be finished within the time that we have allowed. I will quote what Senator Chaney had to say in the 1984 debate. He said:

There are a few unusual aspects to what is happening this afternoon. I do not wish to put on some sort of mock outrage. However, I remind the Senate that this is not quite the normal circumstance in which a guillotine has been laid down. The difference is that this Senate was scheduled to sit through until December. We have now sat for something like 10 days fewer than the number of days programmed by the Government for consideration of the legislation that it was going to put before this place. The fact is that there is no constitutional or legal reason why we should be lifting tomorrow. The view of the Opposition is that we need more time to consider the substantial legislation which is still before the Senate. The fact is there is no constitutional or legal reason for lifting the Senate tomorrow night. There is no more than a campaigning reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —What date was that?

—This was on 23 October 1984. The sorts of things that Senator Chaney said then are the sorts of things that have been said by those opposite tonight—of varying styles, but the same thrust is there—and no doubt in years to come, if the Opposition comes to these benches, we will be saying the same sorts of things.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me to be a bit unfair on the Democrats to heap all the opprobrium onto them. After all, this is the Senate chamber; they are elected to the Senate in accordance with the Constitution. It is not the Democrats who are imposing this guillotine; it is the majority of the Senate. I invite honourable senators to respect the dignity of this chamber. I hope that when the vote is passed and honourable senators have ample time in which to debate the Appropriations in accordance with what Senator Harradine has said, they will graciously go and tell the Democrats that this was really just part of the debate and that they really love them deeply and sincerely as they believe that they contribute considerably to this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are off my list, Barney.

—I hate to see that bitterness in Senator Patterson because she is a woman of the most gracious disposition. I am interested to see who is going to speak next from the other side. I think Senator Bishop is the one who could most graciously put the argument on behalf of the Opposition. If she does not speak on this matter, I will be considerably disappointed because I think that, in her gracious way, she can put points forward in a very convincing manner. That is not to suggest that others should not speak on this matter.

PARA.TAB: The only thing that concerns me is Senator Hill's statement in this morning's Age that we should not be here at all because of the taxpayer's pocket. What worries me a bit about the time we spend in this chamber, not only in dealing with the Estimates but also in dealing with points of order and so on, is the amount of money involved; it would rather shock Senator Hill. My view is that Parliament should not be measured in terms of the amount of money spent in that fashion—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was unnecessary.

—If that is the position that is taken—Senator Hill says that we should not be here because the taxpayers' money is involved—having read Senator Hill's statement in the Age, when we get together we say, `He is right; we have to shorten debate', and we move in and impose the guillotine in accordance with what he said today in the Age. Senator Maguire, is that a picture of Senator Hill in today's Age?

—Mr President, on a point of order: despite the fact that some people are finding this entertaining, I ask you to ask Senator Cooney to direct his comments through the Chair. He is having a little personal discussion with Senator Maguire and I am finding it a little tedious. Would you ask him to direct his comments through you if he is going to speak to Senator Maguire?
—Senator Cooney, please address your remarks through the Chair.

—May I thank Senator Patterson who, in a kind way, has brought me back to the point in debate. Senator Hill—a man we all respect—says that we ought to shorten the sitting times of the Senate and look to the taxpayers' money, yet when we try to do that we are criticised. It is a little hurtful to people on this side, but I tell them to struggle manfully and womanfully to bear the burden of the opprobrium from the other side.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator McMullan's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: REPORT OF ESTIMATES COMMITTEE D

PARA.TAB: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister how he can say that the private hire of Comcars is only using excess capacity. That is the expression he used. How can he say that that is not distorting competition in private enterprise?
—I have already answered the question, Mr Chairman.

—I do not think the Minister has answered the question. He used the term `excess capacity' and said that the Department is only using excess capacity. Does the Minister believe that using excess capacity does not interfere with or distort private enterprise?
—Just before the break I answered a question about Comcar's operations and how they have been directed. I am satisfied that it does not distort the private sector.

—The Minister still has not explained why. All he has done is state that using excess capacity does not distort private enterprise. I know that in any other form of transport using excess capacity does distort competition. I will give a couple of examples. One relates to Australian National Railways returning containers from east to west. It has a high freight volume from east to west, but coming from west to east there is an excess capacity. For freight in that direction it cuts the rate by 80 per cent at least. This results in a distortion of the road transport system.

PARA.TAB: I will not belabour the point much longer. All I will say is that the Minister either does not know what he is talking about or he pleads guilty to not understanding what it means to use excess capacity. The other question I would like to ask is—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why don't you wait for an answer?
—He will not answer it, so I will just carry on.
—Ha, ha!
—What are you laughing at, you halfwit? I will ask the next part of my question. Why, in Western Australia, did the Comcar plate have F put on the end of it?

—We have in the past, of course, used the letter C on Comcar plates. That did cause some problems in Western Australia. I gather that C has been used for plates in Carnarvon, so we had to find a distinguishing letter, and the State Government suggested F, instead of C. Now that we are going to Z, there will be no need for either F or C in Western Australia.
—I fully understand that the Minister said that it was necessary to distinguish between Comcar plates and those of Carnarvon, but why did the Government find it a necessity to distinguish?
—I think it was something that was asked of us by the State Government, Senator.
—Could I have an answer to the question that I just asked? Why did the Government find it a necessity to distinguish?

—I did answer Senator Panizza. What I said was that, in discussions with the State Government, there was a need for a distinguishing letter and the letter F came up. We have now eradicated the problem of having to choose between an F and a C. We have now come up with a Z.
—Can the Minister tell me: what was the need? The Minister just said that the State Government said there was a need. What was that need?

—I think what we might have to do here is go through the archives. I see Senator Parer sharing my problem here. Governments have a need for a distinguishing characteristic in terms of number plates. The Western Australian Government was no different, I presume, in this instance. In other cases, we could use C, but it seemed to be inappropriate to use C in Western Australia. We will go through the archives and see whether there is any other reason why we used F instead of C in Western Australia.
—I ask the Minister: is it a fact that the need arose from continual speeding by Comcar drivers, and then the owner of a car with the same number in Carnarvon getting the speeding tickets?

—If Senator Panizza had known this in the previous 10 minutes or so, he could have told us at the start and we would have been able to work it out for him. I do not know whether that is the case. I will find out. I would not want to prejudge any Commonwealth car driver alleged to have been speeding on the basis of no information or evidence before us. I will just find out for Senator Panizza and let him know.

—Are there any further questions? There being no further questions, that concludes the consideration of the estimates for the Department of Administrative Services. The Committee will now go to the estimates for the Department of Social Security. Are there any questions about the items not allocated to a program?

—I would like to raise a matter concerning the answers which I got in the Estimates committee hearing to my questions about the variation between the original estimates for savings in the Department of Social Security's data matching program and the actual savings. There were enormous variations. In fact, the savings were a lot less than the Government anticipated.

PARA.TAB: In the Estimates, I was given one table which was quite different from the one in the Social Security report on data matching. The Minister has written to me and apologised for the fact that I got two different tables. I want to know why I was given the wrong data in the Estimates when the data for that report must have been already prepared and in print. I want to know why the Estimates Committee was given the wrong data.

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that the new data was not available at the time of the Estimates proceedings and, as a consequence, this data was given to Senator Patterson. It was obviously an error to give it to her in a premature form. But the advice of officers is that, though that error was made, the new data would not have been available at that time.
—Can the officers tell me what date the final copy of the data matching report went for printing?
—I will have to take that question on notice.

—I cannot continue my questioning until I get that answer. The Minister tells me that the data was not available, but that report came out at almost the same time—I have not looked at the dates—as the Estimates hearings were occurring. I believe that the table must have been prepared at least a week before to go to printing and that I was given the wrong data. I want to know why I got the wrong data in the Estimates. The answer the Minister has given me is not satisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know what point Senator Patterson wants to pursue in respect of this matter. The advice I have been given is that the latter data was not available at the time we met as an Estimates committee. My understanding is that, though the initial figures show $23.06m for 1991-92, the actual savings proved to be $25.3m. So we do have those two sets of figures placed on the public record, I seek leave to incorporate Mr Blewett's letter to Senator Patterson into Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: 11 November 1992
Senator Kay Patterson
270 Clayton Road
CLAYTON VIC 3168
Dear Senator

When the latest progress report on the Data-matching Program was tabled in the Senate on 15 October 1992, you asked for clarification on the difference between savings figures which were provided to Senate Estimates Committee D and the savings figures contained in the progress report. I apologise for the delay in responding to you on this.

The figures which were supplied to the Estimates Committee did not reflect the final actual savings for 1991-92. They were in fact estimates done part way through the year and were based on results to that point. The total of this estimate of savings for the financial year was $23.06m.
In the event the total actual savings for the financial year were $25.3m.

It is regretted that you were not provided with the most up-to-date information in the Estimates Committee. However, I can confirm that the tables you had incorporated in Hansard on 15 October from the progress report do reflect the actual savings.
Yours sincerely
NEAL BLEWETT

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister can tell me the day on which the data matching report was tabled in the Senate.
—The advice I have is that, from the debate following, the tabling of the data matching program progress report was 15 October. From the best information available to me, it was 15 October.
—The Minister might refresh my memory and tell me what date we met as an Estimates committee to discuss social security data matching.
—We will have to refresh not only Senator Patterson's memory but also mine. It was not one of those memorable occasions in my life that I will never forget. It was 17 September.
—Can the Minister tell me when the report on data matching went to the printer?

—I think that we are going around in circles. That is the question we were not able to answer earlier, and it would appear that we are unable to answer it now. It is one that we will have to take on notice.

—I thank the Minister. It is fairly difficult to operate when one gets one set of tables and two or three weeks later another set of tables. I remind the Minister that when we wanted to change one word in the Bill we were told that this would mean millions of dollars and that the Government was not able to do it. We were told that there would be all these savings and that this was the reason the Government had to extend the use of the tax file number.

PARA.TAB: Mr Keating, when he was Treasurer, told us that when the Government instituted the tax file number it would be used for taxation purposes only. Then, with a bit of creep, we got the extension of its use into Social Security so the Government could make more savings by identifying those people whose taxation information was at variance with the data and information they gave Social Security.

For example, we were told that the original savings estimate of income from Social Security for the retired would be $162m. I do not have the correct figure from the report which was tabled in the Senate, but it was about a third or so less. The same thing happened with income from Social Security for people with disabilities and sickness. We will not get the same savings there. I want to know why we were told the first time, with the first data matching report, not enough cycles had been done to make the savings. That is not an excuse this time. We agreed in this chamber to have people's freedoms and privacy infringed yet again, given that we were told these savings were to be made, but we now find that the actual savings are nowhere near the savings that the Government claimed. I want to know why the estimated savings from data matching are more than double the actual savings made.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a case of fighting attacks from all directions. Senator Patterson kicks off with a condemnation of us because I gather we picked up some $2m more this financial year than was initially notified to the Committee.
—What?
—Perhaps one of these figures is wrong.
—I think it is. Go back and start again.

—All right. In terms of the savings now, the data matching program, as Senator Patterson knows, has been in effect now for a short time. The Government's position is that the program is proving to be effective in the detection of fraud and incorrect payments, although, as she rightly says, the savings are not as high as originally estimated.

PARA.TAB: In respect of that, a number of points need to be noted. There are three main reasons why savings from data matching have been less than estimated. First, the measure was implemented later than expected, owing to the need for a thorough consultation between agencies and the Privacy Commissioner to protect those understandable concerns about privacy and natural justice. So those processes were followed.

The concept of data matching has developed over the years. I was the person who initially tossed it into the public debate as an alternative to the Australia Card. I believed then that it was an appropriate alternative to an intrusive system. But the Government, in implementing our programs, has been concerned to ensure that the processes with the Privacy Commissioner have been thorough and meaningful. As a consequence, the measure was introduced later than expected, partly because of those processes.

The second reason why the savings are not as much as had been planned is that a significant part of the program depends on the acquisition and use of tax file numbers. Collecting the millions of tax file numbers has been a huge task. That has taken longer than anticipated. Again, great efforts have been made to explain to clients why they are needed and how they will used.

The third aspect which should be kept in mind when making an assessment of the program is that the Department's overnight check of new claims through accelerated claimant matching is proving to be more successful than expected. This means that discrepancies are being identified earlier—at the time of grant rather than later on through data matching. In 1991-92, for instance, ACM savings totalled some $142.969m, reported in the data matching report as $143m. This was $88.4m more than the original estimate of $54.6m.

This ACM initiative will be extended to all offices in 1992-93. We anticipate that it should result in 1,200 cancellations or variations, with additional net program savings of almost $9m. They are three reasons, probably amongst a number of others, why the estimates have not been achieved. I think it is fair to place on the public record that the process has been quite useful and productive. It has been implemented in consultation with the Privacy Commissioner.

TALK.START.PARA: —Even if the Minister is satisfied with those explanations, I am not. The savings are less than half what he predicted. I sat through those meetings of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs when we were told that they were not guesstimates but `We know that these are the savings we are going to get'. I kept arguing that some of the figures were very rubbery and that it was unlikely that those savings would be made. We see this happening over and over again. We have seen it happen with the Health Insurance Commission. Savings were going to be made by having us all swipe a card in a pharmacy—another move towards the Government's Australia Card, with data matching, tax file numbers and an upgraded Medicare card.

PARA.TAB: What is happening, bit by bit, is fairly obvious. It ought to make the public more wary of the claims the Government makes about the various procedures it will put in place and the fact that we give up our freedom and our personal privacy on the basis of estimates the Minister gives us which are so far out that they are laughable. I suppose there is nothing much we can do except put on the public record that it is yet another example of the inability of the Minister and his Government and this Department to come up with accurate figures about estimates of the savings.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should be noted that the anticipated savings for the next financial year are very close to $150m. I do not think all that many taxpayers would think that that is small fry and object to Government, through detection and matching measures, being able to recoup that amount of money. I think Senator Patterson is trying to play it from both sides here and is falling through the middle.
—Are there any matters in relation to program 1?
—I want to ask questions about income security for the retired. When will the first assessment occur? Will it be backdated 12 months from September 1993?
—I am informed that the assessment will take place in September 1993 and it will be based on the movement in shares over the previous 12 months.
—Will shareholding pensioners be reassessed every three months?
—I am informed that that is the case.

—Over what period will all pensioners and beneficiaries be initially assessed under this initiative? Is the Government concerned, as has been recently expressed by the Stock Exchange, that the initiative will result in pensioners redirecting their investments away from shares and into the private property market or banks or other forms of investment?

—I am informed that the assessments will take place on a day in September 1993. In respect of Senator Patterson's second point, I think the Government's position on this has been made very clear by the Minister. What we are doing here is very much providing an equitable and level form of comparison between this form of investment and others.
—That has not quite answered my question. Does the Minister anticipate that pensioners will redirect their investments away from the share market?

—That is very much a decision to be made by individual pensioners in their own circumstances. We might find that most of them feel that this is still the best investment to have in their circumstances; others may feel it is not. Some may take out shares as opposed to their former forms of investment. I think it is fair to say that there is no prediction one could make in respect of this.

—The Council on the Ageing has expressed concern that two pensioners with identical shareholdings will receive different pensions depending on the share prices at the date of assessment. Is that correct? Will it be possible for two people with similar holdings to have a different assessment because of the date on which the assessment is made?

—Two people with the same equity holding in shares assessed on the same day will be treated equally. I do not know what point Senator Patterson is pursuing, but my advice is that the assessment of the same shares held for the same period—if that is the totality of income—will be the same.

—The Council is expressing concern about people who have the same shareholdings but a different date of assessment and the shareholdings have a different value at that date. That is the question the Council on Ageing has raised.

—I think the important point is that the initial assessment will be made on the same date, and that will be the benchmark for the assessment of shares thereafter. For instance, if one were to hold onto one's shares for a few extra months and the price of those shares was to go up over that period, obviously there would be a different assessment. If the price were to go down, I presume there would also be a different assessment. The important aspect, to get this right from the start, is to have an assessment made on the same date for everybody.

—That might answer the question to begin with, but later on, for future assessments, there might be a mismatch. I think that is what the Council on Ageing is concerned about. I suppose we can pursue that in the guillotined debate on that Bill.
—Are there any matters in relation to program 2?

—I have some questions on the marketing of the disability reform package. Has the Minister been informed whether the Office of Government Information and Advertising will be providing me with a copy of the study of the effectiveness of the disability reform package which was conducted by Art/Craft Research Ltd and completed in July 1992? I requested that on notice. I may not have caught up with its arrival in my office, but I am not sure that it has.
—I do not know whether it has arrived in Senator Patterson's office either. We will have to find out whether it has been sent to her.

—I really would appreciate that being sent to me before tomorrow afternoon because the guillotine will be applied and the debate will be finished by 3.30. I asked for that information on notice and it is appropriate for me to have it. Could the Minister guarantee that I will have it before close of business tomorrow afternoon?
—For all we know it might very well be at the honourable senator's office now, but I will undertake to try to get it to Senator Patterson as soon as possible.

—I would also appreciate it if the Minister could give me a copy of the letters which are being sent out to 150,000 businesses and 25,000 general practitioners this month as part of the disability reform package marketing strategy. What is the objective of these two initiatives and what will be their total cost? Was the cost of these 150,000 letters to businesses and 25,000 letters to general practitioners included in the total budget for Corporate Impacts for publicising the disability reform package, or is it an additional cost over and above the money given to Corporate Impacts or the contract it was given to market the disability reform package?

—The advice I have is that the cost comes from the area Senator Patterson referred to, but I will make sure that the officers clarify that overnight and let her know by lunchtime tomorrow. In respect of the letters, we obviously do not have them here, but if they can be located, they will be located by lunchtime tomorrow as well and brought to her.
—I wish to know in those answers whether the cost of that project is included in Corporate Impacts' original budget for the last financial year.
—That is the advice I have at this stage, but if that advice proves to be wrong we will clarify the matter for Senator Patterson by lunchtime tomorrow.

—I want to know about disability panel workloads. Can the Minister tell me what proportion of new disability support pensioners the Government considered would be in the active category—that is, capable of becoming work ready within a reasonable period—when the disability reform package was passed in this Parliament?

—I have some information before me in respect of the panels and how they work. I do not have the answer that Senator Patterson wants, nor do I have a departmental officer here with responsibility in this particular area. Senator Patterson can throw her pen down, but I can probably throw mine further.I give Senator Patterson an assurance that not only will this information be available by midday tomorrow, but also it will be available by start of play in the morning.

—This is a perfect example. We have been asked to cooperate in Estimates and speed up the process in this chamber because the Australian Democrats have guillotined this debate. Senator Kernot has not been listening, but what has happened tonight is that I have come into this chamber and listened to the Democrats giving the reasons why they are prepared to tell us we have to stop the Appropriations debate at 3.30 tomorrow afternoon. We have been asked to cooperate. We go into Estimates committees and sit there for hours on end.

PARA.TAB: We never see a Democrat at those Estimates committees when we are looking at how the Government is spending money. If the Democrats got into government—God help us—they would spend so much money that we would be taxed beyond belief. But that does not matter because they do not come and look at what is happening to taxpayers' money and where it is all going. That is too hard and it takes a lot of time. They might have to come here in non-sitting weeks and sit all night. They might have to do a lot of homework to know about the programs and what is involved in them. We do not see the Democrats, but they are prepared to guillotine the debate tonight and tomorrow.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a pity that you should resort to such nastiness.
—I am not resorting to nastiness; I am telling Senator Kernot how it is. If the Democrats want to participate in Estimates, that is fine.

—Madam Chair, I raise a point of order.
