Senator Patterson is quite within her rights to seek information and, in responding to that information as sought, we as a government attempt to provide as much assistance as possible. We all know that Social Security is an amazingly diverse department and everyone cannot be here from the Department to answer questions tonight.

PARA.TAB: However, Senator Patterson is embarking upon an attack on the Democrats which is totally outside the province of this committee process. Madam Chair, I ask you to ask her to return to the subject before the Chair. If she asks questions about that, we will try to answer them. Although an attack on the Democrats might be merited, even though I may not agree with it, it will probably not produce any productive result in the next few hours that we have to get through this process.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the point of order, Madam Chair: the Minister was warned that Senator Patterson had some questions she wished to pursue. It is a great pity that the advisers are not here to deal with those issues.
—That has nothing to do with the point of order.

—Yes, it has. It is precisely to do with the point of order. As far as Senator Patterson's comments about the Democrats are concerned, those comments set the context of the type of debate that she wished to pursue and, it seemed to me, were quite appropriate and valid.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—I ask Senator Patterson to come back to program 2. Does she have any further questions on program 2?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do. I believe I was in order because I was setting the scene as to why I think it is appropriate for me to pursue this issue.
—Perhaps Senator Patterson could come to the point now.

—I am coming to the point. We were cooperating here. We are supposed to go to Estimates—and as I said, I never see the Democrats at Estimates and that is an appropriate comment to make in this context. The guillotine has been applied, and it was appropriate to mention that. The system now involves putting reservations on areas where we feel we have not received appropriate answers. I did so, and I restricted them as much as possible to try to facilitate the passage of these Appropriations through the chamber.

PARA.TAB: Under program 2, I asked for information on the marketing disability reform package and disability panel workloads. I could not have been more specific, yet the Minister tells me that no-one is here to answer my questions and I will get the answers tomorrow morning. But we will be onto some other topic by then, such as industrial relations or some other issue, and I will not get the chance to ask my questions in detail.

The issue with regard to disability panel workloads is that again they have not achieved their estimates or what they said they would achieve. This program is designed to facilitate the return to work of people who are in receipt of disability pensions. It is a goal that I believe all of us would want to achieve: to give people who have been on disability pensions the opportunity to get back to work, if they are deemed to be in the active category.

I want to know how successful the process has been, but the Minister cannot even tell me what the goal was and how many people the Department thought would be in those active categories. It is fairly easy to answer—it is about 12,000. I wanted to know the basis of that in order to confirm that the figure was correct—because it may have changed like all the other figures which wobble around in this place. But I think 12,000 was the figure we were given. I then wanted to pursue three or four other questions, but I cannot pursue them because the Minister does not have the people here. I do not think that is appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The information that has already been given to Senator Patterson is that some 12,447 people are proceeding to panel interviews. Senator Patterson can come in here and grandstand all she likes but she has had this information for some time now. If she wants to pursue her next set of questions, she should go ahead and do so. An attack on us, on the Democrats and everyone else may make her feel better, but it does not get her any further in this process.

PARA.TAB: Senator Patterson has the information already. If she wants to come in and ask the question again, so be it. But I would have thought we would be doing much more productive things than teaching her how to read.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not appreciate the Minister's gratuitous comments. I find them typical of the sort of thing he would say. I want to know the proportion of new disability support pensioners that the Government considered would obtain rehabilitation or training assistance and how this compares with the actual numbers to date.

—This is very much a specific question relating to a specific area in Social Security. I will take that question on notice and provide an answer. As I said, I could have the whole of the Department of Social Security sitting outside waiting from Thursday at 2 o'clock, waiting all Thursday night, waiting all Friday morning, waiting all day today and waiting all night tonight. We have given Senator Patterson a fair whack of information. She is probably developing the reputation of being the David Vigor of the Opposition. To that extent, she has been given mountains of information.

PARA.TAB: Amongst that information is the estimate that the proportion of new disability support pensioners who would receive rehabilitation or training assistance in 1991-92 was in the order of 17 per cent, and that the proportion of new disability support pensioners who would received assistance up to 21 June 1992 was approximately 2.5 per cent. That is probably the information which Senator Patterson sought in this question—but she has been given it already. Does she want to ask another question to which she has been given the answer already or does she want to go on to something new?

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether I have to tolerate the abuse from the other side of the chamber but I agree that I put a large number of questions on notice. The reason I did that was to facilitate the passage of these Bills. I put innumerable questions on notice to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. It gave me very full answers and I think I now have about three or four questions to ask of that Department. I think it is reasonable to carry on the business of the committee in that way.

PARA.TAB: I admit that I have put a large number of questions on notice to Social Security, but I also say that I use that information. I do not ask questions for the sake of asking questions. I use the information in debates on Bills, in policy formation and for a number of other reasons, including to advise constituents. I find the fact that the Minister tells me that I should not be putting questions on notice offensive and inappropriate, and it means he does not understand the process of what opposition is all about. But the Minister will learn real fast real soon.
An incident having occurred in the gallery—
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Order in the gallery! We will proceed to subprogram 2.3, Carer pensions.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister obviously did not have any reply to that, but that is not unexpected. Given that money was provided to the disability panels to interview about 30 per cent of new disability pension claimants and that 17 per cent of the new claimants have been considered by panels, while only 6 per cent have actually been interviewed, what work have these panels been doing other than interviewing clients?

—It has been doing a couple of things: assessing claims and establishing the processes. Senator Patterson should also keep in mind—I think the information has already been given to her—that the panel process got going effectively only in February-March 1992. The average duration of the programs—37 weeks for CRS, for instance—means that people are only now completing programs and going into employment Jobsearch.

PARA.TAB: The other information that Senator Patterson has been given is that the panel activity has increased sharply since the commencement. For instance, the number of persons referred to panel interviews is now running at some 1,500 every four weeks, compared to 200 each four weeks in November-December 1991. An extra 28 DSOs in the Budget context will also assist. That will bring the number up to 148. So there has been a marked increase in activity as the program has been rolling.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the Minister finally finds someone in the Department from whom he might be able to get some information, could he tell me the average case load now of each of those officers. That would be of assistance so that we could know what they are doing. If I could have the case load of those officers on a weekly or monthly basis, whatever is an effective time period, that would give me some idea of how that program is going and enable the making of a comparison when we ask questions about those review panels at the next Estimates hearings. Presumably Senator Bolkus will be asking the questions then.
—I will take that question on notice.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Zakharov)—Is there anything further on program 2? If not, we move to program 6, Corporate and other services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to ask the Minister about sick leave taken by DSS officers. What action is the Department taking to reduce the amount of sick leave taken by departmental officers? The figure he gave me for 1991-92 was that 214,544 days—or more than 10 days per year per departmental officer—have been taken. Why is that and what is the Minister doing to reduce that figure?
—I ask Senator Patterson whether she has received information to question No. 86.
—I may have but I do not have it right here. I am asking what action the Minister has taken to reduce sick leave.

—Apart from the answer that has been provided to Senator Patterson and the general public sector-wide occupational health and safety program—which comes under another portfolio area—I do not think there is much more I can add.

—That is not a satisfactory answer. The number of sick days taken is more than for other departments. Maybe the Minister could give me a comparison and tell me what number of sick days people in other departments take, but I believe it is fewer than 10 per officer. What has the Department done to reduce the number of sick days that people are taking, since 10 sick days a year seems to be rather excessive?

—I have a couple of points to make in response to Senator Patterson further to the ones I have made already. The answer to question No. 86, to which I referred, has within it information which shows that the sick leave rate in DSS in comparison to others is not the worst around. That is part of the information provided to Senator Patterson.

PARA.TAB: The other point that needs to be made is that under the recent agreement with the public sector unions I think there was a target of a reduction of some 20 per cent in the number of days lost through sick leave. It is anticipated that that will be achieved through a plethora of mechanisms, including greater use of medical certificates and so on. But the target of 20 per cent is well and truly on the table. As I say, although the figures in isolation may look unacceptable, they are not as high as in some other organisations. The Government is placing great store on achieving that cutback of one in five days through the public sector agreement which, as I say, was probably entered into some 10 to 14 days ago.

TALK.START.PARA: —How is the Government going to achieve that 20 per cent cut?
—As I said, those mechanisms, including the use of medical certificates. The agreement is a public agreement; maybe it is best that we make it available to Senator Patterson.

—I would like the Minister to give a fuller answer and explain what he means by the use of medical certificates. I presume medical certificates are used now after a certain number of consecutive days have been taken. What does the Minister mean? Are there any other measures being taken?

—The information I am getting is that there will be expanded requirements for medical certificates. Whether it is one day or two days absence, in situations in the past where maybe a doctor's certificate was not required—that is consistent, I think, both in public and private sectors—there will be greater concentration on the necessity to provide medical certificates in some circumstances where there might be a one or two day absence from work. Mechanisms such as that will be put into place. The target reduction of one in five days is very much on the agenda.

—I just shake my head that the Minister thinks he is going to achieve a one in five reduction by the introduction of more stringent measures for medical certificates. I would have expected him to give me some other managerial answer as to how he is going to reduce sick leave amongst DSS officers. Obviously there are a number of other issues about why people take sick leave other than that they are rorting the system. It may also mean that some of the Minister's officers are under a great deal of stress because of the unprecedented unemployment levels and the number of demands that are being made on Social Security officers. I would have thought that getting the unemployment levels down and having a plan of action, such as the coalition has, would reduce stress on DSS officers. But no, the Minister cannot think of anything else, except some bureaucratic answer telling me that they are going to fill out more forms. That is typical of the Minister and his Government. There are no creative suggestions about reducing unemployment, about making people in DSS feel part of the system, and about getting them to feel that they have a corporate responsibility.

PARA.TAB: The Government would be looking at all those issues if it were on about good management. But we would not expect anything but a bureaucratic answer from the Minister. So I expect we will not achieve the one in five or even greater reduction. I suppose we will be looking at a similar figure this time next year. After that, I presume it will decrease because the Minister will not be here.

TALK.START.PARA: —On the latter point—

PARA.TAB: An incident having occurred in the gallery—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! If those people in the gallery want to clap they should go to a concert. They are not to do it here.

—If Senator Patterson wants a discussion about stress in the Public Service, on the public sector, and which of the two alternatives is guaranteed to induce more stress, then we can have that. If Senator Patterson wants to talk about the stress that will be imposed on people who will find themselves off unemployment benefits after nine months, if she wants to talk about the stress on families who will find themselves off benefits after children turn 12 years of age, if she wants to talk about the stress on individual Australians in the community who will suffer because of some $10 billion cutback in this area as a result of deliberate Opposition policies, then we will talk about stress. We will talk about how the figures in Fightback are wrong and how they do not take into account the extra resources that will be needed for those sorts of representations that will come continually from a public denied of services.

PARA.TAB: If Senator Patterson wants to talk about stress, then she needs to talk about stress not only in the Department of Social Security but also in all of our offices. We would be at the forefront of those attacks and representations to do over the inequity that will be put in place by the Fightback policies. I will tell Senator Patterson about stress, but one thing that will ensure that that sort of stress is not perpetrated on the Australian people is the Fightback policy of 12 months ago; the knock-back policy of now; the Dr Marvel of 12 months ago; the Dr Marvel of now. Those opposite are being exposed to the public for the frauds that they are. The growing awareness in the community of fear of lack of security under Dr Hewson's one-man band policies will ensure that those opposite do not win the election. The pollsters are not talking to those people in the public gallery.

If those opposite want to do away with occupational health and safety programs, they will induce stress on the Public Service. If they do not want to talk about constructive engagement with the Public Service unions, then they will induce stress. Look at the levels of stress in the Public Service in Victoria, for instance, where Senator Patterson comes from. She ought to be ashamed of herself for coming in here trying to raise those sorts of arguments in this context. We are constructively addressing the problem of sickness leave; we have entered into an agreement to reduce that by some 20 per cent. If she wants to come in here and throw cheap political points to the gallery, she may do so. I am more intent on trying to do something constructive about reducing those levels of sick leave and also trying to get through this process tonight.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister is talking about fraud and social security and says that we are frauds. This is a social security matter so it is appropriate to talk about it here. I want to tell the Minister about something that happened during the State election. Do not talk to me about stress and other issues. I want to talk to him about the Cambodian people who live in north Dandenong. They received a letter from one of the Minister's State colleagues. I got it translated and I was so shocked by the translation that I took it to the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and had it translated again because I wanted to make sure the translation was right. The translation said that we were going to cut off all social security after nine months—the sort of rubbish that the Minister has been putting over the airways and again in this chamber tonight. The translation said that wages and conditions will be lowered under the coalition. It said, `If they get in and you can't get a job you will be left to starve to death'. That is what one of the Minister's State members wrote on her letterhead.
—You are entitled to your opinion.
—Senator Faulkner says, `You are entitled to do it'.
—I said that you are entitled to your opinion. That is right.

—One is entitled to write to the Cambodians in Khmer, in their own language, with no English translation and frighten the living daylights out of them? Those people are vulnerable. They have come from a country where they have been threatened by authority, where they are frightened not to believe the government, and they get a letter from a sitting member saying that we are going to cut off all social security after nine months. Senator Tate ought to be listening to this. These are his mates; these are his friends.
—Have you got the letter?
—Yes, I have a copy of it.
—Read it into Hansard.

—I cannot. It is written in Khmer. I would not put Hansard through that, but I can give it the translation. I will put this on the public record: it is disgusting that a sitting member would write that letter. That is the sort of nonsense that the Minister is again talking about here in the chamber tonight—that we on this side of the chamber will cut off unemployment benefits after nine months. Senator Bolkus should go back and read the package and get it right for a change instead of purveying that distortion of the truth around the traps, including the distortion of the truth that his colleague made in my State to a group of people who are not able to protect themselves in the same way, in writing to them in their own language such absolute drivel.

PARA.TAB: It is a total travesty of what the Minister is supposed to stand for; it is appalling. I hope that some of those opposite are squirming because one of their colleagues would do that. That is what their colleagues wrote and told those people.

TALK.START.PARA: —We remember the law and order campaigns and their effect on older people.

—But at least through the law and order campaign, older people have become concerned about their security. This was telling people that they would starve to death under the Liberals. Let me tell honourable senators that those two people on the other side, those baby boomers—and I am a baby boomer too—grew up under a Liberal Government. They did not starve to death under a Liberal Government; they, in fact, look very well fed—some of those opposite look far too well fed.
—Socrates isn't here; he's so well fed.

—That is right; he is travelling overseas. But these untruths—I suppose I am not allowed to say `lies'—are purveyed around by this mob on the other side and their State colleagues, and they have the gall to come in here and tell me that we are not worried about stress and that they have the monopoly on caring.
—It makes you sick.

—It does make you sick; it makes you absolutely sick. I was disgusted by that letter. I thought, these are not even fair tactics; they do not even play the game fairly. I thought the statement that the Minister made before was totally inappropriate and he deserved the response I gave him.

PARA.TAB: The other issue I want to know about is reconciliation of the DSS cheques. This is another charming little bit of information that I got in Estimates. I asked a question about a gentleman who received Social Security cheques for four years. These cheques were put in a drawer in an institution in Sydney, until the institution returned them to Social Security and said the man had died four years previously. The cheques had kept coming and they had been put in a drawer at the institution, and finally they came back to Social Security. I asked Social Security, `Don't you have any way of reconciling your books?'.

I know that with my own personal cheque account—as with my colleagues—if I had been writing cheques to somebody for four years and they were not cashed, I might think that something had happened—that person might have dropped off the limb. But no, officers of the Department told me that they reconcile them by hand. After I had time to think about this, with hindsight I thought well, if they reconciled them, how come they did not find out? How come they needed the institution—or whoever it was, because we were not able to find out who it was who came with a drawer full of cheques—to come to Social Security, and that is when they discovered, `Oh, we've been sending these cheques to somebody who has been dead these four years'.
I want to know how the Department undertakes its reconciliation and what length of time it takes to discover that somebody is receiving cheques who, in fact, is dead.

TALK.START.PARA: —I don't think Senator Patterson has asked another question yet.

—I asked the Minister how long it takes for the Department to undertake a manual reconciliation. I did ask it in a rather different way. I understand why the Minister may not have understood it because really he understands very little about Social Security. I would say, bring back Senator Richardson because at least he could answer the questions. Can the Minister just tell me how long it takes to reconcile by hand the cheques that are sent out from Social Security? Some 3 per cent, I think it is, of Social Security payments are made by cheque. How long does it take for reconciliation to occur when cheques are not cashed?

—The information already given to Senator Patterson with respect to this is that, under the old reconciliation system, every fourth and subsequent cheque for the same client remaining unrepresented was identified in the microfiche. The new system, which is called the cheque reconciliation information system, CRIS, is a Department of Finance system utilised by Social Security. It provides a screen based facility and allows access to information to assist in the reconciliation of the value of unrepresented cheques. Under this new system it should not take more than—
—Four years.

—It should not take more than a couple of weeks. It is automatically updated and we should know within a few weeks now. I think someone yelled out `four years'. That was pretty bright. I think there were some pretty peculiar circumstances involved here.

PARA.TAB: Let me make one point in respect of this: Senator Patterson comes in here time and time again attacking the concept of data matching. If there is one sure way of tracking down cases of fraud, then data matching has been proven and, as I said earlier on, is proving even more so to be successful in attacking this particular problem.

If Senator Patterson is concerned about fraud, then she should tell her mates why she opposed data matching, a system which will recover some $150m or so in wrongful payments for the forthcoming financial year. Why does she not explain that to her colleagues instead of picking on one case where she knows the circumstances were peculiar under an old system? We have moved on to the new reconciliation information system. It is part of this Government's process. Senator Patterson just does not seem to accept that we can do things with technology to reduce the levels of incidents of wrongful payments of fraud in this area. We will continue to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to put the record straight. I did not oppose data matching. I was here in the chamber when we voted on it. What I did was to scrutinise it as closely as possible. The Opposition put in a large number of amendments to ensure that the privacy issues were addressed as completely as we thought they ought to be.

PARA.TAB: The Minister should not come in here and tell me that I opposed data matching. What I did was undertake an appropriate analysis as a member of the Opposition, as I would have done as a member of the Government, for that matter. I would be just as stringent if, heaven forbid, I happened to be on the Minister's side in his Party. I would have been just as interested in data matching because privacy is an issue about which I have a great concern. But the Minister should not come in here and tell the chamber that I opposed it, because I was voting for it. That is a nonsense. What I did was to take an active interest in it to ensure that the issues of privacy were addressed. I wish the Minister would get his facts straight when he actually speaks in this place; it would be of assistance.

The Minister said that I had been given an answer as to how the reconciliation was to take place. I have just skipped through the Hansard of 17 September when we discussed it and the detail the Minister has just given me I had not been given. It may have come by way of an additional answer, but I do not believe it did. So, again, the Minister comes in here and tells me that I was given that information; I do not believe I was—and I was not given a full answer like that by Mr Volker on 17 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am informed that Mr Volker did discuss the actual case. He may not have done so in as much detail as we have. The thrust of my response basically was that we are moving to an automated system now rather than sticking with the old system.

—That is not the point I made. The point I made was that the Minister told me the mechanism by which the new reconciliation would be undertaken. I was not advised of that. The Minister comes in here and makes it sound as though I am asking questions to which I have already been given the answers. I have not been given the answers.

PARA.TAB: During this time we have had three instances of this at least. The Minister said, first, that we on this side of the chamber would cut off unemployment benefits after nine months; secondly, that I had had an answer to a question which I had not received an answer to; and, thirdly, that I was given information which I believe I was not given. If the Minister plays fair in this place, I will play fair with him. Some of the Ministers give me decent responses. Senator Tate does in connection with Health, Housing and Community Services. We do not have this nonsense and I do not get myself so irate because he at least makes an attempt to answer my questions and not belittle me and my attempts all the time.

I want to know the answer to this, and perhaps the Minister can give me a paper on how that reconciliation is going to take place. I think it is quite a concern. The Minister indicated that it was some sort of fraud. It does not seem to me to be much of a fraud. The man did not cash his cheques; he was dead. The Department did not reconcile it, and I want to know how it is going to do so in future. If the Department could provide me with a paper, I would appreciate it.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can do that.

—I want to ask about distribution of ministerial press releases. I ask the Minister whether all organisations on the Department's ministerial press release mailing list receive copies of all ministerial press releases regardless of whether they are purely political or not?

—While the officer finds out the answer to that question, let me just get the setting right. I suppose an attack will be coming up with respect to the use of government services to distribute what Senator Patterson will call political press statements.

PARA.TAB: My understanding is that the Minister's press statements, or whatever they are, will be distributed to all on the mailing list if they relate to his portfolio activities in the Department of Social Security. That is not a new occurrence; it is not an innovation under this Government. It is something that has gone on for quite some time. Dr Blewett has not initiated something new to disseminate political information. It has been an accepted part of the machinery of government for some years now and what Dr Blewett is doing is what has been accepted as being proper and appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to read into the Hansard record a complaint I received. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Over the past two days we have received the following media releases mailed to us through the social security department. Of the five releases, three of them I consider to be blatant political propaganda, not social security feeding relevant data about alterations, considerations, et cetera.

That was faxed to me because they thought it was inappropriate—I have had a number of comments from a number of organisations—that they should receive blatantly political information. I can appreciate the need to send faxes of press releases because this Government legislates by press release so it is quite useful for people to know what is going on. They get the press release and they can find out what they can do about taxation and other things. I guess it is quite an advantage to know what is going on because we do not get the legislation until quite a lot later.

PARA.TAB: This organisation and a number of other people have complained to me that blatantly political press releases are not appropriate to be sent unless they ask for them. They are asking for information on the Department as it affects their organisation and they do not particularly want to have their faxes jammed with, or have their paper used for—that is what this Government is doing, because the organisations supply the paper for the fax machines—the Government's faxes of a political nature.

I believe that the Government needs to look carefully at that because faxes were not in vogue when we were in government. Now the Government is actually using someone else's paper. If the Government chooses to use its own paper that is fair enough, but it is using other people's paper to send its propaganda and some of them are fed up with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to put a couple of things on the record. First of all, with a few exceptions, people ask to go on the list. Secondly, people can always ask to go off the list. Thirdly, I seek leave to incorporate into Hansard a number of press releases which indicate that this process has been going on for some time and that it has been accepted as a legitimate use of resources and a legitimate way of disseminating information for some time. The press releases I wish to incorporate are: 2 October 1980 from former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle with the headline `Hayden misleads pensioners'; 23 September 1980, `Mr Hayden and social security' from the same Minister—
—Don't bother because I am not going to give you leave.

—There is another attack on Mr Hayden by former Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle in October 1980 on the family income support statement. On 7 December 1977 there is another press statement by the same Minister entitled `Labor attacks on family allowances'. I could go on. Senator Patterson will not give me leave to incorporate these in Hansard, but I think just by reading out the titles I make the point that we do have a case of selective indignation before us at the moment.

—The Minister has missed the point. The press releases he just referred to were not faxed. I am talking about faxing information using the organisation's fax machine and paper. The Government churns these out on their fax machines. That is the point I am making. The press releases the Minister referred to were pre-fax, remember? Like pre-computers; pre-fax. I did not give the Minister leave because it was not relevant. We are talking about faxed press releases.

PARA.TAB: I now have some questions to ask about tendering for click charge photocopiers. Can the Minister tell me how long before the deadline for the invitation to register interest the prospective tenderers received the evaluation criteria? Why was the evaluation criteria not provided with the initial invitation to register interest?

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I ask the Minister to respond, I notice that click charge photocopiers are under program 6.2. Does that mean, Senator Patterson, that you have finished those items that were listed just under program 6, and that we have passed program 6.1 and are now on to 6.2?
—Yes.

—As quite often happens, this was a two-stage process. The first was for calling of interest and that proceeded without the evaluation documents. For the second one, where the formal tender process commenced, those documents were available. As I say, it is not unusual for that sort of approach to be taken and that is what happened in this case.
—Could the Minister tell me how often the deadline was changed for the invitation to register interest and the reasons for these changes?

—My advice is that the initial time period was extended at the request of those who were seeking to lodge expressions of interest. Their argument was that they had been given too little time to comply with the prerequisites. As a consequence, my information is that the time period was extended once, but that is something we will check and I will come in with the precise dates.
—Was the tender for 800 photocopiers and 1,200 printers? Could the Minister tell me what the estimated financial value of this contract was? Has the final tender now been resolved?

—The advice I can give is that we expect to have this process wound up at the end of this calendar year, at which stage we will know the value of the tender. Obviously, before it is completed we cannot give a precise figure.
—Has the successful tenderer been decided yet?
—No.

—Did any of the prospective tenderers express concerns to the Minister? If so, did the Minister consider any of these concerns valid? What action did the Minister take to address the concerns of the prospective tenderers?

—There were representations to both the Minister and the departmental secretary with respect to the tender. My advice is that those representations went to two points. With respect to one of those points—and the process is still continuing—the Department, if not the Minister as well as the Department, took action to take into account the problems raised by the complainants. With respect to the other, both the Minister and the departmental secretary responded to complainants, explaining the situation and taking the position that that complaint was not a valid one.
—What was the complaint that was valid, Minister?
—It was with respect to the other specification for one aspect of photocopiers. Some other specifications were involved, as was argued, and that point was upheld.
—Was there a pilot project undertaken prior to this tender being put up?
—Yes, there was.
—Could you tell me how the company that undertook the pilot program was selected?

—I am advised that a particular company approached the Department and put a proposition to it. That proposition was evaluated and, before the process went any further, that company's equipment was extracted from the process. I do not know whether it is appropriate at this stage to actually mention the company's name, but I would be inclined not to unless Senator Patterson was quite insistent.

—I know the company's name, so I do not know that it is all that secret. The company approached DSS to run a pilot program. It was not then thought appropriate by DSS to ask other similar companies to outline a possible pilot program and select from them. It would seem that the company that has the pilot program is highly likely to be one of the successful tenderers as it is more familiar with the Department and the Department's requirements. By approaching the Department, a company puts itself in an advantageous position, I would have thought.

—The advice I have is that the innovative idea was put to the Department by this particular company. The Department exhaustively assessed it, I suppose that is the best way to put it. Before it went any further, having assessed it, the Department then approached other companies and issued an invitation for expressions of interest from the public at large, I suppose, to see what other ideas were about in relation to this particular proposal. So the idea was initially assessed, but before it went too far down the track, calls for expressions of interest were made public.

—I just want to get this straight. Is the Minister telling me that the company approached DSS with an idea and then DSS assessed it and issued a statement calling for expressions of interest for people to run the pilot program?

—The best way to sum it up is that, having been presented with an innovative idea, the Department was keen to assess it and was also keen to establish whether it was an idea that would work financially. Having in the first instance assessed its feasibility, the Department then went out to the broader community to see who could fulfil the program once its feasibility was established. So the first part was to establish its feasibility; the second part where the public was invited was basically the business part of the deal.

—The Minister is using the word `feasibility' now when I am using the term `pilot program'. Is what we are getting at that the feasibility program was undertaken by the company that initiated the contact with DSS?

—I think that what we are getting lost on here is the definition of the term `pilot project'. The potential efficiencies of a click charge system were proposed to the Department. The Department then undertook a trial in a small number of offices: the National Administration Systems Division, the Goulburn regional office, the south-west New South Wales area office and the Springwood regional office in Victoria. That was the extent of the feasibility of the project.

PARA.TAB: The feasibility went very much to the question of what sort of cost could be retained and whether the proposal was cost-effective. That is what the feasibility program based in four offices was geared to ascertain. So it was not a major pilot project with the company getting a leg in on this basis. The Department checked the financial costing, probably more than any other aspect of the proposal. Having made an assessment, on 1 April the Department issued an invitation to the broader community for expressions of interest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was the company that approached DSS involved in that trial, feasibility, pilot project, pilot program, whatever we call it, process?
—I think we all know that it was. As I tried to say earlier—
—I did not know that it was. That is why I am asking.
—That was one of the complaints that has been put forward. I presumed that Senator Patterson knew that.
—I am asking the Minister.

—I am now telling Senator Patterson that the company was involved. As I say, the important aspect of that first step in the process, I am informed, was to assess the feasibility in terms of costing of the proposal. That was one of the points that was raised by way of complaint by some of the tenderers to the Minister and to the departmental secretary. That was the other complaint that I referred to earlier.

—The reason I asked that question was that I wanted to know from the Minister. I do not think I got the answer last time I asked the question, maybe because I was not asking it the right way. What I wanted to know was: were any people involved in that company that approached the Department's former officers; or were the principals, managers or people involved in that company former DSS employees or ministerial staff—anybody who would have had a previous association with DSS?
—Not that the officers are aware.
—Could the Minister tell me whether this pilot project included mainframe and desktop publishing printers as well as photocopiers?
—It included desktop printers, but not mainframe printers.
—Would the Minister agree with the comment that the way the pilot project was conducted left the Department open to criticism of over-identification with one company?

—The advice I have is that the process, after the preliminary analysis of responses, was such that, given the controversy which the proposal aroused—particularly in the photocopying industry—the Department proceeded to release a draft tender for industry comment in June for a period of four weeks. Industry comments were taken into account in the final preparation of the tender.

PARA.TAB: Further advice is that this process is in keeping with government IT policy. Although the Department did not originally plan to issue a tender in this way, it undertook a staged procurement process to define its requirements more clearly and, through that, to allow industry sufficient time to prepare for an innovative way of doing business with the Commonwealth. The point of all that is that releasing a draft tender for industry comment was an important aspect of broader public consultation and participation. The other point I make is that I am informed that the process that was adopted was in line with government tendering processes in the IT area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did DAS approach DSS or vice versa to discuss either the conduct of the pilot feasibility study or the tender process?

—The advice I have, which I think has been given to Senator Patterson in answer to question No. 122, is that there have been discussions between the purchasing services branch of DAS and DSS about the tender process. The advice I have is that at no stage was it suggested that the Department's approach contravened procurement guidelines or that there was any concern about the tender process. As I say, that answer has been provided already. It might be in Senator Patterson's office if she does not have it here.
—Have any criteria other than price been involved in determining the successful tenderer and will the tender go to the tenderer who produces the lowest bid?

—As to the first part of the question, the process has not been completed and we would not want to pre-empt it. As to the second part of the question, there are different components to the tender. For the sake of the record, 21 responses were received to the tender; two tenders offered total solutions and 14 are part tenders. In terms of the government procurement policy, if the DAS guidelines were to be applied, the concept of value for money would be the determinative factor, rather than the cheapest price. That concept of value for money takes into account all sorts of other factors. The evaluation criteria have obviously been published. We could make them available to Senator Patterson. That might help her to define on what grounds the final decision will be taken.

—I appreciate that and I would also appreciate it if the Minister could give me a copy of the invitation to register interest and the tender documents and evaluation criteria for this tender. The Minister spoke of part tenders. Is that associated with those who are not able to meet the mainframe computing and desktop publishing printers? Is the problem that some of them cannot actually deal with both parts of the project?

—It is not as simple as that. The tender does call for total or partial solutions. The partial solutions Senator Patterson mentioned are not the only partial solutions that have been tendered. We are talking about tenderers who might, in part tendering, tender for mainframe, photocopying, desktop, specialist printing and distributive printing. All those specific aspects of the tendering plan can be, and have been, individually tendered for.
—Is it a prerequisite that one company be able to supply the photocopier, the printers and the mainframes, or can it supply part of it?
—It does not have to be one company. Partial tenders are, of course, allowed.
—Was the invitation to register interest designed and conducted in-house by DSS?
—Yes.
—Was the Department of Administrative Services involved at all in that process?
—I am informed that DAS was not involved in the initial RTO. There have been consultations since then, as I mentioned earlier, but my Department was not involved in the initial RTO.
—How did the Minister's Department get involved and in what way?

—The advice I am getting is that, since DSS followed the guidelines, there was no need for DAS intervention. The degree of DAS intervention has been consultation in respect of the tendering process and advice on guidelines and what guidelines meant. If there is anything further to add to that, we will let Senator Patterson know. That seems to be the extent of the interaction.

—How many of the Department's current photocopiers will be replaced as a result of changing to click charge photocopying? What will happen if any of those photocopiers are made obsolete? Will they be made obsolete before the normal time they would have been made redundant by being depreciated at the rate they are in the Department?

—As a general rule, there will be replacement of all domestic photocopying equipment. As part of the request for tender, the issue which needs to be addressed is that of purchasing photocopiers which are already in place. That is one determinative factor in the final selection process. One can see from that that, in our lay person's jargon, a bit of a trade-in arrangement has been anticipated. The other aspect which needs to be taken into account is that the Department has been discouraging its officers from buying new photocopiers over recent months so that there is not a major problem with new photocopiers when this arrangement comes into place.

—Finally, given the number of complaints that the Minister, my colleagues and I have received, how confident would the Government be if an independent investigation were undertaken into the conduct of this tender from the commencement of the pilot project onwards?
—It is fair to say that nothing has been brought forward that would warrant an investigation. That is the Government's position.
—So you would be happy if we had one?
—No. Nothing has been brought forward that would warrant an investigation.

—I wish to put a question on notice. Can the Minister provide an outline of the organisational structure—that is, the chain of command or hierarchical structure—including names of the officers involved, from the lowest level of the Department's ACT printing facilities upwards during the period 1985-90. Who is the most senior person responsible in the printing department at Tuggeranong? To whom does he or she report? Who is the next most senior person?

PARA.TAB: I then want a hierarchical structure of the Department down to the most junior person in the Department. I would like to have the names of the officers who held those positions during 1985-90. I ask that that information be given to us by the end of next week, if that is possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can produce organisational structures, and we will do so. In terms of names, we need to tread sensitively here, not for the reason that the matter has been referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs for further examination but because of the fact that it is being investigated by the Federal Police. We need to be careful that we do not in any way jeopardise either their investigations or any proceedings that might come after that.

PARA.TAB: It is not an intention to keep anyone out of the public spotlight; it is very much to ensure that due process of investigations and the law are not jeopardised. So we will provide the structure, but I am loath at this stage to say that we will provide the names of personnel who might be under investigation. We will take that aspect of it on notice. If we can provide information, we will do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not find that a satisfactory answer. I do not think that giving us the names of the people in the various positions is in any way likely to jeopardise the investigations of the Australian Federal Police. We have had this out once before in the Estimates Committee. I was told then I could not be given the information for a number of reasons. I sought legal advice and found that none of those reasons was justified. I sought to try to look at this as sensitively as possible, given the fact that all of us would like to see, if there has been a misuse of the Department's printing facilities, that those responsible be brought to account. I do not believe that giving me the structure and the names of those people who fitted into it over the period from 1985 to 1990 will jeopardise this in any way. I request that the Minister provide me with that information.

—I have nothing further to add. If people are to be brought to account in these circumstances, they should be brought to account in accordance with the law, the investigative procedures that are laid down for the Federal Police and the processes of justice. I do not think that we at this stage should be intervening in that in any way.

PARA.TAB: I have tried to be helpful. But my advice to Senator Patterson is that it would be at least inappropriate to release the names of people at the moment. People are under investigation, and that investigation should be allowed to run to its conclusion before we intervene at this level.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not asking the Minister to release the names of the people under investigation. I am asking him to give me the hierarchical structure and the people who filled those positions from 1985 to 1990. I do not want asterisks on the list indicating those who are currently under investigation. All I want to know is who was in those positions between 1985 and 1990.
—I have already answered the question as best I can. I do not think that I can add anything else that would be productive.

—I request those names. If the Minister will not give me those answers, I will pursue the matter further. It is appropriate for this Senate to have the names of people—it is fairly public information—and who filled what positions. I request that the Minister give me that information. If he refuses that request, I will seek alternative ways of obtaining that information. I am telling the Minister this now so that, if he wants, he can make it easy for himself. He ought to trust me on the way that I will use that information. I do not think I have ever abused that trust—
—I wouldn't trust you as far as I could throw you.

—I thank the Minister. I find that absolutely charming. The feeling is most probably mutual. My record stands for those occasions when I have been given information in confidence. I can give the Minister a perfect example. I was trying to pursue the names of those doctors who were on the vocational register for Medicare. I was told in the Estimates Committee that I was not able to get a list of those people because of the privacy aspects of the Health Act. That was absolute nonsense. It was the same sort of garbage that the Minister is giving me now.

PARA.TAB: If I wanted to, I could go to every Medicare office and get the list of every vocationally registered doctor and form the list myself, and that was the argument I put forward. When Senator Tate felt that I had sufficient information to indicate that there were problems with those lists, he gave me that list in confidence. Senator Zakharov is sitting on the opposite side of the chamber. She knows that I was given that list as a member of that Committee. I used it with absolute discretion, and I did not abuse it.

As a result of my having had that list, we now have a much better list. Unfortunately, we have vocationally registered doctors, but that is beside the point. But we have a much more accurate list than we had before because the Department was held to account. That was an appropriate use of this Senate and this procedure.

I find the fact that this Minister will not give me that information not acceptable, as I do his belief that I would abuse it in any way. Are the Australian Federal Police investigations into the alleged misuse of the Department's printing facilities being conducted by the ACT branch or the central branch of the Australian Federal Police?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is best that Senator Patterson ask that of the Australian Federal Police.
—I want to know whether the ACT branch or the central branch of the AFP is involved in the investigations.

—It is an organisational issue of the AFP. We do not know. Senator Patterson should ask the question of the Australian Federal Police when they come up and, if they feel that they can answer it, she will find out and then we will all know.

—I am asking the Minister whether the ACT branch or the central branch of the AFP is involved. Somebody in the Department must know whether the ACT branch or the central branch of the AFP is dealing with this.
—I have already answered this question. Senator Patterson can ask the AFP.
—I want to know whether the ACT branch or the central branch of the AFP is involved in the investigation.
—I just do not know. I have told Senator Patterson that we do not know. How many times do I have to tell her?
—I ask the Minister to find out.
—The honourable senator can ask the Federal Police tomorrow.

—I am asking the Minister. This is a departmental inquiry—an inquiry that is being undertaken in the DSS. I want to know whether the ACT branch or the central branch of the AFP is involved. I have a reason for asking it.

—This is the Department of Social Security, as distinct from the Australian Federal Police. This is not a departmental investigation; this is an AFP investigation. This Department is not conducting it; the AFP is. Some time later today, members of the AFP will be here. Senator Patterson should ask them then. We just do not know. The people here with me tonight do not know. Senator Patterson will find out much quicker if she asks them tomorrow. If they are in a position to tell her, I am sure they will. I am in no position to tell her and nor is anyone here. Senator Patterson should get it straight: this is not a departmental investigation; this is an AFP investigation.

—I know it is an AFP investigation, and I know that the Minister could get one of his departmental officers to find out which branch it is. If the Minister were reasonable, he would be able to give me that answer before we rose tomorrow. I think it is inappropriate to say to me, `You can sit here and wait until the AFP comes on'. She has come in here and asked for information all night, and she has received a fair whack. I cannot give her this one—unlike her shower and unlike her change of nominee. She is a disgrace to her side of the Parliament. I have told her that I cannot do it. I will not ring someone at 12.30 tonight, wake them up and say, `Is it the ACT mob or the Federal Police?'. TALK.START.PARA: —The first Department to be considered is the Attorney-General's Department. We will again take the matters as they appear on the running sheet. I will start with program 1 and subprogram 1.1. Are there any matters for consideration? Are there any matters on program 2, component 2.2.1? Are there any matters on component 2.3.1? We will move to program 3. Are there any matters on subprogram 3.1? Are there any matters on subprogram 3.4?

—I wish to refer to the provision of legal aid and family services. During the Estimates hearings I raised the issue of Australian taxpayers funding legal expenses for Iranian nationals. Whilst the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate) said that some of the Iranians had resident status, others were not Australian citizens. I take that one step further by asking: of those who are receiving legal aid, what is the total number who are Australian taxpayers?

PARA.TAB: I feel this point is important because it is other taxpayers who are paying for the defence of the Iranians. I believe that it is necessary to know exactly how much those Iranians may have contributed to our system and how much they have cost our system. So could I get a more up-to-date estimate of the order of costs which will be involved in defending the Iranians and ask what has been spent to date.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, there are several elements to Senator Calvert's question, which concerns the provision of legal aid to enable certain persons charged with serious offences in relation to the attack on the Iranian Embassy to obtain representation so that counsel could be provided in the committal proceedings, which I think were concluded a couple of days ago, with 13 defendants being committed for trial.

PARA.TAB: I think I have explained before that, of the 13 charged in relation to the incident, five were denied legal aid. That means that eight were provided with legal aid. The five being denied legal aid were, of course, denied legal aid on various bases, but included amongst them would have been a sufficiency of assets.

Of the eight who were left qualified to receive legal aid, they were citizens or lawful residents; they had permanent residence. I need to just emphasise that because in some popular imagination there is some image of those charged being persons who had just flown in to create this incident, about which I do not want to say a great deal.

So the eight who were left qualified and who were assessed as fulfilling the criteria to enable them to receive legal aid from the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission were citizens or lawful residents. By definition, in order to qualify for legal aid, they have to have a very low capacity to fund their own legal representation. So the normal rules would have been applied by the Australian Capital Territory Legal Aid Commission to their income and assets. The threshold is such that one has to be really very poor indeed these days to qualify for legal aid from the point of view of means.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not kidding.

—Senator Macdonald agrees with that comment. In that situation, whilst I am unable to tell Senator Calvert—obviously it would be a matter of privacy and confidentiality between the ACT Legal Aid Commission and the applicants as to even the amount of income which they might have earned in any one year—I think we can assume that their income would be such that their payment of tax would be very small indeed, if at all. In that respect, I can give only an indirect answer.

—I will follow that up by asking: what guidelines apply for overseas nationals receiving legal aid? Is a period of permanent residency required to receive legal aid or can anybody who comes in from overseas on a visitors visa and who becomes stranded here receive legal aid?

—I am not quite sure of the answer to that. It may vary from commission to commission. We are now in a difficult transition situation where the High Court, the highest judicial tribunal in Australia, ruled only two days ago that there is a common law right to a fair trial. Included in that common law right is the notion that if a person is faced with the prospect of being convicted for a serious offence, which I guess is judged by the sort of penalty that might be imposed if the conviction were secured by the prosecution, if a guilty verdict were obtained, then the judge ought to consider whether that person needs to be represented. If that person is not represented, a magistrate has been invited by the High Court to consider adjourning the matter. In other words, the prosecution cannot proceed.

PARA.TAB: The implication from that decision of the High Court—as I say, brought down only two days ago—would be that a person, whatever his background, if faced with a criminal trial for a serious offence, would be in a situation where the High Court ruling would oblige the judge to consider whether a fair trial requires representation. In many situations, that would involve representation through an arrangement made by the relevant legal aid commission.

I can get the exact details of the current practice, but it will have to change. Legal aid commissions around Australia have been alerted to this High Court decision. My best inference from the decision would be that any person facing a serious charge has a right to a fair trial in so far as that includes representation. If the person cannot afford that representation, it is likely that the matter would be adjourned until the representation is provided, no doubt at public expense, through a legal aid commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand then that at this point in time anybody is entitled to legal aid. There does not seem to be any upper limit on the amount of legal aid provided. Could the Minister tell me whether the estimate that he gave me during the Estimates hearings of about $1m for this particular defence of these eight lawful residents still stands?

—I am asking the officers to find the exact amount. But, as I recall, at the time of Estimates, it looked as though the funding required for the committal stage would not be anywhere near as much as had been anticipated.
—About $100,000, as I remember.

—About $100,000. As I am advised, the 13 people have been committed for trial in the ACT Supreme Court. That will no doubt involve considerable expenditure, once again because of the complexity and the novelty of the common purpose charge which has been laid against them and which will be the subject of the criminal trial. I imagine there would be considerable expenditure, but my officers cannot give me an indication at the moment. It will be considerable, I would have to concede that.

—I think the original estimate was up to $1m. Given that we are such a generous nation and given the reasons the Minister has advanced this morning why we should provide legal aid, it is very hard for me to explain the position to people who come into my office on an almost weekly basis and say they have been denied legal aid because they happen to own a house. These people come from places such as Glenorchy and Chigwell. They are having problems getting legal aid for family settlements and the like. I do not think it is of any benefit to them to realise that eight people, who, as the Minister pointed out, are lawful residents of Australia—certainly they came from overseas not all that long ago—are going to receive up to $1m.

PARA.TAB: On top of that, we find that the Iranian Embassy staff who were injured during that attack are going to get $300,000 in compensation from the Federal Government, and the Embassy itself is going to receive $187,000. So on top of the estimated $1m that the defendants will get in legal aid, the Government is going to be very generous and cough up another half a million dollars. This raises a few other matters. Where is the money coming from? Is this an admission of guilt on behalf of the Federal Government for the lack of security at the Iranian Embassy?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question of security at the Embassy has already been dealt with in various forums of the Senate. I will explain how the ordinary operations of legal aid commissions, in order to fund precisely the sorts of cases that come to honourable senators on a constituency basis, are preserved by Federal Government arrangements. If the Legal Aid Commission in the ACT had been faced with catastrophic costs from a major criminal trial, it would been bankrupted and would have been stripped of the funds that would otherwise have been used for referrals in perhaps the equivalent of many hundreds of cases.

PARA.TAB: Where there is such a major funding problem confronting a legal aid commission, we would require the commission to pay, I think, 5 per cent of the prospective costs, or $100,000 in the case of the ACT, whichever is the less, and we make up the balance. We do so precisely to enable the legal aid commissions to keep their funds intact for the many hundreds, if not thousands, of cases which we are all very familiar with and which are very deserving.

The ACT Legal Aid Commission applied the normal criteria to decide on the eligibility of those who allegedly were involved in this incident at the Iranian Embassy. The costs, in prospect, were enormous. The Federal Government applied this particular new arrangement and has come in to assist in the funding. That preserves funds for the other ACT residents who may wish to make application to the Legal Aid Commission for help in criminal or family law matters or whatever it may be.

Under the very dynamic leadership of Mr Colin Brown, the Tasmanian Legal Aid Commission is operating without a deficit. It has reached a situation where, certainly in the coming year, it will be in a very strong position to broaden its capacity to offer legal aid to those who come seeking such assistance. This is very meritorious and much to be commended.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has not answered the other question I asked about the amount of money being paid in compensation to the Embassy. I made the point that the Federal Government has been very generous in compensating the Embassy itself for injuries. Why did the Embassy not institute civil proceedings against those who committed the crime and why should the Australian taxpayers have to pay all this compensation?
—I am not quite sure that that question is covered by this subprogram. If the Minister has any comment, I will ask him to make it.

—Mr Chairman, you are quite right: this is a matter that would be best and only really capable of being answered by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Gareth Evans). But very broadly speaking, there must be some obligation on the Australian Government, as the guarantor or protector of foreign embassies and consulates in Australia, where damage is done and where vandalism or attack leaves a premises in disrepair. The obligation falls on the Australian Government, no doubt under some international arrangement, provision, treaty or convention, as the responsible authority in that particular situation. This is the normal international practice and I believe it would be followed in this case. I can undertake to get Senator Calvert a more authoritative statement from the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade.

PARA.TAB: The Hansard of the Estimates of 10 September shows that I told Senator Calvert that at that stage the ACT Legal Aid Commission had been paid $103,000; that at that stage there were two or three more days to go in the committal; and that it was estimated that committal costs, including amounts already paid, should be no more than $200,000. Across the chamber earlier I may have said $100,000. The guess, if it went to trial, was between $700,000 and $800,000. I will undertake to get a better written estimate for Senator Calvert. Now that the committal proceedings have been concluded, we ought to have the final figures for that and some estimate of the likely cost of the trial.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vanstone, do you wish to speak to subprogram 3.4 or 4.2?

—I have a reservation in relation to subprogram 3.1. TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that Senator Vanstone has received certain information relating to the travel details she sought of what she terms as frequent travellers. It was a fairly broad request within the Estimates committee process. I do not think there can be any fault attached to those who have forwarded the information to Senator Vanstone or the Committee in not understanding the further more elaborate detail which she requires.

PARA.TAB: I understand that Senator Vanstone indicated to the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission officer yesterday, or perhaps on Friday, that she was seeking further details. Each of the commissioners, or the most frequent travellers, have been notified in writing of that further request and they have obviously been asked to go through their travel diaries and provide the further information. I am quite confident that that will be forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —When does the Minister think it will be forthcoming? We are talking about $52,000 worth of travelling allowance—two months of a year spent away. I wish to correct what might be a misunderstanding of my first remarks. I am not casting any aspersions in respect of the officers who prepared the original information. I made a point of saying that I thought there might have been a misunderstanding as to what I was asking for when I asked for further information. That was only in relation to the top three travellers.

PARA.TAB: Quite frankly, we read that the Human Rights Commissioner, who is so concerned—and rightly, I might add—about homeless children and what we should be doing for lower income groups, has walked away with $52,000 worth of travelling allowance. It says Geneva, London and Paris. It is really not good enough, is it? The travel allowance for one of those trips was in the vicinity of $12,000 and the other was roughly the same. So, about half of the Commissioner's travelling allowance was taken up by overseas travel. It is just not good enough to say that he was attending meetings of the such and such committee.
