In relation to Commissioner Bryce and Commissioner O'Connor, my concern is not anywhere near as serious because their travelling allowance was significantly less. Nonetheless, each of them was away for one month. The explanation as to what they were doing for that month is a bit thin. It is all very well for the Minister to say that the information is forthcoming but it is not here now. It is not available for scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing I should do is indicate that it was most unfortunate that Senator Vanstone contrasted the travel allowance that the Human Rights Commissioner has received with homeless children. The honourable senator tried to insinuate that that is somehow at odds with his professed concern for homeless children. That was a juxtaposition and a way of putting things which I think is grossly unfair. On further consideration, I do not believe that trying to make that contrast properly reflects Senator Vanstone's real belief in this matter.

PARA.TAB: The question properly before the Committee is whether the travel allowance, whatever amount it is, was properly justified and therefore authorised, and whether payments were properly made. Senator Vanstone has conceded that there was no attempt to obfuscate the situation in terms of what was provided to her initially. It may have been a genuine misunderstanding. She clarified that with the officer yesterday or on Friday. The material is being further sought. There will be no hesitation or problem in it being put together. It is simply a question of time to go through the diaries. I would imagine that by the time we resume next week the material will be available to Senator Vanstone. There is no attempt to impede or frustrate her getting access to this material; it is simply a question of putting it together, and that will be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can I take it that it will be done by the time we come back next week?
—I am instructing that it be done—that is as much as I can do—in order that it be available for Question Time when we next resume.
—Is it correct that the commissioners need to seek approval for their overseas travel before they go?

—Certainly in my portfolio, and I would think in regard to commissioners of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission, it is normal practice to seek the approval of the Minister for overseas travel.

—Perhaps I will try to put a couple of questions into one question. Would the requests to the Attorney-General reveal the information that I want? Would the Commissioner be able to write to the Attorney and say, `I want to go away for a month overseas to these cities to attend these committees', and just leave it at that, or would the Attorney require further detail than that before he agreed to pay travelling allowance for each of the days that the Commissioner is away? That would be of some assistance. If it is the case that before travelling allowance is paid for each day away one has to justify to the Attorney what one is doing on these days, the correspondence between the Attorney-General's Department and the Human Rights Commissioner would give me the information I require.

PARA.TAB: If that is not the case, I suppose it means that the Attorney-General has approved these trips simply by being told that the Commissioner needs a month away to do a certain number of things, and we will have no more detail than that. In that case, the detail will have to come from the Human Rights Commission. That is the first question. In summary, that relates to the detail that is provided to the Attorney-General prior to his approving travel.

The second question is: have there been occasions when the Human Rights Commissioner has either gone overseas without such approval or has undertaken activities overseas which were not in the first instance approved by the Attorney-General? The third question is: has there been any correspondence between the Attorney-General's Department and the Human Rights Commission expressing dissatisfaction or concern in any way whatsoever with the travel entitlements and/or arrangements and the procedure for approving travel by the Human Rights Commissioner?

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first question, my experience as a Minister is that the head of an agency indicates that an invitation has been received, or that a paper is to be delivered at a conference in a particular destination; some indication might be given either formally in writing or informally over the phone, or in person, about the sorts of activities that might be undertaken, the sorts of people that might be seen, and the deliberations and consultations that occur; but, no, the request itself is not made in a detailed hour by hour form, which is apparently what Senator Vanstone is seeking.
—Not hour by hour; day by day.

—We will have to await the response that Senator Vanstone is seeking from the commissioners concerned. Secondly, Senator Vanstone asked whether the Human Rights Commissioner has ever travelled abroad without prior approval from the Attorney-General. I would say almost certainly not, but we can check that. I cannot conceive that that would be the case.

PARA.TAB: Senator Vanstone also asked whether an alteration in the itinerary has taken place in the course of the travel overseas. Once again, I suppose she was referring to an alteration without some notification to the Attorney-General and a request to approve that alteration in the itinerary. That can be checked on. But in relation to one incident which Senator Vanstone mentioned to me privately, that particular diversion was notified to the Attorney-General's office and approval was given for that particular trip. That is my understanding. If there is anything different to report, we can triple check that.

Thirdly, Senator Vanstone asked whether there had been any correspondence or any indication from within the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission of some misgivings or dissatisfaction with the way in which travel arrangements were made. I am not aware of any such correspondence, memo or submission. If one can be found in the Attorney-General's Department, we will check it out. But the officers here who have some supervisory role in that area are not immediately aware of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister whether he would be happy to table as soon as possible—possibly later today—any correspondence, documents or memos that indicate the dates and times when approval was sought by the Commissioner for the trip to Moscow, and the detail that was offered to the Attorney-General, in whatever form it was offered, to allow him to assess whether or not he would approve the Commissioner's trip to Moscow. In other words, is it exactly right that permission was sought for that trip prior to it being undertaken?

—Our clear understanding is that prior approval was sought. That is definitely what is understood by officers here. Of course, that can be checked. As far as any documentation, memorandums or memories of telephone conversations are involved, as soon as we can put some material together we will no doubt be in a position to advise Senator Vanstone about this. But I could not guarantee to have that available by 3.30 p.m. Without the House of Representatives sitting, the Attorney-General and his office are functioning in Melbourne today rather than in Canberra at Parliament House. But we will notify them of Senator Vanstone's request as soon as possible.
—Could you guarantee to have it available by the next sitting of the Senate—by next week?
—I imagine I will be able to answer all of these questions by the time the Senate comes together.
—When does the Minister think I will have the opportunity to ask all these questions, as this is all being shoved through at the last minute?
—Senator Vanstone is one of the most innovative, imaginative and aggressive senators from the other side, and I am sure that with due grace but perseverance she will find a way.

—Are there any further questions in relation to subprogram 3.1? I think we have covered subprogram 3.4, and there being no further questions we will move to program 4. Are there any matters to be raised under subprograms 4.2, 4.4 or 4.5?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make some comments quickly about Auscript and see what the Minister has to say in terms of clarifying for me exactly where Auscript is heading. Auscript cost the taxpayer $6.8m in the last financial year, and will cost the taxpayer $4.3m in 1992-1993. I think it is the time to ask about the question of fairness of the subsidisation of a service that apparently engages in predatory pricing against its private sector competitors, yet delivers a service at far greater cost than is produced by private court reporting services. I want to know how the Minister can justify this along the lines of the same issue that was raised with Comcar. I draw the attention of the Committee to particular answers that I obtained to a series of questions with regard to Auscript. These related to billable hours and total pages transcribed over 1991-92, and to revenue and expenditure for that year. When the market rate of $25 per hour is applied to 68,193 billable hours, we get a total $1.7m. But applying the market rate of $7 per page to 767,966 pages results in a total of $5.4m. Thus, in the absence of Auscript, the commercial sector could have done the same work at a cost of $7.1m. Instead, actual revenue obtained by Auscript was $12.6m—an excess of $5.5m that can only suggest that Auscript is benefiting from a clientele that is still locked in and is certainly unable to benefit from market rates. When the figure of expenditure of $19.5m is considered, it can be said that the workload of Auscript cost an extra $12.4m. I would like to know from the Minister how he can possibly justify that.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is surprising that an answer to my question as to an average cost per page of transcript could not be supplied. But it has been made clear, in the answers to my questions on notice and in the answers given by Auscript, that as a government agency it operates under significantly different conditions than its private sector competitors. I ask the Minister, if Auscript is going to compete in the private sector, why that should be. Auscript is, of course, free of the requirement to pay sales tax, payroll tax, company tax and fees to the ASC. In the last two financial years, it has received capital grants of $3.9m from the taxpayer for its commercial establishment—grants that it is not required to repay. The private sector would be laughed at if it asked for a grant of $3.9m from the taxpayer.

The Deputy Secretary of the Attorney-General's Department told the Estimates Committee on 10 September that Auscript makes a payment to Comcare that is equivalent to a workers compensation payment, but went on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I make no suggestion as to how it might relate to a commercial organisation's premium.
I suppose that that is exactly right. Auscript certainly comes from a different world.

PARA.TAB: On the other hand, we were told that Auscript requires a $2.5m direct subsidy as the net difference for the cost disadvantage caused by operating in the government sector. Pretty weak examples of superannuation costing Auscript $775,000 in higher rentals are cited. I can only say that claims of disadvantage do not impress the commercial court reporters, who have to operate under the ultimate sanction—either you pay or go out of business. For example, in Western Australia, a private company has been beaten to a tender by Auscript by one dollar.

We are getting beyond the stage of reality. On the one hand, the answers to questions show only too well that the Australian taxpayer would get better value for money if Auscript were scrapped and all services were contracted to the private sector. But, on the other hand, it is clear that Auscript is using inflated revenue from its government clients and its protected position to engage in predatory competition with the commercial sector. I would like the Minister to explain to me why that is fair. I still relate it to the Comcar case, because it is very similar.

It is stated that non-government clients are being targeted, and we can see the results of an expenditure of $424,000 in marketing for 1991-92. How can the Government justify spending nearly half a million dollars on marketing when the private companies would obviously not be able to do that and have to charge more? Some of this marketing would seem to take the form of approaching the client of a commercial firm and offering to perform, as I mentioned before, the same service for $1 per page less.

Given the revenue figures per volume of work, we can only conclude that Auscript is charging such rates at as much as one-third of the average costs. It is ironic that this Government has now instituted the independent inquiry into competition policy to resist anti-competitive conduct that `should apply to all market participants, regardless of the form of business ownership'. One of its own agencies is clearly violating this principle. I hope that such matters are pursued vigorously by the Hilmer Committee.

We have to be suspicious of the switch by the New South Wales Independent Commission Against Corruption to Auscript because it offered a `significantly cheaper tender than Spark and Cannon'. The normal practice was not followed and details of the tender were not released to its unsuccessful rival. I ask the Minister why. What is Auscript trying to hide? Let us face it, Auscript remains a government agency supported by the taxpayers' money. The figures prove that we are not getting value for money. We should not be giving a public agency support to enable it to undercut the commercial private sector.

I have raised a number of issues that are of great concern to the private sector. I certainly seek the Minister's answer as to what it can expect in the future. Will this predatory pricing continue? What sort of subsidy will Auscript get from the Government in the months ahead?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Knowles raised a series of matters in relation to Auscript and its operation. It has been a matter of concern to Estimates committees over the years because, quite frankly, the transition into the marketplace by Auscript has been far too slow. I certainly know that Senator Vanstone and I have commented on that at various times during Estimates committees over the years.

PARA.TAB: We have to be extremely careful about some of the allegations made by Senator Knowles. I am not in a position, and I do not know that Senator Knowles is, to speak of what prices might have been offered or what tenders might have been put in by Auscript in competition with other providers of such services, or to know whether the claim about predatory pricing could be justified. It needs to be pointed out that the Trade Practices Commission jurisdiction applies to Commonwealth agencies such as Auscript. So if it has indulged in predatory pricing or if those in the marketplace consider that those sorts of practices have been engaged in to their detriment, without wanting to encourage any particular course of action, I point out to those people that there is a proper avenue to pursue that.

I believe very strongly that Auscript ought to be very conscious of its obligation to refrain from predatory pricing, not as a matter of goodwill or charity to others in the marketplace but as a matter of law. This Parliament says in the Trade Practices Act that, in this case, this Commonwealth agency shall not engage in predatory pricing. I would be very anxious to ensure that that law is adhered to.

There is also a bit of quid pro quo in this whole matter. I believe that the transition to subject Auscript to proper market disciplines has been too long. But, as Senator Knowles will know, from 30 June next year the tied Commonwealth work will no longer be guaranteed to Auscript. I am talking here about the Federal Court and the Family Court. I think the Industrial Relations Commission is tied; certainly the courts are.

In this situation, private enterprise will be able to tender and really put Auscript to the test. That will be a very exciting and traumatic time. It will really test Auscript and the private competitors. I believe that, in that situation, much of this difficulty that we have all adverted to will come to the crunch.

TALK.START.PARA: —But Auscript still won't have the overheads of the private sector.

—It remains true that it will have a different set of overheads to those of the private sector. That is no doubt the case. But I also have confidence that some of those overheads are such that they will increase costs. I do not have the exact analysis of the full components of those overheads, but I imagine that, nevertheless, the sorts of costs per page that we know are charged in relation, for example, to Family Court transcripts and so on indicate that great expenses are still built into the operation. I feel confident that Auscript will be really put to the test by the private sector from 30 June next year.
—Will it still get the capital grants?

—I am told that it will be budget supported to the extent to which being a government agency imposes greater costs on it than would otherwise be the case if it were operating solely as a private sector organisation.
—As there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 4.5, we will move to subprogram 6.1.

—Mr Chairman, with your indulgence, I wish to raise another matter involving program 3. I will put on notice my questions in relation to the Hmong family in Hobart, which was receiving legal aid; the Minister can answer them later. I also have a few more questions on subprogram 6.1, which concerns whether the Federal Police were consulted about paying compensation in relation to the Iranian Embassy. I will put them on notice. In terms of subprogram 6.4—
—We have not quite got there yet. You were behind me and now you are ahead of me. As there are no questions in relation to subprogram 6.1, we will now move to subprogram 6.4.

—We all know that we are racing through today and putting questions on notice because the Australian Democrats did a deal with the Government in applying the guillotine. Nevertheless, I wish to ask some very serious questions, particularly under subprogram 6.4, regarding the Law Enforcement Access Network, known as LEAN. I have some grave concerns about that, as does the Privacy Commissioner. I received confusing advice during Estimates about the number of terminals that will be provided—be it 10,500 or 3,000—and whether the code passwords will be secure. Those matters are of concern to me, as they should be to the people of Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also raised concerns during Estimates hearings about the letting of a contract to Admiral Computing in England of some $60,000 a month to advise on the tender process. When I asked questions on that particular matter I ran into a brick wall. I hope the Department is in a better frame of mind now and can answer these questions when I put them on notice because I want to know whether the Australian people got value for money from this particular advice. The fact of a quarter of a million dollars going to a computing company which returned to England before the job was completed does worry me a bit.

Whilst we are on computer programs, I have some questions here on the Department's legal office information system, commonly known as LOIS. The questions on notice will be asking the Minister and the Department where the project is and whether it is true that the whole thing has been stopped because the KPMG solutions team has found that software development is an impossible task. They have allegedly had $17m to date and we have nothing to show for it. So I will put all those questions on notice if I may.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you.

—There being no further questions, that concludes the examination of the Estimates for the Attorney-General's Department. We now move to the Estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. There being no questions on previous programs, we move to subprogram 2.2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe the Department has contacted Senator Newman about this matter. It is well aware that I will be asking questions on this matter, particularly regarding a constituent, Mr David Fleming. I will try to be as brief as I can because I believe that Health has to be completed by 11 o'clock. I put the other questions on notice so that I could spend a little more time on this matter.

PARA.TAB: During Estimates hearings, Senator Newman put a number of questions on notice. In answer to one of the questions, on page E213, `Why has the Department been unable to supply a leg which satisfies the needs of Mr Fleming?', the Minister stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Department has gone to exceptional lengths to assist Mr Fleming.
He also stated:
The most recent example was at the Central Development Unit in Melbourne on 8 May 1992 when a socket was made which, in the opinion of the CDU staff and the specialist involved, fitted properly.
I would like to ask why Mr Ashford, in a letter to Mr Fleming of 24 June, said:

I have therefore decided that the only solution for you is to take the limb to Hobart RALAC where the staff can make any reasonable adjustment. However I have instructed the manager that he will not be permitted to spend unlimited time on your case.

I can accept all of that, but why was Mr Fleming referred to Hobart when the Repatriation Hospital Heidelberg documents dated 8 May show that the patient was to be advised as to future appointments at CDU in Melbourne to further pursue the socket work. It was also referred to again in another document of 4 June from the Royal Hobart Hospital. The document states: `further treatment if necessary to be advised re the Melbourne appointment'. The `exceptional lengths' that were gone to in CDU in Melbourne on 8 May to fit Mr Fleming with an above-knee prosthesis, to me anyway, do not seem to be followed up.

PARA.TAB: The matter was referred to Hobart and Mr Fleming in fact believes that the attention he would get there would not be the same as that which could be supplied at CDU in Melbourne. I know it is a complicated question, but I just hope the Minister's advisers have some answers.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a complicated case. It is always difficult when a highly personal matter such as this is dealt with as it involves medical assessments and elements quite apart from the question of the way in which the artificial limbs scheme might be responding as a professional service to the requests of a particular person who, I think all senators who have been involved in this matter would agree, has received many, many hours of attention over many years in order to try to fit him with a limb which would be satisfactory to his requirements, which are expressed by him in conversations with all of us as being at the outer limits perhaps of technology and of the work which he wants to be able to undertake while wearing such a limb.

PARA.TAB: Whatever the history, which has been so complicated, the fact is that it is not simply a question of being referred, if you like, to the repatriation hospital in Hobart. As I understand it, the latest offer to Mr Fleming by way of a letter to him on 26 August was to send Dr Fahrer, who is said to be a world renowned specialist in this field. It has been put to Mr Fleming that he should attend in Hobart for a day with Dr Fahrer and Dr Heddle and that there be a joint medical assessment made. They believe that Mr Fleming ought to be examined again before a decision can be taken on his future treatment.

I certainly have put to Mr Fleming that, whatever his misgivings or concerns or fears or scepticism about the process, surely after all these years and with all the difficulties, submitting himself for a day to this particular examination could only aid and assist his case and would not be a great frustration or hindrance or impediment to his making further progress. But until that particular consultation is undertaken, then I think it is fair that the artificial limbs scheme be able to say quite properly that it has done as much as it is able to do to this point.

I believe that the best advice to Mr Fleming, which certainly I offered in my office when he came to see me, was that he should undertake this day's reassessment even if it might be, from his point of view, pointless, and take it from there. It can only prove a foundation for something better and surely cannot be a frustration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Having observed Mr Fleming, I guess one would have to sympathise with him. As the Minister is a person who has suffered himself, not with a prosthesis but with a hip injury, and he knows the pain involved, surely he can understand the frustration of a person who has had a limb that has fitted him and been very good and now, for reasons that the Minister has stated and other reasons that I have documented evidence of here, it seems he cannot get the attention he requires.

PARA.TAB: I asked a question during Estimates hearings—that is how I got involved—about whether we in Australia were up to world standard with our supply of artificial limbs. The answer I got was: `We are confident that the standard is high'. I would have to query that as a result of the huge amount of documentation I have been given since and changes that have been made in the world scene. I have seen prostheses advertised in the USA which enable amputees to play basketball and racketball; Edward Kennedy's son can walk around on limbs that seem to be much more effective than the ones available in Australia; even a high wire artist has an artificial limb and can walk a high wire with an artificial limb.

I do not believe that sort of technology is available in Australia. Even if it were, the major problem with Mr Fleming, it seems, is that he cannot get a decent fit for his socket. The latest socketry CAT-CAM is not available in Australia. When are we going to catch up? What are we trying to do to acquaint ourselves with this latest technology? I know for a fact that this American company, which is so up-to-date with this technology, has offered to make Mr Fleming—I have a fax here which I can provide to the Department—a $US20,000 limb for the price of a normal limb in Australia. He is, as honourable senators can imagine, rather frustrated—or perhaps he may even be rather excited that the offer has been made.

Getting back to the questions I asked, do we really have world-class prosthesis available in Australia? Are there a lot of people out there disabled at the moment who believe they have good limbs and do not realise that there is far better technology available? I would like to, if I may, table this other letter that I have from Mr Thomas Guth, who I am sure the Minister's advisers would be aware of. He is one of the top prosthetists in the world and has, as I said, made this offer to Mr Fleming for an up-to-date, above-the-knee prosthesis that is world-class for the price of one that is available here in Australia. I guess that might be creating a precedent, but I would like to at least put that on the record. It may be something that the Department should consider.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the question of technology, whilst, as I understand it, the artificial limb scheme has a very high reputation indeed—and deservedly so—there may be areas which are not at the absolute forefront of world technology. I understand that the computer-aided design regime—Senator Calvert used the acronym CAT-CAM—is available at the centre in Melbourne and is used in appropriate cases. I believe that a high degree of technology and technical skills are available within the Australian system.

PARA.TAB: It may well be, of course, that a breakthrough and an expertise has been achieved by a team elsewhere. Senator Calvert says this particular specialist in the United States might have something better to offer. I certainly think his offer is well worth having a look at. I appreciate the availability of the letter. I think we will just take it from there. We will put it on the record and I will ask officers to have a look at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have the letter incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The letter read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: November 13, 1992
Senator Paul Calvert
3 Brook Street
Hobart, Tasmania
AUSTRALIA
RE: Mr David Fleming
Dear Senator Calvert:
We have been contacted by Mr David Fleming and are aware of his difficulty in obtaining an above-the-knee prosthesis that will allow him to return to his normal lifestyle.

The leg that Mr Fleming requires normally costs between $15,000 and $20,000 (United States dollars). Due to Mr Fleming's circumstances, however, we are extending an offer to make him the leg for the price the Australian government normally pays for an above-the-knee prosthesis.
Please discuss this offer with your fellow Senators. If your government will pay RGP the normal price it pays for this leg, we are prepared to provide it to Mr Fleming in the very near future.
Thank you for your consideration. If I can provide you with additional information, please call me at (619) 545-1932.
Sincerely,
Thomas Guth, C.P.
Chief Prosthetist

TALK.START.PARA: —Finally, on this matter I just say again that Mr Fleming has been made the offer to go back to the CDU. Does the Minister think it is fair that he should have to sign a paper virtually committing himself to whatever the hospital may like to do? It is almost like my going for a fitting for a set of false teeth and having to sign a paper at the dentist before I say that I will accept what I am given. I believe that any patient, even one as difficult, sometimes, as Mr Fleming, should have the right of recourse. If he does not get a prosthesis or does not receive satisfaction from the CDU, I believe he should have some recourse and should not have to sign a paper before the hospital will see him.

—This has been an extremely long and drawn out matter and I think tension has built up on all sides. All that is being said to Mr Fleming is that, first of all, as I say, the assessment that has been offered in Hobart by Dr Fahrer and Dr Heddle ought to be undertaken with whatever misgivings or scepticism on the part of Mr Fleming. If further treatment is indicated at the CDU in Melbourne then, as I understand it, all that is being requested of him is that he undertakes to abide by the professional advice that is offered to him and the professional regime of a mixture of physiotherapy and the way in which the prosthesis has to work properly without interference to the technical operation of that particular artificial limb. In other words, if he is provided with this particular service, he should agree to go along with the professional advisers who are amongst the best, certainly the best in Australia.

—I think that is where the problem will arise, because I do not believe that Mr Fleming accepts that we have the best professionals. We may have some top professionals in Australia, but I do not believe that he accepts that we have, at this point in time any way, world-class professionals. I will be following this matter through with the Department. I can understand the problems of the Department and the Minister with the frustration of this particular patient, but in the interests of this person and others throughout Australia, who have disabilities, I believe it is important that this offer that is made to him for a subsidised limb from the United States which is of the latest technology is something that certainly should be looked at.
—I have undertaken to do that.
—Thank you. I will certainly be following up with the Department and the Minister's office to ensure that Mr Fleming and any other people with disabilities get the best possible service.

—In view of the gag which the Government and the Democrats have placed on this debate, I only wish to add my voice to that of my colleague Senator Calvert. We have both been very interested in and concerned about this issue. Rather than take the time of the Committee, I just associate myself with Senator Calvert's questioning. I also point out that it seems not unreasonable for the Department to assist a Tasmanian to go to the mainland to see a private prosthetist, which is available to mainlanders who have the choice between private and the RALACs. That is not available easily to Tasmanians. I think at the very least that should be looked at by the Department. I now wish to turn to program 1 and the data-matching program, which is a reservation of mine.
—It certainly was, but we have gone past it. But with my normal flexibility, we will go back to it.

—Thank you very much. I have just two or three questions about that. I explicitly asked how much the Department saved from the data-matching program in 1991-92, and that question was taken on notice by the Department at the Estimates. The answer given refers to particular cases, but it provides no overall figure. I first of all ask: why was no overall figure provided?
—I understand that no savings were made in 1990-91 because of the delay in bringing the scheme into effect.

—Could we turn now to 1.2, which is the question of compensation. In answer to a question taken on notice, it was stated that the Department is currently reviewing the major pensions and allowances payable under the compensation subprogram to assess whether or not these benefits are appropriate in meeting the needs and concerns of veterans in the 1990s and beyond. Could the Minister tell me just what issues have so far been addressed and what are likely to be addressed?

—I think most of this will become apparent to the Parliament and the Senate when the audit report is tabled next week, we expect, but some would have to do with age related disability, smoking matters—tobacco products, I presume—and rehabilitation for younger veterans. The officer is scouring his mind. They are some indications, but there will be a full report on this tabled apparently next week.
—I am sorry, did the Minister say that the Auditor-General's report would be tabled next week or that the review would be tabled?
—The Auditor-General's report.
—Of course, I was asking about the departmental review.

—The officer says that they cover the same issues, and that was the point he was trying to make. The review itself, I am advised, has not led to the production of a discrete report; it is an ongoing process. But the review does cover those sorts of matters I have indicated.

—I thank the Minister, but the answer was quite specific: the Department is currently reviewing the major pensions and allowances payable; it does sound like a major review in progress. Am I to understand perhaps that the Department is just relying on the Auditor-General to provide its review for it?

—I think these things are sometimes complementary and provoking. I think quite often these processes can be seen as in tandem, as it were, and I think that that is probably what has occurred in this case.
—I thank the Minister. Could the Minister tell me when the departmental review was initiated?

—Apparently it is just part of an ongoing administrative practice of consideration and deliberation on the operation of these pensions and benefits, but apparently it has no particular elevated status.

—So we were given the impression that it had an elevated status, but in fact it is just simply a normal departmental activity that constantly, like good managers, reviews everything they do. Is that what I am to understand?
—I understand that we were somewhat misled.
—I was wondering whether the Department's review had anything to do with its knowledge that the compensation subprogram was to be audited.

—I am sure that it would keep the officers of the Department on their toes and I believe, as I say, there is always an interplay between the Department and the Auditor-General. I think drafts are normally provided by the Auditor-General and departments normally try to respond and obviously try to get the most favourable outcome as is possible by either setting the Auditor-General's mind at ease in a particular matter about which he has misgivings or by undertaking to remedy the matter as quickly as possible.

—Perhaps the Minister could tell me: when did the Auditor-General's review audit start and how did it start? Did it start at the initiative of the Auditor-General, at the request of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, or at the request of the President of the Repatriation Commission-cum-Secretary to the Department? Who initiated that audit?

—The officers believe that the Auditor-General's Office initiated it. It would have been well over two years ago, so it has been a long running program of the Auditor-General apparently. But I will confirm what formal initiating documents might be able to be found.

—I thank the Minister for that. I would be very interested to know whether it was at the Auditor-General's own initiative or whether he cheerfully acceded to a request in-house, one might say, in some form or another. Madam Temporary Chairman, could I turn now to program 3 and war graves?

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—Is there nothing on subprogram 2.2 or subprogram 2.4? I think that brings us to program 3. Does anyone have anything to say on subprogram 3.2?

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Estimates hearing, I wrote to the Minister seeking information on how much money was to be spent on attending to the cemetery in Kamunting Road, how it was to be spent and when it was to be spent. The answer that I received outlines the correction to Mr Taggart's evidence that there will be no new expenditure but that money will be found from the existing allocation. It does not really provide any real answers to my substantive questions: when will work begin; what work will be done; and how much will be spent?

—This particular project depends very much on cooperation with the British defence ministry. The steps being taken to ensure the cooperation and working, as I say, in harmony with that particular ministry are under way. The alternatives in the program include the removal of the graves to Taiping War Cemetery, all maintenance in situ by the War Graves Commission, or Australia taking the initiative and acting alone in the restoration and rehabilitation of the cemetery. These are three alternatives which are being considered, but the first one is the preferred option and is being pursued with the British defence ministry at the moment. At the moment the cost is unable to be quantified.

—I thank the Minister. If the first option—that is, the removal of the graves to the war cemetery—is undertaken, I presume that will mean that the dependants' graves will be left in the civilian cemetery. Will any steps be taken to maintain those?
—The proposal is that the Service persons' graves and those of their dependants be moved.

—That is very good. I hope that that option does actually get put into place. I thank the Minister for the answers. As he will realise, I will be keeping a close watching brief on that issue, as will many ex-servicemen. Madam Temporary Chairman, I wish to move to program 5, if none of my colleagues has any objection.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—If that is all on program 3, is there anything on program 4? There being nothing on program 4, we will move to program 5.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the questioning about the war memorial, when I was asking about the B25, I was told that tenders had not closed. I understand that that in fact is not correct, that they had closed. If I can now ask: what was the outcome of that?
—Senator Newman is correct to say that tenders have closed, but I am advised that the process of assessing those tenders has not been completed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I read the Hansard of the Estimates Committee E hearing on this issue of the disposal of the Mitchell bomber and was astonished at the incorrect information that was given to the Committee by the witness Dr McKernan. He said in evidence:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . as the B25 Mitchell bomber was a lightly used aircraft by the RAAF in the Second World War, the decision was taken by Council, and then referred on to the Minister . . .
Over the page he said:
No, not significantly. The type we have was used very infrequently by Australians—by the RAAF . . .

That is not true. The RAAF operated two Mitchell squadrons. I think No. 22 was one of the RAAF squadrons. Certainly No. 18 squadron was a RAAF squadron which was manned mainly by Dutch personnel from what was then the Dutch East Indies. The Mitchell was an aircraft that had a significant role in the order of battle. When we talk about a war memorial, we do not necessarily talk about items of equipment of historical significance which were necessarily used by one of the arms of the Australian defence forces—the Army, the Navy or the Air Force. We do talk about equipment which was of relevance to the combined arms. It would be difficult to think of an aircraft in the Pacific campaign which was more important to the Australian Army—the AIF and the AMF—in the campaigns in New Guinea, than the Mitchell in the bombing role.

PARA.TAB: The three dominant aircraft would have to have been the P40, the fighter, operated principally by the RAAF; the Lightning, operated by the USAF; and the Mitchell, in the strike or bombing role—it was the dominant aircraft and is of great historical significance. It was also highly significant to the divisions that were in the North African campaign in the earlier part of the war, before those divisions were brought back to Australia. It was also important in New Guinea. To say that the B25 was not a significant aircraft in Australia's history in the Second World War is to make a statement of great ignorance. I do not know anything about Dr McKernan—I have never met him—but the statement that he made that it was an insignificant aircraft with respect to Australia's military history is grossly incorrect.

The point that Senator Newman was clearly making before the Committee was that we cannot sell items of great significance. Senator Newman, quite correctly, drew attention to the obvious deficiencies in the acquisitions policy of the Australian War Memorial. It is quite proper where there are a number of items in a collection to trade or sell them to add to other items for which there is a priority need. In this case, that aeroplane has great significance to Australia's effort in the Pacific. There is no way on earth that any responsible body could move to sell it, particularly when it was acquired at such low cost and low effort by the museum initially.

A great deal of volunteer effort went into preparing that aeroplane for flight in the United States—making it airworthy, bringing it out here and then handing it over in airworthy condition to the museum. While I do not believe there is anything in writing in the way of a contractual obligation, there certainly was a clear understanding that that aircraft would never be sold. I am appalled at the action of the museum in putting this aircraft up for tender. I do not believe there is much in the War Memorial's collection that should ever go out for tender. I could agree with items being swapped for things of a higher priority, but I believe the museum, and the Council—if it is blamed, as Dr McKernan seems to do in his evidence—have behaved in a grossly irresponsible way.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator MacGibbon has raised some interesting points from his virtually encyclopaedic knowledge of matters aerial. I will ensure that they are made available for consideration by the relevant authorities at the War Memorial.
—Could I have a brief outline of the present contractual arrangements for the Official Historian?

—Dr Peter Edwards was appointed as Official Historian under section 82(4) of the Public Service Act 1922 for an initial period of seven years by the then Fraser Government on 21 February 1983, with the agreement of the then Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Bill Hayden. Dr Edwards's initial appointment was to the then level of second division officer level 2, which now equates to the upper SES band 1 level. The original conditions of Dr Edwards's appointment specified a midterm review of his level. This review was undertaken in 1987. Dr Edwards was consequently reclassified, with effect from 1 November 1987, to SES level 3, which presently equates to a lower SES band 2 position. Dr Edwards was reappointed to the position of Official Historian for five years from 20 February 1990. Dr Edwards's reappointment was endorsed at the time, on advice from the then Leader of the Opposition, the Hon. Andrew Peacock. It is a fixed term appointment, as I understand it.
—Is the work on the official history to be completed by 1995, which is five years from the date of appointment?
—I think that is the current plan of expectation.
—Has there been any suggestion, formally or informally, that the Official Historian should be appointed to a permanent position, with work to continue beyond the completion of the official history?
—I am advised that the answer is no.
—Can I be once again assured that there has been no suggestion, either from the Official Historian or from within the Memorial, that the Official Historian will be made a permanent APS position?
—I understand that the arrangement is that the Official Historian be on this fixed term appointment. I understand that nothing further than that is contemplated at the moment.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—There being no further questions on program 5, we will move on to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. Are there any matters on program 2?

—Senator Walters, it might be of some assistance to the Minister and to me if you could indicate which subprogram you are addressing.

—Medicare benefits, subprogram 2.1. It is about excessive servicing. The Minister would recognise that a report about overservicing and excessive servicing would come under the Medicare benefits subprogram. I made a reservation under program 2, Health care access, subprogram 2.1, Medicare benefits.
—Madam Temporary Chair, I raise a point of order. Senator Patterson has also made a reservation under Medicare benefits, subprogram 2.1.
—We both have. It is in the report. I fail to see the problem.

—I raise a point of order—although it is not really a point of order; it is a point of indulgence. If I may crave your indulgence, Madam Chair. We have gone past program 1 in a split second. I thought there was a reservation from Senator Walters and, therefore, naturally I did not need to make a reservation. I did want to ask some questions of the Minister in respect of that matter.

PARA.TAB: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—Are you happy with that Senator Walters?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am asking about the recommendations that were made by the legal working group which were reported in today's Australian concerning a statement made by the intergovernmental committee on AIDS entitled National Blueprint for HIV Law Reform. The headline in the Australian this morning is `AIDS taskforce targets schools' and states:

SPEECH.PARA: The States should decriminalise prostitution and make condoms more readily available, including in schools. . .
I ask the Minister: what is the Government's policy in respect of this question of making condoms available in schools? What is the view of the Federal Government in respect of that matter?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had the opportunity to look at this report of the working group. It has gone no further than being put down by the working group for public discussion, and no doubt for response by the governments concerned—both Federal and State.

PARA.TAB: The question of the availability of condoms in schools is, as I know from controversy in Tasmania, a matter for State education departments or relevant boards of management of private or independent schools. It is certainly not a question where the Federal Government has any policy in relation to the matter. That is not the policy of the Federal Government. It is a matter which has been put forward by the working group for consideration and has no higher status than that.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, according to the press release, one can assume that this policy has been endorsed by the Federal Government. The press release says, contrary to what the Minister is saying, that the recommendations have been endorsed in principle by the HMAC. That is clearly the statement.

PARA.TAB: The legal working party had previously come forward with working documents which were distributed and made available. This is the actual recommendation that has been made as a result of further consideration of those documents.

Am I to understand that the Commonwealth Government does not endorse the recommendations that have been made, including the one that is reported to have been made by the working party? Perhaps the Minister might table the report. I have asked for a report and I have not received one as yet. I understand that the Department, or whoever is responsible, is getting one to me urgently; but I have not received one. Yet we read it in the press and apparently it has gone to the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council.

I am asking two things. Firstly, does the Federal Government endorse the availability of condoms in schools and, secondly, what is meant by yesterday's press release which said that the recommendations of the working party have been endorsed in principle by the Australian Health Ministers Advisory Council? Does that mean that the Tasmanian health Minister has endorsed that policy?

TALK.START.PARA: —I say very adamantly that the Commonwealth Government has not considered or decided upon any policy to endorse the availability of condoms in the schools of Australia. What we have is a recommendation of a working group. As I understand it, the council and its endorsement that the honourable senator is referring to is a council of senior officials. I think it is perhaps made up of the secretaries of the departments or something like that. It is a group of very senior officials drawn from all jurisdictions and governments throughout Australia.

PARA.TAB: It does not represent the views of governments or of the health Ministers concerned. We are a long way short of any governments—and I would include the Tasmanian Government in this—coming to a formal position in response to any of the recommendations that have been made. It is not the policy of the Federal Government to endorse the availability of condoms in Australian schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are there any further matters in relation to program 1? I think we were on program 2 before. Is there anything further in relation to 2.1?

—I have not started. I gave way to Senator Harradine because he had only just come in and we went back to program 1. As I said, we have had a problem on the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. We put down a report on the excessive servicing of diagnostic imaging. We received a response from the Government to our report on 5 November. The Committee then decided that it was so inaccurate, so blatantly wrong and, we believed, deliberately misleading that we would write a response to the Government's response to us.

PARA.TAB: The Committee decided to write a letter to the Minister inviting him to give us the reason why the report was so badly inaccurate. However, when contacted, the Department told us that the Minister was going away and that it would not have time within the period to write any sort of response to us and it was left at that. At a much later time we were informed that the officer—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters, I am finding it difficult to—
—We have been through this and the Temporary Chairman understood the situation. I made a reservation under 2.1, Medicare benefits, and excessive servicing of radiology comes under Medicare benefits.

—I was out of the chamber for a short period. When I came back I was told that we had been to program 2 and Senator Harradine wanted to go back to program 1, and we did so. I called program 2 again and Senator Walters suggested to me that we should start again at program 1—if we go according to the running sheet, which is what we have been doing. It seems to me that the honourable senator is talking about program 2.1.
—That is right; that is what we are on. We have passed program 1 altogether.
—Let me get it straight. Is there any further matter in relation to program 1? There being none, program 1 is finished.
—Do you want me to start all over again?
—No.
—I cannot see how I can get the flow of what I am saying when I keep getting interrupted.

—Senator Walters, it is the duty of the Chair to get these Estimates through, and we are going according to the running sheet. At the moment I cannot see how your particular comments relate to the estimates before us. By the estimates before us, I mean the appropriations that we are charged to examine. Please proceed and I will see whether I can find a thread there.

—Mr Chairman, if I could explain, Medicare benefits is where I made the reservation. Excessive servicing of diagnostic imaging cannot help but come under Medicare benefits. It is not possible for excessive servicing of radiology to come under anything else but Medicare benefits. It is in that connection that I am attempting to speak on this matter. The Committee received the report, endorsed by the Minister, and the Committee was so concerned at its inaccuracies and, we believed, an attempt to mislead that the Committee chose to ask the Minister for an explanation. We asked the Secretary to write a letter to him. However, when the Secretary rang the Department we were told by the Department that the Minister was going away and that there was no opportunity to answer such a letter, if we wrote it, in the required time.

PARA.TAB: The Committee had decided at that meeting that we would put forward a report expressing our concerns about the Government response. Later, the Committee was informed by the Minister that we would get a briefing. The briefing had nothing to do with our concerns, as I understood it, and so we—the members of the coalition—and the Democrats, decided that the report accompanied by our concerns should go out. After all, it has been held from 5 November and it still has not been tabled. It is now 17 November. There was a feeling amongst us that the Government members of our Committee were deliberately trying to suppress the report before giving the Minister an opportunity of correcting, perhaps—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I am very sorry, but this seems to be a dispute about a standing committee and what documents might be published by it. I am not au fait with it, but really it has nothing to do with the consideration of the report of Estimates Committee E within the Committee of the Whole. It is a matter of concern, apparently, and, perhaps, dispute within the Standing Committee—but not the Estimates Committee. I really feel that this is a very artificial way to bring this dispute to the Committee of the Whole, considering the Estimates. I do not believe that it is properly before us.

—Mr Chairman, it is related, because the report concerns the Medicare benefits refunds for radiological services. Under the Government's own estimates, it affects $20m of the Budget that is to be refunded from radiological services. So there is a very direct connection. If the Minister does not understand the connection, that is his problem, with respect, Mr Chairman.

—I think the Minister was speaking about something else. The situation is that we have in front of us at the moment program 2, Health Care Access. We are looking at subprogram 2.1, Medicare Benefits. Any matter in relation to Medicare benefits is relevant to the Committee because there is a reservation which actually lists Medicare benefits. What we should be doing, if we want to raise this matter, is raising the matter of Medicare benefits itself—not necessarily what happened in the Committee and whether there was a main report or a supplementary report. Matters relating to Medicare benefits are open for discussion and we should keep it at that—but not necessarily all the intricacies of what went on in the Committee.

—Mr Chairman, could I short-circuit this system, then, and move that the documents quoted by Senator Walters be tabled under standing order 168, that is, the Government's report on excessive servicing and comments on the report by, effectively, Senator Walters, Senator Herron, Senator Lees and myself? They do, incidentally, relate to over-servicing in Medicare benefits. That is why I am seeking to have the documents tabled now.

—I will come back to your suggestion in a moment. It seems to me that there is no problem at all in raising the matter of over-servicing or Medicare benefits because it is actually in the reservation. I am concerned about extraneous matter being debated here that has something to do with internal conflict within a committee.
—Just in the essence of time, that is all: I am bit concerned that we are now at 11.17 a.m. and I am just trying to facilitate the process expeditiously.
—I cannot quite see how the tabling of these documents would assist.

—I am not clear as to what we are speaking about. Are we talking about a document received by a standing committee of the Senate, to which members of the Committee have compiled a response? Has the Committee passed a resolution to publish the document?
—Yes.
—If a resolution has been passed, it must be a public document.
—Minister, you will not let me finish.

—I am not going to just allow the Estimates committee procedure to be used for the publication and tabling of a document when it is the responsibility of the Standing Committee to pass the various resolutions and to achieve that end—not the Estimates Committee or the Committee of the Whole.

—As I said to the Minister, a resolution had been put and passed that the report be tabled. That has not occurred. As a result, we have a problem. But it comes under this program and, indeed, under Medicare benefits because it is totally associated with that. The Chairman and other members of the Committee were told that it would be brought up here. We are not doing it in any surreptitious way. We had advised the Committee members that this would be what we were doing.

—I am still extremely unhappy with this. This must be terribly boring to the outside world, but I just do not think that a Committee of the Whole, reflecting and deliberating on the reports of Estimates committees, should be used as a forum within which reports of standing committees and what is alleged to be a Government response to, perhaps, a draft report of the Committee should be tabled.
—It is not alleged.
—A report of the Government by way of response to a standing committee report ought to be put down in the normal way when the report itself is published and not in the Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the documents quoted by Senator Walters be tabled.

SPEECH.PARA: I move that motion under standing order 168.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have grave misgivings; I think this is an abuse of the process of the Committee of the Whole. But, given the exigencies of the need to try to facilitate debate within stringent time limits, I am not prepared to divide on this matter.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Still on Medicare benefits, and I hope that I am still in the right area on this—
—You certainly are.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. What does the Minister know about a company called Med-Network Pty Ltd, which under the Health Insurance Commission will establish an electronic data information system involving the direct debit of Medicare from the doctor straight into the Health Insurance Commission? Who are the principals of Med-Network Pty Ltd? What is the company's background?

—I do not have officials here who have that sort of detail as to principals of companies and so on. I will certainly undertake to provide the information. It is a very good question for Estimates committees or to be placed on notice but difficult to take on in the Committee of the Whole.
—I thank the Minister for his answer. Could I then ask the Minister when I will be likely to get that answer.
—I think it will be available next time we meet.

—I am at a little bit of a loss to know what the delay is. Is it that there is no information on Med-Network and what it actually does? Could I please have that information on Med-Network, what it does and how the system is planned to operate? Perhaps the other questions that I have asked could be responded to either later today or when we return.

—The general idea of Med-Network is to provide computing services to primary medical practitioners to aid communication between those practitioners, but that is very general information. We can provide answers to those questions, particularly on the structure of the organisation, certainly by the time the Senate resumes on Tuesday.

—That will also involve a bit more information about Med-Network itself, what it will actually do and how it will do it. At the risk of being difficult, could I ask how we will bring that information back into the Committee when Appropriations have been passed and the Committee has disappeared?
—I suppose I can find some mechanism to table what will astound Senator Knowles as a most comprehensive answer.

—Last night in the debate on Estimates Committee D on Social Security, I was subjected to a totally inappropriate personal attack by Minister Bolkus. I think that was precipitated by his reluctance and the inappropriate way in which he did not answer my questions as compared with the way in which we dealt with the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services in the Estimates procedure. If the records were looked at, they would reveal that on previous occasions it has taken something like 20 or more hours in the committee stage of Estimates. In fact, during the last Estimates we put a large number of questions on notice. I know that placed an undue strain on the departmental officers, but it reduced the time we spent in Estimates by almost half.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on the public record my appreciation to the Minister responsible, Senator Tate, and also to the officers who responded with answers to those questions. In order to facilitate the time in the chamber here today, in discussions with me on a number of issues on which I put reservations, Senator Tate agreed to answer those questions. The answers were dealt with by one of his staff members, who then conveyed the information to the Department which answered those questions. I presume that those answers will go on the record as an official record of the Committee of the Whole because they came to me via the Secretary of that committee.

That seems to be a fairly efficient way of dealing with the questions rather than the difficulties we faced last night and the length of time it took us to get through those Estimates because the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, made the situation difficult and was not at all helpful. But that is by the by and is history.
There were a couple of issues raised when the Department did give me answers. Maybe it was the way in which I asked the question, but I want to go over that again. A young Australian trained doctor—

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I just interrupt for a moment.
—I am on Medicare benefits.
—That is fine, as long as we keep going according to the running sheet.

—A young medical doctor has written to me indicating that he was concerned about people who travel to Australia from countries where Australia has a Medicare agreement to treat patients from those countries when they visit our country—for example, an agreement between Britain and Australia. He asked whether a person travelling to Australia with travel insurance ought not be treated in Australia as if that person had personal health insurance: for example, when Australians who currently have private health insurance go to a doctor or a hospital and are asked whether they have private health insurance. A similar situation arises with a tourist coming from overseas who has travel insurance which includes medical insurance. Could the Department please explain why these people are not treated as private patients, just as Australians are in similar circumstances.

—The short answer is that these are a series of reciprocal arrangements which, indeed, provide great benefits for Australians who travel to the countries concerned, whether one is talking of the United Kingdom, Italy, Malta, Sweden, the Netherlands or New Zealand. In other words, if one visits those countries and has an episode of ill health, an accident or some trauma, then one is entitled, as an Australian in those countries, to have access to the host country's public health care system. In so far as that is reciprocated, that is exactly what it is: a recognition that, whilst costs would be borne by the Australian community in providing that benefit—that access to the public health system to visitors from those countries—Australians benefit when they are in a similar situation of some jeopardy in those countries. The thought is that the balance is in favour of helping to ensure that Australians are not faced with catastrophic medical expenses when they visit those countries and fall ill or have an accident.

PARA.TAB: As for tourists from countries other than those that visit Australia, they do not have access to Medicare and would be required to meet the cost of any medical treatment or hospitalisation either out of their own funds or through some travel insurance arrangement that they have made.

TALK.START.PARA: —So the Minister is saying that a person travelling here with travel insurance cover is treated differently from an Australian in Australia who has private health insurance.
—I think the answer to that question is no. An Australian would have access to the public health system and Medicare services also.
—If there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 2.1, and none in relation to subprogram 2.2, we will move to subprogram 2.3.

—I understand from the media that there is to be an advertising campaign to explain the benefits of Medicare. After eight years I would have thought that was unnecessary. I ask the Minister how much is being expended and what is the purpose of that expenditure?

—This particular campaign follows the 2 1/2 years of review through the national health strategy, which has indicated that whilst there is a high level of public support in the community for Medicare, there is also some lack of understanding relating to patient entitlements under Medicare. We believe it is our responsibility to ensure that all Australians are informed of their rights and entitlements to health care.

PARA.TAB: The campaign will focus on providing factual information on Medicare entitlements, such as how to access free public hospital treatment under Medicare; free treatment, and whether costs or charges apply; explaining the difference between emergency and elective surgery in public hospital admission procedures; and reform measures under Medicare and what they will mean for public hospital service provision. We believe the information will enable people to make better decisions about their treatment and care.

I understand that $3 1/2m has been allocated for a media and public relations campaign. Six advertising agencies and four public relation firms have been briefed on the exercise. I am not quite sure what stage that has reached; it has not reached finality yet. An additional amount of $1.5m is also available for the Medicare hospitals campaign to cover the costs of production of the public patients hospital charter, information kits and other material for the general public and the health industry.
A second publicity and information campaign on the general practice budget reform package, with a budget of $4m, is currently in train, but Senator Herron is aware of that.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the Medicare system having been in place for eight years, how can the Minister justify that? Where has the Government failed in explaining the Medicare system to the general public? Why is it now asking taxpayers to pay, at the beginning anyway, $3 1/2m? Why has the Government failed to explain the system to the public?

—I believe that all organisations which are providing services to the Australian community, whether they are private enterprises, voluntary organisations or government agencies, have an obligation from time to time to ensure that those who are the intended beneficiaries of programs that are offered well understand the various elements of those particular programs. Whilst it is true that there may be a vague appreciation of the role of Medicare in the Australian community, there is, no doubt, use—and it is perfectly proper—in a more detailed understanding of some of the elements being sought to be engendered in the Australian population which, after all, is the beneficiary of this longstanding and very successful program of health care.
—The Minister said that $3 1/2m has been allocated. What is the total all-up cost of the program? Does it reach $9m, as has been alleged, of taxpayers' money?
—I have quoted scrupulously the brief that I had provided to me.

—No, the $4m was for the general practice budget reform package. That has nothing to do with this particular matter. I have read to the Senate what I have available to me in the brief. I do not believe that that adds up to $9m—well it does not.
—Is the $3 1/2m solely for a public relations and advertising program?
—Yes, it is for a media and public relations exercise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I see also under the same program that Mr Keith Wilson, the Minister for Health in Western Australia, resigned on Friday. The West Australian states:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Wilson quit as Health Minister after criticising Canberra for failing to recognise private health insurance as an important source of funding for public hospitals.

PARA.TAB: Mr Wilson said Federal Health Minister Brian Howe's approach was unintelligent and called on Prime Minister Paul Keating to intervene.

SPEECH.PARA: There we have a Labor State health Minister resigning on the general principles of Medicare and its failure to allow private insurance to accommodate the excess number of people that the Medicare system cannot cope with. The Australian Hospitals Association—the public hospitals association—combined with the Private Hospitals Association, and they have said the same thing. The Australian Medical Association has said the same thing. The consumers representatives have said the same thing.

PARA.TAB: Is the Government deaf? Does the Minister not understand what is occurring out in the community? He is running a public relations campaign costing $3 1/2m. The country is in recession. We have one million unemployed and another one million underemployed and the Government is going to spend $3 1/2m to try to sell a program that is not accepted by any reputable body of consumers, patients, the medical profession and the nurses union in the whole country. It is trying to put a big $3 1/2m worth of bandaid on a system that has failed.

When will the Government face reality and start allowing private insurance to those people who wish to be treated privately, a system that is being supported by the Public Hospitals Association? The people who actually treat patients in public hospitals are advocating a system where there should be freedom of choice. Members of the public should be given the right to insure if they wish to do so. Already it is known that 10 to 12 per cent of them are carrying their own insurance and are paying for private treatment. They cannot insure themselves because this Government will not allow them to insure. Would it not be better, instead of throwing $3 1/2m of taxpayers' money away, to allow those taxpayers the freedom of choice to insure themselves as they wish to do so?

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is unfortunate that in the short time available to us, rather than the Opposition seeking information, we appear to be getting propaganda statements from it in favour of its own particular idea of the way in which private health insurance should be elevated as an element of the Medicare principles.
—You are spending $3 1/2m on propaganda.
—Mr Chairman, would you allow me some space in order to contribute to this debate.
—If you can't take the heat, get out of the kitchen.
—Order! The Minister has the floor.

—The Opposition wishes us to adopt its policy so far as private health insurance is concerned. We have no intention of doing that. The Opposition is proposing to add compulsory private health insurance to the tax contributions and the Medicare levy contributions of Australians to our health care system. Under the Fightback package, every individual and every household in Australia would have to add to the tax and Medicare levy contributions they make to our health care system the payment of a premium to a private health insurance agency of some sort or another. That is an impost on individuals and households which we in the Labor Party do not believe ought to be required as a compulsory and mandatory way in which to fund the health system.

PARA.TAB: The Opposition says, `We don't really believe in free choice in this area. We believe that everybody must carry private health insurance and pay the premiums. If they are on extremely low incomes, we will provide some sort of subsidy'. Where are they going to get the money to pay for this subsidy, which will run into many hundreds of millions of dollars—I think some estimates have been $1.3 billion—worth of subsidies for these private health insurance premiums? The answer is very clear: it will come from the public hospital system. The Opposition is, for example, intending to strip 5 per cent off the funds available to all the States. The States, of course, need those funds in order to fund, amongst other things, their hospital systems, their education and roads and many other services they provide. The Opposition is saying that rather than use taxpayers' dollars to help fund the public hospital system and to provide better services within the hospital system it will use taxpayers' funds to subsidise private health insurance for those at the very low end of the income scale.

It is no wonder that this Government refuses to elevate that sort of private health insurance proposal to the status of a Medicare principle, which is apparently what the Opposition and some organisations wish to do. We will not do it. We believe that funds that are available from the taxpayers to support the health system should go into our public hospital system to enable a reduction in waiting lists and the better provision of medical and hospital services rather than in the provision of subsidies to private health insurance premiums. We do not believe that that is the way that Australian taxpayers' funds should be used.

TALK.START.PARA: —You do not believe in freedom of choice.

—The interjection was that we do not believe in the freedom of choice. In fact, what the Opposition is doing is proposing a compulsory, mandatory requirement on every Australian to take out private health insurance. It is also saying that GPs will not be able to operate in complete freedom either, because they will not be allowed to bulk bill, for example.
—Mr Chairman, I have a point of order. The Minister must tell the truth.
—I am telling the truth. Senator Walters will not allow me to finish the sentence.
—Senator Walters, you and I have been here since 1975. By 1976 both you and I knew that that was not a point of order, and it is still not a point of order.
—I was saying that I do not believe that the ideology of freedom of choice has been applied by the Opposition in its Fightback policy.
—Five minutes of our guillotined time to put across your propaganda!

—I am responding to propaganda. I say it is unfair because I have been trying to answer questions very fairly and succinctly during the morning. If Senator Herron wants to introduce propaganda, I will respond. That is what I have done.

—I would like to come back to the point that Senator Herron was making about the publicity campaign. I cannot let some of Senator Tate's comments go. If he is talking about compulsion, what is Medicare other than compulsion? That is absolute compulsion. To say that our policy is doing away with bulk billing is absolutely and utterly wrong; and, as Senator Walters said, that is absolutely false. I will put those two corrections on the record.

PARA.TAB: The Government has run a publicity campaign telling people how to die at the end of the Medicare queue, which is what it is all about, inviting people to go to the public hospitals and how they can get more free service. It has not done a single solitary thing to stop health fraud, and here it is going on and spending more and more money. I ask the Minister: when will this program start; how long will it run; what mediums will it cover; will it be radio, television, newspapers, magazines or whatever; how many letters will be sent out to doctors and everyone else? If the Minister remembers, last time the Government did some exercise like this many doctors got four and five letters each at an enormous cost—

TALK.START.PARA: —Like I get from the drug companies.

—You would not be able to read them anyway, so I would not worry about sending them to you. But where is the money coming from; is the money allocated in this year's Budget, or is it going to be another appropriation; and when was the decision made to run with this program, a purely political exercise, at the taxpayers' expense, leading up to the next Federal election?

—This has deteriorated somewhat into a propaganda war for the last quarter of an hour or so of the Committee of the Whole. The money is coming from the running costs of the Department; there will be no additional estimates. In other words, it comes out of the appropriations which are before the Committee at the moment.
—Who is paying for it all?

—Of course, it will come out of the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the Government. In relation to the other comments made by Senator Knowles, fulminating about the compulsory nature of Medicare, it is interesting to note that the Opposition in its Fightback package intends to keep the compulsory Medicare levy. It intends not only to keep the compulsory Medicare levy, in addition to compulsory taxation, but it intends to add the compulsory purchase of a private health insurance policy. I believe that that is compulsion of the nth degree.

—The Minister has not answered one of those questions. When is this program starting; for how long will it run; on what mediums; and when was the decision made? Is he going to answer the questions or not? The people of Australia have a right to know these answers.
—It is their money you're spending.
