—As Senator Campbell has said, it is their money you are spending; not yours. It is not coming out of your pocket.

—The decision was taken in the Budget context. I have already indicated to honourable senators that the advertising and the public relations firms who have been briefed on the exercise are making their presentations. When those presentations are complete a decision will be made as to which way to go as to the agency and as to the various elements which those agencies, from my memory in like situations, provide as to the variation between radio, television and print media time and so on. As soon as that is available I will make sure that the Senate is provided with the detail.

—Are there any further matters in relation to subprogram 2.3? I will now move to program 3, subprogram 3.2. I would ask honourable senators who may be going to raise some matters to keep their eye on the running sheet because we cannot keep going backwards and forwards.
—I have one issue I want to raise and put on the public record in relation to subprogram 2.3. I stood to my feet just as you were announcing it, Mr Chairman.
—We have gone well past that.
—No, we have not, Mr Chairman. You said, `Are there any more on 2.3?' and I stood up.

PARA.TAB: I want to put on the public record that during the Estimates hearings I asked questions about an inquiry that was undertaken by the Department into the health insurance funds. I believe 57 of them received letters demanding within 14 days full details of payments made by them during the past year to various lobby groups and whether the funds were using such groups for political purposes. During the Estimates inquiry it was revealed, and it was reported in the Australian of 14 August, that a spokesman of the Department said,`There were concerns that some insurers were involved in the undesirable practice of using members' money for political campaigns'. This witch-hunt went on. During Estimates we discovered that it was one person. One person had gone to a departmental officer. Obviously the delegation of power was such that it did not require ministerial approval for this witch-hunt to be undertaken. One departmental officer investigated all these health funds, asking for details about all their expenditure to ensure that they had not spent any of their members' money for political purposes.

Who was that member? None other than George Gear; none other than Mr Gear. He set up this witch-hunt, he went to somebody in the Department, and he asked for this information. We all know Mr Gear's views about health and nationalising medicine. Mr Gear instigated a witch-hunt. I think it should be on the public record that one person can go to the Department and have an inquiry—I do not know whether it was right in the Australian—but the spokesman said there were concerns expressed by one person. I think it is appalling that all those health insurance companies were investigated in that way without the Minister giving his approval, I presume, for that officer to make that inquiry. I think the public should know that that is the sort of thing that goes on and that is the way their money is spent; and that is the way their organisations, to which they belong, are investigated by this Government with very little information from somebody who has such a prejudiced view about health and how health ought to be run.

TALK.START.PARA: —As there are no further questions in relation to subprogram 2.3, we will move to subprogram 3.2.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to the resident classification instrument validation process under the home and community care for the aged program. At a public hearing of the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs, evidence was given in relation to the expenditure on this program. I was told that consultations were occurring between the home and community care program administrators and the unions and the Australian Nursing Federation in relation to the classification.

PARA.TAB: Since then, I have received a letter from the secretary of the Queensland Nurses Union which states that it passed a number of resolutions in relation to the RCI classification. I understand from it that no consultations have occurred. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: The mood of the meeting could be described as one of controlled anger by those present also a determination to ensure that if a more positive solution is not forthcoming before the next meeting on the 1st December, 1992 that anger may be channelled into a more intense campaign to achieve a satisfactory result.

I asked previously what time constraint was put on the consultations in relation to the RCI instrument. I understood that those consultations were occurring, but according to this information they are not. So there seems to be a discrepancy in the evidence that was given at the last public hearing. The first resolution, resolution 1, carried by the members at that meeting on 2 November states:

That the membership confirms its dissatisfaction with the current R.C.I. validation process as an unnecessarily complex and bureaucratic funding assessment mechanism which has the effect of causing an efficient use of nursing time, time which could be better applied to the care of the nursing home residents.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, consultations were undertaken between the Department and the ACTU, which is the organisation that obviously has an umbrella aegis in relation to the particular nurses union that Senator Herron mentioned. I also understand that particular consultations have taken place with representatives of the Queensland Nurses Union and the Minister, who has met with them. I do not quite know at what stage in the process the consultations and deliberations occurred, but I believe that there has been some communication and consultation.

—When will a finality be reached in relation to the reclassification? The letter that I received from the Queensland Nurses Union states that it is a matter of urgency. It intends taking industrial action if something is not resolved before 1 December. So it is just not good enough to say that consultations are occurring. Consultations can keep on occurring for the next millennium.
—I think we understand the urgency of the matter as Senator Herron has outlined it. I will ensure that the relevant officers in the Department respond to that urgency.
—As there are no further matters in relation to subprogram 3.2, we will move to subprogram 7.1.

—Before concluding, Mr Chairman, I want to say that, due to the guillotine that has been placed on us by the Government and the Australian Democrats, I am now unable to ask a number of questions that I would have liked to ask because we have already gone past our timetable. I speak not only on my behalf but on behalf of all my colleagues. There were a number of very important questions to be asked about the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. But the Government is ducking for cover and the Democrats have helped it. It does not need the Appropriations until later. I for one object very strongly to the Government's approach.

—I have a matter that deals with the Attorney-General's Department rather than the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. I was going to deal with it at the end of Estimates Committee E when we dealt with the report of the Committee, but I may as well put it on the record now and get it done.

PARA.TAB: Last night, Senator Patterson asked some questions concerning the status of the AFP investigation into allegations of theft and impropriety in the national production unit of the Department of Social Security in Tuggeranong. The investigation was carried out by members of the AFP's Headquarters Fraud and General Crime Division. That investigation has now been completed. A brief of evidence is currently being prepared and, when completed, will be forwarded to the Commonwealth Director of Public Prosecutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that, because I was not able to get it from the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus). I appreciate his response.
—He did not know.
—Well, his Department would have known. I appreciate the Minister's response.

—We have concluded the Estimates for the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services. We will now move to the Estimates for the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs and proceed according to the running sheet. As there are no other questions, we will begin with subprogram 1.5, which is entitled Refugees, Humanitarian and Special Assistance.

—I have a number of questions relating to this subprogram which need to be answered. My first question to the Minister relates to the 113 boat people who were forcibly repatriated from Christmas Island after having been on the island for a mere eight days. Were each of those boat people interviewed separately? If so, were they informed of their rights under the Convention and Protocol relating to the Status of Refugees?

—I understand that each of the persons who arrived was interviewed separately, with interpreters where required, and that the persons were asked—this helps answer the second question—on what basis they were claiming to be able to seek to stay in Australia. As I understand it, the answers given did not give rise to the sorts of considerations which would lead to an explanation of rights under any convention to do with refugee status.

—Does the Minister mean that each of the 113 people was interviewed separately as to their particular concerns? Were they asked questions as to whether they had a well-founded fear of persecution on their return? Secondly, were they given the opportunity of either legal representation or representation and assistance by any persons from refugee organisations or the UNHCR?

—As I understand it, each of the 113, including children, was interviewed separately and a separate report or assessment was made on each of them. They were asked basically: `Why did you leave China?' and `On what basis do you claim to be able to stay here in Australia now that you have landed on Christmas Island?'. It was on the basis of their answers to those questions that an assessment was made against all relevant criteria or legal bases that may be available for them to stay in Australia.

—Has anyone other than the Department been provided with the opportunity of assessing, in an independent way, the exercise by the departmental officers of directions that were given to them? In other words, were refugee groups or legal assistance made available to these persons?

—No. The matter has not been referred further than the high ranking departmental officers and procedures that were involved in the process. As to whether refugee organisations, perhaps, might have played some role, that might have been the case had refugee status been sought or mentioned as a ground for either leaving China or for seeking to stay within Australia. I am advised that that was not the case and that the question of being assisted by those sorts of community organisations therefore did not arise.
—Were these boat people asked specifically about their possible fate on their return to China?
—No. The questions were: `Why did you leave?' and `On what legal basis do you claim to be able to stay?'.
—Going to the question of `what legal basis do you claim to be able to stay', were the boat people given an explanation of what that legal basis might be?

—They were not presented in a list to the boat people. The boat people themselves had arrived on our shores. They were simply asked: `Why did you leave China?' and `On what basis do you claim to be able to enter Australia?'. They were asked the questions and they gave certain answers which led to the conclusion that there was no legal basis for them to remain in Australia.

—Are the responses now available for consideration in a confidential capacity or other capacity to review the assessment that was made by officers of the Department? Were the interviewing officers the same persons who made the assessment, or who in the Department made the assessment? Was it a senior officer, and what was the grade of the officer? Was the officer a person with legal qualifications, or what were the qualifications of the officer who made these assessments?

—As I understand it, the interviews were carried out and assessments made by the interviewing officers. They were then reduced obviously to writing. The reports were then faxed to a very senior officer within the Department here in Canberra who reviewed their assessments and made the decisions. In other words, the interviewing and assessing officers did not make the decision for removal. That was made by a senior division head here in Canberra.

—Has the Minister become aware of a statement made over the SBS program Dateline on 11 November by a departmental officer by the name of Michael Phillips? It referred to, I think, a rejection mentality by the Department in respect of its attitude to refugees and accused the Department of prejudice and the whole system of being vitiated by a policy of rejection. What comments has the Minister to these very serious allegations, which, if correct, throw a very grave question mark over the whole of our immigration system? I also refer to the statement that was made by Mr Justice Einfeld to the immigration conference in Sydney late last week at which he said that Australia's treatment of boat people seeking asylum has been shameful and a blot on its compassion and humanity. What responses has the Government to those particular statements, which appear to come from people who ought to know the facts?

—I am not prepared to concede that Mr Justice Einfeld would necessarily know. It is not as though a case has been presented before him and he is making a judicial determination on evidence properly before him, with the benefit of full argument. As to Mr Phillips, I have only an awareness from a newspaper report. I understand that the Minister has, of course, strongly repudiated the claims of a general culture of rejectionism running within the Department. The bias or prejudice which would have to be the foundation of any such general culture would need to be the subject of very clear articulation by Mr Phillips. I do not know that he has done that, certainly in the public arena.

PARA.TAB: I understand that some of these matters are before the Merit Protection Review Agency and that Mr Phillips has lodged a grievance there. I do not know how far I can go in relation to matters before the MPRA. But I understand that he is still an officer of the Department and that the matters he has raised publicly are also being considered within a due process within the Department. I understand that the Minister himself has made some comments. Perhaps I can obtain a copy of the Minister's comments, which would probably be more authoritative and carefully considered than mine in the Committee of the Whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question relates to the earlier line of questioning that Senator Harradine was pursuing; that is, the matter of the 113 Chinese boat people who arrived at Christmas Island. What was the cost to the Australian taxpayer of the chartering of the aircraft to repatriate the people to China? Could the Minister give me some information on the additional costs to the Australian taxpayer for accommodation, food and medical treatment, if any was provided; and also the cost to the Department from having to send officers to Christmas Island to undertake lengthy interviews over quite a number of days?

—I can give Senator McKiernan a broad indication. I am advised that it is in the region of $400,000. I can provide the exact elements in better detail at a later time. But the great bulk of that is, of course, the $250,000 charter flight back to China. I think some $40,000 or $50,000 would have been paid to Australian Protective Service officers who provided escort. As to the elements that went into the operation at Christmas Island, that would account for the balance. I can provide a more precise answer, but it would have to be at a later date. But they are the broad parameters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia has an obligation, does it not, under the UN convention and protocol on the status of refugees to give sanctuary to persons who are refugees? It seems to me incredible that the Department can assess the refugee status of these 113 individual persons against the background of accusations that have been made about the Department's culture of rejection. That is what I am asking. If we add the question of not only cultural rejection but also how much money it is going to cost us to assess refugees, I believe we would be acting, like Mr Justice Einfeld said, in a shameful manner and lacking compassion and humanity. I am not yet saying that; but that is what he said.

PARA.TAB: I want to go to the general impression in the community that there are thousands of boat people in Australia awaiting consideration or assessment of their claims for refugee status. To put the record correct and straight, what is the percentage of boat people awaiting assessment as compared with the total number of persons in Australia awaiting assessment of their particular refugee or other status?

TALK.START.PARA: —Of those seeking refugee status, there would be 20,000 such applications currently being processed within Australia. Of those, some 500 would be boat people claiming that status.

—I thought it was over 20,000. I thought it was something like 23,000 and something like 500 boat people. That puts the matter into perspective—that there are not a large number of boat people in this category.

PARA.TAB: I go to the question of the seven boat people who were repatriated forcibly by the Department to China from Port Hedland; the people who were dragged out of their beds at 5 o'clock in the morning and sent back to China. In answer to the question that I asked the Department, the Department indicated to me:

SPEECH.PARA: In the case of unsuccessful asylum seekers, the fact that a careful and exhaustive individual assessment of their claims to refugee status has resulted in a negative decision means that the Minister or his delegate is satisfied that they do not face persecution, and that return to their home country would not put them in a situation requiring monitoring by this Department.

My question therefore is: what has happened to those seven boat people who have been forcibly repatriated from Port Hedland? Reports have come from China that they have been and are continuing to be punished. What is the situation? What has the Department done to check these reports? What is the latest information about that?

TALK.START.PARA: —Inquiries have been made through the Australian Embassy in Beijing as to the fate or circumstances of those who were returned in that way. The answer that has been received from the embassy—of course, from the Beijing authorities—is that the persons returned were of no particular political interest to the authorities and that we, at the moment anyway, have no reason to suppose that they have been incarcerated or at the moment are imprisoned or suffering any ill-fate. That is as much as we have been able to ascertain.
—So the Department is taking the word of the PRC Government?

—Inquiries, as I say, have been initiated by the Department through the Australian Embassy in Beijing. It has used its best endeavours to understand and to be able to answer the sort of question that Senator Harradine is properly concerned with. Of course we are dependent on receiving information from the authorities in the country concerned. That is the way in which the embassy has to work.

—Is it not also correct to say that one of the seven people who were deported from Australia has been interviewed by an international correspondent with the national broadcaster? Would that not indicate to the Senate that that individual at least is free and able to move around freely in his homeland in order to be able to take a telephone call and talk to the people of Australia to say that he is in good health, good spirits and is free?

—Officials indicate to me that the person who was interviewed was in fact not one of the seven, but had been deported to China in August of this year and, as Senator McKiernan said, had been interviewed by an international media organisation.
—I think it was by Monica Attard.

—Senator McKiernan draws the inference that if that particular person was able to be interviewed in that way, then certainly he was enjoying some freedom at that time. I suppose that is a reasonable inference.

—I repeat my question about the seven people from Port Hedland who have not been interviewed—and, even if they had been interviewed, one wonders about the circumstances that they would be considering in their own minds as to what consequences might follow. Why should the Department rely just on this statement that it has given to me: that the fact that a negative decision has been made about refugee status means that these people will not face persecution? That appears to me to be a non sequitur. Has the Minister stated quite often that he accepts the word of the PRC Government?

PARA.TAB: In respect of the seven people who were forcibly repatriated from Port Hedland, I want to know, as an Australian and as an Australian senator, what has happened to them. There are constant reports coming from China that they are suffering persecution and that they are being punished. Now we are being told by the Minister that the Department says that it has been advised by our embassy in Beijing, which has been advised by the PRC, that these people are not being punished.

Frankly, we have no confidence—and no reason to be confident—in the assurance of the PRC Government. This is the same Government that said originally that nothing happened to anybody in Tiananmen Square. Why, for example, is the delegation in China now not having a look at this particular case? This is an important question: why is the delegation not going to that area and continuing to see whether people coming back from Australia are being punished?

The person mentioned by the Minister, who was not one of the seven, in fact was placed under detention for about a fortnight. In fact, he had his papers taken from him so that he could not get work. I am not sure whether those papers have been returned to him. If they have not been returned to him, he cannot get work and he is being punished. The Minister may not be able to answer these questions now, and I note that the time is getting on. I will conclude, but this is a very important question and we just cannot accept the assertions of the PRC Government when it comes to violations of human rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to Mr Dong, I have a little more information here. He was deported from Australia in August 1992; detained for nine days at the airport before entering China; his passport was taken from him and he was given a receipt to enable him to obtain an ID card to use as a means of ID—this is apparently standard practice; he was questioned once while in detention and had one other conversation. After his release, he travelled with his family to Shanghai where he now lives with his wife in a house which has a telephone; there was no further contact with any other officials; and was able and willing to travel to an establishment near the Consulate-General in Shanghai to meet with our migration officer. They are some dot points which officials have been able to hand to me.

PARA.TAB: With respect to Senator Harradine's very good suggestion about the present parliamentary delegation travelling in China, it is a good suggestion and therefore has occurred to others. Indeed, that delegation has been briefed on precisely this matter. It is amongst its working papers and documents, as I understand. I am quite sure that there would be persons within the delegation who would have an opportunity—and, as a delegation, there would be an opportunity—to utilise that brief in order to follow up the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did want to go to the question of the Cambodians, but as I will have to follow up this matter at some other stage because of the time constraints I will leave that question. But I want to ask the Minister about something with which he may be able to help. The Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Anthony Mason, expressed serious concern about the gist of the proposed migration legislation and its capacity to create an enormous backlog of work for the courts. The letter, which I believe was dated early November—I do not know the precise date—was sent to the Attorney-General, Mr Duffy, but it related to the proposed migration laws which are within this Department's bailiwick. Could the Minister table the letter for the edification of the Parliament and the Committee?

—We are in an extremely delicate area where there is correspondence between the Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia exercising the judicial power of the Commonwealth, and the Attorney-General of the Commonwealth of Australia who obviously has responsibilities which made it proper for the Chief Justice to address a letter to him. That letter from the Chief Justice has been responded to and a lengthy reply has gone from the Attorney-General to the Chief Justice. I have no knowledge of any further reply from the Chief Justice or whether he has been satisfied with the response.

PARA.TAB: In other words, the correspondence is not correspondence which is in the control of this Department or this ministry. It is a matter for the Attorney-General and the Chief Justice. I will seek advice from the Attorney-General as to the best course of action, given the honourable senator's request. But I add a cautionary note that I would have some prudent caveats on the making public of correspondence of that kind.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will have to take up these other matters relating to Chinese students and immigration during the debate on the migration laws. But on the question of legal representation, I have eight short, straightforward questions. Could the Minister take those on notice, please?
—Yes, we will take them on notice.
—Are there any further questions in relation to subprogram 1.5? Do you wish to incorporate those questions in Hansard, Senator Harradine?
—No.
—Are there any further questions in relation to subprograms 2.1, 3.4, program 4 or subprogram 6.1?

—Mr Chairman, I have a long series of questions that I wanted to ask in the interests of local governments around Australia. But, in view of the scandalous curtailment of this debate by the Australian Democrats in conjunction with the Labor Party, I will be prevented from doing that. That is a great pity because a lot of local authorities around Australia demand answers to questions which obviously will not be able to be put. Therefore, I do not intend to pursue most of my reservations.

PARA.TAB: The only one I want to raise relates to the local capital works program. In the last couple of days, the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins, has said that he is bringing forward $55m of that program. That program was to commence no later than 1 December 1992, under the original rules, with all projects to be completed by 31 December 1993—that is, in one year's time. What is the purpose of bringing forward the $55m, apart from some fairly cheap political capital to pretend to this Australian nation that this Government is doing something about the record 11.3 per cent unemployed in Australia at the present time?

It seems to me that that $345m was already committed. The program had to be started by December this year. The plans take some time to get moving, but most of the plans are in. By bringing forward $55m from 1 July to 30 June, what possible benefit can that have to local authorities or the unemployment question? What possible benefit could it have to anyone except the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Treasurer? They are trying to get some political mileage by fiddling with these figures, as they have already done on a number of occasions, with the local capital works program—doubling and quadrupling the moneys going to each electorate, showing that money goes to marginal Labor held electorates.

All those things have already been done. Here it is again: with a stroke of the pen the Government will bring forward $55m from one financial year to an earlier one when that money had already been committed. How is this stroke of the pen, this bit of creative accounting, in any way going to help local authorities with the unemployment tragedy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again, we have been berated with propaganda rather than seeking real information. If we had not been here today, I would have been on the north-west coast of Tasmania talking to the Devonport Council, for example, about its capital works program and helping it to get under way some very good projects. That is not in a marginal Labor seat. Marginal Labor seats have nothing to do with the matter. The criterion is that in the local government area concerned the unemployment rate has to be above the national average. That is the only criterion upon which these areas have been selected.

PARA.TAB: It is pretty remarkable—and I think Senator MacDonald would acknowledge this—that councils, their engineers and elected officials have been very adept in bringing forward these projects in an exemplary way. It is quite clear that more projects can be got under way very quickly. That makes good sense because one wants to generate economic activity within these local government areas. That will be done by increasing the activity and employment in those areas via this capital works program. This will provide many benefits to communities over years to come.

TALK.START.PARA: —If by spending $345m and by getting the local councils to do it the Government will cure the unemployment problem—I concede that most of them are doing a very good job—why did the Government not spend $700m or a couple of billion and really do the right thing and fix the problem properly? The councils could have well spent that money. The Minister is aware that, whilst about 45 per cent of councils got something, more than 50 per cent got absolutely nothing from this program. The councils are very unhappy. All councils have very worthwhile projects. They also have very large numbers—possibly not in percentage terms—that would entitle them, one would think, under the Government's rules to some benefit.

PARA.TAB: Why did the Government not spend a bit more if this is going to cure it all? Why did the Government not distribute the money more evenly rather than being selective with it? As I have said, we would not have given this money for those projects, not because they are not worthwhile projects but simply because the money is not there. It is borrowed on the international bankcard and our kids and grandkids will have to pay it off in the years ahead. If the Government thinks that the unemployment problem will be cured by borrowing $345m, fiddling with the figures, bringing $55m forward from one year to other, why did the Government not spend a couple of billion dollars?

TALK.START.PARA: —What happens when the money runs out and they all go back again?

—The program which has been brought forward in part and which is already being undertaken in various local government districts has been assessed very scrupulously according to the proper criterion of unemployment within those communities being above the national average. We believe that the programs are manageable, sensible, being undertaken properly and funded by the Government in a responsible way—not in an outrageously $2 billion way, which is what Senator Macdonald is suggesting and advocating should be the case. We would regard that as profligate.
—I'm not advocating it. Don't tell fibs.

—Senator Macdonald is saying that if the program is to occur it should be a bigger program. We are saying that we have hit the right funding formula and the right outer limits to the expenditure that should be undertaken. That is why the program is being greeted with such acclaim in the various local government areas that I visit.

—I take up Senator Brownhill's interjection. What is going to happen to all those unemployed who may be employed by this program on 31 December 1993 when the program runs out, the money stops, the work stops and the job stops?

—This sort of generation of economic activity within particular areas will have its own ongoing momentum. If a subcontractor works for a council and gets a job which carries him through for three or four months and enables him to keep the team together or to take on others within the team, that gives him a stability which then enables him to tender for and obtain other jobs. This is a continuing process. It does not all come to an end on a particular day. It enables a strengthening of the employment opportunities of local communities by generating economic activity as expenditure takes place and as wages are spent within the community. That all has an effect which creates more employment opportunities, enduring employment opportunities, within those areas.

—I noted that Senator Tate admitted to Senator MacDonald something that I have been saying all the time—that this does not create any new jobs. The Minister said that it may save some jobs for people who are working for subcontractors. I have always believed that capital works under these rather massive allocations to local government tended to go to contractors that already had a work force, and not necessarily ones that belong to that area. That answer to Senator MacDonald's question has confirmed my fears.

PARA.TAB: I seek a reason from the Minister for the fact that the Western Australian City of Stirling got $7m, but the City of Wanneroo, which is right alongside it, got nothing. I understand that the unemployment figure in Stirling was just above the line whereas the figure for Wanneroo was just below the line. Although the City of Wanneroo was just below the line, it still has a high number of people unemployed. I cannot see why it was not given an allocation—except that the City of Stirling is very marginal whereas Wanneroo, being part of the Federal electorate of Moore, is very safe for the coalition.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is simply a matter of an application of a totally objective formula which tries to ascertain where expenditure can best take place by targeting those local government areas where the unemployment rate is above the national average. It is a perfectly defensible and sensible criterion. There will always be those places which fall a bit above or a bit below the line. I can understand the heartache that that causes, but it is a proper approach by a government which is trying to target its expenditure in these areas.

—In relation to these local government capital works, can the Minister give me an up-to-date figure for the number of new jobs created in Western Australia—or he can give me a figure for Australia if he likes—as opposed to those already working? Also, what percentage of the capital works program—and I could not get this out of the Department of Finance—has been spent?
—As to the amount that has been spent—
—The percentage.

—We will get that figure for Senator Panizza, but it will vary from week to week; so much is rolling out day by day. We will try to get that for him, but not today. As to the first question on new jobs, the criterion for the councils when they make their applications is that local economic activity be generated. As at 1 p.m. on 16 November, which was yesterday, $52.2m had been spent. That is a more rapid take-up than was anticipated at the time of the Budget. It represents 21.3 per cent of the anticipated outlay of $245m which was announced at Budget time.

PARA.TAB: The employment creation aspects of this capital works program are not to be measured simply in terms of new jobs; they are to be measured in terms of the economic activity generated in the local government area and the expenditure of moneys which, as I have said, secure jobs and generate further economic activity. That is quite apart from those people who might be taken on as extras.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Panizza, in his question before the last one, mentioned the wonderful and beautiful City of Wanneroo. The inference in his question was that the money had been allocated to the City of Stirling because it was included in the Federal electorate of Stirling, which is held by Ronald Edwards. Is it not true that a large part of the electorate of Cowan, a very marginal Labor Party seat held by Carolyn Jakobsen, falls within the boundaries of the City of Wanneroo?

PARA.TAB: Is it not true that suburbs of Perth such as Peppermint Grove and Dalkeith, which could not be said to be Labor Party areas, were allocated funds under this program? The program was for job creation, and that job creation was spread around in Western Australia, irrespective of the political affiliations of the members of Parliament. That can be seen to be the case right throughout the country region. I am aware of the moneys that have been allocated within the electorate of O'Connor, which is held by our dear friend the honourable Wilson Tuckey.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh, cut it out!

—As a matter of fact, Senator Crane, today, had it not been for the Opposition senators' behaviour in filibustering last week, I would have been in the City of Bunbury, which is within the Federal electorate of Forrest, presenting cheques to the value of over $100,000 to the local authority for job creation programs to get people back into employment.

—Mr Chairman, I am terribly sorry; I am unable to answer Senator McKiernan's question because, of course, I have never paid, nor has the Minister, any attention to which marginal seats are within these local government areas.
—That concludes the consideration of the report of Estimates Committee E.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the report of Estimates Committee F be adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —We will again follow the running sheet, as we have done with the other committees. Are there any matters to be raised before we get down to program 1?

—Before I begin the specific questions I have for the Minister, I would like to express my dismay at the progress of Estimates Committee F in relation to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. At this moment I have not received answers to over half the questions which I placed on notice before the Department. If I do not have the answers to questions in the Estimates Committee, I cannot follow up the important issues, as is the right of every senator as part of the function of review. The answers that I am still waiting on cover a very wide range of departmental programs. They include all questions on general recurrent funding, schools, national priorities for schools, questions relating to the Australian National University, the University of Southern Queensland, the University of Canberra, the Australian Research Council, Aboriginal employment and training, Austudy, Abstudy, management services and youth affairs.

PARA.TAB: I think the Minister will agree that many of these areas are of particular significance to the community. They are major Budget items and are of significance to the current economic climate, and the public is entitled to know whether the money is being well spent. They are particularly significant in view of the fact that the Department of Employment, Education and Training has one of the poorest records of financial management in the Federal Public Service. This is the Department whose financial accounts for last year were heavily qualified by the Auditor-General. Time and again, on specific project audit, the Auditor-General has made severe criticisms and wide ranging recommendations. Usually the recommendations have been poorly followed up, and this has been the case from year to year. It is a mega-department and now it is too big, and so the Department needs very careful scrutiny and review.

Unfortunately, however, this review cannot be properly undertaken before the Appropriation Bills are passed because we do not have answers to very important questions. A large part of the blame we lay at the feet of the responsible Minister. The hearing did not actually take place until 21 October 1992, a delay of four weeks. The Committee was continually delayed because the Government could not provide a Minister to attend the Committee. Finally, the only date available was 21 October, and then we did not have the Minister normally responsible for DEET but we had the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button), who spent most of his time doing his homework out of a series of blue folders.

Quite clearly, this Government is contemptuous of the review processes of the Senate. The Committee meeting was held four weeks ago and it is not surprising that the Department has not answered all the questions on notice, given that there were hundreds. Nevertheless, after a period of four weeks, we would expect the reply rate from the Department to be higher than 50 per cent, particularly on the many important programs that were covered. This makes a farce of the procedures of the Senate and severely curtails our review function. Given this situation, I ask the Minister to give an undertaking that all questions on notice that are currently unanswered will be answered by 1 December 1992.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have heard most of what Senator Tierney has had to say. He would be aware, as I am sure other senators are aware, that the original hearing for the estimates of the Department of Employment, Education and Training was scheduled for an earlier time than it was actually held. The reason why the hearing at the earlier time did not proceed was that the hearings of preceding portfolios took longer than the program managers anticipated and drove us into the wee small hours of the mornings on those days. That put us in a position of clearly not being able to do justice to the consideration of a portfolio as important and as central to Government policy as the portfolio of Employment, Education and Training, so a time was set at which most members of the Committee were available to devote a full day to those hearings. But, alas and alack, the demands of other members of the Senate Estimates Committee to pursue issues in the Primary Industries and Energy portfolio even intruded into part of that time, limiting it. That is not a fault of the Government, that is a fault of how the program unfolded. Perhaps if I were being unkind—which I will not be—I could say it was filibustered, but I do not think that is a fair description.
—I am sure of it.

—It came close, but I do not think it is a fair description of it if one is precise about what the circumstances were. But I do not think it is fair, either, to then say that the Government has not enabled proper scrutiny because the times were truncated by virtue of the way in which the events took place.

PARA.TAB: The next matter was the number of questions that were asked when the portfolio came on for scrutiny. The number of questions on notice asked before the hearing was 88. The number of questions asked during the hearing which required information to be obtained which was not available to the officers appearing before the Committee was 49. All up, a total of 137 questions were asked. Of those questions that were asked, some 50 per cent have been answered. The problem about dealing with numbers and percentages is that it does not go to the complications about obtaining an accurate, fully checked answer in each case. I think there is common and fair accord between us that some of those questions involved quite considerable coordination across various sections and divisions within the Department in order to get together the information from which an answer can be given.

I am advised by departmental officers that they expect to have answers to 89 per cent of all the questions that have been either put on notice or asked directly in the committee proceedings in the possession of the Committee by the end of next week. The remaining 11 per cent of questions will take a little longer than that, because of the difficulty about obtaining the information. These are answers to questions where the information does not sit neatly and discretely in a pigeonhole somewhere so that it can be plucked out and put down, but needs a lot of coordination. With the glut of questions that have been before the Department, obviously there is a question of trying to do the right thing; but the more complicated and complex the research needed in order to answer those questions, the longer it takes.

So in answer directly to Senator Tierney's question to me today, I give an undertaking that by 1 December there will be an answer to all of the questions. I can answer now that it is my expectation that 89 per cent of the questions will be answered in a week or so, and certainly by that date. The Department is pursuing the target of trying to answer all of those questions as quickly as possible in all the reasonable circumstances. I do not think I can fairly say now that all answers will be in and available by the date specified, although I am assured by the Department that they will be in and available as soon as possible and within a reasonable time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the comments of my colleague Senator Tierney, and I intend to do so very quickly and as precisely as possible. I also want to bring to the notice of the chamber the fact that we are left with one hour and 45 minutes to consider the report of Estimates Committee F, which covers the portfolios of Employment, Education and Training, including ATSIC; Industrial Relations; and Primary Industries and Energy. I think that what the Government has done, in collusion with the Democrats, is absolutely outrageous. When the Government's total outlays for 12 months are in the order of $110 billion, to guillotine the examination of that expenditure is absolutely outrageous. There are other words that I can think of but I should not use them in this place.

PARA.TAB: As the Minister quite correctly said, the scheduled hearings of the estimates for DEET were put back, but I point out that some of the most important information that we required to present questions was received either on the day before those hearings or on the day of the hearings. I refer particularly to paragraph 5 of the Committee's report. I will not go into it in detail because of the limitation of time. However, it would be interesting to know whether, if the hearing had been held on the date originally scheduled for it, the information would have been available at that time. If so, the question could be asked: why was it not given to us at that time and not held back until we actually got to the hearings?

I wish to make one point about what the Minister just said with regard to the additional time that was taken to consider the estimates for the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. We agreed between us—I acknowledge the efforts of Senator Beahan—that we would start an hour early to facilitate the additional questioning that was required for Primary Industries and Energy, which was in relation to AQIS. In fact, we did start an hour earlier and I think we used 15 minutes of the time allocated to DEET. The point that the Minister did not mention was that we also finished an hour earlier than anticipated because, as Senator Tierney has already pointed out, the Minister who was with us that day, Senator Button, had to leave an hour early. That took an hour off our time. I want to emphasise that many of those questions could not have been asked prior to that time because we did not have all the information that we required.

I also refer to paragraph 9 of the report to the Senate by Estimates Committee F, which deals with training and management, management skills, and a committee chaired by Mr David Karpin. I bring that to the attention of the chamber.

I have two further comments to make. I highlight what I term the mismanagement of the Department in relation to the increase in its administration costs. It is worth noting that they are growing at a significantly faster rate than the delivery of services. In the current situation one would have thought the reverse would apply because of the extra demands on the Department through DEET. In looking at those we find that running costs, other than outlays, increased by 20.43 per cent and total outlays increased by 17.4 per cent. That highlights the point that I wished to make.

The next point I wish to make is that there are incomplete program performance statements requiring supplementary derivation tables. In making that particular point, the other one I make is that there were movements from one program to another in terms of expenditure and funding. While we were told that that was to do with modernising—I guess that is the right word—the presentation of the reports, there was no way, from looking at them, in which one could identify the changes that had been made.

I will conclude these opening comments by summarising my points. Firstly, the time given was totally inadequate for us to scrutinise DEET properly—hence, the huge number of questions which were put on notice. Secondly, at a time when we have record and unacceptable levels of unemployment because of the mismanagement of this Government, we find ourselves being left with probably about 45 minutes to deal with this whole program here in the chamber today. It does no credit to the Government, nor the Democrats, for gagging this debate.
The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Vanstone)—If there are no more general remarks, we will move on to the specific programs. Program 1, Schools, subprogram 1.1.

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to schools, program 1, I raise the fact that the total outlays for this division increased from $2,634m to $2,790m between 1991 and 1993. Administration costs increased from $10.75m in 1991 to $11.9m in 1991-92 and $14.21m in 1992-93, a rise of 32 per cent over two years and 18.6 per cent this year.

PARA.TAB: That is a significant increase in expenditure, and it begs the question, which will come up later on in these hearings, as to why, in terms of the delivery of services through DEET and schools, in particular, that could not have been addressed rather than putting in place ANTA, which will become once again a liability, I believe, on taxpayers because two similar programs or situations will be running alongside one another. Of course, the introduction of ANTA really highlights the fact that the Government—Mr Beazley, in particular—is showing a lack of confidence in the Department. It should have been addressed within the Department and within TAFE rather than increasing, as I have already said, the administration costs here and setting up what will be an entirely new bureaucracy, which we will deal with in a moment or two.

TALK.START.PARA: —We move to program 2, Higher Education, subprogram 2.1.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Estimates Committee F, Mr Zuber made the following comment regarding the open learning initiative:

SPEECH.PARA: Two things would be lacking from that open learning approach compared with the distance education approaches . . . One would be the level of interaction between students and tutors. The residential or summer programs that are often associated with external courses are not an essential part of this. For the $300 we are assured—
I repeat, `assured'—
. . . that an adequate package can be provided to students. The students are then able, at their own cost, to pay for additional services.
I ask, first of all: what comprises the additional services which students will be required to pay for?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —These matters, I am informed, are still subject to negotiation. The tertiary authority in this case is Monash, so they are subject to negotiation with the Monash University. The area of negotiation concerns assistance in tutorials and things of that nature.

—So if I refer back to the comment by Mr Zuber when he was assuring us at that point a month ago that these things are going to be charged, I assume it refers to the marking of assignments, telephone calls and services of tutors. Are these the sorts of things? Surely, if Monash assured the Minister of this matter, it had in mind what it was going to charge the additional costs for. In that case, what were those specific items and, surely, that must have been determined before the $300 figure was established?

—Some of those things that the honourable senator referred to, such as marking of tutorials and things of that nature, are part of a core provision, and that is what the fee is about, but where there is a requirement for additional tutorials or other particular assistance, those are the matters that are being negotiated.

—The Minister will understand that there is some scepticism out in the universities about this $300 per course. I remind the Minister of assurances that he gave me in this place that quality courses offered through open learning would be maintained, as the universities involved strive to protect their reputation. How could the Minister say that the universities will guarantee the quality of their open learning courses when, at $300 per unit for a basic course, all the experts in open learning say that the quality simply cannot be provided at such a low cost?

—We are confident—and I think the universities are confident—that it can be provided. The universities are not likely to put their academic reputations on the line, if this were the case, to deliver a substandard service with their reputations attached to it. They are not going to do that, and I do not believe that it will be a substandard service; it will be a service to the level of excellence that those institutions are used to delivering.

PARA.TAB: What we are quibbling about here is not the quality of academic training that they are offering; we are quibbling about the cost of it and whether they can sustain it in their budgets. The core fee covers, essentially, the provision of the core service, but there are other add-ons that one has to take into account, and they are subject to negotiation.

It is premature to try to anticipate the outcome of that and what the final package will look like, but the Government has great confidence in this being an important initiative that provides, by means of open learning, access to higher education that would not ordinarily be available for people who cannot attend university at the given time. That in itself is quite a positive and welcome step forward in lifting the level of access to education in this country, and in turning Australia down the route of being a clever country.

The quibbling about money, I guess, always occurs and people take positions to argue in the best way they can, in order to lever out of the debate the most favourable position for themselves in terms of who is going to pay what. One expects that. That is life. We do not retreat from it. But it is premature to judge outcomes before they have been arrived at, and I suspect that many of the things that the honourable senator has heard and puts under the rubric `disquiet' are related to positioning for that debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clearly, Minister, that is nonsense. I did work in this sector. I have been a student and a senior lecturer in the field of open learning, and I assure the Minister—and the rest of the industry would support it—that we are not quibbling about costs. We are talking about the Government's provision of what is about one-quarter of what is required.

PARA.TAB: We have seen in the papers today—we have seen in the papers all week, as a matter of fact—comments on how universities are being starved of funds. We read how they are actually carrying out science courses on computers at UTS because they cannot afford the materials. We find humanities departments at Sydney University cutting back greatly on what they are providing—the number of tutorials they are providing and the number of face to face hours they are providing. What the Minister is doing here is exactly the same thing again—providing cut-price education. That makes an absolute mockery of quality assurance and makes a mockery of your Government's aim of achieving the clever country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a political statement and this is not the forum for a political debate. I do recognise Senator Tierney's previous occupation as being in academia and I do not in any way detract from that. I think he has a sound reputation, but he is here, as a senator, attacking the Government on a political basis to score political points. That puts this debate in a slightly different category, and before the honourable senator raises those issues I suggest that he look at his own Party's policy. That is my political point in return, because that policy would not deliver the sorts of recipes that he seems to be asserting we do not deliver. In fact, it would turn education into a province for the rich and not for the community. It would starve universities and turn Australia down the route of the ignorant country, not the clever one. But that may well be a political debate. We will have it at another time. As far as these Estimates are concerned, I think the answers that I have given adequately reply to the questions of merit raised by Senator Tierney in these questions.

—The only thing with which I can agree in the last statement was that the Minister was making a political statement which certainly has nothing to do with the Fightback package and what we are going to do for education, particularly in this area of higher education and open learning. I will leave that at this point because we need to move on to other programs.
—As there is nothing further on subprograms 2.1 or 2.2, we will move to subprogram 3.1.

—My question relates to vocational education and training. The Department has advised that data is not collected on the number of young apprentices who complete their training and achieve trade qualifications while employed by group training companies. I ask: what percentage of those participating in group training programs enter unsubsidised employment on completion of their training?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unable to give the honourable senator an answer to that question. The honourable senator is asking the Commonwealth Government here to answer on behalf of all of the States and provide him with an aggregated outcome for the answer to his question. If I may, I will seek the information from the States and provide an answer at a later date.

—I thank the Minister for that response. The Department has provided a list of costs for meetings of the Ministerial Council on Vocational Education, Employment and Training. I ask why it is necessary for these meetings to be conducted in five-star hotels which include the Ritz-Carlton in Sydney and the Hyatt Regency in Adelaide.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know, and I am a bit surprised that that, in fact, is the case. But there may be an answer. As a member of several ministerial councils in my capacity as Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, I am aware that many of these meetings in the States are held—where there are consultations between the Commonwealth and the State—with the State, in particular, hosting those meetings and setting the venue rather than the Commonwealth setting the venue. But I will ascertain whether in fact that is the case in these circumstances.

PARA.TAB: I have been handed a schedule—how you pronounce the word `schedule' depends on which school you went to. Is it pronounced `skedule' in the honourable senator's school? Well, it is probably `skedule' in mine.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which school did you go to?

—I went to a working-class school. I am a graduate of Nailsworth Boys Technical High School in South Australia. It is a very good school. That is as far as I went in education until I went into the part time university stream.

PARA.TAB: There is a list here of hotels. The venues, as best as I can tell from this record, are selected by the other party to the consultations, that is the States or, in one case, New Zealand. They are paid out of central secretariat funds in most cases. I can make this list available to honourable senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —I've got the list.
—That is fine.

—I wish to raise a couple of issues with the Minister on this particular program with regard to vocational education and training systems. In particular, I ask him to address the issue of the establishment of the Australian National Training Authority, or ANTA, which is separate from DEET. As honourable senators would be aware, DEET is administered through the States. I note that, in terms of the operations of ANTA, it appears to be replacing a number of the functions of DEET.

PARA.TAB: I ask the Minister: why was it necessary, firstly, to put in place another bureaucratic structure? Secondly, in view of the fact that it will be replacing a number of functions of DEET, is it the intention of the Government in the medium term to withdraw funding from the States for the operations of TAFE?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, the Australian National Training Authority is a body that has been negotiated between the Commonwealth and the States to oversee the provision of funding and services to the technical and further education area. ANTA arose as a consequence of our commitment as a government to enhancing technical and further education in Australia by an amount, as I recall, in the One Nation statement of about $72m. The purpose of that was to provide training for skill and training in the technical areas to match the commitment that we have given to the more academic stream through universities.

PARA.TAB: Because TAFEs are under State jurisdiction, what had occurred over the years was that, by comparison, each State operating its own particular TAFEs in its own way had not allowed them to grow in a manner equivalent to the needs of industry and of the community. They had not grown in a way which we, as the Federal Government, thought was healthy for the balance of skills in the economy. That situation required an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States, because we are not in the business of funding schemes that do not deliver the goods just so that the State jurisdictions can prosper. It is the delivery of the goods that is the important thing, not how much funding a particular State captures. Therefore, we have national standards. ANTA was set up to help draw all parts of Australia into a proper national structure.

I would have thought that that was something that even the most States rightist advocates in education would think was a good thing. The fact that States of all political stripes have joined with the Commonwealth to set national standards and to work in this way is a positive development in a federation such as Australia. So I do not see ANTA, as the honourable senator depicted it in his question, as yet another bureaucratic structure. It does not exist to perpetuate a bureaucracy but, in fact, to meet a real national need and to provide a comprehensive and coherent mechanism to service that need.

The honourable senator's second question, as I took it down, was: since this will replace a number of DEET functions, does this mean that there will be less money available for TAFE? I will need to check with my advisers about the precise terms I should use in answering that question, in order to ensure its accuracy. However, my understanding is that there are more funds available to the TAFE system because of the commitment of the Federal Government to improving technical and vocational education in this country. The Government is particularly keen to make it available to young Australians who are out of the school system but who are still in search of training and skills for occupational needs. Much more funding is available for those requirements. However, whether that means that there is less funding available to supplement bureaucratic back-up at State level, I am not sure. I will ascertain that answer.

I am advised that ANTA will be established as a Commonwealth statutory authority to advise a ministerial council, chaired by the Commonwealth Minister. The council will determine agreed national goals, objectives and priorities, strategic directions and planning processes, and vocational education and training. The States and the Commonwealth will jointly fund the national training system through ANTA. The Commonwealth will maintain its current level of financial support for vocational education and training, and will add the $720m in growth funding announced in One Nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that $720m or $72m?

—It was $720m. If I left out the last digit which was a zero in order of magnitude, all I can say is thank God you have corrected me. I would hate to be accused of misleading the Committee by underreporting the amount of contribution we have made. Let me go on with the advice. State training agencies will manage the delivery of vocational education and training, in accordance with planning profiles developed in conjunction with ANTA and agreed by the ministerial council. These new arrangements will enable a major expansion and upgrading of the system to the benefit of industry and young people entering the work force. The advice goes on, but in terms of Senator Crane's question about replacing TAFE functions and making less money available, it is not clear from this advice what the precise answer to that is. I will come back to that a little later and provide the honourable senator with a direct answer.

—I note the answer that the Minister gave. I also acknowledge that it was not complete—in terms of my final question. It was made quite clear in the documentation that staff levels in DEET were going to fall and that ANTA would be replacing some of the functions of DEET. The Minister also made it quite clear—as I understood his answer—that as far as the establishment of ANTA is concerned, agreement has been reached between the States and the Commonwealth. I am certainly not going to criticise the fact that an agreement was reached. I am critical of why that agreement could not have been developed through the current structures that are in place. From the information that has been given to us—I anticipate it will also be in the additional information to come—it seems that the operations of TAFE are being reduced, at a time when it is more than ever needed in this country. With the current levels of unemployment and underemployment, I would suggest that it will be needed for a long time into the future.

PARA.TAB: I find it totally abhorrent that, in establishing ANTA in the way it has been, it is going to be at the expense of the TAFE operations in the various States. I refer particularly to my State, and the Minister's State, too—Western Australia. In most areas in Western Australia, if not all, TAFE has done a reasonably good job. What it needed, if anything, in terms of delivering the services was gingering up and better management.

I think there are two things in the way this has now been structured: firstly, in terms of the run-down of the TAFE operation, a system that is going to address the problem quickly has not been put in place; and, secondly, a structure has been put in place that will increase costs and the problems that I raised in my opening comments. There will be further administration costs; there will be further salary costs rather than the emphasis going to the training side of it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any answer to give because these are points of belief, as Senator Crane has said.
—No, they're not points of belief.
—I understood Senator Crane to say, `I believe' and `I think' and so on in his presentation.
—I said that I believe that your answer would confirm what I said.

—Okay. Let me join with Senator Crane on the points that he has made. I do not think there is any foundation at all to say that, simply because a more coherent and comprehensive structure like ANTA is being established, the bureaucracy will expand at the cost of training delivery. In fact, it is the objective of the Commonwealth to ensure that, whatever the necessary ratio of bureaucracy to trainers and training places, that ratio is kept as slim as possible on the bureaucratic side and as wide as possible on the places and trainers side. When there are six States running TAFEs there are by no means the same degrees of efficiencies. One of the coherences that ANTA brings is to try to get that as the most efficient national model and to overcome the bureaucratic end where it is a bit fat in some of the States.

PARA.TAB: When a new service or a new structure like this is created there is a phasing in time in which there is a little duplication, but essentially the outcome is a better focus on service delivery. Since we are both Western Australian senators, and Senator Crane was kind enough to make that remark, I too have a high regard for TAFE. In fact, the Commonwealth Government has such a high regard for the TAFEs in the various States that it has chosen to put an extra $720m into them to ensure that they deliver an even better service and have the means to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have one further comment to make because I believe in terms of the comment the Minister has just made that he has successfully shot himself in the foot. The expenditure which is there shows quite clearly that administration costs and salary costs are climbing at a significantly faster rate than the delivery of services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I did say there is some duplication at the phasing in and transitional stage. That is an obvious and fairly trite fact. This thing has to be given a go; it has to be given a chance to function, to get set up, to run. My recollection is that it was only July of this year when the Commonwealth and the States came to this conclusion. This is now mid-November. In terms of restructuring the whole of the national training effort, it is a bit premature to judge outcomes at this stage.
—Are there any further matters in relation to subprograms 3.1 or 3.2? We will move to program 4, subprogram 4.1.

—During the Estimates Committee—and this refers to Jobtrain—the Department said that it was satisfied with the outcomes of Jobtrain despite the low outcome rate and explained the low outcome rate as a result of recessionary factors. This would appear to be at odds with an article in the Department's October jobs report which featured a story entitled `Study shows labour market programs given even greater edge in the recession'. Can the Minister explain this discrepancy?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not an avid reader of departmental literature, particularly when the department is not my own, so I do not have a first-hand knowledge of the departmental article, but I see the honourable senator waving aloft a document which I take to be the article. If it is, I will read it and no doubt exchange some comments upon it with him.

PARA.TAB: It is my understanding that the particular program that Senator Tierney has mentioned is not as successful as other programs run by the Department. So the comparison is between other programs and this particular program in terms of hitting the mark in the strategic objectives that those programs have. It is not an argument to say that those programs should not exist, because they do serve a clear need. It is an argument to look at better ways of achieving that need. These programs do serve an important need and should continue.

If I understand the point raised by the honourable senator on the article, there is no inconsistency. In fact, it is a fair comment to make that a department that is on the case and up with the pace and does its job will always keep a critical eye on the service delivery function and evaluate its progress to make sure that it is achieving the best results, and from time to time will compare its hitting rate in a particular program with that of other programs in that department. I do not see any inconsistency, other than to say that the Department appears to be doing its right monitoring role.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have two further questions relating to that, but I will place them on notice. These relate to the low rates of outcome. What additional measures have been undertaken to improve the efficiency of Jobtrain? Given that a 30 per cent rate of positive outcome is considered acceptable by the Department, can the Department explain what targets have been established for 1992-93 and beyond? I put those questions on notice.
—I'll take those on notice.

—The Estimates Committee was advised that the skills focus under the Jobtrain program was a reflection of individual needs and local labour market requirements. In view of the Department's findings and its report on Australia's work force in the year 2001, what action has been taken to ensure that future participants will be trained in skills which will improve their employability in the long term?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a big question for me to answer in a short time. It goes beyond Jobtrain, of course; it goes to questions of skills accreditation, competency based training and a wide range of factors other than the particular focus of the Jobtrain program. Can I suggest that I take this on notice and provide Senator Tierney with a fuller answer across the face of all of those issues as soon as possible?
—Yes.

—The point that I raise with the Minister in terms of employment access, or subprogram 4.1—as with my other questions—refers to management control of the various programs that are in place. I particularly refer to Jobtrain, Jobstart, Jobsearch and special intervention. I refer to an answer that was given to me at the Estimates, when I asked a question with regard to the duration of some of these programs and the expenses.

PARA.TAB: I asked a question with regard to the duration and the expenses of some of these programs and the answer was: `We expect to have a slightly longer average duration'. I asked the question: `Do you expect one, or will you have one?'. I make that particular point because the answer was: `We expect one'. It was continually repeated. The various points that I made during the discussions we had and the questions we asked are in the Hansard record. Following on from Estimates hearings, I wish to ask the Minister about the cost of these four programs. In terms of the unit cost, Jobtrain has risen by 5 per cent, Jobstart by 13.5 per cent, Jobsearch by 2 per cent, and the special intervention program by 150 per cent. I say to the Minister, in view of the fact that additional funds have been given because of additional demand on those services, just by economies of scale, that those costs should be coming down, not increasing. Does the Minister have an explanation which the Department was not able to give us at Estimates for the increase in the costs per unit, when I believe that in the current situation they should be coming down?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —If the Department could not give it to the honourable senator at Estimates, I must say that I do not think my advisers here now can provide me with an answer. If this is a debate between the words `expect to occur' or `will occur', all I can say is that, in the case of `expect', that is a speculative proposition: this is what people believe may be the outcome. `Will occur' is non-speculative: it is about what has happened and what is the case. It may be that, in relation to the difference that Senator Crane is playing with here, it is somewhat idle to have a debate about what the Department believes may be the case and what would be prudent provision to meet it, if it were the case; or about what will be the case when, maybe, insufficient time has elapsed to establish the case in the first place. But one would expect that a department would make prudent provision along its lines of anticipation and forecasting. As for answering Senator Crane's other question about why these changes are there in the first place, I will take that on notice and see whether there is anything further that I can add.

—Since I did raise this issue previously, I would have thought it would have been addressed, because I think it is a very important point or aspect of the whole program and it was my line of questioning. The reason that I raised the situation about the words `expect' or `will expect' in terms of asking direct questions was that one of them is very vague and the other one is in a much more positive vein. I do not wish to get into a debate about words; I am not here to get into a debate about words. The answers that we were given were very consistent.
