The point that I would make is that, if, in fact, costs could be held per unit, in view of the additional demand or economies of scale, as I put it, then we would be looking at an additional 130,000 positions which would be available under current funding without having to pour in the additional amounts of money. Alternatively, we would get to a lot more people. That is a particular point that I wanted to make.

PARA.TAB: The same situation occurs with the accredited training for young people and the land care and environment action program. In fact, if the costs per unit of delivering these services could be held down to previous levels, we would see at least an additional couple of hundred thousand people serviced.

I think it really highlights that, particularly under the management of the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Beazley—he is known in his electorate of Swan as the Minister for unemployment—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! That term cannot be used in relation to the Minister.
—I am not sure what I said wrong.
—You referred to the Minister for Employment as the Minister for unemployment.
—No, I said that that is how he is known in his electorate.
—Whether you say that he is known as that in his electorate or not, it is not parliamentary. Please continue, Senator Crane.

—Thank you, Mr Chairman. Those are the basic points that I wish to raise with the Minister—that the costs of the delivery of the services in terms of Jobtrain, Jobstart, Jobsearch and special intervention are blowing out. There is less in terms of unit costs and there is less being provided for people unfortunate enough either to be unemployed or underemployed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer Senator Crane to page F240 of the Senate Estimates Committee F Hansard of 21 October. In both columns of that page, particularly the outside column, he will see answers from Mr Campbell, of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which I think answer this question and which, I put to Senator Crane respectfully, answered it at the time he asked it as well. But to further elaborate briefly—sure, in the cases of many of our programs the unit cost has gone up, and there are good reasons for that. In the case of the special intervention program, the Department of Employment, Education and Training took over a program that existed for non-English speaking migrants from the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. That means that the costs for that program have increased in this Department, although they have decreased in the other department, and the global outcome across government is that the costs are relatively constant.

PARA.TAB: In the case of Jobstart, a program that has come in for special mention today, I have to say this: we make no apologies as a Government for providing programs to help unemployed people find work.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not criticised that.

—No, you have not, although I might say that by implication the Opposition does so in the Fightback package by abolishing a lot of these programs. However, Senator Crane has not criticised it today. That is a fair point.

PARA.TAB: The reason why the costs for Jobstart have increased is that the Government increased the length of time during which people are entitled to assistance from that program, as well as the amount per week it would pay. It did both those things in recognition of the level of unemployment and the need to provide positive assistance for people who are looking for work and to encourage them to do so. So, while the point can be made that this appears in these Estimates to be a blow-out of costs, the reason for the higher cost is that we have extended a more humanitarian helping hand by extending the length of time and the amount of subsidy provided for people who are unemployed, and I think that that is a reasonable thing for a government to do in the current economic circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of time constraints, I will have to stop, but I would like to respond to the Minister's answer. The first point is that I did not criticise Jobtrain or Jobstart; I will be doing that when we bring down the report on employment, education and training in relation to youth. At that stage I intend to address the many obstacles that stand in people's way in terms of getting access to those programs. In fact, this has been described to us as a funnel: the further you go down the funnel, the narrower the outlet gets, and your chances of coming through the bottom are in many instances fairly remote.
—You get jammed in the funnel.

—People get jammed in the funnel and then they get flipped out the end. The point I was making was in terms of per unit costs and comparing the same thing. If unit costs had been held where they were—and I believe that they should have been and that that is reasonable—instead of there being 290,000 people who could receive assistance under the programs, with the additional funding it could have been increased to 438,000. That is the very point I am making about what I would call the waste and mismanagement in providing these particular programs.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —We seem to have a different point of view. The honourable senator says that unit costs should be kept down. We say in recognition of market circumstances that a program like Jobstart should go for longer and pay more to the recipients of that program. Honourable senators may think it should go for a shorter time and pay less, we think it should go for a longer time and pay more.
—I didn't say that.

—The implication of what the honourable senator is saying is clear. He is saying that unit costs should be contained. We have deliberately made a choice to increase unit costs by extending the operation of the program and increasing the amount payable. If the honourable senator disagrees with that and thinks that we should retain the old unit cost ratio, then the honourable senator disagrees with an increase in the amount and the length of provision. That is a difference in point of view. We think we are right. We think we are recognised universally as being right, but the honourable senator is entitled to his point of view, and I respect that. However, we do not agree with that. I do not know how to resolve that question.

PARA.TAB: The other point that ought to be made on this subject of labour market programs, as we are now moving into the heavy end of this debate, is that from the year 1991-92 to this year's estimates for 1992-93, we have increased expenditure on labour market programs by over 100 per cent. The old estimates were, as I recall, $590m.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is 109 per cent.
—I thank the honourable senator for the correction. We have gone up to just over $1.1 billion.
—That is the amount of unemployment you have generated in this recession.

—That is in recognition of the need to provide programs to those who are unfortunate enough to be unemployed. It is to help them find work or to help them acquire skills to make them more employable and, if they are inevitably faced with an enforced period of unemployment, to make that a period not of idle time, but of training, so that they can pick up places early in the recovery when jobs become more plentiful.

PARA.TAB: It seems to me that that is a sensible thing for a government to do. If economic activity is as it is, and there is a recession, we cannot hide from those facts. We must help people in those circumstances. While the primary settings of government policy are to end the recession and to have an enduring recovery so that we do not get into a cycle of boom and bust again, one of the labour market support strategies that is being debated here is to use the unfortunate down time to skill up the work force so that we have a highly skilled, better trained work force able to adapt more to new technology and to movements in the market for manufactured goods and services.

While we do not yield on the point of our concern for unemployment, we think we have got it right in terms of providing those supports. We do not wait in anticipation of recognition from the Opposition that we have got it right, because we know the Opposition's settings are to effectively abolish a lot of these programs and introduce a sham program which would have no effect but to deskill the work force and to penalise people who are the victims of unemployment because they become unemployed by kicking them off the dole after nine months. I see nothing in that policy of removing entitlements to unemployment benefits after nine months that speaks at all to the issues of humanitarian concern for those people unfortunate enough to be unemployed.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about time the Minister became a little honest in the debate. It is absolutely false for him to say that we would be kicking people off the dole after nine months, and he knows that that is so. The test might be different, but we will not be kicking people off the dole—and he knows that. It is time for him to show a little honesty. The Minister has completely misread my question. He identified, quite correctly and rightly, that we are just getting to the serious part of this debate and how it is best to handle his broader mismanagement in terms of the people the Government has thrown on the streets. That is what it has done through its mismanagement. It is very unfortunate that the Minister, as part of the Government, with his sleazy dealing with those people who sit down here and whom we do not see—
—Where are they today?

—They are not here, but the Government has done a sleazy deal with them to cut off this debate. I would hope that at 3.30 p.m. the Minister will do the right thing and say, `These programs are important; employment is important', and will give us some more time to go through these issues and debate them fully and properly when we get back next week.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —There was a reflection made on me about the way in which I approached the question of the Opposition's policy under the consumption tax package of removing people from unemployment benefit after nine months. That is not a case of misrepresentation by me. That is the situation with the Opposition's policy. I understand that those opposite may be embarrassed by it and may want to play a sort of hide the pea trick by shuffling such people around to special benefit on welfare and, by the way, pretending that that is a labour market policy. But it is a policy, clearly and unambiguously, of blaming the victims and treating people who are unemployed as if they lack the initiative to find employment. It is a disreputable policy. I can understand why they would hide from it, but I have nothing further to add on that point.

—It is a matter of great regret that I still have 30 questions to ask and that, because of the guillotine imposed by this Government and supported by the Democrats, who are not here today, I cannot ask these 30 questions. It is a travesty of democracy that I cannot ask these questions in the chamber, and I will place these questions on notice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —On the question of an alleged travesty of democracy, I was talking just recently to a Minister in the New South Wales Government, a Liberal government, who told me that, when the Estimates process was introduced there under the administration of Premier Nick Greiner, time limits were imposed on the amount of time that estimates could be debated in the Committee of the Whole. A Liberal government in New South Wales limited debate and thus prevented filibustering in the Committee of the Whole debate.

PARA.TAB: What is interesting about the discussion I had—and I will not name the Minister for fear of embarrassing him—was that he said to me that the reason for the time limits was to avoid the Bronwyn Bishop situation of endless and pernicious questioning which actually had no real point. All of these protestations about a limit on democracy are just rubbish. If honourable senators in this place want to ask questions, they have the time available to them to do so. They have the facility to put questions on notice, and they will be answered.

Simply because those opposite wish to filibuster and are thwarted in their effort to filibuster is no ground for them to stand up and make the wild and baseless allegations that they do because the Democrats in this chamber, who represent the fourth party here, are persuaded that they are filibustering and thus want to bring some order and rationality to the proceedings of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to make a very brief comment in support of Senator Tierney. The Minister does not seem to appreciate that his policies have thrown a million Australians out of work. His policies have cut the real wages of Australians who still are in jobs. His policies over 10 years have been an absolute disaster. For him to come in here and misrepresent the Fightback policies—the only plan which is on the table now to try to raise the living standards of Australians, the only plan which is available to get Australians back to work—is appalling.

PARA.TAB: I put it to you, Mr Chairman, that there are many questions which have got to be asked about this most serious crisis that any of us have seen in this country. Certainly, everyone accepts now that this is the worst crisis in the economy for 60 years, and it is appalling to say that we are wasting time by asking the Government about its policies which have created this massive crisis and which have created record unemployment—which it does not argue about now—and by asking the Government to justify its policies which helped to plan this dreadful recession which we still have, despite Mr Keating's attempts to pretend that the recovery is under way. I believe that Senator Tierney and Senator Crane are absolutely correct in wishing to continue to press Senator Cook on his Government's policy so that we can try to get Australia back to work.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALKER.NAME: Senator COOK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations and Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —In point of fact, neither Senator Tierney nor Senator Crane is pressing me on the Government's policies about getting the country into economic recovery. What they are talking to me about is the estimates for the Department of Employment, Education and Training relating to labour market policies which are aimed at supporting people who are unfortunate enough to find themselves unemployed. They are arguing that the amount we are spending on this is too high.

PARA.TAB: However, since Senator Kemp has introduced the question of Fightback, I do appreciate that whenever anyone on the Government side raises a question of material fact about the Fightback policy, we are accused of not understanding it or misrepresenting it. We never have countervailing argument to disprove the material fact that we raise. We never have reference to the Fightback! document to show that we are in error. We simply have such comments as, `But in subsection 43, page 128, or some other page, there is a provision for this'. What we have from the Opposition is a bit of black magic, a bit of hocus pocus, a bit of an allegation—`You do not understand what you have not read'. The fact that is sitting very uncomfortably with the Opposition now is this unexceptional fact, which is its policy, that people who are on unemployment benefits are removed from them after nine months.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is wrong.

—That is not wrong, Senator. That is true. I know the honourable senator does not like the truth, but it is true. To argue that they did not somehow become welfare recipients at a different rate is not an appropriate answer because the Opposition's model stands alongside our model in helping people who are unemployed and the comparison for those opposite is a shameful one. There is no indication of humanitarian concern. There is no real indication of how one trains and skills people in a recession.
—I seek leave to table the documents which were promised for Senator Patterson late last night.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
Progress reported.
Senator Crane—Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented and I seek leave to make a personal explanation.
Leave not granted.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is in Jakarta on Government business. Questions relating to the portfolios of Prime Minister and Cabinet and of Industry, Technology and Commerce should be directed to me as Acting Leader of the Government in the Senate. Questions relating to the Treasury and Finance should be directed to Senator Cook.

PARA.TAB: I also inform the Senate that Senator Evans is in Jakarta on Government business and that questions relating to his portfolio responsibilities should be directed to me. I further inform the Senate that Senator Collins is ill and will be absent from Question Time. Questions relating to the portfolio of Transport and Communications should be directed to Senator Cook; questions on the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, and on Tourism, should be directed to Senator Bolkus; and questions on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs should be directed to Senator Tate.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment—under this Government, perhaps more appropriately `Unemployment'—Education and Training, relates to the One Nation statement. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's statement on 30 June 1992 when he said:

QUESTION.PARA: Now we've got our One Nation package out there working, really in earnest from this financial year beginning tomorrow. So most of the One Nation spending will start to hit its straps in the coming months, the next month or two, and that will itself start to pull the economy up even faster.

Why did it take the Government nine months and for the unemployment figure to reach 980,000 before it was realised that money was not being spent and projects were being delayed? What monitoring mechanism, if any, did the Government establish to track the progress of One Nation and to provide the Government with figures on how many people were being employed? Exactly how many jobs has One Nation created?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —The One Nation statement was a commitment in February of the Government to stimulate the economy by an injection of funds—by investing more directly but not exclusively in public infrastructure in the economy. As well, we made a massive commitment to training and skills programs in Australia in order to turn this country into a more clever country than it has been in the past.

PARA.TAB: At the time our effort at stimulation was criticised by the Opposition. The Opposition remains consistent in that it continues to criticise. It does so in the face of the fact that that is exactly what the Japanese economy did; that is exactly what Bill Clinton is proposing to do in the United States; and that is exactly what the OECD is advising its constituent members to do to help stimulate the world economy and bring on world economic growth. In contradistinction, the Opposition's policy is to remove some $7 billion from fiscal policies, thus putting a considerable brake on recovery and reducing the prospect of full employment.

Let me turn to the question. The goals of investing in public infrastructure are worth while. There is no argument that the rail system in this country does need the national rail freight initiative; there is no argument that the rail-port interface investments and the investments elsewhere in training are necessary.

The fact that there has been an undue delay in getting agreement from the States does not reflect badly on the worthiness of the goals we have pursued. It does not reflect badly on the Federal Government that, for example, a conservative dominated Legislative Council in Western Australia should hold up the national rail freight initiative to make it more difficult for us to get the initiative up. It does not reflect on us that the parties there of those opposite blocked those initiatives.

However, we have now reached a point where we believe the goal of stimulating the economy needs to be addressed further. That is why last Friday the Treasurer made a speech in which he redirected some of those funds to create an extra 20,000 jobs immediately by providing for further investment in Jobstart to help every major employer employ more people. Rather than being attacked and diminished by the Opposition, that should be applauded and praised as a positive step to push through the recovery and make it more general, stronger and enduring.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I remind the Minister that One Nation was supposed to be a job creation program through the development of these infrastructure programs. Therefore, I again specifically ask: how many jobs has One Nation created?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a multi-faceted initiative. One of those facets is to have regard to stimulating employment. But the way in which that is done is by stimulating economic recovery, and that has been the key feature of One Nation.
—How many?

—In terms of the number of jobs that One Nation initiatives have created in the economy, Senator Hill knows full well, as do all of the baying members of the Opposition, that it is not possible to disaggregate the figures. For example, it is not possible to disaggregate the 25,000 extra jobs reported by the Bureau for last month and say that this number or that number or this percentage or that percentage applies because of One Nation initiatives or because of other changes in the economy and growth elsewhere in the private sector. It is clear, though, that the confidence engendered may well have encouraged others to create further employment.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is the Federal Government contemplating introducing legislation to penalise workers for breaking a workplace agreement? Will the Government apply criminal penalties to workers as the Kennett Government has done in Victoria?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —No, the Federal Government will not be introducing legislation to unfairly penalise workers as the Kennett Government is doing in Victoria. We also will not be providing an opportunity for conditions, such as penalty rates and leave loadings, to be `negotiated away' as Dr Hewson has expressed support for and as the Kennett Government is doing.

PARA.TAB: The Victorian employee relations legislation is particularly a vicious piece of legislation. It makes industrial action in Victoria a criminal offence. It provides criminal penalties for breaking an employment contract. I do not think any Australian can in any way regard the contention that arises in workplaces as to what is a fair share of the cake—whether it should go to returns to shareholders or returns to the workers who help generate it—as a contention that involves criminality.

These criminal penalties are in addition to penalties for unlawful industrial action and damages actions of up to $5,000 against individual employees. The Federal Government will not be enacting legislation which attacks the rights of individual workers in our society. The amendments by the Victorian Government do nothing to dilute the legislation. The Victorian Government said the amendments were going to do that, but they do not do that. A Victorian lawyer on radio last week said:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the provision which criminalises breaches of contracts of employment of workers still remains in the legislation.
Comments by the Victorian Government that this has been watered down are, therefore, revealed by an impartial and independent source not to be true.

PARA.TAB: In addition, workers on Federal awards are still caught by the Victorian legislation. Here we have the weirdness of the Victorian Government wanting to visit particular penalties upon its own citizens under its own awards and through its own commission, both of which will be turned into sham awards and a sham commission under its legislation. As well as that, it has caught all workers employed under Federal awards—real awards—as a consequence of having access to a real commission, the Australian Industrial Relations Commission.I am advised that the legislation covers workers under both State awards in the jurisdiction of Victoria and Federal awards in the jurisdiction of the Commonwealth.

The same Victorian lawyer who spoke on the ABC said that the Victorian workers covered by Federal awards will not be exempted from the legislation. The fact is that Federal award employees are still caught by the Kennett legislation.That is cause for this Parliament to become concerned about the incursion into our jurisdiction of a State imposing criminal level sanctions against workers under Commonwealth employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations and follows his somewhat evasive answer to me in relation to the Government's failed One Nation program. I remind him that in February the Prime Minister promised that that program would create more than 800,000 jobs over the next four years. Since then, according to official statistics, a further 60,700 full time jobs have been wiped out, 72,100 more people are out of work and the unemployment rate has climbed from 10.2 per cent to 11.3 per cent with no change in the participation rate. Therefore, I ask the Minister: now that the Government has in effect abandoned its One Nation policy as a failure, what is it offering to solve this long term crisis in Australia, or is it simply offering Australians more of the same?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, there is no doubt that Senator Hill would want to put the worst case that he possibly can. It is the Opposition's desire to talk down the economy, undermine confidence in the private sector and damage the quality of the recovery. Those opposite celebrate and enjoy bad figures. They want to see visited on Australia a worse situation so that they can extract from that where they possibly can some semblance of political point scoring, because they believe that this helps them and their electability.

PARA.TAB: What is true is that, because of the policies of this Government, there are now in excess of 1,450,000 extra people in the work force during our period of government than there were during the time when the Opposition occupied the treasury bench. In fact, if the participation rate that applied during the Fraser years applied now, the level of unemployment in Australia would be around the 8 per cent level and not the figure that now shows. It is the fact that more people are offering for employment—that is, the participation rate is higher under us than under the Opposition—that a greater number of people are listed as unemployed.

It is not fair to directly link the number of people who are among the 25,000 extra people who got work in October to the One Nation initiatives. Nor, for example, could one say that when the Reserve Bank cuts interest rates and reduces the price of housing and other commodities in Australia that directly links to a given number of new jobs in the jobs list. What is true about the figures from last month is that an extra 25,000 Australians or thereabouts got work, and if that trend continues over a full year, it will be a significant growth in employment around the economy. That is the truth. One does not and cannot disaggregate the figures to show what particular macro-economic settings stimulate particular growth in employment. To go on about it in this way is a falsity. There will be a macro outcome and, when the full weight of the One Nation initiatives are felt, we will be able to chart the course of that macro outcome and give the Opposition a global figure of jobs growth due to those initiatives.

What is also fundamental is that if the One Nation expenditure that has occurred and that is now imminent did not occur, there would not be the stimulation in the economy and the access to continuing economic growth needed to lead us into recovery. There would not, therefore, be a meeting of the needs of the unemployed, whom Senator Hill pretends to be concerned about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister does not seem to understand. With one million Australians unemployed, obviously Government policies have failed—presuming that that was not the objective of the Government policies. The question now is: with that failure of Government policy, One Nation being the latest of such failures, is this Government offering anything new? Is it offering any alternative to its failed policies, or is it offering more of the same?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the same as a question asked of me a moment ago. On Friday, the Treasurer announced a repositioning of some of the One Nation expenditures so that they can have a more immediate and direct impact on stimulating economic growth and jobs growth. That was the clear direction of that policy. Our policy is unashamedly one of providing responsible economic stimulation of the economy. It is not a policy that the Opposition espouses, of taking away public investment from the economy and hoping somehow that that will create employment, when all of the academic studies show that it will have a damaging effect on the quality and sustainability of growth. We will not, for example, be doing a number of things that the Opposition proposes. We will not cut people off the dole after nine months. We will not throw 90,000 people off the unemployment benefit. We will not cut hundreds of thousands of labour market programs immediately.

—My question is also directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations, seeing as he is on a roll. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to the campaign being run by the Housing Industry Association, claiming that the Government has changed the Industrial Relations Act in an attempt to unionise workers, and that this will lead to an increase in housing prices? Has the Government enacted such legislation? What will be the impact of any changes on housing prices?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day in Australian public life when an organisation like the HIA—whose charter seems to be to encourage design improvement and to be a source of information about developments in the housing sector—should turn itself into an adjunct of a political party and pursue a political crusade which is not supported by any objective evidence at all and which is clearly not supported by any of the other responsible organisations that cover people and that have interests in the housing industry. For example, the Master Builders Association, which has more people directly employed in the housing industry than does the HIA, clearly sees through the falsity of what the HIA is saying. It sees the HIA as proceeding to be an adjunct of the Liberal Party, engaged in politics rather than in servicing the housing sector.

PARA.TAB: This Parliament passed legislation on 22 June 1992 concerning the right of independent contractors, where they have been injured in terms of the employment contract, to have access to speedy arbitration over whether a contract is harsh and unreasonable. That is the sensible thing for a government to do. That is what the New South Wales Government did. That is what we have done. The HIA did not attack the New South Wales Government. The HIA has attacked our Government and has perpetuated lies, mistruths and misrepresentations as to the facts. The Master Builders Association does not support the HIA. It knows better. It says that consumers of housing in Australia should be on the lookout because the HIA wants to use this smokescreen—the allegation, for whatever reason, in our case that the price of housing might increase—to increase its own prices.

There is no campaign to unionise the private housing sector where subcontract labour is applied. This fact was admitted by no greater Opposition luminary than Senator Crane. He acknowledged that in a question to me the other day. It has had no impact at all. The fallacy that has been perpetuated that it is going to affect housing prices has been unmasked by the MBA. It says it will not. It is in a position to know. We say that it will not. We are in a position to know. The HIA is revealed as not speaking the truth even by Senator Crane, who says that in his experience it has no impact. This coming campaign should be seen for what it is—nothing more than a political stunt.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories and follows a question asked yesterday during the committee stage of the Appropriations. Firstly, why were letters from Simon Woodley, environment section of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, dated from late July to 4 August 1989 not put before the Administrative Appeals Tribunal when it heard an appeal by Island Voice against permission to construct the Magnetic Keys development on Magnetic Island? Secondly, is it not likely that had these letters been produced before the AAT, the Tribunal may have reached a very different conclusion? Finally, the recently released Whitehouse inquiry concluded, firstly, that:

QUESTION.PARA: No adequate insurance policy covering rehabilitation in the event of financial failure was taken out . . . as required by the terms of paragraph 3.1 of the Deed of the Agreement.
The reason the insurance coverage required by the Deed of Agreement was not taken out is unclear.

Can the Minister now shed more light on why, having pursued the matter of insurance most assiduously, the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority suddenly dropped all requirements for insurance, with the disastrous economic and environmental results that are all too apparent?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time has expired.
—He gave you a copy of it anyway.

—I do have some information relating to this question, but not the total information. The reason why I have some information about it, more than any other reason, is that this issue was raised by Senator Coulter late last night during Estimates proceedings.
—Does he know what Estimates are?

—He knows what Estimates are; I think he learnt from David Vigor. The first part of Senator Coulter's question relates to some letters that may or may not have been put to the AAT when it heard the appeal by Island Voice against the permission to construct the development on Magnetic Island. My understanding about this particular issue is not much more than it was late last night. Late last night I said to the Senate that we were not clear at that stage what correspondence Senator Coulter was referring to. We now have some more information from Senator Coulter by way of the question he has asked today. That information will be passed to the Department and I promise to get an answer back to Senator Coulter in respect of that. Given the fact that I cannot answer adequately and fully the first part of his question and the second part is based on the answer required to the first, I cannot go into that.

PARA.TAB: The other part of Senator Coulter's question relates to insurance. The Whitehouse report, which has been accepted by the Department—not in totality, I gather, but in major part—contains criticisms of the Authority in several areas. The report is critical of the adequacy of the insurance for the site. As a result of Mr Whitehouse's findings, the insurance matter was referred to the Attorney-General's Department. Its advice supports the Authority's position that because removal of the break walls was not regarded as a practical proposition, its insurance did not need to cover that eventuality. That goes some way towards answering the third part of Senator Coulter's question in respect of insurance coverage.

I cannot give him much more by way of an answer than that. I think I have clarified a couple of areas. In asking his question, the honourable senator has clarified for us what correspondence he is concerned about and we will get him an answer in respect of that correspondence.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister's reply is really a non sequitur. The insurance policy should clearly have been taken out before the construction began. I have in front of me a note from the Government Solicitor indicating to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority in the relevant period—namely, 8 August 1989—that he did not think that the clause in the insurance policy adequately covered the deeds. I repeat the question for the Minister: what happened between 4 August and 14 August 1989 to cause the Great Barrier Marine Park Authority suddenly to dispense with the requirement for $20m worth of insurance?

—As I said in my first answer, the question of insurance, I am informed, was covered by advice from A-Gs. The advice I have is that when the question of insurance was assessed, when it was referred to the Attorney-General's Department, its advice supported the Authority's position that, because the removal of the breakwater was not regarded as a practical proposition, the insurance did not need to cover that eventuality.

PARA.TAB: I do not know what happened between those two days that Senator Coulter mentioned. I do not know whether anything did happen, but if anything did happen that we can tell Senator Coulter about we will come back and tell him. I think Senator Coulter has raised another matter in respect of the insurance. He has raised the question of further correspondence from the Attorney-General's Department. That question should also be taken on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Consumer Affairs. Is the Minister aware of a Trade Practices Commission report which suggests that consumers could save up to $80m a year if conveyancing laws were liberalised to allow non-lawyers to perform such duties?

—I am aware of a draft report of the Trade Practices Commission which certainly challenges the conveyancing monopoly held by many lawyers' unions in various States of Australia. It indicates quite clearly that competitive market forces ought to be brought into the provision of those conveyancing services. I believe that in some States there is some competition through non-lawyer licence conveyances, and that has had an impact in reducing the price which people have to pay in order to get this sort of advice and the security that comes with the conveyancing of their house.

PARA.TAB: There are some 800,000 conveyances a year, which I found to be an astonishing figure. The Trade Practices Commission estimates that the industry must be worth about $1 billion every year to those who charge these fees. That is a tremendous amount to come out of the pockets of Australians for the security of knowing that their home transfer is indeed able to be undertaken with certainty. I believe that Professor Fels said that if there was a $100 reduction in the cost of conveyancing for each transaction, some $80m would be saved to those Australians undertaking conveyancing in those more market-oriented conditions. That is to be welcomed.

Of course, all that would be undone if there were a tax paid on the service of conveyancing. If, for example, a services tax of some 15 per cent were to be imposed on that $1 billion industry, then Australians would pay $150m in conveyancing costs by way of taxation to the Federal Treasury. That is an incredible addition. If the reforms of Professor Fels came into place, they might save $80m to $100m. If a 15 per cent GST were imposed on conveyancing fees—the $1 billion industry—then $150m extra would have to be paid by Australians for the privilege of having the certainty of knowing that the legal transaction involved in buying and selling homes was one that they could undertake with certainty and security. I believe that that sort of imposition of a goods and services tax ought to be resisted. It would undo great reforms in this area and would completely set at nought and render null and void the advantages that would come from breaking the monopoly of lawyers' unions in respect of this conveyancing.

I hope to see the TPC report implemented. I hope to see it challenging the conveyancing monopolies that exist. I would certainly hate to see it undone or for there to be any tax on the services which lawyers would charge or, even in a liberalised marketplace, any conveyancer would charge for the conveyance of a house.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to the Prime Minister's comments on radio yesterday in support of the Kelty-Halfpenny national day of action or, should I say, national day of industrial sabotage planned for 30 November. How will this nationwide stoppage help the one million Australians who are registered unemployed? In view of the $12m that the Keating Government is doling out to trade union mates this financial year, why is the Government effectively funding strikes to throw even more people out of work?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding of the one day of national strike action that is scheduled by the ACTU for 30 November is that it is a decision by that body to protest against the repressive industrial relations legislation in Victoria and the effect of that legislation in making the workers of that State worse off by removing from them things that have been established in law as their entitlement, such as holiday leave loading, shift penalty rates and other matters of that nature.
—Answer the question—how will it help the unemployed?

—I am being enjoined, `How will it help the unemployed?'. Senator Crane can invite this comparison. When we came to office in Australia in 1983, Bob Hawke, the then Prime Minister, took immediate steps to bring the nation together, to heal the division in the community and to develop a plan of growth using the mandate that he got from the people to do so. That is what Prime Minister Mulroney did in Canada and that is what President Bill Clinton is proposing to do in the United States. One can ask oneself, `Why did Jeff Kennett, with the overwhelming mandate he had, not sit down with all the social parties and do the same?'.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order concerning relevance. The Minister has now been speaking for two minutes and he has made no reference whatsoever to the content of my question. I ask you to ask him to answer the question.
—Order! The question that was asked deals with industrial action and unemployment. The Minister has been answering along those lines.

—The question is: why did Jeff Kennett in Victoria not take action, given his overwhelming mandate, to heal any divisions in Victorian society and develop a plan for recovery in that State, rather than trying to mug his own community by taking away people's rights that had been established at law and—I know I will get a vexatious point of order when I say this, but I will not be stood over by the Opposition on it—by the Victorian Liberal Government lying to the electorate of Victoria before the election and saying that no-one would be worse off.

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You have ruled in the past that the word `lying' is out of order. Coming from the mouth of a Minister who has helped to create one million unemployed and who promised prior to the last election that there would be no recession, it is a bit rich.

—On the point of order: Mr President, you have ruled on this point many times, and as recently as yesterday on a point of order taken by Senator Kemp at that time in exactly the same terms as he is now taking this point of order. Mr President, at that time and on many other occasions you have ruled that I am in order and that the point of order is out of order. The fact that Senator Kemp has risen again to use the device of taking a point of order as an opportunity to make a political statement reflects badly on him, as does the vexatious use of points of order in this chamber to prevent Ministers answering questions.

—Order! I ruled on this matter yesterday. As I heard the Minister, he was referring to the Victorian Government. The remark was therefore in order. However, if he had referred to the Premier, Mr Kennett, I would have asked him to withdraw.

—The Victorian Government lied to its electors before the election. It said that no-one would be a cent worse off. After the election, it broke its promise and made everyone worse off. I do not think that any government can embark on that course without expecting a reaction from the community. It is not something that we take any joy in, but there is social division, upheaval and industrial disputation in Australia as a result of the actions of the Kennett Government. We have a good reputation for being an industrially harmonious country. The level of—

—Mr President, I raise another point of order. Once again, it refers to relevance. The Minister has now taken 3 1/2 minutes to answer this question and he has not addressed either part of the question that I asked. I ask you to bring the Minister to order and ask him to answer the question that I asked.
—Order! I ruled on the point of order previously. The Minister is in order.

—Mr President, I recognise that the confrontationist cast of the legislation that the Victorian Government has introduced will have a damaging effect on the Australian economy. But it is its fault that it has that effect. It is for those reasons that I have been actively exploring ways of providing a lifesaver for Victorians to bring them under the control of the Federal Industrial Relations Commission, which is a real commission and not a false commission such as the one that the Kennett Government proposes to set up in Victoria. It will give them the security of real Federal awards and not false awards.
—Order! The Minister's time has expired.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question—
—Can we have a minute to answer it?

—Yes, the Government can have a minute to answer it. Obviously the Minister did not listen to what I asked in the first place, so I will ask again: how will this nationwide stoppage help the one million Australians who are registered as unemployed? Secondly, in view of the $12m the Keating Government is doling out to its trade union mates this financial year, why is it effectively funding strikes to throw even more people out of work?
—That sounded exactly like the first question, but I will allow it.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have clearly answered this question. Where a government takes provocative action, it should expect some sort of reaction. We take no joy in the fact that industrial disputation has grown in Victoria. It reflects badly on Australia's national reputation abroad. We have done everything we can to avoid it. The responsibility for it lies with the Kennett Government; it does not lie with us. I know that this is an exercise in trying to make it appear that somehow or other we are responsible for the disgraceful behaviour and lying approach of the Victorian Government. We are not responsible for that.

PARA.TAB: I understand how Australians can be traumatised by the threat to their civil liberties and the threat to their living standards by the actions being taken in Victoria. As I have said, I am taking positive steps in order that they can avoid that by transferring their State awards to Federal awards and have the protection and security of a dinky-di award rather than the false operations in Victoria.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health. Has the Minister seen recent press reports stating that the Health Department of New South Wales underspent its budget by $15m? Is the New South Wales health Minister protesting signing the Medicare agreement because, amongst other things, he claims the money to New South Wales would not be enough? Is the Commonwealth Government concerned that scarce health resources are not being spent for the people of New South Wales? Will the Commonwealth Government take the underspent money into account in future Commonwealth-State negotiations? What steps can the Commonwealth Government take to ensure that precious health dollars are spent by the States?

—I accept the premise to Senator Crowley's question that, in fact, $15m has been underspent by the New South Wales Government in relation to health services, which it could have taken up. This is a considerable amount of money which, no doubt, could have provided better medical and hospital care for New South Wales residents. It is always disappointing when a State government underspends moneys which would otherwise be available to it, particularly in relation to these programs which are so important to the medical and health care of Australians. It actually makes nonsense of its claims that it is being underfunded by the Federal Government.
—One day's expenditure.

—Senator Herron dismisses it as one day's budget. I believe that $15m would be regarded by Australians, particularly those in the waiting queues and those who are trying to get proper medical and hospital services, as an important sum of money which could have relieved their suffering or that of members of their family. To dismiss it as simply an arithmetic budgetary matter, as Senator Herron does, does no justice to the pain and suffering which people might otherwise have had alleviated if that $15m had been spent properly and adequately.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the amount of money which would flow into the public hospital system around Australia if the Medicare agreement were to be signed would greatly benefit those who depend on our great public and teaching hospitals for the provision of care. In fact, the Federal Government proposes to put some $1.6 billion over six years into the public hospital system.

That, we believe, is a proper expenditure of taxpayers' money in a way which would support the health care of Australians under the umbrella of Medicare. Medicare enjoys widespread community support because it has principles of equity and fairness which appeal to all Australians, rather than the Opposition which wants to add to the tax support for the hospital and health care system in Australia. If the Opposition came to government it would add compulsory and mandatory private health insurance to the Medicare levy system, so that all Australians and their households would have to pay an insurance premium in addition to their Medicare levy. We believe that is not the way to fund the health care system here in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. The Minister will be aware that in May last year the Prime Minister, while Treasurer, purchased for $430,000 a half share in a piggery group that the company's accounts claimed was worth $4.2m only six weeks later. As the corporations law and the Australian Securities Commission exist to protect the public from false and misleading company accounts, and in view of detailed evidence of major breaches of these laws by this piggery group presented to this chamber last week, what has the Minister done to satisfy himself that the accounts of the Euphron-Brown and Hatton Group companies are not false and misleading?

—I am very pleased to say that in the democracy that we are privileged to inhabit it is not a matter for Ministers with overall political responsibility for companies and securities in Australia to involve themselves in determining whether in a particular instance any particular accounts are false and misleading. Of course, because I certainly have not been persuaded by anything which Senator Baume has put into this chamber, I reject that that is the case in this instance. I must say that that is a matter for the proper judgment of the Australian Securities Commission, which has been established by this Parliament with its statutory independence precisely to prevent political interference which would either encourage it to undertake a particular investigation with a view to a particular result or discourage it from undertaking any particular investigation.

PARA.TAB: I am extremely confident that the Australian Securities Commission—understanding as it does that the necessity in Australia was to have a regulator and a commission set up to superintend our companies and securities area which would engender confidence amongst investors, both domestic and overseas—would take its responsibilities extremely seriously, in an impartial sense and with full integrity and certainly without any political interference whatsoever on the part of Ministers. The implication which is behind Senator Baume's particular question is one that I would certainly reject. Nevertheless, I would hope that the Australian Securities Commission would be well aware of the sorts of allegations that have been made, would have access to the Hansards and would be well equipped to make its own impartial and independent judgment in relation to these matters.

It would then, of course, be a matter, if it came to any conclusion whatsoever, for other independent authorities, such as the Director of Public Prosecutions, to make their assessment. In all instances, it would be a great folly, would undermine investor confidence and would be, I think, a show of political partisanship one way or another for Ministers to interfere in this process.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a supplementary question, Mr President. As I have referred these matters to the Securities Commission for investigation, does the Minister's answer mean that he as Minister representing the Attorney-General is now refusing to support a proper inquiry by the Securities Commission into these breaches—breaches which have never been denied by either the Prime Minister or officers of the companies which actually signed these false returns?

—That is precisely the sort of political intimidation and harassment of a statutory independent agency about which I was speaking. Of course I support any proper investigation, but Senator Baume's getting up under parliamentary privilege and speaking of breaches and false reports instead of alleged breaches and apparently false reports indicates his attempt to pre-empt and to prejudice the Australian Securities Commission in its investigation. He pretends to be putting something into its hands in order for it to carry out an investigation impartially and with integrity. In fact, he is trying to influence the outcome under privilege in Parliament.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer the Minister to his statement reported on 14 October wherein he said that the open learning initiative would:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . confer an advantage on the community by bringing higher education . . . to those with social and physical disabilities.

In light of this statement, I ask the Minister: firstly, can he confirm that the ABC is unable to continue funding subtitling services of the expanded open learning program for those students who are deaf and hearing impaired; secondly, if the ABC is unable to expand this service, how does this wash with the Government's stated intention of protecting people with disabilities from being discriminated against by providers of services, including education; and, finally, will the Minister give an undertaking that TV open learning programs will continue to be fully subtitled, in line with the Government's policy of eliminating discrimination so recently affirmed in the passage of the Disability Discrimination Act?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS; SHIPPING AND AVIATION SUPPORT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have an answer to those questions from Senator Sowada. It is not true that captioning services for broadcast TV units in the expanded open learning program will cease. Indeed, the bid led by Monash University to implement the program—that is, the bid which has received the Government's in-principle support—placed considerable stress on the importance of this issue for ensuring equitable access to the system. It will be obvious from the quote used by the honourable senator that the Commonwealth shares that concern and that commitment.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note that the captioning of the pilot's open learning television units was hailed by the Australian Caption Centre as `unquestionably one of the most important breakthroughs in television and tertiary education in Australia'. Finally, let me once again assure the Senate that the captioning of broadcast television units will continue under the much expanded open learning initiative.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General, who is in charge of the Federal Police. I refer the Minister to the Prime Minister's obvious and publicly recorded defacing of the currency at the weekend in Townsville in contravention of section 16 of the Crimes Currency Act 1981—and I hold up a photograph which records him doing it. As the penalty for a breach of section 16 is imprisonment for two years, would a conviction of this offence by the perpetrator disqualify him from sitting in the House of Representatives pursuant to section 44(ii) of the Constitution? I also ask the Minister what stage the Federal Police investigation has reached. Will the Minister assure me that, because of the individual involved, the investigation will proceed without fear or favour? Could the Minister also indicate to me, in view of the fairly obvious evidence—and again I show the Minister the photograph of the Prime Minister defacing the currency in Townsville—when prosecutions will be launched?
—Next he'll be burning the flag.

—No. There is a little bit of drama here but, once again, it is not for Senator Macdonald to assume that the offence has been committed; he should know that as a lawyer. In fact, the matter will be looked at by the Australian Federal Police in the normal way. The matter has been drawn to its attention and it will undertake whatever inquiries are appropriate and normal. I am quite sure that this task will be undertaken in the same impartial way, full of integrity, as should be the case with the Australian Securities Commission and with the Director of Public Prosecutions.

PARA.TAB: In all these instances, there will be no political interference whatsoever in the undertaking of these normal and proper inquiries. I can give Senator Macdonald that assurance, and I am quite sure that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police is concerned to ensure that normal processes are undertaken in relation to this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I wonder whether the Minister could confirm to me that warrants have been taken out to search premises in Townsville to obtain evidence about this matter. Could the Minister also indicate that, if it is proved, the Prime Minister would plead guilty in the same way as the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke, pleaded guilty when he was caught not wearing a seat belt? Did the Minister not hear the first question?
—I did not catch the second one.

—Would the Minister confirm or speak to the Prime Minister about possibly entering a plea of guilty, as did Mr Hawke when he was publicly shown on television as committing an offence against the Queensland Traffic Act?

—I would not divulge anything I know of any operational matters that are being undertaken by the Federal Police in this matter. In fact, I do not know that—if I did know I would not tell Senator Macdonald—and probably for the very good reason that the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police quite properly is not taking any step which would give any indication that I as a Minister had any influence or any particular interest in this matter. This is an inquiry for the Federal Police to conduct in its normal way. I have absolute confidence in the integrity of the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police. I hope those opposite share my confidence.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. In 1989 the Government negotiated an agreement with Kodak designed to ensure that the company continued to produce photographic film in Australia. Can the Minister outline the bounty payments to Kodak under that agreement and the returns to Australia from the agreement with the company? Is it true that Kodak has more than repaid the money it received in bounty payments through company taxation?

—In 1989 the Government agreed to pay a bounty of up to $36m over three years to Kodak in return for undertakings to keep the company's photographic film manufacturing operations in Australia. Without that agreement, Kodak would have closed down its plant at Coburg in Melbourne and imported photographic film into Australia instead of manufacturing it here. The Opposition opposed the bounty payments. It always chooses blind obedience to ideological prejudice over positive pragmatic policy making.

PARA.TAB: Yesterday Kodak won the inaugural Australian quality prize; evidence that the Kodak plant is one of Kodak Eastman's best in the world, in quality terms. Kodak has eight film processing plants around the world. Both the Australian and the Mexican plant operations now have the lowest operating costs of those eight plants. As I said earlier today, Kodak did receive $36m over three years. In the first two years of the agreement, Kodak paid $63.2m in company tax and it is expected to pay a further $33m this year, making a total of $96m in company tax. This is almost three times the level of the bounty.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The reason those opposite are getting upset is that on page 269 of Fightback Dr Hewson promised to abolish the Kodak bounty, overlooking the fact that it has already run out. The Opposition has proved quite fearless in abolishing things that no longer exist. Had those opposite been in government in 1989, there would have been no more bounty and 700 jobs at the Coburg plant would have gone overseas. Without the bounty, there would be no ongoing research and development investment in Australia, where the company has spent $6.7m. Without that bounty, Australia would have lost a significant export earner.

PARA.TAB: In 1991, Kodak's exports totalled $166m. These exports are going to the Asia-Pacific region, with South Korea becoming the largest customer of Kodak film. The estimate is that in the five years until 1994, it will export $1 billion worth of products from Australia. The Kodak story underlines the importance of a pragmatic approach to industry policy and the great dangers of the inflexible ideological approach taken by those opposite. What we have shown is that the Kodak agreement works in practice, while the Opposition complains that it does not work in theory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services. I point out to the Minister that Professor John Chalmers, the Dean of Medicine at Flinders University and former Chairman of the Medical Research Committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council, was recently reported in the Australian as claiming that, because of cuts in funding, one of the new research units dedicated to areas of government priority such as women's health, Aboriginal health and ageing is likely to miss out, with the loss of approximately 100 research jobs. Can the Minister confirm Professor Chalmers's claim? If so, which of these new units of medical research will miss out, and what will be the impact of the loss of these medical research jobs?

—This Government's support of medical research over the last several years has been absolutely incredible. I cannot understand the question. In monetary terms, the support has risen more than 100 per cent in real terms since we came to office in 1983. In 1982-83, the Government's support of health and medical research ran at some $30m. There is now a commitment of $109m in 1992-93. I am sure that Senator Newman would acknowledge, from her scrutiny of the Budget over these nine or 10 years, that very few programs would be able to match that sort of record.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators will know that the Government provided an additional $3m for each calendar year of 1993 and 1994 in the recent Budget to support the National Health and Medical Research Council's research strategy. I think that is to be divided between public health research and medical research.

It has also been important to provide some marginal extra funding for mental health research: an extra $1m for each calendar year from 1993 to 1997 is being provided. When one adds the provision that has been made for indexation—I think about $4.5m—one will see that there has been a very considerable support for medical research in Australia over the years of this Government's tenure of office. I believe it is quite remarkable and unparalleled support for that sort of research.

I understand that no decisions have been made on grants for 1993. But it is anticipated that there will be fewer grants for next year compared with this year. This is not due to any cuts in funding—there have not been any, as I have illustrated—but to continued obligations flowing from grants decisions taken in earlier years. I understand that discussions are taking place to try to alleviate some of these matters. Such questions as researchers taking up superannuation entitlements are impacting on the level of medical research funding available. These matters all have to be taken into account.

The number of project grants supported has increased from around 600 in 1983 to around 900 and the number of large scale program grants has increased from 14 to 19. The major institutes have received increases in funding and new forms of grants to support new researchers have been introduced. I could go on with what is contained in the brief.

I am sure that the commitment of this Government to supporting medical and health research is unparalleled. There has been a tremendous increase not only in monetary terms but also in the number of projects and grants that have been able to be sustained and undertaken as a result of this tremendous increase in funding. It certainly underpins the very great reputation which Australian researchers have in the medical and health research areas. It is one of the great glories of Australia that we have this sort of innovative, imaginative and compassionate scientific research that is undertaken, and it has been well supported by the Federal Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for the answer to the question that I did not ask him. He is obviously able to read a brief. He is obviously not able to address the specific question I asked him, which was that a very senior professor in Australia says we are going to lose researchers and research in areas of women's health, Aboriginal health and ageing. I asked the Minister whether he would confirm or deny it. He did neither. I asked, if there are to be cuts, which area is to be cut. Is it too much to ask the Minister for a specific answer? These are very important issues to those communities, as they should be to the Government which announced them as its areas of priority.

—As in so many of these instances, there is a very complex relationship between government funding at the very considerable levels I have indicated and decisions made by bodies as to who should get the research moneys. There is tremendous competition. There will never be enough money to satisfy all the grants and the listing of priorities for which some people make application.

PARA.TAB: This sort of funding indicates sufficiently that we are committed to supporting medical and health research. I cannot enumerate the particular areas, grants or projects that might not be able to go forward because of a supposed insufficiency at some levels. Most of the decisions made in these areas are made by peer groups and by research institutions of repute themselves and research councils so that governments do not interfere in the actual allocation of moneys to particular projects or scientific institutions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories. I refer to the Treasurer's statement last Friday which indicated job creation grants for community, heritage and sport facility programs. Will the Minister give a guarantee that the formula used in the One Nation statement for the allocation of $20m for the restoration of heritage buildings will not be used on this occasion? That formula saw Queensland, with only half the number of heritage buildings as Tasmania, receiving seven times the amount of my State. In the allocation of the funds for recreational and sporting facilities, will the Minister give consideration to the fact that Tasmania has the highest unemployment level in Australia?

—Senator Harradine refers to last week's statement. The relevant part of it is entitled `Community heritage and sports facilities'. That part of the statement refers to funding of an extra $20m for community heritage and sports facilities. The statement goes on to indicate that of that $20m, $1.25m will be spent on refurbishing the old Parliament House with a view to providing access by the public to that very significant heritage building. The remaining $18.75m is to be provided for the community, cultural, recreational and sports facilities program. Of the $20m, $1.25m goes to the old Parliament House and the other $18.75m goes towards enhancing the program and the commitment this Government has to increased participation across Australia in sport. Our funding is not only geared towards an elite level; it is also based on a recognition of the need to increase funding at a participation level. That $18.75m is to be spent essentially on capital works in local communities across the country.

PARA.TAB: Having said that, this program does build on an allocation of funding which came through at the time of the Budget, which funding had a component for heritage spending. I think that is what Senator Harradine referred to in his question. The funding provided for in the Budget ensured that community-based sponsorship of sports programs could be funded. This extra $20m is to enhance that funding allocation provided for in the Budget.

Senator Harradine mentioned Tasmania. My understanding is that of the initial funding allocation of some $12m in the sports area, Tasmania received $450,000, which was a fair share proportion of that $12m. I am assured by my colleague Senator Tate, and my colleague in the lower House Duncan Kerr, that they are already lobbying for Tasmania to get its fair share of the $18.75m. I am sure Senator Harradine's question will enhance the prospect.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

—by leave—Before Question Time started, in the debate on the Appropriation Bills Senator Cook said that Senator Tierney and I had criticised the fact that government expenditure had been too high. We did nothing of the sort. As the Minister is very fond of quoting Fightback, in my personal explanation I refer to the fact that the expenditure in Fightback is some $200m more than the Government's commitment. Nonetheless, what I referred to was the allocation of that expenditure. Administration has gone up by 20 per cent, although outlays have increased by only 17.4 per cent. The cost of the delivery of services was diminishing in real terms and the cost of administration and salaries was increasing. Neither of us—I certainly did not—criticised the Government or the Minister for the level of funding.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice of motion, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Hill moving a motion in the following terms: That the committee condemns the Government and the Australian Democrats for imposing a guillotine on debate which has resulted in it being impossible to consider seriously the appropriations for the Departments of Industrial Relations and Primary Industries and Energy.

SPEECH.PARA: The position has developed into a farce. The effect of the guillotine, the conspiracy of the Government and the Australian Democrats—and I say in passing that I hear that four of the Australian Democrats have gone home, after imposing the guillotine on us and restricting our debate—is that, despite all due diligence by this side of the chamber, it will be impossible to deal with at least two major departments of state. I make specific reference to the Department of Industrial Relations, because industrial relations and the policies of this Government have helped contribute to a situation where we have a million unemployed in this country.

PARA.TAB: We have a right on this side of the chamber to ask questions of the Government's policy in that critical area. Primary industry is but another one. Aboriginal affairs is another area that will not be pursued, not because we do not want to but because this Government is not giving us the opportunity under its guillotine and has been supported by the Australian Democrats in that decision. It seems appropriate, therefore, as only about 20 minutes would be left for this debate—which means that it is absolutely impossible even to properly commence consideration of these portfolios—for this chamber to condemn the Government and the Australian Democrats for conspiring in this way to restrict debate in order that we cannot do our job, the job that we have been sent here by the people of Australia to do, and that is to question the Government on these critically important matters.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I accept the motion moved for the suspension of Standing Orders, but not as a contingent motion because a contingent motion has to be between items of business in the Senate. This is not between items of business.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the Government does not support the suspension of Standing Orders. A lot of agony has been expressed, as though we have had a very limited amount of time to discuss these Appropriation Bills. We have had more than 200 hours of examination of these Bills—approximately 170 hours in the Estimates committees and approximately 35 hours in the Appropriation debates.

PARA.TAB: Are we here to take responsibility for the fact that some people on the other side took an inordinate amount of time to pursue trivia? Now, with the reasonable limitations that have been set, some people who think that their issues at the end of proceedings are more important are concerned. They should not take it up with us. They should take it up with their colleagues who took up all the time at the start. They know who they are as well as we do—the people who took 10 minutes to read into Hansard a document that is on the public record; the people who asked the same question five times, one after the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —We asked again because we could not get an answer.

—I was not actually referring to Senator Patterson, but she did it also. There has been more than ample opportunity. It is hard to imagine that people can say, `We have been unreasonably constrained; we have only been able to examine the Appropriation Bills for more than 200 hours'. By any stretch of the imagination, any Australian asked to consider whether that was sufficient time would have to say yes, it was. By any stretch of the imagination, those of us who spent those 200 hours debating this legislation would know that most of the time has been wasted. It is a dramatic pursuit of the trivial; it is the minor in pursuit of the trivial; it is another example of the immediate displacing the important.

PARA.TAB: If Opposition senators think there are some things of great import that should properly have been pursued in these Appropriation debates, then that is simply a matter of appalling management on their side. They are entirely incapable of disciplining some people who constantly abuse the procedures of this place and who have used those 200 hours for self-indulgence rather than for proper parliamentary purposes. Obviously, we will not vote to perpetuate that self-indulgence, nor will we vote to censure people who got sick of listening to it.

That the motion (Senator Hill's) be agreed to.
