SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that we have only just over three minutes to go, I seek leave to have a series of questions incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The questions read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: At the Estimates Committee meeting on 10 September, I asked the Minister a variety of questions on notice about Corporate Services expenditure. I would now like to seek clarification of some points:

In the last three months of the 1991/92 financial year, the Department bought 5 mobile telephones. Could the Minister please advise the Senate as to what level officers received these telephones, and what their duties are that require them to use a mobile telephone?

During 1991/92, the Department paid for airline lounge memberships for 14 of its officers. The Minister has provided the levels of these officers. But could I please request the actual positions of these officers and the reason for their frequent travel, resulting in the Department paying for their airline lounge memberships?
During 1991/92, the Department also paid for airline lounge memberships for 10 non-departmental officers.
Could the Minister please provide employment details for these people?
Are they employed full-time by the Department?
On what salary range are they employed?
How often do these non-departmental officers travel on behalf of the Department?

During the sitting of Estimates Committee F on September 10th, I asked the Minister about the independent evaluation of the Australian Defence Force function and, in particular, the person employed to perform the evaluation.
I was informed that it was performed by a temporary employee, Mr Tim Burke, who was employed because of his particular background and experience.
Could the Minister please elaborate on Mr. Burke's background and experience and how it qualified him to write this report?
(Has Mr. Burke ever been an employee of the Department of Industrial Relations?)
(Has Mr. Burke ever been a member of the Australian Defence Force?)
If the answer to this is `no':
(I just wondered because I found some of the report to be expressed in a most unmilitary style. If I could read the following sentence to the Minister:

"The effectiveness of a collegiate approach in the pay-productivity context, particularly if the focus is on workplace reform rather than broader award-type issues, is likely to depend on both the robustness of supplementation policies and on collaborative agenda setting between the parties.")

In these situations, when an independent report is being prepared, would it not be wise for the Department to consider, at the least, commissioning a co-authored report—combining someone with experience in Industrial Relations with someone who is aware of the actual effect of Department decisions about ADF pay and conditions on ADF members themselves (that is, an ADF member)?

The report talks about the objectives of this sub-program being to provide "fair and reasonable conditions of employment for Australian Public Service and Defence staff". Could the Minister please provide a definition of "fair and reasonable"?
Page 2, para 1.1.1:
Against what criteria is "fair and reasonable" judged?
Who defines "fair and reasonable"—is it the Department of Industrial Relations or the Australian Defence Force?

On page 12 of the report, it states: "This report looks at fairness, reasonableness and inconsistency in several ways but does not address the underlying issue of whether the ADF's pay structures are themselves fair and reasonable." How can the report look at fairness and reasonableness if it doesn't examine whether the structures themselves are fair and reasonable?

The Executive Summary of the report, on page 1, states that the evaluation found "that the system is, overall, working reasonably well and is delivering outcomes to ADF personnel that are fair and reasonable". How can the report make this judgement when, by its own admission, the report didn't look at whether the pay structures themselves are fair and reasonable?
The report itself, on page 7, paragraph 2.2.13, says, and I quote:
"DIR, in dealing with pay and conditions for the ADF, does not have expert knowledge of the ADF "workplace", nor is it involved in the same way as it is with the APS.
Why isn't the Department involved in the ADF to the same extent as it is with the Australian Public Service?
If the Department is lacking in expert knowledge of the ADF workplace, has the Department considered actively recruiting ADF members with experience in HQADF's Pay and Conditions Branch?

On page 8,para 2.3.3, the report states that: ". . . some observers with significant experience of ADF pay and conditions view the ADF's management/advocacy dilemma and relative lack of industrial relations expertise, combined with DlR's distance from the workplace and its reliance for information on the ADF, as a cause for serious concern, suggesting there is a continuing risk that ADF claims will not be as fully tested as they ought.
What is the Department doing to address this matter, described by the evaluator, as "a cause for serious concern"?

On page 8, para 2.3.1, the report states that: "On conditions for which the Minister for Industrial Relations and his department, rather than the DFRT, have direct responsibility, the ADF seems reasonably satisfied with the outcomes for its members but criticises DIR for slowness and unwillingness to explain decisions.
Can the Minister explain what "reasonably satisfied" means and how this fits in with the Department's objectives of providing fair and reasonable conditions of employment?
Why is the Department slow and unwilling to explain decisions?

Page 16 of the report states that the Cross Report, completed in 1988, "was critical of DIR, particularly in regard to the processing of some allowances, in the context of a wide range of criticisms or concerns about the management, training, and pay and conditions for the ADF." The report goes on to say that the Government has responded to this by focussing on the Structural Efficiency Principle process. Can the Minister please explain exactly how using the SEP process has been used to address the problems raised in the Cross Report?
(What concrete and tangible changes has the Department made since 1988 to improve the processing of allowances and reduce concerns about management, training and ADF pay conditions?)

The Defence Force Advocate, Mr Robert Buchanan QC, has recently resigned. Upon his resignation, Mr Buchanan highlighted problems caused by the Department of Industrial Relations in the determination of ADF pay and allowances. This independent report didn't refer to any difficulties the Defence Force Advocate might have had and I wonder why not?
Will the Department, or has the Department, taken note of the problems raised by Mr Buchanan and will they be acted upon?

Page 19 of the report states that: ". . . the management reporting system, revolving around fortnightly narrative reports, is not formatted so as to allow ready evaluation of progress against the key areas, nor to facilitate a management view on whether priorities are changing or should change.
What actions have taken place since the completion of this report to correct these problems?
Has the Department developed a management information system "to rectify these deficiencies" as the report recommends?

In the final part of the report, on page 20, it is stated that: "Better planning and communication between the ADF and DIR should help to further improve the working relationship between them [to be] less volatile, help them find common ground, improve the presentation of cases before the DFRT, and facilitate the timely conclusion of high priority matters.
Is there now better planning and communication? In what form?
Is the relationship between the ADF and the Department less volatile?

The report also recommends that the Department's First Assistant Secretary, Remuneration and Conditions Division meet regularly with the Assistant Chief of the Defence Force, Personnel. Are these meetings now taking place? How regularly?
Have seminars for middle ranking and lower level officers in the Department and HQADF, as recommended on page 20 of the report, started to take place?

SPEECH.PARA: 1.How many members of the Board of the Construction Industry Development Agency (CIDA) are or have been connected with construction groups in which one or more company of the group was identified as paying or receiving undisclosed unsuccessful tenderers fees by the NSW Building Royal Commission?
2.Is the Chairman of the Board such a person?

3.How many members of the Board are drawn from the ranks of major contractors, the union movement, consultants who undertake regular Commonwealth work and Commonwealth bureaucrats; what proportion of the total does this represent?
4.Is there any representative of subcontractors or suppliers of building materials and equipment on the Board?

5.How many full-time staff members of or consultants to CIDA earning more than $40,000 per annum (or at that rate) have been employed by a trade union, an ALP government department or in an ALP ministerial office: what proportion is that of the total number of employees or consultants earning more than $40,000 per annum (or at that rate)?

6.Does the Commonwealth Construction Industry In Principle Reform and Development Agreement administered by CIDA require that all Commonwealth building jobs enforce compulsory unionism and `no ticket no start'; and that all builders and subcontractors on Commonwealth jobs must abide by each and every extra-award sweetheart deal made in the past between the BLF, the BWIU and the major contractors on CBD jobs such as BUSS, CERT, site allowances and top-up insurance? Will any Commonwealth Code of Conduct so require?
7.What total financial contribution has been made by the industry to CIDA as was laid down by the Minister in his second reading speech, by whom has it been made and in precisely what form?

8.What specific restrictive labour practices have the building unions unequivocally agreed to immediately abandon without reservation through CIDA, and how has any such agreement been put into effect and given binding force?
9.How can CIDA credibly formulate plans for the rating of contractors when its Chairman and other Board members have an obvious conflict of interest?

10.Will the proposed rating system for contractors to be imposed through CIDA in relation to Commonwealth building jobs involve compliance by contractors with compulsory unionism and all CBD extra-award deals made in the past with the building unions? Will approval by and good relationships with the building unions be a criterion for approval of a contractor?
11.What effect upon a CIDA rating will disclosure of unacceptable or illegal behaviour by a contractor have?

12.Is the objective of the proposed CIDA rating system the concentration of Commonwealth building work in a few hand-picked union-approved contractors who have, with the unions, been responsible for the disgraceful state of the industry leading to the waste of billions of dollars over the last decade?

13.Will CIDA and the Government insist upon or facilitate the spread of Sydney, Melbourne, Canberra and Perth CBD building union demands to residential and civil construction, and to the suburbs, the country and other States and Territories?

14.Was the Government's real objective in establishing CIDA to entrench the building union/major contractor sweetheart status quo agenda against genuine reform of the industry as proposed by the NSW government and by a Hewson Government?

PARA.EMPHASIS: FURTHER QUESTIONS ARISING FROM ESTIMATES HEARING ON 21/10/92

SPEECH.PARA: 1.Could the Minister confirm that the original draft of the June 3 letter—as disclosed by Mr Thompson in the recent Estimates hearing—talked about Minister to Minister discussions of pig semen? PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 16 September 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to Bender's Quarry in southern Tasmania, why has the Government failed to honour its undertaking, in a letter dated 18 August 1988 to Bender's Quarry owner and manager, Mr Bender, signed on behalf of the Tasmanian Government and the Commonwealth on 24 November 1988, that the operation would not be closed.

(2) Why was there no proper notification of the broken promise given to the Quarry manager and workers whose families will suffer, the first notification being via a national media release by the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories.

(3) Why has this Government claimed that compensation has been offered for the loss of this $4 million industry and rejected by the State Government when, in fact, the $475,000 which was offered is a pittance and $275,000 of that was to be arbitrarily required to be paid by the State Government out of funds already allocated to other projects.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Government's position in relation to the continued operation of Bender's Quarry, as stated in Senator Cook's letter to Mr Bender of 18 August, 1988, was based upon the extent of Quarry operations at that time and available knowledge of the Exit Cave karst system.

(2) Mr Bender was advised of the Government's decision to restrict quarry operations by means of Regulations under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 in a letter from Mrs Kelly which was hand delivered to him at his home on 20 August 1992. I also issued a media release on 20 August 1992.

(3) Legal advice available to me concludes there is no legal obligation for the Commonwealth to pay compensation to Benders Pty Ltd under Clause 16 of the Cook/Groom Agreement. However the Commonwealth has offered to negotiate with Benders Pty Ltd an ex-gratia payment for closure of the Quarry within the limits of the Commonwealth relocation and redundancy offer to Tasmania of $476,000.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Tertiary Institutions: Funding by Defence Equipment Manufacturers

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the extent of funding to universities and other tertiary institutions from companies engaged in defence equipment manufacturing.
(2) (a) What is the nature of the funding; (b) does it include provision for scholarships; and (c) what provision is made for equipment and travel cost assistance in the funding.

(3) (a) Which institutions have received such funding in the financial years 1990-91, 1991-92 and/or anticipate such funding for the years 1992-93; and (b) what is the nature and extent of research contracts which are currently in place.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Commonwealth does not collect detailed information on funding for tertiary education institutions by source. Universities, in particular, receive considerable amounts of funding from a wide variety of sources. The Commonwealth encourages collaboration with industry but management of this collaboration is the responsibility of universities as autonomous, self-governing institutions. Other tertiary institutions such as colleges of technical and further education are the responsibility of State governments. The detailed information you are seeking would only be available directly from tertiary education institutions.
(2) Not available.
(3) Not available.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 October 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the overall amount of research grants from the Defence Budget and the Defence Science and Technology Organisation (DSTO) to universities and other tertiary institutions for the financial years 1990-91, 1991-92 and 1992-93.
(2) What are the names of those institutions which have, or will be, receiving grants from the Defence Budget and the DSTO in those years.
(3) What is the amount of each grant and the nature of the research required.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The bulk of the money paid to tertiary institutions by the Department is from the DSTO appropriation. However, DSTO does not make `grants' as such to tertiary institutions. All payments are either in respect of Technical Support Service (TSS) contracts or Research Agreements. TSS contracts are negotiated when it is expected that the research will result in the delivery of a tangible item, such as a piece of software or equipment, and payment is only made for work done. Research Agreements are negotiated with tertiary institutions when the objective of the research is to improve the understanding of certain phenomena of interest to Defence. The outcome of such research is normally in the form of a scientific report of the research results. Payment for Research Agreements is annually in advance.
(2)-(3) The details sought by the honourable senator are provided in the following tables (1-8 inclusive).
The honourable senator should note that the information given for the 1992-93 financial year cannot be complete at this time, as contracts are still being considered.
